601 of 992 DOCUMENTS


N.Y. Ass'n of Convenience Stores v. Urbach


Index # 4895-95, RJI # 01-95-ST6026


SUPREME COURT OF NEW YORK, ALBANY COUNTY


181 Misc. 2d 589; 694 N.Y.S.2d 885; 1999 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 316



July 9, 1999, Decided



DISPOSITION:  [***1] Judgment dismissing the Petition is granted to the Respondents.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioners sought to compel respondents to assess and collect state excise and sales taxes for sales to non-Indians by Indian retailers on reservations within the state, contending that respondents' failure to do so enabled the Indians to sell products at reduced rates, thereby damaging petitioners.


OVERVIEW: Petitioners brought suit in the nature of mandamus to compel respondents to assess and collect state excise and sales taxes for the sale of tobacco products and motor fuel to non-Indians by Indian retailers on Indian reservations within the state. In dismissing the petition, the trial court concluded that if it were to grant the requested relief, it would be wrongfully substituting its judgment for that of the respondents, who were the entities charged with the obligation of administering the state's tax laws. Further, the regulations petitioner sought to enforce, which were the only mechanism for the collection of the subject taxes, had been repealed by respondent department of taxation after determining that there was no practical manner for enforcement. Mandamus was an extraordinary remedy that was rarely granted and was not proper when the granting of relief would cause public disorder.


OUTCOME: The petition was dismissed, as it improperly requested the court to substitute its judgment for that of the entities charged with enforcing and administering the state's tax law and as the regulations petitioners sought to enforce had been repealed.


HEADNOTES

Constitutional Law - Equal Protection of Laws - Enforcement of Taxing Statutes and Regulations against On-Reservation Retailers

A rational basis supports determinations by the State respondents to repeal tax collection regulations and to cease efforts to enforce the collection of tobacco product and motor fuel excise and sales taxes as applied to sales made to non-Indian consumers on Indian reservations; accordingly, petitioner convenience stores which compete with on-reservation Indian retailers are not entitled to a writ of mandamus compelling respondents to determine, assess, collect and enforce the excise and sales taxes. A grant of mandamus would wrongfully substitute the court's judgment for that of the respondents who are charged with the obligation of administering the tax laws of this State. Even if petitioners were to possess a right to mandamus, such relief should not be granted if, as here, the granting of the relief would cause public disorder. The regulations were repealed only after respondents determined that there was no practical manner for enforcement. The majority of Indian retailers refused to comply with the regulations and, given tribal sovereignty, respondents' enforcement powers were limited. Also, enforcement attempts resulted in the blockading of public highways, threats of violence, actual violence and public unrest. Negotiations were intense, prolonged and failed to produce permanent agreements. Moreover, the State actions were taken on the basis that the most reasonable resolution is legislative action.

 

602 of 992 DOCUMENTS


People v. Santiago


Indict. # 210/99


COUNTY COURT OF NEW YORK, MONROE COUNTY


1999 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 671; 1999 NY Slip Op 40004U



July 8, 1999 Decided


NOTICE:  [*1] THIS OPINION IS UNCORRECTED AND WILL NOT BE PUBLISHED IN THE OFFICIAL REPORTS.

 

603 of 992 DOCUMENTS


People v. Wilson


Indictment No. 97-126, No. 98-26


COUNTY COURT OF NEW YORK, CATTARAUGUS COUNTY


181 Misc. 2d 356; 695 N.Y.S.2d 672; 1999 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 304



July 2, 1999, Decided


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: The prosecution sought to enhance defendant's sentence after defendant was convicted of various drug charges, by arguing that defendant was a predicate offender due to defendant's convictions for sexual imposition and failure to appear after release in North Dakota.


OVERVIEW: The court withheld final judgment on the issue of whether defendant was a predicate offender. Defendant was convicted of various drug charges and the prosecution sought to have defendant's sentence enhanced as a predicate offender due to defendant's North Dakota convictions for sexual imposition and failure to appear after release. Defendant first argued that the conviction for failure to appear after release was not a felony in New York. The court agreed, stating that the New York statute provided a 30-day grace period after failing to appear, so defendant's action would not be a felony in New York and could not be used to enhance defendant's sentence. Defendant also argued that the conviction for sexual imposition was also not a felony in New York. The court, however, disagreed and found that N.D. Cent. Code § 12.1-20-04 and the New York penal statutes were sufficiently similar to find that the act would have been a felony in New York. Nevertheless, the court ordered a hearing on the sexual imposition charge because defendant argued that the conviction was the result of ineffective assistance of counsel, and the court withheld final judgment pending the outcome of the hearing.


OUTCOME: The court held that defendant's convictions for sexual imposition would have been a felony in New York, but the conviction for failure to appear after release would not have been a felony. The court, however, withheld final judgment on the issue of whether defendant was a predicate offender pending the outcome of a hearing in which defendant claimed his conviction for sexual imposition was the result of ineffective assistance of counsel.


HEADNOTES

Crimes - Sentence - Second Felony Offender - North Dakota Bail Jumping Statute 

1. Defendant's bail jumping conviction in North Dakota cannot serve as a predicate for enhanced sentencing purposes. A bail jumping conviction in North Dakota would not necessarily constitute a felony in New York, since the North Dakota crime is apparently committed as soon as the defendant fails to appear. New York, however, requires a failure to appear within 30 days of the scheduled appearance, which essentially gives a nonappearing defendant a 30-day grace period before his failure to appear becomes a crime (see, Penal Law § 215.56). Because a comparison of the elements of both statutes establishes that they are not equivalent, the North Dakota bail jumping conviction may not serve as a basis for enhanced sentencing.

Crimes - Sentence - Second Felony Offender - North Dakota Sexual Offense Statute - Threats

2. For purposes of determining the predicate felon status of defendant, who has been convicted of various drug-related felonies, a threat that satisfies the North Dakota statute defining "sexual imposition," under which defendant was previously convicted, would by definition constitute a sufficient threat under Penal Law § 130.00 (8) (b) where the North Dakota crime requires a threat "that would render a person of reasonable firmness incapable of resisting". The New York statute does not require a threat to be that severe; the threat of simply a physical injury (i.e., impairment of physical condition or substantial pain) will suffice even if the victim is not a "person of reasonable firmness," as required by North Dakota. Therefore, if there is a difference between the two States in the "threat" component of their sexual abuse statutes (see, Penal Law § 130.65 [1]), the threshold for establishing the qualifying threat is higher in North Dakota than in New York.

Crimes - Sentence - Second Felony Offender - North Dakota Sexual Offense Statute - Gratification of Violent Desires

3. For purposes of determining the predicate felon status of defendant, who has been convicted of various drug-related felonies, the provision in North Dakota's "sexual imposition" statute, under which defendant was previously convicted, that the offensive touching be for the purpose of satisfying the defendant's "sexual or aggressive desires" does not sufficiently differentiate the North Dakota crime from New York's sexual abuse statute (see, Penal Law § 130.65 [1]), which requires only that the offensive act be done in order to satisfy either the criminal's or the victim's sexual desires. Although there is a literal difference between the two statutes, construing that difference in order to remove the North Dakota conviction as a predicate felony would lead to an absurd result: a defendant could admit the fact of the prior conviction but claim that he molested the victim to satisfy his violent tendencies; he could then argue that the crime cannot be used for enhanced sentencing purposes because it was not committed to gratify either his or the victim's sexual desire. While the modern consensus is that sex crimes are more often crimes of violence than crimes of desire, such a minor difference in the statutes does not require rejection of the People's request for second felony offender sentencing. Moreover, statutes need not be precisely identical for enhanced sentencing purposes.

 

604 of 992 DOCUMENTS


People ex rel. Spitzer v. 14 West Garment Factory Corp.


Index No. 400717/99


SUPREME COURT OF NEW YORK, NEW YORK COUNTY


182 Misc. 2d 146; 697 N.Y.S.2d 458; 1999 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 322



June 28, 1999, Decided


SUBSEQUENT HISTORY:  [***1] As Corrected November 2, 1999.



DISPOSITION: Motion for preliminary injunction granted; cross motion to dismiss denied.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner, state attorney general, filed a motion for a preliminary injunction to prevent respondent from shipping, delivering, or selling goods manufactured in violation of the minimum wage and wage payment laws. Respondent filed a cross motion to dismiss, arguing that the injunction constituted an unconstitutional taking of respondent's property and that respondent did not have knowledge of the violations of the labor statutes.


OVERVIEW: The court granted petitioner's motion for a preliminary injunction and denied respondent's cross motion to dismiss. Petitioner, the state attorney general, moved for the injunction after petitioner discovered that clothes manufactured by another company were produced in violation of the state minimum wage and wage payment laws. Respondent argued that they should not be enjoined from shipping, delivering, or selling the clothing because they did not know that the manufacturer did not comply with the minimum wage and wage payment laws. The court, however, held that respondent's knowledge was not required for finding violations of N.Y. Lab. Law § 345 (10)(c) because the only requirement was that the goods were manufactured illegally. Furthermore, the court held that respondent had notice of the potential violation and failed to remedy the situation. Finally, the court held that that this was not an unconstitutional taking requiring dismissal because the needs of the government outweighed any private interest. Therefore, the court granted the preliminary injunction and denied respondent's motion to dismiss.


OUTCOME: The court granted petitioner's motion for a preliminary injunction because respondent was liable under the state's minimum wage and wage payment statutes and petitioner met the appropriate standard for a preliminary injunction. The court also denied defendant's cross motion to dismiss because the injunction was not an unconstitutional taking of respondent's property.


HEADNOTES

Labor - Hours and Wages - "Hot Goods" - Failure to Pay Workers - Injunction against Sale of Apparel

1. Pursuant to Labor Law § 345, the "hot goods" law, petitioner Attorney General is granted a preliminary injunction prohibiting respondent from shipping, delivering, or selling certain items of apparel where an investigation has revealed that the workers who manufactured the apparel have not been paid in violation of Labor Law articles 6 and 19. Although the statute contains an exemption for retailers who acquire such apparel without notice that the apparel was unlawful, that exemption is not applicable to contractors and manufacturers, since the law contains no requirement that a manufacturer know that apparel was illegally manufactured at the time the garments were produced. Rather, respondent is strictly liable under the statute because the goods were produced illegally, and the exception expressly states that it applies to retailers; no mention is made of an exemption for contractors or manufacturers. The "hot goods" law is a remedial statute enacted to combat the underpayment and nonpayment of poor laborers, and exemptions for a retailer acting in good faith and in compliance with the law makes sense. However, manufacturers and contractors are more closely involved in the compensation of these laborers and, therefore, they are in a better position to ensure compliance with the Labor Law.

Labor - Hours and Wages - "Hot Goods" - Failure to Pay Workers - Injunction against Sale of Apparel

2. Pursuant to Labor Law § 345, the "hot goods" law, petitioner Attorney General is granted a preliminary injunction prohibiting respondent from shipping, delivering, or selling certain items of apparel where an investigation has revealed that the workers who manufactured the apparel have not been paid in violation of Labor Law articles 6 and 19, since petitioner has demonstrated that more than likely it will prevail on the merits, and the remedial nature of the "hot goods" law and the deterrent effect that enforcing it serves weigh heavily in favor of granting the relief sought. The practical effect of the injunction is to protect laborers from further mistreatment and to ensure their compensation for the goods in question by demanding payment before the injunction could be lifted. One way to insure that the workers will be compensated is to prevent manufacturers from profiting from illegal labor, and it is in the power of the respondents, at any time, to lift this injunction.

Labor - Hours and Wages - "Hot Goods" - Failure to Pay Workers - Injunction against Sale of Apparel - Constitutional Taking

3. Pursuant to Labor Law § 345, the "hot goods" law, petitioner Attorney General is granted a preliminary injunction prohibiting respondent from shipping, delivering, or selling certain items of apparel where an investigation has revealed that the workers who manufactured the apparel have not been paid in violation of Labor Law articles 6 and 19. Enforcement of the "hot goods" law will not constitute an unconstitutional taking of property without just compensation. The economic impact of the regulation is an outgrowth, not of the diminished value of the apparel, but of the obligation to cure the nonpayment in order to unfreeze these goods for sale; once the situation is rectified, the goods may be sold. Moreover, any "reasonably backed investment expectation" could not and should not expect to profit from the fruits of illegal labor. Further, the government action is not to appropriate the goods for public use but rather to enforce a statutory scheme that ensures that cheaper, illegal apparel does not compete with lawfully made goods.

 

605 of 992 DOCUMENTS


Igoe v. Pataki


Index No. 111230/99, Index No. 111272/99, Index No. 111322/99, Index No. 111325/99, Index No. 402228/99


SUPREME COURT OF NEW YORK, NEW YORK COUNTY


182 Misc. 2d 298; 696 N.Y.S.2d 355; 1999 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 260



June 28, 1999, Decided


SUBSEQUENT HISTORY:  [***1] As Amended October 5, 1999. As Corrected November 22, 1999. As Corrected January 24, 2000.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff commuters sought to enjoin as unconstitutional the collection of the tax imposed on non-residents of the State of New York who commute into New York city while in-state residents that commute were excluded from the commuter tax.


OVERVIEW: Defendant state amended an existing commuter tax law that repealed the part of the tax that was imposed on the earnings of defendant state's residents and only imposed the tax on non-city residents who were also non-state residents. The court held that the tax violated the Privileges and Immunities Clause and was unconstitutional because defendant state failed to show a substantial reason for the difference in treatment between resident and non-resident commuters and failed to establish that the discrimination practiced against nonresident commuters bore a substantial relationship to its objective. The court also held that the tax violated the Commerce Clause and clearly favored intrastate economic activity over equivalent interstate activity by taxing the interstate labor market. Further, the tax violated Equal Protection and Due Process because although defendant state wished to ease the tax burdens for its residents to increase their spending power, residency alone was a wholly arbitrary and irrational basis on which to create distinctions among taxpayers.


OUTCOME: The court granted plaintiffs' motions for summary judgment and declared the commuter tax unconstitutional in violation of the Privileges and Immunities Clause, the Commerce Clause, and the Equal Protection Clause of the United States Constitution, along with the Equal Protection Clause of the New York State Constitution.


HEADNOTES

Taxation - Personal Income Tax - Constitutionality of Statute Imposing Commuter Tax on Nonresidents Commuting to New York City - Privileges and Immunities Clause

1. The recent amendment to the Commuter Tax (Tax Law § 1305 [b]; Model Local Law § 1 [h] [General City Law § 25-m], as amended by L 1999, ch 5), which requires only nonresidents of New York State commuting to New York City, and not residents who commute, to pay the Commuter Tax into New York City's general fund, violates the Privileges and Immunities Clause of the United States Constitution (US Const, art IV, § 2). The State has failed to show a substantial reason for the difference in treatment and consequently has failed to establish that the discrimination practiced against nonresident commuters bears a substantial relationship to its objectives. The Privileges and Immunities Clause specifically prohibits States from imposing unduly burdensome taxation on nonresidents. New York State's desire to balance the tax burden as to its own residents because resident commuters allegedly bear a heavier tax burden than nonresident commuters in terms of fiscal support provided to New York City is not a substantial reason for the implementation of the amendment. The mere fact that the Legislature has already taxed its citizens to a certain degree does not lead to the conclusion that it may subsequently tax nonresidents in an attempt to equalize the burden. Moreover, while it may be a legitimate government objective to seek to ease the tax burden of commuters, residence is not a legitimate limiting factor.

Taxation - Personal Income Tax - Constitutionality of Statute Imposing Commuter Tax on Nonresidents Commuting to New York City - Commerce Clause

2. The recent amendment to the Commuter Tax (Tax Law § 1305 [b]; Model Local Law § 1 [h] [General City Law § 25-m], as amended by L 1999, ch 5), which requires only nonresidents of New York State commuting to New York City, and not residents who commute, to pay the Commuter Tax into New York City's general fund, violates the Commerce Clause of the United States Constitution (US Const, art I, § 8). States are prohibited under the Commerce Clause from interfering with interstate trade, and any State statute imposing a tax that is found on its face to discriminate against out-of-State commerce will be struck down unless the State demonstrates that the statute advances a legitimate local purpose that cannot be adequately served by reasonable nondiscriminatory alternatives. New York State desires to balance the tax burden as to its own residents because resident commuters allegedly bear a heavier tax burden than nonresident commuters in terms of fiscal support provided to New York City. However, it has failed to identify the specific intrastate tax for which it is attempting to compensate, and to demonstrate that the tax being compensated for is roughly approximate to the Commuter Tax. Moreover, the alleged compensatory taxes that the State relies upon are not imposed on the same activities that give rise to the Commuter Tax and have not been proven to support the services provided to interstate commuters by New York City.

Taxation - Personal Income Tax - Constitutionality of Statute Imposing Commuter Tax on Nonresidents Commuting to New York City - Equal Protection of Laws - Due Process of Law

3. The recent amendment to the Commuter Tax (Tax Law § 1305 [b]; Model Local Law § 1 [h] [General City Law § 25-m], as amended by L 1999, ch 5), which requires only nonresidents of New York State commuting to New York City, and not residents who commute, to pay the Commuter Tax into New York City's general fund, violates the Equal Protection and Due Process Clauses of the New York and United States Constitutions (US Const 5th, 14th Amends; NY Const, art I, §§ 6, 11). The Equal Protection and Due Process Clauses prohibit States from subjecting individuals to discrimination based on invidious classifications, and while States have some latitude in the area of taxation, classifications of taxpayers based on factors other than race, national origin, or gender must be rationally related to a legitimate government interest. While New York State wishes to ease the tax burdens for its residents to increase their spending power, residency alone is a wholly arbitrary and irrational basis on which to create distinctions among taxpayers.

 

606 of 992 DOCUMENTS


Arvelo by Arvelo v. City of New York


Index No.: 10151/98


CIVIL COURT OF THE CITY OF NEW YORK, RICHMOND COUNTY


182 Misc. 2d 101; 695 N.Y.S.2d 653; 1999 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 377



June 10, 1999, Decided


SUBSEQUENT HISTORY:  [***1] As Corrected December 13, 1999.



DISPOSITION: Granted.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiffs moved by oral motion during the course of a personal injury action for permission to file a late Notice of Claim against defendant board of education. Defendants opposed the motion on the grounds that the civil court lacked jurisdiction.


OVERVIEW: Plaintiffs, an infant and her father, commenced an action against defendants, the city and the board of education, for personal injuries sustained during gym class at school. Plaintiffs alleged that defendants were negligent in the supervision, instruction and safety of the child. It was determined at trial that plaintiffs had failed to file a Notice of Claim against defendant board of education. They moved by oral motion for permission to file a late Notice of Claim. Defendants opposed the motion on the grounds that the civil court lacked jurisdiction to entertain the motion pursuant to N.Y. Gen. Mun. Law §50-e(7). After review, the court concluded that it had jurisdiction to consider plaintiffs' motion because §50-e(7) was unconstitutional. Not allowing the civil court to have jurisdiction would have deprived plaintiffs of the equal protection of the laws. The court granted plaintiffs' motion for a late filing because defendant board of education was not prejudiced by plaintiffs' inadvertence to file a separate Notice of Claim against it. It was aware of the details and facts of the incident through its counsel which also represented defendant City.


OUTCOME: Plaintiffs motion for a late filing was granted because the additional ministerial task of further serving defendant board of education was a superfluous act in light of the board's knowledge of the action as a result of the Notice of Claim filed against defendant City.


HEADNOTES

Municipal Corporations - Notice of Claim - Late Notice - Jurisdiction of Civil Court to Entertain Motion to Serve Late Notice

1. The Civil Court of the City of New York has jurisdiction to entertain plaintiff's motion for leave to file a late notice of claim, notwithstanding the explicit requirement in General Municipal Law § 50-e (7) that such motion "shall be made to the supreme court or to the county court." The exclusion of the Civil Court from the statute renders it unconstitutional because the Legislature, in adopting General Municipal Law § 50-e (7), created a restriction on a class of persons, i.e., residents of the City of New York, which results in a denial of equal protection of the laws for those persons without any rational basis. By providing that a motion for late filing of a notice of claim be made in either Supreme or County Court, the Legislature presumably intended that a lower court of limited jurisdiction would also have jurisdiction to determine the issue, but inadvertently omitted the reference to the Civil Court.

Municipal Corporations - Notice of Claim - Late Notice - Defendant's Knowledge of Claim

2. In an action for damages brought against the City of New York (City) and the New York City Board of Education (Board) in which plaintiff filed a notice of claim against the City but inadvertently failed to file a separate notice of claim against the Board, plaintiff's motion pursuant to General Municipal Law § 50-e (5) for leave to file a late notice of claim against the Board is granted. The City and the Board interposed a single answer through the Corporation Counsel's office, which represents them both. The Board, through its counsel, had knowledge of the details and the facts of the incident early in the litigation, mounted an informed and well-prepared defense, and has not shown that it would have defended the action any differently had plaintiff completed the ministerial task of filing a notice of claim at the Board's offices. There is no prejudice to the Board as a result of any late filing, and to deny plaintiff's motion would result in severe prejudice to the plaintiff, effectively dismissing her claim.

 

607 of 992 DOCUMENTS


Cohen v. State


INDEX # 13394/99


SUPREME COURT OF NEW YORK, KINGS COUNTY


180 Misc. 2d 643; 694 N.Y.S.2d 840; 1999 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 268



May 21, 1999, Decided


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioners, members of the New York State Legislature, sought a declaration that 1998 N.Y. Laws 635 was unconstitutional and violated the separation of powers doctrine and N.Y. Const. art. III, § 6.


OVERVIEW: The New York State Legislature passed legislation that provided that if the State budget was not enacted and approved by the State Comptroller by the start of the fiscal year, the salaries of the legislators would be withheld until a budget was enacted. The governor signed the bill into law as 1998 N.Y. Laws 635. Petitioners, members of the legislature, maintained that 1998 N.Y. Laws 635 violated N.Y. Const. art. III, § 6 and the separation of powers doctrine. The court agreed and struck down the challenged statute after determining that the natural and intended consequence of the law was to coerce passage of a timely budget by the infliction of personal financial hardship upon some legislators. The court found that the law impermissibly tipped the balance of powers by threatening to impose on the Legislature a budget that is not the product of thoughtful deliberation and debate and that to place any legislator undue economic pressure in exercising his or her judgment, while expecting that person to act in accordance with his or her oath of office, was unconstitutional.


OUTCOME: The challenged statute was unconstitutional because it violated the separation of powers doctrine and the New York State Constitution.


HEADNOTES

Constitutional Law - Validity of Statute - Statute Withholding Legislators' Salaries until State Budget is Passed

Chapter 635 of the Laws of 1998, which amends Legislative Law §§ 5 and 5-a so as to provide that if legislative passage of the State budget does not occur prior to the first day of any fiscal year, legislators' salaries will be withheld until legislative passage has occurred, is unconstitutional in that it violates the separation of powers doctrine and article III, § 6 of the New York Constitution, which sets forth the legislators' right to compensation. The natural and intended consequence of chapter 635 is to coerce passage of a timely budget by the infliction of personal financial hardship upon some legislators. This manifestly inhibits legislators from performing their function as an independent branch of government and impermissibly tips the fragile balance of powers that is the keystone of the State system of government.

 

608 of 992 DOCUMENTS


Grinberg v. Safir


Index No. 104799/99


SUPREME COURT OF NEW YORK, NEW YORK COUNTY


181 Misc. 2d 444; 694 N.Y.S.2d 316; 1999 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 259



May 18, 1999, Decided


SUBSEQUENT HISTORY:  [***1] As Corrected July 7, 1999.



DISPOSITION: The petition is denied and the proceeding dismissed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner challenged the constitutionality of New York City's driving while intoxicated vehicle forfeiture policy, New York City, N.Y., Admin. Code § 14-140.


OVERVIEW: Petitioner was arrested for driving while intoxicated (DWI). As a result, officers took petitioner's car for forfeiture under New York City, N.Y., Admin. Code § 14-140. Petitioner sought a final judgment invalidating the city's policy and the taking and retention of his car. A police department property clerk commenced a separate action against petitioner for a judgment declaring the vehicle forfeited as the instrumentality of the crime of DWI. The criminal action was pending. The court upheld the new automobile forfeiture policy and dismissed the petition. The court found that no hearing pre- or post-seizure were required under state or federal due process principles as long as the criminal case was pending. Moreover, seizure of the car did not violate the federal or state constitutional ban on excessive fines. The court held that the automobile of a drunk driver was the quintessential instrumentality of a crime. Because an automobile was an integral part of DWI, the court observed retention prevented the vehicle from being used for repeated illegal activity.


OUTCOME: The court denied a petition seeking to declare New York City's driving while intoxicated forfeiture policy unconstitutional and dismissed the proceeding. No hearing pre-or post-seizure was required under state or federal due process principles as long as a criminal case was pending. Similarly, the car seizures did not run afoul of the federal constitutional ban on excessive fines.


HEADNOTES

Forfeitures and Penalties - Forfeiture of Proceeds or Instrumentality of Crime - Forfeiture of Vehicle Used to Facilitate Driving while Intoxicated - Statutory Authority

1. The application of the Property Clerk Forfeiture Law (Administrative Code of City of NY § 14-140) to vehicles operated by individuals arrested for driving while intoxicated is statutorily authorized. Administrative Code § 14-140, adopted under the police power provision of the Municipal Home Rule Law, defines the status of property by its nexus to crime and declares the City's right to hold it; it directs that property "suspected of having been used as a means of committing crime or employed in aid or furtherance of crime" be given into the custody of the Police Department Property Clerk (Administrative Code § 14-140 [b]). The Property Clerk may decline to return the property if there is "reasonable cause to believe that [it] ... was the proceeds or instrumentality of a crime" and must then initiate a civil forfeiture proceeding (38 RCNY 12-36, now 38-A RCNY 12-36). A drunk driver's vehicle is the quintessential instrumentality of a crime--the sine qua non without which the crime could not have been committed--and it is irrelevant that the vehicle is not needed as evidence or that the District Attorney might not object to petitioner's request for its return.

Forfeitures and Penalties - Forfeiture of Proceeds or Instrumentality of Crime - Forfeiture of Vehicle Used to Facilitate Driving while Intoxicated - Forfeiture Provisions of New York City Administrative Code Not Preempted by State Law

2. State law does not preempt the application of the Property Clerk Forfeiture Law (Administrative Code of City of NY § 14-140) to vehicles operated by individuals arrested for driving while intoxicated. The State asset forfeiture law ( CPLR art 13-A) does not apply to petitioner, who is not charged with a felony. CPLR 1352 explicitly preserves the availability of other forfeiture rights and remedies provided by law outside of CPLR article 13-A, and nothing in article 13-A's legislative history indicates that the State intended to occupy the field of forfeiture.

Forfeitures and Penalties - Forfeiture of Proceeds or Instrumentality of Crime - Forfeiture of Vehicle Used to Facilitate Driving while Intoxicated - Forfeiture Does Not Constitute Additional Criminal Sentence or Punishment

3. A forfeiture action commenced against petitioner after he was arrested for driving while intoxicated and his vehicle seized is not an additional criminal punishment or sentence imposed in violation of the separation of powers. Suits to forfeit contraband or instrumentalities are considered civil, remedial and nonpunitive. It is the nature and purpose of the remedy sought that is significant, not the form of the action or the method of obtaining jurisdiction, and since the forfeiture action seeks only a declaration of rights to the vehicle, it is irrelevant that the action was brought against petitioner instead of his car.

Forfeitures and Penalties - Forfeiture of Proceeds or Instrumentality of Crime - Forfeiture of Vehicle Used to Facilitate Driving while Intoxicated - Reasonableness of Warrantless Seizure of Vehicle

4. The warrantless seizure and retention of petitioner's vehicle following his arrest for driving while intoxicated does not constitute an unreasonable seizure in violation of the Federal or State Constitution (US Const 4th Amend; NY Const, art I, § 12). The seizure was reasonable under the plain view exception, which permits warrantless seizure of instrumentalities in plain view; as incident to lawful arrest, since petitioner was not legally able to resume control of the vehicle and the police had the right of possession given the vehicle's instrumentality status; and under the automobile exception, which permits police with probable cause to search a vehicle for an instrumentality of a crime, and logically to seize a car that is itself an instrumentality.

Forfeitures and Penalties - Forfeiture of Proceeds or Instrumentality of Crime - Forfeiture of Vehicle Used to Facilitate Driving while Intoxicated - Constitutionality of Forfeiture Procedure - Standing

5. Petitioner, whose vehicle was seized and retained under the Property Clerk Forfeiture Law (Administrative Code of City of NY § 14-140) after his arrest for driving while intoxicated, is not estopped from challenging the constitutionality of the City's forfeiture procedures (see, 38 RCNY ch 12, subch B, now 38-A RCNY ch 12, subch B), which were codified pursuant to Federal consent decrees following a class action challenging the prior procedure, as plaintiff was not a member of that class and the issues litigated and determined in that action are not the same as those raised by petitioner.

Forfeitures and Penalties - Forfeiture of Proceeds or Instrumentality of Crime - Forfeiture of Vehicle Used to Facilitate Driving while Intoxicated - Constitutionality of Forfeiture Procedure

6. The application of the Property Clerk Forfeiture Law (Administrative Code of City of NY § 14-140) to vehicles operated by individuals arrested for driving while intoxicated, which authorizes the police to take and retain vehicles without a preseizure hearing, does not violate the Due Process Clauses of the Federal or State Constitution (US Const 14th Amend; NY Const, art I, § 6). Although the Due Process Clause guarantees that, absent extraordinary circumstances, individuals must receive notice and an opportunity to be heard before the government deprives them of property, civil forfeiture actions inherently may present such extraordinary circumstances. A prehearing seizure of an instrumentality for forfeiture comports with due process when it is necessary to secure an important governmental or general public interest; there is a special need for very prompt action; and the person initiating the seizure is a governmental official responsible for determining, under the standards of a narrowly drawn statute, that it is necessary and justified. The seizure of a drunk driver's vehicle upon arrest serves the important governmental interest of permitting the Property Clerk to assert jurisdiction in order to conduct a forfeiture proceeding, and it is necessary because the arrestee is legally and physically incapable of driving. The arresting officers are government employees who evaluate an offense committed in their presence and must have probable cause before making the arrest. Moreover, the City's interest in deterring drunk driving and ensuring enforceability of a subsequent forfeiture order clearly outweighs the private interest affected.

Forfeitures and Penalties - Forfeiture of Proceeds or Instrumentality of Crime - Forfeiture of Vehicle Used to Facilitate Driving while Intoxicated - Constitutionality of Forfeiture Procedure

7. The application of the Property Clerk Forfeiture Law (Administrative Code of City of NY § 14-140) to vehicles operated by individuals arrested for driving while intoxicated, which authorizes the police to take and retain vehicles without a postseizure hearing prior to the conclusion of the forfeiture action, does not violate the Due Process Clauses of the Federal or State Constitution (US Const 14th Amend; NY Const, art I, § 6). Due process requires a meaningful adversarial proceeding at a meaningful time, but it is a flexible constitutional concept calling for such procedural protections as a particular situation may demand. The factors considered in determining whether the delay between a seizure and the initiation of judicial proceedings violates due process include the length of delay, the reason for the delay, the defendant's assertion of his right, and prejudice to the defendant. Pendency of a criminal action is a legitimate reason for the delayed filing of a forfeiture proceeding, and thus retention of a drunk driver's vehicle without a hearing, while the criminal action is pending, is also permissible. There is a strong public interest in withholding the vehicle in order to prevent it from being used for repeated illegal activity. Moreover, the nexus between the crime and the property, and thus the justification for forfeiture, is obvious at arrest, and there has been no showing that any additional or substitute safeguard would lessen the risk of an erroneous deprivation of petitioner's property.

Forfeitures and Penalties - Forfeiture of Proceeds or Instrumentality of Crime - Forfeiture of Vehicle Used to Facilitate Driving while Intoxicated - Constitutionality of Forfeiture Procedure

8. The application of the Property Clerk Forfeiture Law (Administrative Code of City of NY § 14-140) to the vehicle operated by petitioner upon his arrest for driving while intoxicated (DWI) does not violate the Excessive Fines Clauses of the Federal or State Constitution (US Const 8th Amend; NY Const, art I, § 5). The vehicle is the instrumentality of a charged crime, inseparable from it, and its prerequisite. DWI is a serious crime in both sentence and effect, a crime which injures and kills, and an unparalleled public menace. When the gravity of the offense and its unquestioned societal impact are compared with petitioner's and his wife's inconvenience, the retention of the 11-year-old vehicle worth $ 2,000, in which petitioner's wife was a passenger at the time of his arrest and acquiesced in his driving, is not unreasonably harsh as a matter of law.

 

609 of 992 DOCUMENTS


Aliessa v. Whalen


IAS PART 13, INDEX NO. 403748/98


SUPREME COURT OF NEW YORK, NEW YORK COUNTY


181 Misc. 2d 334; 694 N.Y.S.2d 308; 1999 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 235



May 17, 1999, Decided


SUBSEQUENT HISTORY:  [***1] As Corrected October 4, 1999.



DISPOSITION: Plaintiffs are entitled to a declaratory judgment as prayed for in their complaint. Further, a permanent injunction is granted with respect to plaintiffs, as is an order directing defendant to reimburse them for expenses that would have been covered and paid for through Medicaid, if such assistance had in fact been provided.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant state health agency brought a motion for dismissal of plaintiff immigrants' declaratory action seeking Medicaid benefits. Plaintiffs brought a motion for summary judgment, claiming New York State Social Services Law, § 122, violated equal protection under the N.Y. Const. Article XVII, § 1, and under the federal Constitution where it treated plaintiffs differently than immigrants entering the United States at an earlier date.


OVERVIEW: Plaintiff immigrants were entitled to Medicaid benefits where New York State Social Services Law, § 122, improperly restricted benefits to plaintiffs by violating a requirement under N.Y. Const. art. XVII, § 1, that the state provide aid, care, and support for the needy. Defendant state health agency denied Medicaid benefits to plaintiffs based on a state statute restricting benefits to immigrants who were not qualified aliens under the Federal Personal Responsibility and Work Opportunity Reconciliation Act of 1996, 8 U.S.C.S. § 1601. Plaintiffs brought a declaratory action to have the state statute declared unconstitutional. Defendant brought a motion to dismiss for failure to state a cause of action or for summary judgment. Plaintiffs also brought a summary judgment motion. The trial court granted plaintiff's motion and denied defendant's, holding the statute violated the state constitution's requirement that the state provide aid to the needy. The state's justification for denial based on fiscal concerns and limited resources was rejected and violated the state and federal equal protection where the statute created an invidious distinction between classes of citizens.


OUTCOME: The trial court granted plaintiff immigrants' motion for summary judgment in its action seeking a declaration that a state statute denying Medicaid benefits was unconstitutional. Where the state constitution required the state to provide aid and care to the needy, the statute was unconstitutional. The statute violated federal and state equal protection where it created an invidious distinction among classes of citizens.


HEADNOTES

Constitutional Law - Equal Protection of Laws - Strict Scrutiny Test Applied to Statute Determining Medicaid Eligibility for Lawfully Resident Aliens

1. A strict scrutiny analysis must be used in determining the constitutionality of Social Services Law § 122, which provides that eligibility for State-funded Medicaid coverage for lawfully resident aliens depends on whether the person is a "qualified alien" under the Federal Personal Responsibility and Work Opportunity Reconciliation Act of 1996 (8 USC § 1601 et seq.). State welfare laws which condition benefits on citizenship and duration of residency violate the Equal Protection Clause of the US Constitution 14th Amendment. Thus, classifications based on alienage are inherently suspect and subject to close judicial scrutiny.

Constitutional Law - Equal Protection of Laws - Medicaid Eligibility for Lawfully Resident Aliens

2. Social Services Law § 122, which provides that eligibility for State-funded Medicaid coverage for lawfully resident aliens depends on whether the person is a "qualified alien" under the Federal Personal Responsibility and Work Opportunity Reconciliation Act of 1996 (8 USC § 1601 [PRWORA]), violates the Equal Protection Clauses of the United States and New York Constitutions. Section 122 creates classifications of legal aliens and restricts the availability of public assistance benefits based upon those classifications. Fiscal concerns and the distribution of limited resources are inadequate justifications for denying some legal aliens public assistance, since the saving of welfare costs cannot justify an otherwise invidious classification. Although the PRWORA preamble empowered the States to choose to follow the Federal classification in determining the eligibility of aliens for public assistance, this pronouncement does not save the statute from a constitutional challenge.

Constitutional Law - Validity of Statute - Medicaid Eligibility for Lawfully Resident Aliens

3. Social Services Law § 122, which provides that eligibility for State-funded Medicaid coverage for lawfully resident aliens depends on whether the person is a "qualified alien" under the Federal Personal Responsibility and Work Opportunity Reconciliation Act of 1996 (8 USC § 1601 et seq.), violates New York Constitution, article XVII, § 1, which requires the State to provide aid, care and support for the needy. The declaration of the objectives of "Medical Assistance for Needy Persons" provides that such assistance is a matter of public concern and a necessity in promoting the public health and for promoting the State's goal of making available to everyone, regardless of race, age, national origin or economic standing, uniform, high-quality medical care (Social Services Law § 363). Furthermore, the Legislature may not deny all aid to certain individuals who are admittedly needy, solely on the basis of criteria having nothing to do with need. In addition, the State emergency Medicaid is not available to help all needy residents and the Safety Net Assistance Grant is insufficient to meet the required care for some needy aliens and only provides cash assistance for two years in a lifetime.

Social Services - Medical Assistance - Lawfully Resident Aliens

4. Plaintiffs, lawful permanent residents who entered the United States on or after August 22, 1996 and persons residing in the United States under color of law, who successfully challenged the constitutionality of Social Services Law § 122, which provides that eligibility for State-funded Medicaid coverage for lawfully resident aliens depends on whether the person is a "qualified alien" under the Federal Personal Responsibility and Work Opportunity Reconciliation Act of 1996 (8 USC § 1601 et seq.), are entitled to a judgment declaring Social Services Law § 122 unconstitutional, and a permanent injunction directing defendant State to reimburse them for expenses that would have been covered and paid for through Medicaid, if such assistance had in fact been provided.

 

610 of 992 DOCUMENTS


In re Custody & Guardianship of Marino S.


Docket # B9937-9/99, NA8220-2/97


FAMILY COURT OF NEW YORK, NEW YORK COUNTY


181 Misc. 2d 264; 693 N.Y.S.2d 822; 1999 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 262



May 7, 1999, Decided



DISPOSITION:  [***1] The parental rights of the respondents were terminated and the child care agency was directed to proceed expeditiously with the children's adoption by foster parents.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: A termination of parental rights case based upon grounds of severe abuse was before the courts, which required an interpretation of the New York Adoption and Safe Families Act of 1999.


OVERVIEW: A motion was brought to terminate the parental rights of respondents based on severe abuse. The court terminated respondents' parental rights based on its interpretation of the New York Adoption and Safe Families Act of 1999 (NY-ASFA). NY-ASFA, a remedial statute, was applied retroactively and respondent's felony sex offense for reckless endangerment was grounds for parental rights termination under NY-ASFA, even though the proceedings occurred before passage of NY-ASFA. Petitioner sufficiently established that respondents severely abused their children. Respondent mother was aware of sexual abuse of one child, yet did nothing to stop it. The abuse of one child was enough to terminate respondents' parental rights in all of their children, as it was shown the abuse occurred during a proximity in time when the other children were living in respondents' household and no meaningful distinction between the children was shown. Aggravated circumstances under section 1012(j) of the Family Court Act were able to be shown after the termination of parental rights petition was filed, and under such circumstances, diligent reunification efforts were not required.


OUTCOME: The court terminated respondents' parental rights as severe abuse was shown under New York Adoption and Safe Families Act of 1999 based on a prior felony sexual offense involving one of the children. Even though aggravated circumstances were not established until after the petition was filed, petitioner was not required to establish diligent reunification efforts under the circumstances.


HEADNOTES

Statutes - Retroactive Application of Statute - New York Adoption and Safe Families Act

1. Chapter 7 of the Laws of 1999 (NY-ASFA), which was designed to bring New York into conformity with the Federal Adoption and Safe Families Act of 1997 (Federal ASFA), is remedial legislation refining the law concerning permanency planning for children in foster care so that New York more fully and expeditiously accomplishes its preexisting goals and thus may be applied retroactively to proceedings to terminate parental rights filed before its passage. Statutes affecting the welfare of children and furthering important public policies are generally given retroactive effect. Moreover, Federal ASFA by its express terms is applicable to all children in foster care on the date of its enactment, and, in order to comply with Federal law, NY-ASFA must also apply to those children. Accordingly, in a proceeding to terminate respondents' parental rights which was commenced prior to the passage of NY-ASFA, petitioner was entitled to amend the petitions after the passage of NY-ASFA but before the fact-finding hearing was commenced in order to add new causes of action of severe abuse pursuant to Social Services Law § 384-b (8) (a) (i) and (ii) as amended by NY-ASFA.

Parent and Child - Termination of Parental Rights - Severe Abuse - Sufficiency of Evidence

2. In a proceeding to terminate respondents' parental rights, petitioner established by clear and convincing evidence that respondent mother severely abused her daughter, as that term is defined in Social Services Law § 384-b (8) (a) (i) and (ii), by knowingly allowing her boyfriend to rape her daughter and by her conduct after the rape that endangered her daughter's life, which was proven beyond a reasonable doubt by her conviction for first degree reckless endangerment and her daughter's medical records. The psychological report submitted by respondent in support of her defense that she herself was abused by her boyfriend and was therefore powerless to protect her daughter failed to establish either that respondent's conduct was prompted by the circumstances of her relationship with her boyfriend or that she would be able to function better as a parent if she were removed from that relationship.

Parent and Child - Termination of Parental Rights - Derivative Finding of Severe Abuse - Sufficiency of Evidence

3. In a proceeding to terminate respondent mother's parental rights to her three children and her boyfriend's parental rights to the two youngest children, the severe abuse of the oldest child by both her mother, which was proved by clear and convincing evidence, and her mother's boyfriend, which was proved beyond a reasonable doubt by his conviction for raping the child (see, Social Services Law § 384-b [8] [a] [i], [ii]), constitutes grounds for termination of both parents' rights to the two youngest children based on a derivative finding of severe abuse. Where a respondent's severe abuse of one child is proximate in time with his or her care of another child and the respondent has been unable to demonstrate any meaningful distinction between the children, the law should protect both children fully and equally. Moreover, New York child welfare law and policy strongly favor keeping siblings together, and without derivative findings of severe abuse, the sibling of a severely abused child would be on a different permanency planning track from the target child and might not be able to be moved to the adoptive home located for the severely abused child.

Parent and Child - Termination of Parental Rights - Aggravated Circumstances Excusing Reasonable Efforts to Return Child Home - When Determination of Aggravated Circumstances Need be Made

4. An agency seeking to commence a proceeding to terminate parental rights need not first move pursuant to Family Court Act § 1039-b for a determination that aggravated circumstances are present which excuse the agency from making diligent or reasonable efforts to encourage and strengthen the parental relationship. To require otherwise would promote neither the child's need for permanency nor the court's concern with judicial economy. While a motion pursuant to section 1039-b is one route for determining whether reasonable efforts may be dispensed with, such a determination may also be made in a termination of parental rights proceeding. Within the termination proceeding itself the court is required to consider the threshold question of the appropriateness of the agency's efforts, or lack thereof, to reunify the family, and it must decide the same issues that would have been raised in a section 1039-b motion. The court in a termination proceeding also revisits the question of possible reunification of the family at the time of the dispositional hearing in order to determine whether a respondent shows greater promise of rehabilitation than he or she did prior to the initiation of the termination proceeding.

Parent and Child - Termination of Parental Rights - Aggravated Circumstances Excusing Reasonable Efforts to Return Child Home - Sufficiency of Evidence

5. In a proceeding to terminate respondent mother's parental rights to her three children and her boyfriend's parental rights to the two youngest children, petitioner has proved by clear and convincing evidence that both respondents over the course of at least four years engaged in conduct that caused severe, perhaps irreparable, harm to at least one of the children and therefore petitioner need not exercise diligent or reasonable efforts to encourage and strengthen the parental relationship. During that four-year period, attempts at intervention by petitioner and law enforcement representatives were unavailing. Respondent father did not present any evidence that he is capable of rehabilitation, and the psychological report submitted by respondent mother in support of her claim that she is capable of rehabilitation revealed that she is still minimizing her role in her daughter's tragedy, that she is not inclined to discuss her problems, and that she still requires at least two years of intensive therapy, which has only a 70% chance of moderate success.

 

611 of 992 DOCUMENTS


Toussie v. Central Pine Barrens Joint Planning & Policy Comm'n


Index No. 1998-17135, Motion No. 001 MD SUB J


SUPREME COURT OF NEW YORK, SUFFOLK COUNTY


182 Misc. 2d 582; 700 N.Y.S.2d 358; 1999 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 528



April 27, 1999, Decided



DISPOSITION:  [***1] Summary judgment denied.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner landowner brought a motion for summary judgment in his action challenging the number of credits awarded petitioner by respondent land development commission for the development parcels owned by petitioner.


OVERVIEW: Petitioner landowner purchased eight parcels of property in a land development association. Respondent planning and policy commission awarded credits to petitioner for the parcels. The credits would allow petitioner to realize a substantial profit on his investment if he accepted the credits. Petitioner brought a motion for summary judgment in his action challenging the number of credits awarded by respondent. The court denied petitioner's motion, holding that the number of credits awarded to petitioner was not arbitrary, unreasonable, or confiscatory. The court found that respondent used a reasonable means to determine the credits due to the parcel owners, including petitioner. Further, landowners who were dissatisfied with the credit program were not required to participate. Petitioner's argument that the land use plan must be strictly construed because it was in derogation of common law was without merit. The single and separate ownership privilege contained in most zoning codes was not a common law privilege.


OUTCOME: The court denied petitioner land parcel owner's motion for summary judgment in his action challenging the number of credits awarded by respondent planning and policy commission where respondent used a reasonable means to determine credits due to parcel owners and the number of credits awarded to petitioner was not arbitrary, unreasonable, or confiscatory.


HEADNOTES

Constitutional Law - Taking of Property - Transferable Development Rights Program - Long Island Pine Barrens Protection Act

Petitioner, who purchased eight small parcels in residentially zoned, remote areas located within a limited-development area subject to the Long Island Pine Barrens Protection Act (ECL 57-0103 et seq.) and was awarded a total of 1.1 development credits by respondent under the regional transferable development rights (TDR) program, pursuant to which property owners receive development rights or credits which they may sell to developers in designated growth areas, is not entitled to a full credit for each parcel. The comprehensive regional land use plan covering the affected properties only provides that all parcels must receive a minimum .10 credit and that one full credit may be allocated to a parcel of at least 4,000 square feet if it has frontage on an "existing improved road." Furthermore, petitioner is not entitled to receive a full credit for each parcel of property under a common-law "single and separate" ownership privilege. A statute, as here, that restricts development on parcels that were once permissible to build upon, but under present law may no longer be built upon, is not in derogation of common law and need not be strictly construed. Moreover, petitioner has failed to show that the TDR program results in an unconstitutional taking without compensation.

 

612 of 992 DOCUMENTS


Tri-State Christian T.V., Inc. v. Dillenberg


Index No. K1-1998-001950


SUPREME COURT OF NEW YORK, CHAUTAUQUA COUNTY


180 Misc. 2d 417; 689 N.Y.S.2d 386; 1999 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 147



April 8, 1999, Decided


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Municipal defendants moved for a stay or dismissal of plaintiff organization's 42 U.S.C.S. § 1983 action that alleged defendants engaged in acts of religious discrimination in application of a property tax.


OVERVIEW: Plaintiff organization filed a 42 U.S.C.S. § 1983 action against municipal defendants alleging religious discrimination in the form of property taxes assessed upon plaintiff. Plaintiff contended that the application of the tax was improper, not the tax itself. Moreover, plaintiff sought a declaratory judgment and injunctive relief, in addition to attorney's fees pursuant to 42 U.S.C.S. § 1988. Defendants moved to stay or dismiss plaintiff's action. The court granted defendants' motion to dismiss. The court reasoned that pursuant to 42 U.S.C.S. § 1983, injunctive and declaratory relief were not available to the plaintiff as forms of recovery when plaintiff had an adequate remedy at law available to it. Moreover, the court reasoned that because plaintiff could obtain legal relief in the form of a refund, equitable relief was effectively precluded. Additionally, associated attorney's fees sought were also not recoverable.


OUTCOME: Defendants' motion to dismiss plaintiff's 42 U.S.C.S. § 1983 religious discrimination action was granted. The court reasoned that because plaintiff had an adequate state law remedy, declaratory and injunctive relief as well as attorney's fees were not viable remedies; therefore, plaintiff's case was dismissed accordingly.


HEADNOTES

Taxation - Exemptions - Federal Civil Rights Action

An action pursuant to 42 USC § 1983 alleging that defendants, as an act of religious discrimination, imposed property tax on plaintiff despite plaintiff's status as a nonprofit, tax-exempt, religious organization, must be dismissed where plaintiff has brought a separate proceeding pursuant to the Real Property Tax Law in which it seeks a determination that it is entitled to tax-exempt status and in which, if successful, it would be entitled to a refund of improperly collected taxes, in addition to the correction of the property's misclassification. Federal law will not generally interfere with the administration of State taxes, and injunctive or declaratory relief under section 1983 is not available when there is an adequate remedy at law, as opposed to equity. Plaintiff has a remedy at law in the form of tax refunds, and it is immaterial that plaintiff's challenge to the property tax statutes is that they are unconstitutional as applied, rather than on their face.

 

613 of 992 DOCUMENTS


People v. Edwards


Indictment No. 97-13


COUNTY COURT OF NEW YORK, SCHOHARIE COUNTY


180 Misc. 2d 564; 690 N.Y.S.2d 404; 1999 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 176



April 6, 1999, Decided


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant moved to withdraw his guilty plea to the charge of first degree murder in violation of N.Y. Penal Law § 125.27.


OVERVIEW: Defendant was charged with first degree and second degree murder, second degree conspiracy, and second degree criminal possession of a weapon used in the victim's death. Defendant entered into a plea agreement and entered a guilty plea to the charge of first degree murder in violation of N.Y. Penal Law § 125.27. Prior to entering into the plea agreement, the prosecutor agreed to withdraw his intent to seek the death penalty against defendant. The court accepted defendant's knowing and voluntary guilty plea pursuant to the plea agreement. Defendant then moved to withdraw his guilty plea in light of recent caselaw. Defendant contended his plea agreement was invalid because the notice of intent to seek the death penalty was pending. The court denied defendant's motion and held that his plea agreement was valid. The court reasoned the new caselaw did not invalidate his plea because the prosecutor had withdrawn his intent to seek the death penalty when defendant entered into the plea agreement. Moreover, the prosecutor had no conditions attached to the plea agreement regarding the death penalty; hence, the motion was denied and the guilty plea was affirmed accordingly.


OUTCOME: Defendant's motion to withdraw his guilty plea to first degree murder was denied. The court held that the defendant entered into a voluntary and valid plea agreement with the prosecutor, which was accepted and entered by the court. The court reasoned that because the prosecutor had withdrawn his intent to seek the death penalty prior to or simultaneously with defendant's entering into the plea agreement, the agreement was valid.


HEADNOTES

Crimes - Plea of Guilty - Withdrawal of Plea - Death Penalty Case

Defendant, relying on the unconstitutionality of the plea provisions in the State's death penalty statute (see, CPL 220.10 [5] [e]; 220.30 [3] [b] [vii]), is not entitled to withdraw his plea of guilty to first degree murder where defendant does not allege that his plea was involuntary, unknowing or unintelligent, or that he believes he is innocent, since there is no constitutional infirmity to a guilty plea to first degree murder if the notice of intent to seek the death penalty is absent. Mindful of the constitutional infirmity of the plea provisions, the court refused to accept defendant's guilty plea until after the prosecutor withdrew the notice of intent to seek the death penalty, which followed defendant's plea allocution. Consequently, when the plea was entered, the notice of intent had been withdrawn with no conditions attached which would allow for reinstatement, and at the very least, the plea was allocuted in conjunction with the withdrawal of the notice of intent. Moreover, otherwise valid guilty pleas are not involuntary because they were induced by the fear of the death penalty.

 

614 of 992 DOCUMENTS


Clara C. v. William L.


99-285


FAMILY COURT OF NEW YORK, KINGS COUNTY


181 Misc. 2d 241; 692 N.Y.S.2d 569; 1999 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 261



March 31, 1999, Decided


SUBSEQUENT HISTORY:  [***1] As Corrected October 4, 1999.



DISPOSITION: Petitioner's objections to the order of the Hearing Examiner denied. Petition is dismissed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner mother filed an action against respondent, a man whom blood tests had earlier revealed to be the father of her child, seeking a declaration of paternity and an order of support. Respondent filed a motion to dismiss the petition upon the argument that it was barred by the terms of an agreement that the respective parties had entered into pursuant to N.Y. Fam. Ct. Act § 516, which had resolved a prior paternity proceeding.


OVERVIEW: Petitioner, the mother of a child, had previously commenced a paternity action against respondent that sought a declaration of paternity and an order of support. Blood tests revealed respondent's paternity. Nonetheless, rather than pursuing the suit, petitioner opted to settle her claims by entering into an agreement whereby respondent, without admitting paternity, agreed to pay petitioner a specified amount of monthly child support until the child turned 21. In return, assuming compliance with respondent's obligations, petitioner agreed to dismiss the suit and neither seek child support nor commence another paternity proceeding. The agreement was subsequently approved and confirmed by a court pursuant to N.Y. Fam. Ct. Act § 516. Ten years later, petitioner commenced another paternity proceeding against respondent seeking the same relief sought in the earlier action. The court granted respondent's motion to dismiss the petition because it was barred by the terms of the agreement entered into pursuant to § 516, because respondent had not violated the terms of that agreement, and because the agreement was found to be a valid limitation upon the mother's right to proceed.


OUTCOME: Respondent's motion to dismiss petitioner's paternity and support action was granted because petitioner had previously entered into a court approved settlement agreement whereby she agreed to not bring such an action against respondent in the future in return for his agreement to pay petitioner a specified amount of monthly child support until the child turned 21. Because respondent had not violated the agreement, petitioner could not proceed.


HEADNOTES

Children Born out of Wedlock - Paternity Proceeding - Support Agreement between Mother and Putative Father - Enforceability of Provision Barring Subsequent Paternity and Support Proceedings

1. Petitioner mother's proceeding seeking a declaration of paternity and an order of support from respondent, the alleged father of petitioner's child, is barred by the terms of a 1987 agreement between the parties entered into pursuant to Family Court Act § 516 (the Agreement) which resolved a paternity proceeding commenced by petitioner and under which respondent, without admitting paternity, agreed to pay petitioner child support in exchange for petitioner agreeing to dismiss the proceeding and to neither seek child support nor commence another paternity proceeding in the future. The Agreement was approved by the court, as required by Family Court Act § 516 (a), and there is no legal or factual basis upon which it might be second-guessed almost 12 years later. In addition, Family Court Act § 516 (c) provides that respondent's complete performance of the Agreement bars other remedies of petitioner for support, and petitioner's claims of respondent's inadequate performance, which were raised a full 10 years after the Agreement was signed, do not constitute a substantive breach sufficient to excuse petitioner's obligations under the Agreement. Moreover, although a parent who has an obligation to support a child cannot permanently fix that obligation by contract with the other parent whether or not the child has been born of married parents or out of wedlock, no order of filiation was ever entered against respondent and there is no predicate for the imposition of a support obligation under Family Court Act § 513 which would always be reviewable and subject to modification by the court.

Children Born out of Wedlock - Support - Support Agreement between Mother and Putative Father - Constitutionality of Statute Permitting Support Agreement

2. Family Court Act § 516, which permits a mother and a putative father to enter into a binding agreement for the support of their out-of-wedlock child and bars other remedies of the mother or child for support and education of the child, does not discriminate against illegitimate children in violation of the Equal Protection Clause of the Fourteenth Amendment. The statute does not permit disparate treatment between legitimate and illegitimate children whose parents are obligated to provide support under Family Court Act §§ 413 and 513 and cannot contract to fix their obligations; rather, it only permits disparate treatment between children of parents who are subject to obligations under sections 413 and 513, and those as to whom paternity has not yet been established and are therefore not subject to such obligations. Such classification is substantially related to important governmental objectives, which include encouraging compromise of litigation and assuring adequate support for the concerned child by eliminating the unpredictability of the litigation process. These governmental interests are not made any less significant by improved genetic testing since there are many circumstances where test results simply will not resolve the issue of paternity.

 

615 of 992 DOCUMENTS


State v. Sour Mt. Realty


Index No. 986/99


SUPREME COURT OF NEW YORK, DUTCHESS COUNTY


183 Misc. 2d 313; 703 N.Y.S.2d 854; 1999 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 616



March 30, 1999, Decided


SUBSEQUENT HISTORY:  [***1] As Corrected February 28, 2000.



DISPOSITION: Plaintiffs' motion for a preliminary injunction enjoining defendant (1) from continuing to violate the New York State Endangered Species Act by disturbing, harrying or worrying timber rattlesnakes, (2) from unlawfully preventing, deterring or otherwise interfering with the normal disbursal, migration or movement of timber rattlesnakes, and from modifying and/or degrading the timber rattlesnake habitat in the vicinity of defendant's property through the erection and maintenance of snake-proof fencing along and/or near the boundary of that property, and (3) to remove all the snake-proof fencing it has erected along and/or near the boundary of its property, is granted. The fence will be removed by defendant on or before April 3, 1999.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff State Department of Environmental Conservation brought an action seeking the issuance of a preliminary injunction barring defendant landowner from interfering with or modifying the habitat of timber rattlesnakes based upon defendant's alleged violation of N.Y. Envtl. Conserv. Law § 11-0535. Additionally, plaintiff sought a preliminary injunction requiring defendant to remove a snake-proof fence located on the defendant's property.


OVERVIEW: Under the provisions of N.Y. Envtl. Conserv. Law § 11-0535, plaintiff state department of conservation brought an action seeking preliminary injunctive relief preventing defendant land owner from interfering or modifying the habitat of certain timber rattlesnakes. The court held the defendant's modification of rattlesnake habitat constituted a taking of endangered animals as prohibited under N.Y. Envtl. Conserv. Law § 11-0103[13]. The court held that although the expert witness testimony, as to whether defendant's proposed snake-proof fence would modify snake's habitat, raised issues of fact and credibility, plaintiff established a likelihood of success they would suffer irreparable injury if preliminary injunctive relief was not granted. Based on expert testimony, should the defendant's fence interfere with the rattlesnakes' migratory patterns or deprive them of habitat for foraging, a taking of the rattlesnakes would have occurred. In addition, the court held a balance of the equities favored granting plaintiff injunctive relief. Defendant could not refuse plaintiff access to site in question and then use the lack of concrete evidence to defeat plaintiff's expert testimony.


OUTCOME: The court granted plaintiff conservation department's preliminary injunctive relief barring defendant land owner from continued violations of Endangered Species Act and requiring removal of existing snake-proof fence. Plaintiff established a likelihood of success they would suffer irreparable harm, based on modification of snake habitat, if injunctive relief was not granted. In addition balance of equities favored grant of injunctive relief.


HEADNOTES

Administrative Law - Administrative Interpretation - "Taking" of Threatened Species - Protection of Timber Rattlesnakes by State Department of Environmental Conservation

1. In an action by the State Department of Environmental Conservation (DEC) to protect the habitat of a threatened species, viz., the timber rattlesnake, by preventing defendant from violating ECL 11-0535, which prohibits the "taking" of any threatened species, absent case law or other indicia of the meaning of "taking" in ECL 11-0103 (13), it is appropriate to rely on traditional principles of statutory construction while recognizing that DEC's interpretation of statutes and regulations in the area of its expertise must be afforded deference. Given the clear statement in section 11-0103 (13) that "pursuing, shooting, hunting, killing, capturing, trapping, snaring and netting" protected species are prohibited, the subsequent term "all lesser acts" must mean acts of less significance or impact than those enumerated, or else the inclusion of "lesser acts" would be merely redundant. Thus, the statutory terms "disturbing, harrying or worrying" are merely examples of lesser included acts and do not encompass all lesser acts which are prohibited. Resort to the plain meaning of the operative words is appropriate. In light of the dictionary definitions of "disturb," "harry," and "worry," and the plain language of the statute, a modification of rattlesnake habitat constitutes a "taking." Accordingly, whether a fence erected by defendant to keep the snakes away from its land actually modifies the habitat of those snakes whose den is some 260 feet from defendant's property line is determinative.

Environmental Conservation - Fish and Wildlife - Protection of Threatened Species - Timber Rattlesnake - Fencing of Habitat

2. In an action to compel defendant to remove a fence it erected in order to prevent timber rattlesnakes from coming onto its property, plaintiff, the State Department of Environmental Conservation, which seeks a preliminary injunction on the theory that the fence constitutes a modification of the snakes' habitat and is thus a prohibited "taking," has met its burden of showing a likelihood of success on the merits. Although defendant asserted that there was no significant rattlesnake habitat on its property, defendant's experts only looked for snakes at times when they would be expected to be near their den, which was not on defendant's property. Also, defendant refused to allow plaintiffs' experts to enter its property to determine if it is part of the snakes' habitat, and the very fact that defendant erected the fence supports the contention that its property is part of that habitat. Should the fence interfere with the normal migratory patterns of the rattlesnakes, or deprive them of habitat for foraging, shedding, mating, basking, or gestational activities, a "taking" of such rattlesnakes would occur. The court is not required to allow such a taking prior to enjoining acts in violation of ECL 11-0535.

Environmental Conservation - Fish and Wildlife - Protection of Threatened Species - Timber Rattlesnake - Fencing of Habitat - Irreparable Harm

3. In an action to compel defendant to remove a fence it erected in order to prevent timber rattlesnakes from coming onto its property, plaintiff, the State Department of Environmental Conservation (DEC), which seeks a preliminary injunction on the theory that the fence constitutes a modification of the snakes' habitat and is thus a prohibited "taking," has met its burden of showing a likelihood of success on the merits. Moreover, plaintiff has met its burden of showing irreparable harm if the defendant is permitted to maintain its snake-proof fence. DEC is charged with the protection of all threatened species, including the timber rattlesnake, and harm to such species impacts upon the quality of life of all State residents and is not compensable by monetary damages. Finally, a balance of the equities clearly favors plaintiffs: while defendants contend that any harm to timber rattlesnakes flowing from its snake-proof fence is purely speculative, it is its refusal to allow plaintiffs' experts access to its property which has denied plaintiffs the opportunity to actually determine the risk posed by the fence. Defendant cannot refuse access to its property and then use the lack of concrete information resulting from that refusal to defeat plaintiffs' experts' testimony.

Environmental Conservation - Environmental Quality Review - Preliminary Injunction - Removal of Fence Modifying Habitat of Threatened Species

4. In an action to compel defendant to remove a fence it erected in order to prevent timber rattlesnakes from coming onto its property, a preliminary injunction ordering the removal of the fence, which purportedly modifies the habitat of the rattlesnakes in violation of ECL 11-0535, is not warranted on the theory that defendant violated the State Environmental Quality Review Act ( ECL art 8) or 6 NYCRR 617.3 (a), which provides that "[a] project sponsor may not commence any physical alteration related to an action until the provisions of SEQRA have been complied with." "Physical alteration" is defined as "construction of buildings, structures or facilities" (6 NYCRR 617.2 [ab]), and it is undisputed that defendant's proposed mining project sought to construct snake-proof fencing around the mining site and not around the property's boundary. Thus, the construction of the fence on the border of defendant's property is not "related to" the mining proposal.

 

616 of 992 DOCUMENTS


People v. Trabazo


Docket No. 98Q044181


CRIMINAL COURT OF THE CITY OF NEW YORK, QUEENS COUNTY


180 Misc. 2d 961; 690 N.Y.S.2d 829; 1999 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 193



March 22, 1999, Decided


SUBSEQUENT HISTORY:  [***1] As Corrected August 2, 1999.



DISPOSITION: Accordingly, no legal reason having been presented to this Court requiring the relinquishment of its jurisdiction over this case, the defendant's motion to dismiss the information, or in the alternative, to transfer the criminal action to Supreme Court pursuant to Supreme Court's order is denied in its entirety.


CASE SUMMARY:
