PROCEDURAL POSTURE: This matter came before the court on defendant's motion to dismiss the information charging defendant with criminal contempt and harassment, or in the alternative, to transfer the criminal action to the New York Supreme Court pursuant to the Supreme Court's order.


OVERVIEW: Defendant was charged in an information with criminal contempt in the second degree and harassment in the second degree as a result of conduct in violation of an order of protection issued by a supreme court justice presiding over the matrimonial action between defendant and his wife. Defendant moved to dismiss the information, or in the alternative, to transfer the action to the supreme court pursuant to an order of the supreme court purporting to transfer and merge the criminal action with the matrimonial action. The court denied defendant's motion in its entirety. The supreme court had no jurisdiction over the criminal matter because there had been no action by a grand jury and no superior court information had been filed. Moreover, the supreme court lacked the power to transfer the criminal action from the instant court to itself.


OUTCOME: The court denied the defendant's motion to dismiss or transfer the information charging him with criminal contempt and harassment because the supreme court lacked jurisdiction over the criminal action.


HEADNOTES

Courts - Transfer to Other Court - Jurisdiction of Supreme Court to Order Transfer of Criminal Action to Itself for Merger into Pending Matrimonial Action

Where defendant is charged in the New York City Criminal Court with misdemeanor family offenses for violating an order of protection issued by a Supreme Court Justice presiding over the matrimonial action between defendant and his wife, Supreme Court lacks subject matter jurisdiction to order removal of the criminal action for the purpose of merging it into the pending matrimonial action even if all of the parties consent. While Supreme Court, as a court of general original jurisdiction (NY Const, art VI, § 7), has concurrent jurisdiction with that of the Criminal Court over misdemeanors, its power to exercise trial jurisdiction over criminal offenses is triggered only by the intervention of the Grand Jury or by the filing of a superior court information ( CPL 10.20, 10.30). Since there has been no action by the Grand Jury as to the pending charges, nor has a superior court information been filed, Supreme Court has no jurisdiction over the trial of the misdemeanor offenses. Furthermore, while the Supreme Court Justice presiding over the matrimonial action could, in the exercise of discretion, sit as a local criminal court pursuant to CPL 10.20, the Justice's jurisdiction would be limited only to arraigning defendant and setting bail, procedural matters that have already been concluded. Moreover, even assuming that Supreme Court may exercise trial jurisdiction over a misdemeanor not involving the action of the Grand Jury or a superior court information, absent some legitimate procedural mechanism, Supreme Court has no constitutional authority (see, NY Const, art VI, § 19 [a]) to order the transfer of a criminal action to itself.

 

617 of 992 DOCUMENTS


Ricketts v. City of New York


Index No. 102455/97


SUPREME COURT OF NEW YORK, NEW YORK COUNTY


181 Misc. 2d 838; 688 N.Y.S.2d 418; 1999 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 133



March 18, 1999, Decided


SUBSEQUENT HISTORY:  [***1] As Corrected October 4, 1999.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Both parties brought motions for summary judgment in plaintiff commuter service operators' action to nullify local legislation giving the defendant City of New York authority to grant franchises for the operation of commuter van services in the city.


OVERVIEW: Plaintiffs were operators of existing commuter services in defendant New York City who had been denied their requests to expand operations or were seeking to obtain authorizations for new commuter van services. Plaintiffs filed an action challenging a city law that gave defendant authority to grant franchises for the operation of commuter van services in the city. Both parties moved for summary judgment. The court found that the law was constitutional because a rational relationship existed between the law and the defendant's police power. The court did, however, find that procedural due process required defendant to give reasons for an adverse licensing determination.


OUTCOME: The court granted defendant city summary judgment after finding a rational relationship between the grant of local control over commuter service franchises and defendant's exercise of its police power to regulate traffic on the public streets. The court concluded that the law was constitutional. The court also found that due process required that reasons for an adverse decision be given.


HEADNOTES

Judgments - Collateral Estoppel - Validity of Local Law Regulating Commuter Van Services

1. In an action brought by the operators of existing commuter van services challenging the validity of local legislation giving the City of New York authority for the granting of franchises for the operation of commuter van services, the City defendants are estopped from relitigating the validity of those provisions of the local legislation that grant the City Council final approval over licensing determinations since the City defendants had a full and fair opportunity to litigate this issue in another action which declared those provisions to be invalid (see, Giuliani v Council of City of N. Y., 181 Misc 2d 830).

Municipal Corporations - Regulation of Commuter Van Services - Municipality's Police Power to Regulate Traffic

2. In an action brought by the operators of existing commuter van services challenging the validity of local legislation giving the City of New York authority for the granting of franchises for the operation of commuter van services, those provisions of the legislation that prohibit commuter vans from traveling on certain bus routes and from picking up and discharging passengers except at their homes and at non-bus-route stops fall within the City's police power to regulate traffic in the public streets (Vehicle and Traffic Law § 1640 [a] [5]) and are thus valid. It cannot be said beyond a reasonable doubt that there is no rational relationship between the challenged provisions and the City's police power to regulate traffic in the general public interest.

Municipal Corporations - Regulation of Commuter Van Services - Removal of Permanent Status to "Grandfather" Franchises

3. In an action brought by the operators of existing commuter van services challenging the validity of local legislation giving the City of New York authority for the granting of franchises for the operation of commuter van services, the City's failure to continue the permanent status that existing franchises had while the licensing of commuter vans was under State control is not violative of any State law. The "grandfather" clause in the enabling statute (Transportation Law § 80 [5]) merely requires that those commuter van franchises that had been given permanent licenses by the State be allowed to continue to operate through the transition period. It clearly evinces the State's intention for the City to chart its own licensing policy undisturbed by the prior licensing policy of the State. In addition, the City's removal of permanent status from the "grandfather" franchises does not constitute an unconstitutional taking of property and a denial of plaintiffs' liberty right to earn a living. Plaintiffs' licenses to operate their franchises do not constitute a property right protected by the State and Federal Constitutions, nor do their businesses fall under the Liberty Clauses of those Constitutions. Moreover, there is a rational relationship between the City's approach to the "grandfather" franchises and both the State's grant of local control over commuter van franchises and the City's exercise of its police power to regulate traffic on the public streets.

Municipal Corporations - Regulation of Commuter Van Services - Effect of Invalidation of Portion of Local Legislation 

4. In an action brought by the operators of existing commuter van services challenging the validity of local legislation giving the City of New York authority for the granting of franchises for the operation of commuter van services, the fact that those provisions of the local legislation that grant the City Council final approval over licensing determinations made by the Taxi and Limousine Commission have been invalidated (see, Giuliani v Council of City of N. Y., 181 Misc 2d 830) does not require that the entire legislation be struck down since the main focus of the legislation is still viable in the absence of the City Council's call-back power. The City Council's reservation of the final word on franchise approvals is only incidental to the main purpose of the legislation, which is to shift control of the approval and regulation of commuter van franchises to local City authorities. This purpose is achieved with the removal of the City Council's power of approval of commuter van franchises.

Constitutional Law - Due Process of Law - Denial of License Application

5. The provision of a local law that permits applications for commuter van services to be denied by a municipality without an explanation or a record for review after the passage of 180 days without a hearing being held is violative of fundamental due process, which requires that a licensee be given notice of adverse action by the licensing authority, an opportunity to be heard and the reasons for an adverse decision. A full evidentiary hearing might not be required in every circumstance so long as plaintiffs are given a full and fair opportunity to present their cases.

 

618 of 992 DOCUMENTS


People v. Geel


99-171


JUSTICE COURT OF NEW YORK, TOWN OF SAND LAKE, RENSSELAER COUNTY


180 Misc. 2d 272; 690 N.Y.S.2d 827; 1999 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 130



March 17, 1999, Decided



DISPOSITION:  [***1] Defendant's Motion to Dismiss is granted.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant was charged with a violation of Town of Sand Lake, N.Y., Code § 170-2(E), which he moved to dismiss pursuant to N.Y. Crim. Proc. Law §§ 170.30(1)(f), 170.35(1)(c), and 210.45.


OVERVIEW: Defendant was charged with violating the Noise Pollution Control Law, Town of Sand Lake, N.Y., Code § 170-2(E). With leave of the court, defendant filed a motion to dismiss the charge against him. Defendant alleged that the town ordinance, as written, was unconstitutional because it was vague and therefore violated the defendant's due process rights pursuant to the federal and state constitutions. The court granted defendant's motion and held that there was not enough of an objective standard to allow another to determine whether the noise was unlawful, without more. The court noted that a measuring standard, by scientific means, needed to be set. Therefore, the court held that the Noise Pollution Control Law was unconstitutional based on both the federal and New York State Constitutions.


OUTCOME: The court granted defendant's motion to dismiss charges that he violated a town noise pollution control law. The court held that the town's noise pollution control law was unconstitutional based on both the federal and New York State Constitutions because there was not an objective standard to allow another to determine whether the law was unlawful.


HEADNOTES

Constitutional Law - Validity of Statute - Noise Control Ordinance - Vagueness

Noise Pollution Control Law of the Town of Sand Lake (Code of Town of Sand Lake) § 170-2 (E), which prohibits "loud or raucous noises likely to annoy or disturb people" between 11:00 P.M. and 6:00 A.M., is unconstitutionally vague because there is not enough of an objective standard to allow another to determine whether the noise is unlawful.

 

619 of 992 DOCUMENTS


McGee v. McGee


96-22054


SUPREME COURT OF NEW YORK, SUFFOLK COUNTY


180 Misc. 2d 575; 694 N.Y.S.2d 269; 1999 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 153



March 16, 1999, Decided



DISPOSITION:  [***1] Family Court Act § 262 is an enactment by the New York State Legislature and is entitled to a presumption of constitutionality. Nothing raised by defendant's counsel gives this Court reason to set aside this presumption.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: In a custody modification case, defendant wife moved for an order directing plaintiff husband to pay her counsel fees pursuant to N.Y. Dom. Rel. Law § 237 and an order transferring the case to the family court or assigning her free counsel.


OVERVIEW: Plaintiff husband commenced an action to modify child custody in the supreme court. Defendant wife moved for an order that would require plaintiff to pay her counsel fees pursuant to N.Y. Dom. Rel. Law § 237. Defendant also sought an order to transfer the case to family court or assign free counsel to represent her. The court denied the motion to require plaintiff to pay defendant's counsel fees without prejudice for her to renew her application upon a proper showing by appropriate proofs of indigency. The court denied defendant's motion to transfer the case to family court or appoint free counsel to represent defendant because N.Y. Fam. Ct. Act § 262(a) provided that only family courts could assign counsel for indigent persons in specifically enumerated cases and that power was not given to the supreme court by the legislature. Further the court found there was insufficient evidence to rebut the presumption that the statute was constitutional.


OUTCOME: The court denied defendant's motion for an order requiring plaintiff to pay defendant's counsel fees without prejudice for her to present proof of her own indigence and that of plaintiff. The court denied defendant's motion to transfer the case to the family court or to assign her free counsel, finding that defendant was not constitutionally entitled to free counsel in a child custody action in the supreme court.


HEADNOTES

Husband and Wife - Divorce - Indigent Parent's Right to Free Counsel on Issue of Custody

1. In an action for divorce and ancillary relief in which one of the issues in dispute is the custody of the parties' two young children, defendant wife, who claims to be indigent, is not entitled to court-appointed free counsel pursuant to Family Court Act § 262 (a) (v) since that statute, which provides for the appointment of counsel for an indigent litigant who is "seeking custody or contesting the substantial infringement of his or her right to custody", applies only to Family Court proceedings and should not be extended to actions in Supreme Court in the absence of express legislative authorization. Qualification for court-appointed free legal counsel ordinarily requires a risk of personal liberty and there is no such risk involved in a civil dispute between a husband and wife over physical custody of their children. At this point in the litigation there is no credible evidence or proof demonstrating that existing remedies will not serve defendant if plaintiff were ordered to pay her counsel fees (see, Domestic Relations Law § 243 et seq.; see also, CPLR 5241, 5242). Moreover, defendant has not presented sufficient proof of plaintiff's and her own indigency to warrant referral of the custody issue to Family Court. Defendant's condition precedent to free representation in a Family Court custody proceeding is her establishment, by adequate proof, that she is unable to afford counsel, that plaintiff cannot afford to pay her counsel and that together they cannot afford her counsel fees. More than defendant's simple claim of indigency is required.

Husband and Wife - Divorce - Indigent Parent's Right to Free Counsel on Issue of Custody - Equal Protection

2. In an action for divorce and ancillary relief in which one of the issues in dispute is the custody of the parties' two young children, the failure of Supreme Court to provide defendant wife, who claims to be indigent, with court-appointed free counsel pursuant to Family Court Act § 262 (a) (v) because that statute only applies to child custody proceedings in Family Court does not violate defendant's equal protection rights. There is only one class with two forums and all persons in the class have access to both forums. Defendant cannot demonstrate that indigent custody litigants in Family Court are deprived of rights that they would have had in Supreme Court especially since, in referred cases (see, Family Ct Act § 467 [a]), Family Court exercises the same powers that Supreme Court possessed. No inference can be made that Family Court is not fully able to resolve child custody cases and that litigants in Family Court are relegated to Family Court simply because they are indigent. In addition, any distinction between Family Court indigent litigants and those in Supreme Court bears a rational relationship to a legitimate purpose and does not invidiously or arbitrarily discriminate against any class. The Legislature could have reasonably intended to restrict free legal counsel to Family Court in ancillary issues such as child custody because of the impracticality of providing counsel solely for custody purposes in complex matrimonial actions and the financial impact expanding free legal counsel would have. Supreme Court should not expand the right to free legal counsel and thereby increase public expenditures without explicit legislative authorization.

Husband and Wife - Divorce - Indigent Parent's Right to Free Counsel on Issue of Custody - Litigant's Right to "Free Access" to Court

3. In an action for divorce and ancillary relief in which one of the issues in dispute is the custody of the parties' two young children, the failure to provide defendant wife, who claims to be indigent, with court-appointed free counsel pursuant to Family Court Act § 262 (a) (v) does not violate defendant's right to "free access" to the court. However desirable or necessary, representation by counsel in a matrimonial action is not a legal condition to access to the courts. An indigent litigant does not have any constitutional or statutory right to free counsel in all civil actions, in all forums. Supreme Court is available to defendant if she wishes to act as her own counsel. Moreover, court-appointed free counsel is available to defendant in Family Court if defendant so desires and qualifies.

 

620 of 992 DOCUMENTS


People v. 610 Video Store, Inc.


Docket No. 98N050635Z


CRIMINAL COURT OF THE CITY OF NEW YORK, NEW YORK COUNTY


180 Misc. 2d 458; 689 N.Y.S.2d 609; 1999 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 158



March 15, 1999, Decided



DISPOSITION:  [***1] Granted defendants motion to dismiss without prejudice.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant filed a motion to dismiss the information filed against it for violating New York City, N.Y., Admin. Code § 26-126(a) and Zoning Resolution § 42-01(b). Defendant challenged the information as facially insufficient pursuant to N.Y. Crim. Proc. Law § 100.40(1)(c).


OVERVIEW: Defendant was charged by information with violations of New York City, N.Y., Admin. Code § 26-126(a) and Zoning Resolution § 42-01(b) (Resolution). The information alleged defendant was operating an adult establishment within 500 feet of a church. Admitting it was an adult establishment, defendant filed a motion to dismiss the information as facially insufficient under N.Y. Crim. Proc. Law 100.40(1)(c). The court granted the motion. The court found that the information properly pleaded that defendant operated an adult establishment, that the church identified was, in fact, a church, and that the subject church was located within 500 feet of defendant's establishment. The court determined, however, that the Resolution did not apply if the church was established on or after a specified date. The court concluded that the Resolution contained an exception to its own prohibited conduct, that the information should have alleged the offense by defendant was not within that exception, and that the failure to do so rendered the information insufficient on its face.


OUTCOME: The court dismissed the information against defendant, which alleged violation of a city zoning resolution that prohibited operating an adult establishment within 500 feet of a church. The court found that the information was facially insufficient for failing to allege the essential elements of the offense, which included an exception, because the information did not allege that defendant's offense was not within the exception.


HEADNOTES

Municipal Corporations - Zoning - Zoning Amendment Restricting Location of "Adult Establishment" - Sufficiency of Information Charging Zoning Violation

An information charging defendant with illegally operating an adult "sex shop" within 500 feet of a church in violation of New York City's Amended Zoning Resolution, which, effective October 25, 1995, prohibits the location of an "adult establishment" within 500 feet of a church, provided that the church has existed at the same location since April 10, 1995 (NY City Zoning Resolution § 42-01 [b]; Administrative Code of City of NY § 26-126), is dismissed for facial insufficiency pursuant to CPL 100.40 (1) (c) because of the failure to allege that the church existed in the subject location on or before April 10, 1995. Since the Amended Zoning Resolution does not classify the narrow exception to the 500-foot rule as a defense that the defendant must plead and prove, the date that the subject church was established at the location in question is a necessary element of the offense that must be alleged in the accusatory instrument. Consequently, in order to establish a prima facie case, the People must allege in the accusatory instrument that the violation is not within the exception, especially since the necessary information, whether the church was established on or before April 10, 1995, is not uniquely in defendant's possession. Accordingly, since the People have failed to assert all of the requisite elements of the zoning violation, defendant's motion to dismiss is granted without prejudice for the People to file a new information.

 

621 of 992 DOCUMENTS


Coleman v. Seldin


MOTION SEQ. NO.: 001, INDEX NO.: 30380-1997


SUPREME COURT OF NEW YORK, NASSAU COUNTY


181 Misc. 2d 219; 687 N.Y.S.2d 240; 1999 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 83



March 8, 1999, Decided


SUBSEQUENT HISTORY:  [***1] As Corrected October 4, 1999.



DISPOSITION: Defendants' motion for order dismissing complaint granted in part and denied in part.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendants, members of a board of assessors and a county, sought an order pursuant to N.Y. C.P.L.R. 3211 to dismiss plaintiff homeowners' complaint for racial discrimination in the determination of residential real property assessments.


OVERVIEW: Plaintiff homeowners sought declaratory and injunctive against defendants, members of the county board of assessors and the county. Plaintiffs contended that that defendant county maintained a racially discriminatory residential assessment system that had a disparate impact on minority homeowners. Action was brought alleging violations of Title VI of the Civil Rights Act of 1964, 42 U.S.C.S. § 2000d, Title VIII of the Civil Rights Act of 1968 (The Fair Housing Act), 42 U.S.C.S. § 3601, and the Nassau County, N.Y., Gov. Law § 603. Defendants' sought dismissal pursuant to N.Y.C.P.L.R. 3211. The motion was granted as to the claim under Title VI because defendant county's real property tax assessment program was not part of any federal financial assistance program. The motion was denied as to the Fair Housing Act claims because under that statute, plaintiffs were required only to allege discriminatory effect not discriminatory intent. The motion was denied as to the remaining count because plaintiffs made a sufficient showing to withstand the dismissal motion.


OUTCOME: The motion to dismiss plaintiff homeowners' discrimination complaint was granted in part because the real property assessment program that was being challenged was not a program receiving federal financial assistance. The motion to dismiss was denied in part because the complaint made sufficient allegations to survive a motion to dismiss on the remaining claims.


HEADNOTES

Taxation - Assessment - Assessment Method Challenged as Racially Discriminatory - Applicability of Civil Rights Act of 1964 Title VI

1. In an action for declaratory and injunctive relief against defendants Nassau County and its Board of Assessors in which plaintiff homeowners contend that the County maintains a racially discriminatory residential assessment system that impacts minority homeowners, defendants' motion to dismiss plaintiffs' cause of action for violations of title VI of the Civil Rights Act of 1964 (42 USC § 2000d) and its implementing regulations affecting housing (24 CFR 1.4) on the ground that the complaint does not allege that the County's real property tax assessment system is a Federally assisted program is denied. Nassau County is a proper defendant in the title VI action and the Board of Assessors and the real property assessment program administered by them are subject to title VI and its implementing regulations. Title VI prohibits "any program or activity receiving Federal financial assistance" (42 USC § 2000d) from discriminating on a racial basis, and it broadly defines "program or activity" as "all of the operations of" specific entities, including "a department, agency, special purpose district, or other instrumentality of a State or of a local government" (42 USC § 2000d-4a [1] [A]). Accordingly, where any part of an entity's operations is extended Federal financial assistance, all of that entity's operations are programs or activities and are subject to title VI.

Taxation - Assessment - Assessment Method Challenged as Racially Discriminatory - Violation of Civil Rights Act of 1964 Title VI - Necessity of Proof of Intentional Discrimination

2. In an action for declaratory and injunctive relief against defendants Nassau County and its Board of Assessors in which plaintiff homeowners contend that the County maintains a racially discriminatory residential assessment system that impacts minority homeowners, defendants' motion to dismiss plaintiffs' cause of action for violations of title VI of the Civil Rights Act of 1964 (42 USC § 2000d) and its implementing regulations affecting housing (24 CFR 1.4) on the ground that there is no proof of intentional discrimination is granted. Title VI prohibits only intentional discrimination, not actions that have a disparate impact upon minorities, although it does delegate the authority to promulgate regulations incorporating a disparate impact standard to Federal agencies. Plaintiffs, however, are not entitled to utilize the lower disparate impact standard in evaluating the County's alleged discriminatory practices relating to real property. No Federal agency administers any program of aid or financial assistance in support of real property assessment in the County, nor has any Federal agency promulgated any regulations relating to this function or that is otherwise connected to the County's real property assessment programs or policies. On its face the legislation was not intended to cover all discrimination, but rather that discrimination in any Federal financial assistance program.

Taxation - Assessment - Assessment Method Challenged as Racially Discriminatory - Prior Notice to County of Assessment Method's Disparate Impact

3. In an action for declaratory and injunctive relief against defendants Nassau County and its Board of Assessors in which plaintiff homeowners contend that the County maintains a racially discriminatory residential assessment system that impacts minority homeowners, the County is on notice that its current practice of assessment has or may have a disparate impact on minority communities. Beginning in 1964, litigation involving the County's method of assessment has shown that it may have a disparate impact, and has highlighted the inevitability of County-wide assessment. What in the past may have been viewed as "unintentional" discrimination may now fairly be considered intentional, and the County's continued failure to act in reliance on "unintentional" discriminatory results can no longer act as a shield for the County's practices.

Taxation - Assessment - Assessment Method Challenged as Racially Discriminatory - Standing to Maintain Action for Violation of Fair Housing Act

4. In an action for declaratory and injunctive relief against defendants Nassau County and its Board of Assessors in which plaintiff homeowners contend that the County maintains a racially discriminatory residential assessment system that impacts minority homeowners, defendants' motion to dismiss plaintiffs' cause of action for violations of the Fair Housing Act (42 USC § 3601 [FHA]) on the ground that the FHA, which addresses "Discrimination in the sale or rental of housing" (42 USC § 3604), cannot apply as plaintiffs already own their own homes is denied. Plaintiffs' allegations that the assessment system has an adverse discriminatory impact upon minority homeowners and inhibits their ability to own, buy, sell and rent dwellings and obtain mortgages, that this system of assessment has an impact on the community, and that governmental services and benefits are thus distributed in a discriminatory manner are sufficient to establish plaintiffs' standing as aggrieved persons under the FHA. The FHA applies to the real property assessment policies, procedures and conditions practiced and imposed by defendants.

Taxation - Assessment - Assessment Method Challenged as Racially Discriminatory - Violation of Fair Housing Act - Proof of Discriminatory Intent Not Necessary

5. In an action for declaratory and injunctive relief against defendants Nassau County and its Board of Assessors in which plaintiff homeowners contend that the County maintains a racially discriminatory residential assessment system that impacts minority homeowners, defendants' motion to dismiss plaintiffs' cause of action for violations of the Fair Housing Act (42 USC § 3601 [FHA]), which prohibits racial discrimination in the sale, rental or purchase of housing, on the ground that no intent to discriminate can be shown by plaintiffs is denied. A plaintiff stating a claim under the FHA need allege only discriminatory effect and need not show that the decision complained of was made with discriminatory intent.

Taxation - Assessment - Assessment Method Challenged as Racially Discriminatory - Violation of Nassau County Government Law § 603 - Exhaustion of Administrative Remedies Not Necessary

6. In an action for declaratory and injunctive relief against defendants Nassau County and its Board of Assessors in which plaintiff homeowners contend that the County maintains a racially discriminatory residential assessment system that impacts minority homeowners, defendants' motion to dismiss plaintiffs' cause of action for violations of Nassau County Government Law § 603, which requires an equitable and scientific system of assessing property for taxation, on the ground that plaintiffs have failed to exhaust their RPTL remedies is denied. While generally a taxpayer who challenges his property assessment is relegated to a tax certiorari proceeding brought under the provisions of RPTL article 7 for review of the assessment, one may forego this procedure and instead mount a collateral attack on the taxing authority's action if the challenge is to the assessment method.

Taxation - Assessment - Assessment Method Challenged as Racially Discriminatory - Violation of Nassau County Government Law § 603 - Sufficiency of Evidence

7. In an action for declaratory and injunctive relief against defendants Nassau County and its Board of Assessors in which plaintiff homeowners contend that the County maintains a racially discriminatory residential assessment system that impacts minority homeowners, defendants' motion to dismiss plaintiffs' cause of action for violations of Nassau County Government Law § 603, which requires an equitable and scientific system of assessing property for taxation, on the ground that it was previously determined that the County's method of assessment was not illegal or unconstitutional is denied. The data underlying the cause of action in that previous determination dates from 1989 and before, and a reexamination of the effects of the County's methodology is appropriate. The alleged disparity between the market value and assessed value of property in different County locations and the need to utilize equalization rates which are 3.17% County-wide but vary with the community seriously argue against either a scientific or equitable system of assessment determination. Defendants' attempt to realign disparate community property assessments established in 1938 and 1964 cannot be considered scientific when the underlying data may be so dated as to defy adjustment except on an individual basis, and no assessment system can be equitable if the community variations are substantial and the redress is confined to certiorari proceedings which are voluntary, must be commenced by individual taxpayers, invite substantial delays in reimbursement for overpayment, and necessarily require the payment of unreimbursed attorney's fees and costs.

 

622 of 992 DOCUMENTS


Masi Mgmt., Inc. v. Town of Ogden


Index No. 98/9877


SUPREME COURT OF NEW YORK, MONROE COUNTY


180 Misc. 2d 881; 691 N.Y.S.2d 706; 1999 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 140



February 25, 1999, Decided



DISPOSITION:  [***1] Plaintiff did not bring itself within the protection of either clause of the Constitution.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendants, town and its officials, filed a motion pursuant to N.Y. C.P.L.R. 3211(a)(7) to dismiss plaintiff contract-vendee's suit against them for failure to state a cause of action. Plaintiff filed suit against defendants under 42 U.S.C.S. § 1983 and the New York Constitution.


OVERVIEW: Plaintiff contract-vendee brought an action against defendants, town and its officials, which alleged that defendants intentionally delayed action on plaintiff's proposed development until they could obtain submission and approval of a competing project proposed by another developer who hired an attorney married to a town councilwoman. After defendants denied plaintiff's application, plaintiff filed a 42 U.S.C.S. § 1983 action alleging a deprivation of its constitutional rights and equal protection violations. The court rejected plaintiff's substantive due process claim, because plaintiff failed to establish that it was similarly situated to the developer whose proposal was accepted by defendants. Furthermore, plaintiff failed to establish the second element of an equal protection claim, which required that selective treatment be based on impermissible or discriminatory animus against plaintiff, or that plaintiff was maliciously singled out for disparate treatment because of the exercise of constitutional rights, or bad-faith intent to injure plaintiff.


OUTCOME: Defendant town and its officials' motion to dismiss plaintiff contract-vendee's complaint on the basis that it failed to state a cause of action was granted. Plaintiff failed to show that it was similarly situated to the other developer and that defendants intentionally or purposefully discriminated against it. Thus, plaintiff failed to state a violation of equal protection by selective enforcement claim.


HEADNOTES

Civil Rights - Federal Civil Rights Claim - Ripeness - Failure to Exhaust Administrative Remedies

1. In an action pursuant to 42 USC § 1983 in which plaintiff, a contract vendee of land in defendant municipality, alleges that defendants caused plaintiff to forego submitting a formal subdivision proposal for a two-family duplex project which would have been permitted under the local zoning code then in existence, and instead expend effort and money to secure subdivision approval of a different land use project that defendants never intended to approve, plaintiff has failed to state a cause of action for violation of its substantive due process rights. Plaintiff's claim that it has a substantive due process interest in the continued classification of the land as R-2 zoning in order to accommodate the original proposal to build two-family duplexes, despite the recent amendments to the zoning code which would not permit approval of the original proposal, is not ripe for review since plaintiff chose to forego submission of a duplex subdivision plan, thereby preventing final or even preliminary agency action. A failure to see the administrative process through a final decision renders a substantive due process claim not ripe for review.

Civil Rights - Federal Civil Rights Claim - Property Interest - Insufficient Claim of Entitlement

2. In an action pursuant to 42 USC § 1983 in which plaintiff, a contract vendee of land in defendant municipality, alleges that defendants caused plaintiff to forego submitting a formal subdivision proposal for a two-family duplex project which would have been permitted under the local zoning code then in existence, and instead expend effort and money to secure subdivision approval of a different land use project that defendants never intended to approve, plaintiff has failed to state a cause of action for violation of its substantive due process rights. Plaintiff's claim that it has a substantive due process interest in the continued classification of the land as R-2 zoning in order to accommodate the original proposal to build two-family duplexes, despite the recent amendments to the zoning code which would not permit approval of the original proposal, must fail because the original proposal was not simply for two-family duplexes permitted in R-2 districts. Rather, it called for a small portion of the duplex subdivision to be commercial in nature, and multiple family residential, which would have required variances or a rezoning of those minor portions, and the officials of defendant municipality have broad discretion to grant or deny a variance, which precludes a claim of entitlement sufficient to create a property interest cognizable under the substantive due process doctrine.

Civil Rights - Federal Civil Rights Claim - Property Interest - Insufficient Claim of Entitlement

3. In an action pursuant to 42 USC § 1983 in which plaintiff, a contract vendee of land in defendant municipality, alleges that defendants caused plaintiff to forego submitting a formal subdivision proposal for a two-family duplex project which would have been permitted under the local zoning code then in existence, and instead expend effort and money to secure subdivision approval of a different land use project that defendants never intended to approve, plaintiff has failed to state a cause of action for violation of its substantive due process rights. Plaintiff does not have a substantive due process interest in the continued classification of the land as R-2 zoning in order to accommodate the original proposal to build two-family duplexes, despite the recent amendments to the zoning code which would not permit approval of the original proposal, because plaintiff intended a major subdivision which would require Planning Board approval under the local zoning code. Under Town Law §§ 276 and 277, a planning board has wide discretion in approving or disapproving a subdivision plat, which precludes a claim of entitlement sufficient to create a property interest cognizable under the substantive due process doctrine.

Civil Rights - Federal Civil Rights Claim - Ripeness - Failure to Exhaust Administrative Remedies

4. In an action pursuant to 42 USC § 1983 in which plaintiff, a contract vendee of land in defendant municipality, alleges that defendants caused plaintiff to forego submitting a formal subdivision proposal for a two-family duplex project which would have been permitted under the local zoning code then in existence, and instead expend effort and money to secure subdivision approval of a subdivision proposal for a large-lot, single-family and patio-home project defendants told plaintiff they preferred but actually never intended to approve, plaintiff has failed to state a cause of action for violation of its substantive due process rights. Plaintiff's claim that it has a substantive due process interest in the continued favorable consideration of the large-lot, single-family and patio-home project and enactment of amendments to the local zoning code that would have been necessary to facilitate the project is not ripe for review since plaintiff did not pursue the proposal. Although plaintiff formally submitted the proposal, it did not make any effort to obtain a vote on it from defendants, and by abandoning the approval process, plaintiff prevented a final decision from the issuing agency. A substantive due process claim is not ripe for review absent the rendering of a final decision by the governmental entity.

Civil Rights - Federal Civil Rights Claim - Property Interest - Failure to Define Property Interest

5. In an action pursuant to 42 USC § 1983 in which plaintiff, a contract vendee of land in defendant municipality, alleges that defendants caused plaintiff to forego submitting a formal subdivision proposal for a two-family duplex project which would have been permitted under the local zoning code then in existence, and instead expend effort and money to secure subdivision approval of a subdivision proposal for a large-lot, single-family and patio-home project defendants told plaintiff they preferred but actually intended to reject in favor of a proposal presented by a locally favored developer, plaintiff has failed to state a cause of action for violation of its substantivedue process rights. Plaintiff's claim focuses on defendants' alleged arbitrary and capricious misleading conduct, without establishing or even recognizing whether a property interest is invoked in the first instance, and plaintiff cannot define a correlative property interest in a particular aspect of the application process, specifically, the give and take between an applicant and town officials in the context of a competing application from another developer.

Constitutional Law - Due Process of Law - Claim for Violation of Substantive Due Process Rights Entitled to No Broader Consideration under State Constitution

6. In an action brought pursuant to 42 USC § 1983 and under the New York Constitution in which plaintiff, a contract vendee of land in defendant municipality, alleges that defendants caused plaintiff to forego submitting a formal subdivision proposal for a two-family duplex project which would have been permitted under the local zoning code then in existence, and instead expend effort and money to secure subdivision approval of a subdivision proposal for a large-lot, single-family and patio-home project defendants told plaintiff they preferred but actually never intended to approve, plaintiff has failed to state a cause of action for violation of its substantive due process rights under the Federal Constitution and is entitled to no broader consideration under the State Constitution. Even if plaintiff may maintain such a constitutional tort action against local government officials, it has failed to demonstrate convincingly why a standard different from that provided by the Federal Constitution should be imposed as a matter of State constitutional law.

Civil Rights - Federal Civil Rights Claim - Equal Protection of Laws - Selective Enforcement

7. In an action pursuant to 42 USC § 1983 in which plaintiff, a contract vendee of land in defendant municipality, alleges that defendants caused plaintiff to forego submitting a formal subdivision proposal for a project which would have been permitted under the local zoning code then in existence, and instead expend effort and money to secure subdivision approval of a project defendants told plaintiff they preferred but actually intended to reject in favor of a proposal presented by a locally favored developer, plaintiff has failed to state a cause of action for violation of its equal protection rights. A violation of equal protection by selective enforcement arises if the person, compared with others similarly situated, was selectively treated and such selective treatment was based on impermissible considerations. Plaintiff, however, withdrew the second proposal, which took it out of the class of those who might be similarly situated to the competing developer.

Civil Rights - Federal Civil Rights Claim - Equal Protection of Laws - Selective Enforcement

8. In an action pursuant to 42 USC § 1983 in which plaintiff, a contract vendee of land in defendant municipality, alleges that defendants caused plaintiff to forego submitting a formal subdivision proposal for a two-family duplex project which would have been permitted under the local zoning code then in existence, and instead expend effort and money to secure subdivision approval of a subdivision proposal for a large-lot, single-family and patio-home project defendants told plaintiff they preferred but actually intended to reject in favor of a proposal for a senior citizen apartment complex coupled with patio homes presented by a locally favored developer, plaintiff has failed to state a cause of action for violation of its equal protection rights. A violation of equal protection by selective enforcement arises if the person, compared with others similarly situated, was selectively treated and such selective treatment was based on impermissible considerations. Where governmental actors are given statutory discretion, as defendants were, the applicable test is that, within the limits of the discretion conferred, the targets of regulation are similarly situated when their circumstances present no distinguishable legitimate prosecutorial or regulatory factors that might justify making different prosecutorial or regulatory decisions with respect to them. Plaintiff and the competing developer were not similarly situated because their proposals do not meet any conceivable test of similarity.

Civil Rights - Federal Civil Rights Claim - Equal Protection of Laws - Bad-Faith Intent to Injure Plaintiff

9. In an action pursuant to 42 USC § 1983 in which plaintiff, a contract vendee of land in defendant municipality, alleges that defendants caused plaintiff to forego submitting a formal subdivision proposal for a two-family duplex project which would have been permitted under the local zoning code then in existence, and instead expend effort and money to secure subdivision approval of a subdivision proposal for a large-lot, single-family and patio-home project defendants told plaintiff they preferred but actually intended to reject in favor of a proposal for a senior citizen apartment complex coupled with patio homes presented by a locally favored developer, plaintiff has failed to state a cause of action for violation of its equal protection rights. A violation of equal protection by selective enforcement arises if the person, compared with others similarly situated, was selectively treated and such selective treatment was based on impermissible considerations. Plaintiff does not allege selective treatment based on cognizable group factors or that any selective treatment resulted from an intentional effort by defendants to punish it for exercising its constitutional rights, but rather that defendants had a bad-faith intent to injure plaintiff. However, political motivation of the kind alleged by plaintiff, that defendants preferred the locally favored developer whose attorney is the husband of a defendant Town Council member, does not establish malice within the rule of bad-faith or malicious intent to injure.

 

623 of 992 DOCUMENTS


Slattery v. City of New York


Index No.: 113307/98


SUPREME COURT OF NEW YORK, NEW YORK COUNTY


179 Misc. 2d 740; 686 N.Y.S.2d 683; 1999 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 35



February 8, 1999, Decided



DISPOSITION:  [***1] Complaint dismissed, plaintiff's motion for preliminary injunction denied, cross-motion to dismiss granted.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff property holders challenged the validity of New York, N.Y. Local Law No. 27 (1998), the Domestic Partners Law, which extended insurance and other benefits to domestic partners of city employees, on the grounds that defendants city and mayor acted illegally and unconstitutionally by legislating in the area of marriage and domestic relations, and asked the court to permanently enjoin defendants from implementing the law.


OVERVIEW: Defendants city and mayor codified N.Y. Local Law 27 (1998), which extended health, retirement, and other benefits to the domestic partners of city employees. Plaintiff property holders and taxpayers challenged the law, asserting that defendants impermissibly legislated in the area of marriage and improperly utilized their legislative powers. Dismissing the complaint, the court distinguished domestic partnerships from marriage and concluded that under N.Y. Gen. City Law § 20, defendants were authorized to extend health and retirement benefits to the domestic partners of city employees under a flexible definition of the term "family". The court also held that the power to determine the salaries and benefits of city employees was specifically conferred upon local governments by N.Y. Const. art. IX, § 2, the "home rule" article. The court concluded that the challenged provision did not exceed the city's statutory and constitutional authority, and was neither irrational nor inconsistent with state law, and dismissed plaintiff's complaint.


OUTCOME: The court dismissed plaintiffs' complaint by granting defendant city's cross-motion to dismiss, and denied plaintiffs' motion for a preliminary injunction, holding that in enacting the Domestic Partners Law, defendant did not impermissibly legislate in the area of marriage and properly utilized its legislative powers.


HEADNOTES

Landlord and Tenant - Rent Regulation - Succession and Occupancy Rights of Registered Domestic Partners of City Employees

1. Local Laws, 1998, No. 27 of the City of New York validly qualifies a City employee's registered domestic partner, who is a tenant in a building operated by the New York City Housing Authority or a tenant or cooperative resident in a building under the jurisdiction of the Department of Housing Preservation and Development, as a family member for the purpose of succession and occupancy rights. The Local Law reiterates State law as expressed in Braschi v Stahl Assocs. Co. (74 NY2d 201) and the relevant State regulations (9 NYCRR 1727-8.2, 2104.6, 2204.6) and, thus, is not only consistent with, but patterned after State law.

Municipal Corporations - Home Rule Powers - Extending Health and Retirement Benefits to Domestic Partners of City Employees

2. Local Laws, 1998, No. 27 of the City of New York, which entitles registered domestic partners of current and retired City employees to certain medical, health and retirement benefits, is not impermissible legislation in the area of marriage and domestic relations, which is under the exclusive jurisdiction of the State Legislature, since a domestic partnership is different in many respects from a marriage. A domestic partnership is marked by a lack of formalization, lack of legal protections and by significantly fewer rights extended to the domestic partners. Parties register as domestic partners by executing an affidavit of domestic partnership and the partnership terminates either automatically upon marriage of one or both of the parties or by filing a termination statement. No grounds for termination need be specified and no further procedures are required to effectuate termination. The formal requirements regulating marriages are far more stringent. Several prerequisites to marriage must be satisfied, the marriage license is far more detailed and a marriage must be solemnized. Once people enter into marriage, they acquire certain rights and responsibilities with respect to their spouses and receive financial rights relating to their spouse's properties. Upon the death of a spouse, the surviving marital partner has rights relating to the estate and wrongful death actions which are unavailable to a domestic partner. Further, upon and after termination of a marriage, a marital partner retains substantial protections unavailable to the domestic partner.

Municipal Corporations - Home Rule Powers - Extending Medical and Insurance Benefits to Domestic Partners of Current City Employees

3. Defendants City and Mayor did not exceed their statutory or constitutional authority when enacting Local Laws, 1998, No. 27 of the City of New York, which entitles a registered domestic partner of a current City employee to certain medical and health insurance benefits. General City Law § 20 (29) authorizes defendants to furnish medical benefits to current City employees "and their families". The term "families" is not restricted to those who have formalized their relationship by obtaining a marriage certificate or an adoption order. The term should be interpreted to protect those who reside in households having all of the normal familiar characteristics of a family, and often refers to such persons as habitually reside under one roof and form one domestic circle, or such persons as are dependent on each other for support or among whom there is a legal or equitable obligation to furnish support.

Municipal Corporations - Home Rule Powers - Extending Medical and Insurance Benefits to Domestic Partners of Retired City Employees

4. Defendants City and Mayor did not exceed their statutory or constitutional authority when enacting Local Laws, 1998, No. 27 of the City of New York, which entitles a registered domestic partner of a retired City employee to certain medical, health and retirement benefits. The power to determine the salary of employees is specifically conferred upon local governments (NY Const, art IX, § 2). In light of the broad grant of power given to local governments in this area, the courts should not intervene absent an absolute conflict with statutory or constitutional authority. Benefits authorized under Local Law 27 are encompassed within the definition of salary. In turn, health insurance benefits are a form of compensation encompassed within the definition of terms and conditions of employment. Although General City Law § 20 (29-b) provides for reimbursement of medical-related charges incurred by retired officers and their spouses, General Municipal Law § 92-a (2) describes the power to offer medical and related services or insurance to retired employees and their families. Because the General Municipal Law is more broadly worded, creating some ambiguity regarding legislative intent, there is no clear conflict and the City interpretation should be given force. Furthermore, the use of the words "dependent children" and "spouse" in describing death benefits (General City Law § 20 [29-a]) does not necessarily evince an intent to exclude domestic partners from coverage. It is not unreasonable for defendants to interpret the law in a fashion that allows them to keep pace with the societal and legislative trend of giving greater rights and recognition to unmarried domestic partners and nontraditional family units in general.

 

624 of 992 DOCUMENTS


United Communs. Corp. v. 1st Tee, Inc.


Civil Index # 15172


CITY COURT OF NEW YORK, WATERTOWN


179 Misc. 2d 896; 686 N.Y.S.2d 679; 1999 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 71



February 4, 1999, Decided



DISPOSITION:  [***1] The Court rules that the New York State Constitution Article 6, 1(c) prohibits physical service of a Watertown City Court process outside Jefferson, St. Lawrence, Lewis or Oswego counties and that Business Corporation Law Section 306(c) "an ordinary act of the legislature" (Bischoff) cannot circumvent the territorial boundaries set by the Constitution.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: The court raised, sua sponte, the question of whether jurisdiction had been obtained over defendant pursuant to service of process authorized by N.Y. Bus. Corp. Law § 306(c), in light of N.Y. Const. art. VI, § 1(c), which defined the territorial limits within which process could be served.


OVERVIEW: The court held that N.Y. Bus. Corp. Law § 306(c), which authorized service of process upon the secretary of state, did not confer jurisdiction over defendant, and sua sponte dismissed plaintiff's complaint. The court stated that N.Y. Const. art. VI, § 1(c), restricted the court's jurisdiction by defining the territorial limits within which a city court process could be served for city courts outside New York City, and held that § 306(c) could not nullify that. The court stated that art. VI, § 1(c), limited service of process from the city courts other than the city courts of New York City to any part of the county in which such courts were located or in any part of any adjoining county. The court held that its jurisdiction could not be enlarged by a mere act of the legislature, such as § 306(c), but only by a constitutional amendment. Thus the court held that § 306(c), which for actions in courts of limited jurisdiction authorized service on the secretary of state if the office of defendant corporation was in the county in which such court was located, was unconstitutional and ineffective to confer jurisdiction over defendant in this matter.


OUTCOME: The court, sua sponte, dismissed plaintiff's complaint. The court held that it lacked jurisdiction over defendant, because plaintiff had made service of process on defendant in a manner which, although authorized by the legislature, contravened the court's constitutionally limited jurisdiction.


HEADNOTES

Process - Service on Secretary of State - Territorial Limit of Service of Process of City Court Outside New York City

Service of process upon the Secretary of State in Albany pursuant to Business Corporation Law § 306 (c) does not confer jurisdiction over defendant corporation in Watertown City Court as such service violates the constitutional limits of New York State Constitution, article VI, § 1 (c), which states that "processes ... of ... city courts outside the city of New York may be served and executed in any part of the county in which such courts are located or in any part of any adjoining county". The Legislature knew of Business Corporation Law § 306 (c) when drafting and submitting to the voters an amendment to the Constitution enacting article VI, § 1 (c) to expand to State-wide the territory within which the process of New York City Civil Courts and District Courts could be served while leaving the City Courts outside the City of New York with the territorial limits of their home or adjoining county. Exclusion of State-wide jurisdiction for City Courts outside New York City was not a legislative oversight but rather an indication that the exclusion was intended. Physical service of a Watertown City Court process is limited to Jefferson County or an adjoining county, and Business Corporation Law § 306 (c) cannot circumvent the territorial boundaries set by the Constitution.

 

625 of 992 DOCUMENTS


In re Travis S.


99-061


FAMILY COURT OF NEW YORK, KINGS COUNTY


180 Misc. 2d 234; 685 N.Y.S.2d 886; 1999 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 18



January 27, 1999, Decided


SUBSEQUENT HISTORY:  [***1] As Corrected June 14, 1999.



DISPOSITION: Motion to dismiss the petition is denied.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant filed a motion to dismiss the petition charging him with false personation in violation of N.Y. Penal Law § 190.23, arguing that the statute was unconstitutionally vague and asserting he was not given adequate warnings as required by the statute and Miranda.


OVERVIEW: Defendant was charged with false personation in violation of N.Y. Penal Law § 190.23. Defendant moved to dismiss the petition on grounds that the statute was unconstitutionally vague. Defendant also argued that he was not given sufficient warnings of the consequences of giving false information. The court held that the statute was not unconstitutionally vague. Because an element of the crime was a police warning of the conduct forbidden by the statute, and the warning given to defendant sufficiently notified him of prohibited conduct, the statute was definite. The court held that Miranda warnings were not required because the biographical questions posed to defendant were reasonably related to administrative functions and did not pertain to the police investigation into the crime for which defendant was arrested. No crime was committed until after the statutory warning had been given and defendant gave another false answer. Because formal Miranda warnings were not required and the warnings given by the police officer to defendant were sufficient to put defendant on notice of the consequences of giving false pedigree information, defendant's motion to dismiss was denied.


OUTCOME: Defendant's motion to dismiss was denied because defendant was given sufficient statutory warning of the consequences of giving false pedigree information to the police officer and Miranda warnings were not required because the false information was given during routine booking questions. The court entered a conviction because the elements of false personation were proven beyond a reasonable doubt.


HEADNOTES

Crimes - False Personation - Miranda Warnings - Statutory Warnings

In a juvenile delinquency proceeding, respondent's motion to dismiss the petition charging him with false personation (Penal Law § 190.23) is denied where respondent was arrested when a police officer suspected that he was too young to be driving an automobile, and was charged with false personation after the officer informed him that he could be liable for that crime, yet he persisted in giving the officer inaccurate pedigree information. The officer satisfied the statutory warning requirement that a person be told of "the consequences" of knowingly misrepresenting pedigree information to a police officer, by informing respondent that if he did not tell her his correct name, address and date of birth, he could be charged with false personation in addition to the crime for which he was arrested. The officer was not required to give respondent the Miranda warnings, since the officer's biographical questions were confined to basic identification information, did not exceed the scope of Miranda's "pedigree exception," were reasonably related to the performance of administrative duties connected with law enforcement, and did not pertain to her investigation of the crime for which respondent was initially arrested. The warning the officer gave was not for the purpose of entrapping respondent into committing a crime or to induce him to perpetuate the lie she suspected he told; rather, it was for the purpose of preventing him from doing so. The pedigree questions do not lose their administrative character and become investigatory unless a crime has been committed and the answers are pertinent to culpability. Moreover, the exclusionary rule does not protect individuals from their own independent acts involving a calculated risk.

 

626 of 992 DOCUMENTS


People v. Medina


Docket No.98CO010798


CRIMINAL COURT OF THE CITY OF NEW YORK, NEW YORK COUNTY


179 Misc. 2d 617; 685 N.Y.S.2d 599; 1999 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 15



January 26, 1999, Decided



DISPOSITION:  [***1] The motion to dismiss is denied.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant filed a motion to dismiss the information that charged him with misdemeanor prostitution under N.Y. Penal Law § 230.00, arguing it did not contain nonhearsay allegations that established every element of the offense.


OVERVIEW: Defendant was charged with misdemeanor prostitution under N.Y. Penal Law § 230.00. Defendant filed a motion to dismiss the information, arguing that it was legally insufficient because it did not contain nonhearsay allegations that proved every element of the offense. Defendant contended that the information did not establish that he agreed to engage in sexual conduct for a fee; the information alleged that defendant agreed to engage in sexual intercourse for a fee, but defendant argued that it was legally and factually impossible for two males to engage in sexual intercourse. After reviewing the legislative history and intent behind N.Y. Penal Law § 230.00, as well as the meaning of the terms used in the statute, the court determined that "sexual intercourse" implied heterosexual or homosexual activities. Thus, the court held that the allegation that defendant agreed to engage in sexual intercourse with a male undercover police officer was sufficient to establish that he agreed to engage in sexual conduct. Because the information contained facts that sufficiently established all elements of the offense, defendant's motion was denied.


OUTCOME: Defendant's motion to dismiss the indictment was denied because the nonhearsay allegations established that defendant agreed to engage in sexual conduct for a fee. Though the information alleged that defendant agreed to engage in sexual intercourse with a male, sexual intercourse implied homosexual activities and thus constituted sexual conduct under the statute.


HEADNOTES

Crimes - Prostitution - Sex Act between Members of Same Sex

In a prostitution prosecution, the allegation in the information that the defendant, a male, agreed to engage in "sexual intercourse" for a fee with another male adequately pleads that the defendant agreed to perform a sex act with another person which constitutes sexual conduct within the meaning of Penal Law § 230.00. Pursuant to Penal Law § 230.00 a person is guilty of prostitution "when such person engages or agrees or offers to engage in sexual conduct with another person in return for a fee". Although "sexual conduct" is an element of this offense and all other prostitution-related offenses contained in Penal Law article 230, the term is not defined in the article, and in the absence of an explicit definition the statute must be interpreted in a manner that comports with its purpose. Penal Law article 230 represents a legislative decision to regulate the commercialism of sex, whether heterosexual or homosexual, and Penal Law § 230.10 specifically provides that it is no defense to a prostitution prosecution that the two parties to the sexual conduct are of the same sex. Moreover, "sexual intercourse" has been interpreted broadly to encompass both homosexual and heterosexual activity.

 

627 of 992 DOCUMENTS


People v. Van Dyne


Ind. No. 97-0736


COUNTY COURT OF NEW YORK, MONROE COUNTY


179 Misc. 2d 467; 685 N.Y.S.2d 591; 1999 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 11



January 20, 1999, Decided


SUBSEQUENT HISTORY: Reversed by, Remitted by People v. Van Dyne, 2004 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 13945 (N.Y. App. Div. 4th Dep't, Nov. 19, 2004)


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant moved the court to accept his guilty plea to murder in the first degree. The prosecution moved to withdraw its notice of intent to seek the death penalty and recommend a life sentence for defendant without the possibility of parole.


OVERVIEW: Pursuant to a plea agreement, defendant wanted to withdraw his not guilty plea and admit that he committed murder in the first degree. The prosecution sought to withdraw its notice of intent to seek the death penalty and recommend that defendant receive a life sentence without the possibility of parole. The court accepted defendant's guilty plea because defendant knowingly, intelligently, and voluntarily entered such plea. Under N.Y. Crim. Proc. Law § 220.60(2)(a), defendant could plead guilty when there was no notice of intent to seek the death penalty pending. Because the prosecution withdrew its notice, defendant could enter his plea. Even though defendant's plea was entered to avoid facing the death penalty, it was voluntarily entered.


OUTCOME: The court accepted defendant's guilty plea because he entered such plea knowingly, intelligently, and voluntarily after the prosecution withdrew its notice of intent to seek the death penalty.


HEADNOTES

Crimes - Murder - Capital Murder - Plea of Guilty upon Withdrawal of Notice of Intent to Seek Death Penalty

In a capital murder case, the court may accept a plea agreement in which the District Attorney withdrew the notice of intent to seek the death penalty upon defendant's agreement to enter a plea of guilty, waive his right to appeal and receive a sentence of life imprisonment without parole. The plea entered by the represented defendant was based upon a knowing, intelligent and voluntary waiver of rights and is consistent with Matter of Hynes v Tomei (92 NY2d 613), which rendered certain plea provisions of the Death Penalty Law unconstitutional under circumstances where a defendant seeks to enter a plea of guilty while a notice of intent to seek the death penalty is pending, but left intact the plea provision which permits a defendant, with both the permission of the court and the consent of the People, to withdraw a not guilty plea and enter a plea of guilty ( CPL 220.60 [2] [a]). Defendant sought the court's acceptance of the guilty plea immediately after the withdrawal of the notice of intent to seek the death penalty and has set forth other valid reasons for the withdrawal of his not guilty plea, including genuine remorse, sparing the families a trial, the strength of evidence against him and a desire to avoid the death penalty.

 

628 of 992 DOCUMENTS


Silver v. Pataki


Index No. 110553/98


SUPREME COURT OF NEW YORK, NEW YORK COUNTY


179 Misc. 2d 315; 684 N.Y.S.2d 858; 1999 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 2



January 7, 1999, Decided



DISPOSITION:  [***1] Motion to dismiss the action or, in the alternative, to transfer venue to Albany County, is denied in all respects. Cross-motion of plaintiff for summary judgment pursuant to CPLR 3211(c) is held in abeyance and adjourned to February 19. Defendant granted until January 29 to serve an answer to the complaint and to the motion for summary judgment and to serve any cross-motion.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Pursuant to N.Y. C.P.L.R. 3211(a)(2), (3), defendant governor filed a motion to dismiss plaintiff speaker's action claiming that plaintiff speaker lacked standing to challenge defendant governor's use of the line-item veto. In the alternative, defendant sought to transfer venue. Plaintiff filed a cross motion to convert defendant's motion to one for summary judgment in plaintiff's favor.


OVERVIEW: Plaintiff filed this action as a member and speaker of the New York state assembly and asserted that defendant governor had no constitutional right to veto items in non-appropriation bills and that such bills were required to be either approved or vetoed in their entirety. Plaintiff sought a declaration that defendant's use of the line-item veto in 55 instances violated N.Y. Const. art. IV, § 7 and that legislation relating to the executive budget was not subject to defendant's line-item veto power where the legislation did not appropriate money. Defendant filed a motion to dismiss pursuant to N.Y. C.P.L.R. 3211 (a)(2), (3) and claimed that plaintiff lacked standing to bring the action. Plaintiff filed a cross-motion to convert defendant's motion to one for summary judgment in his favor. The court denied defendant's motion to dismiss because plaintiff was an appropriate party to present the question of legality of defendant's use of the line-item veto to the court. Defendant failed to set forth a valid basis to transfer venue. Plaintiff's motion was held in abeyance.


OUTCOME: The court denied defendant governor's motion to dismiss and also denied defendant's alternative request to transfer venue. The court held that plaintiff speaker was an appropriate party to uphold the acts of the legislature against a claimed unconstitutional employment of the veto power. The court held in abeyance plaintiff's cross-motion for summary judgment.


HEADNOTES

Parties - Standing - Action by Member and Speaker of Assembly Challenging Governor's Line-Item Vetoes in Non-Appropriation Bills

1. Plaintiff member and Speaker of the New York State Assembly has standing in his official capacity to challenge the Governor's line-item vetoes in non-appropriation bills as unconstitutional. Plaintiff is not seeking to obtain a result in a courtroom which he failed to gain in the halls of the Legislature, but rather seeks to uphold the acts of the Legislature against a claimed unconstitutional employment of veto power. There has been a loosening of standing restrictions, particularly where a failure to permit standing could construct an insurmountable wall against judicial review of a challenged act. Many of the vetoes would neither provide a basis for litigation in a taxpayer suit nor grounds for a plaintiff to show that he or she is aggrieved. Moreover, the legal issue as to the propriety of the Governor's actions is novel, and a member of the Legislature, particularly the Speaker, is an appropriate party to present the question.

Parties - Capacity to Sue - Action by Member and Speaker of Assembly Challenging Governor's Line-Item Vetoes in Non-Appropriation Bills

2. Plaintiff member and Speaker of the New York State Assembly has the capacity to challenge the Governor's line-item vetoes in non-appropriation bills as unconstitutional. Capacity to sue concerns a litigant's power to appear and bring its grievance before the court.

Trial - Place of Trial - Demand for Change of Venue - Action by Member and Speaker of Assembly Challenging Governor's Line-Item Vetoes in Non-Appropriation Bills

3. Venue of an action by plaintiff, in his official capacity as a member and Speaker of the New York State Assembly, challenging the Governor's line-item vetoes in non-appropriation bills was appropriately placed where plaintiff resides, in New York County. There is no claim of inconvenience to any witnesses to support a change of venue to Albany County, and no CPLR venue provision applicable to the Governor, who maintains a principal office in New York County.

 

629 of 992 DOCUMENTS


People v. Diaz


Indictment: 2134/86, Motion: CPL. § 440.20


SUPREME COURT OF NEW YORK, NEW YORK COUNTY


179 Misc. 2d 946; 686 N.Y.S.2d 595; 1999 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 59



January 7, 1999, Decided



DISPOSITION:  [***1] Defendant's motion setting aside his sentence is granted, and he is resentenced to ten years to life.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant filed a motion to set aside his sentence of 15 years to life for criminal possession of a controlled substance after having served 11 years with an exemplary prison record. Defendant claimed that his sentence was grossly disproportionate and it constituted cruel and unusual punishment given the disparate treatment of his codefendant, defendant's lack of a prior criminal record, and defendant's low risk of danger to society.


OVERVIEW: Defendant was convicted of criminal possession of a controlled substance and criminal possession of a weapon. Defendant was sentenced to 15 years to life on the narcotics conviction. Having served 11 years with an exemplary prison record, defendant filed a motion to set aside his sentence on the ground that his sentence constituted cruel and unusual punishment. The test to determine whether defendant's sentence constituted cruel and unusual punishment focused on the gravity of the offense, the character of the offender, and the danger the offender posed to society. The court found that both of defendant's offenses were serious. However, the court considered defendant's young age at the time of the offense, the absence of an arrest record, defendant's family circumstances, and the fact that defendant did not engage in the sale of drugs. The court also found that defendant posed little risk of danger to society because defendant was subject to deportation to the Dominican Republic upon his release. The court granted defendant's motion to set aside his sentence and held that defendant's original sentence was grossly disproportionate and constituted cruel and unusual punishment.


OUTCOME: The court granted defendant's motion and set aside his sentence because his original sentence was grossly disproportionate as applied to him. The court found that defendant's sentence was constitutionally prohibited as cruel and unusual punishment given the disparate treatment of the codefendant, the nature of the offense, and the lack of physical violence. The court resentenced defendant to 10 years to life.


HEADNOTES

Crimes - Sentence - Cruel and Unusual Punishment

A defendant's continued incarceration under a 15-year-to-life sentence, upon a conviction for criminal possession of a controlled substance in the first degree and criminal possession of a weapon in the third degree, constitutes a violation of his constitutional right against cruel and unusual punishment under the Broadie rare case exception (see, People v Broadie, 37 NY2d 100). A grossly disproportionate sentence constitutes cruel and unusual punishment. The imposition of cruel and unusual punishment renders a sentence unconstitutional, and thus illegally imposed, and a court may set aside a sentence upon the ground that it was illegally imposed ( CPL 440.20). The factors in determining whether a sentence constitutes cruel and unusual punishment include the gravity of offense, the character of the offender and the danger the offender poses to society. Although the charges are serious, defendant's rehabilitation during the last 11 years of incarceration, as evidenced by numerous certificates and achievement awards, is genuine. Defendant is not a career criminal, there is no evidence that he was an integral part of a drug ring and he did not sell drugs, or physically commit violent acts. Defendant's character and the circumstances of his offense show little risk of danger to society, especially since he will be deported to the Dominican Republic upon release. Also, the comparative treatment of codefendants may be weighed as a factor in determining gross disproportionality and the outcomes here are extreme and disproportionate in that on previous appeals the case against a codefendant charged with the exact same crimes was dismissed. Further, although the changing view on the Rockefeller drug laws is not a factor, society's perception of justice is relevant and citizens have the right to expect judicial outcomes to be reasonable and uniform.

 

630 of 992 DOCUMENTS


People v. Edinger


Index No. LB65089 and LB64354


CITY COURT OF NEW YORK, LONG BEACH


179 Misc. 2d 104; 683 N.Y.S.2d 820; 1998 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 618



December 4, 1998, Decided



DISPOSITION:  [***1] The other objection raised by the Defendants are moot. Both Defendants' motions to dismiss are granted.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendants brought a motion for dismissal of the charges of using a leaf blower a violation of Long Beach, N. Y., Mun. Code of Ordinances § 23-8(b) (1994) on the grounds that the information was defective and the statute defining the offense was unconstitutional on its face and application.


OVERVIEW: Defendants were charged with violating Long Beach, N. Y., Mun. Code of Ordinances § 23-8(b) (1994), which prohibited the use of power blowers. Defendants were charged with using a leaf blower. Defendants brought a motion for dismissal under N. Y. Crim. Proc. Law §§ 170.30(1)(a), 170.35(1)(c), upon the grounds that the information was defective and the statute defining the offense charged was unconstitutional on its face and in its application.
