The court granted defendants' motion, finding that the state under its police power could have established regulations designed to preserve the public health, safety, and morals, or to promote the general welfare. There was no showing that the ordinance achieved, promoted, or addressed any valid purpose or objective, but was merely a complete prohibition. Therefore, the court found that Long Beach, N. Y., Mun. Code of Ordinances § 23-8(b) (1994) was unconstitutional.


OUTCOME: The court dismissed the charges of using a leaf blower against defendants. The court found that the ordinance prohibiting the use of power blowers was unconstitutional because there was no rational basis for the legislation and the legislation was not to achieve, promote, or address any valid purpose or objective.


HEADNOTES

Constitutional Law - Validity of Statute - Prohibition on Use of Leaf Blowers

A municipal ordinance absolutely prohibiting the use of leaf or power blowers is unconstitutional where the sole reason given for enacting the ordinance was a mere comment that power blowers were jamming the sewers, since no facts support the ordinance and there is no reasonable relationship between this ordinance and the protection of the health, safety, morals, or welfare of the people of the municipality. Although courts may not substitute their judgment for that of a legislative body, no showing has been made by the municipality that the enactment of the ordinance in question was to achieve, promote or address any valid purpose or objective. Accordingly, the motions of defendants to dismiss informations charging them with violating the ordinance are granted.

 

631 of 992 DOCUMENTS


People v. Koertge


Docket No. 022840/98


DISTRICT COURT OF NEW YORK, NASSAU COUNTY


182 Misc. 2d 183; 701 N.Y.S.2d 588; 1998 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 708



December 4, 1998, Decided



DISPOSITION:  [***1] Denied.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Criminal defendant filed a motion challenging the constitutionality of N.Y. Crim. Proc. Law §§ 530.12 and 530.13, and argued that the failure of these statutes to provide for an adversarial evidentiary hearing at defendant's request before a temporary order of protection was issued or continued deprived defendant and others similarly situated of due process guarantees of U.S. Const. amends. V and XIV and N.Y. Const. art. I, § 6.


OVERVIEW: Criminal defendant was arraigned on a single count of aggravated harassment in the second degree and the court issued two separate stay-away orders protecting four named individuals. Defendant requested a hearing to test the legality of the orders. The People withdrew their prior consent and objected to holding the hearing, arguing that defendant did not have a right to an evidentiary hearing solely at his request. The court first held that the issuance of the protection orders sufficiently impacted defendant's liberty or property interests so as to trigger due process protection and analysis. Applying procedural due process analysis, the court determined that N.Y. Crim. Proc. Law §§ 530.12 and 530.13 were constitutional as written and held that defendant did not have the right to an evidentiary hearing to contest the continuance of the temporary orders based on the unconstitutionality of the statutes.


OUTCOME: The court denied criminal defendant's motion on the basis that the statutes in question were constitutional as written and violated neither the United States nor the New York Constitutions and because defendant offered nothing to show that the statute as applied to him was unconstitutional.


HEADNOTES

Crimes - Order of Protection - Constitutionality of Statutes Authorizing Issuance of Temporary Order of Protection without Hearing - Standing

1. In a prosecution for second degree aggravated harassment where the court issued two separate nonfamily offense orders of protection pursuant to CPL 530.13 requiring defendant to stay away from four named individuals, defendant has standing to challenge, as unconstitutional, the failure of CPL 530.12 (orders of protection for family offenses) and 530.13 (orders of protection for nonfamily offenses) to provide for an adversarial hearing at defendant's request before a temporary order of protection is issued or continued. CPL 530.12 and 530.13 sufficiently impact liberty or property interests so as to trigger due process protection and analysis in that they can impact upon a defendant's right to use and enjoy a domicile, a defendant's relations with persons neither witnesses nor victims of the crimes alleged, and any license to carry, possess, repair or sell firearms, which in turn may significantly impact on a defendant's legitimate professional or business pursuits.

Crimes - Order of Protection - Constitutionality of Statutes Authorizing Issuance of Temporary Order of Protection without Hearing

2. The failure of CPL 530.12 and 530.13 to provide for an adversarial hearing at a defendant's request before a temporary order of protection is issued or continued does not deprive the defendant of the due process guarantees of the 5th and 14th Amendments to the United States Constitution and article I, § 6 of the New York Constitution. The Legislature's intent in enacting CPL 530.12 and 530.13 was not to punish the subject of the temporary order of protection, but rather to protect the victims of domestic violence and victims and witnesses of crimes and their families. The State has a legitimate and significant interest in doing so and the statutes in question are reasonably related to these lawful and proper objectives. Moreover, the procedures available to a defendant who is the subject of the temporary orders of protection issued pursuant to these statutes are more than adequate to protect against an erroneous temporary deprivation of a liberty or a property interest.

 

632 of 992 DOCUMENTS


People v. Ortiz


INDICTMENT #:6665/97


SUPREME COURT OF NEW YORK, BRONX COUNTY


180 Misc. 2d 783; 691 N.Y.S.2d 683; 1998 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 688



November 18, 1998, Decided


SUBSEQUENT HISTORY:  [***1] As Corrected June 14, 1999.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant was convicted of attempted assault in the second degree by the Trial Court (New York). The court conducted a hearing to determine whether defendant should have been adjudicated a persistent felony offender under N.Y. Penal Law § 70.10.


OVERVIEW: Defendant was convicted of attempted assault in the second degree. The court adjudicated defendant a persistent felony offender under N.Y. Penal Law § 70.10, and sentenced him to 15 years imprisonment to life. The court ruled that the history and character of defendant and the nature and circumstances of his criminal conduct were such that extended incarceration and lifetime supervision was necessary to best serve and protect the public interest. The court held that defendant's criminal history demonstrated that he had been a menace to society for many years and remained so.


OUTCOME: The court adjudicated defendant a persistent felony offender and sentenced him to a term of 15 years to life. The court concluded that the character of defendant and the nature of his criminal conduct were such that extended incarceration and supervision were necessary to protect the public.


HEADNOTES

Crimes - Sentence - Persistent Felony Offender - Crime in Another Jurisdiction as Previous Felony Conviction

1. For purposes of determining whether defendant should be adjudicated a persistent felony offender pursuant to Penal Law § 70.10 for having been previously convicted of a felony in New York and a felony in California in addition to the felony he presently stands convicted of, defendant's conviction for burglary in California, for which he was sentenced to two years, can serve as a predicate for persistent felony offender status regardless of whether the California burglary would constitute a felony in New York. Penal Law § 70.10 does not require that a crime in another jurisdiction be a felony under New York law in order to constitute a previous felony conviction, only that it be a "crime in any other jurisdiction" for which "a sentence to a term of imprisonment in excess of one year ... was imposed" (Penal Law § 70.10 [1] [b] [i]).

Crimes - Sentence - Persistent Felony Offender - Challenge to Presumption of Regularity of Previous Felony Conviction - Sufficiency of Allocution

2. In a proceeding to determine whether defendant should be adjudicated a persistent felony offender pursuant to Penal Law § 70.10 for having been previously convicted of a felony in New York and a felony in California in addition to the felony he presently stands convicted of, defendant has failed to contradict the presumption of regularity accorded to previous felony convictions with his claim that there had been no actual allocution when he entered his guilty plea in California, as the transcript of the plea reveals that defendant's lawyer informed the court: "[We] [c]oncur in the plea, join in the waivers, and believe there is a factual basis for the plea". The allocution by the California court was far more than is constitutionally required under New York law.

Crimes - Sentence - Persistent Felony Offender - Challenge to Presumption of Regularity of Previous Felony Conviction - Presentation of Probation Report

3. In a proceeding to determine whether defendant should be adjudicated a persistent felony offender pursuant to Penal Law § 70.10 for having been previously convicted of a felony in New York and a felony in California in addition to the felony he presently stands convicted of, defendant has failed to contradict the presumption of regularity accorded to previous felony convictions with his claim that no probation report was presented in the California conviction as the plea minutes reveal that the California court received and reviewed the probation report.

Crimes - Sentence - Persistent Felony Offender - History and Character of Defendant

4. Following a hearing to determine whether the history and character of the defendant, who has been adjudicated a persistent felony offender as defined in Penal Law § 70.10, and the nature and circumstances of defendant's criminal conduct "are such that extended incarceration and lifetime supervision of the defendant are warranted to best serve the public interest" ( CPL 400.20 [1]), defendant is sentenced as a persistent felony offender to 15 years to life. Defense counsel conceded that defendant's rap sheet is a substantially accurate reflection of defendant's "actual criminal history", which began in 1964 and includes 34 arrests and at least 23 convictions in New York as well as 20 arrests and at least 10 convictions in California. Defendant's crimes of violence have resulted in one death and almost caused a second, and his history of violence, of disdain for lawful authority, and of uninterrupted criminal behavior evinces an individual who poses a real and imminent danger and threat to the lives, safety, and security of residents of every community in which he chooses to circulate.

 

633 of 992 DOCUMENTS


People v. Price


DOCKET NO. 98N056667


CRIMINAL COURT OF THE CITY OF NEW YORK, NEW YORK COUNTY


178 Misc. 2d 778; 683 N.Y.S.2d 417; 1998 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 559



November 17, 1998, Decided


NOTICE:  [***1] EDITED FOR PUBLICATION



DISPOSITION: Defendant's motion to dismiss the fourth count of the information, charging a violation of Pl 240.26(1), denied.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant was charged with three counts of aggravated harassment in the second degree, in violation of N.Y. Penal Law § 240.30 (1), and one count of harassment in the second degree, in violation of N.Y. Penal Law § 240.26 (1). Defendant filed a motion to dismiss the accusatory instrument for facial insufficiency.


OVERVIEW: Regarding the aggravated harassment charges, the accusatory instrument stated that defendant threatened his attorney by means of a letter and a telephone call. The attorney was then representing defendant in a civil case. Regarding the harassment in the second-degree charge, the accusatory instrument alleged that defendant made a further threat to his attorney in a civil courthouse and that defendant was not permitted to leave the courthouse at the same time as his attorney. Defendant contended that the accusatory instrument was not facially sufficient because the speech activity at issue was constitutionally protected speech. The court held that (1) the alleged telephone message and mail constituted invasions of the attorney's privacy interest; (2) the two counts of aggravated harassment relating to the telephone and letter were facially sufficient because the content of these communications evinced an intention to harass, annoy, threaten or alarm the attorney; (3) the third count of aggravated harassment contained no factual allegations and was insufficient; and (4) the indictment adequately alleged a violation of § 240.6(1).


OUTCOME: The court denied the motion to dismiss the two counts charging aggravated harassment in the second degree with respect to the alleged threats made by a letter and telephone call. The court dismissed the remaining aggravated harassment count. The motion to dismiss the charge of harassment in the second degree was denied.


HEADNOTES

Crimes - Information - Facial Sufficiency - Aggravated Harassment

1. Two counts of an information charging defendant with aggravated harassment in the second degree (Penal Law § 240.30 [1]) are facially sufficient based upon allegations, respectively, that defendant sent a letter to the attorney who was representing him in a Housing Court matter which stated "you better be careful, I won't be responsible if you speak to me like that again", and that defendant left his attorney a telephone message stating, "You will be ... sorry, you're playing with fire, you better get me my apartment free and clear with no rent for five years, that's the only way it will be balanced, I' [sic] be at [the attorney's address], no doors will keep me out, you better perform magic on Thursday." A person is guilty of aggravated harassment in the second degree when, with intent to harass, annoy, threaten or alarm another person, he or she communicates, or causes a communication to be initiated by mechanical or electronic means or other form of written communication, in a manner likely to cause annoyance or alarm (Penal Law § 240.30 [1]). Whereas public speech that is abusive may be protected, the possession of a telephone does not constitute an open invitation to uninvited abuse. Such "trespass by telephone" constitutes a violation of privacy. Here, the defendant's alleged telephone message and mail constitute invasions of complainant's privacy interest. Accordingly, because the content of the two alleged communications evince an intention to harass, annoy, threaten or alarm the complainant, two counts of aggravated harassment in the second degree are facially sufficient. However, because only two communications using the telephone or mail are alleged, a third count, for which there are no factual allegations, must be dismissed.

Crimes - Information - Facial Sufficiency - Harassment

2. A person is guilty of harassment in the second degree when, with intent to harass, annoy or alarm another person, he or she strikes, shoves, or kicks or otherwise subjects such other person to physical contact, or attempts or threatens to do the same (Penal Law § 240.26 [1]). Accordingly, the count of an information charging defendant with harassment in the second degree (Penal Law § 240.26 [1]) is facially sufficient based upon allegations that defendant stated to the attorney who was representing him in a Housing Court matter, "in substance," "I'll get you," while "shaking his hand" at her and that "the defendant was not permitted [by court officers] to leave [the courthouse] at the same time" as the attorney.

 

634 of 992 DOCUMENTS


People v. Mazzochetti


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


JUSTICE COURT OF NEW YORK, TOWN OF IRONDEQUOIT, MONROE COUNTY


181 Misc. 2d 701; 696 N.Y.S.2d 618; 1998 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 703



November 11, 1998, Decided



DISPOSITION:  [***1] Dismissed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: In a criminal action, the state charged defendant with the offense of illegally constructing a fence without a permit and failing to correct the violation to comply with the municipal code, in violation of Town of Irondequoit, N.Y., Mun. Code, ch. 98, art. III, § 98-9 (A).


OVERVIEW: Without a permit, defendant constructed a wooden, split rail, construction, which fronted a small garden near her driveway. It consisted of three posts three feet in height, with four rails connected thereto that were six to seven long. The court dismissed the charges with prejudice. The court held that the construction did not constitute a "fence" under Town of Irondequoit, N.Y., Mun. Code § 235-4(B) and thus Town of Irondequoit, N.Y., Mun. Code §§ 98-9, former § 235-69 did not apply to defendant. It neither enclosed nor screened the property, and no more constituted a "fence" than plastic pink flamingoes constituted an aviary. Defendant was not subject to the continued restrictions that would be imposed if she had nonconforming fencing which "legally existed" prior to the adoption of Town of Irondequoit, N.Y., Mun. Code § 235-69 (Aug. 1998). Town of Irondequoit, N.Y., Mun. Code § 235-69(A), (E) was void as unconstitutionally vague and indefinite. Town of Irondequoit, N.Y., Mun. Code § 235-69(C)(1) was an unconstitutional confiscatory restriction on property owners' rights. The requirement of licensing all "fences," both good and bad, was unreasonable.


OUTCOME: The court dismissed, in its entirety and with prejudice, the prosecution for illegally constructing a fence without a permit and failing to correct the violation to comply with the municipal code.


HEADNOTES

Municipal Corporations - Zoning - Regulation of "Fencing"

1. Defendant homeowner, who built a split-rail wooden "fence", approximately six to seven feet in length consisting of three posts approximately three feet in height with a total of four rails partially enclosing a small garden near a front corner of her driveway, may not be prosecuted for "illegally constructing a fence without a permit" in violation of a Town ordinance defining "fence" as an "artificially constructed enclosure or barrier or any material or combination of materials ... erected to enclose or screen areas of land." The small collection of split rails and posts does not constitute a "fence" as defined in the ordinance since it neither encloses nor screens the subject property nor any portion thereof. The construction complained of is no different, and no more a barrier, than any number of other lawn decorations that homeowners use to beautify their property as they see fit.

Municipal Corporations - Zoning - Regulation of "Fencing"

2. Town "fencing" ordinances which place height and location restrictions on the construction of "fences, walls and any other similar construction," and further provide that all fences "shall require a building permit," regardless of size or location or even the most obvious compliance with height and setback requirements, are unconstitutionally vague and overbroad. The all-encompassing requirement of licensing all "fences" or "fencing" constitutes an unreasonable infringement of basic property rights of homeowners. The provision in the ordinance requiring that fencing be "open-type construction (split rail, picket or the like)" leaves it to guesswork as to what "the like" is; whether pickets or rails might be too close together so as to be "solid"; and whether or not the construction can enclose a tree or a small garden, even if it is set back 50 feet from a sidewalk. Furthermore, the provision limiting fencing to "30 total linear feet" makes no differentiation for the vastly different frontages and lot sizes in the Town. The arbitrary provision that fencing "must be set back a minimum of three feet from the front property line" makes no provision for older boundary lines that may be referenced to the center of a street. When read with other provisions of the Town Code, the "fencing" ordinances lack the clear, precise, definitive and certain terminology which is required to properly inform a landowner of what is prohibited and what is permitted.

 

635 of 992 DOCUMENTS


Daniel v. New York State Div. of Hous. & Community Renewal


Index No. 102540/98


SUPREME COURT OF NEW YORK, NEW YORK COUNTY


179 Misc. 2d 452; 683 N.Y.S.2d 404; 1998 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 562



November 2, 1998, Decided


SUBSEQUENT HISTORY:  [***1] As Corrected March 15, 1999.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioners, tenants, sought judicial review of rent overcharge claims on apartments owned by respondent real estate company, that were either wrongfully denied or were still pending with respondent New York State Division of Housing and Community Renewal (DHCR). Petitioners alleged that respondent DHCR had denied legitimate overcharge complaints and relying upon an unconstitutional statute, Rent Regulation Reform Act of 1997, 1997 N.Y. Laws 116.


OVERVIEW: Petitioners, tenants, filed rent overcharge claims against respondent real estate company with respondent New York State Division of Housing and Community Renewal (DHCR). Petitioners alleged that respondent DHCR had denied legitimate overcharge complaints by engaging in improper and wrongful conduct and relying on an unconstitutional statute, Rent Regulation Reform Act of 1997, 1997 N.Y. Laws 116, that changed the statute of limitations period. The court held that although respondent DHCR's failure to act within the required time provided the basis for a mandamus to review, for reasons of comity and judicial economy and adherence to the requirement for administrative finality, the better course was to direct the agency to render a final determination within a reasonable and definite time period, thus the court granted the petitions of certain petitioners to the extent of remanding those matters to respondent. The court held that there was no constitutional impediment to legislation that retroactively increased or decreased a period of limitations, providing petitioners had reasonable time to commence the action, thus the court dismissed other petitions on the merits.


OUTCOME: The court held that Rent Regulation Reform Act of 1997 was constitutional and that petitioners, tenants, could not be certified as a class because they had not met the class requirements. The court granted the petitions of certain petitioners to the extent of remanding those matters to respondent New York State Division of Housing and Community Renewal, and dismissed other petitions for failure to exhaust administrative remedies or on the merits.


HEADNOTES

Proceeding against Body or Officer - When Remedy Appropriate - Failure of Agency to Timely Respond to Petition for Administrative Review - Rent Overcharge Proceeding

1. Where petitioner tenants seek judicial review of rent overcharge complaints that are still pending with respondent Division of Housing and Community Renewal (DHCR), the failure of DHCR to respond within 90 days or obtain an extension of time within which to respond to the petitions for administrative review filed by petitioners after their rent overcharge complaints were denied provides the basis for a CPLR article 78 proceeding in the nature of a mandamus to review. However, for reasons of comity and judicial economy as well as adherence to the requirement for administrative finality, the matters will be remanded to DHCR with a direction to render final determinations within 60 days after service of a copy of the judgment.

Administrative Law - Failure to Exhaust Administrative Remedies - Rent Overcharge Proceeding

2. A CPLR article 78 proceeding seeking judicial review of a rent overcharge complaint denied by order of the Rent Administrator is dismissed for failure to exhaust administrative remedies where petitioner tenants failed to file their petition for administrative review of the order with the Division of Housing and Community Renewal within 35 days after the order was issued, as required by Rent Stabilization Code (9 NYCRR) § 2529.2.

Landlord and Tenant - Rent Regulation - Rent Overcharge - Failure of Rent Administrator to Timely Respond to Rent Overcharge Complaint

3. The petitions in a CPLR article 78 proceeding seeking judicial review of rent overcharge complaints which were brought more than five years ago but have not yet been determined by the Rent Administrator are granted to the extent of remanding the matters to the Division of Housing and Community Renewal (DHCR) with directions to issue determinations (Rent Stabilization Code [9 NYCRR] § 2527.6) within 60 days after service of a copy of the judgment. Although the Emergency Tenant Protection Regulations and Rent Stabilization Code do not contain any time limit for a determination by the Rent Administrator, a reasonable time to act is presumed when no specific time is given, and a delay of over five years is inherently unreasonable, particularly where DHCR has not offered any indication as to what stage, if any, has been reached on these applications, or any approximate date for a determination. Accordingly, this is an appropriate case for the extraordinary remedy of a mandamus to compel.

Administrative Law - Failure to Exhaust Administrative Remedies - Rent Overcharge Proceeding

4. A CPLR article 78 proceeding seeking judicial review of a rent overcharge complaint denied by order of the Rent Administrator which was brought by tenants who failed to file a petition for administrative review of the order with the Division of Housing and Community Renewal or make a request for reconsideration, is dismissed for petitioners' failure to exhaust their administrative remedies.

Actions - Class Actions - Certification - Rent Overcharge Proceeding

5. In a CPLR article 78 proceeding in which petitioner tenants seek judicial review of rent overcharge claims that were either allegedly wrongfully denied or are still pending with respondent Division of Housing and Community Renewal (DHCR), petitioners are not entitled to class action certification since most of the petitioners are still awaiting decisions from DHCR and thus have failed to exhaust their administrative remedies; the unique factual circumstances concerning the denials of the various overcharge complaints are not common to all members of the proposed class; and there is nothing to indicate that petitioners would fairly represent the interests of the proposed class. Moreover, class action certification is inappropriate in CPLR article 78 proceedings because subsequent petitioners will be adequately protected by the principles of stare decisis.

Landlord and Tenant - Rent Regulation - Rent Overcharge - Examination of Rental History - Application of Four-Year Limitation

6. In a CPLR article 78 proceeding in which petitioner tenants seek judicial review of the determinations of the Division of Housing and Community Renewal (DHCR) which affirmed the orders of the Rent Administrator denying petitioners' rent overcharge complaints, it was not arbitrary and capricious for DHCR to refuse to consider the rent history of the respective apartments beyond four years from the date each overcharge complaint was filed. Rent Stabilization Law of 1969 (Administrative Code of City of NY) § 26-516 (a) (2) (ii) was recently amended to specifically "preclude examination of the rental history of the housing accommodation prior to the four-year period preceding the filing of a complaint", and this amendment was to take effect immediately and apply to any action or proceeding pending in any court, which would include petitioners' rent overcharge complaints.

Landlord and Tenant - Rent Regulation - Rent Overcharge - Examination of Rental History - Application of Four-Year Limitation - Constitutionality

7. The application of Rent Stabilization Law of 1969 (Administrative Code of City of NY) § 26-516 (a) (2) (ii), which was recently amended to specifically "preclude examination of the rental history of the housing accommodation prior to the four-year period preceding the filing of a complaint", to petitioners' proceeding seeking judicial review of the denial of their rent overcharge complaints by the Division of Housing and Community Renewal (DHCR), which was pending at the time the amendment was enacted, is appropriate and constitutional. The amendment neither created nor diminished nor abrogated petitioners' right to commence and maintain an overcharge proceeding under the Rent Stabilization Law. The four-year Statute of Limitations for bringing an overcharge proceeding was in the statute before it was amended and thus petitioners had the full four years in which to bring an overcharge complaint; the amendment merely clarified the law to limit the examination of the rental history to the same four-year period. An individual does not have a vested interest in any rule of law or legislative policy which entitles him or her to have such law or policy remain unaltered for his or her benefit.

 

636 of 992 DOCUMENTS


Initiative for Competitive Energy v. Long Island Power Auth.


INDEX NO. 12125-98, MOTION # 001; 002; 003; 004; 005;-CASEDISP


SUPREME COURT OF NEW YORK, SUFFOLK COUNTY


178 Misc. 2d 979; 683 N.Y.S.2d 391; 1998 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 553



October 7, 1998, Decided


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiffs, utility ratepayers and others, filed a motion for preliminary injunction under N.Y. C.P.L.R. 6301, 6314, and cross motion for leave to amend complaint under N.Y. C.P.L.R. 2035(b). Defendant power authority filed cross motion for an order under N.Y. C.P.L.R. 505 and N.Y. Pub. Auth. Law § 1020-y to change venue or to dismiss complaint under N.Y. C.P.L.R. 3211(a). Proposed intervenor governments filed motion for leave to intervene.


OVERVIEW: Plaintiffs, utility ratepayers and others, filed a motion in the trial court for a preliminary injunction under N.Y. C.P.L.R. 6301, 6314. Defendant power authority filed a cross motion for an order under N.Y. C.P.L.R. 505 and N.Y. Pub. Auth. Law § 1020-y to change venue or to dismiss the complaint under N.Y. C.P.L.R. 3211(a); plaintiffs filed a cross motion to amend the complaint under N.Y. C.P.L.R. 2035(b); and proposed intervenor governments sought to intervene. The court denied plaintiffs' motion for a preliminary injunction, holding that plaintiffs lacked standing to challenge defendant's issuance of bonds due to lack of injury in fact. The court held that plaintiffs failed to state causes of action by failing to show that the utility rates would not be lower, because N.Y. Const. art. X, § 5 did not apply; because under 42 U.S.C.S. § 1983 there was no protectable property interest in the utility rates charged; and due to collateral estoppel and res judicata. The court denied plaintiffs' motion to amend the complaint due to failure to state a cause of action; granted defendant's motion to dismiss the complaint; and denied proposed intervenors' motion to intervene as moot.


OUTCOME: The court denied plaintiffs', utility ratepayers and others, motion for a preliminary injunction and to amend the complaint, and granted defendant power authority's motion to dismiss the complaint due to lack of standing, failure to state causes of action, collateral estoppel, and res judicata. The court denied proposed intervenor governments' motion to intervene, holding that such was moot in light of the complaint's dismissal.


HEADNOTES

Trial - Place of Trial - Demand for Change of Venue - Challenging Action Taken by Long Island Power Authority

1. A motion by defendant Long Island Power Authority (LIPA) to transfer an action challenging its actions under the LIPA Act (Public Authorities Law § 1020 et seq.), from Suffolk to Nassau County, is denied. Although LIPA's principal office is in Nassau County, venue in Suffolk County is proper since facilities involved in the action are located in Suffolk County. Additionally, no timely objection was raised by defendant.

Courts - Ripeness Doctrine - Challenging Action Taken by Long Island Power Authority

2. A declaratory judgment action challenging defendant Long Island Power Authority's (LIPA) actions under the LIPA Act (Public Authorities Law § 1020 et seq.), on the ground that LIPA lacks authority to finance acquisition of the Long Island Lighting Company by issuing bonds and using the bond revenues to finance a proposed tax settlement agreement, rebates and credits and a Suffolk County surcharge, is dismissed on the ground that the claims are not ripe for judicial review. A court may only render a declaratory judgment upon a justiciable controversy ( CPLR 3001). An action is justiciable when the controversy presented touches the legal relations of parties having adverse interests from which harm is presently flowing or could flow in the future in the absence of a court determination of the parties' rights. Plaintiffs' complaint centers on objections to a proposed property tax settlement and a proposed bifurcated rate structure plan. No agreement has been reached with the taxing jurisdiction to resolve the tax refunds ordered in a previous judgment. In addition, the projected resultant bifurcated rate plan which is contingent upon the tax settlement agreement, and imposes a surcharge on Suffolk ratepayers, is not to occur until 2003.

Parties - Standing - Challenging Action Taken by Long Island Power Authority

3. Plaintiffs, a group of Suffolk County business and residential electric ratepayers, lack standing to challenge defendant Long Island Power Authority's (LIPA) statutory authority under the LIPA Act (Public Authorities Law § 1020 et seq.) to issue bonds, to use the proceeds to finance proposed settlements and to set or collect rates to consummate various proposals for the purpose of acquiring the Long Island Lighting Company (LILCO). To have standing, an aggrieved party must sustain an injury in fact, different from that of the public at large, which falls within the zone of interests sought to be promoted or protected by the statutory provision under which the agency acted. Plaintiffs have failed to make any proffer that its members have sustained an injury in fact or that any alleged injury differs from that suffered by the community at large. The Public Authorities Law grants LIPA the authority to issue bonds and enter agreements in furtherance of its primary statutory objective (to lower rates and replace LILCO). In addition, the claim that defendant may not issue bonds to finance a tax settlement agreement is premature in that no agreement has occurred.

Parties - Standing - Challenging Action Taken by Long Island Power Authority

4. Plaintiffs, a group of Suffolk County business and residential electric ratepayers, lack standing to challenge defendant Long Island Power Authority's (LIPA) actions under the LIPA Act (Public Authorities Law § 1020 et seq.) to acquire the Long Island Lighting Company, by entering into a proposed tax settlement agreement and recovering a tax refund under Public Authorities Law § 1020-q (3). Public Authorities Law § 1020-f (h) authorizes LIPA to enter into agreements with municipalities to fulfill the primary statutory objectives. Also, LIPA has determined that the most cost effective means of compromising a tax certiorari judgment against Suffolk County is by implementation of the tax settlement agreement. Plaintiffs have made no showing they have sustained an injury in fact resulting from LIPA's proposals. Nor is there any evidence that plaintiffs are within the "zone of interest" section 1020-q (3) was designed to protect. Plaintiffs' claim under this statute is also premature since there has been no agreement on this issue.

Parties - Standing - Constitutional Challenge to Action Taken by Long Island Power Authority

5. Plaintiffs, a group of Suffolk County business and residential electric ratepayers, lack standing to challenge action taken by defendant Long Island Power Authority (LIPA) under the LIPA Act (Public Authorities Law § 1020 et seq.) to acquire the Long Island Lighting Company, by issuing bonds and implementing a bifurcated rate structure, as unconstitutional under New York Constitution, article X, § 5, based upon their status as voters who have constitutional rights to challenge issuance of State bonds. Plaintiffs have not asserted that any individual members are registered to vote and, therefore, are representative of the group as voters. Nor can an entity claiming to be residential and commercial ratepayers be considered to represent Suffolk County voters. Even assuming the individual plaintiff is a voter and taxpayer does not provide status to challenge the bond issues. The bonds, as financial instruments of an independent public authority, are not State-issued or State-guaranteed bonds and thus, by nature, are not subject to the article X, § 5 claims advanced.

Parties - Standing - Action under Suffolk County Tax Act

6. Plaintiffs, a group of Suffolk County business and residential electric ratepayers, lack standing to challenge a bifurcated rate structure proposed by defendant Long Island Power Authority (LIPA) under the LIPA Act (Public Authorities Law § 1020 et seq.), on the ground that the rate structure violates Suffolk County Tax Act § 3 (L 1920, ch 311, as amended by L 1996, ch 636, § 1). The Tax Act provides no private cause of action for individual citizens and no legislative intent may be implied granting a private citizen the right to maintain a claim under its provisions.

Public Authorities - Claims against Public Authorities - Challenging Action Taken by Long Island Power Authority

7. A motion by defendant Long Island Power Authority (LIPA) to dismiss plaintiffs' complaint challenging its actions under the LIPA Act (Public Authorities Law § 1020 et seq.), on the ground that there is another action pending between the same parties for the same cause of action ( CPLR 3211 [a] [4]), is denied. Dismissal is required where the court in which the prior action is pending retains jurisdiction and where that action was not terminated before the time at which the defense or claim in issue is asserted. Here, the Nassau County companion action was dismissed prior to commencement of this action.

Judgments - Res Judicata

8. A motion by defendant Long Island Power Authority (LIPA) to dismiss, on res judicata grounds ( CPLR 3211 [a] [5]), plaintiffs' claims that defendant may not compensate the Long Island Lighting Company (LILCO) and/or enforce a tax certiorari judgment previously obtained by LILCO in order to acquire LILCO pursuant to the LIPA Act (Public Authorities Law § 1020 et seq.) is granted. A party asserting collateral estoppel must show that the issue in question is identical with an issue in a prior proceeding, that the issue was actually litigated or necessarily determined in the prior action, and that the determination of the issue was necessary to reach the judgment awarded in the prior proceeding. Here, Suffolk County previously commenced a CPLR article 78 proceeding, in which plaintiff successfully intervened as a party/petitioner and claimed that LIPA's proposed LILCO takeover violated Public Authorities Law § 1020-q (3). The court dismissed plaintiffs' claims by concluding that section 1020-q (3) does not bar LIPA from compensating LILCO for the tax certiorari judgment. This determination remains the law of the case and bars plaintiff from relitigating the identical claim in any subsequent proceeding.

Public Authorities - Claims against Public Authorities - Authority of Long Island Power Authority

9. Plaintiffs' claims against defendant Long Island Power Authority (LIPA), alleging that LIPA exceeded its statutory authority under the LIPA Act (Public Authorities Law § 1020 et seq.) when attempting to acquire the Long Island Lighting Company (LILCO), fail to state a cause of action ( CPLR 3211 [a] [7]). LIPA's authority to issue bonds, to use bond proceeds and to set and collect utility rates (Public Authorities Law §§ 1020-a, 1020-f, 1020-h, 1020-k) was conditioned on a requirement that utility rates to LILCO customers not be higher than LILCO would have charged had there been no takeover. LIPA has provided evidence of its compliance with this requirement. In addition, plaintiffs have failed to show that LIPA's decision will not result in lower rates.

Public Authorities - Claims against Public Authorities - Authority of Long Island Power Authority to Issue Bonds and Establish Rate Structure

10. Plaintiffs' claims against defendant Long Island Power Authority (LIPA) alleging that, while acting under the LIPA Act (Public Authorities Law § 1020 et seq.) to acquire the Long Island Lighting Company, LIPA's issuance of bonds and promulgation of a bifurcated rate structure violated Public Authorities Law § 1020-q (3), the New York Constitution, and the Suffolk County Tax Act (L 1920, ch 311, as amended) are dismissed for failure to state a cause of action ( CPLR 3211 [a] [7]). The LIPA Act does not bar LIPA from asserting its right to collect property tax over-assessments or to enter into any agreement settling over-assessments including a tax certiorari judgment against the County. Public Authorities Law § 1020-f (u), which grants LIPA the authority to fix utility rates, supports the proposed bifurcated rate structure and the structure does not impose a tax which violates the Suffolk County Tax Act. Furthermore, the municipal liability disclaimer contained in Public Authorities Law § 1020-k, releasing any municipality from liability on the bonds, is also on the LIPA-issued bonds and is consistent with the New York Constitution.

Public Authorities - Claims against Public Authorities - Rate-Making Authority of Long Island Power Authority

11. Plaintiffs' claims against defendant Long Island Power Authority (LIPA) alleging that LIPA's adoption of a bifurcated rate structure under the LIPA Act (Public Authorities Law § 1020 et seq.) is arbitrary, capricious and without a rational basis, and violates 42 USC § 1983 and the New York Constitution, are dismissed for failure to state a cause of action ( CPLR 3211 [a] [7]). State agency rate-making decisions are accorded substantial deference and cannot be set aside unless they lack a rational basis. LIPA has submitted evidence detailing the reasons for its final decision sufficient to show that its decision was rationally based and neither arbitrary nor capricious. Also, claims alleging a violation of 42 USC § 1983 cannot be sustained since the ratepayers have no protectable property interest in rates they are charged by their utility provider.

Public Authorities - Claims against Public Authorities - Acquisition of Long Island Lighting Company by Long Island Power Authority

12. Plaintiffs' motion for a preliminary injunction to prevent defendant Long Island Power Authority (LIPA) from proceeding under the LIPA Act (Public Authorities Law § 1020 et seq.) to acquire the Long Island Lighting Company (LILCO) is denied where plaintiffs failed to show the likelihood of ultimate success on the merits, irreparable injury absent the granting of the preliminary injunction and a balancing of the equities in their favor. The LIPA Act granted LIPA sole discretion to purchase all or any part of LILCO assets provided the ratepayers thereby benefit from lower rates. Defendant has submitted sufficient evidence to show its compliance with the broad and flexible mandates granted by the LIPA Act.

 

637 of 992 DOCUMENTS


People ex rel. Willis v. Travis


W-565


SUPREME COURT OF NEW YORK, NASSAU COUNTY


178 Misc. 2d 469; 680 N.Y.S.2d 422; 1998 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 496



October 6, 1998, Decided


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner, an alleged parole violator, brought a habeas corpus proceeding to challenge the legality of his detention, claiming that he did not receive required written notice of the time, place, and purpose of his preliminary parole revocation hearing within five days of the execution of the warrant as required by N.Y. Exec. Law § 259-i(3)(c)(iii).


OVERVIEW: Petitioner was released on parole, then convicted of a drug offense and re-released on parole. His supervision was transferred to North Carolina, and he waived extradition to New York. While on parole, he was convicted of a misdemeanor and sentenced to probation. After being convicted of another misdemeanor, he was found to have violated probation and was sentenced to jail. Based on the misdemeanors, a New York parole warrant was forwarded to North Carolina to detain petitioner. Petitioner was served with written notice of charges and returned to New York five days after the division received written confirmation of his availability, which was more than two weeks after the division received oral notice of his availability. Petitioner sought relief, claiming that he did not receive written notice within five days of the execution of the warrant pursuant to § 259-i(3)(c)(iii). The court sustained the writ. The court held that habeas relief was available where the division failed to give timely notice of a preliminary parole revocation hearing. The court found that oral notice triggered the obligation to serve written notice of the hearing within five days under § 259-i(3)(c)(iii).


OUTCOME: The court sustained the writ of habeas corpus in petitioner's action alleging unlawful detention based on a parole revocation proceeding. The court directed the division of parole to restore petitioner to parole status.


HEADNOTES

Parole - Revocation - Timely Notice of Preliminary Parole Revocation Hearing

Oral notice that a parolee is being detained exclusively on a New York warrant triggers the New York State Division of Parole's (Parole) obligation to serve written notice of the preliminary parole revocation hearing within five days of the execution of the warrant (Executive Law § 259-i [3] [c] [iii]); accordingly, relator did not receive timely notice of his preliminary parole revocation hearing where he was taken into custody by North Carolina probation authorities for parole/probation violations in that State and, upon resolution of the issues and discharge from probation in that State, Parole was notified by telephone that he was available for return to New York, but Parole never served written notice as required by Executive Law § 259-i (3) (c) (iii) until after it received a requested written confirmation of relator's availability. Parole need not receive written confirmation that the parolee is being detained exclusively on the New York warrant to trigger its obligation to serve written notice of the preliminary revocation hearing on the parolee.

 

638 of 992 DOCUMENTS


People v. Arroyo


Indictment # 97-13, Motion No. A-38 E XVI, XVII


COUNTY COURT OF NEW YORK, SCHOHARIE COUNTY


178 Misc. 2d 653; 683 N.Y.S.2d 788; 1998 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 528



September 30, 1998, Decided



DISPOSITION:  [***1] The Court has considered the defendants' argument that the death penalty runs counter to prevailing societal standards of decency and finds this argument erroneous. All other arguments posed by defendant are lacking in merit.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: In an action for murder, conspiracy, and criminal possession of a weapon, defendants filed a motion to strike the notice of intent to seek the death penalty on the grounds that N.Y. Penal Law §125.27 and N.Y. Crim. Proc. Law § 400.27 constituted cruel and unusual punishment, violated the defendants' fundamental right to life, and invited the arbitrary and discriminatory, including racially discriminatory, imposition of the death penalty.


OVERVIEW: The death penalty was sought against defendants, who were charged with murder, conspiracy, criminal possession of a weapon, and criminal solicitation. Defendants filed a motion to strike the notice of intent to seek the death penalty and contended that N.Y. Penal Law § 125.27 and N.Y. Crim. Proc. Law § 400.27 constituted cruel and unusual punishment, were violative of the fundamental right to life, and invited arbitrary and discriminatory imposition of the death penalty. The court found that defendants made no showing of prosecutorial conduct that indicated arbitrary prosecution or that the prosecutor's decision to seek the death penalty was improperly or illegally made. The court also found that defendants' statistical analysis of death cases too was unpersuasive on the issue of discriminatory enforcement of the death penalty statutes. The court held that based on the conduct underlying the crimes charged, which satisfied the criteria of N.Y. Penal Law §125.27(1)(a)(vi), and the lack of specific abuse on the part of the prosecutor in electing to seek the death penalty, there was no discriminatory enforcement.


OUTCOME: Defendants' motion to strike the notice of intent to seek the death penalty was denied.


HEADNOTES

Crimes - Murder - Capital Murder - Cruel and Unusual Punishment - State Constitution

1. Defendants' motion to strike the notice to seek the death penalty filed against them on the ground that the death penalty, as enacted and applied (see, Penal Law § 125.27; CPL 400.27), constitutes cruel and unusual punishment is denied. The death penalty is not unconstitutional per se under the Federal Constitution, and New York's death penalty scheme includes the safeguards approved under the Federal Constitution. Moreover, State statutes have a strong presumption of constitutionality and the New York Constitution infers the constitutionality of capital punishment in that the need for certain special procedures for crimes punishable by death is referred to in several sections of article I. The determination of whether the "cruel and unusual punishment" clause of article I, § 5 of the New York Constitution provides constitutional protections greater than those required by the Federal Constitution is best left to the Court of Appeals.

Crimes - Murder - Capital Murder - Equal Protection - Discriminatory Imposition of Death Penalty

2. Defendants' motion to strike the notice to seek the death penalty filed against them on the ground that Penal Law § 125.27 and CPL 400.27, as enacted and applied, invite arbitrary and discriminatory imposition of the death penalty is denied as defendants' statistical analysis of death penalty cases to date is unpersuasive, the conduct underlying the crimes defendants are charged with satisfies the statutory criteria of the first degree murder statute they are charged under, and defendants have made no showing of any specific abuse on the part of the prosecutor in electing to seek the death penalty. Moreover, New York's capital punishment scheme ensures a standard and uniform application by including an extra protection for a defendant sentenced to death in the form of a review of the defendant's case by the Court of Appeals in the context of all other similar cases.

 

639 of 992 DOCUMENTS


People v. Arroyo


Indictment # 97-13, Motion No. A-25, 27 E XVIII. XXII.


COUNTY COURT OF NEW YORK, SCHOHARIE COUNTY


1998 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 720; 1998 NY Slip Op 40002U



September 29, 1998, Decided


NOTICE:   [*1] THIS OPINION IS UNCORRECTED AND WILL NOT BE PUBLISHED IN THE OFFICIAL REPORTS.


SUBSEQUENT HISTORY: As Corrected December 17, 2001.



DISPOSITION: Motions denied.

 

640 of 992 DOCUMENTS


Zobel v. New York State Bd. of Elections


INDEX NO. 5221-98, (RJI No. 0198 055199)


SUPREME COURT OF NEW YORK, ALBANY COUNTY


178 Misc. 2d 439; 679 N.Y.S.2d 534; 1998 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 503



September 23, 1998, Decided



DISPOSITION:  [***1] Petition to invalidate is granted and the two petitions to validate are dismissed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioners, candidates and political party, sought to validate a nominating petition for a state wide slate of candidates circulated by the party. The petition had been declared invalid by the respondents, New York State Board of Elections (board).


OVERVIEW: The party collected signatures pursuant to N.Y. Elec. Law § 6-142, in order to place their candidates in a state wide election. The board invalidated the petitions, finding that a large number of the signatures were invalid as the signer or subscribing witness listed an improper town, city or county on the petition in violation of N.Y. Elec. Law § 6-140(1)(a). The court granted the petition to invalidate, holding that the burden resulting from reasonable, nondiscriminatory restrictions was not enough to override the state's important regulatory interests' in having the restrictions in place. The requirement of listing the town or city served the purpose of allowing rapid checks of the petition signatures to occur within the narrow time frames imposed by the Election Law. The court found that, noted by the candidates' own witness, the errors in the petition would have been easily prevented through a more organized and proper collection procedure. The court found that the statute did not impose unduly harsh restrictions on those seeking nomination.


OUTCOME: The court granted the petition to invalidate the election petitions.


HEADNOTES

Constitutional Law - Validity of Statute - Election Law § 6-140 (1) (a) 

 Election Law § 6-140 (1) (a), which mandates that a signer or subscribing witness list his/her town, city or county on a nominating petition, is not unconstitutional; accordingly, the independent nominating petition for a State-wide slate of candidates circulated by the Term Limits Party which contained 6,345 invalid signatures for failure of the signer or subscribing witness to list the proper town, city or county on the petition is rendered invalid for failure to contain the necessary 15,000 valid signatures (Election Law § 6-142). In determining the constitutionality of Election Law § 6-140 (1) (a), the State's interests include requiring some preliminary showing of a significant modicum of support, assuring the validity of the signature and protecting against fraud, assuring party membership of each signature and regulating the number of candidates on the ballot. The Legislature may place reasonable restrictions upon the election process. The town or city listing requirement serves the purpose of allowing rapid checks of the petition signatures, serves a necessary and essential function and does not impose an overly burdensome procedure on the election process. The statute is not rendered unconstitutional based on the existence of a computerized State-wide election registry.

 

641 of 992 DOCUMENTS


416 West 47th St. Assocs. v. Fountain House, Inc.


Index No. L&T 56911/98


CIVIL COURT OF THE CITY OF NEW YORK, NEW YORK COUNTY


179 Misc. 2d 351; 684 N.Y.S.2d 813; 1998 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 645



September 18, 1998, Decided


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner landlord commenced this nonprimary residence holdover proceeding against respondent corporate tenant (tenant) to recover possession of the subject premises. The landlord filed a motion for summary judgment pursuant to N.Y. C.P.L.R. § 3212. The tenant filed a cross-motion for summary judgment.


OVERVIEW: The court found that both parties agreed upon the facts, but differed as to whether the premises retained their rent-regulated status. The court found that prior caselaw, which held that if the premises are used as the primary residence of the contractually designated parties then a rent-stabilized lease renewal must be offered, had been implicitly overruled. The court found that, particularly where a broad-based class designated in a lease included those occupying a rent-stabilized unit incident to employment, such a renewal was not mandatory. The court held that a corporate tenant in a rent-stabilized unit is entitled to a renewal lease only where the lease specifies a particular individual as the occupant and no perpetual tenancy is possible. The landlord was thus entitled to possession.


OUTCOME: The court granted the landlord's motion for summary judgment and denied the tenant's cross motion. The court ordered that a final judgment of possession in favor of the landlord was to issue forthwith, with execution stayed through a date certain, conditioned upon the tenant paying use and occupancy through that date.


HEADNOTES

Landlord and Tenant - Rent Regulation - Renewal Lease - Not-for-Profit Corporate Tenant

Respondent not-for-profit corporation, which provides social services, employment programs and housing accommodations to individuals with disabilities, is not entitled to a rent-stabilized renewal lease where the lease sets forth a broad-based class including those who receive services offered by respondent, staff, trainees and other persons associated with respondent. Rent Stabilization Law of 1969 (Administrative Code of City of NY) § 26-504 (a) (1) (f), which provides that a rent-stabilized tenant is entitled to a renewal lease unless the unit is not occupied by the tenant as his or her primary residence, provides a corporate tenant with the right to a renewal lease where the lease specifies a particular individual as the occupant and no perpetual tenancy is possible. The renewal lease will not be granted where a broad-based class designated in a lease includes those occupying a rent-stabilized unit incident to employment. Here, the terms of the lease allow perpetual tenancy. Although the current occupant appears to be an individual who receives services offered by respondent, upon his vacatur, the premises could be occupied by a staff member or trainee of respondent.

 

642 of 992 DOCUMENTS


Dollinger v. Pataki


Index No. 7351-97, RJI No. 019053495


SUPREME COURT OF NEW YORK, ALBANY COUNTY


1998 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 787



September 18, 1998, Decided


NOTICE: NOT APPROVED BY REPORTER OF DECISIONS FOR REPORTING IN STATE REPORTS.

 

643 of 992 DOCUMENTS


People v. Fortune


Indictment No. 5753-95


SUPREME COURT OF NEW YORK, BRONX COUNTY


178 Misc. 2d 499; 682 N.Y.S.2d 803; 1998 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 475



September 15, 1998, Decided



DISPOSITION:  [***1] The Court has chosen to issue this opinion in explaining its ultimate decision on counsel's application which is granted, but in a modified form.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: After defendant's acquittal, assigned counsel submitted a voucher in the amount of $ 11,580 for 357 hours of work on the case to the trial court. The court considered the appropriate fee award.


OVERVIEW: Defendant was indicted and charged with murder in the second degree in violation of N.Y. Penal Law § 125.25 in the stabbing death of a victim. After trial, defendant was acquitted of all charges pending against him. Defense counsel, who had been assigned to defend the accused, submitted expenses to the court in excess of the statutory maximums. The trial court found that for the first 15 months of the life of the case, there were 11 court appearances for a total of 12 hours or approximately one hour per appearance. Over the next 13 months, there were an additional nine appearances for a total of 12 hours or approximately a little over one hour per appearance. During the final six months prior to the appearance of the case before the trial court, there was a total of 10 appearances for a total of 31 1/2 hours, or roughly three hours per appearance. In sum, the length of both hearing and trial were largely due to counsel's unreasonable behavior. Thus, virtually every day would begin with an application for some relief by counsel--most of which were baseless.


OUTCOME: The attorney's fee was reduced to be more in line with the actual hours expended working on the case.


HEADNOTES

Attorney and Client - Compensation - Assigned Counsel - Behavior Which Unnecessarily Prolonged Proceeding

The expense voucher submitted by counsel assigned pursuant to County Law article 18-B to represent defendant, who was tried and acquitted of second degree murder, in which counsel seeks payment of $ 11,580 for 177 hours of in-court time (at $ 40 per hour) and 180 hours of out-of-court time (at $ 25 per hour) is excessive with respect to the in-court time portion since the extended nature of both the pretrial hearing and the trial was due in large part to the actions of defense counsel; accordingly, payment for the hours of in-court time claimed for the pretrial hearing and trial is reduced by one third. While counsel's fee request exceeds the applicable statutory maximum of $ 1,200 (County Law § 722-b), the statute gives the court the discretion to authorize compensation in excess of the statutory limits in "extraordinary circumstances", and in reviewing counsel's fee request the court must consider a number of factors, including the low rates of reimbursement authorized by the statute as well as the overhead and expenses occasioned simply by virtue of the location of counsel's practice in New York City. Although compensation in excess of the statutory maximum is warranted, the court will not simply approve the total hours requested but must consider the degree to which unreasonable delay was caused by the behavior and trial conduct of assigned counsel and factor that into the calculation of the appropriate compensation.

 

644 of 992 DOCUMENTS


People v. McFadden


Ind. No. 735


SUPREME COURT OF NEW YORK, MONROE COUNTY


178 Misc. 2d 343; 683 N.Y.S.2d 694; 1998 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 457



August 25, 1998, Decided



DISPOSITION:  [***1] Both application of the defendant are granted.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant, who was charged with sodomy, rape, sexual abuse, and endangering the welfare of a child, requested two judicial subpoenas duces tecum under N.Y. C.P.L.R. 2307 for records in the custody of the Department of Social Services (DSS).


OVERVIEW: Defendant contended he was entitled to production of confidential records regarding the complainant's former abuse reports made to the DSS. The court held that (1) upon an assertion of valid reasons, the confidentiality mandated by N.Y. Soc. Serv. Law §§ 372(4), 136(2) must yield to the right of the defendant to be provided with material necessary to his defense, (2) with regard to the first application, the defendant demonstrated that the prohibition of § 422(5) would deprive him of material necessary for his defense, therefore, (4) the prohibition was negated and the appropriate information must be admitted at trial. However, the court found that a portion of § 422(5) precluded admissibility of allegations of sexual abuse that were investigated and determined to be unfounded.


OUTCOME: The court granted the applications and ordered the two subpoenas to be issued for the records sought, noting they would be examined in camera to determine which material will be released to the defendant.


HEADNOTES

Crimes - Disclosure - Records Pertaining to Complainant in Custody of County Department of Social Services

1. Defendant is entitled to a judicial subpoena duces tecum for the production of foster care records pertaining to complainant in the custody of the County Department of Social Services (DSS) on the grounds that a portion of these records, which involve the same time frame as the sex offense crimes charged in the indictment, contain dates of the complainant's contact with defendant, her father, information regarding the complainant's sexual activity with other males, information of prior false allegations of sexual assault and statements of the complainant evidencing contact with the defendant. Social Services Law § 372 (4) (a) and § 136 (2) protect the confidentiality of foster care records and communications and information relating to a child receiving care from a social services agency. However, the statutory confidentiality of DSS records is not always sacrosanct and, upon an assertion of valid reasons as here, the confidentiality must yield to the right of defendant to be provided with material necessary to his defense.

Crimes - Disclosure - Records Pertaining to Complainant in Custody of County Department of Social Services - Unfounded Report of Sexual Abuse

2. Defendant is entitled to a judicial subpoena duces tecum for the production of records of an investigation of the complainant's prior allegations of sexual conduct conducted by the County Department of Social Services (DSS), which were determined to be unfounded, on the grounds that a portion of these records, which involve the same time frame as the sex offense crimes charged in the indictment, contain dates of the complainant's contact with defendant, her father, information regarding the complainant's sexual activity with other males, information of prior false allegations of sexual assault and statements of the complainant evidencing contact with the defendant. The statutory confidentiality of DSS records (see, Social Services Law § 372 [4] [a]; § 136 [2]) is not always sacrosanct and, upon an assertion of valid reasons as here, the confidentiality must yield to the right of defendant to be provided with material necessary to his defense. While Social Services Law § 422 (5) provides that an unfounded report shall not be admissible in any judicial or administrative proceeding or action, defendant demonstrated that the prohibition provided for in section 422 (5) would deprive him of material necessary for his defense and, therefore, such prohibition must be declared unconstitutional as applied to defendant and negatived and the appropriate information must be admitted at trial. The part of section 422 (5) which precludes admissibility, i.e., that allegations of sexual abuse were investigated and determined to be unfounded, renders the unfounded report impeachment material for cross-examination of the complainant.

 

645 of 992 DOCUMENTS


Village of Hoosick Falls v. Eastern Rensselaer County Solid Waste Mgmt. Auth.


98-492


SUPREME COURT OF NEW YORK, RENSSELAER COUNTY


178 Misc. 2d 44; 677 N.Y.S.2d 751; 1998 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 391



August 24, 1998, Decided


NOTICE:  [***1] EDITED FOR PUBLICATION


SUBSEQUENT HISTORY: As Corrected October 19, 1998.



DISPOSITION: Petition dismissed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner village filed a N.Y. C.P.L.R. 78 action against respondent, Eastern Rensselaer County Solid Waste Authority (Authority), seeking to annul and invalidate tax bills, to enjoin the Authority from issuing additional tax bills, an order to direct the Authority to account for tax revenues collected to date, and an order to direct the Authority to refund the tax bills collected.


OVERVIEW: The village maintained that the issuance of the tax bills violated the service agreement between the parties and that the public hearing at which the Authority adopted the formal resolution to issue the tax bills violated the notice provisions contained in N.Y. Pub. Auth. Law § 2050-ee (14). The Authority contended that it was authorized to bill taxpayers directly; and that the parties' service agreement had no application to the matter. The court dismissed the petition. The village did not have the authority to bring the proceeding in a representative capacity on behalf of other property owners. Under § 2050-ee (14) the Authority was granted the power to fix and collect rates, rentals, fees, and other charges for the use of its facilities or services rendered. The Authority thus had the power to issue the bills in question in conformity with § 2050-ee (14). It was not necessary for the Authority to advise in the public notice that property owners would be issued bills, inasmuch as the power to do so was inherent in the powers of the Authority. The failure to notice the public hearing in strict compliance with § 2050-ee (14) did not render the public hearing invalid.


OUTCOME: The court dismissed the village's petition and denied all relief.


HEADNOTES

Public Authorities - Solid Waste Management Authority - Standing of Municipal Member to Challenge Bills Issued by Authority to Property Owners

1. Petitioner village, a member of respondent Eastern Rensselaer County Solid Waste Management Authority which is a public benefit corporation created for the purpose of processing and/or disposing of solid waste generated by those towns and villages that elected to become members of the Authority, has standing in its capacity as a property owner to challenge the issuance of a bill by respondent for solid waste disposal services. Petitioner does not, however, have the authority to bring the proceeding in a representative capacity on behalf of other property owners located within the village.

Limitation of Actions - Four-Month Statute of Limitations - When Cause of Action Accrues

2. Petitioner village, a member of respondent Eastern Rensselaer County Solid Waste Management Authority which is a public benefit corporation created for the purpose of processing and/or disposing of solid waste generated by those towns and villages that elected to become members of the Authority, was not required to bring its CPLR article 78 proceeding challenging respondent's determination to issue bills to property owners for solid waste disposal services within four months of the deadline respondent had fixed to commence issuance of bills since petitioner's cause of action had not yet accrued at that time. It was not until more than one year after the deadline passed that respondent held a public hearing at which it adopted a budget and resolved to issue bills to property owners and then actually issued those bills; petitioner's proceeding, which was brought within the next four months, was therefore timely commenced. The Statute of Limitations does not begin to run until the party aggrieved by an administrative determination is notified of a determination that is unambiguous and certain in its effect, and finality does not occur until the administrative agency has arrived at a definitive position on the issue which inflicts actual concrete injury.

Public Authorities - Solid Waste Management Authority - Power of Authority to Bill Property Owners for Solid Waste Disposal Services

3. Respondent Eastern Rensselaer County Solid Waste Disposal Authority, a public benefit corporation created for the purpose of processing and/or disposing of solid waste generated by those towns and villages which elected to become members of the Authority, has the power under Public Authorities Law § 2050-ee (14) to issue bills to property owners for solid waste disposal services. The statute grants respondent the power to fix and collect "rates, rentals, fees and other charges" which "shall be a lien upon the real property" upon which services were provided, and directs respondent's treasurer to prepare and transmit to the respective legislative body of each town or village a list of properties where the payment of fees is in arrears, with the payments to be collected by each municipality and turned over to respondent's treasurer. Absent the issuance by respondent of bills for solid waste removal services, there could be no list of delinquent property owners to deliver to the municipalities for levy in tax bills as contemplated by the statute. Moreover, the service agreement between the parties does not prohibit respondent from directly billing property owners within petitioner village.

Public Authorities - Solid Waste Management Authority - Notice of Public Hearing to Establish Fees for Services Rendered - Sufficiency of Notice

4. In a proceeding brought by petitioner village to challenge the issuance to property owners of bills for solid waste disposal services by respondent Eastern Rensselaer County Solid Waste Disposal Authority, a public benefit corporation created for the purpose of processing and/or disposing of solid waste generated by those towns and villages which elected to become members of the Authority, respondent's failure to strictly comply with the notice requirements for noticing a public hearing as set forth in Public Authorities Law § 2050-ee (14) before holding the hearing at which it adopted a budget and resolved to issue bills to property owners does not render the hearing invalid. Although notice of the public hearing was published in a newspaper by respondent only eight days before the hearing was held and not 10 days before as required by Public Authorities Law § 2050-ee (14), that defect in the notice, in and of itself, is not sufficient to invalidate the actions taken at the public hearing. The text of the notice fully comported with the statute by advising that a public hearing would be held to establish and fix rates, rental fees and other charges. It was not necessary for respondent to advise in the public notice that property owners would be issued bills inasmuch as the power to do so is inherent in the powers of respondent.

 

646 of 992 DOCUMENTS


People v. McIntosh


Ind. No. 146/96, Motion # 17


COUNTY COURT OF NEW YORK, DUTCHESS COUNTY


178 Misc. 2d 433; 682 N.Y.S.2d 795; 1998 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 490



August 7, 1998, Decided


SUBSEQUENT HISTORY:  [***1] As Corrected November 16, 1998.



DISPOSITION: Motion denied.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant filed a motion for an order invalidating and striking down N.Y. Crim. Proc. Law § 400.27(11) to the extent that the second clause of the provision provided for a vague and standardless determination by a capital sentencing jury whether to impose a sentence of death or a sentence of life in prison without parole on defendant.


OVERVIEW: After being convicted of murder, defendant contested N.Y. Crim. Proc. Law § 400.27(11) to the extent that it provided a vague and standardless determination by a capital sentencing jury whether to impose a death sentence or sentence for life in prison without parole. The court denied defendant's motion because § 400.27 was constitutionally sound, the jury did not have unbridled discretion, and the statute permitted the jury to weight aggravating circumstances. The court found that the legislation was constitutionally sound because it was sufficiently narrow in its categories of capital crimes and a sentence could only be imposed if the jury found unanimously and beyond a reasonable doubt that there were aggravating factors that substantially outweighed the mitigating factors. The court found that the jury did not have unbridled discretion where the death sentence was impermissible unless the unanimously determined that the death sentence should be imposed. The court also noted that statutes were presumed constitutional.


OUTCOME: The court denied defendant's motion for an order invalidating and striking down a provision as vague and standardless used by a capital sentencing jury to determine defendant's appropriate punishment.


HEADNOTES

Crimes - Sentence - Constitutionality of Death Penalty Sentencing Provisions

 CPL 400.27 (11) (a), which provides that a jury may not impose a sentence of death unless it unanimously finds beyond a reasonable doubt that the aggravating factor(s) substantially outweigh the mitigating factor(s) established, if any, and unanimously determines that the penalty of death should be imposed, is constitutional. The death penalty may not be imposed under sentencing procedures that create a substantial risk that it will be inflicted in an arbitrary and capricious manner; thus, a State must establish rational criteria that narrow the decisionmaker's judgment as to whether the circumstances of a particular defendant's case meet the threshold. The Legislature has sufficiently narrowed its category of capital crimes by classifying homicides into six categories and providing that only defendants charged under Penal Law § 125.27 face the possibility of the death penalty. After a defendant is considered death-eligible, a sentence of death can only be imposed if the jury finds, unanimously and beyond a reasonable doubt, that there exist aggravating factors which substantially outweigh any mitigating factors. Moreover, the defendant may raise, subject to evidence rules, evidence relevant to any mitigating factor contained in CPL 400.27 (9), and reliable hearsay evidence in support of mitigation ( CPL 400.27 [6]). Once the jury determines a defendant is a member of the class made eligible for that penalty it may be given unbridled discretion in determining whether to impose that penalty. Also, CPL 400.27 limits the sentencing jury to consider only those aggravating factors proven beyond a reasonable doubt at trial and permits a jury to decline to impose the death penalty even though the aggravating circumstances outweigh the mitigating circumstances.

 

647 of 992 DOCUMENTS


People v. McIntosh


Ind. No. 146/96


COUNTY COURT OF NEW YORK, DUTCHESS COUNTY


178 Misc. 2d 427; 682 N.Y.S.2d 791; 1998 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 486



August 5, 1998, Decided


NOTICE:  [***1] EDITED FOR PUBLICATION


SUBSEQUENT HISTORY: As Corrected November 16, 1998.



DISPOSITION: Motion denied.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant was convicted of murder in the first degree, murder in the second degree, attempted murder in the first degree, assault in the first degree, and criminal possession of a weapon in the second degree. Defendant filed a motion for an order invalidating N.Y. Crim. Proc. Law § 400.27(10), which instructed the jury on the possible sentence if they could not agree on one. He also requested immediate sentencing on the noncapital counts.


OVERVIEW: Defendant was convicted of multiple counts of first and second-degree murder, as well as attempted murder, assault, and criminal possession of a weapon. The state filed notice under N.Y. Crim. Proc. Law § 250.40 that it sought the death penalty. Defendant sought the invalidation of N.Y. Crim. Proc. Law § 400.27(10), which instructed the jury that defendant would be sentenced to between 20 to 25 years to life if the jury could not reach a unanimous sentence. He also sought immediate sentencing on the non-capital counts. The court denied defendant's motions. The court did not believe that § 400.27(10) would have coerced jurors into voting for the death penalty because they knew that if they could not agree on a sentence, defendant might have received only 20 years imprisonment. If the jury was not given the information in § 400.27(10), wild speculation on the sentence could lead to acquittal. The language of the statute was mandatory and carried a strong presumption of validity. Defendant was not entitled to immediate sentencing on the non-capital counts because N.Y. Crim. Proc. Law § 390.20(4) required a presentence report prior to the imposition of an indeterminate sentence.


OUTCOME: The court denied defendant's motions for the invalidation of a state statute that informed the jury of defendant's possible sentence if the jury could not agree on a sentence and for immediate sentencing on the non-capital counts.


HEADNOTES

Crimes - Sentence - Constitutionality of Death Penalty Sentencing Provisions

CPL 400.27 (10), which requires the court to instruct a jury prior to the sentencing phase of a capital murder trial that the defendant will receive a sentence with a minimum term of between 20 to 25 years and a maximum term of life in the event the jury fails unanimously to agree on a verdict of either death or life imprisonment without parole at the conclusion of the sentencing proceeding, is constitutional on its face and as applied to the defendant whose jury rendered a decision of life imprisonment without parole on two counts of a murder in the first degree conviction but could not come to a unanimous determination on the other two counts of a murder in the first degree conviction. This statute is not fatally coercive nor otherwise constitutionally prohibited.
