Rather, the mandated instruction will prevent unacceptable speculation about the consequences of a nonunanimous verdict. In addition, the language of CPL 400.27 (10) is mandatory and this statute carries a strong presumption of validity, to be stricken as unconstitutional only as a last resort. In the absence of controlling Federal authority to the contrary, and because CPL 400.27 (10) is at least arguably valid, there is no basis to strike this section as unconstitutional.

 

648 of 992 DOCUMENTS


PEOPLE v. DONATO


Docket Nos. 30590-97, 30605-97, 30609-97, 30620-97, 30629-97, 30637-97, 30681-97, 30682-97, 30685-97, 30687-97, 30688-97, 30704-97, 30705-97, 30707-97, 30708-97, 30849-97, 30850-97, 30851-97, 30871-97, 30872-97, 30982-97, 31034-97, 31126-97, 31165-97, 31521-97


CITY COURT OF NEW YORK, NEW ROCHELLE


179 Misc. 2d 192; 684 N.Y.S.2d 394; 1998 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 619



July 17, 1998, Decided


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant filed a motion to dismiss criminal charges lodged against him for violations of New Rochelle, N.Y., Code (Code) art. II, § 213-5[E], based on the noise created by his barking dog. Defendant contended that § 213-5[E] was too vague to be capable of application consistent with due process.


OVERVIEW: Defendant had been cited numerous times for allowing his dog or dogs to bark continuously for up to at least 25 minutes at a time. Section 213-5[E] prohibited unnecessary noise generated by animals. In granting defendant's motion and dismissing the charges, the court held that the section was too vague in some critical respects. The court held that one of the standards by which the noise was to be measured, namely that it disturbed a "considerable" number of persons, was incapable of application, because while "considerable" reasonably meant more than 1 or 2, whether it meant 3, 4, or 10 was a mystery. Furthermore, it was unclear whether the requisite number of people had to be disturbed all at once, or whether sequential annoyance was adequate. The volume or intensity of noise was also not reasonably quantified. Thus the statute left too much discretion in police to say when it was violated, and was unconstitutionally vague.


OUTCOME: The court granted defendant's motion to dismiss the charges against him.


HEADNOTES

Constitutional Law - Validity of Statute - Vagueness - Statute Prohibiting Unnecessary Animal Noise

New Rochelle Code § 213-5 (E), which prohibits an animal owner from allowing the animal to cause "unnecessary noise", is unconstitutionally vague since it does not provide fair notice to a person of average intelligence that his or her contemplated conduct is forbidden by the statute, and does not provide sufficiently clear standards to those charged with enforcing it because the terms used to define "unnecessary noise" are capable of subjective measurement and/or interpretation. While the statute defines "unnecessary noise" as that which disturbs "a considerable number of persons" (New Rochelle Code § 213-4), it does not specify how many people constitute "a considerable number" or whether the requisite number of people have to be disturbed all at once. Nor does the statute specify what volume or intensity of noise, or what duration of the noise would constitute the kind of noise disturbance that would disturb a person of reasonable sensibilities, thereby leaving it up to the particular police officer investigating a complaint to determine whether there has been a violation by reference to the officer's own concept of reasonability. Accordingly, the charges against defendant for multiple violations of New Rochelle Code § 213-5 (E) for allowing his dog to bark inside his garage are dismissed.

 

649 of 992 DOCUMENTS


New York City Comm. for Taxi Safety v. New York City Taxi & Limousine Comm'n


Index No. 109457/98, Index No. 109981/98, Index No. 110336/98


SUPREME COURT OF NEW YORK, NEW YORK COUNTY


177 Misc. 2d 855; 677 N.Y.S.2d 449; 1998 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 350



July 2, 1998, Decided


NOTICE:  [***1] EDITED FOR PUBLICATION


SUBSEQUENT HISTORY: As Corrected September 14, 1998.



DISPOSITION: Petitioners' request for a judgment annulling the air conditioning regulation on the ground that it was adopted in violation of CAPA denied. Petitioners' request for a judgment annulling each of the other fifteen regulations denied.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner New York City Committee for Taxi Safety requested that the court declare null and void regulations adopted by respondent New York City Taxi and Limousine Commission and enjoin respondents from enforcing those regulations.


OVERVIEW: Respondent posted notice of a hearing on proposed regulations. After changing the location, respondent re-posted notice. The court refused to annul the regulations because respondent complied with the City Administrative Procedure Act (CAPA). The CAPA did not support rigidity and agencies could change location without postponing hearings for an additional 30 days. The court upheld most of the regulations because they were rationally related to legitimate governmental objectives. Respondent could require taxicab owners to require lists of all taxicabs in which he or she had a financial interest because respondent already had the information and having the owners compile the lists saved time and money. Respondent could not require taxicab owners to disclose other corporate ownerships because it was not rationally related to the legitimate governmental purpose of making sure that taxicab owners had sufficient income to operate their businesses and protect the public. The court held that respondent could regulate standards of passenger service. The court held that the regulations were not vague because individuals of ordinary intelligence were not forced to guess at their meanings.


OUTCOME: The court denied petitioner's request for a judgment annulling regulations adopted by respondent because respondent complied with the City Administrative Procedure Act, petitioner had an opportunity to be heard, and the regulations were rationally related to a legitimate government purpose. The court annulled respondent's financial disclosure regulation because it was not related to a legitimate governmental purpose.


HEADNOTES

Administrative Law - Rule Making - Notice of Change in Location of Public Hearing

1. Defendant New York City Taxi and Limousine Commission did not violate New York City Charter § 1043 (b), which requires that notice of the time and place of a public hearing on proposed agency rules be published 30 days prior thereto, when it published notice of the proposed rules over 30 days prior to the scheduled date, but thereafter changed the location of the hearing twice within that 30-day time period. The statute does not require new notice upon changing the location of a hearing. Moreover, defendant afforded the public and the taxicab industry adequate notice and opportunity to comment.

Administrative Law - Rule Making - Fact-Finding Hearing

2. Regulations promulgated by defendant New York City Taxi and Limousine Commission amending existing rules will not be declared invalid for defendant's failure to hold a fact-finding hearing. Regulations such as these carry a strong presumption of constitutionality including a rebuttable presumption of the existence of necessary factual support for their provisions, and judicial interference is not warranted if the regulations are supported by any known or assumed state of facts. The amendments are based on information which the Commission received as well as on its own perception of changes that should be made in the rules. The rationality of each of these regulations turns on whether they are reasonably related to legitimate governmental objectives, not on whether factual data establishes that these amendments are necessary.

Municipal Corporations - Regulation of Taxicab Business - Validity of Regulation Imposing Financial Disclosure Requirements on Taxicab and Limousine Industry

3. A regulation promulgated by defendant New York City Taxicab and Limousine Commission requiring that each officer or shareholder of a corporate taxicab owner disclose to the Commission every other licensed taxicab in which he or she has a financial interest (35 RCNY 1-02 [g]) is not invalid. The regulations previously required that corporate owners disclose the identity of all such officers and shareholders; thus, the Commission already has this information on file. The regulation advances the legitimate objective of facilitating the process of preparing a list as a matter of administrative convenience and efficiency. In addition, the Commission has broad authority to adopt regulations relating to the taxicab industry, and this information is relevant to the regulation of the industry. Moreover, this regulation does not conflict with any provision of the Business Corporation Law.

Municipal Corporations - Regulation of Taxicab Business - Validity of Regulation Imposing Disclosure Requirements on Taxicab and Limousine Industry

4. A regulation promulgated by defendant New York City Taxicab and Limousine Commission, which imposes on the officers and shareholders of a corporate taxicab owner and the corporation itself a duty to file a statement which discloses the individual and corporate assets, liabilities, income and net worth (35 RCNY 1-02 [l]), to enable the Commission to ensure that taxicab owners have sufficient income and assets to operate their businesses and to protect the public, is not rationally related to a legitimate governmental purpose and is, therefore, annulled. In the absence of a requirement that all corporate officers and shareholders maintain a minimum level of assets, the mandatory financial disclosure imposed by the regulation serves no apparent purpose. Thus, the regulation unnecessarily imposes stringent and onerous disclosure requirements upon officers and shareholders.

Municipal Corporations - Regulation of Taxicab Business - Validity of Regulation Amending Taxicab and Limousine Commission's Persistent Violator Program

5. A regulation promulgated by defendant New York City Taxicab and Limousine Commission to amend the Persistent Violator Program, under which penalties are imposed upon taxicab drivers who violate Commission driving rules, by adding a number of rules, eliminating the designation of three classes, establishing a point system and developing a new penalty system, is not invalid. The Commission has a right to make rules to ensure riders receive safe, courteous and responsible service; thus, the Commission may reasonably penalize taxicab drivers for conduct which falls short of an acceptable standard of service. Also, the standards of conduct are not void for vagueness since all of the terms used in describing conduct for which penalty points will be assessed may be given their commonly accepted meaning which, when placed in context, do not require speculation. Furthermore, review of the regulations and the penalties imposed for a violation thereof reveals that none of the penalties is shocking to one's sense of fairness in relation to the alleged conduct; they represent a rational and fair application of the Commission's rule-making authority and a proper discharge of its obligations to the public.

Municipal Corporations - Regulation of Taxicab Business - Validity of Rule Imposing Fines and Suspending or Revoking Licenses of Taxicab Owners

6. A regulation promulgated by defendant New York City Taxicab and Limousine Commission, which authorizes the Commission to impose fines and suspend or revoke the licenses of taxicab owners who "commit or attempt to commit, alone or in concert with another, any willful act of omission or commission which is against the best interest of the public, although not specifically prescribed in these rules" (35 RCNY 1-60 [b] [2]), is not void for vagueness. Matter of Fernandez v New York City Taxi & Limousine Commn. (193 AD2d 423) rejected the argument that Taxicab Drivers rule 109, which uses language identical to the language found in this rule, was unconstitutionally vague. Thus, this court is constrained to find that the regulation is not unconstitutionally vague on its face.

Administrative Law - Rule Making - Notice of Public Hearing

7. Defendant New York City Taxi and Limousine Commission complied with New York City Charter § 1043 (b), which requires that notice of the time and place of a public hearing on proposed agency rules be published 30 days prior thereto, when it provided 33 days' notice of a public hearing on an air-conditioning regulation, and three months after the public hearing the issue was raised for discussion and a vote at a Commission meeting without providing the public additional notice and an opportunity to be heard. The New York City Administrative Procedure Act does not mandate that public notice be provided every time a proposed regulation is discussed or considered at a public meeting. The Act merely requires that the public be given 30 days' advance notice of the opportunity to submit written comments and a public hearing on a proposed regulation.

 

650 of 992 DOCUMENTS


People v. Harris


Indictment 15265/96


SUPREME COURT OF NEW YORK, KINGS COUNTY


177 Misc. 2d 378; 676 N.Y.S.2d 458; 1998 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 282



June 30, 1998, Decided


NOTICE:  [***1] EDITED FOR PUBLICATION



DISPOSITION: Defendant's motion denied in its entirety.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant brought a motion to hold N.Y. Crim. Proc. Law § 400.27 (11)(a) unconstitutional on the grounds that the portion of the statute requiring a final determination of the appropriate sentence was vague and standardless, that such vagueness made the sentencing determination unreviewable, and that it created a risk of arbitrary and capricious sentencing.


OVERVIEW: Defendant claimed that because N.Y. Crim. Proc. Law § 400.27 (11) (a), the capital sentencing statute, required the jury to take two separate steps before it could render a death sentence, the absence of standards governing the second step left the jury impermissibly unguided. Defendant brought a motion to hold the statute unconstitutional on the grounds that the portion of the statute requiring a final determination of the appropriate sentence was vague and standardless, that such vagueness made the sentencing determination unreviewable, and that it created a risk of arbitrary and capricious sentencing. The court rejected defendant's argument and denied his motion because the statute met constitutional standards and appropriately reflected a sentencing jury's power to exercise considerable discretion. The court also held that the statute empowered the jury to exercise its mercy function and decline to impose the death penalty even if it has found, after weighing aggravating and mitigating factors, that death would be warranted.


OUTCOME: The court denied defendant's motion to have the capital sentencing statute declared unconstitutional.


HEADNOTES

Crimes - Sentence - Constituti onality of Death Sentencing Provisions

1. CPL 400.27 (11) (a), which provides that a jury may not impose the death sentence unless it unanimously finds beyond a reasonable doubt that the aggravating factors substantially outweigh the mitigating factors and, thereafter, unanimously determines death should be imposed, is not unconstitutional to the extent that it requires the jury to take two separate steps before it may render a death sentence, since the statute meets constitutional standards and appropriately reflects a sentencing jury's power to exercise considerable discretion. A capital sentencing scheme must narrow the class of death-eligible murders and reasonably justify the death sentence. Statutory aggravating factors serve this purpose by circumscribing the class of persons eligible for the death penalty. Penal Law § 125.27 (1) details 12 separate aggravating categories of murder which, if proven at the guilt phase of trial, are incorporated into the sentencing phase and deemed proven beyond a reasonable doubt. Also, the jury must consider the character and record of the individual offender and the circumstances of the particular offense. Further, CPL 400.27 (9) provides a wide range of mitigators to be presented to the jury, which may be proffered to the sentencing jury as reliable hearsay and need be established only by a preponderance of the evidence ( CPL 400.27 [6]). The statute provides an additional safeguard in that the jury then unanimously must determine whether death is appropriate. At this stage articulated specific guidelines are not constitutionally required.

Crimes - Sentence - Constituti onality of Death Sentencing Provisions

2. The permissive use of the word "may" in CPL 400.27 (11) (a), which provides that any member or members of a jury who find a mitigating factor to have been proven by the defendant by a preponderance of the evidence "may" consider such factor established regardless of the number of jurors who concur that the factor has been established, does not render the statute unconstitutional but, rather, permits individual jurors who have already found specific mitigating factors proven by a preponderance of the evidence to independently evaluate and weigh the mitigation evidence they found established regardless of other jurors' views of that same evidence, thereby encouraging jurors to maintain conscientiously held positions.

 

651 of 992 DOCUMENTS


People v. Harris


Indictment 15265/96


SUPREME COURT OF NEW YORK, KINGS COUNTY


177 Misc. 2d 259; 676 N.Y.S.2d 798; 1998 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 270



June 15, 1998, Decided


NOTICE:   [***1] EDITED FOR PUBLICATION


SUBSEQUENT HISTORY: As Corrected July 27, 1998. As Revised July 31, 1998.
Later proceeding at People v. Harris, 177 Misc. 2d 378, 676 N.Y.S.2d 458, 1998 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 282 (N.Y. Sup. Ct., 1998)



DISPOSITION: Defendant's motion is denied.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant was charged by indictment with committing three murders in the course of the same criminal transaction, attempted murder followed by one of the three intentional murders, intentionally killing one of three persons, and attempting to kill another in the course of and in furtherance of robbery in the first or third degree. He filed a pretrial motion to dismiss all but one of the counts on the ground of prejudicial multiplicity.


OVERVIEW: The three alleged murders and the alleged attempted murder with which defendant was charged were committed at a social club and in the course of a short period. The court rejected defendant's argument that because N.Y. Crim. Proc. Law § 300.40 (3) required the court to submit to the jury at the sentencing stage all first degree murder charges on which it had returned guilty verdicts the jury could be misled as to the number of aggravating factors to be considered. The court noted that, based on the evidence adduced at trial, it was possible that not all the counts would be submitted to the jury. The court also ruled that the potential problem could be avoided through appropriate instructions. The court ruled that the multiple counts in the indictment properly avoided the situation where the prosecution would be bound to a single theory as to the chronological order of the alleged crimes. The court ruled that the indictment adequately linked the murder charges to the robbery charges to satisfy the jurisdictional requirements for a charge of intentional felony murder in the first degree. The court ruled that there were no fatal defects in the grand jury proceedings.


OUTCOME: The court ruled that the counts of the indictment were not fatally multiplicious and denied defendant's pretrial motion to dismiss multiple counts of the indictment.


HEADNOTES

Crimes - Indictment - Capital Murder - Multiplicitous Counts

1. In the prosecution of defendant for murder in the first degree under Penal Law § 125.27 (1) (a) (viii) based on charges that defendant intentionally killed three persons and attempted to kill a fourth in a social club within a very brief time period, six counts of the indictment charging defendant with the intentional killing of two victims in different sequences, and three counts charging him with an attempted murder of a surviving victim followed by one of the three intentional murders, are not multiplicitous ( CPL 200.20 [1]) on the ground that the jury could be misled about the number of aggravating factors to be considered because CPL 300.40 (3) requires the court to submit to the jury at the sentencing stage of the trial all first degree murder charges on which it has returned guilty verdicts. The challenged counts are all necessary in order to accurately reflect the offenses with which defendant is charged. Penal Law § 125.27 (1) (a) (viii) requires the prosecution to prove the intentional killing of one victim, and the intent to cause serious physical injury or death to at least one other person. Although the prosecution, in its response to defendant's discovery demands, has provided a chronological account as to the sequence and manner in which it claims defendant killed three persons, it should not be irrevocably bound by this theory. Assuming arguendo that the court does submit more than one count charging murder in the first degree to the jury and that defendant is convicted on all submitted, the court can anticipate and avoid the possibility that jurors at the sentencing stage will view each count as a separate aggravating factor and be more inclined to vote for the death sentence by its instructions to the jury at the sentencing stage. The rules against multiplicity are designed to assure that a defendant is not punished more than once for the same crime; they do not preclude jury consideration of multiple offenses containing overlapping elements.

Crimes - Indictment - Capital Murder

2. The counts of an indictment charging defendant with intentional felony murder in the first degree in violation of Penal Law § 125.27 (1) (a) (vii), attempted felony murder in the first degree, are not jurisdictionally defective on the ground that they omit an element of the crime because they allege only that the victim "was killed while the defendant was in the course of and in furtherance of committing" the robbery and do not also allege as required under section 125.27 (1) (a) (vii) that the victim was killed in furtherance of the robbery. The language in the challenged counts is sufficiently clear to satisfy the requirements of CPL 200.50.

 

652 of 992 DOCUMENTS


People v. Marchetta


Docket No. 98Q003489


CRIMINAL COURT OF THE CITY OF NEW YORK, QUEENS COUNTY


177 Misc. 2d 701; 676 N.Y.S.2d 791; 1998 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 333



June 12, 1998, Decided


NOTICE:   [***1] EDITED FOR PUBLICATION



DISPOSITION: Defendant's motion to suppress his written statement, given on August 16, 1997, denied.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Before the court was defendant's motion to suppress a written statement he provided in the criminal action against him that charged defendant with menacing in the second degree and disorderly conduct.


OVERVIEW: The victims were followed in their car by another driver. When they stopped, the other driver brandished a weapon and made threatening statements. The victims reported the incident at the local police station where they found that the other driver, the defendant, was a uniformed police officer. As a result of their complaint, the defendant's supervisor indicated that he needed to get a written statement from defendant regarding the incident. Defendant was formally charged, and at his trial, defendant filed a motion to suppress the written statement. Defendant claimed that the statement was entitled to use immunity, or in the alternative, it should have been suppressed because it was obtained in violation of his constitutional rights. The court held that the statement made by defendant did not reflect the type of overt threat of imminent sanctions that would have invoked the protection of immediate suppression, thereby cloaking defendant's statement in use immunity. In addition, the totality of the circumstances did not necessitate reading defendant Miranda warnings prior to obtaining the statement.


OUTCOME: Defendant's motion to suppress his written statement was denied.


HEADNOTES

Courts - New York City Criminal Court - Power to Suppress Statements Pursuant to Terms of Collective Bargaining Agreement

1. In the prosecution of defendant, a Port Authority police officer, for menacing in the second degree and disorderly conduct, Criminal Court of the City of New York cannot grant suppression of a written statement made by him to the Port Authority police at the direction of a superior officer on the ground that he is entitled to use immunity with regard to the statement pursuant to a collective bargaining agreement. Defendant seeks an interpretation of the terms and conditions of the collective bargaining agreement, a ruling that a breach of that contract occurred and retroactive enforcement of the rights he feels are due under that agreement, which is not the type of relief Criminal Court is empowered to grant. The jurisdiction of the Criminal Court is restricted to hearing, trying and determining criminal charges, specifically misdemeanors and petty offenses. A remedy for a breach of the collective bargaining agreement is available to the defendant in the proper forum if or when he seeks redress for any job-related sanctions he might incur. Thus, in determining whether the defendant's statement should be suppressed, the proper avenue of inquiry for Criminal Court is that set forth in Miranda v Arizona (384 US 436): to analyze the particular circumstances as presented at the time the statement was made and decide whether they were likely to exert such pressure on the defendant as to disable him from making a free and rational choice.

Crimes - Confession - Statement by Public Employee Made Pursuant to Employer's Rule

2. In the prosecution of defendant, a Port Authority police officer, for menacing in the second degree and disorderly conduct, a motion by defendant to suppress a written statement made by him to the Port Authority police at the direction of a superior officer on the ground that he is entitled to use immunity with regard to the statement pursuant to a collective bargaining agreement is denied. It is unconstitutional to condition public employment upon a waiver of the privilege against self-incrimination. While Rule 4 of the collective bargaining agreement provides use immunity to employees who give statements in connection with criminal investigations under the potential penalty of dismissal from employment for failure to cooperate, defendant gave his statement after being read Rule 3, which provides that all employees "must cooperate in authorized investigations of any act, omission or occurrence in or upon Port Authority property ... provided, however, that this rule shall not require any employee to give evidence against himself in connection with this investigation of an alleged act of misconduct on his part." Defendant was never informed that he would be dismissed or experience any definite job-related sanction if he refused to submit a written statement.While the defendant was told he "must" cooperate, he was also distinctly informed that he was not required to "give evidence against himself in connection with [the] investigation." The advisory to the defendant that if he chose to speak, anything he said could be used in evidence at a disciplinary proceeding would, if anything, have the effect of chilling a reasonable person's desire to speak, not coercing a potentially inculpatory statement. Alerting the defendant that a disciplinary proceeding "may be commenced against him" did not amount to such an explicit threat that use immunity would have automatically attached to any statement he made.The fact that the District Attorney's office was contacted prior to the statement being obtained is not determinative. Nor were Miranda warnings required, as the elements of custody and interrogation were absent.

 

653 of 992 DOCUMENTS


People v. Harris


Indictment 15265/96


SUPREME COURT OF NEW YORK, KINGS COUNTY


177 Misc. 2d 165; 676 N.Y.S.2d 440; 1998 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 269



June 11, 1998, Decided


NOTICE:  [***1] EDITED FOR PUBLICATION


SUBSEQUENT HISTORY: As Corrected July 27, 1998. As Revised August 31, 1998.



DISPOSITION: Defendant's motion denied.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant filed a motion to find N.Y. Crim. Proc. Law § 400.27(3) unconstitutional on its face because at a capital sentencing proceeding it barred defendant from challenging aggravating factors proven at trial and required the sentencing jury to deem those aggravating factors established beyond a reasonable doubt.


OVERVIEW: Defendant sought an order finding N.Y. Crim. Proc. Law § 400.27(3) unconstitutional on its face. The court denied defendant's motion, holding that the statute was constitutional. At the sentencing phase, the only aggravating factors that the jury could have considered were those proven beyond a reasonable doubt at trial. The existence of such aggravating factors or the extent to which they were proven at trial could not be relitigated. Defendant could challenge the facts behind the aggravating factors by presenting as mitigating evidence any other circumstance concerning the crime, his state of mind, or condition at the time of the crime that would have been relevant to mitigation or punishment for the crime. Defendant had no constitutional right to relitigate the aggravating factors in order to create a lingering doubt in the jurors' minds. The only evidence the prosecution could have introduced at the sentencing phase was as rebuttal to the mitigating evidence offered by defendant.


OUTCOME: Defendant's motion to find New York's capital sentencing statute unconstitutional was denied.


HEADNOTES

Crimes - Murder - Capital Murder - Constitutionality of Limitation on Challenge to Aggravating Factors at Sentencing Proceeding

 CPL 400.27 (3) is not unconstitutional on its face on the grounds that the statute, by prohibiting a direct challenge to the existence of aggravating factors, fails to allow for individualized sentencing, permits the imposition of the death penalty based on aggravating factors that defendant has not had a meaningful opportunity to litigate, and improperly limits defendant's presentation of mitigating evidence. Rather, defendant may challenge the facts behind the aggravating factors by presenting as mitigating evidence "any other circumstance concerning the crime, the defendant's state of mind or condition at the time of the crime ... that would be relevant to mitigation or punishment for the crime." ( CPL 400.27 [9] [f].) Further, defendant has no constitutional right to relitigate the aggravating factors in order to create a lingering doubt in the jurors' minds.

 

654 of 992 DOCUMENTS


People v. Barrows


Indictment No. 15872/96


SUPREME COURT OF NEW YORK, KINGS COUNTY


177 Misc. 2d 712; 677 N.Y.S.2d 672; 1998 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 332



June 9, 1998, Decided


NOTICE:  [***1] EDITED FOR PUBLICATION



DISPOSITION: The motion to set aside the verdict of guilty under Count 1 is denied.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant challenged his conviction for one count of promoting obscene sexual performance by a child in violation of N.Y. Penal Law § 263.10 and two counts of attempted disseminating indecent material to minors in the first degree in violation of N.Y. Penal Law §§ 110.00 and 235.22; he moved pursuant to N.Y. Crim. Proc. Law § 330.30(1), to set aside the verdict on the grounds that the statutes at issue were unconstitutional.


OVERVIEW: The case involved the use of the Internet as a means by which defendant, operating from his personal computer in Connecticut, solicited an individual represented to be a 13 year old female in New York for sexual purposes. To the extent that the communications involved in count 7, which involved the alleged inducement of the child to masturbate during the cyberchat, were practically limited to pure speech, the court found that they fell within the parameters of Reno. Both as applied to the case and in light of the nature of the Internet, N.Y. Penal Law § 235.22 was unconstitutionally vague in also chilling First Amendment-protected communications between adults via the Internet. To the extent that such communications involved interstate transmissions, the statute also violated the Commerce Clause. The verdict as to count 7 was set aside. The verdict as to count 8, involving defendant's entry into the State of New York for the purpose of engaging in live sex acts, was similarly set aside. However, the court found no merit in defendant's constitutional challenge to N.Y. Penal Law § 263.10, and denied the motion to set aside the verdict of guilty under count 1.


OUTCOME: The motion to set aside the verdict of guilty under counts 7 and 8 were granted; the motion with respect to count 1 was denied.


HEADNOTES

Crimes - Disseminating Indecent Material to Minors - Constitutionality of Statute 

1. A verdict convicting defendant of attempted disseminating indecent material to a minor in the first degree (Penal Law § 235.22) for communicating on the Internet with someone he thought was a 13-year-old girl, sending her sexual stories and photographs and allegedly inducing the child to masturbate during a cyberchat, is dismissed. The actual "conduct", as prohibited by the statute, amounts only to speech in its purest form and the action which the statute seeks to prevent is required to be taken by the recipient of the message. Generally, such suggestions are likely to be "mere words", unaccompanied by any overt or provable acts. To the extent such communications are practically limited to pure speech both as applied to the particular facts of this case and the international and geographically borderless nature of the Internet, the statute is unconstitutionally vague in chilling First Amendment-protected communications between adults via the Internet. The statute fails to provide a clear and predictable definition of what transmissions will be deemed patently offensive to prevailing standards of a universal audience. To the extent that such communications involve interstate transmissions, Penal Law § 235.22 also violates the Commerce Clause.

Crimes - Disseminating Indecent Material to Minors - Constitutionality of Statute 

2. A verdict convicting defendant of attempted disseminating indecent material to a minor in the first degree (Penal Law § 235.22) for communicating on the Internet with someone he thought was a 13-year-old girl, sending her sexual stories and photographs, arranging a meeting with her in New York and then traveling from his home in Connecticut to meet her, is dismissed. To the extent that satisfaction of Penal Law § 235.22 (2) is premised upon defendant's entry into this State for the purpose of engaging in live sex acts with the "child" such purposeful acts evidence an intent to commit crime within this State and, thus, the constraints of the Commerce Clause do not apply. However, the statute is facially unconstitutional under the First Amendment. Penal Law § 235.22 (1) has been found void for vagueness and the statute reads in the conjunctive, i.e., requiring both the prohibited transmission via the Internet under subdivision (1) and the use of such communication to importune, invite or induce some action on the part of the minor under subdivision (2). The absence of a clear and uniform national standard of what is appropriate for children and the differences regarding moral standards among communities exacerbates the risk that section 235.22 will be deliberately misapplied to effect a chill over ways of thinking that are deemed wrong by some. Given the unique and pervasive nature of the Internet together with the inherent vagueness of the terms "importune", "invite", "induce" and "for his benefit", used to describe elements of a crime which requires action by a third person, enforcement of section 235.22 affords the opportunity to insidiously chill virtually all communication on the Internet related to sex, whether protected by the First Amendment or not and regardless of the age of the discoursers.

Crimes - Promoting Obscene Sexual Performance by Child - Constitutionality of Statute 

3. A verdict convicting defendant of promoting an obscene sexual performance by a child (Penal Law § 263.10) for transmitting to another person via Internet a photograph depicting a nude, pre-or early adolescence female in genital sexual intercourse will not be set aside since section 263.10 is neither vague nor overbroad and does not violate the Commerce Clause of the US Constitution. Penal Law article 263 was enacted for the protection of the child performers who were necessarily exploited and abused in the process of creating the pornographic communication. Child pornography is not protected under the First Amendment and the production and dissemination of child pornography is statutorily proscribed in virtually all States and by Federal legislation. The inherently illegal, indeed criminal, nature of the conduct required in producing child pornography itself justifies removing such expression from the protection of the First Amendment.

 

655 of 992 DOCUMENTS


People v. Doyle


Ind. No.: 1920-93


SUPREME COURT OF NEW YORK, SUFFOLK COUNTY


177 Misc. 2d 74; 675 N.Y.S.2d 854; 1998 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 260



June 9, 1998, Decided


NOTICE:  [***1] EDITED FOR PUBLICATION



DISPOSITION: The court will entertain a motion to reargue based upon constitutional grounds, with proper service upon the Attorney General.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant challenged the sex offender board's assessment that classified him as a sex offender with a level three risk of recidivism.


OVERVIEW: Defendant was convicted to two counts of second-degree sexual abuse. Defendant sought to have his recidivism risk assessment reduced from a three to a one. The court denied defendant's application to review the assessment of his recidivism risk because there was no statutory procedural basis for the court to review defendant's classification under Megan's law, N.Y. Correct. Law § 168-f. The court also noted that defendant could not challenge the constitutionality of the statute because he did not serve the attorney-general.


OUTCOME: The court dismissed defendant's petition to have his recidivism risk assessment reduced. The court indicated that it would permit a motion to reargue upon constitutional grounds with proper service on the attorney general.


HEADNOTES

Crimes - Sex Offenders - Sex Offender Registration Act - Jurisdiction of Court to Review Risk Level Classification by Department of Probation

An application by defendant, a convicted sex offender on probation at the time the Sex Offender Registration Act (Correction Law art 6-C [Megan's Law]) took effect, to challenge his classification as a level 3 risk by the Board of Examiners of Sex Offenders through the Department of Probation is denied as the sentencing court does not have jurisdiction to review risk level classifications by the Department of Probation. The advisory power of a criminal court ends with the imposition of sentence which marks the termination of the criminal action, and the classification of a sex offender is neither an amendment to the judgment of conviction, nor a resentencing. Risk level determinations are a consequence of convictions for sex offenses, but are not a part of the criminal action or its final adjudication. Moreover, neither the Criminal Procedure Law nor Megan's Law specifically provides the court with jurisdiction. The court will, however, entertain a motion to reargue based upon constitutional grounds with proper service on the Attorney-General.

 

656 of 992 DOCUMENTS


Matthews v. Barrios-Paoli


Index No. 404575/97


SUPREME COURT OF NEW YORK, NEW YORK COUNTY


178 Misc. 2d 602; 676 N.Y.S.2d 757; 1998 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 325



May 29, 1998, Decided


NOTICE:  [***1] EDITED FOR PUBLICATION


SUBSEQUENT HISTORY: As Corrected December 21, 1998.



DISPOSITION: The motions to intervene are granted, without opposition; however, the certification of the class appears to moot the intervention issue. Preliminary injunction granted and the cross motion for summary judgment denied.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff students filed motions for a preliminary injunction and for class certification, and defendant agencies filed a cross motion for summary judgment in the students' action, which alleged that their public assistance workfare assignments interfered with their high school studies, in violation of the New York State Constitution and state law.


OVERVIEW: The agencies assigned the 19-year-old high school students to workfare assignments as a condition of their families receiving public assistance. The students filed an action challenging the agency action because it failed to allow homework time and failed to create an employability plan for the students as required by the N.Y. Soc. Serv. Law § 336. The parties filed several motions, and the court granted the students motions for a preliminary injunction and for class certification and denied the agencies' summary judgment motion. The court found that the work assignments interfered with the students' educational activities in violation of the statute and that insofar as the implementing regulations narrowed educational activities to classroom attendance and eliminated homework they were unduly restrictive. The court held that the balance of the equities favored the students. The court also noted that the students' failure to challenge their assignments at fair hearings did not bar the claims because the administrative exhaustion rule did not apply where the agency's action was challenged as unconstitutional or resort to the administrative remedy would have been futile.


OUTCOME: The court granted the students' motions for a preliminary injunction and for class certification and denied the agencies' cross motion for summary judgment.


HEADNOTES

Social Services - Public Assistance - Conflict between Work Experience Program Assignments and Educational Activities

Plaintiffs, 19-year-old high school students who receive Safety Net Assistance benefits and have been assigned to the Work Experience Program (WEP), are entitled to a preliminary injunction staying the enforcement of their WEP obligations until there is a determination as to whether their WEP assignments interfere with their high school studies in violation of the New York Constitution and State law. It is likely that it will be shown that the WEP assignments interfere with Social Services Law § 336-a, which requires that 18 and 19 year olds be assigned to educational activities unless it is determined that educational activities are not appropriate; that WEP assignments be consistent with a participant's employability plan and not interfere with educational activities assigned pursuant to an employability plan; and that WEP assignments not be made prior to conducting an assessment and developing an employability plan. Plaintiffs are assigned to pursue and complete their high school education, but are not given enough time to do so because under the State regulations (12 NYCRR 1300.9 [c] [5]) only the hours spent attending class are counted towards the 40 hours per week that the participants are required to be participating in assigned activities; they are expected to be working at their WEP assignments for the rest of that time. No consideration is given for time spent doing homework, independent studies, tutoring, and other extracurricular activities, and these regulations will likely be found to be unduly restrictive. Moreover, none of the plaintiffs have been assigned to work pursuant to an employability plan as required. Plaintiffs have also shown irreparable harm in that the income that they and often their families need to survive will be impacted if they fail to show up for work, or they may fail school if they choose the work assignment over school. The balance of the equities favors plaintiffs, and in fact defendants will benefit greatly from facilitating the completion of plaintiffs' education.

 

657 of 992 DOCUMENTS


People ex rel. Smith v. Greiner


Index No. 97/19476


SUPREME COURT OF NEW YORK, WESTCHESTER COUNTY


176 Misc. 2d 931; 674 N.Y.S.2d 588; 1998 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 209



May 28, 1998, Decided


NOTICE:  [***1] EDITED FOR PUBLICATION


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner prisoner brought a habeas corpus proceeding pro se against respondent Superintendent of Sing Sing Correctional Facility (Superintendent).


OVERVIEW: The prisoner was convicted of robbery in the first degree and sentenced to an indeterminate term of imprisonment of 8 to 16 years. On July 15, 1992, the prisoner was released to parole supervision. He was subsequently arrested on a parole violation warrant on April 23, 1997. Following a final revocation hearing held on October 3, 1997, the prisoner was found to have violated the terms of his parole release. Upon this finding, the Administrative Law Judge (ALJ) followed the guidelines of N.Y. Comp. Codes R. & Regs. Tit. 9, § 8005.20(c), which was adopted earlier in 1997. This recently enacted regulation placed the prisoner in a category that mandated the imposition of at least 15 months' additional incarceration upon a finding of violation. Therefore, the ALJ determined that the prisoner would be held in custody until his maximum expiration date of August 18, 1998. The prisoner then brought a writ of habeas corpus pro se against the Superintendent. The court sustained his writ, by holding that § 8005.20(c), was unconstitutional as applied to him because it violated the Ex Post Facto Clause of U.S. Const. art. I, § 10, as it was retrospective and it worked to his detriment.


OUTCOME: The court sustained the prisoner's writ of habeas corpus pro se that was brought against the Superintendent.


HEADNOTES

Constitutional Law - Ex Post Facto Law - Regulation Establishing Guidelines for Punishing Parole Violators

 9 NYCRR 8005.20 (c), which was adopted in early 1997 and established parole revocation guidelines, is unconstitutional as applied to petitioner, who was convicted in 1983, released on parole in 1992 and found to have violated the terms of his parole in April 1997, in that it violates the Ex Post Facto Clause (US Const, art I, § 10). A law is unconstitutional as ex post facto when it is both retrospective and works to the disadvantage of the offender affected by it. Here, the amendment is retrospective. Whatever consequences flow from a finding that a defendant has violated parole are ultimately related to the punishment imposed for the predicate crime, not for the conduct that triggered the violation proceeding. Also, application of this regulation works to petitioner's detriment. Under the regulations in effect at the time of the commission of the original offense, a parole violator could have been restored to parole supervision or resentenced to incarceration for as little as 90 days. Now the minimum period of additional incarceration is 15 months. Although administrative guidelines that seek to clarify what factors an administrative agency should apply in exercising discretion do not offend the constitutional proscription on ex post facto laws, an enactment such as this, which imposes a previously nonexistent mandatory minimum penalty, removes discretion and this, if retrospective, is subject to ex post facto rejection.

 

658 of 992 DOCUMENTS


People v. Henderson


98-438


JUSTICE COURT OF NEW YORK, VILLAGE OF BRIARCLIFF MANOR, WESTCHESTER COUNTY


177 Misc. 2d 672; 677 N.Y.S.2d 669; 1998 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 353



May 26, 1998, Decided


NOTICE:  [***1] EDITED FOR PUBLICATION



DISPOSITION: The court cannot grant the defendant's request for leave to make additional motions. Application is, at best, premature and is denied without prejudice to any subsequent application upon good cause shown.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant was charged with aggravated harassment in the second degree, N.Y. Penal Law § 240.30(1). Defendant filed a motion to dismiss the information on the basis of her contention that § 240.30(1) was unconstitutionally vague and overbroad.


OVERVIEW: Defendant allegedly sent a threatening letter to an elected official's home address. Section § 240.30(1) provided that a person is guilty of aggravated harassment in the second degree when, with intent to harass, annoy, threaten or alarm another person, he or she communicates or causes a communication to be initiated by mechanical or electronic means or otherwise, with a person, anonymously or otherwise, by telephone, or by telegraph, mail or any other form of written communication, in a manner likely to cause annoyance or alarm. The court reasoned that the content of the letter and the forwarding of such a letter to the residence of a public official, taken together, were clearly within the "hard core" of the proscribed activities of the harassment statute. Noting that the statements in the letter were profane, extremely inflammatory, and, by any measure, threatening, the court held that the statute was constitutional in its application to the alleged conduct of defendant.


OUTCOME: The court denied defendant's motion to dismiss the information.


HEADNOTES

Constitutional Law - Validity of Statute - Aggravated Harassment

 Penal Law § 240.30 (1) which provides that a person is guilty of aggravated harassment in the second degree when, with intent to harass, annoy, threaten or alarm another person, he or she, inter alia, communicates with another person by mail in a manner likely to cause annoyance or alarm, is not unconstitutional as applied to the alleged conduct of defendant in mailing to a public official at his residence address a letter that was not only profane but contained statements that were extremely inflammatory and, by any measure, threatening. The content of the defendant's letter and the forwarding of such a letter to the residence of a public official, taken together, are clearly within the "hard core" of the proscribed activities of the harassment statute. The core of the statute is the proscription against communication, even if unobjectionable in content, which is directed to an unwilling listener under circumstances wherein substantial privacy interests are being invaded in an essentially intolerable manner. The harassment statute punishes annoying and harassing communications transmitted directly to the complainant. Moreover, the content of the letter as described in the information was not in the nature of a political grievance but was extremely threatening in tenor. The statements that "you should be killed instantly" and "be attacked in a violent and brutal way" are clearly not constitutionally protected forms of speech. Additionally, although the recipient of the letter was an elected public official, even an elected official has a substantial privacy interest with respect to communications at his residence.

 

659 of 992 DOCUMENTS


People v. Gilmour


Indictment No. 326/97


SUPREME COURT OF NEW YORK, RICHMOND COUNTY


177 Misc. 2d 250; 678 N.Y.S.2d 436; 1998 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 243



May 21, 1998, Decided


NOTICE:  [***1] EDITED FOR PUBLICATION



DISPOSITION: Defendant's motion for discovery and a bill of particulars granted to extent that the information sought is provided in the voluntary disclosure form, People's answer and other papers and documents already served. In addition, defendant is to be provided with liberal access to the alleged physical evidence for the purposes of inspection, examination and analysis by such scientific, medical and other experts as he may deem advisable, under such circumstances regarding the preservation of that evidence as the People may require. Defendant's motion for a Huntley/Dunaway hearing granted. Defendant's further motion for a Massiah hearing is desired, without prejudice to renewal in the event that facts are adduced to draw into question the People's representation that "no law enforcement personnel were involved in any statement made to a 'non-law enforcement person'" in this case. A Sandoval/Ventimiglia hearing granted and reserved for trial. The People are directed to provide the defendant with any exculpatory material that should come into their possession pursuant to Brady v. Maryland. The court reserves decision on defendant's motion to suppress [***2] physical evidence.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant filed a motion to dismiss the indictment against him for possession of child pornography in violation of N.Y. Penal Law § 263.16.


OVERVIEW: Defendant was charged with, inter alia, possessing a quantity of child pornography. Defendant sought to dismiss the indictment on the grounds that N.Y. Penal Law § 263.16 was unconstitutional, investigation by the state of internet dissemination of child pornography was a violation of the Commerce Clause of the Federal Constitution, and the New York State Attorney-General lacked the statutory authority to supersede the Richmond County District Attorney for the purposes of the prosecution. The court held that 1) the available affirmative defense of showing that an accused believed in good faith that the minor depicted in prohibited material was 16 years old did not constitute a shift of the burden of proof to the accused, 2) the statute was not unconstitutional because it had a scienter element identical to that approved in New York v. Ferber, 458 U.S. 747 (1982), 3) the statute was not preempted by federal legislation, 4) the use of the internet as an investigative tool did not violate the dormant commerce clause of the federal Constitution, and 5) the jurisdiction of the Attorney-General was properly invoked pursuant to N.Y. Exec. Law § 63(3).


OUTCOME: The court denied defendant's motion to dismiss the indictment.


HEADNOTES

Crimes - Possessing Sexual Performance by Child - Constitutionality of Statute 

Defendant's motion to dismiss the counts of an indictment charging him with possessing a sexual performance by a child in violation of Penal Law § 263.16 on the ground that the statute is unconstitutional because it contains no scienter requirement as to the minority of the children appearing in the proscribed pornographic depictions is denied as the statute specifically requires that a defendant have "know[ledge of] the character and content" of the material possessed, which knowledge constitutes scienter, in addition to requiring proof that the child appearing in the performance is less than 16 years old. Once the People have met the significant burden of proving that the unknown child performer was less than 16 years of age, the defendant is given an opportunity to escape liability by showing his good-faith reasonable belief that the child depicted was 16 years of age or older (Penal Law § 263.20 [1]). The requirement of a defendant's knowledge of the nature and content of the proscribed material, coupled with the ready availability of an affirmative defense, constitutes a constitutionally permissible degree of scienter for a State statute in the area of regulating child pornography, where States are entitled to greater leeway.

 

660 of 992 DOCUMENTS


Butler v. Wing


Index No. 403520/97


SUPREME COURT OF NEW YORK, NEW YORK COUNTY


177 Misc. 2d 779; 677 N.Y.S.2d 216; 1998 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 349



May 20, 1998, Decided


NOTICE:  [***1] EDITED FOR PUBLICATION



DISPOSITION: Plaintiffs' motions for partial summary judgment and for class certification granted as indicated. Motion for leave to intervene denied as unnecessary. Defendants' cross-motion denied in all respects and their second, fourth, sixth, seventh and eighth affirmative defenses dismissed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: In a declaratory judgment action challenging a state program, plaintiff taxpayers moved for partial summary judgment on several causes of action and for class certification. Defendants, Department of Taxation and Finance (DTF) and Office of Temporary and Disability Assistance (OTDA), cross-moved for partial summary judgment on several affirmative defenses, or for an order converting the action to a N.Y. C.P.L.R. art. 78 proceeding.


OVERVIEW: The Statewide Offset Program, N.Y. Tax Law §§ 171-d and 171-f , which allowed the DTF to offset the taxpayers' state income tax refunds against debts they owed to state agencies, was challenged as unconstitutional. The court ruled that the action was not suitable for conversion because more was sought than an art. 78 proceeding permitted. The taxpayers' motion for class certification was granted because the members would have been oppressively burdened if required to commence individual actions. The taxpayers were granted summary judgment on their claim that the OTDA violated their due process rights because the tax offset procedure authorized by § 171-f did not notify of the possible preclusive effect of the failure to take timely action to contest the underlying debt. Regulations promulgated by the OTDA that denied the taxpayers an opportunity for a hearing and limited the available defenses were invalidated as inconsistent with the provisions of the statute. Summary judgment was granted on the claim that the taxpayers' rights were violated by the use of preoffset notices that did not provide information about the nature of the alleged overpayment.


OUTCOME: The taxpayers' motions for partial summary judgment and for class certification were granted. A motion for leave to intervene was therefore denied as unnecessary. The cross-motion for partial summary judgment was denied and the corresponding affirmative defenses were dismissed.


HEADNOTES

Actions - Conversion of One Form of Action to Another - Constitutional Challenge to Statewide Offset Program

1. Plaintiffs' declaratory judgment action challenging the constitutionality of the Statewide Offset Program (Tax Law §§ 171-d, 171-f), which allows the Department of Taxation and Finance to offset taxpayers' State income tax refunds against debts owed by the taxpayers to New York State agencies, will not be converted to a CPLR article 78 proceeding. Plaintiffs challenge both the practices of defendants, as they pertain to the individual plaintiffs and taxpayers in general, as well as the constitutionality of the statute upon which defendants base their actions. Thus, plaintiffs seek more than may be permitted under an article 78 proceeding and their challenge is properly the subject of a declaratory judgment action.

Actions - Class Actions - Challenge to Statewide Offset Program

2. The named plaintiffs are granted class certification to represent a class of plaintiffs in a declaratory judgment action challenging the constitutionality of the Statewide Offset Program (Tax Law §§ 171-d, 171-f) which allows the Department of Taxation and Finance to offset taxpayers' State income tax refunds against debts owed by the taxpayers to New York State agencies. Plaintiffs can fairly and adequately protect the interests of the class members and defendants have failed to propose any form of relief that purports to protect the rights of taxpayers in the event the challenge has merit. Commencement of individual actions and/or filing of motions for leave to intervene will be oppressively burdensome for the members of the proposed class and class action certification will promote the efficient use of judicial resources. Further, stare decisis will not adequately protect class members. Common practices of defendant agencies and common statutory requirements of the Tax Law as they pertain to due process, predominate over any differences between the procedures employed by each agency and to the extent differences are significant, the class can be divided into subclasses.

Constitutional Law - Due Process of Law - Statewide Offset Program

3. The Statewide Offset Program (Tax Law §§ 171-d, 171-f), which allows the Department of Taxation and Finance to offset taxpayers' State income tax refunds against debts owed by the taxpayers to New York State agencies, is unconstitutional on its face and as implemented by defendant Office of Temporary and Disability Assistance (OTDA) as violative of the Due Process Clauses of the US and NY Constitutions. In determining whether a statute affords due process the following factors are considered: the private interest; the risk of erroneous deprivation and the probable value of additional safeguards; and the government's interest. Taxpayers have a property and private interest in tax refunds that is protected by due process safeguards. Here, the notice sent to plaintiffs pursuant to the statutory scheme mentions an outstanding debt but does not inform the debtor of possible preclusive effects of failing to challenge the debt, nor does it adequately convey information essential to an evaluation of whether to challenge the determination. This initial notice eventually leads to certification by OTDA that there is a past-due legally enforceable debt, which means the State agency has made a final administrative determination regarding the overpayment issue (Tax Law § 171-f [3] [b]). Thus, there is a risk of error in the procedure. Also, the government's interest in collecting the debt is not outweighed by due process considerations and taxpayers' rights to their own earned income.

Administrative Law - Validity of Regulation - Statewide Offset Program

4. Regulations promulgated under the Statewide Offset Program (Tax Law §§ 171-d, 171-f) by the Office of Temporary Disability and Assistance (OTDA), which provide that a preoffset notice must inform taxpayers of their right to present written arguments and evidence in support of any defense to the offset (18 NYCRR 374.2 [e]) and which limit the taxpayers' defenses to four specifically delineated situations (18 NYCRR 374.3), fail to comply with the statutory scheme, and, thus, are invalid. Tax Law § 171-f (3) (c) gives the taxpayer the option of choosing to appear at a conference to present oral arguments and evidence or of only submitting written evidence and arguments in support of a defense. Further, Tax Law § 171-f includes no limitation of defenses.

Constitutional Law - Due Process of Law - Statewide Offset Program

5. In implementing the Statewide Offset Program (Tax Law §§ 171-d, 171-f), which allows the Department of Taxation and Finance to offset taxpayers' State income tax refunds against debts owed by the taxpayers to New York State agencies, defendant Office of Temporary Disability and Assistance (OTDA) violated plaintiff taxpayers' rights under 18 NYCRR 374.2, which requires that a preoffset notice include a statement identifying the nature of the overpayment and the amount of the overpayment that is due, when the notices it sent failed to provide any information regarding the nature of the overpayment, the time period for which the claim is being made or the basis for the claim. The omission of these elements vital to beneficiaries who wish to object to the overpayment constitutes a denial of due process under the US and NY Constitutions. The taxpayers are not provided with enough information to discern whether they can assert defenses such as full or partial repayment.

 

661 of 992 DOCUMENTS


People v. Harris


Indictment 15265/96


SUPREME COURT OF NEW YORK, KINGS COUNTY


177 Misc. 2d 160; 677 N.Y.S.2d 659; 1998 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 263



May 15, 1998, Decided


NOTICE:  [***1] EDITED FOR PUBLICATION


SUBSEQUENT HISTORY: As Corrected July 27, 1998. As Revised August 31, 1998.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant filed a motion for the finding that N.Y. Crim. Proc. Law § 400.27(10) was unconstitutional pursuant to the Fifth, Sixth, Eighth, and Fourteenth Amendments to the United States Constitution and N.Y. Const. art. I, §§ 1-6, 11, 12, and 14. N.Y. Crim. Proc. Law § 400.27(10) provided a deadlocked jury instruction in a capital case.


OVERVIEW: Defendant argued that § 400.27(10) would have coerced a sentencing jury into rendering a death verdict and that as a coercive pressure on jury deliberations it would have led to an arbitrary and unreliable verdict. The court agreed and granted defendant's motion. The court held that a grave and substantial risk existed that the statutory instruction could have coerced a verdict of death, which was an unconstitutional result. The court decided that the question of the constitutionality of the statute was ripe for resolution. The court also determined that the instruction had the likely practical effect of deliberately injecting uncertainty into the sentencing proceedings. Because any criminal defendant, especially a capital defendant, was entitled to the uncoerced verdict of the jury and the statutory instruction had the potential of coercing a unanimous death sentence, the statute was unconstitutional because it undermined the reliability of the jury's verdict.


OUTCOME: The court granted defendant's motion and held that the statutory deadlock instruction was unconstitutional.


HEADNOTES

Crimes - Murder - Capital Murder - Constitutionality of Instruction to Sentencing Jury Regarding Sentencing Procedure if Jury is Deadlocked

 CPL 400.27 (10), which requires the court in a capital murder prosecution to "instruct the jury that in the event the jury fails to reach [a] unanimous agreement with respect to the sentence, the court will sentence the defendant to a term of imprisonment with a minimum term of between twenty and twenty-five years and a maximum term of life", is unconstitutional as there is a grave and substantial risk that the statutory instruction could coerce a verdict of death. The instruction has the unforeseen but likely practical effect of deliberately injecting uncertainty into the sentencing proceeding in that it alerts the jurors to the possibility that if they do not reach a unanimous verdict defendant may within 20 or 25 years be released from custody. Jurors favoring life without parole may relinquish their conscientiously held views and join the majority in voting to impose the death penalty to avoid the possibility of a potentially lighter sentence if they see as a real prospect defendant's eventual return to society, and thus the mandated instruction has the strong potential of acting as a thumb on death's side of the scale.

 

662 of 992 DOCUMENTS


People v. Hankin


Doc. No. 97K011682


CRIMINAL COURT OF THE CITY OF NEW YORK, KINGS COUNTY


177 Misc. 2d 116; 675 N.Y.S.2d 792; 1998 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 227



May 14, 1998, Decided


NOTICE:  [***1] EDITED FOR PUBLICATION



DISPOSITION: Motion to dismiss granted. Second information dismissed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant filed a motion for dismissal of the second accusatory instrument filed by the prosecution, following the court's dismissal of the first information, in which defendant was charged with one misdemeanor count under N.Y. Jud. Law § 482 and one misdemeanor count of falsifying business records in the second degree under N.Y. Penal Law §175.05.


OVERVIEW: Defendant accepted an unsolicited offer by a state government informant, posing as a private investigator, to refer a client with a personal injury case, followed by the signing of a retainer agreement by defendant and an undercover police officer, posing as the accident victim and client, who was brought to defendant by the informant. The trial court dismissed the first information, and defendant filed a motion to dismiss the second accusatory instrument. The court granted the motion to dismiss. The prosecution did not make any substantial changes from the way § 175.05 was pleaded, nor did it proceed by way of motion to reargue or notice of appeal. The N.Y. Jud. Law § 482 count was substantially revised; however, the mere fact that an investigator came into contact with a potential client who needed a referral to a lawyer did not mean that the investigator actually, affirmatively solicited that client for the lawyer. The statute was not violated by mere referral of legal business. The pleading did not indicate solicitation by defendant, and that flaw was fatal to the prosecution. The statute was unconstitutional as applied to defendant's charged conduct.


OUTCOME: The court dismissed the second accusatory instrument filed by the prosecution, following the court's dismissal of the first information, in which defendant was charged with one misdemeanor count of employing a person for the purpose of soliciting legal business and one misdemeanor count of falsifying business records in the second degree.


HEADNOTES

Crimes - Solicitation of Law Clients - Sufficiency of Information

1. The count of a misdemeanor information charging defendant with violating Judiciary Law § 482, which prohibits an attorney from employing any person for the purpose of soliciting legal business, supported by allegations that on several past occasions an informant posing as a private investigator referred personal injury claimants to defendant for legal representation and that on each of those occasions defendant paid the informant a sum of money for the referral, and that discussions and negotiations between the defendant and the informant for payment in his case, as well as the payment itself, were handled after the retainer agreement was signed by the defendant and an undercover agent posing as the accident victim, is dismissed as legally insufficient. The allegation regarding past practice between the defendant and the investigator may satisfy the required element of employment in the statute for pleading purposes. However, referral of legal business is not synonymous with the solicitation of such business and not equally violative of this statute. The statute seeks to prevent harmful effects on the public and potential clients, who may be pressured, misled or otherwise wrongfully induced by nonlawyers to engage the services of a lawyer. The prosecution does not claim such conduct took place. Active solicitation necessarily includes the initiation of contact by the solicitor and involves efforts to obtain by asking or persuading, implying a personal petition.

Parties - Standing - Constitut ionality of Statute Penalizing Attorney for Solicitation of Clients

2. Defendant who was charged with violating Judiciary Law § 482, which prohibits an attorney from employing any person for the purpose of soliciting legal business, has standing to challenge the statute's constitutionality. This statute regulates primarily content-based commercial speech and related conduct, and defendant has standing to challenge the statute if the commercial speech concerns lawful activity and is not misleading. The acquisition, whether by referral or solicitation, of clients by or on behalf of admitted lawyers is a lawful activity, notwithstanding that it can be performed in an improper way and is subject to regulation. Neither the manner nor the content of the speech and conduct in this case as pleaded was misleading in any way.

Constitutional Law - Validity of Statute - Statute Penalizing Attorney for Solicitation of Clients

3. Judiciary Law § 482, which prohibits an attorney from employing any person for the purpose of soliciting legal business, is unconstitutional for overbreadth as applied to defendant, who allegedly paid an informant posing as a private investigator a sum of money for referring personal injury claimants to him for legal representation. In commercial speech cases, a determination of constitutionality involves analysis of whether the expression is protected by the First Amendment, the governmental interest is substantial, the regulation directly advances the governmental interest, and the regulation is more extensive than necessary to serve that interest. The State's substantial interest is in avoiding evils to the public and potential clients which are worthy of proscription, particularly when caused or facilitated by nonlawyers, who are not subject to the same professional regulation and discipline as attorneys. Nevertheless, the statute criminalizes any use of nonlawyers, however straightforward and innocuous, to recruit legal business and does not restrict or refine its scope to proscribe generic types of coercive or fraudulent solicitation tactics, or in any other way limit its reach. To the extent it may be argued that the very act of solicitation implies, at a minimum, pressure tactics, no such tactics were used here, but that did not stop the prosecution from bringing the criminal action.

 

663 of 992 DOCUMENTS


Gelston v. New York State Div. of Hous. & Community Renewal


INDEX NO. 4814/98


SUPREME COURT OF NEW YORK, QUEENS COUNTY


177 Misc. 2d 431; 676 N.Y.S.2d 765; 1998 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 310



May 11, 1998, Decided


NOTICE:  [***1] EDITED FOR PUBLICATION



DISPOSITION: CPLR 213-a and the limitations provisions set forth in the Rent Regulation Reform Act of 1997 are valid, and they were properly applied by the Commissioner of the DHCR in his decision and order of January 15, 1998 and this decision was neither arbitrary nor capricious, and had a reasonable basis in the law and the record. Plaintiffs are not entitled to enjoin the DHCR from applying these statutes. Plaintiffs have failed to establish any claim under 42 USC §§ 1983 and 1988. Plaintiffs' claims regarding the hardship application, and a prior order of the DHCR are not properly before this court, and, will not be considered. Plaintiffs are not entitled to any further stay of the landlord-tenant proceeding.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner tenants filed a N.Y. C.P.L.R. art. 78 proceeding by which they sought a declaration that N.Y. C.P.L.R. 213-a and 1997 N.Y. Laws 46 were unconstitutional and orders that would enjoin respondent New York State Division of Housing and Community Renewal (DHCR) from utilizing the laws in its determination of rent overcharges, grant relief for civil rights violations, grant attorney fees, and grant a stay of landlord-tenant proceedings.


OVERVIEW: The tenants took occupancy in 1985 and filed a rent overcharge complaint in 1990. The rent administrator determined that the tenants were paying less than the legal regulated rent and imposed a rent freeze because the owner had not served an amended initial registration form in 1985. The rent administrator determined that there was an overcharge resulting from the freeze. The tenants filed a petition for administrative review (PAR), challenging the calculations. The owner served the registration form and filed a PAR, alleging that there was no overcharge. DHCR granted the owner's PAR and denied the tenants' PAR on grounds that rental events occurring more than four years before filing a complaint were not subject to challenge. The tenants refused to pay the legal rent, alleged hardship, and sought a stay of a landlord-tenant proceeding. The court held that the New York City, NY, Admin. Code § 26-516 (a)(amended) was constitutional. The tenants had no vested property interest in the rent freeze. The rent administrator's order became an intermediate, nonbinding order upon the filing of the PARs by the tenants and owners.


OUTCOME: The challenged provisions were valid and they were properly applied by DHCR. The tenants were not entitled to enjoin the DHCR from applying the statutes, failed to establish a civil rights violation, and were not entitled to a stay of the landlord-tenant proceeding. The hardship application and a prior order of the DHCR were not properly before the court and were not considered.


HEADNOTES

Constitutional Law - Validity of Statute - Rent Regulation Reform Act of 1997

The Rent Regulation Reform Act of 1997 (L 1997, ch 116) which provides, inter alia, that an award in a residential rent overcharge action may not be based upon an overcharge having occurred more than four years before the complaint is filed, and precludes examination of the rental history of the housing accommodation prior to the four-year period preceding the filing of the complaint ( CPLR 213-a; Rent Stabilization Law of 1969 [Administrative Code of City of NY] § 26-516 [a] [2]) is constitutional on its face; accordingly the Division of Housing and Community Renewal appropriately refused to examine issues raised on appeal by petitioner tenants who filed an overcharge complaint in June 1990, based on the owner's failure to serve the tenants with an amended initial registration form in 1985, more than four years prior to the filing. The tenants have not shown that this legislation is so lacking in reason that it is essentially arbitrary. The amendments did not create, diminish or abrogate the tenants' right to commence and maintain the proceeding. Also, the law in effect at the time of commencement as well as the amendments limit the award for a rent overcharge proceeding to the four-year period preceding the complaint, and limit the examination of the rental history to the same four-year period. The tenants' claim in support of their constitutional challenge, that they have a vested property interest in the Rent Administrator's order which was based on events that occurred more than four years prior to the filing, is without merit. An individual has neither a vested right to rent control nor a vested interest in a rule of law or policy which entitles him or her to have such law or policy remain unaltered for his or her benefit. Moreover, the order became an intermediate nonbinding order upon the filing of the parties' appeals.

 

664 of 992 DOCUMENTS


People v. Couser


Indictment # 97-743-1,2, Index # 97/735


COUNTY COURT OF NEW YORK, ONONDAGA COUNTY


176 Misc. 2d 101; 674 N.Y.S.2d 887; 1998 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 163



May 6, 1998, Decided


NOTICE:  [***1] EDITED FOR PUBLICATION



DISPOSITION: Court adheres to its prior determination.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: At the prosecution's request, the County Court, Onondaga County (New York), granted reargument on its determination that N.Y. Penal Law § 125.27(1)(a)(vii) defining first degree murder, was unconstitutional because it violated the U.S. Const. and N.Y. Const. art I § 6 due process guarantees. The Attorney General appeared pursuant to N.Y. Exec. Law § 71.


OVERVIEW: After the court determined that N.Y. Penal Law § 125.27(1)(a)(vii) defining first degree murder, was unconstitutional because it violated the U.S. Const. and N.Y. Const. art. I § 6 due process guarantees, the court granted reargument so the Attorney General could appear pursuant to N.Y. Exec. Law § 71. Part of a state's responsibility was to define the crimes for which death may be the sentence in a way that obviated standardless sentencing discretion. It was one thing to "interpret" and another to "define" terms in statutes, and therefore it was not for any court to give it a definition It was the legislature's function to provide that meaning. The term "command" appeared to narrow the subclass of defendants convicted as accessories to only those determined to have "commanded" the killing, but the dilemma was that the term "command" was not "undefinable;" it was undefined by the legislature.


OUTCOME: The court's determination that N.Y. Penal Law § 125.27(1)(a)(vii) defining first degree murder was unconstitutional because it violated U.S. Const. and N.Y. Const. art I § 6 due process guarantees was confirmed on reargument because the term "command" was not "undefinable;" it was undefined by the legislature.


HEADNOTES
