Constitutional Law - Validity of Statute - Commander Portion of First Degree Murder Statute 

Reargument of defendant's motion to dismiss the count of the indictment charging defendant with first degree murder in violation of Penal Law § 125.27 (1) (a) (vii) is granted, and upon reargument the court adheres to its prior determination (see, 176 Misc 2d 86) that to the extent Penal Law § 125.27 (1) (a) (vii) seeks to impose accessorial liability through the "command" term borrowed from Penal Law § 20.00, the failure of either section to define what constitutes a "command" renders the statute unconstitutionally vague in violation of the due process guarantees of both the Fourteenth Amendment of the US Constitution and article I, § 6 of the NY Constitution. 

 

665 of 992 DOCUMENTS


People v. Harris


Indictment 15265/96


SUPREME COURT OF NEW YORK, KINGS COUNTY


177 Misc. 2d 102; 675 N.Y.S.2d 743; 1998 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 237



May 1, 1998, Decided


NOTICE:   [***1] EDITED FOR PUBLICATION


SUBSEQUENT HISTORY: As Revised July 23, 1998.



DISPOSITION: Defendant's motion is denied.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant moved to dismiss the capital murder indictment issued pursuant to N.Y. Penal Law § 125.27 or, alternatively, to strike the death notice filed by the district attorney pursuant to N.Y. Crim. Proc. Law § 250.40.


OVERVIEW: Defendant was charged with capital murder. He moved to dismiss the indictment or to strike the death notice filed by the district attorney. He contended that New York's statutory scheme for selecting candidates for the death penalty violated due process and the prohibition against cruel and unusual punishment. He claimed that it was an impermissible delegation of legislative authority. He argued that N.Y. Crim. Proc. Law § 250.40 must contain specific standards and a detailed procedure for deciding in which cases to seek the death penalty. In denying the motion, the court held that (1) the legislature was not required to set standards for deciding in which cases to invoke § 250.40 and seek the death penalty; (2) prosecutors had wide discretion to charge offenses under the law, and their decisions were generally beyond judicial review; (3) defendant made no charge of discriminatory intent by the prosecution in seeking the death penalty; and (4) section 250.40 was constitutional because it genuinely narrowed the class of persons eligible for the death penalty and reasonably justified the imposition of a more severe sentence on defendant compared to others found guilty of murder.


OUTCOME: The court denied defendant's motion to dismiss the indictment against him or, in the alternative, to strike the death notice filed by the district attorney.


HEADNOTES

Crimes - Murder - Constitutionality of Capital Murder Statute - Prosecutorial Discretion

New York's statutory scheme for selecting candidates for the death penalty does not violate due process of law and the constitutional prohibition against cruel and unusual punishment afforded to criminal defendants by the New York and Federal Constitutions nor impermissibly delegate legislative authority to the prosecutors of the State's 62 counties on the ground that New York's statutory scheme provides no guidelines or procedures for the prosecution to follow in selecting those cases in which it will seek the death penalty. To pass constitutional muster the legislation need not contain specific standards and detailed procedures for the charging authorities to follow in determining the cases in which it will invoke the provisions of CPL 250.40 for seeking the death penalty. Under the long and widely accepted concept of prosecutorial discretion, prosecutors are given wide latitude to charge offenses under the law, and prosecutors in capital cases are not held to a higher standard of accountability. A capital sentencing scheme must genuinely narrow the class of persons eligible for the death penalty and must reasonably justify the imposition of a more severe sentence on the defendant compared to others found guilty of murder, and the New York statute meets this standard.

 

666 of 992 DOCUMENTS


People by Vacco v. Chazy Hardware


INDEX NO. 36083, RJI NO. 98-0038


SUPREME COURT OF NEW YORK, CLINTON COUNTY


176 Misc. 2d 960; 675 N.Y.S.2d 770; 1998 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 232



April 24, 1998, Decided


NOTICE:  [***1] EDITED FOR PUBLICATION


SUBSEQUENT HISTORY: As Corrected August 3, 1998.



DISPOSITION: Respondent's motion for discovery and inspection has been rendered moot by this Court's decision on the merits of the petition and is denied.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner, state attorney general, initiated a case against respondent hardware store for violation of the price gouging statute, N.Y. Gen. Bus. Law § 396-r, and sought injunctive relief, an accounting, and restitution to all entitled consumer. The hardware store filed a motion to dismiss and a motion for discovery and inspection of the attorney general's records and policies.


OVERVIEW: The hardware store secured the purchase of electric generators from a supplier after an ice storm left thousands without electricity. The hardware store took orders for the generators on Saturday, and opened for business on Sunday to distribute the generators. The hardware store then increased the price of the generators that had not been preordered. The attorney general instituted a case under § 396-r for price gouging. The hardware store filed a motion to dismiss and a motion for discovery and inspection. The court found that the hardware store was a merchant as contemplated by § 396-r. The court held that the hardware store's Sunday price for the same generators was unconscionably excessive and granted the attorney general's request for injunctive relief and restitution. The court enjoined the hardware store from selling or offering to sell electric generators for an amount that represented an unconscionably excessive price during any abnormal disruption of the market for generators. The court denied the hardware store's motion for discovery and inspection because the issue was rendered moot by the court's decision of the petition on the merits.


OUTCOME: The court denied the hardware store's motion for discovery and inspection because the issue was rendered moot by the court's decision on the merits.


HEADNOTES

Consumer Protection - Price Gouging - Portable Electric Generators Sold during Power Failure - Hardware Store Owner as Merchant

1. In a special proceeding brought by the Attorney-General against respondent hardware store in which it is alleged that respondent is guilty of "price gouging" in violation of General Business Law § 396-r for selling electric generators at an unconscionably excessive price during a severe ice storm, respondent's defense that it is not a "merchant" within the meaning of the statute because it was not in the business of selling electric generators prior to the ice storm is without merit. Although respondent only had one generator in its inventory for the 15 months prior to the ice storm, there is no evidence that it was for respondent's own use and thus respondent is a merchant selling consumer goods as contemplated by General Business Law § 396-r (2).

Consumer Protection - Price Gouging - Portable Electric Generators Sold during Power Failure - Unconscionably Excessive Price

2. In a special proceeding brought by the Attorney-General against respondent hardware store in which it is alleged that respondent is guilty of "price gouging" in violation of General Business Law § 396-r for selling electric generators at an unconscionably excessive price during a severe ice storm, the petition for injunctive relief, restitution, and a civil penalty is granted as respondent's price of $ 1,190 on Sunday, January 11, 1998, for the same two models of generators that were sold the previous day for $ 780 and $ 890 (and which respondent had purchased for $ 533 and $ 656, respectively), is grossly disparate from the Saturday prices and not justifiable under the statute. Respondent's Sunday price of $ 1,190 constituted a markup of 93% and 59% over all costs claimed by respondent to be associated with the procurement and sale of the two models of generators. The January ice storm, which left thousands of homes and businesses without power, created an abnormal disruption in the market for consumer goods and services, and electric generators fall within the scope of such goods vital and necessary for the health, safety and welfare of consumers, as required by General Business Law § 396-r.

 

667 of 992 DOCUMENTS


W.J.F. Realty Corp. v. State


INDEX NO.: 94-22784


SUPREME COURT OF NEW YORK, SUFFOLK COUNTY


176 Misc. 2d 763; 672 N.Y.S.2d 1007; 1998 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 160



April 22, 1998, Decided


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff freeholders challenged the Long Island Pine Barrens Protection Act, N.Y. Envtl. Conserv. Law chs. 262 and 263 (the Act), as effecting an unconstitutional per se physical taking, a temporary regulatory taking of property without compensation under the New York Constitution, and a violation of federal due process and equal protection rights.


OVERVIEW: Several freeholders challenged the application of the Act to their property. The court considered the balance between the rights of landowners and the collective right to preserve natural resources. The freeholders alleged that the Act, as written and applied, effected a per se physical taking, a regulatory taking, a temporary regulatory taking of property without compensation under the New York Constitution, a violation of Federal and State constitutional due process, a violation of equal protection rights under 42 U.S.C.S. § 1983, an inverse condemnation, and a de facto appropriation of property. The court, after examining the history of freeholder rights, as well as the duty of the government as the guardian of natural resources, held that the Act promoted a legitimate governmental interest in a constitutionally permissible manner. The court therefore held for defendant, the State of New York.


OUTCOME: The court granted judgment in favor of the State of New York, holding that the Act promoted a legitimate governmental interest in a constitutionally permissible manner.


HEADNOTES

Constitutional Law - Validity of Statute - Long Island Pine arrens Protection Act

The Long Island Pine Barrens Protection Act ( ECL 57-0103 et seq.), which, under the doctrine of public trust, preserves the natural resources of the region, is constitutional facially and as applied to plaintiff property holders since it promotes a legitimate government interest in a constitutionally permissible manner. Legislative actions are given a presumption of constitutionality and a plaintiff bears the burden to establish unconstitutionality beyond a reasonable doubt. This Act satisfies due process requirements and the need for tangible compensation subject to judicial review. Under the Act, the Pine Barrens Commission oversees administration and grants building permits for owners who can demonstrate hardship. The statute requires either condemnation/compensation or the granting of a building permit. The Commission makes a final decision on permit applications within 60 days, and the Act provides for judicial review. If an uncompensated taking has occurred, the Commission must set aside the determination of the governing body or acquire the land under the power of eminent domain. The compensation provision, which includes a transfer of development rights (TDR), is constitutional since a TDR is one of several options, and TDR provisions assure preservation of the very real economic value for the development rights as they existed when still attached to the underlying property.

 

668 of 992 DOCUMENTS


N.Y. State Crime Victims Bd. v. T.J.M. Prods.


Index No.: 401695/97


SUPREME COURT OF NEW YORK, NEW YORK COUNTY


176 Misc. 2d 777; 673 N.Y.S.2d 871; 1998 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 178



April 22, 1998, Decided


NOTICE:  [***1] EDITED FOR PUBLICATION



DISPOSITION: Defendants' motions to dismiss the complaint granted.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendants, mobster witness, author, corporation, agent, publisher, and movie rights owner, filed motions to dismiss the amended complaint of plaintiff New York State Crime Victims Board (board), which alleged violation of the Son of Sam Act, N.Y. Exec. Law § 632-a.


OVERVIEW: The board alleged that the mobster witness was paid for assisting with the writing of a book on the mob in violation of § 632-a. The motions to dismiss alleged that the board failed to state a claim under § 632-a or alternatively that the statute was unconstitutional. The court agreed that the board failed to state a claim and hence did not reach the constitutional question. In support of said conclusion, the court noted that the Son of Sam Act required notice to the board of contracts for or payment of any profit from a charged or convicted crime under state law but the mobster witness was convicted of federal law; compared N.Y. Exec. Law § 621(3), where the definition of crime was broader than the definition contained in N.Y. Exec. Law § 632-a(1)(a); compared the Son of Sam Act to its predecessor; and compared the treatment of similar language in other New York statutes. Also in support of the dismissal, the court held that the board failed to state a claim as to the publisher, and the movie rights owner, because such were not in privity of contract with the mobster witness, and as to the mobster witness due to lack of allegations of violating the statute.


OUTCOME: The court granted the motions to dismiss.


HEADNOTES

Crimes - Crime Victims Board - Son of Sam Law - Application to Person Convicted of Federal Crimes

1. An action under the Son of Sam Law (Executive Law § 632-a) against several entities and individuals associated with the writing and publication of a book which recounts the life of defendant, who was convicted of Federal racketeering crimes, is dismissed, since the Son of Sam Law reaches only "profits from the crime" committed by a person "charged or convicted" of a felony "defined in the Penal Law" or any other law of this State (Executive Law § 632-a [1] [a]). The word "defined" refers to a criminal charge or conviction pursuant to New York's Penal Law, and not to charges or convictions based on criminal laws of other jurisdictions. When the Legislature intends statutory consequences to flow upon criminal convictions from other jurisdictions, it embodies that intent in statutory language. That the Legislature intended a narrower definition is evident from Executive Law § 621 (3), contained in the same article as section 632-a (1) (a), which broadly defines "crime" to include an act which would constitute a crime as defined in and proscribed by law, and would have embraced defendant's conviction. Also, the former Son of Sam Law contained a broader definition of crime that would have embraced defendant's conviction.

Crimes - Crime Victims Board - Son of Sam Law

2. An action under the Son of Sam Law (Executive Law § 632-a) is dismissed as against defendants publishing entities, film corporation and a former member of a crime family, all of whom are associated with the writing and publication of a book which recounts the life of defendant criminal who was convicted of racketeering charges, since none of these defendants are alleged to have entered into an agreement with the defendant criminal for payment to him of profits from the crimes of which he was convicted. The duty to provide notice of agreements involving "profits from a crime" applies only to a person or entity who "contracts for, pays, or agrees to pay any profit from a crime, to a person charged with or convicted of that crime" (Executive Law § 632-a [2] [a]). The current version of the Son of Sam Law, unlike its predecessor, does not reach agreements with the representative or assignee of a person charged with or convicted of a crime. The Board's attempt to bring defendant criminal, the publishers and the film corporation within the ambit of the statute by alleging that they entered into a "scheme" to circumvent the statute does not state a cause of action.

 

669 of 992 DOCUMENTS


Lang v. Pataki


INDEX NO. 404573/97


SUPREME COURT OF NEW YORK, NEW YORK COUNTY


176 Misc. 2d 676; 674 N.Y.S.2d 903; 1998 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 175



March 30, 1998, Decided


NOTICE:  [***1] EDITED FOR PUBLICATION



DISPOSITION: Plaintiffs' motion for a preliminary injunction and class certification denied.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff tenants moved for a preliminary injunction against defendant State, as well as a class certification, regarding the amendments to N.Y. Real Prop. Acts. Law §§ 745(2) and 747-a, which dealt with deposit requirements and expedited schedules for adjudication.


OVERVIEW: The tenants asserted that they were at risk of wrongful eviction based on the allegedly unconstitutional laws. The tenants argued that the laws deprived tenants of a property interest in violation of due process because its restrictions on tenant requested adjournments, absent a deposit, denied tenants the time necessary to be heard at a meaningful time and in a meaningful manner. They also contended that a tenant may be denied adjournments needed to prepare for trial and may be penalized for delays caused by the court considering a pretrial motion. They then claimed that the provisions violated due process by depriving a tenant of the right to a hearing on defenses before payment. The State countered that the tenant's due process rights were protected by the fact that the statute provided for a trial, albeit immediate, and allowed a tenant to pursue dismissed defenses and counterclaims in a separate proceeding. It also asserted that there was no violation of due process in requiring a deposit because the tenant was contractually responsible for rent. The court held that the deposit requirement and the expedited schedule for adjudication did not violate due process guarantees.


OUTCOME: The court denied the tenants' motion for a preliminary injunction and class certification.


HEADNOTES

Constitutional Law - Due Process of Law - Deposit of Postpetition Rent in Summary Proceeding

1. RPAPL 745 (2), which provides that the tenant in a summary proceeding must deposit all postpetition rent or use and occupancy upon a request for a second of two adjournments, or upon the 30th day after the first appearance in court and that failure to deposit accruing rent or use and occupancy entitles the landlord to immediate trial of the issues raised in the tenant's answer, does not violate due process guarantees. The time restrictions are not insufficient per se. The warranty of habitability does not mandate a contrary result since the tenant may raise this warranty as a defense and receive a prompt hearing on the issue. To the limited extent that the tenant's ability to assert a breach of the warranty as a defense is affected, such modification does not rise to a constitutional deprivation. To a very limited extent, the Legislature reinstituted the concept that the obligation to pay rent is independent of the landlord's leasehold obligations.

Constitutional Law - Equal Protection of Laws - Deposit of Postpetition Rent in Summary Proceeding

2. RPAPL 745 (2), which provides that the tenant in a summary proceeding must deposit all postpetition rent or use and occupancy upon a request for a second of two adjournments, or upon the 30th day after the first appearance in court, and that failure to deposit accruing rent or use and occupancy entitles the landlord to immediate trial of the issues raised in the tenant's answer, does not violate the equal protection of the law. In the area of economics and social welfare, legislation is presumed valid and will be sustained if the classification is rationally related to a legitimate State interest. Because of the unique factual and legal characteristics of the landlord-tenant relationship, tenants may be constitutionally subjected to different standards. The tenant is in possession of the landlord's property and may deny the landlord income rights. Speedy adjudication is desirable to prevent subjecting the landlord to undeserved economic loss and the tenant to unmerited harassment and dispossession.

Constitutional Law - Separation of Powers - Deposit of Postpetition Rent in Summary Proceeding

3. Recent amendments to the RPAPL which provide that where the tenant in a summary proceeding fails to deposit postpetition rent or use and occupancy as it accrues in order to obtain additional adjournments, the court may order an immediate trial of the issues raised in the tenant's answer which will continue day to day until completed with no stay unless the tenant continues to deposit accruing charges ( RPAPL 745 [2] [c] [ii]), and which prohibit a stay of the issuance or execution of any warrant of eviction or the reletting of the premises ( RPAPL 747-a), are facially constitutional but, as applied, may violate the separation of powers between the legislative and judicial branches. The Legislature has the power to regulate the court's powers and procedures and has broad regulatory control over the Civil Court (NY Const, art VI, § 15). CPLR 2201 also supports the Legislature's power to restrict the use of stays. However, each branch may not interfere with the discharge of the inherent functions of the other and a fundamental element of inherent judicial power is the authority to control the court's calendar exercised through the discretion to stay proceedings. Thus, the "immediate trial" provision, if literally read, deprives a court of the authority under any circumstances to adjourn or stay the matter. Nevertheless, the statutes are facially constitutional since the restrictions only apply to a tenant who has appeared in the proceeding and RPAPL 749 (3), which allows a court to vacate a warrant "for good cause shown prior to the execution thereof", would allow a tenant who defaulted in appearing in the proceeding and claims a lack of jurisdiction to have the warrant vacated without making a deposit.

Actions - Class Actions

4. A request by plaintiff tenants and tenants' rights organizations for class certification of a plaintiff class of all tenants in residential housing in New York City is denied in an action which challenges the constitutionality of RPAPL 745 (2) and 747-a. If all tenants in the City were bound to the determination of constitutionality in this action, a tenant appearing in Housing Court (who did not opt-out of the class) would not be permitted to challenge the constitutionality of any aspect of the statute which was upheld. Furthermore, plaintiffs seek to deny the landlords the right to challenge the constitutional conclusions reached.

Actions - Class Actions

5. A request by plaintiff tenants and tenants' rights organizations for class certification of defendant classes of all Judges and all clerks assigned to the Housing Court is denied in an action challenging the constitutionality of RPAPL 745 (2) and 747-a. No individual Judges, except Administrative Judges, are parties to the action. Also, the Administrative Judges do not have authority to dictate how Civil Court and Housing Court Judges must rule on constitutional challenges to these laws through an administrative order. Even if the Administrative Judges possess such power, it would not be appropriate for this court to enjoin colleagues from reaching their own conclusions as to the constitutionality of the relevant provisions.

 

670 of 992 DOCUMENTS


Suffolk County v. Long Island Power Auth.


Index No. 344878/97


SUPREME COURT OF NEW YORK, NASSAU COUNTY


177 Misc. 2d 208; 673 N.Y.S.2d 545; 1998 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 149



March 24, 1998, Decided


NOTICE:  [***1] EDITED FOR PUBLICATION


SUBSEQUENT HISTORY: As Corrected July 6, 1998.



DISPOSITION: Petition denied and proceeding dismissed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioners, county and a coalition of interested groups, challenged the ratification of a purchase agreement between respondent power authority and a utility company that accepted conditions imposed by a state control board.


OVERVIEW: Respondent power authority reached an agreement in principle to buy the stock of a utility company, and the control board approved the project under N.Y. Pub. Auth. Law § 1020-f subject to certain conditions. Respondent voted to accept those conditions and ratified the definitive agreements. As a result, petitioners, county and a coalition of interested groups, commenced a proceeding seeking the annulment of respondent's ratification of the agreement, but the court denied the request and dismissed the proceeding. The court held that although petitioners commenced the proceeding in a timely fashion and the control board was not a necessary party, respondent's acceptance of the conditions was not arbitrary, capricious, or irrational. The conditions were all aimed at rate reduction, which was the explicit goal of the Long Island Power Authority Act, N.Y. Pub. Auth. Law § 1020-a. Therefore, respondent's action in ratifying the definitive agreement and accepting the control board's conditions was lawful.


OUTCOME: The court denied the request of petitioners, county and coalition of interested groups, to annul the ratification of an agreement between respondent power authority and a utility company because respondent's acceptance of the conditions set by the control board was not arbitrary, capricious, or irrational.


HEADNOTES

Limitation of Actions - When Cause of Action Accrues - Agreements between Public Power Authority and Private Investor-Owned Utility

1. A cause of action challenging respondent public power authority's acceptance of conditions placed, by the Public Authority Control Board (PACB), on agreements to acquire the assets of respondent investor-owned utility, accrued in August 1997 when the public power authority's Board accepted the conditions, and not in June when the agreements were executed nor in July when the PACB approved the project subject to the conditions. PACB was statutorily required to approve the agreements, thus any challenge to the June resolution is premature. Also, petitioners challenge the August resolution, not PACB's conditional approval. The conditions were lacking in import with respect to petitioners and respondent until the conditions, as well as respondent private utility's commitment to the agreements, became final and binding.

Parties - Necessary Parties - Agreements between Public Power Authority and Private Investor-Owned Utility

2. An action challenging agreements made pursuant to the Long Island Power Authority Act (Public Authorities Law § 1020-a et seq.) to transfer the assets of respondent private investor-owned utility to respondent public power authority will not be dismissed based on petitioners' failure to join, as a necessary party, the Public Authority Control Board (PACB), which has review power over the public power authority's projects and placed conditions on the agreements. Petitioners do not challenge the PACB's authority to impose the conditions; rather, they question the public power authority's actions in accepting them.

Parties - Standing - Agreements between Public Power Authority and Private Investor-Owned Utility

3. Petitioner county has standing to challenge agreements made pursuant to the Long Island Power Authority Act (Public Authorities Law § 1020-a et seq.) in which respondent public power authority acquired the assets of respondent private investor-owned utility and agreed to accept conditions placed on the agreements by the Public Authority Control Board, which has the power to review the public power authority's projects. As a representative of its residents under Public Service Law § 109 the county may appear as a party in any action or proceeding involving rates, service or other matters affecting the municipal corporation or any of its residents.

Public Authorities - Claims against Public Authorities - Agreements between Public Power Authority and Private Investor-Owned Utility

4. Respondent public power authority appropriately ratified agreements made pursuant to the Long Island Power Authority Act (Public Authorities Law § 1020-a et seq.) to acquire the assets of respondent investor-owned utility, which contained conditions imposed by the Public Authority Control Board (PACB). The public power authority was statutorily required to apply to the PACB for approval (Public Authorities Law § 1020-f) and its acceptance of the conditions imposed by PACB are within the Act's statutory framework. Respondent public power authority may accept approvals upon such terms and conditions as it deems appropriate and the conditions closely relate to the factors enumerated at Public Authorities Law § 1020-f (aa) which the PACB was mandated to consider.

Public Authorities - Claims against Public Authorities - Agreements between Public Power Authority and Private Investor-Owned Utility

5. A determination by respondent public power authority to ratify agreements made pursuant to the Long Island Power Authority Act (Public Authorities Law § 1020-a et seq.) to acquire the assets of respondent investor-owned utility, which contained conditions imposed by the Public Authority Control Board (PACB) was not arbitrary, capricious or irrational. The conditions are all aimed at rate reduction, the explicit goal of the Act itself. Respondent public power authority's conclusion that it could commit to the conditions is based upon exhaustive analysis by multiple professionals and lengthy hearings and detailed communications.

Public Authorities - Claims against Public Authorities - Agreements between Public Power Authority and Private Investor-Owned Utility

6. A determination by respondent public power authority to ratify agreements made pursuant to the Long Island Power Authority Act (Public Authorities Law § 1020-a et seq.) to acquire the assets of respondent investor-owned utility, which contained conditions imposed by the Public Authority Control Board (PACB), did not illegally irrevocably relinquish powers to the PACB. Respondent public power authority affirmatively agreed to conditions which it unquestionably could have imposed upon itself. To the extent that the conditions create unanticipated problems, respondent can return to the PACB and modifications can be sought. Should the PACB fail to respond favorably, respondent has options under Public Authorities Law § 1020-g (f).

Public Authorities - Claims against Public Authorities - Agreements between Public Power Authority and Private Investor-Owned Utility

7. A determination by respondent public power authority to ratify agreements made pursuant to the Long Island Power Authority Act (Public Authorities Law § 1020-a et seq.) to acquire the assets of respondent investor-owned utility, which contain a condition obligating the public power authority to reduce utility rates by 14% over 10 years, does not violate the public power authority's obligations under Public Authorities Law § 1020-g (n) to acquire from respondent private utility all franchise and utility service responsibilities for all ultimate consumers of gas and electricity within the private utility's former service territory, including the responsibility to provide safe and adequate service. There is no evidence that an inconsistency exists.

Public Authorities - Claims against Public Authorities - Agreements between Public Power Authority and Private Investor-Owned Utility

8. A determination by respondent public power authority to ratify agreements made pursuant to the Long Island Power Authority Act (Public Authorities Law § 1020-a et seq.) to acquire the assets of respondent investor-owned utility (see, Public Authorities Law § 1020-a et seq.), which contain a condition obligating the public power authority to reduce utility rates by 14% over 10 years, does not violate its statutory authority to set utility rates. In accepting this condition respondent has afforded the Public Service Commission only a limited right of review. In any event, Public Authorities Law § 1020-g (e) specifically authorizes respondent to seek approvals of other agencies and to accept those approvals on terms it deems appropriate. The statute contemplates respondent succumbing to the jurisdiction of other agencies and does not intend to give it sole and exclusive authority to set rates. Furthermore, respondent has not acted arbitrarily, capriciously or irrationally in establishing this boundary.

Public Authorities - Claims against Public Authorities - Agreements between Public Power Authority and Private Investor-Owned Utility

9. Agreements made pursuant to the Long Island Power Authority Act (Public Authorities Law § 1020-a et seq.) to transfer the assets of respondent investor-owned utility to respondent public power authority (see, Public Authorities Law § 1020-a et seq.) were just to the ratepayers and were not in violation of Public Authorities Law § 1020-h (2) (g) insofar as the public power authority agreed to compensate the private utility for the Shoreham asset. Public Authorities Law § 1020-h mandates just compensation for ratepayers, provides for the exercise of the power of eminent domain, and states that the private utility has no reasonable expectation of realizing actual earnings from the Shoreham plant. In view of the public power authority's broad discretion, a rational showing that the compensation is just will suffice. Here, the public authority sought and obtained an opinion from its financial advisor which found the deal financially fair. The public power authority's agreement to compensate the private utility for its as yet unenforced tax certiorari judgment and to impose a rate surcharge on Suffolk ratepayers does not violate Public Authorities Law § 1020-q (3). Section 1020-q (3), which has been found unconstitutional as to the private utility, does not bar the public power authority from compensating the private utility for judgments. In addition, there has been no definitive determination by the authority to impose a surcharge on Suffolk ratepayers; thus, this claim is not ripe for judicial review. Conditions imposed on the agreements by the Public Authority Control Board (PACB), whose approval was mandatory, are by virtue of the PACB resolution applicable to the agreements. Having explicitly accepted the agreements, the public power authority is bound to proceed, if at all, in accordance with the conditions.

Public Authorities - Claims against Public Authorities - Agreements between Public Power Authority and Private Investor-Owned Utility

10. Respondent public power authority did not violate the State Administrative Procedure Act when it ratified agreements made pursuant to the Long Island Power Authority Act (Public Authorities Law § 1020-a et seq.) to acquire the assets of respondent investor-owned utility, which contained conditions imposed by the Public Authority Control Board (PACB). Respondent public power authority's authorization of the agreements was a contract determination authorized by Public Authorities Law § 1020-h and, thus, did not constitute rule-making as defined by State Administrative Procedure Act § 102 (2) (a). Nor did its acceptance of the PACB's conditions amount to rule-making.

Public Authorities - Claims against Public Authorities - Agreements between Public Power Authority and Private Investor-Owned Utility

11. Respondent public power authority did not violate the State Environmental Quality Review Act (SEQRA) when it ratified agreements made pursuant to the Long Island Power Authority Act (Public Authorities Law § 1020-a et seq.) to acquire respondent investor-owned utility, which contained conditions imposed by the Public Authority Control Board (PACB), since Public Authorities Law § 1020-s (2) exempts actions of the public power authority to acquire the securities or assets of respondent private utility from SEQRA. Respondent public power authority's acceptance of the PACB's conditions does not go beyond the exemption. The Act exempts from SEQRA any action by respondent public power authority to effect the acquisition and, pursuant to the statutory framework, these actions are all necessary to effect the acquisition.

 

671 of 992 DOCUMENTS


People v. Lynch


IND # 97-406


COUNTY COURT OF NEW YORK, ROCKLAND COUNTY


176 Misc. 2d 430; 674 N.Y.S.2d 894; 1998 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 117



March 16, 1998, Decided


NOTICE:  [***1] EDITED FOR PUBLICATION



DISPOSITION: The defendant's motion to dismissed the indictment is denied.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant, a school board trustee who benefited financially from a school board vote, moved to dismiss an indictment charging defendant with official misconduct under N.Y. Penal Law § 195.00(2). In seeking to dismiss the indictment, defendant challenged the constitutionality of § 195.00, the facial sufficiency of the indictment, and the sufficiency of the evidence supporting the indictment.


OVERVIEW: Defendant, a school board trustee, benefited from voting to approve contracts with insurance providers. When defendant was charged with official misconduct under N.Y. Penal Law § 195.00(2), defendant moved to dismiss the indictment, and the motion was denied. Noting § 195.00's presumption of constitutionality, the court held § 195.00 was not unconstitutional because § 195.00 apprised reasonable persons of the acts prohibited and of what conduct was required. Furthermore, the court held the indictment was not facially insufficient because by providing in each count the name and section of the statute violated, defendant was given fair notice of the nature of the charges and of the manner, time, and place of the conduct underlying the accusation. Similarly, the court held a bill of particulars had provided defendant with fair notice. The court also held evidence had supported the charges that defendant had failed to perform a duty clearly inherent in the nature of defendant's office. Finally, the court held defendant's ethical obligation to procure insurance for the school district free from a conflict of interest had not preempted imposition of criminal sanctions.


OUTCOME: Court denied a motion to dismiss an indictment charging defendant, who had benefitted financially from a school board vote, with official misconduct because the official misconduct statute was constitutional under the reasonable person standard, the indictment and bill of particulars gave fair notice, evidence supported the failure to perform a duty inherent in defendant's office, and ethical obligations had not preempted criminal sanctions.


HEADNOTES

Constitutional Law - Validity of Statute - Official Misconduct

1. Penal Law § 195.00 (2), which provides a public servant is guilty of official misconduct when with intent to obtain a benefit or deprive another person of a benefit he knowingly refrains from performing a duty which is imposed upon him by law or is clearly inherent in the nature of his office, sufficiently apprises a reasonable person of the nature of the acts prohibited and of what conduct is required of him to comply with due process protections. Unconstitutionality must be demonstrated beyond a reasonable doubt. A penal statute need only inform those who are subject to it what conduct on their part will render them liable. A duty which is clearly inherent in the nature of the office encompasses those unspecified duties that are so essential to the accomplishment of the purposes for which the office was created that they are clearly inherent in the nature of the office. The statute proscribes the failure to perform an essential and unspecified duty by a public servant at a time when the public servant possesses a criminally culpable state of mind.

Crimes - Indictment - Facial Insufficiency - Official Misconduct

2. The indictment charging defendant with official misconduct (Penal Law § 195.00 [2]) was sufficient wherein it provided in each count the name and the section of the particular statute violated since an indictment that states no more than the bare elements of the crime charged and, in effect, parrots the Penal Law is legally sufficient. The primary purpose is to give defendant fair notice of the nature of the charges, and the manner, time, and place of the conduct underlying the accusations, so as to enable the defendant to prepare or conduct an adequate defense.

Crimes - Indictment - Sufficiency of Evidence before Grand Jury - Official Misconduct

3. Defendant's motion to dismiss the indictment charging him with official misconduct (Penal Law § 195.00 [2]) is denied where defendant, while acting allegedly pursuant to the Education Law which authorizes a school board to procure group health insurance, voted to approve the paid services of an insurance consultant and contracts with insurance providers and benefited financially from the transaction. The obligation to act free from conflicts of interest and to disclose such conflicts is codified in General Municipal Law article 18. Defendant took an oath of office and was provided with an ethics policy, enacted pursuant to article 18, which required defendant to publicly disclose the nature and extent of any direct or indirect financial or other private interest he had in any legislation he participated in before the Board; prohibited him from soliciting or accepting anything of value from individuals or companies who are vendors or potential vendors to the district; and prohibited him from receiving, or entering into any agreement, express or implied, for compensation for services to be rendered in relation to any matter before the school district. Defendant refrained from disclosing his financial interest in legislation on three separate occasions and on each occasion, he was present, voted and ratified the action taken. Also, at the time the Board was voting on the contract for the health insurance policy for the district, the defendant had a preexisting fee sharing arrangement with his employer and the agent. He was an insurance professional and could appreciate and understand that a multi-million dollar insurance premium would result in a substantial commission. Furthermore, a violation of the ethical rules promulgated under article 18 is itself punishable as a misdemeanor and, therefore, there is no improper delegation of legislative authority to the prosecutor to institute criminal proceedings premised upon a violation of the provisions of an ethical code.

 

672 of 992 DOCUMENTS


Brewer v. State


98-201


COURT OF CLAIMS OF NEW YORK


176 Misc. 2d 337; 672 N.Y.S.2d 650; 1998 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 104; 32 Bankr. Ct. Dec. 558



March 12, 1998, Decided


NOTICE:  [***1] EDITED FOR PUBLICATION


SUBSEQUENT HISTORY: As Corrected June 1, 1998.



DISPOSITION: The application of movant for an order pursuant to Court of Claims Act § 10(6) permitting it to serve and file a late claim is granted to the extent of permitting the service and filing of a claim containing the causes of action set forth in counts two, three and four of the proposed late claim, upon the condition that the service and filing take place within forty-five days of the date of the filing of this decision and order.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Movant, trustee of bankrupt company, sought an order pursuant to the Court of Claims Act §10(6) permitting him to serve and file a late claim against defendant corrections department seeking a judgment to avoid pre-petition and post-petition payments made to it, with interest.


OVERVIEW: The court permitted trustee to serve and file a late claim for money had and received, contract implied in law, and conversion. The statute of limitations on the federal claim based upon bankruptcy law was tolled by 11 U.S.C.S. § 108. The motion for leave as to the remaining claims were brought within their applicable statutory period under state law, N.Y. C.P.L.R. 213 and 214. However, trustee did not timely serve and file a claim or a notice of intention after the accrual of the claims under the Court of Claims Act §§10(4) and 10(3-b). Trustee's failure to do so because it believed that the bankruptcy court had jurisdiction until corrections department filed a dismissal motion based upon constitutional grounds was found to have been reasonable. Further, corrections department had prompt notice of the payments and bankruptcy proceeding, had the opportunity to investigate, and was not prejudiced. The court had subject matter jurisdiction to determine a claim for money had and received even if the right to the money was derived from a federal statute. Finally, trustee demonstrated potential merit as to all except the appropriation claim.


OUTCOME: The court granted trustee's application as to the counts based on money had and received, contract implied in law, and conversion.


HEADNOTES

State - Court of Claims - Jurisdiction over Claim for Money Owed under Bankruptcy Code

1. The Court of Claims has subject matter jurisdiction over a claim brought by the bankruptcy trustee for a corporation seeking to set aside, as avoidable preferences under the Bankruptcy Code (11 USC), prepetition and postpetition payments made to the State pursuant to a contract between the corporation and the State as the trustee may use common-law causes of action such as money had and received to recover the payments where the right to the payments derives from a Federal statute.

State - Claim against State - Unconstitutional Taking of Property - Retention of Money

2. In a claim brought by the bankruptcy trustee for a corporation seeking to recover prepetition and postpetition payments made pursuant to a contract between the corporation and the State, the cause of action asserting that "the defendant has wrongfully appropriated the personal property of the Estate", which is an attempt to come within the language of Court of Claims Act § 9 (2) which gives the court the jurisdiction to hear and determine any claim "against the state for the appropriation of any real or personal property", is meritless as the retention of money does not constitute a taking of property. Court of Claims Act § 9 (2) provides a means of recovering money damages when the State, through its eminent domain power, appropriates property. In order for a compensable loss to occur under the power of eminent domain a "taking" of property must occur, but the appropriation of money may not be viewed as a permanent physical occupation of property and thus may not constitute a taking, as money, unlike real or personal property, is fungible.

State - Claim against State - Claim for Money Had and Received

3. In a claim brought by the bankruptcy trustee for a corporation seeking to recover prepetition and postpetition payments made pursuant to a contract between the corporation and the Department of Correctional Services (DOCS), claimant has stated a cause of action for money had and received, the elements of which are that the defendant received money belonging to the claimant, the defendant benefited from receipt of the money, and under principles of equity and good conscience, the defendant should not be permitted to keep the money. Claimant has pleaded those elements in that it is alleged that DOCS received money belonging to the estate the trustee is administering, has benefited from the receipt of the money, and under principles of equity and good conscience should not be allowed to keep the money to the detriment of all of the corporation's other general creditors.

 

673 of 992 DOCUMENTS


Seymour v. State Div. of Hous. & Community Renewal


Index No. 116894/97


SUPREME COURT OF NEW YORK, NEW YORK COUNTY


175 Misc. 2d 996; 670 N.Y.S.2d 1017; 1998 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 66



March 9, 1998, Decided


NOTICE:  [***1] EDITED FOR PUBLICATION



DISPOSITION: Petition granted only to the extent that the matter is referred back to DHCR for reconsideration. Cross motion by respondent DHCR denied.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Respondent State of New York Division of Housing and Community Renewal (DHCR) issued a default deregulation order against petitioner tenant under the Rent Regulation Reform Act of 1993, 1993 N.Y. Laws 253, §§ 6 and 7, New York City, N.Y., Admin. Code §§ 26-504.1, 26-504.2, 26-504.3. The DHCR then denied the tenant's petition for administrative review (PAR). The tenant filed a petition, under N.Y. C.P.L.R. 78, to annul the DHCR's determination.


OVERVIEW: The tenant received an income certification form (ICF) from her landlord. For various reasons, the tenant never submitted the form. The DHCR issued its default regulation order and denied the tenant's PAR, refusing to consider the tenant's evidence of her income because her inadvertent neglect did not excuse her failure to return the ICF. The court determined that the DHCR's original deregulation order was proper because the tenant failure to provide the required information. However, the court held that the DHCR's decision that it could not vacate the default order was arbitrary and capricious because the clear intent of the state legislature with the Reform Act was not to deregulate apartments of people in the tenant's income bracket. Moreover, there was a strong policy to consider cases on their merits. Additionally, the court found that the Reform Act was not intended to set forth immutable schedules; this was evidenced by the fact that the DHCR did not abide by the schedule when it failed to timely issue the order of deregulation to the tenant. The Reform Act accorded discretion to the DHCR so long as there was no complete failure to provide the required information.


OUTCOME: The court granted the tenant's petition for judicial review to the extent that the matter was referred back to the DHCR for reconsideration of the tenant's case on its merits under the Reform Act.


HEADNOTES

Landlord and Tenant - Rent Regulation - Deregulation of Apartment Due to Tenant's Failure to Timely Provide Information Regarding Household Income

The determination of respondent Division of Housing and Community Renewal (DHCR), which deregulated petitioner's apartment pursuant to the luxury deregulation provisions of the Rent Regulation Reform Act of 1993 (L 1993, ch 523) after petitioner failed to timely provide the required information verifying her household income, and then denied her petition for administrative review and request for reconsideration, is annulled as DHCR's refusal to reconsider the deregulation order after receiving uncontroverted evidence that petitioner's household income fell far below the $ 250,000 threshold for deregulation was improper. While an agency's determination should not be disturbed where the determination is found to be rationally based on the law and the administrative record, a statute should be construed to effectuate the intent of the Legislature. Deregulation was intended to affect only those tenants whose incomes exceeded $ 250,000 per year for two consecutive years, and was not intended to set forth immutable schedules. According to the language of Administrative Code of the City of New York § 26-504.3, only the complete failure to provide the information leads to deregulation, not the failure to provide the information within 60 days. In view of the strong policy of considering issues on the merits, and the clear intent of the Legislature not to deregulate apartments of people in petitioner's income bracket, the DHCR should have addressed the issue of vacating the default when petitioner promptly submitted undisputed evidence of her household income and requested reconsideration after receiving the notice of deregulation.

 

674 of 992 DOCUMENTS


Williams v. Foubister


AP97/0109


COUNTY COURT OF NEW YORK, MONROE COUNTY


176 Misc. 2d 702; 673 N.Y.S.2d 840; 1998 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 164



March 5, 1998, Decided


NOTICE:  [***1] EDITED FOR PUBLICATION



DISPOSITION: The decision of the Rochester City Court affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff attorney appealed from the order of the Rochester City Court (New York), which dismissed his complaint against defendant client for attorney's fees for representation in a proceeding to recover unpaid child support. The trial court had held that the matter should be resolved through the matrimonial fee arbitration program. The attorney challenged the constitutionality of the court rules.


OVERVIEW: Plaintiff attorney represented defendant client in a proceeding for unpaid child support. The attorney brought an action to recover attorney's fees, and the trial court dismissed the complaint because the matter should be resolved through the matrimonial fee arbitration program. The attorney moved for a new trial and appealed its denial. The court held that: (1) the rules were promulgated under N.Y. Jud. Law § 90(2) under the authority to regulate the practice of law; (2) the client could elect to resolve the dispute by arbitration pursuant to N.Y. Comp. Codes & Regs. tit. 22, § 136.2; (3) no court had jurisdiction to hear the matter because an arbitration was pending, and the rules did not conflict with the requirement that an action for a money judgment was required to permit a jury trial de novo, under N.Y. C.P.L.R. 3405, N.Y. Const. art I, § 2; (4) attorneys fees were controlled by N.Y. Jud. App., Code Prof. Resp. DR 2-106, N.Y. Comp. Codes & Regs. tit. 22, § 1200.11; and (5) the rules did not deny matrimonial lawyers equal protection of the law because a rational basis existed.


OUTCOME: The order that dismissed plaintiff attorney's complaint against defendant client for attorney's fees for representation in a matrimonial dispute was affirmed.


HEADNOTES

Constitutional Law - Validity of Regulation - Domestic Relations Fee Arbitration Requirements

1. 22 NYCRR 136.2, which grants a domestic relations client the right to arbitrate an attorney fee dispute, and 22 NYCRR 136.5, which provides that the complaint in an attorney's action for recovery of fees must allege that the client received notice of this right, do not conflict with CPLR 3405, which guarantees a party the right to a jury trial de novo in a money judgment action after an unsuccessful attempt at arbitration; accordingly, plaintiff attorney is not entitled to a jury trial in City Court of his action to recover fees in a domestic relations matter where he failed to notify the client of his arbitration rights. CPLR 3405 is limited by its own terms to actions pending in any court. Under the fee arbitration rules no court would have jurisdiction to hear a matter involving an attorney's fee dispute in a domestic relations matter unless certain conditions were met. Inasmuch as the conditions precedent to the filing of the action were not met, the trial court could not have jurisdiction. Also, the domestic relations fee arbitration rules have a separate authority source which is consistent with the authority of the courts to regulate the practice of law and oversee the conduct of attorneys (Judiciary Law § 90 [2]) and is not inconsistent with the statutory law.

Trial - Right to Jury Trial - Domestic Relations Fee Arbitration Requirements

2. The domestic relations fee arbitration requirements of 22 NYCRR 136.2 and 136.5 do not violate an attorney's right to a jury trial (US Const 7th Amend; NY Const, art I, § 2). The right to a jury trial in a suit at common law for more than $ 20, which is guaranteed by US Constitution 7th Amendment, is not incorporated in the 14th Amendment and, thus, only applies to Federal, not State, actions. Also, the requirements do not violate the attorney's right to a trial by jury under the New York State Constitution (NY Const, art I, § 2), since the action is equitable in nature and, thus, jury trial is not mandated.

Constitutional Law - Equal Protection of Laws - Domestic Relations Fee Arbitration Requirements

3. The domestic relations fee arbitration requirements of 22 NYCRR 136.2 and 136.5 do not deny an attorney equal protection of the law to the extent that they only apply to fees that an attorney seeks in a domestic relations case. Inasmuch as domestic relations lawyers are not a suspect class the equal protection analysis requires only that a rational basis exist for such treatment based upon a valid governmental interest. A strong presumption of validity accompanies such classification. The State has a compelling interest in regulating attorney's fees, maintaining client confidence in the legal system and enabling attorneys to collect their fees in a fair and timely manner. The rules were the result of an extensive and thorough inquiry into the practice of matrimonial law (22 NYCRR part 1400). The fact that the regulation of fees is limited at this time to fee disputes in domestic relations cases does not defeat the rational basis for that regulation in that the approach is incremental.

 

675 of 992 DOCUMENTS


People v. Calloway


98-179


COUNTY COURT OF NEW YORK, MONROE COUNTY


176 Misc. 2d 161; 672 N.Y.S.2d 638; 1998 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 94



March 4, 1998, Decided


NOTICE:  [***1] EDITED FOR PUBLICATION



DISPOSITION: Defendant's motion to dismiss denied.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant was charged with one count of engaging in a course of sexual conduct against a child in the first degree pursuant to N.Y. Penal Law § 130.75(a). Defendant filed a motion to dismiss the indictment for its failure to conform to the requirements of N.Y. Crim. Proc. Law §§ 200.50(3), (6), and (7).


OVERVIEW: Defendant argued that N.Y. Penal Law § 130.75(a) violated his rights under U.S. Const. amend. VI and N.Y. Const. art. I, § 6 to be informed of the nature and cause of the accusation against him. In denying defendant's motion to dismiss the indictment, the court held that defendant failed to meet his burden of proving that § 130.75(a) violated his constitutional rights, as the statute was not vague; the language in the endangering the welfare of a child statute, N.Y. Penal Law § 260.10, was less specific than the language in N.Y. Penal Law § 130.75(a) and had been repeatedly upheld as not unconstitutionally vague. Defendant also argued that § 130.75(a) effectively violated his constitutional right to a unanimous jury verdict. The court rejected that argument, noting that it was unclear how allowing how allowing jurors to convict upon unanimous agreement that two sexual assaults were committed during a certain time period, without requiring agreement as to which two, was an infringement on defendant's right to a unanimous verdict.


OUTCOME: The court denied defendant's motion to dismiss the indictment.


HEADNOTES

Crimes - Course of Sexual Conduct against Child - Constitutionality of Statute 

1. Defendant's motion to dismiss the indictment charging him with one count of course of sexual conduct against a child in the first degree in violation of Penal Law § 130.75 (a) on the ground that the statute is unconstitutionally vague is denied as the statute meets the test of whether a reasonable person subject to the statute would be informed of the nature of the offense prohibited and what is required of him or her. Generally, so-called "course-of-conduct" crimes have a long history and their constitutional legitimacy has been tested and established. It is evident from the language of Penal Law § 130.75 (a) that the Legislature intended to create a single crime, viz., the repeated sexual assault of the same child during a specified period of time. Further, the language of Penal Law § 130.75 (a) is even more specific than the language in the endangering the welfare of a child statute (Penal Law § 260.10), a course-of-conduct crime which has been held to meet the constitutional requirement of specificity.

Crimes - Course of Sexual Conduct against Child - Constitutionality of Statute 

2. Defendant's motion to dismiss the indictment charging him with one count of course of sexual conduct against a child in the first degree in violation of Penal Law § 130.75 (a) on the ground that the statute effectively denies his State constitutional right to a unanimous jury verdict by allowing jurors to convict upon unanimous agreement that two sexual assaults were committed during a certain time period without requiring agreement as to which two is denied. Penal Law § 130.75 is not unconstitutional on its face as violative of a State constitutional right to a unanimous jury verdict.

Crimes - Course of Sexual Conduct against Child - Right to Specificity in Indictment

3. Defendant's motion to dismiss the indictment charging him with one count of course of sexual conduct against a child in the first degree in violation of Penal Law § 130.75 (a) on the ground that the statute violates his right to specificity in the indictment ( CPL 200.50) is denied. A court reviewing an indictment must determine whether the indictment charges the time and place and nature and circumstances of the offense with clearness and certainty, and must also consider, in determining whether a more specific date could have been provided in the indictment, the age and intelligence of the victims and other witnesses, the surrounding circumstances, and the nature of the offense. No reasonable inference arises from the language of Penal Law § 130.75 that the Legislature intended to alter those considerations when reviewing an indictment charging the crime of a course of sexual conduct against a child.

 

676 of 992 DOCUMENTS


People v. Couser


Indictment # 97-743, Index # 97/735


COUNTY COURT OF NEW YORK, ONONDAGA COUNTY


176 Misc. 2d 86; 674 N.Y.S.2d 887; 1998 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 120



February 26, 1998, Decided


NOTICE:  [***1] EDITED FOR PUBLICATION



DISPOSITION: Count Two dismissed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: A co-defendant who was charged with murder in the first degree of several victims, in violation of N.Y. Penal Law § 125.27(1)(a)(vii), and with other crimes filed a motion to dismiss all the substantive counts he was charged with on the ground that the evidence before the grand jury was insufficient to establish that he shared his co-conspirators' intent to kill or that he attempted to cause the victims' deaths.


OVERVIEW: A co-defendant moved to dismiss the charge of murder in the first degree, under N.Y. Penal Law § 125.27(1)(a)(vii), and other charges against him on the ground that he did not share the requisite intent to kill the victims. He alleged that the "command" that he gave to kill was intended for one other than those whose deaths were the subject of the prosecution. On the co-defendant's motion, the court dismissed the first degree murder count and held that § 125.27(a)(1)(vii) was impermissibly vague. The court ruled that, to the extent that the statute sought to impose accessorial liability through the "command" term borrowed from N.Y. Penal Law § 20.00, the language of N.Y. Penal Law § 125.27(a)(1)(vii) ran afoul of the due process guarantees of both the Fourteenth Amendment of the United States Constitution and N.Y. Const. art. I, § 6 because it failed to define what constituted a "command" under either N.Y. Penal law § 20.00 or § 125.27(a)(1)(vii). Therefore, the statute did not provide a meaningful basis upon which to distinguish the few cases in which the death penalty was imposed from the many cases in which it was not, and the statute was unconstitutionally vague.


OUTCOME: The court granted the co-defendant's motion to dismiss the murder in the first degree count against him because it deemed the statute impermissibly vague and violative of the due process guarantees of the Fourteenth Amendment to the United States Constitution and of the New York Constitution.


HEADNOTES

Constitutional Law - Validity of Statute - Commander Portion of First Degree Murder Statute 

The count of the indictment charging defendant with first degree murder in violation of Penal Law § 125.27 (1) (a) (vii), which imposes liability upon a defendant for "having commanded another person to cause the death of the victim or intended victim pursuant to section 20.00 of this chapter" where the victim is killed during the commission of a felony, is dismissed as the failure to define what constitutes a "command" either under section 20.00 or section 125.27 (1) (a) (vii) of the Penal Law renders the statute unconstitutionally vague in violation of the due process guarantees of both the Fourteenth Amendment of the US Constitution and article I, § 6 of the NY Constitution. Neither the Legislature nor the courts have given any guidance about what constitutes a "command" under this statute, and the arguments and counterarguments offered by the parties about what might be contemplated by the use of this term only serve to underscore the vagueness of the term. A statute which makes a defendant eligible for the death penalty must contain an aggravating circumstance which generally narrows the class of persons eligible and must reasonably justify the imposition of a more severe sentence, and while Penal Law § 125.27 (1) (a) (vii) narrows the accomplice liability to a single concept, "command", and places the burden of establishing it on the People, the failure to define what constitutes a "command" renders the statute impermissibly vague.

 

677 of 992 DOCUMENTS


Countryman v. Schmitt


Index No. 95/3640


SUPREME COURT OF NEW YORK, MONROE COUNTY


176 Misc. 2d 736; 673 N.Y.S.2d 521; 1998 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 97



February 5, 1998, Decided


NOTICE:  [***1] EDITED FOR PUBLICATION


SUBSEQUENT HISTORY: As Corrected June 1, 1998.



DISPOSITION: The petition is granted to the extent that a declaratory judgment may be entered consistent herewith.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: In a N.Y. C.P.L.R. art. 78 proceeding, petitioner property owner sought annulment of a zoning law adopted by respondent town. The property owner contended that the town, in adopting Local Law No. 2, failed to comply with notice requirements; that the law resulted in an unconstitutional taking of his property; and that the law violated his rights to equal protection of law, as guaranteed by the state and federal Constitutions.


OVERVIEW: After Congress enacted the Telecommunications Act of 1996, the town drafted a local law, which provided that no telecommunication tower could be erected unless a special use permit was issued. Local Law No. 2 modified that law by setting priorities for the siting of telecommunications towers. Lowest on the list were locations in residential districts. The court held that limiting the property owner's freedom to lease his property to a third party for the purpose of constructing a tower could be analogized to the tort of interference with prospective advantage, which was the least favored form of "taking" recognized by the courts. The court held that frustration and appropriation were essentially different things. The court held, however, that Local Law No. 2 was unconstitutional because there was no reasonable nexus between its objective, to protect the aesthetic character of the Town, and the means employed to implement that objective. The court held that Local Law No. 2 deprived the property owner of equal protection because private landowners were treated differently than other classes of landowners and that such disparate treatment served no legitimate state interest.


OUTCOME: The court converted the article 78 proceeding to a declaratory judgment action and declared the local law unconstitutional.


HEADNOTES

Constitutional Law - Validity of Statute - Local Law Prioritizing Locations for Telecommunication Towers - Unconstitutional Exercise of Town's Zoning Powers

1. Local Laws, 1997, No. 2 of the Town of Rush (Local Law No. 2), which prioritizes locations for telecommunications towers in the Town and places residential districts lowest on the priority list, constitutes an unconstitutional exercise of the Town's zoning powers. In order for a zoning ordinance to be a valid exercise of the police power it must have been enacted in furtherance of a legitimate governmental purpose, and there must be a reasonable relation between the end sought to be achieved by the regulation and the means used to achieve that end. While promoting the aesthetic character of the Town of Rush would, in itself, constitute a valid basis for the exercise of the police power, Local Law No. 2 is not rationally related to that purpose, at least insofar as it ranks property owned by the Town and the Fire Department higher on the priority list for telecommunications towers than property located in residential, commercial and industrial districts. Under the Local Law, location of the towers relates solely to the fortuitous circumstance of ownership, without regard to geography, location, district, or other traditional site plan or use district considerations.

Constitutional Law - Equal Protection of Laws - Local Law Prioritizing Locations for Telecommunication Towers

2. Local Laws, 1997, No. 2 of the Town of Rush (Local Law No. 2), which prioritizes locations for telecommunications towers in the Town and places residential districts, where petitioner's property is situated, lowest on the priority list, deprives petitioner of his rights to equal protection under the law. A town denies equal protection when, without a rational basis for differential treatment, it treats persons similarly situated differently under the law, and such a difference may be created by the grant of a preference. Preference by ownership has been enacted by the Town of Rush, as Local Law No. 2 gives preferential treatment to property owners having existing towers and property owned by the Town and the Fire Department, and petitioner's property is treated differently than other property in residential districts, i.e., property owned by the Town and the Fire Department. Since respondents have not demonstrated a rational basis for such disparate treatment, Local Law No. 2 is unconstitutional on equal protection grounds.

 

678 of 992 DOCUMENTS


People v. Harris


Indictment 15265/96


SUPREME COURT OF NEW YORK, KINGS COUNTY


176 Misc. 2d 967; 675 N.Y.S.2d 740; 1998 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 235



February 5, 1998, Decided


NOTICE:  [***1] EDITED FOR PUBLICATION


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant requested that the court find N.Y. Crim. Proc. Law § 270.20(1)(f) unconstitutional on the grounds that permitting pretrial challenges for cause in capital cases precluded formation of a jury that could properly exercise discretion in determining the appropriate sentence in a capital case and compromised defendant's right to a fair and impartial tribunal.


OVERVIEW: Defendant contended that a jury chosen pursuant to N.Y. Crim. Proc. Law § 270.20(1)(f) would be likely to convict, would not represent a fair cross-section of the community, and that questioning jurors prior to a guilt determination concerning their view on the death penalty undermined the presumption of innocence. The court denied defendant's motion. The court held that the voir dire process was not aimed at selecting death-qualified jurors, but rather jurors who could follow the court's instructions on punishment, who would include both life and death-qualified jurors. The court noted that the United States Supreme Court had upheld the constitutionality of another state's statute requiring the death qualification of jurors prior to a capital trial. The Court had held that even if a death qualified jury might be more conviction prone, that factor alone did not impact on the right to a fair and impartial jury. Furthermore, groups defined solely on their attitudes on the death penalty were not distinctive groups for fair cross-section purposes. The court declined to order a separate jury for the sentencing phase, holding that such bifurcation required exceptional circumstances.


OUTCOME: Defendant's motion that the court declare unconstitutional a criminal procedure law regarding jury selection in a capital offense trial was denied.


HEADNOTES

Crimes - Murder - Capital Murder - Composition of Jury

 CPL 270.20 (1) (f), which provides that a juror may be challenged for cause in a death penalty case if he or she entertains conscientious opinions either against or in favor of capital punishment which would interfere with the proper exercise of discretion in the determination of a sentence, does not compromise a capital defendant's right to a fair and impartial tribunal. Under this statute, a juror may be excluded for cause when his or her views on capital punishment would prevent or substantially impair the performance of duties as a juror in accordance with instructions and the oath. This standard is applied both to death and life qualification jurors. Even if a death qualified jury might be more conviction prone, that factor alone does not impact on a defendant's constitutional right to a fair and impartial jury, absent a showing that the jury in the particular case was so inclined. Also, the constitutional requirement of a fair cross-section is not violated by including only death qualified jurors on a capital case jury, since qualification serves the State's legitimate interest in obtaining a single jury that can properly and impartially apply the law to the facts at both the guilt and sentencing phases. Further, CPL 400.27 (2), which provides that a new jury for the sentencing phase will be impaneled after conviction only in extraordinary circumstances and upon a showing of good cause, reveals that the Legislature intended to maintain the continuity of the jury between the guilt and sentencing phase except in the most uncommon and unavoidable circumstances.

 

679 of 992 DOCUMENTS


People v. Jones


INDICTMENT NO. D-10210


COUNTY COURT OF NEW YORK, RENSSELAER COUNTY


175 Misc. 2d 828; 670 N.Y.S.2d 712; 1998 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 50



February 4, 1998, Decided


NOTICE:  [***1] EDITED FOR PUBLICATION



DISPOSITION: Defendant's motion to dismiss pursuant to CPL 30.30 and 30.20 is denied in its entirety.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant challenged the charges against him for burglary in the second degree under N.Y. Penal Law § 140.25(2) and brought a motion before the court to dismiss under N.Y. Crim. Proc. Law §§ 30.20, 30.30. Defendant contended that the People's notice of readiness declared and filed on the date of the arraignment was illusory and insufficient to satisfy § 30.30 because of the subsequent motion to amend and that he was denied a speedy trial.


OVERVIEW: Defendant was indicted by the grand jury for burglary in the second degree. The indictment alleged that defendant knowingly entered and remained unlawfully in the dwelling with intent to commit a crime. The court held that the People's readiness notice filed prior to the motion to amend was legally valid and sufficient to satisfy the requirements of § 30.30. The court opined that the fact that the People subsequently sought to amend did not invalidate the prior readiness statement because the motion was not a direct, and virtually insurmountable, impediment to the trial's commencement. The court observed that a necessary amendment of time, place, or date in the grand jury's evidence that did not change the prosecution theory was not an absolute impediment to commencing the trial, and other solutions were available by statute. The court noted that no rearraignment was required because the amendment was not a new indictment or a substantial break in the proceedings that required a new readiness notice. The court concluded that, despite the People's inexcusable delay, it was not unconstitutional due to the charge's seriousness and the lack of any demonstrable prejudice to defendant.


OUTCOME: The court denied defendant's motion to dismiss pursuant to the statutes regarding the prosecutor's readiness for trial and the right to a speedy trial.


HEADNOTES

Crimes - Right to Speedy Trial - Sufficiency of Declaration of Readiness - Amendment of Indictment after Declaration of Readiness

In a prosecution for second degree burglary where the People filed a written notice of readiness for trial on the date defendant was arraigned on a Grand Jury indictment, which date was well within the six-month speedy trial time limit of CPL 30.30, but subsequently filed, that same day, a written motion to amend the indictment to correctly reflect the time, date and place of the offense as reflected in the Grand Jury minutes, the People's notice of readiness was valid and timely even though the indictment was subsequently amended. The test for determining the validity of the People's notice of readiness for trial is whether the People are presently able to present their case for trial; there should be an indication of present readiness and not a prediction or expectation of future readiness. It is only failures on the part of the People that present a direct, and virtually insurmountable, impediment to the trial's very commencement that will be a basis for dismissal pursuant to CPL 30.30. Any necessary amendment of the indictment to correct errors relating to matters of form including time, place, and date as reflected in the evidence before the Grand Jury that did not change the theory of prosecution was not an absolute impediment to commencement of the trial. CPL 200.70 (1) allows amendment of an indictment at any time before or even during the trial, and provides that the court must order any necessary adjournment of the proceedings to accord the defendant adequate opportunity to prepare his or her defense.

 

680 of 992 DOCUMENTS


Health Servs. Med. Corp. v. Chassin


INDEX NO. 93-0741, RJI NO. 33-97-1017


SUPREME COURT OF NEW YORK, ONONDAGA COUNTY


175 Misc. 2d 621; 668 N.Y.S.2d 1006; 1998 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 30



January 27, 1998, Decided


NOTICE:  [***1] EDITED FOR PUBLICATION



DISPOSITION: Plaintiff shall submit judgment declaring the tax unconstitutional as applied to plaintiff and directing the return of the sum of $ 241,884.40.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff non profit health maintenance organization sought summary judgment from the Supreme Court of New York, Onondaga County (New York) in its declaratory judgment action against defendant state to declare that an increase in the mandated rate of payment to hospitals for in-patient services pursuant to N.Y. Pub. Health Law § 2807-c(2-a) represented a tax and was unconstitutional. Defendant cross moved for summary judgment.


OVERVIEW: The court granted plaintiff non-profit health maintenance organization declaratory judgment because it found that defendant state's increase in the mandated rate of payment to hospitals for in-patient services pursuant to N.Y. Pub. Health Law § 2807-c(2-a) represented a tax. The court then determined that because it was a tax, plaintiff was exempt from payment because such tax was prohibited by the nonrepealer clause of N.Y. Const. art. XVI, § 1. The court found that plaintiff was entitled to a return of the amounts it had paid because its payments were made under protest.


OUTCOME: The court granted plaintiff non-profit health maintenance organization's summary judgment in its declaratory judgment action against defendant state to declare that an increase in the mandated rate of payment to hospitals for in-patient services represented a tax and was unconstitutional as applied to plaintiff.


HEADNOTES

Taxation - What Constitutes Tax - Assessment against Health Maintenance Organization

1.
