Public Health Law § 2807-c (2-a) which increased the amount a health maintenance organization (HMO) must pay to hospitals for in-patient hospital services furnished to their non-Medicaid subscribers by imposing an assessment of 9% over and above the Diagnosis Related Groups rates, and directed that the monies generated by the assessment be deposited to the State's general fund, constitutes a tax and not a regulatory fee. Charges exacted for revenue purposes, or to offset the cost of general governmental functions are generally held to be taxes, while fees are enacted principally as an integral part of the regulation of an activity and to cover the cost of the regulation. Here, the legislation was a revenue act. Also, the amount generated goes to the State's general fund to meet the cost of general governmental functions, and the revenue bears no relationship to the cost of regulation. Also, the policy behind the legislation which seeks to lower the cost of the Medicaid program by forcing enrollment in managed care benefits the wider community of State taxpayers; there is no special benefit to HMOs.

Taxation - Exemptions - Tax Imposed on Health Maintenance Organization

2. Public Health Law § 2807-c (2-a) which imposed a 9% tax on the amount a health maintenance organization (HMO) must pay to hospitals for in-patient hospital services furnished to their non-Medicaid subscribers is unconstitutional as applied to plaintiff, a nonprofit charitable HMO organized under Insurance Law article 43, notwithstanding that plaintiff did not become a nonprofit corporation until two months after the enactment of the law. Plaintiff is exempt from Federal taxes under Internal Revenue Code (26 USC) § 501 (c) (3) as a corporation with a charitable purpose and was issued an exemption from sales and use taxes by the State Department of Taxation and Finance. Insofar as section 2807-c imposes a tax on article 43 corporations, which are exempt from State, county, municipal and school tax (Insurance Law § 4310 [j]), the law cannot repeal an exemption of real or personal property used exclusively for charitable purposes (NY Const, art XVI, § 1). Here, the 9% factor is a tax upon payments to hospitals for services, or the monies paid for hospital services, and that money constitutes personal property. Also, given the purpose of article XVI to protect and preserve the right to tax exemption against adverse legislation, personal property under article XVI includes incorporeal property such as money or payments made for services. Finally, plaintiff, as an article 43 corporation, has a charitable purpose within the meaning of article XVI; the promotion of public health has been expressly recognized as a charitable purpose in this State.

 

681 of 992 DOCUMENTS


People v. Bothwell


Ind. No. 2791/97


SUPREME COURT OF NEW YORK, NEW YORK COUNTY


175 Misc. 2d 592; 671 N.Y.S.2d 595; 1998 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 29



January 15, 1998, Decided


NOTICE:  [***1] EDITED FOR PUBLICATION


SUBSEQUENT HISTORY: As Corrected March 20, 1998.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: This matter was before the New York County Supreme Court on defendant's motion to suppress evidence obtained during his arrest.


OVERVIEW: Two police officers arrested defendant when they saw him holding an open beer bottle in a paper bag. Incident to that seizure, they recovered thirty five bags of crack cocaine. Defendant moved to suppress the evidence, arguing that a mere sighting of an open beer bottle in his hand, without more, did not justify a forcible seizure. The prosecution argued that the Open Container Law, Administrative Code of the City of New York § 10-125 (b), prohibited possession of an open container containing an alcoholic beverage in any public place with intent to drink the same. The court found that the evidence seized and statements acquired by the arrest were not admissible because the police did not see defendant drinking from the bottle, and they never ascertained if the bottle contained beer or was empty. Merely holding an empty beer bottle on a public street was not proper cause for arrest.


OUTCOME: Motion to suppress granted because the police failed to ascertain whether defendant was drinking, or if the bottle contained beer before defendant's arrest for violation of the open container law.


HEADNOTES

Crimes - Unlawful Search and Seizure - Seizure of Suspect Believed to Have Committed Petty Offense

1. Defendant's motion to suppress bags of crack cocaine found on him when two police officers forcibly seized and arrested him for allegedly violating New York City's Open Container Law (Administrative Code of City of NY § 10-125 [b]) after they observed him holding an open beer bottle in a paper bag on the street is granted as the police were not authorized to seize defendant. CPL 140.50 authorizes a police officer to temporarily detain and question a suspect on less than probable cause if the officer has reasonable suspicion to believe the suspect is committing, has committed or is about to commit either a felony or a misdemeanor. A violation of Administrative Code § 10-125 (b) is a petty offense or violation and does not constitute a felony or misdemeanor.

Crimes - Arrest - Probable Cause - Lack of Probable Cause to Believe Defendant Violated Open Container Law

2. Defendant's motion to suppress bags of crack cocaine found on him when two police officers forcibly seized and arrested him for allegedly violating New York City's Open Container Law (Administrative Code of City of NY § 10-125 [b]) after they observed him holding an open beer bottle in a paper bag on the street is granted as the police did not have probable cause to seize defendant. CPL 140.10 (1) (a) authorizes an arrest by a police officer for any offense when he has reasonable cause to believe that the person has committed such offense in his presence, but the officers who seized defendant could not have reasonably believed that defendant had violated the Open Container Law because they never ascertained, before or after the arrest, whether there was any alcohol, or any liquid at all, in the green bottle which one officer claimed to recognize as being a Heineken beer bottle. While Administrative Code § 10-125 (b), by its own terms, creates a presumption that a person in possession of an open container containing an alcoholic beverage possess the same with an intent to consume the contents, that presumption is not available as justification for an arrest when the bottle is empty or when there is no evidence at all of a liquid.

 

682 of 992 DOCUMENTS


Abrams v. New York State & Local Emples. Retirement Sys.


Index No. 2269-97, RJI No. 01-97-ST7693


SUPREME COURT OF NEW YORK, ALBANY COUNTY


175 Misc. 2d 257; 668 N.Y.S.2d 342; 1998 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 4



January 14, 1998, Decided


NOTICE:  [***1] EDITED FOR PUBLICATION



DISPOSITION: Respondents' determination to deny petitioner retroactive membership in the New York State Retirement System was affected by an error of law, and was arbitrary and capricious. The petition is granted and such determination is annulled.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner employee brought an action, under N.Y. C.P.L.R. art. 78, seeking an order annulling respondent officials' determination, pursuant to N.Y. Retire. & Soc. Sec. Law § 803, that held the employee was not entitled to retroactive membership in the state and local employees' retirement system as of July 31, 1975.


OVERVIEW: In his petition, the employee asserted the officials' determination was affected by an error of law, and was arbitrary and capricious. In their answer, the officials contended they acted in full compliance with the law and in no way acted unconstitutionally, erroneously, improperly, arbitrarily, or capriciously. They also contended the determination was on the entire record supported by substantial evidence, and the employee was afforded all required procedural rights. The court annulled the officials' determination because the employee's testimony under oath that he did not participate in a procedure described in to N.Y. Retire. & Soc. Sec. Law § 803(b)(3)(ii) or (iii) met his substantial evidence burden of going forward, and the employer did not came forward with any evidence in support of its contention that the employee participated in a procedure described in § 803(b)(3)(iii).


OUTCOME: The court granted the employee's petition and annulled the officials' determination.


HEADNOTES

Civil Service - Retirement and Pension Benefits - Retroactive Membership

Respondents' determination to deny petitioner retroactive membership in the New York State and Local Employees' Retirement System pursuant to Retirement and Social Security Law § 803 was affected by an error of law and was arbitrary and capricious where respondents erroneously placed the burden upon petitioner to prove that he did not participate in a procedure requiring a formal decision to join a public retirement system and held that petitioner failed to prove that he did not participate in a procedure which a reasonable person would recognize as an opportunity to join or formally decline membership. Retirement and Social Security Law § 803 (b) (3) (iii) provides that the employer must come forward with evidence that petitioner participated in a procedure that a reasonable person would recognize as an explanation or request requiring a formal decision to join a public retirement system. The Legislature very clearly, distinctly, and unmistakably intended something much more comprehensive than a mere opportunity to join a public retirement system. Thus, respondents not only applied an incorrect standard regarding petitioner's burden of going forward but also failed to apply the precise statutory standard as set forth by the Legislature. In addition, there is no rational basis for the administrative determination when evaluated in the context of the correct statutory standards. The only explanation given by respondents consisted of informing petitioner that by not joining the system he could increase his take-home pay. This does not constitute a procedure which a reasonable person would recognize as an explanation or request requiring a formal decision to join a system and the resulting decision not to join cannot be characterized as formal.

 

683 of 992 DOCUMENTS


People v. Fox


Motion Cal. # C-150, Indictment # 97843


COUNTY COURT OF NEW YORK, NASSAU COUNTY


175 Misc. 2d 333; 669 N.Y.S.2d 470; 1997 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 630



December 31, 1997, Decided


NOTICE:  [***1] EDITED FOR PUBLICATION


SUBSEQUENT HISTORY: As Corrected February 23, 1998.



DISPOSITION: Defendant's motion denied in all respects.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant moved to dismiss the indictment against him, alleging that N.Y. Crim. Proc. Law § 730.40(3) was unconstitutional because it violated equal protection and due process protections, or in the alternative, for an order requiring the People to present its case to a new grand jury in the event that the defendant is found competent at a later time.


OVERVIEW: Defendant moved the court to dismiss the indictment against him. Defendant argued that N.Y. Crim. Proc. Law § 730.40(3), which allowed the prosecution to present charges to a grand jury against an accused whose mental competency was being examined pursuant to court order or against an accused who had been adjudicated mentally incompetent, without affording such an accused an opportunity to testify before such grand jury, was constitutionally infirm under both the federal and New York constitutions on equal protection and due process grounds. The motion to dismiss was denied. The right to testify before a grand jury was important, but it was not a fundamental right. The court, using the rational basis review, found that the legislation in question was justified for the reasons proffered by the People. The People proffered adequate justification, avoiding unnecessary and indefinite delay and the possibility of the loss of material witnesses or their memory lapsing. The procedural safeguards in place were not violative of procedural due process. Defendant's alternative requested relief was found premature and more properly presented once he had been found competent.


OUTCOME: The motion to dismiss was denied because the prevention of defendant from testifying before the grand jury did not violate his substantive or procedural due process rights. The alternative request to require representing the matter to a new grand jury was denied as premature.


HEADNOTES

Grand Jury - Right to Appear before Grand Jury - Constitutionality of Statute Denying Right to Mental Incompetents

1. CPL 730.40 (3), which allows the People to present charges to a Grand Jury against a defendant whose mental competency is being examined pursuant to a court order or against a defendant who has been adjudicated mentally incompetent, without affording such defendant an opportunity to testify before such Grand Jury, is not violative of the Equal Protection Clause of either the United States or New York Constitution. In determining the constitutionality of CPL 730.40 (3), the rational basis standard of review is applied since the right to testify before a Grand Jury is not a fundamental right and mental incompetents do not have suspect or quasi-suspect status requiring a heightened standard of review. Under that standard of review the People have proffered more than adequate justification for the legislation in question, i.e., the reduction of unnecessary delay to the system, the indefinite delay which might be caused should the People have to wait for a defendant to be found competent before indictment, and the possibility of the loss of material witnesses or their memory lapses which might be occasioned by such delay.

Grand Jury - Right to Appear before Grand Jury - Constitutionality of Statute Denying Right to Mental Incompetents

2. CPL 730.40 (3), which allows the People to present charges to a Grand Jury against a defendant whose mental competency is being examined pursuant to a court order or against a defendant who has been adjudicated mentally incompetent, without affording such defendant an opportunity to testify before such Grand Jury, is not violative of the Due Process Clause of either the United States or New York Constitution. The right to testify before a Grand Jury is not a fundamental right explicitly or implicitly guaranteed by the United States Constitution, and accordingly there can lie no violation under substantive due process. Moreover, although one's right to testify before a Grand Jury is an important one, the governmental interests that the statute serves, which are the reduction of unnecessary delay to the system, the indefinite delay which might be caused should the People have to wait for a defendant to be found competent before indictment, and the possibility of the loss of material witnesses or their memory lapses which might be occasioned by such delay, are important and legitimate interests, and the procedural safeguards contained in the statute adequately afford procedural due process.

 

684 of 992 DOCUMENTS


People v. Bosco


Indictment No.: 597-19


COUNTY COURT OF NEW YORK, SCHENECTADY COUNTY


175 Misc. 2d 166; 668 N.Y.S.2d 331; 1997 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 623



December 24, 1997, Decided


NOTICE:  [***1] EDITED FOR PUBLICATION



DISPOSITION: Based upon a finding that the People have established that the defendant's release to the community would, under the present circumstances and at the present time, pose a clear and present danger to specific individuals, denial of bail is appropriate.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant, charged with criminal possession of marijuana in the first degree in violation of N.Y. Penal Law § 221.30, brought a motion before the County Court of New York, Schenectady County (New York), that sought an order setting bail.


OVERVIEW: Defendant was charged with criminal possession of marijuana in the first degree in violation of N.Y. Penal Law § 221.30, and brought a motion seeking an order to set bail. The prosecution opposed the motion, arguing that defendant was homicidal and suicidal based on testimony that defendant had a personality disorder and had made multiple violent threats against his former employer. The court denied defendant's motion based on the statutory bail factors contained in N.Y. Crim. Proc. Law § 510.30(2)(a). The court also held that there was clear and convincing evidence that if defendant were released on bail that he would pose a danger to specific individuals and that danger to the community need not be related to the pending criminal charge in order to justify the denial of bail.


OUTCOME: The court denied defendant's motion to set bail. The court held that the prosecution established by clear and convincing evidence that defendant presented a danger to the community and that it was not necessary that the danger to the community be related to the pending criminal charge against defendant.


HEADNOTES

Bail - Right to Bail - Denial Based on Danger to Society

The People established by clear and convincing evidence that the defendant's release to the community would pose a clear and present danger to specific individuals and, therefore, denial of bail is warranted based on preventive detention notwithstanding that the crime defendant faces, a class C felony possession of marihuana, is unrelated to the danger. Evaluation of the statutory bail factors (CPL 510.30 [2] [a]) reveals that the 56-year-old defendant who was terminated several years ago from his job of 25 years repeatedly talks about shooting the people who fired him and his union officials, is unemployed and has limited financial resources, has committed multiple burglaries in the past and faces a maximum sentence of 5 to 15 years in State prison. The granting or denial of bail is a matter of judicial discretion (CPL 530.40 [2]). Although absent from the statutory bail factors, community safety, or preventive detention, may be imposed in rare and extraordinary cases where the proof of danger is clear and convincing. Here, defendant threatened to commit suicide after his planned execution of a series of future murders. The bail factors should be considered broadly since the basis for a defendant's likelihood of appearing in court is often not related to the possible loss of money. Nor is the denial of bail unconstitutional since neither the New York nor Federal Constitution prohibits a court from considering threats of violence and harm that a defendant has made against other individuals and the bail statute requires a court to consider a defendant's mental condition and character.

 

685 of 992 DOCUMENTS


Opusunju v. Giuliani


Index No. 122461/97


SUPREME COURT OF NEW YORK, NEW YORK COUNTY


175 Misc. 2d 541; 669 N.Y.S.2d 156; 1997 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 657



December 19, 1997, Decided


NOTICE:  [***1] EDITED FOR PUBLICATION


SUBSEQUENT HISTORY: As Corrected March 16, 1998.



DISPOSITION: The petition pursuant to CPLR article 78 is denied and dismissed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner residents filed an action under a N.Y. C.P.L.R. art. 78 proceeding against respondent city seeking an injunction.


OVERVIEW: The city wanted to name a street corner after the slain wife of a Nigerian political candidate. The residents and Nigeria objected, claiming that it would embarrass them. The residents and Nigeria claimed that the city had intruded on federal law and interfered with the federal government's power over foreign affairs. The court held that the residents and Nigeria failed to show that the city ventured unconstitutionally into the federal government's foreign affairs by naming the street corner. The court also held that Local Law No. 93 was not irrational or arbitrary.


OUTCOME: The court ruled in favor of the city.


HEADNOTES

Constitutional Law - Validity of Statute - Local Law Renaming Street Corner after Slain Wife of Jailed Nigerian Dissident

1. Local Laws, 1997, No. 93 of the City of New York, which added the name "Kudirat Abiola Corner" to a street corner in New York across from a building owned by the Nigerian government in memory of the slain wife of a jailed Nigerian dissident, does not violate US Constitution article VI which prohibits a State or municipality from enacting any law in conflict with the laws of the United States and which mandates that the Federal Government has exclusive power to conduct foreign affairs. In determining whether a State or local law has crossed the forbidden line into foreign affairs such law must have more than an incidental or indirect effect on foreign affairs before it can be held unconstitutional. A strong presumption of constitutionality applies to State and municipal enactments, and unconstitutionality must be demonstrated beyond a reasonable doubt. Here, the naming of the corner for a slain Nigerian woman whose dissident husband is jailed in Nigeria is not tantamount to the City establishing its own foreign policy. Moreover, the naming does not conflict with any specific Federal policy regarding Nigeria and the naming will not have a "direct impact" on international relations. Also, there is no interference with any overriding Federal policy requiring the local law to give way, and the City has not minutely inquired into the workings of a foreign government or questioned its diplomatic credibility.

Municipal Corporations - Streets - Naming

2. Local Laws, 1997, No. 93 of the City of New York, which added the name "Kudirat Abiola Corner" to a street corner in New York across from a building owned by the Nigerian government in memory of the slain wife of a jailed Nigerian dissident, is not irrational, arbitrary or capricious. Relief under CPLR article 78 requires petitioners to demonstrate a zone of interest and injury in fact entitling them to standing as aggrieved parties. Here, petitioners lack standing since their claims of injury based on an alleged decrease in the value of their building and the possibility of international discord are speculative and do not reasonably flow from the change of name. Therefore, they failed to establish injury. In any event, respondents acted rationally, and not arbitrarily or capriciously, and did not abuse their discretion, in relation to the law. The City has the right to name its own streets. It is not the function of the court to question whether the street corner naming was sufficiently appropriate or discreet. Having found a reasonable and lawful basis for enactment of the law the court's function is exhausted.

 

686 of 992 DOCUMENTS


Doxen v. Wack


Index No. 95400/92


SUPREME COURT OF NEW YORK, NEW YORK COUNTY


175 Misc. 2d 326; 669 N.Y.S.2d 464; 1997 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 635



December 15, 1997, Decided


NOTICE:  [***1] EDITED FOR PUBLICATION


SUBSEQUENT HISTORY: As Corrected March 16, 1998.



DISPOSITION: Motion to preclude testimony and report of Dr. Hegarty denied.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner patient filed a motion before the court to prevent the state from calling a psychiatrist, formerly employed by the State of New York, to testify about the mental status of the patient pursuant to N.Y. Pub. Off. Law § 73.


OVERVIEW: The patient sought to be transferred from a secure mental health facility to a nonsecure facility. The state, in opposing the patient's request, intended to call a psychiatrist who was formerly employed by the state. The patient filed a motion seeking to bar the psychiatrist's testimony under § 73 and the court denied the motion. The court held that § 73 was designed to prevent former government employees from unfairly profiting from or otherwise trading upon the contacts, associations, and special knowledge that they acquired during their tenure as public servants. The court held that whatever contacts the psychiatrist developed with colleagues while employed at the hospital would avail her little when appearing as an expert witness. The court held that it was absurd to contend that such a doctor was exploiting her past associations or employing "inside information" for profit. Such an application would really cripple the use of expert opinions. The court held that the doctor would not profit from her appearance because she will not be compensated for her services in this case. Therefore, the court held that she was permitted to testify.


OUTCOME: The court held that because the psychiatrist was not being paid she was permitted to testify and the patient's motion to preclude her testimony was denied.


HEADNOTES

Public Officers - Conflicts of Interest - Psychiatric Witness Formerly Employed by State

 Public Officers Law § 73, which prohibits a State officer who has separated from service from appearing or rendering services before any State agency or from receiving compensation for any such services rendered in relation to any transaction which the officer was directly concerned with and personally participated in during the period of employment, does not preclude a psychiatrist from appearing before a court and testifying about the mental status of a former psychiatric patient where the psychiatrist was a member of a committee which evaluated the patient and prepared a report concluding that his mental condition posed a substantial danger. Section 73 is designed to prevent former public servants from falling prey to one form of conflict of interest or to the appearances of a conflict and from taking unfair advantage of their insider's knowledge and contacts. A doctor who acquires knowledge of a patient's mental status while in service cannot be considered to be using such knowledge for personal gain and should not be barred from rendering an expert opinion, since such doctor is not exploiting his or her past associations or employing inside information for profit. Also, a proceeding in Supreme Court is not a proceeding before a State agency and the psychiatrist was not directly concerned with the case in that she did not have any personal or financial interest in the case. Moreover, while the prior involvement would bar the psychiatrist from receiving compensation for her services, the psychiatrist will not profit from her appearance. She is not being compensated and she is not receiving a thing of value by enhancement of her reputation.

 

687 of 992 DOCUMENTS


People ex rel. Abraham J. v. Sarkis


INDICTMENT No.: 15676/89


SUPREME COURT OF NEW YORK, KINGS COUNTY


175 Misc. 2d 433; 668 N.Y.S.2d 435; 1997 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 628



December 10, 1997, Decided


NOTICE:  [***1] EDITED FOR PUBLICATION


SUBSEQUENT HISTORY: As Corrected March 2, 1998.



DISPOSITION: Defendant's writ of habeas corpus dismissed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant filed a writ of habeas corpus with the Supreme Court of Kings County (New York) to be released from a psychiatric center to observe a religious holiday.


OVERVIEW: Defendant killed his mother and entered a plea of not guilty by reason of mental disease or defect. After an examination was completed and a retention order issued, defendant was placed in a psychiatric center for a two-year period; he later escaped but turned himself back in. Defendant sought release, by means of a writ of habeas corpus, to his family's custody so that he could celebrate a religious holiday with his family. The court dismissed his writ. The institution's legitimate interests in denying defendant's furlough request were reasonable, and thus did not violate his free-exercise rights under U.S. Const. amend. I.


OUTCOME: Writ of habeas corpus dismissed because, upon balancing the fundamental constitutional rights of the individual and the state's compelling interest in safeguarding him and the community at large, the court found that the restrictions on defendant's ability to practice his religion were not unconstitutional.


HEADNOTES

Mental Health - Person Acquitted of Crime by Reason of Insanity - Religious Freedom - Observation of Jewish High Holy Days

Defendant insanity acquittee, who is detained at respondent psychiatric center pursuant to CPL 330.20 and an adherent of an ultra-observant Hasidic branch of Judaism, is not entitled to furlough or additional accommodations to observe the Holy Days where the respondent already provides a specific area for prayer, relief from duties for prayer, Hasidic yarmulke and garb, Kosher diet, sacred books and prayer accessories, unrestricted growth of beard, an Orthodox chaplain, and special services prior to Holy Days. In determining whether defendant has been denied his religious freedom, his rights must be balanced against respondent's clinical interests including security, confinement, prevention of escapes, therapy, rehabilitation and prevention of patient disruption from unequal treatment. Individuals committed following an insanity plea are subject to reasonable restrictions consistent with the legitimate interests of the institution. CPL 330.20 evidences an intent to keep criminal acquittees within the continued oversight of the Criminal Procedure Law, and to treat criminal acquittees somewhat differently from persons subject to civil commitment. Here, denial of the furlough is consistent with the defendant's safety and that of the community given that defendant, a proven escape risk, is diagnosed with a dangerous mental disorder, posed a danger to himself and others, has failed to prove by a fair preponderance of the evidence that he may be released without danger to himself or others and has not established that his right to free exercise of religion has been violated or that his continued retention is not rationally related to legitimate clinical interests. Furthermore, respondent's accommodations for the Holy Days are adequate, reasonable and/or related to legitimate institutional and societal objectives and pass constitutional muster.

 

688 of 992 DOCUMENTS


Yellen v. Baez


INDEX NO. L&T 53544/97


CIVIL COURT OF THE CITY OF NEW YORK, RICHMOND COUNTY


177 Misc. 2d 332; 676 N.Y.S.2d 724; 1997 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 715



December 8, 1997, Decided


NOTICE:   [***1] EDITED FOR PUBLICATION



DISPOSITION: The amendment to RPAPL 745, requiring that all adjournments of a summary proceeding be charged against the respondent, unless requested by the petitioner, violates both the equal protection clause and due process clause of the New York State Constitution, when applied to adjournments necessary to obtain an interpreter or assistance because of a disability. Therefore, the Court will not charge the adjournment to the respondent.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: At the first court appearance in a summary landlord-tenant proceeding, it was determined that respondent tenants needed a Spanish interpreter and the matter was adjourned. The court was to determine to whom the adjournment was to be charged.


OVERVIEW: Petitioner landlords commenced a summary proceeding against the tenants seeking a money judgment for nonpayment of rent and a warrant of eviction. When the matter first appeared on the court calendar it was determined that the tenants, who were proceeding pro se, needed an interpreter. The matter was adjourned in order that an interpreter could be ordered. The court held that the adjournment should not be charged to the tenants. N.Y. Real Prop. Acts Law § 745, which directed that tenants who had not posted a deposit with the court be charged with certain adjournments, was unconstitutional. Section 745 violated the due process and equal protection provisions of the New York Constitution because it stripped courts of any discretion. Due process of law included the right to have an adequate interpretation of the proceedings. The statute violated the equal protection clause because it created a discriminatory result against all persons who did not speak English.


OUTCOME: The court held that it would not charge the adjournment against the tenants.


HEADNOTES

Landlord and Tenant - Summary Proceedings - Deposit of Rent with Court - Adjournment to Obtain Interpreter to Assist Tenant

In a summary proceeding seeking a money judgment for nonpayment of rent and a warrant of eviction, the adjournment of the proceeding in order to obtain a Spanish interpreter to assist respondent tenant will not be charged against respondent for the purposes of the rent deposit requirements of RPAPL 745. RPAPL 745, which requires the respondent in a summary proceeding to deposit rent payments with the court "upon the second of two adjournments at the request of the respondent, or, upon the thirtieth day after the first appearance of the parties in court less any days that the proceeding has been adjourned upon the request of the petitioner, whichever occurs sooner" (RPAPL 745 [2] [a]), does not give the court any discretion in granting adjournments for the court's purposes or where an interpreter is needed and requires all adjournments other than those requested or consented to by the landlord to be charged against the tenant's 30-day period. However, to charge an adjournment for the purpose of obtaining an interpreter against a non-English speaking tenant violates both the Equal Protection and Due Process Clauses of the United States and New York Constitutions and therefore the court will not charge the adjournment to respondent in spite of the statutory language.

 

689 of 992 DOCUMENTS


People v. Hankin


Doc. No. 97K011682


CRIMINAL COURT OF THE CITY OF NEW YORK, KINGS COUNTY


175 Misc. 2d 83; 667 N.Y.S.2d 890; 1997 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 613



December 5, 1997, Decided


NOTICE:   [***1] EDITED FOR PUBLICATION



DISPOSITION: The motion to dismiss is granted. The information is dismissed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant filed a motion to dismiss the misdemeanor information against him, which charged violations of N.Y. Jud. Law § 482 and N.Y. Penal Law § 175.05.


OVERVIEW: Defendant was an attorney who accepted an unsolicited offer by a state government informant, posing as a private investigator, to refer a client with a personal injury case. Defendant then promised to pay the informant for the referral indirectly, by having the investigator submit a bill for services that were not to be performed. Defendant was charged in a misdemeanor information with violations of N.Y. Jud. Law § 482 and N.Y. Penal Law § 175.05. The court granted defendant's motion to dismiss the information, holding that defendant's payment to the investigator did not constitute prohibited employment of the investigator for the purpose of soliciting legal business because the legal business and retainer had already been secured. The court also found that the requisite intent to defraud was absent because defendant was filing the investigator's bill with his own law firm records.


OUTCOME: The court granted defendant's motion to dismiss the misdemeanor information against him because defendant's conduct did not fall logically fall within the parameters of the statutes' prohibitions and defendant lacked the requisite intent to defraud.


HEADNOTES

Crimes - Solicitation of Law Clients

1. The count of a misdemeanor information charging defendant with a violation of Judiciary Law § 482, which prohibits an attorney from employing any person for the purpose of soliciting legal business, for allegedly accepting an unsolicited offer by an informant posing as a private investigator to refer a client, and then, after the retainer agreement was signed, promising to pay the informant for referring the matter and instructing the informant to send him a bill for investigative services which were not in fact to be performed in order to disguise the payment, is dismissed as legally insufficient. Even the most generous interpretation of the prosecution's pleading does not render defendant's charged conduct violative of the statute since logically, and grammatically, defendant's payment to the informant after the client was retained cannot be said to constitute employment of the informant for the purpose of soliciting legal business or the procurement of a retainer. Overly liberal constructions of criminal laws must always be avoided, especially where, as here, the proscribed conduct is a malum prohibitum, not a malum in se, and even more so when the particular criminal statute is found outside the Penal Law.

Crimes - Falsifying Business Records - Intent to Defraud

2. The count of a misdemeanor information charging defendant attorney with falsifying business records in the second degree in violation of Penal Law § 175.05 for allegedly accepting an unsolicited offer by an informant posing as a private investigator to refer a client, and then, after the retainer agreement was signed, promising to pay the informant for referring the matter and instructing the informant to send him a bill for investigative services which were not in fact to be performed in order to disguise the payment, is dismissed as legally insufficient. As a necessary element of this count, intent to defraud must be pleaded, yet there is not even a suggestion in the accusatory instrument that there was an intent on defendant's part to defraud any person, group or institution by the filing of the investigator's bill with the records of defendant's own law firm. While there may have been an intent to deceive and to cover up an illegal or unethical payment, that does not eliminate the required element of intent to defraud, commonly understood to mean to cheat someone out of money, other property or something of value.

 

690 of 992 DOCUMENTS


People v. Gordon


Ind. No. 273-97


SUPREME COURT OF NEW YORK, QUEENS COUNTY


175 Misc. 2d 67; 667 N.Y.S.2d 626; 1997 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 598



November 18, 1997, Decided


SUBSEQUENT HISTORY:  [***1] As Corrected February 2, 1998.



DISPOSITION: Defense Attorney's motions to dismiss denied in their entirety.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Motion to dismiss an indictment in a murder case in the Supreme Court of New York, Queens County, for multiplicity, duplicity, double counting, and sufficiency.


OVERVIEW: Defendant moved to dismiss the indictment upon the grounds of heightened due process, multiplicity, duplicity, double counting, vagueness, and sufficiency. The court denied the motion, holding that to assume that a capital case required a heightened standard would infer that defendants in nondeath penalty cases warranted a lesser standard. Further, defendant was properly charged with respect to different counts of murder as to each of the three decedents because his alleged conduct, though emanating from one set of acts involving each victim, violated various penal sections. The test used to determine if an indictment contained a duplicitous count was failed. Moreover, a penal statute would not be struck down as unconstitutionally vague as applied if the statute provided persons with sufficient notice of prohibited conduct and did not permit or encourage arbitrary law enforcement.


OUTCOME: Defendant's motions to dismiss denied in their entirety because the counts were not multiplicitous, duplicitous, or double-counted. Heightened due process was not required, the penal statute was not vague and did not double-count, and the indictment was sufficient.


HEADNOTES

Crimes - Murder - Capital Murder - Heightened Due Process

1. When the death penalty is a possible outcome of a criminal prosecution, State and Federal law do not demand a heightened standard of due process at every phase of the case. While it is axiomatic that a death penalty case is qualitatively different from all other kinds, it does not require a judicial rewriting or reinterpretation of the rules governing the various pretrial proceedings. To assume that a capital case requires such a "heightened" standard in pretrial proceedings would invariably conclude that defendants in nondeath penalty cases would warrant a lesser standard of due process.

Crimes - Indictment - Multiplicity - Capital Case

2. In a capital murder prosecution arising out of the slaying of three people during the commission of various felonies, it cannot be said that the inclusion of different felonies in the same statutory subparagraph of murder in the first degree indicated a legislative intent that a single murder can only sustain a single charge under Penal Law § 125.27 (1) (a) (vii). Where each of the various counts charging first degree murder requires proof that the alleged killing of the victim occurred during the furtherance of a different felony, defendant was properly charged with respect to different counts of first degree murder as to each of the three decedents because his alleged conduct, though emanating from one set of acts involving each victim, violated various sections of the Penal Law. The mere fact that the Legislature chose to list a series of felonies together within one of the 12 subparagraphs of the statutory aggravating factors cannot be taken to mean that they intended to allow only one count of intentional murder during the course of a felony to be charged, even if a defendant committed an intentional killing in the furtherance of multiple felonies. Accordingly, counts charging first degree murder under section 125.27 (1) (a) (viii) regarding the death of a victim during the same criminal transaction in which defendant also allegedly caused the death of another victim, and a count charging first degree murder under section 125.27 (1) (a) (x) regarding the killing of a victim while acting in an especially cruel and wanton manner, are not multiplicitous.

Crimes - Indictment - Duplicitous Counts - Capital Case

3. In a capital murder prosecution arising out of the slaying of three people during the commission of various felonies, it cannot be said that the burglary counts contained in the indictment are duplicitous due to the People's failure to particularize and connect a particular entry to a particular charge involving the burglary, where the crimes with which defendant is charged occurred in a three-story structure with a common front door, one apartment per floor, each apartment having its own front door. The three counts charging first degree murder are not duplicitous since there are three different victims; similarly, the three counts of second degree murder, the two counts of attempted first degree murder and the two counts of first degree burglary are not duplicitous since each pertains to a different victim. Furthermore, two counts charging first degree murder--the intentional murder of one person during the commission of sodomy--are not duplicitous, inasmuch as two different acts formed the basis of the two sodomies; and two other counts charging first degree murder--the intentional murder of yet another victim during the commission of sexual abuse--are not duplicitous inasmuch as two different acts formed the basis of the two different sexual abuse conducts.

Crimes - Indictment - Duplicitous Counts - Capital Case

4. In a capital murder prosecution arising out of the slaying of three people during the commission of various felonies, it cannot be said that the burglary counts contained in the indictment are duplicitous due to the People's failure to particularize and connect a particular entry to a particular charge involving the burglary. Although the Mississippi Supreme Court has held that capital murder indictments predicated upon burglary must state the underlying offense to the burglary, the New York Court of Appeals has consistently held that in order to secure a conviction for burglary, the People need only allege and prove a knowing and unlawful entry coupled with an intent to commit a crime therein; there is no requirement that the People allege or establish what particular crime was intended, or that the intended crime actually be committed. Although the Court of Appeals rulings were in noncapital cases, this court will not disregard New York law and hold otherwise because this indictment charges capital offenses.

Crimes - Indictment - Double Counting - Capital Case

5. In a capital murder prosecution arising out of the slaying of three people during the commission of various felonies, it cannot be said that counts of the indictment charging burglary in the first degree, rather than burglary in the third degree, as the felony underlying first degree murder, impermissibly double count the use of a deadly weapon element; nor can it be said that those counts along with the felony murder and attempted murder counts, if all based upon burglaries alleging intent to kill as the criminal intent at the time of entry, impermissibly double count the intent to kill. The use of a gun is not an element in the felony murder counts nor is it an element in the attempted murder counts. Moreover, to establish the murder element of the crime, the People must prove an intentional murder, while as to the burglary element, the People need only prove that the defendant unlawfully entered and remained in the victim's premises with the intent to commit a crime, in this case, an intentional death. There is no prohibition, constitutional or otherwise, of using a single circumstance such as the victim's death to establish more than one element of the crime charged. Accordingly, defense counsel has failed to establish that any counts of the indictment impermissibly double count the use of a weapon or the intent to kill.

Crimes - Murder - Capital Murder - Vagueness of Statutory Elements

6. In a capital murder prosecution arising out of the slaying of three people during the commission of various felonies, it cannot be said that the phrases "in the course of", "in furtherance of", "in the same criminal transaction" and "especially cruel and wanton" are unconstitutionally vague and overbroad, rendering the felony murder statutes unconstitutional. A penal statute must be worded so as to put the defendant on notice of what conduct is prohibited and to limit the potential of arbitrary law enforcement. In this case defendant received fair notice, in the indictment and in the bill of particulars, of the crimes with which he was charged. It cannot be said that the wording of the indictment fails in these requirements; nor is the court aware of any precedent which holds that these contested phrases have been considered unconstitutionally vague in the context of jury instructions pertaining to that crime. Likewise, there is no reason to believe that these phrases are insufficiently precise for the purpose of defining an element of first degree murder.

 

691 of 992 DOCUMENTS


People v. Rosenblatt


Indictment No. 2490/97


SUPREME COURT OF NEW YORK, NEW YORK COUNTY


174 Misc. 2d 976; 667 N.Y.S.2d 886; 1997 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 582



November 17, 1997, Decided


NOTICE:  [***1] EDITED FOR PUBLICATION


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendants filed an omnibus motion for various forms of relief after they were indicted for failure to file sales tax returns and pay sales tax, for selling tickets above the maximum premium price, and for aggravated ticket speculation. One defendant filed a motion to dismiss his indictment.


OVERVIEW: Defendants owned a ticket brokerage firm and were in the business of reselling tickets to sports and entertainment events in 1995 and 1996. During those two years, defendants remitted no sales taxes and filed no sales tax returns. The company sold tickets at prices far above those established by the venue and had not applied for a license to resell tickets. Defendants were indicted for various crimes relating to their business, including failure to pay sales tax. Defendants filed an omnibus motion and a motion to dismiss an indictment, and the court denied the motions. The court found that defendants' discovery motions were procedurally defective, untimely, and inappropriate. The court held that the search warrant was properly issued and that the arrests were legal. The court found that the evidence offered by the defense in support of a claim of selective or inappropriately retributive prosecution was inadequate. The court further found that defendants charged much more than the law allowed and that their illegal profit was not a mere service charge that was not subject to sales tax. The court held that N.Y. Tax Law § 1105 and N.Y. Arts & Cult. Aff. Law § 25 were constitutional.


OUTCOME: The court denied defendants' omnibus motion that requested various forms of relief after they were indicted for failure to file sales tax returns and pay sales tax, for selling tickets above the maximum premium price, and for aggravated ticket speculation. The court also denied one defendant's motion to dismiss his indictment.


HEADNOTES

Taxation - Sales and Use Taxes - Taxation on Resale of Theater and Entertainment Tickets by Ticket Brokerage Company Tax Law article 28 imposes an obligation to collect sales tax for the resale of tickets to customers by a ticket brokerage firm; accordingly, defendant owners of a ticket brokerage firm, in the business of reselling tickets to sports and entertainment events, are responsible for sales tax. To the extent that sales tax was already paid by defendants when they bought the tickets, tax is not due, but tax is due on the balance, whether the ticket is considered a taxable admission charge or, more generally, tangible property.

Constitutional Law - Validity of Statute - Taxation on Resale of Theater and Entertainment Tickets Tax Law § 1105 (f) (1), which imposes sales tax for the resale of tickets to customers by a ticket brokerage firm, is not unconstitutionally vague; accordingly, defendant owners of a ticket brokerage firm are responsible for sales tax on their resale of tickets to sports and entertainment events. Tax Law § 1105 (a) provides that a sales tax must be collected upon the receipts from every retail sale of tangible property except as otherwise provided in article 28, and section 1132 (c) (1) provides that all amusement charges are subject to tax until the contrary is established. Defendants failed to establish that their profits on the sale of the tickets come within any exception. These Tax Law provisions provide a person of ordinary intelligence with adequate notice that defendants owe sales tax.

Constitutional Law - Validity of Statute - Price-Fixing Scheme on Resale of Theater and Entertainment Tickets Arts and Cultural Affairs Law article 25 is constitutional, notwithstanding Tyson & Brother v Banton (273 US 418), which held that the predecessor statute to the statute at issue, Arts and Cultural Affairs Law § 25.09, which set the maximum price for which a theater entertainment ticket could be resold, contravened the Due Process Clause of the US Constitution since, while never explicitly overruled, the holding is no longer applied and is not binding precedent.

 

692 of 992 DOCUMENTS


Davis v. Isaacson, Robustelli, Fox, Fine, Greco & Fogelgaren, P.C.


Index No. 135409/94


SUPREME COURT OF NEW YORK, NEW YORK COUNTY


175 Misc. 2d 40; 667 N.Y.S.2d 608; 1997 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 587



November 12, 1997, Decided



DISPOSITION:  [***1] Defendant Kuttner's motion to dismiss the complaint denied.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant attorney filed a motion to dismiss plaintiff client's legal malpractice action based upon alleged continuance of representation following the referral of plaintiff's workers' compensation case to separate attorneys.


OVERVIEW: Plaintiff client brought a legal malpractice claim against defendant attorney alleging that subsequent to defendant's referral of plaintiff's workers' compensation claim to a separate firm, defendant's representation continued through the conclusion of plaintiff's representation by the firm. Defendant subsequently filed a motion to dismiss plaintiff's claims. The court denied defendant's motion to dismiss. The court held that the amendment to N.Y. C.P.L.R. 214(6) was required to have been treated as technically retroactive in this situation, but held that under the facts of the case, overriding constitutional prohibitions controlled the ultimate outcome. The court ruled that the amendment to N.Y. C.P.L.R. 214(6) could not be applied consistent with constitutional requirements, and would not be applied in order to bar plaintiffs' claims.


OUTCOME: The court denied defendant attorney's motion to dismiss plaintiff client's legal malpractice action. The court determined that constitutional considerations worked to prevent the application of a newly amended civil practice rule with a shortened limitations period.


HEADNOTES

Statutes - Retroactive Application of Statute - Three-Year Statute of Limitations for Legal Malpractice

Plaintiff's action for legal malpractice, which was commenced on January 29, 1997, less than six years after defendant's representation of plaintiff was concluded in November 1991 but after the September 1996 amendment to CPLR 214 (6) which reduced the Statute of Limitations period for legal malpractice from six to three years, is not time barred as it would be unconstitutional to apply the shorter three-year period to plaintiff. Where in shortening the Statute of Limitations the Legislature affords plaintiff no time to prosecute his claims, and no time whatsoever remained for him to sue under the shortened statute, as a matter of law plaintiff is deprived of a reasonable time to bring suit, which violates the constitutional provision that no person shall be deprived of property without due process of law.

 

693 of 992 DOCUMENTS


State ex rel. Henry L. v. Hawes


Index No. 97-538


COUNTY COURT OF NEW YORK, FRANKLIN COUNTY


174 Misc. 2d 929; 667 N.Y.S.2d 212; 1997 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 592



November 10, 1997, Decided


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Relator filed a habeas corpus petition to challenge the action of respondent, the Commissioner of the Office of Mental Retardation and Developmental Disabilities (commissioner), in transferring him from a nonsecure facility to a secure facility. Relator was an acquittee by reason of insanity.


OVERVIEW: Relator challenged his transfer from a nonsecure facility to a secure facility because there was no order of conditions in place at the time. The commissioner challenged the habeas corpus proceeding, claiming the issue should be included in a pending appeal in another case, and that the relator's failure to litigate the issue on two previous occasions barred its consideration here. While the court recognized that the relator's failure to raise the issue in his direct appeal would generally bar its inclusion in the habeas proceeding, it also noted that an exception existed when the allegations dealt with fundamental rights. The court found that the confinement of an individual in a secure facility, when he was entitled to be confined in a nonsecure one, affected such a fundamental freedom. The court found that under N.Y. Crim. Proc. Law § 330.20(14), the pendency of an order of conditions was a jurisdictional condition precedent to a recommitment application. Because there was no pending order of conditions at the time of transfer, the court found that there was no authority for the transfer.


OUTCOME: The court sustained the writ of habeas corpus and ordered that relator be transferred to a nonsecure facility within seven days of the date of its order.


HEADNOTES

Crimes - Insanity - Recommitment Order - Effect of Failure to Follow Procedural Requirements for Obtaining Recommitment Order Relator, an insanity acquittee, was illegally transferred from a nonsecure to a secure facility and has been illegally detained in the secure facility ever since as respondent Office of Mental Retardation and Developmental Disabilities (OMRDD) failed to follow the procedures set forth in CPL 330.20 for obtaining a recommitment order and respondent Commissioner therefore had no authority to transfer relator; accordingly, relator's writ of habeas corpus is sustained and respondent Commissioner is ordered to immediately remove relator from the secure facility and transfer him back to the nonsecure facility. Pursuant to CPL 330.20 (14), the pendency of an order of conditions is a jurisdictional condition precedent to a recommitment application and, as a result, recommitment itself. Relator's order of conditions expired several years ago and was never extended, and no application for a recommitment order was made when the order of conditions was still in effect. Since no timely application was made for recommitment the Commissioner retained absolutely no authority under CPL 330.20 to transfer relator from a nonsecure to a secure facility, and furthermore no jurisdiction exists for any court to order or permit the transfer. The Commissioner has no choice but to proceed civilly pursuant to the Mental Hygiene Law to now obtain the relief he seeks--relator's confinement in a secure facility--and even if relator does currently suffer from a dangerous mental disorder and needs to be confined in a secure facility, that fact alone does not relieve OMRDD of its obligation to accomplish such a result pursuant to statutory and constitutional restrictions.

 

694 of 992 DOCUMENTS


Targee Mgmt., L. L .C. v. Jones


Index No.: L&T 52141/97


CIVIL COURT OF THE CITY OF NEW YORK, RICHMOND COUNTY


177 Misc. 2d 323; 677 N.Y.S.2d 206; 1997 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 714



November 10, 1997, Decided


NOTICE:   [***1] EDITED FOR PUBLICATION



DISPOSITION: The Order to Show Cause is granted on the condition that the tenant post $ 388.30, the amount that was due on October 20, 1997, with the Court.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner landlord requested a warrant of eviction against respondent tenant. The tenant submitted an order to show cause, seeking to prevent the execution of the warrant of eviction requested by the landlord. The parties had entered into a stipulation, and the tenant defaulted.


OVERVIEW: N.Y. Real Prop. Act. Law § 747-a (1997) was enacted by the state legislature and the tenant argued that the statute was unconstitutional. Section 747-a provided that the trial court could not grant a stay of the execution of the warrant of eviction unless the tenant either established that the judgment amount was paid to the landlord prior to the execution of the warrant or that the tenant had deposited the full amount of the judgment with the clerk of the court. The court held that § 747-a could have been applied retroactively to money judgments because it did not go to the essence of the judgment but only affected a postjudgment remedy. However, the court held that the tenant was entitled to a stay of the eviction pending a hearing. The court concluded that § 747-a was unconstitutional because it contradicted both N.Y. Real Prop. Act. Law § 749 and N.Y.C.P.L.R. 2201.


OUTCOME: The court granted the order to show cause on the condition that the tenant post the amount that was due to the landlord with the court.


HEADNOTES

Statutes - Retroactive Application of Statute - RPAPL 747-a 

1. RPAPL 747-a, which provides that in the City of New York in any nonpayment summary proceeding in which the respondent has appeared and the petitioner has obtained a judgment pursuant to RPAPL 747 and more than five days have elapsed, the court shall not grant a stay of the issuance or execution of any warrant of eviction nor stay the reletting of the premises unless the respondent shall have either established to the satisfaction of the court by a sworn statement and documentary proof that the judgment amount was paid to the petitioner prior to the execution of the warrant or the respondent has deposited the full amount of such judgment with the clerk of the court, can be applied retroactively to money judgments since it does not go to the essence of the judgment itself but only affects a postjudgment remedy.

Constitutional Law - Equal Protection of Laws - RPAPL 747-a 

2. RPAPL 747-a, which provides that in the City of New York in any nonpayment summary proceeding in which the respondent has appeared and the petitioner has obtained a judgment pursuant to RPAPL 747 and more than five days have elapsed, the court shall not grant a stay of the issuance or execution of any warrant of eviction nor stay the reletting of the premises unless the respondent shall have either established to the satisfaction of the court by a sworn statement and documentary proof that the judgment amount was paid to the petitioner prior to the execution of the warrant or the respondent has deposited the full amount of such judgment with the clerk of the court, violates the Equal Protection Clause of the New York Constitution (art I, § 11). If the tenant is required to post the entire amount of the judgment outstanding, the court is being deprived of the discretion it was given under RPAPL 749 to evaluate each application on its merits. To use a delay in making one of the scheduled payments as the triggering of a requirement to pay the balance due or the total amount of the judgment in effect negates the agreement of the parties, deprives the court of its discretion to monitor the stipulation and makes access to the court available only to those who can afford to make payments. Additionally, the statute does not make any provision for those tenants who receive assistance from the Department of Social Services or the Jiggetts program and are awaiting payment, which may be delayed. Moreover, while RPAPL 753 and 755 require the tenant to deposit money into court or directly to the landlord, neither of them deprives the tenant of access to the court and a hearing on an order to show cause.

Constitutional Law - Due Process of Law - RPAPL 747-a 

3. RPAPL 747-a, which provides that in the City of New York in any nonpayment summary proceeding in which the respondent has appeared and the petitioner has obtained a judgment pursuant to RPAPL 747 and more than five days have elapsed, the court shall not grant a stay of the issuance or execution of any warrant of eviction nor stay the reletting of the premises unless the respondent shall have either established to the satisfaction of the court by a sworn statement and documentary proof that the judgment amount was paid to the petitioner prior to the execution of the warrant or the respondent has deposited the full amount of such judgment with the clerk of the court, violates the Due Process Clause of the New York Constitution (art I, § 6). A literal reading of the language of the statute requires the payment of the entire money judgment amount and makes no provision for crediting the tenant with payments made to reduce the amount owed the landlord. Thus, the statute would necessitate the tenant paying money into court in excess of the amount owed in order to have a hearing, which deprives the tenant of his or her property, the excess deposit, without due process of law. Further, the inability of the tenant to post the entire money judgment would result in the tenant being evicted from the apartment and deprived of that property right without a hearing and in violation of the Due Process Clause.

 

695 of 992 DOCUMENTS


Bailey v. Goord


Index No. 18,108


SUPREME COURT OF NEW YORK, WYOMING COUNTY


174 Misc. 2d 632; 666 N.Y.S.2d 383; 1997 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 540



November 6, 1997, Decided


NOTICE:   [***1]  EDITED FOR PUBLICATION


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Before the court was the petitioner inmate who pursuant to N.Y. C.P.L.R. art. 78 challenged the constitutionality of the policy of respondent, the Commissioner of the Department of Correctional Services, to segregate him from other inmates because he refused to submit to a tuberculosis test.


OVERVIEW: The inmate filed petition to challenge the constitutionality of a policy to segregate him from other inmates because he refused to submit to a tuberculosis test. The inmate refused to submit to the test, which involved the injection of a protein with a syringe, would improperly invade his body in violation of his religious beliefs. The inmate had agreed to submit to chest x-rays to monitor his health. The Commissioner's policy however mandated that any inmate who refused the test be monitored in special confinement for one year and only released after three chest x-rays yielded negative results. The court found that the policy was constitutional and that the inmate had failed to establish a violation of his constitutional rights. The court determined that the Commissioner had a legitimate and compelling penological interest in preventing the spread of tuberculosis. The court found that policy was adopted in a neutral manner, that it was not directed toward any religious practices or beliefs, and that there was no better means of acCommodating the inmate's beliefs without jeopardizing the institutional goals.


OUTCOME: The court ordered that the proceeding be converted to an action for a declaratory judgment and declared that the inmate failed to show that the policy of segregation for one year after his refusal to allow the tuberculosis test violated his constitutional rights.


HEADNOTES

Prisons and Prisoners - Conditions of Confinement - Restrictive Medical Confinement for Prisoner Refusing to be Tested for Tuberculosis A prisoner's CPLR article 78 petition challenging the constitutionality of a policy which segregates him from other inmates for a one-year period because he has refused to submit to a tuberculosis test on religious grounds is denied. While respondent's policy, which mandates that inmates who refuse a tuberculosis test must be monitored in special confinement for one year and only released after three chest x-rays yield negative results, does infringe upon petitioner's religious rights to some degree by forcing him to submit to a medical procedure which conflicts with his beliefs or accept more restrictive conditions of confinement, the policy is reasonably related to legitimate penological objectives and is therefore constitutional. Respondent has a legitimate and compelling penological interest in preventing the spread of tuberculosis in the State prison system, the policy was adopted in an attempt to advance this interest in a neutral manner, the policy is rationally related to preventing the spread of disease, and respondent limits the duration of restrictive confinement to one year and grants confined inmates daily recreation and three showers per week, conditions which do not constitute cruel and inhuman treatment.

 

696 of 992 DOCUMENTS


Ouziel v. State


Motion No. M-55836


COURT OF CLAIMS OF NEW YORK


174 Misc. 2d 900; 667 N.Y.S.2d 872; 1997 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 600



October 23, 1997, Decided


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: The individual filed an application for an order permitting him to serve a late claim pursuant to the Court of Claims Act § 10(6).


OVERVIEW: Defendant state's Department of Taxation and Finance (Department) levied against the individual's bank account and was paid therefrom a certain sum. The levy was made pursuant to a determination by the Department that the individual was a responsible person of a corporation that failed to timely pay sales tax. The individual alleged that he was a shareholder and not an officer or responsible person of the corporation. The notices of determination of taxes due were issued to the individual on January 9, 1995. On October 7, 1995, the individual wrote to the department requesting that his letter be considered a notice of appeal. That request was repeated in a letter of December 15, 1995. On January 13, 1997, the individual requested a conciliation conference which was denied by the department. The court denied the individual's application by holding that the proposed claim was beyond their subject matter jurisdiction because the primary relief sought was the annulling of the department's determination, which was properly the subject of a N.Y. C.P.L.R. 78 proceeding.


OUTCOME: The court denied the individual's application for an order permitting him to serve a late claim because the proposed claim was beyond the court's subject matter jurisdiction as the primary relief sought was the annulling of the department's determination, which was properly the subject of another proceeding.


HEADNOTES

State - Claim against State - Permission to File Late Claim - Improperly Recovered Sales Tax An application pursuant to Court of Claims Act § 10 for leave to file a late claim alleging that the State Department of Taxation and Finance improperly recovered sales tax unpaid by a corporation from movant because he was not a responsible person of the corporation within the meaning of Tax Law § 1133 is denied where movant neither timely pursued an administrative tax appeal whose determination would have been subject to CPLR article 78 review, nor sought a declaratory judgment that he was not a person responsible for the sales tax. While the State will not be prejudiced by any delay in the filing of the claim, movant's alleged ignorance of his legal remedies and reliance on erroneous information supplied by employees of the Department of Taxation and Finance are insufficient excuses for his delay, and movant had at least two judicial remedies available to him which he chose not to timely pursue. Moreover, the Court of Claims lacks subject matter jurisdiction of a claim in which the requested monetary relief cannot be rendered without reviewing and annulling an administrative determination of the Department of Taxation and Finance since the primary relief sought is equitable in nature and the monetary relief is incidental to the primary claim. The Court of Claims will not have subject matter jurisdiction until such time as movant has the tax statute, implementing regulation or administrative action declared unconstitutional or illegal by a court with the jurisdiction to accord that relief.

 

697 of 992 DOCUMENTS


New York v. Diraimondo


DOCKET NO. 24054/97


DISTRICT COURT OF NEW YORK, FIRST DISTRICT, NASSAU COUNTY


174 Misc. 2d 937; 667 N.Y.S.2d 205; 1997 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 591



October 22, 1997, Decided



DISPOSITION:  [***1] Defendant's motion to dismiss denied in all respects.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant moved for an order dismissing the information charging her with a violation of N.Y. Penal Law § 240.30(1), aggravated harassment in the second degree, pursuant to N.Y. Crim. Proc. Law § 170.30(1) on the grounds that it was defective. Defendant also argued that the statute was unconstitutional because it was overbroad and vague.


OVERVIEW: The complaining witness received several telephone calls asking her for sexual favors, which were caused by defendant posting signs at a train station. Defendant argued that the information did not sufficiently allege that defendant communicated or caused a communication to be initiated and that defendant's conduct, even if true, would not satisfy the element of "causing a communication to be initiated by mechanical or electronic means or otherwise." The court held that the legislature could have limited the scope of the statute solely to communications initiated by mechanical or electronic means by excluding the words "or otherwise", but chose not to do so and dismissed defendant's motion. The court held that under the broad scope of the statute, defendant's acts fell within the conduct prohibited by the legislature in its enactment of N.Y. Penal Law § 240.30(1). The court found that the information was legally sufficient pursuant to N.Y. Crim. Proc. Law § 100.15 and N.Y. Crim. Proc. Law § 100.40. The court held that that there was an intent to harass, annoy, threaten or alarm another person.


OUTCOME: The court dismissed the motion to dismiss, holding that the posting of the signs had no other intent except to cause harassment of the victim and the statute was therefore narrowly drawn and constitutional.


HEADNOTES

Crimes - Aggravated Harassment - Facial Sufficiency of Complaint - Posting of Signs as Causing Communication to be Initiated An information charging defendant with second degree aggravated harassment (Penal Law § 240.30 [1]) for posting signs at a train station indicating "4 Hot Easy Sex call [complainant]" and "Free B. . . J. . . call [complainant]", which caused the complainant to receive several telephone calls asking her for sexual favors, is legally sufficient as defendant's acts fall within the conduct prohibited by the Legislature in its enactment of Penal Law § 240.30 (1). A person is guilty of second degree harassment when, with the intent to harass, annoy, threaten or alarm another, he or she "[c]ommunicates, or causes a communication to be initiated by mechanical or electronic means or otherwise, with a person, anonymously or otherwise ... in a manner likely to cause annoyance or alarm". Although the inclusion of the phrase "or causes a communication to be initiated by mechanical or electronic means or otherwise" was directed towards the use of a commercial device that attaches to a telephone and is capable of making repeated calls of recordings to prospective customers, there is no requirement that the communication be initiated only by mechanical or electronic means. The Legislature could have so limited the scope of the statute by excluding the words "or otherwise", but chose not to do so.

Crimes - Aggravated Harassment - Constitutionality of Statute Defendant's motion to dismiss an indictment charging her with second degree aggravated harassment (Penal Law § 240.30 [1]) for posting signs at a train station indicating "4 Hot Easy Sex call [complainant]" and "Free B. . . J. . . call [complainant]", which caused the complainant to receive several telephone calls asking her for sexual favors, on the ground that Penal Law § 240.30 (1) is constitutionally void for vagueness and overbroad as applied to defendant is denied as defendant has failed to meet her heavy burden of proving the statute unconstitutional beyond a reasonable doubt. Penal Law § 240.30 (1) was intended to deal with communications which are directed to an unwilling recipient under circumstances wherein substantial privacy interests are being invaded in an essentially intolerable manner. There must be an intent to harass, annoy, threaten or alarm another person and the communication must be made in a manner likely to cause annoyance or alarm; the posted signage cannot be interpreted with any other intent.

 

698 of 992 DOCUMENTS


People v. Barrows


Indictment No. 15872/96


SUPREME COURT OF NEW YORK, KINGS COUNTY


174 Misc. 2d 367; 664 N.Y.S.2d 410; 1997 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 473



September 26, 1997, Decided


NOTICE:  [***1] EDITED FOR PUBLICATION



DISPOSITION: Defendant's motion to dismiss indictment denied.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant petitioned the court to dismiss his indictment under N.Y. Penal Law § 235.22 for transmitting child pornography and attempting to lure a minor to engage in deviant sexual acts, on the grounds that the statute was vague or overbroad, and violated the Commerce Clause.


OVERVIEW: Defendant's motion to dismiss his indictment for transmitting child pornography and attempting to lure a minor to engage in deviant sexual acts was denied. The court held that N.Y. Penal Law § 235.22 was not vague or overbroad, and was not violative of the Commerce Clause. In reaching its conclusion, the court held that, while a state could not prohibit or criminalize general transmission of materials over the Internet, a state could criminalize pornographic transmissions that were coupled with the intent to lure a minor into sexual conduct. The court found that, although the first part of N.Y. Penal Law § 235.22 was general and would not withstand constitutional scrutiny standing alone, the second part, which confined the conduct to obscenity or pornographic materials with the intent to lure a minor to engage in sexual conduct, withstood constitutional scrutiny. According to the court, an Internet user need have no fear about the nature or content of transmissions, so long as they were not coupled with an attempt to lure a minor into sexual conduct.


OUTCOME: The court denied defendant's motion to dismiss his indictment, because the statute prohibiting the transmission of obscene or pornographic materials with the intent to lure a minor into sexual conduct was conditionally valid.


HEADNOTES

Crimes - Disseminating Indecent Material to Minors - Constitutionality of Statute Defendant's motion to dismiss the indictment charging him with attempted disseminating indecent material to a minor in the first degree (Penal Law § 235.22) for communicating on the Internet with someone he thought was a 13-year-old girl, sending her sexual stories and photos, arranging a meeting with her in New York and then traveling from his home in Connecticut to meet with her, on the ground that the statute is unconstitutionally vague or overbroad and violates the Commerce Clause, is denied. While the first element of the statute, standing alone, might not survive constitutional scrutiny because it regulates Internet transmissions and does not confine prohibited transmissions to obscene and pornographic materials, it must be read in conjunction with the second required element, which requires conduct luring a minor to engage in sexual conduct, and it is the "luring" element that saves the statute from constitutional infirmity. An Internet user need have no fear about the nature or content of transmissions, under the statute, so long as they are not coupled with an attempt to lure a minor into sexual conduct. Taken in its entirety, Penal Law § 235.22 is not unconstitutionally vague or overbroad and does not violate the Commerce Clause.

 

699 of 992 DOCUMENTS


People v. Kleiner


Ind. # 093/96


SUPREME COURT OF NEW YORK, RICHMOND COUNTY


174 Misc. 2d 261; 664 N.Y.S.2d 704; 1997 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 474



September 16, 1997, Decided


NOTICE:  [***1] EDITED FOR PUBLICATION



DISPOSITION: Defendant's application to set aside jury verdict denied.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant sought review of a judgment from the a trial court (New York), where a jury found defendant guilty of seven counts of unauthorized practice of medicine without a license in violation of N.Y. Educ. Law § 6512(1).


OVERVIEW: A jury convicted defendant on seven counts of unauthorized practice of medicine without a license in violation of N.Y. Educ. Law § 6512(1). Defendant argued that he did not have actual knowledge of the revocation of his medical license, and he could not be found guilty beyond a reasonable doubt of violating § 6512(1). On appeal, the court did not agree with defendant and affirmed defendant's guilty verdict. Section 6512(1) did not expressly require actual knowledge on the part of defendant in order to be convicted of unauthorized practice of medicine without a license. The mailing of the notice of revocation created a rebuttable inference that defendant knew that his license had been revoked and that he was no longer authorized to practice medicine in the state. Plaintiff state had presented sufficient evidence that defendant had been personally served the notice of the charges, and had been mailed the notice of revocation. A jury could conclude beyond a reasonable doubt that defendant knew that his license had been revoked, and this was sufficient for finding him guilty for violating § 6512(1).


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the trial court's judgment, where a jury found defendant guilty of seven counts of unauthorized practice of medicine without a license, because there was sufficient evidence that defendant knew his license was revoked and was sufficient for the jury to find him guilty.


HEADNOTES
