Crimes - Unauthorized Practice of Profession - Physician's Knowledge of License Suspension Defendant's motion to set aside the verdict convicting him of practicing medicine without a license in violation of Education Law § 6512 (1) on the ground that the notice requirements of the civil hearing to revoke his medical license and the notice requirements to advise him that his license was revoked as a result of the civil hearing are unconstitutionally inadequate is denied. The process of revoking or suspending a physician's license is constitutional in that it provides for due process through the civil hearing process of giving notice to the defendant, with an opportunity to be heard, to present evidence on his own and to confront the evidence against him. Education Law § 6512 (1) does not require that defendant have actual knowledge of his license revocation in order to be convicted of this statute; rather, Education Law § 6510 (4) (c) only provides that an order revoking a license be served upon the licensee personally or by certified mail to the licensee's last known address. As the People demonstrated that notice of the hearing and notice of the subsequent revocation were mailed by the Department of Health pursuant to the statutory requirements, a reasonable jury could conclude beyond a reasonable doubt that the notice was sent and can thereby infer that it was received, thereby giving defendant knowledge that his license was revoked. Moreover, defendant clearly acknowledged by his response to the National Practitioner Data Bank, which had notified him that his license had been revoked, that he had actual knowledge that his license was revoked.

 

700 of 992 DOCUMENTS


People v. Mateo


Ind. No. 0914/96


COUNTY COURT OF NEW YORK, MONROE COUNTY


175 Misc. 2d 192; 664 N.Y.S.2d 981; 1997 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 469



August 25, 1997, Decided


SUBSEQUENT HISTORY:  [***1] As Corrected January 26, 1998.



DISPOSITION: Defendant's motion on this issue denied.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant sought to dismiss or reduce several counts of his indictment for felony murder, challenged the grand jury selection process, and sought to declare several state laws unconstitutional.


OVERVIEW: Defendant was charged with three counts of first degree murder under N.Y. Penal Law § 125.27(1)(a)(vii) and (xi). He challenged the indictments. The court held that (1) defendant failed to meet the burden of showing the statutes under which he was charged were unconstitutionally vague and overbroad, (2) N.Y. Penal Law § 125.27(1)(a)(vii) and (xi) were constitutional and they were not applied retroactively, (3) N.Y. Penal Law § 125.27(1)(a)(xi) required proof of prior killings as elements of first degree murder at the trial's guilt phase so it was not an ex post facto law, (4) the count charging the defendant with first degree murder both as a shooter and a commander was not duplicitous, (5) the grand jurors unanimously agreed under sufficient guidance that there was sufficient evidence to indict defendant for trial, (6) the jury represented a fair cross section and there was no systematic exclusion of any group, (7) the evidence before the grand jury was insufficient to establish the similar fashion element of the "serial killer" aggravating factor, (8) the counts of the indictment were improperly joined, and (9) sentencing rules were constitutional and properly followed.


OUTCOME: The court dismissed all of defendant's motions except his argument that there was insufficient evidence to establish a necessary element of the serial killer aggravating factor and that several counts of the indictment were improperly joined because of that error.


HEADNOTES

Constitutional Law - Validity of Statute - Vagueness of Death Penalty Statute 

1. Defendant, who is charged with murder in the first degree under Penal Law § 125.27 (1) (a) (vii), lacks standing to claim that the statute is unconstitutionally vague on its face inasmuch as section 125.27 (1) (a) (vii) involves no First Amendment concerns.

Constitutional Law - Validity of Statute - Overbreadth of Death Penalty Statute 

2. Defendant, who is charged with murder in the first degree under Penal Law § 125.27 (1) (a) (vii), lacks standing to claim that the statute is unconstitutionally overbroad on its face and as applied to him, inasmuch as a statute can be challenged as overbroad when it criminalizes speech, and section 125.27 (1) (a) (vii) (murder during the course of a felony) involves conduct, not speech.

Constitutional Law - Validity of Statute - Felony Murder Death Penalty Statute 

3. Penal Law § 125.27 (1) (a) (vii), which makes it a crime subject to the death penalty to commit an intentional murder in the course of and in furtherance of a felony, is not unconstitutionally vague and overbroad. The statute is sufficiently definite by its terms to give a person of ordinary intelligence fair notice that his contemplated conduct is forbidden by the statute, and does not permit or encourage arbitrary law enforcement. The phrase "in the course of and in furtherance of" limits the types of murders that may be prosecuted as first degree murders. The statute expressly sets forth the specific enumerated felonies during which the intentional murder was committed or attempted to be committed, in order for the defendant to be charged under this statute, thereby limiting the felonies that qualify for felony murder.

Constitutional Law - Validity of Statute - Felony Murder Statute 

4. The felony murder statute (Penal Law § 125.25 [3]) is not unconstitutionally vague or overbroad.

Statutes - Retroactive Application of Statute - First Degree Murder

5. The counts of an indictment charging defendant with violating Penal Law § 125.27 (1) (a) (xi), which provides that a person is guilty of murder in the first degree when, with intent to cause the death of another person, he causes such death, and "the defendant intentionally caused the death of two or more additional persons within the state in separate criminal transactions within a period of twenty-four months when committed in a similar fashion or pursuant to a common scheme or plan", will not be dismissed on the ground that the People are improperly applying Penal Law § 125.27 (1) (a) (xi) retroactively because the two prior deaths are based upon acts that were allegedly committed prior to the effective date of the statute. A statute is not retroactive when made to apply to future transactions, merely because such transactions relate to and are founded upon antecedent events. Penal Law § 125.27 (1) (a) (xi) requires proof of two additional killings as elements of first degree murder. The statute applies to future transactions because the statute is clear that in order for the defendant to be charged with first degree murder, a third death, at a minimum, must occur after two or more deaths have occurred. Therefore, the future transaction would be the third death. The two or more earlier deaths that must occur are antecedent events which are elements of the first degree murder charge. The defendant can only be charged with first degree murder for this third death. Therefore, the defendant did not allegedly violate Penal Law § 125.27 (1) (a) (xi) until the third death occurred after the effective date of the statute.

Constitutional Law - Ex Post Facto Law - First Degree Murder

6. Penal Law § 125.27 (1) (a) (xi), which provides that a person is guilty of murder in the first degree when, with intent to cause the death of another person, he causes such death, and "the defendant intentionally caused the death of two or more additional persons within the state in separate criminal transactions within a period of twenty-four months when committed in a similar fashion or pursuant to a common scheme or plan", does not violate the Ex Post Facto Clause of the United States Constitution. This statute does not punish as a crime an act previously committed which was innocent when done since intentional murder has always been a crime. Neither does this statute make more burdensome the punishment for a crime after its commission since once a violation of the statute has been proven, the sentence options are mandated by the statute, and are not enhanced or retroactively applied after a determination of an individual's guilt. The conduct for which a defendant is charged and convicted does not predate the effective date of the statute. Furthermore, this statute does not deprive an individual charged with a crime of a defense that was available at the time the offense was allegedly committed.

Crimes - Indictment - Duplicitous Count - First Degree Murder

7. The count of an indictment charging defendant with the killing of the victim by shooting him with a gun and commanding another person to kill the victim in violation of Penal Law § 125.27 (1) (a) (vii) is not duplicitous on the ground that defendant is being charged as both a shooter and a commander. The section of the law under which the defendant is charged is contained in one paragraph and one subdivision, and charges only a single offense, involving a single death. The facts alleged in this count only support one offense and, therefore, that count does not violate the statutory requirements set forth under CPL 200.30 (1), (3) and 200.50 (3), (7) (a), and is not duplicitous. Moreover, the language, "commanded another person" is not an additional element to the offense of an intentional killing in the course of and in furtherance of a felony. Rather, under this statute, the People may charge the defendant as a principal, or in a limited situation, as an accomplice. The People do not have to specify whether the defendant is the shooter or the commander under this count, or in their bill of particulars, since the manner of prosecution is the same.

Grand Jury - Defective Proceeding

8. The count of an indictment charging defendant with the killing of the victim by shooting him with a gun and commanding another person to kill the victim in violation of Penal Law § 125.27 (1) (a) (vii) will not be dismissed on the ground that the Grand Jury proceedings were impaired because there is no guarantee that 12 grand jurors concurred when they voted on the first degree murder charges as to the defendant's status as principal or accomplice. There is no legal distinction between liability as a principal and criminal culpability as an accomplice. Therefore, at least 12 grand jurors had to concur that there was sufficient evidence to indict the defendant for the murder of the victim and sufficient instruction as to the definition of "commanded another person" under Penal Law § 125.27 (1) (a) (vii). It is irrelevant whether some grand jurors voted to indict the defendant based upon his actions as a principal or as commander since there is no legal distinction between the two.

Grand Jury - Defective Proceeding

9. The counts of an indictment charging defendant with violating Penal Law § 125.27 (1) (a) (xi), which provides that a person is guilty of murder in the first degree when, with intent to cause the death of another person, he causes such death, and "the defendant intentionally caused the death of two or more additional persons within the state in separate criminal transactions within a period of twenty-four months when committed in a similar fashion or pursuant to a common scheme or plan", will not be dismissed on the ground that the crimes charged cannot be committed in a "similar fashion" if the defendant acted as an accomplice in some of the crimes, but as a principal in others. There is no distinction between liability as a principal or culpability as an accomplice. Although the Grand Jury could have found that the defendant acted as both principal and accomplice, that fact does not make the counts duplicitous or impair the integrity of the Grand Jury. An indictment charging either that the defendant acted separately or jointly with others will sustain a conviction based upon evidence of his participation in the crime.

Grand Jury - Selection of Jury - Fair Cross Section Requirement

10. Young people, poor people and recent migrants to a county do not constitute distinctive groups in the community whose exclusion from a Grand Jury pool would implicate the 6th Amendment requirement that a jury be selected from a representative cross section of the community. A group is distinctive if that group constitutes a substantial and identifiable segment of the community. Young people grouped within an arbitrary age range do not constitute a distinctive group within the community because this group does not share similar specific characteristics. Poor people do not constitute a distinct group within the community because they are not defined and limited by some factor, i.e., race or sex, nor is there necessarily a common thread or basic similarity in attitudes, ideas, experiences, or a community of interests. Moreover, defendant has brought forward no evidence to establish that recent migrants to the county are defined or limited by some factor, or that a common thread or similarity in attitudes and ideas exist among this group, or that there is a community of interests.

Grand Jury - Selection of Jury - Fair Cross Section Requirement

11. African-Americans, Hispanics, and women constitute distinctive groups in the community whose exclusion from a Grand Jury pool would implicate the 6th Amendment requirement that a jury be selected from a representative cross section of the community.

Grand Jury - Selection of Jury - Fair Cross Section Requirement

12. In the Monroe County prosecution of defendant for murder, defendant has failed to establish a prima facie violation of his right under the Sixth Amendment to a fair cross section of the community in the selection of the Grand Jury. A true cross section of the community is virtually unattainable since individuals do not serve on a jury for a wide variety of reasons, such as physical impairments, hearing impairments, and difficulty understanding the English language. The system is clearly open to all individuals, as long as the State does not prevent people from serving on a jury or discriminate against any individuals. The process used to select grand jurors in Monroe County involves facially neutral and random selection from a variety of nondiscriminatory source lists. The process is designed to achieve a fair cross section of the community to the greatest extent possible, and does not discriminate against any distinctive and cognizable group within the community.

Parties - Standing - Equal Protection Claim

13. Hispanics are a distinct and cognizable group, and therefore defendant, a Hispanic male, has standing to challenge the Grand Jury selection process on the grounds that the intentional discriminatory exclusion of distinct and cognizable groups from Grand Jury service violates his right to equal protection.

Grand Jury - Selection of Jury - Equal Protection of Laws

14. In a Monroe County prosecution, defendant has failed to establish a prima facie violation of his right to equal protection arising out of the Grand Jury selection process. In order to establish a prima facie violation of the right to equal protection, the defendant must establish that: recognizable and distinct classes have been singled out for different treatment under the laws, as written and applied; a substantial degree of underrepresentation of distinctive groups on Grand Juries has occurred over a significant period of time; and the Grand Jury selection procedure is not racially neutral and is susceptible to abuse. Defendant has failed to establish that the Grand Jury selection process utilized in Monroe County is discriminatory or systematically excludes any distinct or cognizable groups. The selection process used in Monroe County is fair and reasonable and does not discriminate against any distinct groups. There is no evidence of substantial underrepresentation of a distinct and cognizable group over a significant period of time in Monroe County.

Crimes - Indictment - Sufficiency of Evidence

15. The counts of an indictment charging defendant with violating Penal Law § 125.27 (1) (a) (xi), which provides that a person is guilty of murder in the first degree when, with intent to cause the death of another person, he causes such death, and "the defendant intentionally caused the death of two or more additional persons within the state in separate criminal transactions within a period of twenty-four months when committed in a similar fashion", arising out of four murders involving young men, who were shot with firearms to the left side of the head on the west side of the City and in a cold-blooded fashion, must be dismissed as the "similar fashion" element is unsupported by legally sufficient evidence. The "similar fashion" provision of section 125.27 (1) (a) (xi) reflects an executive and legislative intent to deal with serial murders. Here, aside from the few similarities advanced, there are many dissimilarities among the murders, including: the age and race of the victims; the types of firearms used; the motives for the murders; defendant's role as shooter or commander; the location of the wounds inflicted; and the location of the murders. Thus, there is nothing so unique, ritualistic, or signature-like about these homicides that would support the Grand Jury's decision to indict the defendant under this statute. Even the geographical similarities of the homicide locations are not obvious from a review of the Grand Jury minutes.

Crimes - Sentence - Constitutionality of Death Penalty Sentencing Provisions

16. The death penalty sentencing provisions of CPL 400.27, insofar as they bar defendant from challenging aggravating factors at a sentencing proceeding, are not unconstitutional. The statute specifically prevents the District Attorney from introducing evidence about aggravating factors at the sentencing phase of the trial concerning aggravating factors it did not prove at the guilt phase of the trial. That limitation inures to the benefit of the defendant since it prevents the People, except in two specific circumstances, from introducing any evidence about additional aggravating factors. The People are, therefore, limited to presenting evidence to rebut mitigating evidence presented by the defendant. The New York sentencing provisions exceed the requirements of the New York and United States Constitutions, and genuinely narrow the class of persons eligible for the death penalty and reasonably justify the imposition of a death sentence in those appropriate cases.

Constitutional Law - Validity of Statute - Commander Portion of First Degree Murder Statute 

17. The commander portion of Penal Law § 125.27 (1) (a) (vii), which provides that a defendant is guilty of murder in the first degree when the victim is murdered during the commission of a felony and defendant commanded another person to cause the death of the victim, is not unconstitutionally vague. The word "command" has a long history in New York jurisprudence. There is nothing to indicate that the Legislature intended to give a different meaning to that word than its ordinary meaning. Thus, defendant has not met his burden of proving beyond a reasonable doubt that the term command is unconstitutionally vague.

Crimes - Disclosure - First Degree Murder Prosecution

18. In a prosecution for murder in the first degree, a motion by defendant to compel a further response to the request for a bill of particulars is denied. In crafting the death penalty law, the Legislature declined to change the discovery and bill of particulars provisions of the CPL, and the People have satisfied their obligations as delineated by CPL 200.95.

Crimes - Sentence - Constitutionality of Death Penalty Sentencing Provisions

19. CPL 400.27 (10) is not unconstitutional to the extent that it requires the court to instruct the capital sentencing jury that the defendant will receive a sentence with a minimum term of between 20 to 25 years and a maximum term of life if the jury fails to unanimously agree on a penalty phase verdict.

Crimes - Sentence - Constitutionality of Death Penalty Sentencing Provisions - Reverse Rosario Discovery

20. CPL 400.27 (14) (a) (ii), which incorporates the commonly known "reverse" Rosario discovery provision into the sentencing proceeding in a death eligible case, is not unconstitutional on the grounds that such incorporation unduly restricts the ability to present a complete and thorough defense and will have an unconstitutional chilling effect on his sentencing phase strategy and presentation.

Crimes - Sentence - Constitutionality of Death Penalty Sentencing Provisions

21. CPL 400.27 (6), which provides that at the sentencing proceeding in a death eligible case the burden of establishing mitigating factors is on the defendant and must be proven by a preponderance of the evidence, is not unconstitutional.

Crimes - Sentence - Constitutionality of Death Penalty Sentencing Provisions

22. CPL 400.27 (6), which provides that at the sentencing proceeding in a death eligible case the rules of evidence shall apply to the defendant's presentation of evidence regarding mitigating factors set forth in CPL 400.27 (9), and allows for the admission of reliable hearsay, is not unconstitutional on the ground that it will deprive the defendant of his State and Federal constitutional rights to due process.

Crimes - Sentence - Constitutionality of Death Penalty Sentencing Provisions

23. CPL 400.27 (11) (a), which provides that at the sentencing proceeding in a death eligible case, the sentencing jury must first weigh aggravating and mitigating circumstances and then reach a unanimous decision as to whether death is an appropriate punishment, is not unconstitutionally vague such as would lead to a substantial risk that the death penalty would be imposed in an arbitrary and capricious manner. As part of the sentencing formula, the jury is instructed that their decision must be unanimous (CPL 400.27 [10]). The jury can then only impose a sentence of death if it unanimously finds beyond a reasonable doubt that aggravating factors substantially outweigh mitigating factors established by the defendant by a fair preponderance of the evidence (CPL 400.27 [11]). Thus, the Legislature has insured that once a defendant falls within a class of persons eligible for the death penalty, the procedure for arriving at such a decision is not meted out in an arbitrary or capricious manner.

 

701 of 992 DOCUMENTS


Ramanadhan v. Wing


INDEX NO. 121793/96


SUPREME COURT OF NEW YORK, NEW YORK COUNTY


174 Misc. 2d 11; 662 N.Y.S.2d 393; 1997 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 374



August 12, 1997, Decided


NOTICE:   [***1]  EDITED FOR PUBLICATION


SUBSEQUENT HISTORY: Reversed by Ramanadhan v. Wing, 257 A.D.2d 383, 683 N.Y.S.2d 85, 1999 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 5 (N.Y. App. Div. 1st Dep't, 1999)


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner physician challenged a decision of respondent state department of social services (department), which imposed a fine and suspended the physician from participating in the state Medicaid program.


OVERVIEW: In her pediatric practice, the physician provided care to poor children insured by Medicaid. The department charged the physician with submitting false claims, in violation of 18 NYCRR § 515.2. The physician's Medicaid contract was suspended for three years, causing grave professional consequences. The physician alleged that long delays at the department violated her due process rights. The court agreed that the exhaustion of administrative remedies rule did not apply to her due process claim because she challenged the constitutionality of the department's procedures. The Medicaid regulations, 18 NYCRR §§ 519.1 et seq., did not provide a time limit in which a requested hearing must take place. The court held that the liberty interest protected by the U.S. Const. amend. XIV, § 1 and the N.Y. Const. art. I, § 6 from deprivation without procedural safeguards included the freedom from false determinations disseminated by the government that imposed a stigma and interfered with the ability to work. The suspension of the physician from Medicaid reimbursement threatened her livelihood. The due process clause was designed to prevent exactly this sort of injustice.


OUTCOME: The court granted the petition regarding the physician's due process claim and issued a permanent injunction against the department. The Medicaid regulations regarding the prehearing suspension of Medicaid providers terminated for cause were unconstitutional because they did not provide a time limit within which a hearing must commence. The remainder of the physician's petition was denied with leave to renew after administrative exhaustion.


HEADNOTES

Administrative Law - Failure to Exhaust Administrative Remedies - Constitutional Challenge to Determination by Department of Social Services Petitioner doctor's CPLR article 78 proceeding challenging, on constitutional grounds, a prehearing determination made by respondent New York State Department of Social Services to suspend her from participating in the Medicaid program is not barred for failure to exhaust administrative remedies, since petitioner was not required to exhaust all remedies where an agency's action is challenged as unconstitutional.

Constitutional Law - Due Process of Law - Prehearing Suspension of Medicaid Providers Terminated for Cause The regulations of the New York State Department of Social Services regarding the prehearing suspension of Medicaid providers terminated for cause (18 NYCRR 519.1 et seq.) are unconstitutional under the Due Process Clause of the New York State Constitution, on their face and as applied to petitioner doctor, who was fined and suspended from participating in the Medicaid program prior to a hearing, since they do not provide a time limit within which the hearing must commence and do not mandate that the hearing be conducted in a reasonably continuous manner. Petitioner, whose practice is solely devoted to Medicaid patients, has a constitutionally protected liberty interest in her occupation that entitles her to due process protection: the notice of suspension will be publicly disseminated to all potential employers; the stigma plus test is satisfied given that petitioner's certain loss of hospital privileges will be reported on a national data bank and hospitals must check the data bank before hiring, or granting admitting privileges; our courts historically have protected the right of citizens to pursue occupations and the right to a hearing prior to revocation of a license which is needed to pursue a livelihood; and our State recognizes that due process requires a fair and timely hearing where there is dissemination of stigmatizing charges for loss of employment or demotion, or if the dissemination of information affects professional opportunities. The process that is due depends on the private interest that will be affected, the risk of an erroneous deprivation through the procedures used, and the government's interest. Here, the doctor's livelihood and the continuation of her medical practice are imperiled by a prehearing suspension. The dissemination of her suspension for cause during the protracted hearing process sullies her reputation. The Department's regulations mandate a hearing and there is no justification for holding it in a prolonged manner. The regulations are especially egregious because once the Department imposes a prehearing suspension, it has, in effect, obtained a judgment in its favor and no longer has a motive to expedite the hearing.

 

702 of 992 DOCUMENTS


In re Jonathan W.


DOCKET NO. N0239/41-96V


FAMILY COURT OF NEW YORK, MONROE COUNTY


174 Misc. 2d 210; 663 N.Y.S.2d 771; 1997 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 457



August 5, 1997, Decided


NOTICE:  [***1] EDITED FOR PUBLICATION



DISPOSITION: The petition requesting restoration is dismissed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner sought to have violation petition alleging respondent father's child neglect sustained, because respondent father violated an order of adjournment in contemplation of dismissal.


OVERVIEW: In a child neglect case, an adjournment in contemplation of dismissal order was issued in reference to respondent father. The order required respondent to engage in substance abuse treatment, to cooperate with a caseworker, and to refrain from using or being under the influence of drugs or alcohol in the presence of children. Petitioner sought to sustain the violation petitioner brought against respondent, because respondent violated the order. The court denied the petition, because petitioner failed to show that respondent violated the order. Although respondent relapsed after successfully completing substance abuse treatment, respondent followed the caseworker's recommendation that he complete further treatment. The caseworker testified that respondent had always been truthful with her, and there was no evidence that respondent failed to cooperate with caseworker. Finally, children's statement to caseworker that respondent drank in children's presence was not reliable, because the caseworker's testimony was vague, the children's statement that respondent asked them to go to the store to buy him alcohol was implausible, and respondent denied the allegations.


OUTCOME: Petition to restore neglect case for respondent father's violation of an adjournment in contemplation of dismissal order was dismissed, because petitioner failed to prove that defendant substantially violated the order. Respondent was truthful with caseworker, followed her recommendations, and children's statement that respondent drank in their presence was unreliable.


HEADNOTES

Parent and Child - Abused or Neglected Child - Substantial Violation of Adjournment in Contemplation of Dismissal Order In a child protective proceeding, the Department of Social Services (Department) failed to prove respondent father substantially violated an adjournment in contemplation of dismissal order which prohibited him from using or being under the influence of drugs or alcohol in the presence of children where, after the father successfully completed a substance abuse program, he admitted to the caseworker that he had relapsed and been drinking, and resumed treatment, since the Department failed to show the father had violated the recommendations of the treatment providers; accordingly, the petition requesting restoration of the matter is dismissed. Under Family Court Act § 1039 (e), a case may be restored to the calendar upon a showing that the respondent has failed substantially to observe the terms and conditions of an order or to cooperate with the supervising child protective agency. In enacting this statute, the Legislature contemplated that the Family Court would review and consider all relevant information. The caseworker did not testify to any instances when the father failed to cooperate and the father accepted her suggestions and met with her when requested. Missed appointments due to his child care commitments were never disputed by the caseworker and she testified that he had always been truthful. Also, there was insufficient corroboration of statements made by the children that the father was drinking to find a substantial violation and the caseworker's testimony on this issue was vague.

Parent and Child - Abused or Neglected Child - Substantial Violation of Adjournment in Contemplation of Dismissal Order In a child protective proceeding, assuming the Department of Social Services proved respondent father had substantially violated an adjournment in contemplation of dismissal order which prohibited the father from using or being under the influence of drugs or alcohol in the presence of children, the court, in the exercise of discretion, would decline to restore the case to the calendar under Family Court Act § 1039 (e), which provides for restoration upon a showing that the respondent has failed substantially to observe the terms and conditions of an order or to cooperate with the supervising child protective agency, since the children reside with the mother, who has sole custody, who satisfactorily complied with the order and whose neglect petition has now been dismissed by operation of law. Additionally the father continues in treatment and has in the past voluntarily sought help during a relapse.

 

703 of 992 DOCUMENTS


People v. McIntosh


Ind. No. 146/96, Motion # 11 (constitutionality of plea provisions)


COUNTY COURT OF NEW YORK, DUTCHESS COUNTY


173 Misc. 2d 727; 662 N.Y.S.2d 214; 1997 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 369



August 4, 1997, Decided


NOTICE:  [***1] EDITED FOR PUBLICATION



DISPOSITION: Defendant's motion to declare CPL § 320.10 unconstitutional is denied. The motion to strike down the provisions of the Criminal Procedure Law as unconstitutional is denied in all respects.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant, indicted for first-degree murder, moved to strike down N.Y. Crim. Proc. Law §§ 220.10 (5)(e), 220.30 (3)(b)(vii), and 220.60 to the extent they provided that a death sentence for first-degree murder under N.Y. Penal Law § 125.27 could only be imposed upon conviction after trial, not as result of guilty plea. Defendant also moved to strike N.Y. Crim. Proc. Law § 320.10, which forbid waiver of a jury trial in first-degree murder cases.


OVERVIEW: The appellate court denied defendant's motion to invalidate and strike down N.Y. Crim. Proc. Law §§ 220.10 (5)(e), 220.30 (3)(b)(vii), and 220.60, which provided that a death sentence for first-degree murder could only be imposed upon conviction after trial, not after a guilty plea. Defendant contended that the restriction impermissibly penalized his exercise of his right to a trial because it subjected defendant seeking a trial to the possibility of a death sentence while no such hazard existed with a guilty plea. The court held that defendant, who had been indicted for first-degree murder under N.Y. Penal Law § 125.27, had standing to challenge the statutes. According to the court, the state protected its policy of controlling when the death penalty could be imposed by requiring the district attorney and the court to consent to and approve of a guilty plea. The court held that there was no needless encouragement of guilty pleas. The court also denied defendant's motion to invalidate and strike down N.Y. Crim. Proc. Law § 320.10, which did not allow waiver of a jury trial in first-degree murder cases. The court held that there was no constitutional right to waive a jury.


OUTCOME: The court denied defendant's motion to strike down statutes providing that a death sentence for first-degree murder could only be imposed upon conviction after a trial, not as result of guilty plea, and forbidding the waiver of a jury trial in first-degree murder cases. The court held that the state controlled when the death penalty could be imposed by requiring the district attorney and the court to consent to and approve of a guilty plea.


HEADNOTES

Crimes - Murder - Capital Murder - Statutory Limits on Guilty Pleas - Standing In a prosecution for capital murder, the People's contention that defendant lacks standing to challenge the provisions of the Criminal Procedure Law regulating guilty pleas in capital cases because he has not offered to plead guilty is inherently inconsistent as defendant does not have a unilateral right, under the challenged statutes, to enter a plea of guilty without the consent of the District Attorney and court approval. By being indicted for murder in the first degree defendant has been brought squarely within the statutory scheme which he argues is facially defective and therefore has standing to raise this claim.

Crimes - Murder - Capital Murder - Statutory Limits on Guilty Pleas New York's death penalty statute, which provides that a defendant may not plead guilty and thereby avoid the death penalty unless the District Attorney and the court respectively consent and approve (see, CPL 220.10 [5] [e]; 220.30 [3] [b] [vii]; 220.60), does not needlessly encourage a defendant to waive his or her constitutional right to a jury trial; accordingly, defendant's motion for an order invalidating and striking down the aforementioned Criminal Procedure Law provisions as unconstitutional is denied. By requiring both sides to agree on a prison outcome rather than allowing the defendant unilaterally to avoid the risk of death, there is no needless encouragement of guilty pleas, and, therefore, no needless waivers of constitutional rights. In order to avoid the death penalty, a defendant must strike an agreement with the People with the court's approval, a process that is nothing more than ordinary plea bargaining, a practice repeatedly approved by Federal and New York courts and held to be an indispensable and vital part of the criminal justice system. Moreover, the prohibition against pleading guilty when the risk of death exists reflects New York's long-standing public policy against allowing an accused to plead guilty to a crime which is or may be punishable by death. To require jury trials and pleas of not guilty in all cases cannot be considered to be in defendant's best interest or fair to the many defendants where a nondeath penalty outcome is appropriate.

Crimes - Murder - Capital Murder - No Waiver of Jury Trial In a capital murder prosecution, defendant's motion for an order declaring CPL 320.10, which forbids an accused from waiving a jury trial in capital cases, unconstitutional is denied as defendant has no recognized Federal constitutional right to a bench trial and New York Constitution, article I, § 2 specifically forbids a jury trial waiver in capital cases.

 

704 of 992 DOCUMENTS


People v. Elliott


97-473


SUPREME COURT OF NEW YORK, KINGS COUNTY


173 Misc. 2d 795; 662 N.Y.S.2d 701; 1997 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 384



July 31, 1997, Decided


NOTICE:  [***1] EDITED FOR PUBLICATION



DISPOSITION: Defendant's motion is granted.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant moved to waive his right to a jury trial for murder in the first degree.


OVERVIEW: The supreme court granted defendant's motion to waive his right to a jury trial for murder in the first degree. Plaintiff elected not to seek the death penalty for defendant's first-degree murder charges and consented to defendant's motion. The supreme court found that because defendant was no longer exposed to the potential penalty of death, his case was no longer capital in nature. Thus, the protection of N.Y. Const. art. I, § 2 did not apply, and defendant could waive a jury notwithstanding N.Y. Crim. Proc. Law § 320.10(1), which precluded waiver. The supreme court held section 320.10(1) was not logical or consistent with the constitutional protections afforded defendant.


OUTCOME: The supreme court granted defendant's motion to waive a jury trial because waiver was not precluded under the New York Constitution or by statute.


HEADNOTES

Crimes - Right to Jury Trial - Waiver - Defendant Charged with First Degree Murder Defendant, charged with first degree murder, may waive his right to a jury trial as the prosecution has elected not to seek the death penalty, and since his waiver, executed in open court pursuant to CPL 320.10 (2), was voluntary, knowing and intelligent, it was approved and accepted. While CPL 320.10 (1) states that a defendant is prohibited from waiving his right to a jury if the indictment charges the crime of first degree murder, the New York Constitution prohibits jury waiver only where the crime charged may be punishable by death (NY Const, art I, § 2), and the legislative history of CPL 320.10 (1) indicates that it was amended to incorporate its current language at a time when death was the only available sentence for a conviction of first degree murder. Since that is no longer the case, CPL 320.10 (1) is no longer logical or consistent with constitutional protections afforded defendant or with the rest of the capital punishment statutory scheme and does not preclude a defendant's right to waive a jury trial where the prosecution has elected not to seek capital punishment.

 

705 of 992 DOCUMENTS


People v. Hathaway


Ind. # 96-58


SUPREME COURT OF NEW YORK, ESSEX COUNTY


173 Misc. 2d 701; 662 N.Y.S.2d 234; 1997 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 367



July 22, 1997, Decided


NOTICE:  [***1] EDITED FOR PUBLICATION



DISPOSITION: Defendants' guilty pleas as entered must be permitted to stand and Defendant Hathaway resentenced as a Second Felony Offender.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: The court considered whether guilty pleas entered into by defendant and codefendant could stand and whether the codefendant could be sentenced as a second felony offender.


OVERVIEW: Defendant and codefendant pled guilty to manslaughter, second degree, as charged in the indictment in full satisfaction of it and all other counts. The codefendant was sentenced as a second violent felony offender to the maximum, a determinate term of 15 years. All the parties were laboring under the misimpression that manslaughter in the second degree was included in the listing of class C violent felony offenses in N.Y. Penal Law §70.02 (1) (b). The court held that the guilty pleas and sentences would stand. The court noted that neither the state nor defendants would consent to the undoing of their bargain. The court thus concluded that it was without either statutory or inherent authority to do it for them. The court further concluded, however, that the guilty pleas entered herein were in fact legally permissible under N.Y. Crim. Proc. Law § 220.10 (5)(d)(i) because although not enumerated as such in N.Y. Penal Law §70.02 (1), manslaughter, second degree, was a class C violent felony offense which satisfied the requirements of N.Y. Crim. Proc. Law § 220.10 (5)(d)(i) for purposes of the guilty pleas.


OUTCOME: The court ruled that guilty pleas entered by defendant and codefendant would be permitted to stand and that the codefendant would be resentenced as a second felony offender.


HEADNOTES

Crimes - Sentence - Second Felony Offender - Determinate Sentence for Violent Felony Offense The sentence imposed upon defendant who, following his plea of guilty to second degree manslaughter (Penal Law § 125.15 [1]) was sentenced as a second violent felony offender to the maximum, a determinate term of 15 years (Penal Law § 70.06 [6]), is illegal and must be vacated because second degree manslaughter is not an enumerated violent felony under Penal Law § 70.02 (1) and therefore a determinate sentence pursuant to Penal Law § 70.06 (6) cannot be imposed. The determinate sentencing provisions of Penal Law § 70.06 (6) are only applicable to second felony offenders who are being sentenced for a violent felony offense as defined in Penal Law § 70.02 (1).

Crimes - Plea of Guilty - Vacatur Defendants' pleas of guilty to second degree manslaughter in satisfaction of an indictment charging them with, inter alia, "depraved mind" murder (Penal Law § 125.25 [2] [second degree murder]), an A-1 felony, will not be vacated even though they did not technically satisfy the statutory plea bargaining restrictions in that second degree manslaughter is not listed in the Penal Law § 70.02 (1) (b) definition of class C violent felony offenses, and CPL 220.10 (5) (d) (i) requires that any plea of guilty to an indictment charging a class A felony include at least a plea of guilty to a class C violent felony offense. Here, all of the parties were laboring under the misimpression that second degree manslaughter was included in the listing of class C violent felony offenses in Penal Law § 70.02 (1) (b), the guilty pleas were entered and accepted, sentences were imposed, defendants were committed to the custody of the Department of Correctional Services to begin serving those sentences, and neither the People nor the defendants will consent to the undoing of their bargain; accordingly, the court is without either statutory or inherent authority to do so for them and the guilty pleas, even if improper, must be permitted to stand. While trial courts have the inherent authority to vacate an illegally accepted plea of guilty before sentence is imposed, to vacate a final judgment on grounds of fraud or misrepresentation absent specific constitutional impediment, and to correct their own records where the court merely misspoke or a patent clerical mistake has been made, the limited inherent authority to vacate a plea after imposition of sentence may not be utilized to remedy a substantive legal error in the acceptance of the plea, at least after the defendant has begun serving his sentence or where the proceeding has terminated by the entry of final judgment.

Crimes - Plea of Guilty - Restrictions on Plea to Indictment Charging Class A Felony Defendants' pleas of guilty to second degree manslaughter (Penal Law § 125.15 [1]) in satisfaction of an indictment charging them with, inter alia, "depraved mind" murder (Penal Law § 125.25 [2] [second degree murder]), an A-1 felony, were legally permissible even though they did not technically satisfy the statutory plea bargaining restrictions in that second degree manslaughter is not listed in the Penal Law § 70.02 (1) (b) definition of class C violent felony offenses, and CPL 220.10 (5) (d) (i) requires that any plea of guilty to an indictment charging a class A felony include at least a plea of guilty to a class C violent felony offense. There is no specific reference in CPL 220.10 (5) (d) (i) to a class C violent felony offense "as defined in" Penal Law § 70.02 (1) (b), and it is therefore arguable that a plea of guilty to any class C felony which, under the facts of the particular case, contained the requisite element of violence, would satisfy the plea bargaining restriction in CPL 220.10 (5) (d) (i). Second degree manslaughter, which requires a reckless mental state and reckless conduct and has very serious consequences, must be considered the equivalent of a class C violent felony for plea purposes. Crimes such as first and second degree assault are classified as violent felony offenses, but not second degree manslaughter, which has more severe consequences, and it is inconceivable that the Legislature could have intended such a result when it enacted the plea bargaining restrictions contained in CPL 220.10 (5) (d) (i).

 

706 of 992 DOCUMENTS


In re DiCecco


Index no. 25343/96


SUPREME COURT OF NEW YORK, QUEENS COUNTY


173 Misc. 2d 692; 661 N.Y.S.2d 943; 1997 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 346



July 21, 1997, Decided


NOTICE:  [***1] EDITED FOR PUBLICATION


SUBSEQUENT HISTORY: As Corrected October 27, 1997.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner son filed an application pursuant to N.Y. Mental Hyg. Law § 81 seeking the appointment of a guardian for the personal needs and property management of an alleged incapacitated person (AIP), his mother.


OVERVIEW: The son petitioned for appointment as guardian for the personal needs and property management of his incapacitated mother. The mother suffered from severe dementia and could not make any decision with regard to her personal or financial affairs. She was unable to communicate intelligently, and her condition was not likely to improve. Under N.Y. Mental Hyg. Law § 81.02(b), a determination of incapacity must be based on clear and convincing evidence that the mother was likely to suffer harm because she was unable to provide for her personal needs and/or property management and she could not adequately understand and appreciate the nature and consequences of her inability. The court found that there was clear and convincing evidence that the mother was likely to suffer harm because she could not provide for her person needs and property management and was unable to adequately understand and appreciate the nature and consequences of her inability.


OUTCOME: The court granted the son's application and appointed him as guardian for the personal needs and property of his incapacitated mother.


HEADNOTES

Insane and Other Incompetent Persons - Appointment of Guardian for Personal Needs or Property Management In a Mental Hygiene Law article 81 proceeding involving a 76-year-old woman who suffers from severe dementia, is not oriented as to time and place, and resides in a nursing home, the alleged incapacitated person's (AIP) son will be appointed her personal needs and property management guardian as there is clear and convincing evidence that she is likely to suffer harm because she cannot provide for her personal needs and property management and is unable to adequately understand and appreciate the nature and consequences of this inability.

Insane and Other Incompetent Persons - Appointment of Guardian for Personal Needs or Property Management - Transfer of Assets to Children Petitioner, the alleged incapacitated person's (AIP) son and court-appointed guardian in this Mental Hygiene Law article 81 proceeding, may engage in Medicaid planning by transferring the AIP's residence to himself, allowing the AIP to retain a life estate, and transferring some of the AIP's assets to her children. Notwithstanding the applicability of section 217 of the Health Insurance Portability and Accountability Act of 1996, codified at 42 USC § 1320a-7b (a) (6), which makes it a crime to transfer assets in order to qualify for Medicaid under certain circumstances, it is clear that some of the assets of a person who anticipates applying for Medicaid can be transferred to others provided that enough resources are retained to sustain the person through any penalty period of ineligibility. Of course, the court cannot insulate the guardian or the AIP from State civil liability or Federal criminal liability in connection with the transfer of the AIP's property.

 

707 of 992 DOCUMENTS


Cliff v. Blydenberg


INDEX No.: 35111/96


SUPREME COURT OF NEW YORK, NASSAU COUNTY


173 Misc. 2d 366; 661 N.Y.S.2d 736; 1997 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 294



July 2, 1997, Decided


NOTICE:  [***1] EDITED FOR PUBLICATION



DISPOSITION: Local Law § 943-1996 is unconstitutional, invalid and unenforceable as against plaintiffs.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiffs, members of certain county agencies, brought an action challenging the constitutionality of a law enacted by defendant Suffolk County legislature (New York), that placed limits on their bargained-for rights to compensation, claiming that the law substantially impaired their respective collective bargaining agreements and was not reasonable and necessary to serve an important public purpose.


OVERVIEW: A law was passed by the county legislature, which provided that no county employees could receive compensation equal to or in excess of that paid to the county executive during the prior year. All compensation and reimbursements were included in the definition of compensation. The county employees challenged the constitutionality of the law claiming it substantially impaired their respective collective bargaining agreements and was not reasonable and necessary to serve an important public purpose. The court determined that the law was unconstitutional as applied to the county employees, in that permanent deprivation of compensation earned, and compensation to which the county employees were entitled pursuant to collective bargaining agreements, was a substantial impairment of contract rights that violated U.S. Const. art. I, § 10, cl. 1. Furthermore, the law was constitutionally deficient insofar as it deprived the county employees of due process by unilaterally reducing their negotiated salary and benefits.


OUTCOME: The court found that the challenged law was unconstitutional, invalid, and unenforceable as against county employees.


HEADNOTES

Constitutional Law - Validity of Statute - Local Law Capping County Employees' Salaries Local Laws, 1996, No. 23 of the County of Suffolk, which provides that no County employee shall receive compensation equal to or in excess of that paid to the Suffolk County Executive during the prior year, unconstitutionally impairs, under the Contract Clause of the US Constitution (art I, § 10, cl [1]) collective bargaining agreements which, respectively, impose a partial cap and no cap on salaries. Under the Contract Clause, legislation that substantially impairs a contractual right will be upheld only if it is reasonable and necessary to serve an important public purpose. Moreover, the Contract Clause limits the ability of a State, or subdivision of a State, to abridge its contractual obligations without first pursuing available alternatives. The operation of government at a cost efficient level while providing the services required by the governed is an important public purpose, but is no more important than the knowledge and confidence that government will honor its contract obligation. The challenged law is not the only way to accomplish Suffolk County's purpose of managing staffing and reducing overtime. Any alternative revenue-raising or revenue-saving device is for the Suffolk County Executive and Legislature to determine, not the court, but any such alternative may not include impairing the contract rights of plaintiffs. Alternative management or cost-cutting measures exist in many forms, one of which includes negotiations to produce the salary cap as defined by the challenged Local Law and there is no indication that defendants pursued any negotiations with those unions whose collective bargaining agreement contains a partial cap or those unions whose collective bargaining agreements contain no salary limiting provision. Thus, Local Law No. 23 is not reasonable and necessary to serve an important public purpose.

Civil Service - Compensation and Benefits - Validity of Local Law Capping County Employees' Salaries Local Laws, 1996, No. 23 of the County of Suffolk, which provides that no County employee shall receive compensation equal to or in excess of that paid to the Suffolk County Executive during the prior year, violates NY Constitution, article I, § 17, which guarantees employees the right to engage in collective bargaining through their certified representatives and the Taylor Law (Civil Service Law § 200 et seq.), is an abrogation of the limitations placed on local government by the Taylor Law absent negotiation of any such maximum with the employees' bargaining representative and ratification of this contract provision by the employee members, and violates the provision of the Taylor Law which provides for the enforcement of collective bargaining obligations through the Public Employment Relations Board (Civil Service Law § 205).

Constitutional Law - Due Process of Law - Local Law Capping County Employees' Salaries Local Laws, 1996, No. 23 of the County of Suffolk, which provides that no County employee shall receive compensation equal to or in excess of that paid to the Suffolk County Executive during the prior year, violates the due process rights of police officers who are subject to collective bargaining agreements which, respectively, impose a partial cap and no cap on salaries, because it unilaterally reduces their negotiated salary and benefits.

 

708 of 992 DOCUMENTS


People v. Barbara


INDEX NO. 004058/97


DISTRICT COURT OF NEW YORK, FIRST DISTRICT, NASSAU COUNTY


173 Misc. 2d 669; 662 N.Y.S.2d 211; 1997 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 378



July 1, 1997, Decided


NOTICE:  [***1] EDITED FOR PUBLICATION



DISPOSITION: Defendant's motion to dismiss and to vacate the temporary order of protection is denied.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant filed a motion to dismiss a prosecutor's information charging defendant with violation of N.Y. Penal Law § 240.26(1), harassment in the second degree, and to vacate a temporary order of protection on the grounds that the statute violated U.S. Const. amend. I, as it was overbroad, and that the language set forth in the information, even if proven, did not rise to a legally sufficient level to warrant a conviction.


OVERVIEW: The court denied defendant's motion to dismiss the prosecutor's information charging him with second-degree harassment in violation of N.Y. Penal Law § 240.26(1), and to vacate a temporary order of protection because the statute was not the same as a prior statute that was found overbroad in violation of U.S. Const. amend. XIV, in that it did not require intent or likelihood of public disorder, but an intent to harass, annoy, or alarm an individual. The statute provided that a person was guilty of the crime if he, with the requisite intent, struck, shoved, kicked, or otherwise subjected another person to physical contract, or attempted or threatened to do so. Also, the words set forth in the information were sufficient, as they were more than merely "abusive or vulgar," but were classic "fighting words," which conveyed or were capable of conveying fear of threat or harm to a reasonable person. The court noted that defendant's motion was improperly directed at the level of sufficiency of evidence for conviction after trial, rather than at the sufficiency of the information.


OUTCOME: The court denied defendant's motion to dismiss the prosecutor's information charging him with second-degree harassment and to vacate a temporary order of protection, because the statute differed from a prior unconstitutional statute in that it did not require intent or likelihood of public disorder, but an intent to harass, annoy, or alarm an individual. Also, the words set forth in the information were sufficient, as they were "fighting words."


HEADNOTES

Crimes - Harassment - Constitu tionality of Statute In a prosecution for second degree harassment, defendant's motion to dismiss an information charging him with a violation of Penal Law § 240.26 (1) for telling his employer during the course of a heated argument "The first chance I get to f -- you, I'm going to f -- you big time. It might not be on the job, but I'm going to f -- you" on the ground that the statute is unconstitutionally overbroad is denied. Penal Law § 240.26 (1) is not the same as Penal Law former § 240.25 (2) which was held to be unconstitutional and subsequently repealed.

Crimes - Harassment - Threat of Physical Harm In a prosecution for second degree harassment, defendant's motion to dismiss an information charging him with a violation of Penal Law § 240.26 (1) for telling his employer during the course of a heated argument "The first chance I get to f -- you, I'm going to f -- you big time. It might not be on the job, but I'm going to f -- you" on the ground that the language set forth in the information does not rise to a legally sufficient level to warrant a conviction is denied. The words used by defendant are classic "fighting words" which convey or are capable of conveying fear of threat or harm to a reasonable person, and the exact meaning of defendant's words is an issue for the trier of fact to determine.

 

709 of 992 DOCUMENTS


People v. McIntosh


Ind. No. 146/96, Motion # 9 (Jury selection)


COUNTY COURT OF NEW YORK, DUTCHESS COUNTY


173 Misc. 2d 724; 662 N.Y.S.2d 212; 1997 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 371



July 1, 1997, Decided


NOTICE:  [***1] EDITED FOR PUBLICATION



DISPOSITION: The balance of defendant's motion for an order declaring Criminal Procedure Law § 270.20 unconstitutional is denied.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant moved to invalidate N.Y. Crim. Proc. Law art. 270.20, which provided that a prospective jury could be excused for cause in a death penalty case if his opinions either against or in favor of the death penalty would preclude or substantially impair him from rendering an impartial verdict or from properly exercising his discretion in determining a sentence, because it violated U.S. Const. amend. VI and XIV.


OVERVIEW: The court denied defendant's motion to declare unconstitutional, under U.S. Const. amend. VI and XIV, the New York Constitution, and N.Y. Crim. Proc. Law art. 270.20, which provided that a prospective jury could be excused for cause in a death penalty case if his opinions either against or in favor of the death penalty would preclude or substantially impair him from rendering an impartial verdict or from properly exercising his discretion in determining a sentence. However, the court held that under the state statute it would grant valid defense challenges for cause against prospective jurors whose views in favor of the death penalty would preclude or substantially impair those jurors' ability to perform as a juror in accordance with law, in order to comply with the prevailing federal constitutional standards. The court noted that while the federal disqualification standard was broader, the language of the New York statute was essentially consistent with it.


OUTCOME: The court denied defendant's motion to declare unconstitutional the state statute governing the excuse of a juror for cause in a criminal case based on his opinions regarding the death penalty, but held that it would grant valid defense challenges for cause against prospective jurors whose views in favor of the death penalty would preclude or substantially impair those jurors' ability to perform as a juror in accordance with the law.


HEADNOTES

Crimes - Murder - Capital Murder - Dismissal of Juror Based on Opinion on Death Penalty CPL 270.20 (1) (f), which provides that a juror may be excused for cause in a death penalty case if he or she entertains such conscientious opinions either against or in favor of the death penalty as to preclude such juror from rendering an impartial verdict or from properly exercising the discretion conferred upon such juror by law in the determination of a sentence, passes scrutiny under both the Federal and State Constitutions. The language of CPL 270.20 (1) (f) is essentially consistent with the Federal disqualification standard upheld by the United States Supreme Court, and the New York statute renders it more difficult for prosecutors to excuse for cause potential jurors who have reservations against applying the death penalty because they could not be excused unless their views precluded adherence to the law. However, to the extent that the statutory language may be construed to deny a defendant's challenge for cause to a prospective juror whose views in favor of the death penalty might substantially impair his or her ability to perform as a juror in accordance with law, the court would, of course, be constrained to determine such a challenge based upon the prevailing constitutional standard to insure defendant's right to be tried by a fair and impartial jury. Accordingly, the court will grant valid defense challenges for cause when advanced against those prospective jurors whose views in favor of the death penalty would preclude or substantially impair those jurors' ability to perform as a juror in accordance with law.

 

710 of 992 DOCUMENTS


Bay Fireworks v. City of New York


Index No.: 015120/97


SUPREME COURT OF NEW YORK, QUEENS COUNTY


173 Misc. 2d 396; 661 N.Y.S.2d 731; 1997 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 308



June 27, 1997, Decided


NOTICE:  [***1] EDITED FOR PUBLICATION


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner fireworks company filed a motion for preliminary injunctive relief to enjoin respondent city fire officials from continuing to retain and from destroying certain property, and for the immediate return of such property. The fireworks company also sought relief to enjoin the city fire officials from suspending the fireworks company's certificate of registration and certificate of fitness.


OVERVIEW: The fireworks company transported a truckload of fireworks across a city. As the truck neared the city limits, the city fire officials detained the truck, confiscated the cargo, issued the driver a desk appearance ticket, and issued a summons to petitioner individual for a violation of New York City, N.Y., Admin. Code § 27-4254. The fireworks company later received a letter from the city fire officials explaining the truck was stopped for transporting explosives without a fire department escort in violation of § 27-4034(j). In response, the fireworks company filed their action for injunctive relief, in part contending they were transporting fireworks, which did not require a fire department escort. The fire officials argued New York City, N.Y., Rules of the City of New York, tit. 3, § 40-07(e)(1) required a fully manned escort and included fireworks within the term explosives. The court granted the motion for preliminary injunctive relief because § 40-07(e)(1) was invalid, irreparable injury would have resulted if injunctive relief was withheld, and there was a balance of equities in favor of the fireworks' company.


OUTCOME: The court granted the fireworks company's motion for preliminary injunctive relief and enjoined and restrained the city fire officials from continuing to retain and from destroying or otherwise interfering with the fireworks company's right to possession and to a return of their property, consisting of the truck and the fireworks.


HEADNOTES

Explosions and Explosives - Fireworks - Validity of New York City Fire Department Rules Regulating Transport of Fireworks 3 RCNY 40-07 (e) (1), insofar as it mandates Fire Department escorts for the transportation of fireworks within the City, is invalid on the grounds that it is in excess of the lawful authority of the Fire Department and the Fire Commissioner and it is constitutionally infirm. The Administrative Code of the City of New York, enacted as it is by the City Council, the City's legislative body, cannot be overridden or contravened by executive rules of any City agency, body or department. Although section 489 of the New York City Charter authorizes the Fire Commissioner to make and enforce rules for the transportation of "combustibles ... explosives ... and other dangerous substances," it does not foster the adoption of rules which are inconsistent with legislation promulgated by the City Council. The executive branch may not, by rule or regulation, displace legislation duly enacted by a legislative body, and this is so whether the rule or regulation is advanced or otherwise supported by executive policy or directive. An "explosive" as defined in Administrative Code of the City of New York § 27-4002 (14) does not include fireworks, which are separately defined in Administrative Code § 27-4002 (17); the Administrative Code carefully delineates between the two substances and the applicable rules relating to their sale, transportation, storage, use, etc. The Fire Department Rules, as far as appears, classify fireworks in the same category as explosives in terms of storage and/or transportation. Thus, to the extent that the rules of the Fire Department impose a greater or inconsistent requirement than that directed by the Administrative Code of the City of New York with respect to the sale, transportation, storage, use, etc., of fireworks, they are invalid. Moreover, the effect of 3 RCNY 40-07 (e) (1) is to require an escort for any fireworks transport which passes through a portion of the City, no matter how short the distance, on its way to a display elsewhere in the State, or to another State. Inasmuch as the use of an escort results in the imposition of an hourly fee, the effect is to charge for passing through the City which impinges and has a potential chilling effect upon both intrastate and interstate commerce.

 

711 of 992 DOCUMENTS


People by Vacco v. Lipsitz


Index No. 400945/97, Mot. Seq. No. 001


SUPREME COURT OF NEW YORK, NEW YORK COUNTY


174 Misc. 2d 571; 663 N.Y.S.2d 468; 1997 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 382



June 23, 1997, Decided


NOTICE:  [***1] EDITED FOR PUBLICATION


SUBSEQUENT HISTORY: As Amended.



DISPOSITION: Attorney General awarded costs of $ 2,000 against respondent Lipsitz, who is individually liable for the actions conducted under both the registered and unregistered assumed business names.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner New York Attorney General filed an action alleging that respondent magazine subscription service committed repeated or persistent fraudulent or illegal acts, engaged in deceptive acts and practices violative of N.Y. Gen. Bus. Law § 349, false advertising violative of § 350, and the use of unregistered assumed business names violative of § 130(1)(a).


OVERVIEW: Respondent sold magazine subscriptions through the Internet. The Attorney General received complaints from New York residents and non-residents alleging that respondent failed to provide prepaid subscriptions or provided shortened subscriptions, refused to provide refunds, or retaliated against complaints. The Attorney General petitioned for an injunction, a bond to assure future proper business behavior, restitution, a civil fine and a monetary judgment on behalf of the Attorney General. Upon review, the court determined that it had jurisdiction even though the complained of activity took place on the Internet. Respondent was a resident of New York and the complained of activities initiated in New York. The New York consumer protection statutes did not impermissibly burden interstate commerce with respect to claims arising from Internet activity. The court determined that the Attorney General established respondent fraudulently failed to deliver promised magazines and to honor money back guarantees, falsely advertised consumer satisfaction, and operated under assumed business names without the requisite government filing.


OUTCOME: The court held that respondent was guilty of fraudulent acts, deceptive practices, false advertising, and using unregistered assumed business names. Respondent was enjoined from further deceptive business practices and ordered to file a bond with the state to assure future proper business behavior, to pay restitution to defrauded consumers, and to pay litigation costs.


HEADNOTES

Courts - Jurisdiction - Internet Consumer Fraud New York courts have jurisdiction over respondent who sold magazine subscriptions under various business names from a location in New York by using allegedly deceptive advertising on e-mail through the Internet notwithstanding that the impact may have been in another location, since respondent does business in New York and the acts complained of physically occurred in New York. New York courts have jurisdiction over persons actually present in New York and over organizations and corporations doing business in New York with a fair measure of permanence and continuity. A person or business conducts a business within the forum State by being a subscriber to a local Internet service provider and selling a product through that provider. Here, respondent is physically located within the jurisdiction. Also, the acts done by the litigation target within the jurisdiction provide sufficient minimum contacts with the forum. For Internet consumer fraud claims, the Internet medium is essentially irrelevant. The focus is primarily upon the location of the messenger and whether the messenger delivered what was purchased.

Courts - Jurisdiction - Out-of-State Consumer Fraud Complaints New York courts have jurisdiction over out-of-State complaints in an enforcement action commenced by the Attorney-General against respondent who sold magazine subscriptions under various business names from a location in New York by using allegedly deceptive advertising on e-mail through the Internet since respondent does business in New York and the acts complained of physically occurred in New York. The Attorney-General has authority to seek to restrain illegal business practice by a local business in relation to both in-State and out-of-State residents, notwithstanding that these practices occur on the Internet. There is no reason to exclude consideration of out-of-State complaints and there are no geographical restrictions upon the consumer complaints which serve as a basis for an enforcement action by the Attorney-General. All consumers must be protected regardless of their residency.

Courts - Jurisdiction - Unsworn Complaints In an enforcement action commenced by the Attorney-General against respondent who allegedly fraudulently sold magazine subscriptions on the Internet, both sworn and unsworn complaints will be considered by the court. The Attorney-General can commence enforcement actions even if no complaints existed and there is specific precedent for the presentation of unsworn complaints.

Attorney-General - Enjoining Deceptive Practices - Magazine Subscription Sales on Internet Respondent, who sold magazine subscriptions on the Internet under various business names violated General Business Law §§ 349 and 350 when he created fictitious messages from fictitious satisfied customers extolling the virtues of the magazines and the magazines never arrived, were delayed, or the subscription was shortened, and requests for refunds were not honored. A business practice of failing to deliver as promised is fraudulent and illegal conduct violating section 349. Respondent's business practice is "no magazines, no service, no refunds", although the contrary is promised, making the sales promises deceptive and fraudulent. Additionally, by falsely advertising attentive customer services and disseminating fictitious testimonial, respondent violated General Business Law § 350. Although some gimmicks were designed to inspire confidence, the falsity of the advertising content is sufficient as a basis for the false advertising charge.

Names - Certificate of Doing Business Respondent violated General Business Law § 130 (1) (a), which mandates a filing of an assumed business name certificate with the office of the clerk of the county in which the business is conducted, when he sold magazine subscriptions on the Internet under various business names, and never filed such certificates under two assumed business names.

Attorney-General - Enjoining Deceptive Practices - Injunctive Relief A request by the Attorney-General for an injunction and accompanying bond under Executive Law § 63 (12) and General Business Law § 349 is granted in an enforcement action against respondent who violated General Business Law §§ 349 and 350 when he fraudulently sold magazine subscriptions on the Internet. The requirement of a bond to assure future proper business behavior on the part of an enjoined business traditionally accompanies the injunction and there are no constitutional reasons why a bond should not be ordered.

Attorney-General - Enjoining Deceptive Practices - Restitution A request by the Attorney-General for restitution under Executive Law § 63 (12) and General Business Law § 349 is granted in an enforcement action against respondent who violated General Business Law §§ 349 and 350 when he fraudulently sold magazine subscriptions on the Internet. The fact that respondents have offered to make restitution, but had yet failed to do so does not defeat the request.

 

712 of 992 DOCUMENTS


People v. Hale


Indictment No. 8776/96


SUPREME COURT OF NEW YORK, KINGS COUNTY


173 Misc. 2d 140; 661 N.Y.S.2d 457; 1997 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 311



June 6, 1997, Decided


NOTICE:  [***1] EDITED FOR PUBLICATION


SUBSEQUENT HISTORY: As Corrected September 8, 1997.



DISPOSITION: The motion to dismiss the indictment is denied, expect that count one is dismissed. All other motions are denied, except that the motion challenging the plea provisions is granted to the extent that the plea provisions shall be severed and stricken from the statute.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant filed motion to dismiss indictment under N.Y. Crim. Proc. Law § 210.25(1) on grounds that the counts were multiplicitous, that one count was improperly double counted under N.Y. Crim. Proc. L. § 210.25(3), and that N.Y. Penal Law § 125.27(10(a)(vii) was unconstitutional.


OVERVIEW: The court held two counts of murder in the first degree were multiplicitous as they were predicated upon the same aggravating factor of robbery; as the legislature did not intend to permit multiple charges of murder in the first degree predicated upon different degrees of robbery arising out of the same occurrence. The court found two counts of murder in the first degree with robbery and kidnapping in the first degree as the aggravating actors and two counts of murder in the second degree with the same crimes as underlying felonies were not multiplicitous and double counting under N.Y. Penal Law §§ 125.27(a)(vii), 125.25(3) as different elements required proof of additional facts that other did not. The court held § 125.27 was constitutional as it limited death penalty eligibility to subclass of murders. N.Y. Penal Law § 125.27 was constitutional as the death penalty provision was not grossly disproportionate to the crimes. The court held that N.Y. Crim. Proc. Law §§ 220.10(5)(e), 220.30(3)(6)(vii), 220.60(2)(a) were to have been stricken from the death penalty statute as they were provisions pertaining to capital cases only and did not conform to the Fifth and Sixth Amendments.


OUTCOME: The court denied defendant's motion to dismiss the indictment except as to count one. The motion that challenged the plea provision was granted to the extent the plea provisions were to have been severed and struck from the statute.


HEADNOTES

Crimes - Indictment - Multiplicitous Counts - First Degree Murder - Robbery as Aggravating Factor In a prosecution for capital murder, two counts which charge defendant with first degree murder are multiplicitous where one count alleges as an aggravating factor that defendant committed robbery in the first degree and the other count alleges as an aggravating factor that defendant committed robbery in the third degree, and both counts are predicated upon the same alleged conduct, because the counts charge the same crime, i.e., murder in the first degree predicated upon the felony of robbery. By specifying robbery, without reference to degree in Penal Law § 125.27 (1) (a) (vii), as a felony that may form the basis for an aggravating factor, the Legislature apparently did not intend to permit multiple charges of murder in the first degree predicated upon different degrees of robbery arising out of the same occurrence. That the Legislature chose to describe by degrees all of the other felonies enumerated in the statute adds force to this argument. The crime of murder in the first degree with robbery as the felony aggravating factor requires proof of the intentional killing of the victim in the course of or in furtherance of the defendant's commission of the crime of robbery. As to the underlying felony, it does not require proof of any facts additional to those required for simple robbery, i.e., forcible stealing. Thus, any reference in the indictment to the degree of the robbery must be considered mere surplusage. It cannot be claimed that the counts are permissible by the same logic as permits lesser included offenses pertaining to the same conduct to be charged in an indictment: because the charges are of the same grade or degree, one cannot be considered a lesser included offense of the other.

Crimes - Indictment - Multiplicitous Counts - Cure in Capital Case An indictment containing multiplicitous counts may be remedied either by an election of counts by the prosecution, or by the court's decision to charge only one of the multiplicitous counts to the jury. Accordingly, in a capital case, it is the court's opinion that the preferred practice is to cure the defect before trial, and in so doing, eliminate any prejudice in the penalty phase -- assuming there is to be one -- that might accrue from the jury's consideration of redundant aggravating factors during the guilt phase of the proceedings.
