Crimes - Indictment - Multiplicitous Counts - Multiple Aggravating Felonies In a capital murder prosecution, two counts charging defendant with first degree murder with robbery and kidnapping in the first degree as the respective aggravating factors, and two counts charging defendant with second degree (felony) murder, with the same respective crimes serving as the underlying felonies, are not multiplicitous since the counts at issue have different elements that require proof of additional facts that the others do not. The count charging murder in the first degree requires proof that the alleged intentional killing took place in furtherance of a robbery, while the other count charging murder in the first degree requires proof that the alleged intentional killing took place in furtherance of the crime of kidnapping in the first degree. Similarly, the felony murder counts require proof pertaining to different underlying felonies. For the purpose of determining multiplicity, it does not matter that the charges arose out of the same conduct, so long as each charge requires proof of an additional fact that the other does not.

Crimes - Indictment - Multiplicitous Counts - Multiple Aggravating Felonies In a capital murder prosecution, two counts charging defendant with first degree murder with robbery and kidnapping in the first degree as the respective aggravating factors, and two counts charging defendant with second degree (felony) murder, with the same respective crimes serving as the underlying felonies, are not multiplicitous. By listing a series of felonies together within 1 of the 12 subparagraphs of aggravating factors, rather than listing each of the felonies in a separate subparagraph (see, CPL 400.27 [3]), the Legislature did not intend to permit the charging of only one count of first degree murder premised upon the commission of an intentional killing in the course of a felony, whether or not a defendant, in fact, committed an intentional killing in the furtherance of multiple felonies, since it cannot be the law that, regardless of the number of felonies in furtherance of which an intentional killing is committed, the People are bound to charge only a single count of murder in the first degree. Limiting the charges in this way would preclude the jury's proper and due consideration of the full breadth of the defendant's alleged criminal conduct. That the statute specifies 12 different felonies that may serve as the underlying felony for a subparagraph (vii) aggravator evinces the Legislature's intent to make the commission of an intentional killing in the furtherance of any one of these felonies a crime worthy of the death penalty. Had the Legislature intended to permit only a single charge of murder in the first degree for "intentional murder in the course of a felony" without reference to specific felonious conduct, the Legislature could have said as much. Instead, by listing specific felonies, the Legislature plainly evinced its intent to permit multiple charges of first degree murder premised upon an intentional killing in the course of any one or more of the specified felonies, and its decision to place all of the felony aggravators in a single subparagraph reflects an attempt to make the statute as concise as possible.

Crimes - Murder - Capital Murder - Rationality of Aggravating Factors Penal Law § 125.27, which defines the crime of first degree, or capital, murder, passes constitutional muster: it limits death penalty eligibility to a subclass of murders and none of the aggravating factors is unconstitutionally vague. In particular, the aggravating factors with which defendant is charged, robbery and first degree kidnapping, are quite clear. Furthermore, the court cannot say that in defining the felony aggravating factors, the Legislature acted irrationally in choosing some felonies and exempting others, since all of the felony crimes included as aggravating factors are crimes involving violence or potential violence, and substantial risk of physical injury. It is not the class or grade of felony that must necessarily inform the Legislature's choice; rather, it may rely on the inherently violent nature of the underlying felony in concluding that it renders an intentional killing in the course thereof worthy of death. Nor is the statute rendered unconstitutional because it invites a death sentence for a defendant convicted of murder during a range of felonies, no matter how unplanned or spontaneous, while excluding from capital punishment more serious slayings such as premeditated murders or killings in which the perpetrator stalks or lies in wait for the victim, since the Legislature could have rationally determined that it was more important to punish and deter intentional killings in the course of certain violent felonies, and the court cannot say that this decision was clearly wrong.

Crimes - Murder - Capital Murder - Rationality of Aggravating Factors - Racial Impact of Felony Murders Penal Law § 125.27, which defines the crime of first degree, or capital, murder, passes constitutional muster. It is not rendered unconstitutional by the use of felony murder as an aggravating factor, which according to defendant has a disparate racial impact. The Legislature has not included felony murders -- killings that occur in the course of certain felonies, regardless of intent to cause death -- as death-eligible offenses; rather, the Legislature has included intentional killings occurring in the course of or in furtherance of certain felonies as offenses worthy of the death penalty. Moreover, defendant's reliance upon dated studies of purported discrimination in the application of the death penalty in other States does not show that New York's newly enacted death penalty statute, which has yet to lead to a single death verdict, will necessarily be subject to racial prejudice in its application. To the extent that the defendant relies upon studies pertaining to the use of the death penalty in other States, even those studies do not conclusively establish that race, or any other impermissible factor, intrudes upon the death penalty decision, which is, after all, based upon myriad factors pertaining to the strength of proof of guilt in the individual case, as well as the aggravating and mitigating factors as applied to the specific defendant. Assuming, arguendo, the validity of these studies, based as they are upon experiences in other States at other times, they provide no sound basis for concluding prospectively that the New York death penalty will be so unconstitutionally applied.

Crimes - Murder - Capital Murder - Double Counting Death Committed during First Degree Kidnapping A count of first degree murder charging defendant with an intentional killing in the course of and in furtherance of kidnapping in the first degree, in which the victim allegedly died, does not double count the death of the victim since to establish such count, the People are required to prove two very different things: that the defendant committed an intentional murder in furtherance of kidnapping in the first degree, and that the victim died before he could return or be returned safely. As to the murder element of the crime, the People must prove an intentional killing, while, as to the kidnapping aspect, the People need only prove the victim's death before his safe return, without regard to the defendant's intent, or even causation, and there is no prohibition, constitutional or otherwise, of using a single circumstance, such as the victim's death, to establish more than one element of the charged crime. Ordinary felony murder cases under the former Penal Law which stand for the proposition that the other elements constituting the felony which a defendant is engaged in must be so distinct from that of the homicide as not to be an ingredient of the homicide, are inapposite for the reason that the defendant is not charged with ordinary felony murder, but with capital murder, which, unlike felony murder, requires proof of an intentional killing. Nor is there force to the claim that it is not internally logical to charge defendant with killing to further an offense (first degree kidnapping) an essential element of which was the victim's killing -- i.e., killing to further a killing, since the plain words of the statute and the indictment belie that claim: defendant is not charged with killing to further a killing; rather, he is charged with an intentional killing in the course of and in furtherance of an abduction in which the victim died.

Crimes - Murder - Capital Murder - Double Counting Death Committed during First Degree Kidnapping A count of first degree murder charging defendant with an intentional killing in the course of and in furtherance of kidnapping in the first degree, in which the victim allegedly died, does not double count the death of the victim. Defendant's argument that the Legislature could not have intended to include as an aggravating factor Penal Law § 135.25 (3) kidnappings, while excluding second degree kidnappings, is unpersuasive: if the Legislature had intended to exclude such kidnappings from the list of aggravating factors, it could have expressly done so; it did not. The Legislature could have rationally concluded that intentional killings in the course of kidnappings in which the abductee dies are more worthy of the death penalty than those in which the abductee survives, but a third party is killed incidentally. Moreover, the Legislature could have reasonably concluded that it would be much more likely that a kidnapping victim would be intentionally killed in the course of a kidnapping, rather than some third party intervening in the occurrence, and, therefore, deterrence would be better served by making death-eligible only those kidnappings in which the kidnapping victim dies.

Crimes - Murder - Capital Murder - Method of Assigning Judges The method used to assign Judges to capital cases, whereby six Judges constitute the pool of Judges to which capital cases may be assigned, and all of these Judges are "non-aligned" Judges, i.e., experienced Judges who handle complex criminal cases occurring anywhere within the county without regard to the geographical zones into which the county is divided, is rational, fair and consonant with defendants' rights since the unique nature of capital cases does not require that each and every practice and procedure must be different or more elaborate than that used in an "ordinary" murder case. Moreover, each of the Judges is assigned randomly, on a rotating basis, to sit as the capital case miscellaneous motions Judge for one-month periods, during which time they handle any preindictment motions in potential capital cases, and the capital miscellaneous motions Judge retains any potential capital case he or she handles if that case, in fact, becomes a case in which the District Attorney announces that he is seeking the death penalty. Accordingly, whether a particular Judge in the pool will be assigned to a capital case is random, and it is not unconstitutional to limit the pool to the six Judges since the only criterion by which they were chosen was their long experience in handling complex criminal cases. Judges were not chosen based on their views toward the death penalty, and defendant does not allege that any of them would not judge his case scrupulously.

Crimes - Murder - Capital Murder - Cruel and Unusual Punishment - Federal Constitution Penal Law § 125.27, which defines first degree or capital murder, does not violate the prohibition against cruel and unusual punishment under the United States Constitution. The United States Supreme Court has determined that the death penalty does not constitute cruel and unusual punishment, per se, under the Eighth Amendment to the United States Constitution. The Supreme Court has approved a capital scheme which provides that only a narrow class of murderers may be subject to the death penalty; that, as a prerequisite to a death sentence, the jury must find that a statutory aggravating factor has been established beyond a reasonable doubt; that the jury may consider all factors mitigating against a death sentence; and that a judgment resulting in a death sentence may be appealed directly to the State's highest court, where it will be reviewed for errors of law and to determine whether the death sentence was imposed as a result of passion or prejudice, and whether the sentence in the particular case is disproportionate to those sentences imposed in similar cases, and New York's legislation provides for all of these protections and more.

Crimes - Murder - Capital Murder - Cruel and Unusual Punishment - State Constitution - Interpretive Analysis Although Penal Law § 125.27, which defines first degree or capital murder, does not violate the prohibition against cruel and unusual punishment under the United States Constitution, a separate analysis of the constitutionality of the statute under NY Constitution, article I, § 5, which parallels the Eighth Amendment of the US Constitution, must be undertaken, since the New York Court of Appeals has frequently applied the State Constitution, in both civil and criminal matters, to define a broader scope of protection than that accorded by the Federal Constitution in cases concerning individual rights and liberties. An interpretive analysis, in which the text of the State Constitution is examined to determine if it specifically recognizes rights not enumerated in the Federal Constitution, reveals no basis for interpreting New York's prohibition against cruel and unusual punishment any differently from that of the Eighth Amendment, since the relevant text of the two provisions is the same and they both arose in the same historical context.

Crimes - Murder - Capital Murder - Cruel and Unusual Punishment - State Constitution - Noninterpretive Analysis Although Penal Law § 125.27, which defines first degree or capital murder, does not violate the prohibition against cruel and unusual punishment under the United States Constitution, and does not violate an identical prohibition contained in NY Constitution, article I, § 5 under an interpretive analysis, the court must apply a noninterpretive analysis under the State Constitution to determine if any preexisting State statutory or common law or public policy or conception of fundamental fairness dictates a different result. Although the Court of Appeals in an 1890 case did not squarely address the issue of whether the death penalty per se is violative of article I, § 5, that it determined that a particular method of capital punishment was permissible lends support to the conclusion that it must have found, incidentally, that the death penalty itself was not violative of the Constitution. However, because interpretation of the Cruel and Unusual Punishments Clause must draw its meaning from the evolving standards of decency that mark the progress of a maturing society, the court must consider whether the present death penalty constitutes cruel and unusual punishment in the context of contemporary values.

Crimes - Murder - Capital Murder - Cruel and Unusual Punishment - State Constitution - Noninterpretive Analysis - Historical Considerations In reviewing New York's death penalty law (see, Penal Law § 125.27) under a noninterpretive State constitutional analysis, defendant's claim that the death penalty has dwindled in its availability and use in New York does not accurately reflect the historical and persistent acceptance of the death penalty in this State. In fact, notwithstanding continuing calls for its abolition from some quarters, capital punishment has had an enduring vitality in New York from colonial days to the present, and in recent history, New York was without the death penalty only for relatively brief periods. Neither the Legislature nor the people have rejected the death penalty per se at any point in the State's history. Only for relatively brief periods, primarily as a consequence of judicial intervention, was New York without a death penalty, and the most compelling evidence of the death penalty's acceptance in New York today is the reestablishment of the death sentence in 1995, making New York 1 of 38 States, along with the Federal Government, to sanction the punishment. That juries, historically, have seen fit to impose the death penalty in a small number of cases does not lead to the conclusion that the very existence of capital punishment does not comport with the standards of society. Moreover, it is of little consequence that the latest death penalty scheme includes more death-eligible crimes than the prior statutes, since it cannot be said that punishments must necessarily become more lenient with the passage of time. Rather, the Legislature could have reasonably concluded that the ills of today's society require a more expansive death penalty statute than those which gave rise to the capital statutes of decades past.

Crimes - Murder - Capital Murder - Cruel and Unusual Punishment - State Constitution - Noninterpretive Analysis In reviewing New York's death penalty law (Penal Law § 125.27) under a noninterpretive State constitutional analysis, it is concluded that the framework of the New York Constitution presupposes the availability and permissibility of the death penalty, for there would be no reason for the existence of provisions prohibiting waiver of jury trial in capital cases, limiting jurisdiction of the Court of Appeals to review questions of law, except where judgment is death, and providing for direct appeal to the Court of Appeals for death sentences were it otherwise. Nor can it be said that the administration of the death penalty will inevitably result in invidious discrimination against certain racial groups, or any other constitutionally cognizable class of persons, or that there is a serious risk that innocent defendants will be executed, since the discretion to seek and impose the death penalty is carefully circumscribed by the statute, and only if the District Attorney proves beyond a reasonable doubt all of the elements of the crime, including the statutory aggravating factor or factors, may the jury consider whether to impose a death sentence. Moreover, in making the sentencing determination, the jury's discretion is also carefully guided by statutory mandates. In moving to strike the death notice, what the defendant seeks is a judicial declaration that the Legislature should not be permitted to enact the death penalty under any circumstances, for if New York's present legislation, with its myriad protections and safeguards, cannot pass constitutional muster, it is hard to imagine that any attempt to establish capital punishment in this State could clear the high constitutional hurdle set by such a decision.

Crimes - Murder - Capital Murder - Cruel and Unusual Punishment - State Constitution - Noninterpretive Analysis - Racial Factors In reviewing New York's death penalty law (see, Penal Law § 125.27) under a noninterpretive State constitutional analysis, it cannot be said that the Legislature enacted the death penalty statute with knowledge that its use would result in patent racial discrimination, since such a claim rests upon the oft-cited, yet unproven, allegation that the imposition of the death penalty falls disproportionately upon certain groups because of racial discrimination in the process. The Legislature ensured that New York's capital statute does not permit a jury unfettered discretion to issue the death penalty; sentencing discretion is guided by particularized, racially neutral criteria. In addition, the Court of Appeals is empowered to review a death verdict for any claim of racial bias. Thus, it should be apparent that the Legislature did not enact the death penalty hoping to discriminate against some suspect class, but passed the statute as a consequence of its perception of the ills of society, and in so doing, made every reasonable effort to provide that invidious discrimination would play no part in the process. The statutory scheme ensures that the consideration of the sentence is guided by uniform standards, and that any death verdict will be based upon the merits of the individual case, and not upon passion, prejudice, or bigotry. For the same reasons, it cannot be said that the use of the death penalty will result inevitably in the execution of the wrongly accused. In addition to the extraordinary protections accorded defendants in capital cases, New York law provides for additional protections, e.g., requiring corroboration of accomplice testimony, that greatly reduce the likelihood of an erroneous conviction. Coupled with direct review of death sentences by the Court of Appeals, these unique protections ensure to the greatest degree possible that any death verdict will rest upon a solid foundation.

Crimes - Murder - Capital Murder - Cruel and Unusual Punishment - State Constitution - Noninterpretive Analysis - Contemporary Values In reviewing New York's death penalty law (see, Penal Law § 125.27) under a noninterpretive State constitutional analysis, the overwhelming evidence of the acceptance of the death penalty in the United States generally and New York particularly compels the conclusion that capital punishment is not contrary to the values of contemporary New York society. Among the useful social purposes which the Legislature might conclude are advanced by the death penalty is deterrence of crime, notwithstanding the conflicting evidence on this point. Where there is a dispute as to the desirability and feasibility of a policy, it is not for the court to choose sides and resolve the policy debate, since it cannot say that the Legislature was plainly wrong to credit those studies that find a deterrent effect, and reject those that do not. So, too, the Legislature may have found that the death penalty served a proper retributive purpose. Although retribution is not a valid penological goal standing alone, it may, along with deterrence, constitute one of the ends of the penal law. In addition it cannot be said that the death penalty is disproportionate to the offense of aggravated intentional murder: the court is not aware of any Federal or New York precedent holding that the death penalty is a disproportionate punishment for the commission of the types of aggravated murders prescribed in section 125.27. There is nothing in the text of the New York Constitution or the history and practices of this State that leads to the conclusion that the punishment of death is so grossly disproportionate to the crimes enumerated in section 125.27 as to render the statute unconstitutional.

Crimes - Murder - Capital Murder - Cruel and Unusual Punishment - Fundamental Right to Life In a prosecution for capital murder in which defendant asserts that the imposition of the death penalty against a criminal defendant who has been convicted of committing an aggravated, intentional murder violates the fundamental right to life under the New York Constitution, it is enough to say that there is no support in the Federal or State Constitution, or any other source of Anglo-American law, for the claim that the convicted perpetrator of a particularly atrocious murder enjoys an unqualified right to life, notwithstanding the Legislature's rational determination that the only appropriate sanction for the defendant's egregious conduct is death.

Crimes - Murder - Capital Murder - Equal Protection - Racial Factors In a prosecution for capital murder in which defendant asserts that the death penalty, as applied, violates prohibitions against racial discrimination, apart from conclusory and unsubstantiated hearsay allegations that the District Attorney is seeking the death penalty in this case for political purposes, defendant has failed to allege any specific facts that would support an inference of discrimination, and there can be no invidious discrimination arising from the District Attorneys' practice of accounting for the race of death-eligible defendants, since there is no reason to doubt that the prosecutors are compiling this information for the purpose of complying with the mandate that the death penalty be administered without regard to impermissible factors such as race, as well to record information that may be used in response to challenges to the application of the death penalty. Inasmuch as no defendant has yet been convicted of a capital crime under the new statute, it is impossible to say that the death penalty will be unfairly administered in New York, and it cannot be said that the District Attorneys' charging decisions, based as they are upon numerous permissible factors, are influenced in whole or in part by any impermissible factor, such as race. Moreover, it cannot be said that the discretion left to the District Attorney violates any constitutional prerogatives, since a prosecutor may be entrusted with charging decisions and the exercise of that discretion in the context of capital cases, unless proved to be for an invidious purpose, is not unconstitutional.

Crimes - Murder - Capital Murder - Statutory Limits on Guilty Pleas - Standing In a prosecution for capital murder, the People's assertion that defendant cannot challenge the provisions of the Criminal Procedure Law regulating guilty pleas in capital cases because he has not offered to plead guilty, and therefore has not suffered any injury in fact, is untenable since defendant does not assert merely that he has been denied the right to plead guilty, but that the plea provisions effectively penalize his right to a jury trial. Assuming arguendo that the plea provisions are defective, defendant is, in fact, harmed because his right to a jury trial is impaired by plea provisions that penalize that right. Therefore, even if defendant were to abjure a plea and exercise his right to a jury trial, he would have standing to raise this claim.

Crimes - Murder - Capital Murder - Statutory Limits on Guilty Pleas - Denial of Right to Jury Trial and Privilege against Self-Incrimination New York's death penalty statute, which provides that the death penalty shall only be imposed upon a recommendation of the jury and that a defendant may not waive a jury trial where the crime charged may be punishable by death (see, CPL 220.10 [5] [e]; 220.30 [3] [b] [vii]; 220.60 [2] [a]; see also, NY Const, art I, § 2) is unconstitutional to the extent that a defendant may avoid the risk of death only by pleading guilty and waiving his right to a jury trial and his privilege against self-incrimination. Although an open plea of guilty is not possible under the statutory scheme, the requirement that the prosecutor consent to the plea and the power of a court to reject coerced guilty pleas and involuntary jury waivers only alleviate, but do not totally eliminate the constitutional infirmity, which results in the needless encouragement of guilty pleas. Moreover, it does not suffice to claim that because the intention of the Legislature may have been to mitigate the severity of the death penalty by permitting nondeath pleas to capital crimes, the statute passes constitutional muster, since legislative objectives may not be pursued by means that needlessly chill the exercise of basic constitutional rights.

Crimes - Murder - Capital Murder - Statutory Limits on Guilty Pleas - Denial of Right to Jury Trial and Privilege against Self-Incrimination - Severability of Unconstitutional Provision New York's death penalty statute, which provides that the death penalty shall only be imposed upon a recommendation of the jury and that a defendant may not waive a jury trial where the crime charged may be punishable by death (see, CPL 220.10 [5] [e]; 220.30 [3] [b] [vii]; 220.60 [2] [a]; see also, NY Const, art I, § 2) is unconstitutional to the extent that a defendant may avoid the risk of death only by pleading guilty and waiving his right to a jury trial and his privilege against self-incrimination; however, the plea provisions may be severed from the remainder of the law in light of the death penalty's savings clause (see, L 1995, ch 1, § 37), since there is no reason to conclude that the Legislature did not intend for the statute to remain in effect absent those provisions. There is no question that CPL 220.10 (5) (e), 220.30 (3) (b) (vii) and 220.60 (2) (a) constitute discrete provisions pertaining only to capital cases, and, as such, they may be severed without doing injury to the remainder of the Criminal Procedure Law; nor would severance lead to impermissible results in capital cases. Since the right to plead guilty is a creature of statute, and is not mandated constitutionally, the court may strike the contested statutes, thereby leaving no provision for guilty pleas in death-eligible cases, and thus curing the constitutional defect. The effect of severing the provisions will be to prohibit pleas in cases in which a notice of intent to seek the death penalty has been filed and is in effect. Therefore, CPL 220.10 (5) (e), 220.30 (3) (b) (vii) and 220.60 (2) (a) shall be deemed stricken from the death penalty statute.

Crimes - Murder - Capital Murder - No Waiver of Jury Trial There is no constitutional right to a nonjury trial, and consonant with NY Constitution, article I, § 2, which provides that, "a jury trial may be waived by the defendant in all criminal cases, except those in which the crime charged may be punishable by death," CPL 320.10 (1) provides that a defendant may waive his right to a jury trial, "except where the indictment charges the crime of murder in the first degree." Defendant's claims that he has a constitutional right to opt for a nonjury trial, and that permitting noncapital defendants to waive the right to jury trial violates his right to equal protection is unavailing, since capital defendants may not be considered a suspect class for the purpose of equal protection analysis, and there is a rational basis for requiring that, in all trials in which the charged crime may be punishable by death, rather than leaving the defendant's fate to the judgment of a single individual, the decision should be made by a jury of 12 persons reflecting the conscious and moral judgment of the community.

Crimes - Murder - Capital Murder - Right to Question Prospective Jurors on Their Ability to Impose Death Penalty CPL 270.20 (1) (f), which provides that a juror may be challenged for cause in a death penalty case if he or she entertains conscientious opinions either against or in favor of capital punishment which would interfere with the proper exercise of discretion in the determination of a sentence, and which mirrors the language of the relevant United States Supreme Court opinions, serves the legitimate State interest of permitting the removal of jurors who would be unable to fulfill their oaths to follow the law as given to them by the court. Accordingly, defendant has failed to demonstrate that death qualifying the jury violates any provision of the Federal or State Constitution in achieving this goal. Moreover, the fact that a "death qualified" jury may be more prone to conviction does not rise to a constitutional violation. Death qualification is necessary to the State's concededly legitimate interest in assuring that jurors sworn to determine guilt and sentencing can do so in accordance with the law and the Judge's instructions. The purpose of the statute is to insure an impartial verdict, and no method has been suggested to supplant death qualification in achieving that essential goal. There is no reason to presume that a death-qualified jury, even if more conviction prone, would render a verdict contrary to the facts. In any event, if defendant is convicted and the jury's verdict regarding guilt is contrary to the weight of the evidence, there are adequate remedies available to the defendant, thus assuring his due process rights.

Crimes - Murder - Capital Murder - Composition of Death-Qualified Jury - Cross Section of Community CPL 270.20 (1) (f), which provides that a juror may be challenged for cause in a death penalty case if he or she entertains conscientious opinions either against or in favor of capital punishment which would interfere with the proper exercise of discretion in the determination of a sentence, does not violate a defendant's right to a jury composed of a fair cross section of the community, since groups defined solely in terms of shared attitudes that would prevent or substantially impair members of the group from performing one of their duties as jurors are not distinctive groups for fair cross-section purposes. However, even if death qualification resulted in the disproportionate exclusion of constitutionally cognizable groups, such as women and African-Americans, defendant's motion to preclude voir dire regarding potential jurors' views of the death penalty must still be denied, since exclusion of jurors based on their ability to perform their duties and carry out their oaths advances an important goal, and does not discriminate on the basis of membership in a cognizable group, per se. Death qualification, unlike the wholesale exclusion of blacks, women, or Mexican-Americans from jury service, is carefully designed to serve the State's concededly legitimate interest in obtaining a single jury that can properly and impartially apply the law to the facts of the case at both the guilt and sentencing phases of a capital trial. As such, it does not violate the Sixth Amendment. Moreover, inasmuch as it was clearly the Legislature's intent to have guilt and sentence determined by the same jury in all but the most unusual circumstances, death qualification, to be effective, must precede the guilt phase.

Crimes - Murder - Capital Murder - Composition of Jury - "Life" Qualification CPL 270.20 (1) (f), which provides that a juror may be challenged for cause in a death penalty case if he or she entertains conscientious opinions either against or in favor of capital punishment which would interfere with the proper exercise of discretion in the determination of a sentence, is not unconstitutional because, by its terms, it does not permit the defendant sufficient leeway to "life-qualify" the jury, i.e., to identify and strike those potential jurors who would always impose the death penalty, regardless of any mitigating factors. Although defendant claims that the statute permits him only to strike those jurors whose conscientious opinions would "preclude" them from being fair and impartial and from considering alternatives to a death sentence, and not those jurors whose views would "substantially impair" those abilities, the court rejects defendant's invitation to craft a rule that jurors whose opinions would "likely impair" their abilities to carry out their duties to be fair and impartial and to exercise their sentencing discretion properly may not be stricken, since defendant's request has no support in the statute or in case precedent. The relevant standard provides that defendant may strike those jurors whose opinions will not permit them to decide the case fairly, and this provision assures that defendant's Sixth Amendment rights will be protected. The court is mindful that it has a serious duty to determine the question of actual bias and must be zealous to protect the rights of the accused, and will act accordingly.

 

713 of 992 DOCUMENTS


Daniel S. v. Dowling


Index No. 43829


SUPREME COURT OF NEW YORK, GENESEE COUNTY


172 Misc. 2d 619; 660 N.Y.S.2d 288; 1997 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 221



April 28, 1997, Decided


NOTICE:  [***1] EDITED FOR PUBLICATION


SUBSEQUENT HISTORY: As Corrected July 7, 1997.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner boy brought a N.Y. C.P.L.R. art. 78 action against respondent commissioner of New York state department of social services (commissioner), contending that the statutory and regulatory scheme in child abuse cases was unconstitutional to the extent it denied children due process rights by not providing him with due process. The commissioner contended the court had no authority to issue a declaratory judgment.


OVERVIEW: The boy was allegedly abused by his father and the Statewide Central Register of Child Abuse and Maltreatment investigation found the charges unfounded. The mother filed a family offense petition against the father and a law guardian was appointed for the boy. The law guardian sought an administrative review of the unfounded determination. When the review resulted in no change in the determination this action was brought. The court rejected the commissioner's argument that the court had no authority to issue a declaratory judgment and found that the boy had not been afforded due process rights to be protected. The court determined that the process due reported child victims in cases where the reports are unfounded included prompt notice to the child and to the child's parents or custodian or guardian if other than the parents, or to an ombudsman. The review procedure should have provided the opportunity to be heard and to present evidence to a neutral hearing body or officer. The court ordered the commissioner to provide an administrative hearing for the boy in the same manner accorded an appellant pursuant to its regulations, N.Y. Comp. Codes R. & Regs. tit. 18, § 432.3(k).


OUTCOME: The court held that the regulatory scheme in child abuse cases was unconstitutional to the extent it denied children due process rights by not providing them with due process.


HEADNOTES

Parent and Child - Abused or Neglected Child - Child's Right to Review of Unfounded Determination

In a child protective proceeding resulting in a determination that the allegation that petitioner's father abused him was unfounded, the 10-year-old petitioner was denied his right to due process when, pursuant to a request from petitioner's Law Guardian for an administrative review of the unfounded determination, respondent Department of Social Services failed to provide petitioner with an administrative hearing in the same manner as would be accorded to an alleged perpetrator seeking to challenge an indicated determination. Since there are no provisions in the statutory/regulatory scheme of child protective proceedings for a child to obtain a review of an unfounded determination or even receive notification thereof, the law in this State does not provide due process for a reported child victim to challenge the unfounding of a child abuse or neglect report. The process due reported child victims in cases where the reports are unfounded includes prompt notice to the child and to the child's parents or custodian or guardian if other than the parents. However, since a parent or someone aligned with the parent is usually the alleged perpetrator, notice would have to be given to some independent third person designated by law to act in the child's behalf, possibly an ombudsman, who would have the right to review the file which resulted in the unfounded determination. Due process further requires a review procedure should the child's representative wish to request a review, which procedure would provide the opportunity to be heard in person and to present evidence to a neutral hearing body or officer with a written statement of determination to be provided in a timely manner by the hearing body or officer indicating the basis of the decision rendered. Accordingly, respondent's review of the unfounded determination at the request of petitioner's Law Guardian, which consisted solely of a "paper" review limited to the contents of the file, verifying whether departmental regulations had been complied with, did not suffice to accord petitioner due process, and respondent is directed to provide an administrative hearing for petitioner in the same manner as would be accorded an alleged perpetrator pursuant to its regulations (see, 18 NYCRR part 434).

 

714 of 992 DOCUMENTS


People v. Abramov


97-217


SUPREME COURT OF NEW YORK, QUEENS COUNTY


172 Misc. 2d 186; 658 N.Y.S.2d 567; 1997 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 128



April 9, 1997, Decided



DISPOSITION:  [***1] That branch of the defendant's motion is, in all respects, denied.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant filed a motion, challenging the counts of the indictment charging criminal contempt in the first degree under N.Y. Penal Law § 215.51 as being violative of the Ex Post Facto Clauses of the both the federal and state constitutions, and in the alternative, violative of his due process rights. The motion was denied and defendant sought rehearing.


OVERVIEW: Defendant had violated an order of protection and was charged with criminal contempt in the first degree. Defendant's motion was denied. The crime for which defendant was charged was in existence when he committed the crime. The behavior complained of in the indictment was not innocent behavior when committed; nor was defendant's punishment being increased for his prior crimes. Defendant was charged with a crime that he committed while a valid order of protection was in effect. He had fair warning of the nature of the proscribed conduct in advance of his commission of the offense. The court determined that § 215.51 was constitutional and not violative of the Ex Post Facto Clause of the United States Constitution or the Constitution of the State of New York.


OUTCOME: The court denied defendant's motion and adhered to its original decision.


HEADNOTES

Constitutional Law - Ex Post Facto Law - Criminal Contempt in First Degree

Penal Law § 215.51, criminal contempt in the first degree, is not unconstitutional as inflicting greater punishment for past crimes in violation of the Ex Post Facto Clause of the United States and New York Constitutions; accordingly, defendant's motion to dismiss the counts of the indictment charging criminal contempt in the first degree is denied. For a criminal or penal law to be ex post facto it must be retrospective and disadvantage the offender affected. Although a longer sentence disadvantages a defendant, a statute is not ex post facto because it provides enhanced punishment for the instant offense, not the prior offense. Here, the crime for which defendant was charged was in existence when he committed the crime. The behavior complained of was not innocent behavior when committed; nor is the defendant's punishment being increased for his prior crimes. Also, the defendant is charged with a crime which he committed while a valid order of protection was in effect. He had fair warning of the nature of the proscribed conduct in advance of his commission of the offense.

 

715 of 992 DOCUMENTS


People v. Voelker


Docket # 96K084402


CRIMINAL COURT OF THE CITY OF NEW YORK, KINGS COUNTY


172 Misc. 2d 564; 658 N.Y.S.2d 180; 1997 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 186



March 31, 1997, Decided


NOTICE:  [***1] EDITED FOR PUBLICATION



DISPOSITION: Defendants motion to dismiss is denied.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant moved to dismiss the accusatory instrument that charged him with three counts of animal cruelty, pursuant to N.Y. Agric. & Mkts. Law § 353, alleging that it was facially insufficient. Defendant also maintained that dismissal was required because N.Y. Agric. & Mkts. Law § 353 was being unconstitutionally applied.


OVERVIEW: Defendant cut off the heads of three live, conscious iguanas without justification. Defendant was arrested and charged with animal cruelty, pursuant to N.Y. Agric. & Mkts. Law § 353. Defendant asserted that the accusatory instrument was facially insufficient, and that the killings were justified. Additionally, defendant contended that N.Y. Agric. & Mkts. Law § 353 was being unconstitutionally applied. The court held that justification for the killing or torturing of animals was required to be of the type necessary to preserve the safety of property or to overcome danger or injury, or the type of legal justification specifically authorized by statute. Defendant's justification defense failed, since he did not claim that his acts were necessary to preserve the safety of property or to overcome danger or injury. Additionally, the court held that the animal cruelty statute was not a content-based restriction on speech. Rather, it was a restriction against torturing, injuring, maiming, mutilating, or killing animals. The statute was not directed at any form of communication, and defendant was not being prosecuted because he televised the decapitation.


OUTCOME: The court denied defendant's motion to dismiss animal cruelty charges, because his justification defense failed to claim that his acts were necessary to preserve the safety of property or to overcome danger or injury, and the animal cruelty statute was not a content-based restriction on speech.


HEADNOTES

Crimes - Information - Suffici ency of Information - Cruelty to Animals

Defendant's motion to dismiss as facially insufficient the information charging him with three counts of animal cruelty pursuant to Agriculture and Markets Law § 353 for decapitating three live, conscious iguanas without justification on the ground that the allegation that it was "without justification" is conclusory and insufficient is denied. Justification for killing or torturing animals must be of the type necessary to preserve the safety of property, to overcome danger or injury, or be specifically authorized by statute. The term "without justification" is not a legal conclusion but a factual allegation, and whether or not the People can prove that defendant "unjustifiably" committed these acts is a matter best left to the trier of facts based upon the moral standards of the community.

Constitutional Law - Freedom of Speech - Cruelty to Animals

Defendant's motion to dismiss the information charging him with three counts of animal cruelty pursuant to Agriculture and Markets Law § 353 for decapitating three live, conscious iguanas, an act which was videotaped and then broadcast on television, on the ground that the statute is being unconstitutionally applied to him in violation of his First Amendment right to free expression, is denied. The animal cruelty statute at issue is not a content-based restriction on speech, but rather a restriction against torturing, injuring, maiming, mutilating or killing animals, and although the statute might prohibit the torturing of an animal as a form of expression, it is not unconstitutional as it serves a legitimate governmental interest, which is the prevention of cruelty to animals. Moreover, defendant is not being prosecuted because he televised the decapitation of the iguanas; the broadcast merely provided law enforcement officials with a way to observe defendant engage in criminal activity.

 

716 of 992 DOCUMENTS


67 Vestry Tenants Ass'n v. Raab


Index No. 126556/95


SUPREME COURT OF NEW YORK, NEW YORK COUNTY


172 Misc. 2d 214; 658 N.Y.S.2d 804; 1997 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 124



March 31, 1997, Decided


SUBSEQUENT HISTORY:  [***1] As Corrected May 12, 1997.



DISPOSITION: The petition is denied and the proceeding is dismissed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner residents brought a proceeding which sought a judgment reversing and annulling the decision of the Landmarks Preservation Commission (commission), which issued a certificate of appropriateness to respondent developer. The certificate of appropriateness was granted for the renovation of a warehouse located in a historic district and the construction of a 19-story hotel tower in a location partially adjacent to the historic district.


OVERVIEW: In order to obtain certificate of appropriateness, and against massive community opposition, the developer reduced his proposal to renovate a warehouse from a 31-story building down to a 19-story building. The exhaustion of remedies rule and doctrine of judicial estoppel prevented success on the residents' claim that the commission, led by respondent chairperson, exceeded its authority under the Landmarks Preservation Law, Administrative Code § 25-304(b). The court found the commission was within its authority and did not act arbitrarily in considering the impact that the proposed building would have had on the historic district and in approving the design of the proposed project. The commission's actions were ministerial in nature and thus were excluded from review under the State Environmental Quality Review Act (SEQRA), N.Y. Envtl. Conserv. Law art. 8. In addition, because landmark matters were in issue, the requirement that an environmental impact statement be prepared prior to the grant of a certificate was not applicable: SEQRA regulations specifically excluded the issuance of historic preservation permits.


OUTCOME: The petition which sought a judgment reversing and nullifying the decision of the commission to issue a certificate of appropriateness for developer's proposed structure was denied. The proceeding was dismissed.


HEADNOTES

Administrative Law - Failure to Exhaust Administrative Remedies - Challenging Jurisdictional Authority of Landmarks Preservation Commission to Issue Certificate of Appropriateness

Petitioners are procedurally precluded from objecting to the jurisdictional authority of the Landmarks Preservation Commission (LPC) to issue a certificate of appropriateness for the renovation of a warehouse located on the edge of a historic district and construction of a tower partially adjacent to, but outside of, the historic district, by failure to exhaust administrative remedies. Generally, courts will not review objections to an agency's determination not raised at the administrative level. Although the exhaustion rule need not be followed when an agency's action is challenged as either unconstitutional or wholly beyond its grant of power, application of these exceptions lies in the court's discretion. Here even though petitioners are claiming the LPC exceeded its grant of power, the exhaustion rule is applicable since petitioners not only failed to raise the jurisdictional issue before the LPC, but affirmatively sought the administrative action, which is now claimed to be in excess of LPC's jurisdiction. At the administrative hearing, petitioners voiced concerns regarding the architectural appropriateness of the tower which, upon review by LPC, resulted in a reduction in size from 31 to 19 stories.

Estoppel - Judicial Estoppel - Challenging Jurisdictional Authority of Landmarks Preservation Commission to Issue Certificate of Appropriateness

Petitioners are procedurally precluded from objecting to the jurisdictional authority of the Landmarks Preservation Commission (LPC) to issue a certificate of appropriateness for the renovation of a warehouse located on the edge of a historic district and construction of a tower partially adjacent to, but outside of, the historic district, by judicial estoppel. Judicial estoppel prevents a party from asserting a position in a legal proceeding that is contrary to a position previously taken in a prior legal proceeding. At the administrative hearing, petitioners voiced concerns regarding the architectural appropriateness of the tower which, upon review by LPC, resulted in a reduction in size from 31 to 19 stories. Thus, it was only after the failure of petitioners' strategy of getting the LPC to reject the project altogether that petitioners now claim that it was unlawful for the LPC to do exactly what petitioners previously urged the LPC to do.

Municipal Corporations - Landmarks - Jurisdiction of Landmarks Preservation Commission to Issue Certificate of Appropriateness

Respondent Landmarks Preservation Commission did not exceed its jurisdiction when it issued a certificate of appropriateness for the renovation of a warehouse located on the edge of a historic district, construction of a 19-story tower partially adjacent to, but outside of, the historic district, and a connecting tunnel between the buildings, notwithstanding that its jurisdiction is limited to structures situated within historic districts, since all three structural components of the project are totally integrated into a single building with a single mechanical system. As the project was proposed and approved, no one component can stand on its own, and none can be built without the other.

Municipal Corporations - Landmarks - Authority of Landmarks Preservation Commission to Issue Certificate of Appropriateness

Respondent Landmarks Preservation Commission (LPC) did not violate Administrative Code of the City of New York § 25-307 (3) and § 25-304 (a), which prohibit the LPC from creating regulations or requirements regarding the height and bulk of buildings, when it issued a certificate of appropriateness for the renovation of a warehouse located on the edge of a historic district, construction of a 19-story tower partially adjacent to, but outside of, the historic district, and a connecting tunnel between the buildings, since the LPC did not specifically limit the height of the tower to 19 stories; rather, it merely approved the over-all aesthetic design of the proposed project including the tower's mass in relationship to the warehouse and the project's relationship to the historic district.

Environmental Conservation - Environmental Quality Review - Historic Preservation Permits

6 NYCRR 617.5 (c) (19), effective January 1, 1996, which specifically excludes from the requirements of the State Environmental Quality Review Act (SEQRA) official acts of a ministerial nature involving no exercise of discretion, including historic preservation permits, is applicable to the certificate of appropriateness issued in August 1995 by respondent Landmarks Preservation Commission (LPC). Retroactive application of remedial regulations is warranted unless such application would impair the vested rights of the party seeking relief. Here, the revision did not change or create substantive rights, but rather clarified imperfections in prior law that had led to needless challenges to the issuance of ministerial permits. Also, LPC's decision to issue the certificate, based upon the definite standards imposed by the Landmarks Law, is "ministerial" within the meaning of SEQRA. LPC, which is not authorized to regulate matters ordinarily considered in the zoning process, did not "approve" the project, but determined that the proposal was architecturally appropriate for, and in harmony with, the historic district.

Municipal Corporations - Landmarks - Authority of Landmarks Preservation Commission to Issue Certificate of Appropriateness

A determination by the Landmarks Preservation Commission (LPC) to issue a certificate of appropriateness approving construction of a tower to be connected to a warehouse in a historic district was not arbitrary and capricious for failure to examine the terms of the joint venture agreement between the title owner of the warehouse and the beneficial owner of the warehouse and the Department of Buildings (DOB) objection sheet, where petitioners failed to demonstrate that the terms of the joint venture agreement or the DOB objection sheet have any impact on a historical landmark determination, and failed to identify which LPC rules were violated.

 

717 of 992 DOCUMENTS


Filicore v. Jossel


INDEX NO. 12978/89, CAL. NO. 94L02697


SUPREME COURT OF NEW YORK, NEW YORK COUNTY


173 Misc. 2d 42; 660 N.Y.S.2d 786; 1997 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 247



March 31, 1997, Decided


NOTICE:  [***1] EDITED FOR PUBLICATION


SUBSEQUENT HISTORY: As Corrected August 18, 1997.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant moved under N.Y. C.P.L.R. 4404(a) to set aside a jury verdict that found that defendant had violated N.Y. Real Prop. Law § 236 and awarded damages.


OVERVIEW: In its motion to set aside the verdict, defendant contended that § 263 was unconstitutionally vague and was inapplicable to defendant because it only applied to initial rental. In its determination, the court noted that the statute was designed to prevent housing discrimination against persons with children and applied after initial rental. The court discussed that other such statutes, at both the state and federal levels, had been held to be valid and applied to circumstances similar to defendant's. Moreover, there was a strong public policy towards prohibiting housing discrimination against persons with children which was reflected in the statute.


OUTCOME: The court denied defendant's motion to set aside the verdict and its motion for attorney's fees.


HEADNOTES

Constitutional Law - Validity of Statute - Real Property Law § 236 Real Property Law § 236, which prohibits discrimination in the terms, conditions, or privileges of any dwelling rental, solely on the ground that a person or family has a child or children, is constitutional as a valid and reasonable exercise of New York State's police power for the public welfare. Moreover, the statute is not unconstitutionally vague and provides reasonable due process of law.

 

718 of 992 DOCUMENTS


In re Miller


97-198


COUNTY COURT OF NEW YORK, ALLEGANY COUNTY


172 Misc. 2d 105; 656 N.Y.S.2d 846; 1997 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 125



March 28, 1997, Decided


NOTICE:   [***1]  EDITED FOR PUBLICATION


SUBSEQUENT HISTORY: As Corrected June 16, 1997.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Applicant sought an order requiring respondent state police superintendent to dispense, on religious freedom grounds, with the requirement under N.Y. Penal Law § 400.00(3) that he submit to a photograph in his application for a pistol permit.


OVERVIEW: Applicant, an adult of the Amish faith, sought an order requiring the superintendent to dispense with the requirement under § 400.00(3) that applicant provide a photograph in his application for a pistol permit. Applicant contended that the prerequisite of a photograph was unconstitutionally imposed under the circumstances of the case. The application came before the court pursuant to an order to show cause. The superintendent argued that the state's interests in requiring a photograph were compelling beyond mere administrative convenience. The court, which made no determination whether a permit should be issued to applicant, entered an order granting applicant's request for an exemption from the requirement of § 400.00(3) that he submit a photograph. Although § 400.00(3) was reasonably related to legitimate governmental concerns, applicant's right of religious freedom under N.Y. Const. art. I, § 3 and the Establishment Clause of U.S. Const. amend. I outweighed the governmental objectives of § 400.00(3) where applicant could provide fingerprints as an alternative method of identification.


OUTCOME: The court entered an order granting applicant an exemption, on religious freedom grounds, from enforcement by the superintendent of the mandatory photograph requirement of the state law governing applications for pistol permits.


HEADNOTES

Licenses - Firearms - Dispensing with Photograph Requirement

The County Court, as licensing officer, may exempt on religious grounds an Amish individual from the photograph requirements of Penal Law § 400.00 (3), which directs that an applicant seeking a license to carry or possess a pistol or revolver "shall submit one photograph of himself", provided that he submits to fingerprinting and provided further that he provides law enforcement authorities with an alternative means of immediate personal identification. The legislative enactment directing that a photograph be submitted with an application for a pistol permit is reasonably related to legitimate governmental concerns; it substantially enhances the ability to positively identify the applicant. However, there are suitable and effective safeguards alternative to a photograph, and the applicant has represented that it would not be against his religion to be fingerprinted. Given the exalted stature of religious freedom guaranteed by the Federal and State Constitutions and the undesirability of creating even an appearance that an applicant is precluded from applying for a pistol permit solely because of his religious convictions, the application must be granted.

 

719 of 992 DOCUMENTS


People v. Shulman


INDICTMENT No. 1112-96


COUNTY COURT OF NEW YORK, SUFFOLK COUNTY


172 Misc. 2d 535; 658 N.Y.S.2d 794; 1997 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 142



March 24, 1997, Decided


NOTICE:   [***1]  EDITED FOR PUBLICATION


SUBSEQUENT HISTORY: As Corrected May 19, 1997.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant was charged with one count of murder in the first degree in violation of N.Y. Penal Law § 125.27 (1)(a)(xi) and four counts of murder in the second degree. Defendant filed an omnibus motion following the grand jury indictment seeking relief.


OVERVIEW: Defendant requested that the court dismiss the indictment for legal insufficiency, dismiss count one of the indictment charging him with the crime of murder in the first degree on ex post facto grounds, and compel the State to provide expanded discovery. The court held: (1) the evidence submitted to the grand jury was legally sufficient to support the counts in the indictment; (2) § 125.27 (1)(a)(xi), under which an individual was deemed to have committed first degree murder if the same individual had committed two other murders within the previous two years, was not retroactive when made to apply to future transactions merely because such transactions related to and were founded upon antecedent events; (3) the potential of an increased sentence under § 125.27 (1)(a)(xi) was not prohibited because penalty-enhancing statutes were excluded under the Ex Post Facto Clause; and (4) because the prosecution's discovery obligations were not expanded under the capital murder statutory scheme, the court lacked authority to grant defendant's discovery requests beyond those for provided for in the criminal procedure law.


OUTCOME: The court denied defendant's motions to dismiss the indictment and to dismiss the first degree murder charge from the indictment. The court granted defendant's request for discovery only to the extent allowed by the criminal procedure law.


HEADNOTES

Grand Jury - Inspection of Grand Jury Minutes - Capital Murder Prosecution

The fact that a defendant faces the death penalty, standing alone, does not require a court to release the Grand Jury minutes in a capital murder prosecution.

Constitutional Law - Ex Post Facto Law - First Degree Murder

Penal Law § 125.27 (1) (a) (xi), which provides that a person is guilty of first degree murder if he or she intentionally causes the death of another person and, in a similar fashion or pursuant to a common scheme or plan, intentionally caused the death of two or more additional persons within the State in separate criminal transactions within a period of 24 months, is not unconstitutional as applied to defendant even though two of the three murders defendant is accused of committing in a nine-month period occurred prior to the date that Penal Law § 125.27 became effective. The Ex Post Facto Clause does not prohibit the enhancement of punishment for a present crime based upon a prior crime, even where the prior crime occurred before enactment of the penalty-enhancing statute.

Crimes - Disclosure - Capital Murder Prosecution

A defendant in a capital murder prosecution is not entitled to "heightened due process" and expanded discovery; the right to discovery is statutory rather than constitutional and as the Legislature did not expand the prosecution's discovery obligations when it enacted New York's capital murder statutory scheme, the court lacks authority to grant discovery requests beyond those for which the Criminal Procedure Law currently provides.

 

720 of 992 DOCUMENTS


Hill v. City of New York


INDEX NO. 112578/96


SUPREME COURT OF NEW YORK, NEW YORK COUNTY


172 Misc. 2d 327; 658 N.Y.S.2d 172; 1997 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 177



March 24, 1997, Decided


NOTICE:  [***1] EDITED FOR PUBLICATION


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioners, a union and its members, sought a judgment from the Supreme Court, New York County (New York), declaring that enforcement of New York City Charter § 1127 against individual petitioners was in violation of N.Y. Civ. Serv. Law § 70(2). Respondent city had transferred individual petitioners from employment with New York City Health and Hospitals Corporation to the Fire Department of the City of New York.


OVERVIEW: Respondent city had applied the New York City Charter § 1127 to certain previously exempt emergency medical service (EMS) personnel, who were transferred from the New York City Health and Hospitals Corporation to the Fire Department of the City of New York. Petitioners, the workers and the union representing them, contended that the city had acted arbitrarily and capriciously in applying the charter. The court granted the petition, and ruled that enforcement of § 1127 against the EMS petitioners and other similarly situated employees was in violation of N.Y. Civ. Serv. Law § 70(2). The determination to enforce New York City Charter § 1127 upon petitioners was made in violation of lawful procedure, and was affected by an error of law. N.Y. C.P.L R. 7803(3).


OUTCOME: The court granted the petition, and declared in a judgment that the transfer of individual petitioners was made in violation of lawful procedure, and was affected by an error of law, because the city had applied the city charter arbitrarily and capriciously.


HEADNOTES

Civil Service - Residence Requirement - Agreement of Nonresident Employees to Pay Nonresident Income Tax as a Condition Precedent to Employment

Respondent municipality's actions in applying New York City Charter § 1127, which requires prospective City employees to sign an agreement to pay the equivalent of a City resident's personal income tax should they reside outside of the City during their employment, to petitioners, Emergency Medical Services employees transferred from the New York City Health and Hospitals Corporation to the Fire Department of the City of New York who were exempt from section 1127 prior to the transfer, were arbitrary and capricious and in violation of Civil Service Law § 70 (2). Petitioners' previous exemption from New York City Charter § 1127 is a pecuniary benefit enjoyed for years by petitioners of which they should not be deprived merely because of an administrative transfer of functions. Civil Service Law § 70 (2) guarantees "full seniority credit for all purposes for service rendered prior to such transfer", which includes all financial benefits resulting from years of service, and exemption from New York City Charter § 1127 is one such benefit.

 

721 of 992 DOCUMENTS


Lichtenstein v. Emerson


INDEX NO. 106350/95


SUPREME COURT OF NEW YORK, NEW YORK COUNTY


171 Misc. 2d 933; 656 N.Y.S.2d 180; 1997 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 85



March 21, 1997, Decided



DISPOSITION:  [***1] The Clerk shall enter judgment dismissing the complaint without prejudice.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant moved to dismiss plaintiff's complaint alleging that plaintiff's attorney did not have an office for the transaction of law business within New York within the meaning N.Y. Jud. Law § 470.


OVERVIEW: Plaintiff's complaint showed that he was represented by a Washington D.C. law firm and a lawyer with a New York office. The court dismissed plaintiff's complaint without prejudice because plaintiff's attorney was not a resident of New York and because he did not have an office for the transaction of law business within New York as required by N.Y. Jud. Law § 470. The court held that § 470 was constitutional because there was a rational basis for requiring an attorney to have a local law office. The attorney's New York office was in the basement of a bar and restaurant which he partially owned. The office could only be reached through the kitchen of the restaurant. The attorney did not have a desk in the office, reported no New York income for the last five years, and listed a Washington address for his office address. Based on these facts, the court held that the attorney did not have an office for the transaction on law business in New York, and thus, plaintiff's complaint had to be dismissed.


OUTCOME: The court dismissed plaintiff's complaint without prejudice because plaintiff's attorney, who was not a resident of New York, did not have an office for the transaction of law business within New York.


HEADNOTES

Attorney and Client -- Unauthorized Practice of Law -- New York Office Required for Nonresident Attorney -- Constitutionality of Requirement

1. Judiciary Law § 470 should be interpreted to require all nonresidents, not just residents of adjoining States, who wish to appear as attorneys of record in the courts of New York State to maintain an office in this State, and as so interpreted it cannot be said that the requirement for a local office lacks a rational basis rendering it unconstitutional as valid reasons exist for requiring a local office for a nonresident, but not for a resident (who can employ a home as an office), such as not permitting a nonresident to avoid the expenses, including the payment of local taxes, associated with a New York location.

Attorney and Client -- Unauthorized Practice of Law -- New York Office Required for Nonresident Attorney -- What Constitutes Office

2. The New York office of a nonresident attorney that is located in the basement of a restaurant and bar in which the attorney has a proprietary interest, consists of a 10-foot by 12-foot room that can be reached only by going through the kitchen and down a flight of stairs, and contains three desks, none of which the nonresident attorney claims is his, and no law literature other than a copy of the Federal Rules of Civil Procedure, is not an "office for the transaction of law business" within the meaning of that term in section 470 of the Judiciary Law.

 

722 of 992 DOCUMENTS


Brotherton v. Department of Envtl. Conservation


INDEX NO. 12809-90


SUPREME COURT OF NEW YORK, SUFFOLK COUNTY


172 Misc. 2d 334; 657 N.Y.S.2d 854; 1997 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 180



February 24, 1997, Decided


NOTICE:   [***1]  EDITED FOR PUBLICATION



DISPOSITION: The petition is dismissed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner landowner sought review of the decision of respondent Department of Environmental Conservation of the State of New York (department), which denied the landowner a permit to build a 200-foot bulkhead. The landowner also challenged the decision, arguing that it lacked substantial evidence and constituted an unconstitutional taking of his property.


OVERVIEW: The landowner possessed separate parcels bounded by a canal and an ocean. A road separated the parcels and the deed to each parcel recited a boundary to the center of the road. The parcel abutting the canal was tidal wetlands with a mosquito ditch and wetlands vegetation. The parcel abutting the ocean contained two houses. After the landowner filed an application with the department seeking permission to replace a collapsed bulkhead and to dump 500 cubic yards of fill into the area behind the bulkhead, the department granted the petition, but denied the landowner's request to construct a 200-foot bulkhead. On appeal, the court dismissed the landowner's petition for review of the denial of the permit, holding that there was no competent evidence that the landowner was the sole owner of the property since 1958. The court held that the landowner, who was an experienced developer, took title to the property limited by wetlands regulations and, therefore, had no reasonable investment-backed expectations constituting protected property interests. Thus, the court held that the denial of the landowner's application did not work as an unconstitutional taking of his property interests.


OUTCOME: The court dismissed the landowner's petition requesting a permit from the department.


HEADNOTES

Constitutional Law - Taking of Property - Tidal Wetlands

Petitioner's CPLR article 78 proceeding challenging, as an unconstitutional taking of property, respondent's partial denial of his request to construct certain bulkheads and dump fill on a tract of property consisting almost entirely of tidal wetlands is denied as the property was encumbered by wetlands regulations at the time that petitioner, an experienced builder/developer, took title to the property, and he therefore could not have had any reasonable investment-backed expectations constituting protected property interests.

Constitutional Law - Taking of Property - Tidal Wetlands

Petitioner, the owner of two separate tracts of property bounded by a canal on the north, the Atlantic Ocean on the south, and separated by a road, has failed to demonstrate that the respondent's partial denial of his request to construct certain bulkheads and dump fill on the canal-side tract, which is almost entirely tidal wetlands, constitutes an unconstitutional taking of property. A property owner who challenges land regulation as an unconstitutional taking must demonstrate by "dollars and cents" evidence that under no permissible use would the parcel as a whole be capable of producing a reasonable return and must establish every element of his or her claim beyond a reasonable doubt. There is ample evidence in the record that the canal-side tract itself has recreational value, and the two separate tracts, treated as a whole given their unity of use and ownership since petitioner took title to the properties, together have a value of $ 1,100,000.

 

723 of 992 DOCUMENTS


Russo v. Waller


97-123


SUPREME COURT OF NEW YORK, NASSAU COUNTY


171 Misc. 2d 707; 655 N.Y.S.2d 313; 1997 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 54



February 11, 1997, Decided


NOTICE:  [***1] EDITED FOR PUBLICATION


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant lawyer moved for leave to amend his answer pursuant to N.Y. C.P.L.R. § 3025 to add an affirmative defense that the legal malpractice action against him was time barred because it was instituted more than three years after the acts or omissions that allegedly formed the basis for the complaint.


OVERVIEW: The action involved alleged legal malpractice and the complaint was filed about five years after the alleged malpractice. The lawyer argued that the malpractice action was time barred. The court analyzed the relevant statutes and held that N.Y. C.P.L.R. § 214-a controlled medical malpractice whereas N.Y. C.P.L.R. § 214(6) controlled nonmedical malpractice. The court held that § 214(6) repealed the judicial rule that had provided a six year statute of limitations for nonmedical malpractice and under § 214(6) the statute of limitations was three years. The court noted that § 214(6) did not explicitly state whether it applied to actions that occurred prior to the effective date. Although the court noted that it would have been unconstitutional for the legislation to shorten a statute of limitations so as to render an otherwise viable action time barred, the court held that the legislation did not shorten the limitations period but instead clarified the limitations period. The court held that the limitations period had always been three years under § 214(6).


OUTCOME: The court granted the lawyer leave to amend his answer to add an affirmative defense that the action was time barred. The court held that the leave should be granted because the defense was meritorious and would result in dismissal of his complaint. The court dismissed the complaint.


HEADNOTES

Statutes - Retroactive Application of Statute - Amendment Clarifying Statute of Limitations in Professional Nonmedical Malpractice Actions An amendment to CPLR 214 (6), effective September 5, 1996, which provides that the Statute of Limitations in actions based on professional nonmedical malpractice is three years, regardless of whether the underlying theory is based in contract or tort, applies retroactively to acts of nonmedical malpractice which occurred prior to the effective date; accordingly a legal malpractice action commenced in 1996 alleging malpractice occurring in May 1991 is dismissed as time barred. The general rule of construction favors prospective application of a statute unless a contrary intent is clearly divined. Here, the amendatory language was intended to clarify that the statute, as previously enacted, was intended to provide for a three-year period of limitations in all nonmedical malpractice actions.

 

724 of 992 DOCUMENTS


Knapp v. CONRAIL


97-094


SUPREME COURT OF NEW YORK, ALBANY COUNTY


171 Misc. 2d 597; 655 N.Y.S.2d 732; 1997 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 34



February 7, 1997, Decided


NOTICE:   [***1]  EDITED FOR PUBLICATION



DISPOSITION: Motion to dismiss third-party action in the case at bar is denied.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Third-party defendant carrier sought to have third-party plaintiff railroad's complaint dismissed based on the retroactive application of amendments to the Omnibus Workers' Compensation Reform Act of 1996 (act), N.Y. Law ch. 635 (1996).


OVERVIEW: The carrier filed a motion to dismiss the railroad's third-party complaint against it based on the reasoning that amendments to the act operated retroactively. The court denied the motion holding that the amendments relating to contribution by employers for nongrave injuries were prospective only as guided by N.Y. Cons. Laws ch. 5, §§ 51-66 for determining the retroactive or prospective-only operation of newly enacted statutes. The court found that the right to seek contribution for liability for accidents occurring prior to the effective date of the act was a substantive and vested right that could not have been divested by retroactive operation, and such divestment would have constituted an unconstitutional taking. The court's holding was based on rules of conflict of laws rather than public policy, substantiality or weight.


OUTCOME: The carrier's motion to dismiss the railroad's third-party complaint was denied because amendments relating to contribution by employers for nongrave injuries were prospective only.


HEADNOTES

Statutes - Retroactive Application of Statute - Omnibus Workers' Compensation Reform Act of 1996 The Omnibus Workers' Compensation Reform Act of 1996 (Act) (L 1996, ch 635), which forbids third-party actions against employers for contribution except in cases where the employee sustained a grave injury, is prospective only to accidents occurring subsequent to the effective date of the statute. Inasmuch as a third-party plaintiff possesses a vested right to its cause of action for contribution, due process restraints prevent retroactive elimination of that cause of action; while the quantum of contribution may be inchoate, the right to seek contribution itself is vested. A statute is presumed to operate prospectively, not retroactively, and generally will not be applied retroactively where it would deprive one of a substantial right, or affect antecedent rights. In addition, section 88 of the Act, which calls for an audit by the Superintendent of Insurance of all workers' compensation insurance carriers to determine the value as of December 31, 1996 of the "reserve adjustment" occasioned by the elimination of a particular category of third-party contribution actions by this Act, is not an expression of legislative intent that the Act be retroactive. Rather, it serves the useful purpose of providing a mechanism to transfer the "windfall" profits of a retroactive interpretation to the State's general fund in the event the courts, applying the rules of statutory construction, ultimately hold the new statute retroactive.

 

725 of 992 DOCUMENTS


In re Estate of Tisdale


97-136


SURROGATE'S COURT OF NEW YORK, NEW YORK COUNTY


171 Misc. 2d 716; 655 N.Y.S.2d 809; 1997 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 72



January 31, 1997, Decided
