NOTICE:  [***1] EDITED FOR PUBLICATION



DISPOSITION: The motion to strike the jury demand in the proceeding to set aside the revocable trust is denied.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: The distributees filed objections to the probate of their aunt's will and brought this proceeding to set aside the trust. The distributees demanded a jury trial on their objections concerning execution, capacity, undue influence, and fraud. The trustee filed a motion to strike the jury demand.


OVERVIEW: The distributees objected to a trust established by their deceased aunt. The distributees argued that the charitable beneficiaries of the trust reflected the intentions of the attorney who wrote the aunt's will and trust rather than the intentions of the aunt. The trustee, who was also the attorney, argued that the distributees were not entitled to a jury trial on their objections. The court concluded that: (1) the right to a jury trial depended upon the nature of the relief sought rather then on the forum or the label of the proceeding; (2) the nature of the relief requested in a proceeding to set aside a trust was the same as the nature of the relief requested in a proceeding to set aside a will; and (3) because the distributees were entitled to a jury trial in the will contest, they were likewise entitled to a jury trial in this proceeding, which sought similar relief based upon the revocable trust.


OUTCOME: The court denied the trustee's motion to strike the distributees' jury demand in this proceeding to set aside the revocable trust.


HEADNOTES

Trial - Right to Jury Trial - Proceeding to Set Aside Revocable Trust The distributees of decedent's will are entitled to a jury trial of their proceeding to set aside a revocable trust created at the same time as a pour-over will which incorporated by reference the terms of the trust, since a revocable trust actually functions as a will. In the context of decedent's estates, the right to jury trial exists by express statutory grant for probate proceedings (SCPA 502 [1]), and by constitutional guarantee for proceedings that closely resemble those for which constitutional guarantee is unquestioned. Judicial proceedings with respect to a revocable trust would occur only after the settlor's death at the instigation of the settlor's distributees, as in a will contest. The substantial similarity between these instruments mandates the conclusion that the nature of the relief requested in a proceeding to set aside a trust is the same as the nature of the relief requested in a proceeding to set aside a will. Also, indorsing a distinction between wills and revocable trusts for purposes of the right to a jury trial would create a host of unproductive incentives and practical difficulties, particularly where the will and the trust were executed simultaneously and have the same provisions albeit by incorporation. Additionally, the factual questions and the evidence in all likelihood will be almost identical with respect to both instruments, a situation which may effectively allow for only one factual determination. Finally, individuals preying on elderly or infirm people could subvert distributees' rights to a jury determination simply by utilizing a revocable trust rather than a will as a vehicle for their misdeeds.

 

726 of 992 DOCUMENTS


Doe v. Division of Probation & Correction Alternatives


97-049


SUPREME COURT OF NEW YORK, DUTCHESS COUNTY


171 Misc. 2d 210; 654 N.Y.S.2d 268; 1997 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 7



January 21, 1997, Decided


NOTICE:   [***1]  EDITED FOR PUBLICATION



DISPOSITION: The petition is denied and the proceeding is dismissed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner convict filed a petition pursuant to N.Y. C.P.L.R. art. 78, seeking an annulment of the determination of respondent N.Y. Division of Probation and Correction Alternatives (DPCA) that designated the convict a sexually violent predator.


OVERVIEW: Pursuant to the Sex Offender Registration Act (act), N.Y. Correct. Law § 168 et seq., the DPCA determined that the convict, who had pled guilty to sexual abuse in the first degree, should be designated a sexually violent predator. The convict appealed to the DPCA, which denied his petition. The court also denied the convict's petition. The court declined to address the convict's constitutional challenges to the public notification provisions of the act because the convict's challenges were not ripe for review. The application of the registration requirements of the act to the convict did not violate the Ex Post Facto clause of the federal constitution. The act did not violate the convict's due process rights because he was notified of his classification, an administrative review process existed, and the convict was able to bring a petition for relief in the sentencing court. The act did not deprive the convict of the equal protection of the laws because there was a rational basis for the statutory requirement that the convict be classified by the DPCA. The DPCA's determination to classify the convict as a sexually violent predator was not arbitrary or capricious.


OUTCOME: The court denied the convict's petition for an annulment of the DPCA's determination that he was a sexually violent predator. The court dismissed the proceeding.


HEADNOTES

Constitutional Law - Ex Post Facto Law - Sex Offender Registration Act The Sex Offender Registration Act (Correction Law § 168 ) does not violate the Ex Post Facto Clause (US Const, art I, § 10), to the extent that it provides that sex offenders, like petitioner, who are on parole or probation for a designated offense on the effective date of the statute, are subject to the registration provisions of the Act, since the legislative aim of the statute is not to punish for past activity and the restriction is relevant to the regulation of a present situation. The purpose of the Act is to promote public safety rather than punish sex offenders. The statute's design is remedial rather than punitive and it does not impose a substantial affirmative disability or restraint upon the registrant.

Constitutional Law - Due Process of Law - Sex Offender Registration Act Applied to Probationer Petitioner, a convicted sex offender on probation, was not denied due process of law where he was designated a risk level 3, or sexually violent predator, pursuant to the Sex Offender Registration Act (Correction Law § 168 ), since he was afforded sufficient procedural protection to meet the minimum requirements of due process. The primary concern of due process evaluation in any final proceeding is notice reasonably calculated, under all the circumstances, to apprise interested parties of the pendency of the action and afford them an opportunity to present their objections. Here, petitioner was notified of his classification and of the reasons for the classification. The Division of Probation and Correction Alternatives has established an administrative review process and petitioner may seek judicial review of the administrative decision through a CPLR article 78 proceeding. Also, petitioner may bring a petition for relief in the sentencing court, as provided in Correction Law § 168-o. 

Constitutional Law - Equal Protection of Laws - Sex Offender Registration Act Applied to Probationer Petitioner, a convicted sex offender on probation, was not denied equal protection of the laws because he was designated a risk level 3 pursuant to the Sex Offender Registration Act (Correction Law § 168 ) by the Division of Probation and Correction Alternatives (DPCA), rather than a court, which classifies sex offenders who were incarcerated or institutionalized at the time the Act was enacted. The Equal Protection Clause (US Const 14th Amend) requires that all persons similarly situated be treated in the same manner, but a State may treat differently situated people in a different way. There is a rational basis for the statutory requirement that an individual, such as petitioner, who is already under DPCA supervision, be classified by that agency, since that agency is already familiar with him, his background and history and his behavior while on probation.

Crimes - Sex Offenders - Sex Offender Registration Act - Risk Assessment Instrument A determination of the Division of Probation and Correction Alternatives (DPCA) classifying petitioner probationer as a level 3, sexually violent predator is not arbitrary or capricious because the DPCA assigned points pursuant to a risk assessment instrument prepared by the Board of Examiners of Sex Offenders for petitioner's relationship with a victim and history of alcohol abuse. Petitioner met one of the child victims when the victim participated in a residential camp at which petitioner was employed and the second child victim was a cousin of the first victim and, therefore, the assessment of points in the "relationship with victim" category is neither arbitrary nor capricious and is supported by substantial evidence. In addition, pursuant to the risk assessment guidelines, an offender does not have to be abusing alcohol or drugs at the time of the offense to receive points in this category, and petitioner has not demonstrated that the Board's inclusion of history of drug or alcohol abuse as a factor is arbitrary and capricious.

 

727 of 992 DOCUMENTS


Ganley v. Giuliani


97-104


SUPREME COURT OF NEW YORK, NEW YORK COUNTY


171 Misc. 2d 654; 655 N.Y.S.2d 264; 1997 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 50



January 13, 1997, Decided


NOTICE:  [***1] EDITED FOR PUBLICATION



DISPOSITION: The petition is dismissed. The plaintiffs' motion in Lieutenants' Benevolent Assoc. is denied and the cross-motion for summary judgment is granted.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner civil servants filed a N.Y. C.P.L.R. art. 78 proceeding seeking a declaration that New York City, N.Y., Charter § 1127 was unconstitutional as applied to the civil servants.


OVERVIEW: Civil servants, former members of housing and transit police who did not live in the city, filed a N.Y. C.P.L.R. art. 78 proceeding seeking a declaration that New York City, N.Y., Charter § 1127 was unconstitutional as applied to the civil servants. Civil servants were merged into the New York City Police Department. Under the merger, § 1127 required that all employees who did not reside in the city of New York pay the city an amount equivalent to what would have been paid in income tax if such person lived within the city limits. The court determined that the city's determination that the civil servants were subject to § 1127 was neither arbitrary nor capricious, and the determination was consistent with the legislative intent in enacting § 1127. The provision was intended to prevent the unfairness of a two-tiered agency in which the employment condition would have been applicable to some nonresident New York City Police Department employees but not to others. The court held that the civil servants were not exempt from the city's nonresident employment condition contained in § 1127.


OUTCOME: The court dismissed the civil servants' petition for a declaration that a provision of the city charter was unconstitutional.


HEADNOTES

Civil Service - Police - Application of Nonresident Employment Tax to Transit and Housing Authority Police Officers Transferred to Municipal Police Force Respondent municipality lawfully applied New York City Charter § 1127, which provides that every person seeking employment with the City must sign an agreement, as a condition precedent to City employment, that if such person resides, or changes residence to, outside of the City during the employment period, such person will pay a nonresident City tax, to petitioner former members of the Transit Authority and Housing Authority Police Departments who, upon being merged with the New York City Police Department (Civil Service Law § 70 [2]), became City employees and therefore subject to the employment condition. The employment condition ensures equality between the take-home pay of City employees who reside within the five boroughs and those who live outside the City limits. While the statutory phrase "every person seeking employment" may be ambiguous as applied to the transferred employees, the statute is being applied in a reasonable way. In addition, Civil Service Law § 70 (2), which governed the mergers, does not prohibit the employment condition. As involuntary transferees, petitioners are afforded greater rights than voluntary transferees, but the protection does not extend to the nonresidency payment at issue.

Civil Service - Police - Merger of Housing and Transit Authority Police Forces with Municipal Police Force - Effect on Nonresident Employment Tax Civil Service Law § 70 (2), which authorized a merger of the Housing and Transit Authority Police Forces with the New York City Police Department, does not conflict with New York City Charter § 1127, which provides that every person seeking employment with the City must sign an agreement, as a condition precedent to City employment, that if such person resides, or changes residence to, outside of the City during the employment period, such person will pay a nonresident City tax; accordingly, the condition precedent may be applied to petitioner former members of the Housing and Transit Authority Police Forces. Civil Service Law § 70 (2) does not address terms and conditions of employment and, thus, the merger did not impair petitioners' civil service status, pension, retirement, or seniority benefits. In addition, the employment condition is not a further examination, a qualification, or a change in civil service classification and status as those terms are used in the context of the Civil Service Law. Assuming, arguendo, that the condition precedent does adversely affect a "right" or "privilege", such fact does not violate Civil Service Law § 70 (2), which specifically refers to examination, qualification, classification and status without any reference to "rights" and "privileges". Moreover, the Transit and Housing memoranda of understanding, which implemented the merger resolution, do not provide a greater right than that contained in Civil Service Law § 70 (2).

Civil Service - Police - Merger of Housing and Transit Authority Police Forces with Municipal Police Force - Effect on Nonresident Employment Tax Petitioners, former members of the Transit and Housing Authority Police Forces, which merged with the New York City Police Department, are subject to New York City Charter § 1127, which provides that every person seeking employment with the City must sign an agreement, as a condition precedent to City employment, that if such person resides, or changes residence to, outside of the City during the employment period, such person will pay a nonresident City tax, even though they did not sign a condition of employment agreement, and respondents did not follow the literal language of the statute. A literal application will produce a result at odds with the Legislature's intention to apply the statute to all City employees. In addition, petitioners received notice of the application of section 1127, and are not individual job applicants but members of a large group that have accepted the employment condition by accepting City employment with knowledge of the condition. Their new employment with the New York City Police Department did not adversely affect status, classification, or require further examination or qualification. Also, based on this unusual merger, the City's determination to notify petitioners of the condition and to advise petitioners that their acceptance of City employment constitutes their agreement pursuant to section 1127, in place of the signed agreement, was not arbitrary or capricious. The City did not exercise its sovereign authority to impose a tax on petitioners without consent; instead it obtained this payment based upon the employee's voluntary acceptance of City employment.

 

728 of 992 DOCUMENTS


People v. J.G.


97-045


SUPREME COURT OF NEW YORK, RICHMOND COUNTY


171 Misc. 2d 440; 655 N.Y.S.2d 783; 1996 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 538



December 30, 1996, Decided


NOTICE:   [***1]  EDITED FOR PUBLICATION


SUBSEQUENT HISTORY: As Corrected March 24, 1997.



DISPOSITION: The defendant's motion is denied.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant challenged an order that, upon his Alford-Serrano guilty plea to third-degree rape, granted the state's motion and thereby assessed 10 points against him for not accepting responsibility, for purposes of classifying him under the Sex Offender Registration Act (Act), N.Y. Correct. Law § 168 et seq., and ordered him to submit to a test for human immunodeficiency virus (HIV), under N.Y. Crim. Proc. Law § 390.15.


OVERVIEW: Defendant entered an Alford-Serrano guilty plea to a charge of third-degree rape of his minor daughter. For purposes of classifying him under the Sex Offender Registration Act, N.Y. Correct. Law § 168 et seq., the sentencing court assessed 10 points against him for not accepting responsibility for the crime, under N.Y. Crim. Proc. Law § 168-l, and granted the state's motion, under N.Y. Crim. Proc. Law § 390.15, to compel him to submit to an HIV test that the victim requested. On appeal, the court rejected defendant's claim that the trial court erred by assessing the ten points against him. The court ruled that defendant did not accept responsibility for the crime and he could not maintain innocence and thereby circumvent the collateral consequences of his plea. The court then ruled that the state's interests in alleviating the victim's trauma and curtailing the spread of AIDS outweighed any privacy interest held by defendant and thus the HIV test was not an unreasonable search and seizure. The court also ruled that § 390.15 did not violate the Ex Post Facto clause because the statute was not punitive in nature.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the order. Defendant was properly classified under the Sex Offender Registration Act and was properly assessed the statutory points for not accepting responsibility for the crime. The court-ordered HIV test was not an unreasonable search and seizure and the statute under which it was ordered did not violate the Ex Post Facto clause of the federal constitution.


HEADNOTES

Crimes - Sex Offenders - Sex Offender Registration Act - Application to Defendant Who Enters into Alford-Serrano Guilty Plea Defendant who negotiated an Alford-Serrano plea to rape in the third degree, whereby he maintained his innocence but acknowledged that the prosecutor may be able to obtain a conviction, is subject to the collateral consequences of that conviction, including classification under the Sex Offender Registration Act (SORA; Correction Law § 168 et seq.); accordingly, pursuant to the SORA Risk Assessment Instrument, which determines the presumptive risk level of a sex offender by assigning a point value to various factors, including those factors contained in Correction Law § 168-l, the court may assess the defendant with 10 points for not accepting responsibility for the offense. The defendant cannot protest his innocence while pleading guilty by way of an Alford-Serrano plea and then claim that no consequences or conditions subsequent to the plea should apply to him. Therefore, lack of taking responsibility for his actions is a factor rightfully considered in assessing points against a defendant on the SORA worksheet for classification as a sex offender.

Crimes - Unlawful Search and Seizure - Mandatory HIV Testing of Sex Offender Defendant, who negotiated an Alford-Serrano plea to rape in the third degree, will not be subjected to an unreasonable search and seizure (US Const 4th Amend; NY Const, art I, § 12), where the People requested that he submit to an HIV test pursuant to CPL 390.15 (1) (a), which authorizes testing of a defendant convicted of a felony offense enumerated in Penal Law article 130 and where sexual intercourse or deviate sexual intercourse was an element of the crime for which the person was convicted, since the government's interests in informing the victim, lessening the victim's trauma, stopping the spread of HIV and securing Federal antidrug funding outweigh defendant's right to privacy. HIV testing under CPL 390.15 presents a special need which warrants balancing the government's interest against that of the defendant. Here, the order granting the test and all related papers will be sealed and the test results will only be given to the person making the application who may only redisclose the information to certain individuals (CPL 390.15 [3], [6] [a] [ii]). Civil penalties and criminal sanctions may be imposed against the person who wrongfully discloses such information (Public Health Law § 2783 [1], [2]). The procedure is not brutal, offensive or shocking to the conscience.

Crimes - Sex Offenders - Mandatory HIV Testing - Ex Post Facto Clause The Ex Post Facto Clause (US Const, art I, § 10) will not be violated if defendant, who negotiated an Alford-Serrano plea to rape in the third degree, is required to submit to an HIV test pursuant to CPL 390.15 (1) (a), which authorizes testing a defendant convicted of a felony offense enumerated in Penal Law article 130 and where sexual intercourse or deviate sexual intercourse was an element of the crime for which the person was convicted. The Ex Post Facto Clause only applies to penal statutes which disadvantage the offender affected by them. Even where procedural changes disadvantage the accused the clause is not violated. Here, the blood test is not punishment since such tests have become routine in our lives and the procedure involves no risk, trauma, or pain. The statute is intended to ease the trauma of the victim of a sex crime with respect to the HIV related disease, not to punish.

Crimes - Sex Offenders - Mandatory HIV Testing - Request by People on Behalf of Victim The People's request that defendant, who negotiated an Alford-Serrano plea to rape in the third degree, whereby he maintained his innocence but acknowledged that the prosecutor may be able to obtain a conviction, submit to an HIV test pursuant to CPL 390.15 (1) (a), which authorizes testing of a defendant convicted of a felony offense enumerated in Penal Law article 130 and where sexual intercourse or deviate sexual intercourse was an element of the crime for which the person was convicted, is treated as a request made on behalf of the victim, defendant's daughter who was 15 at the time of the crime and of limited intelligence. A victim is one with whom a defendant engaged in the act of sexual intercourse or deviate sexual intercourse (CPL 390.15 [1] [b]). A representative of the victim may request the test if the victim is an infant or incompetent person (CPL 390.15 [4]). Even though defendant never admitted his guilt, the daughter is still a victim.

 

729 of 992 DOCUMENTS


Syracuse Hous. Auth. v. Boule


Index No. 96/02160LT


CITY COURT OF NEW YORK, SYRACUSE


172 Misc. 2d 254; 658 N.Y.S.2d 776; 1996 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 578



December 23, 1996, Decided


NOTICE:  [***1] EDITED FOR PUBLICATION



DISPOSITION: Dismissed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner landlord, a public housing authority, brought a holdover proceeding to recover possession of premises leased to respondent tenant. The landlord contended that the tenant violated the terms of her lease by permitting a guest to engage in drug-related activity on the property. The tenant adamantly opposed the petition.


OVERVIEW: In pertinent part, the parties' lease provided that the tenant shall cause her guests to refrain from engaging in drug-related criminal activity on or near the apartment. When her usual babysitter became unexpectedly unavailable, the tenant asked the child's father to care for the child that day. The tenant did not want to jeopardize her job by failing to go to work for lack of child care. While the tenant was still at work, the child's father and two of his friends were arrested for possessing and selling illicit drugs out of tenant's apartment. Pursuant to 42 U.S.C.S. § 1437d (l)(5), the landlord sought to terminate the lease. When the tenant refused to leave, the landlord filed the instant petition. The court dismissed, holding that good cause for termination of the lease and eviction did not exist because the tenant was not personally at fault for the drug-related criminal activity of the "guests." Finding that a literal reading of § 1437d (l)(5) was clearly contrary to congressional intent, the court reasoned that the statute did not impose strict liability upon tenants for all criminal activity irrespective of their knowledge of or ability to control the acts.


OUTCOME: The court dismissed the landlord's petition seeking to recover possession of premises leased to the tenant.


HEADNOTES

Public Housing - Eviction of Nondesirable Tenant - Illegal Sale of Drugs by Guest

A public housing authority lacked good cause to evict respondent on the ground that she violated the terms of her lease by permitting a guest to engage in drug-related activity on the property where unbeknownst to respondent and while she was at work the father of her child and two of his friends were arrested for possessing and selling illicit drugs out of the apartment, since good cause for termination of the lease and eviction does not exist where a public housing tenant is not personally at fault for the drug-related criminal activity of a guest. The lease provides that the tenant must cause her guests to refrain from engaging in criminal activity and, although not expressly set forth in the lease, a violation of this provision is cause for termination and eviction. In addition, a literal reading of 42 USC § 1437d (l) (5) provides for termination of the tenancy where a guest of a tenant has engaged in drug-related criminal activity on or near the premises regardless of fault. However, courts are not bound to blindly construe statutes or regulations in a manner contrary to legislative intent with unreasonable, absurd or unexpected results, and a literal reading of the statute here is clearly contrary to congressional intent. Public housing authorities should use discretion, consider the circumstances of the matter on a case-by-case basis and make a humane disposition of the case. Here, respondent did not know the father had invited the other two persons upon the premises; none of the persons arrested reside at the apartment; respondent was unaware of the presence or sale of the drugs on the premises; respondent was not involved and was not criminally charged; respondent believed that the father did not have a criminal record; and neither neighbors nor the housing authority notified respondent of the criminal activity during its occurrence.

 

730 of 992 DOCUMENTS


People v. Toback


97-010


CITY COURT OF NEW YORK, LONG BEACH


170 Misc. 2d 1011; 652 N.Y.S.2d 946; 1996 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 501



December 17, 1996, Decided


NOTICE:   [***1]  EDITED FOR PUBLICATION



DISPOSITION: Defendant's motion to dismiss is denied in all respects.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant was charged with 16 violations of Long Beach. N.Y., Code of Ordinances ch. 16. Defendant filed a motion to dismiss the complaints pursuant to N.Y. Crim. Proc. Law §§ 170.30(1)(a), 170.35(1)(c), upon the grounds that the statute was unconstitutional on its face and in its application. Defendant also filed a motion for dismissal, pursuant to N.Y. Crim. Proc. Law § 170.40, in the interests of justice.


OVERVIEW: Defendant was charged with 16 violations of ch. 16. Defendant brought motions to dismiss the charges on the grounds of unconstitutionality and in the interest of justice. The court denied the motions. The court held that the ordinance did not impermissibly burden defendant's free speech rights. The ordinance placed a valid time, place and manner restriction on the decibel level of noise in the city without regard to the content of the speech. Alternative channels existed for defendant to transmit his message. The ordinance permitted expressive activity so long as the decibel level was not over 65. In sum, the ordinance was not vague or overbroad, and it complied with the First Amendment.


OUTCOME: Defendant's motion to dismiss the complaints against him for violations of the city noise ordinance was denied.


HEADNOTES

Constitutional Law - Validity of Statute - City Ordinance Prohibiting Sound Greater than 65 Decibels - Restrictions on Free Speech in Public Forum A city noise code which prohibits, inter alia, the use of amplified sound at a level greater than 65 decibels is not unconstitutional as a restriction on First Amendment protected speech in a public forum since it is content neutral, narrowly tailored and leaves open alternative channels of communication. A decibel meter, by definition, is content neutral. By codifying and articulating specific decibel levels and the locations from where to take these measurements, the code prevents arbitrary or discriminatory enforcement. The exception for municipally sponsored events held in an otherwise problematic location and at a higher volume is not content based. The narrow tailoring requirement is satisfied in that the city seeks to eliminate the intrusiveness of loud noise, not the message. The regulation of sound and noise in public areas is an important function of city government. Furthermore, the Legislature's determination that 65 decibels is a valid and reasonable level that welcomes free speech, without interfering with the rights of others, is a valid exercise of its legislative responsibility.

Constitutional Law - Validity of Statute - City Ordinance Prohibiting Sound Greater than 65 Decibels - Vagueness A city noise code which prohibits, inter alia, the use of amplified sound at a level greater than 65 decibels is not unconstitutional as vague, since the decibel level limitation is clear and precise and the code details the specific permissible volume of sound that may be generated by amplifying equipment at very specific geographic points and at designated hours.

Constitutional Law - Validity of Statute - City Ordinance Prohibiting Sound Greater than 65 Decibels - Overbreadth A city noise code which prohibits, inter alia, the use of amplified sound at a level greater than 65 decibels is not unconstitutional for overbreadth since a statute is not deemed facially invalid unless its deterrent effect on legitimate expression is both real and substantial and the deterrent effect of the code is neither real nor substantial; the purpose of the code is the regulation of noise, not suppression of protected speech.

Constitutional Law - Validity of Statute - City Ordinance Prohibiting Sound Greater than 65 Decibels - Equal Protection of Laws A city noise code which prohibits, inter alia, the use of amplified sound at a level greater than 65 decibels and exempts government sponsored events from the decibel ceiling does not deprive a person of equal protection under the law, since the code is not based on the actual content of the music or message. All speakers are permitted to speak in the designated areas, as long as they maintain a volume of 65 decibels or less in accordance with the statute.

 

731 of 992 DOCUMENTS


Leepson v. Holland


97-020


SUPREME COURT OF NEW YORK, NEW YORK COUNTY


171 Misc. 2d 84; 653 N.Y.S.2d 841; 1996 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 513



December 12, 1996, Decided


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner tenants brought an action for declaratory relief against respondent, Commissioner of the State of New York, Division of Housing and Community Renewal--Office of Rent Administration (DHCR), to declare the Rent Regulation Reform Act of 1993 (Reform Act), 1993 N.Y. Laws 253, unconstitutional. DHCR filed a cross-motion to dismiss the petition and for a judgment to declare the Reform Act constitutional.


OVERVIEW: The Reform Act amended the New York Rent Stabilization Law, New York City, N.Y., Admin. Code § 26-501 et seq. Respondent intervenor landlord filed a petition with DHCR to deregulate the rent controls on the tenants' apartment pursuant to the Reform Act. DHCR granted the landlord's petition on the ground that the tenants failed to submit income verification information and denied the tenants' petition for an administrative review. The tenants argued that New York City, N.Y., Admin. Code § 26-504.3(a), violated the Equal Protection Clause by using federal adjusted gross income, rather than realized actual income, as the measure of income to define and classify high income households. The court held that the Reform Act did not violate the Equal Protection Clause because the tenants failed in their burden to establish that the classification constituted invidious discrimination or was palpably arbitrary and that the Reform Act lacked a rational basis. The court found that the legislature's use of federal adjusted gross income as the measure to eliminate rent regulation protection for high income tenants was rationally related to the legislative scheme underlying rent regulation.


OUTCOME: The court denied the tenants' petition to declare the Reform Act unconstitutional and granted the DHCR cross-motion to dismiss the tenants' petition and declared that the Reform Act was constitutional.


HEADNOTES

Constitutional Law - Equal Protection of Laws - Rent Regulation Reform Act The Rent Regulation Reform Act of 1993 (L 1993, ch 253), which provides for the decontrol of "high rent" apartments occupied by "high income" households, and defines "high income" as the total sum of the Federal adjusted gross income of the apartment's tenants (Administrative Code of City of NY § 26-504.3 [a]), rather than the realized actual income, does not violate the Equal Protection Clause by exempting those households whose actual income meets the high income threshold but whose Federal adjusted gross income does not, since the Legislature's decision to adopt adjusted gross income as the measure in defining "high income" was not arbitrary or capricious. The Equal Protection Clause does not bar the Legislature from creating classifications which result in some inequality as long as there exists some reasonable basis. In acting to eliminate rent regulation protection for high income tenants, the Legislature's adoption of the definition of income as adjusted gross income, as set forth in the taxing statute, is reasonably related to the legislative scheme underlying rent regulation as well as the intent of the Reform Act.

 

732 of 992 DOCUMENTS


People v. Griffin


96-592


SUPREME COURT OF NEW YORK, NEW YORK COUNTY


171 Misc. 2d 145; 652 N.Y.S.2d 922; 1996 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 488



December 5, 1996, Decided


NOTICE:   [***1]  EDITED FOR PUBLICATION


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant filed a motion in opposition to his certification as a sex offender under the provisions of the Sex Offender Registration Act (SORA), N.Y. Correct. Law § 168 et seq.


OVERVIEW: Defendant was convicted of one count of sodomy in the first degree in violation of N.Y. Penal law § 130.50(2) and one count of falsifying business records in the first degree in violation of N.Y. Penal Law § 175.10. After the issuance of a stay of execution of the sentence by the appellate court, the issue of the parties inadvertent failure, upon conviction of the sodomy charge, to have certified the defendant as a sex offender under provisions of SORA was raised. On review, the court held that (1) certification of defendant as a sex offender would have involved scrutinizing the conviction and confirming that it related to a statutory "sex offense", and then declaring that fact for the record; (2) a simple statement that the defendant had been certified to be a sex offender was sufficient to alert the correctional authorities as to defendant's status; (3) the defendant was neither nearing release from confinement nor commencing service of a nonincarceratory sentence and had no imminent duty to register under SORA nor was there an obligation to advise him of such duty; (4) certification was regulatory, not punitive in nature and did not violate ex post facto laws.


OUTCOME: The court certified the defendant as a sex offender under the SORA.


HEADNOTES

Crimes - Sex Offenders - Certification under Sex Offender Registration Act Notwithstanding Stay of Execution of Sentence Pending Appeal Where an appellate court stayed execution of a judgment and sentence pending an appeal by defendant, a convicted sex offender (CPL 460.50 [1]), the trial court is not precluded from complying with the requirements of the Sex Offender Registration Act (Correction Law § 168-d [1]) that a court certify the defendant as a sex offender upon conviction, which the trial court initially failed to do, since, to the extent that the certification procedure does not involve the sentence, certification is not covered by the stay. A judgment comprises a conviction and sentence, and is completed by imposition and execution of the sentence. A stay of the execution of judgment does not address the conviction, i.e., the adjudication of guilt, inasmuch as that aspect of the judgment is complete when the jury renders its verdict or upon entry of a guilty plea. Accordingly, the only portion of the judgment unconsummated at the time of the CPL 460.50 (1) stay is the sentence and the sole function of the stay is to prevent its execution until the appeal can be resolved.

Crimes - Sex Offenders - Certification under Sex Offender Registration Act Notwithstanding Stay of Execution of Sentence Pending Appeal A trial court may certify defendant, a convicted sex offender, pursuant to the Sex Offender Registration Act (SORA) (Correction Law § 168-d [1]) despite a stay of execution of the judgment and sentence pending appeal (see, CPL 460.50) granted by an appellate court, where the trial court initially failed to certify the defendant upon conviction, since a court has the inherent power to correct its own records where, as here, the court failed to certify defendant as a sex offender as mandated by SORA. The court must correct the obvious error in the record. Amendments to correct defects in sentencing orders are permitted notwithstanding the statutory prohibition against modification of sentences (see, CPL 430.10).

Crimes - Sex Offenders - Sex Offender Registration Act - Ex Post Facto Prohibition A claim by defendant, a convicted sex offender, that application to him of the certification requirements of the Sex Offender Registration Act (SORA) (Correction Law § 168-d [1]) violates the Ex Post Facto Clause (US Const, art I, § 10, cl [1]) because the criminal conduct occurred before the effective date of the statute must fail, where he offered a vague, general declaration that SORA violates the prohibition, and failed to address with specificity the manner in which the certification requirements contravene the Ex Post Facto Clause, either facially or as applied to him.

Crimes - Sex Offenders - Sex Offender Registration Act - Ex Post Facto Prohibition Application of the certification requirements of the Sex Offender Registration Act (SORA) (Correction Law § 168-d [1]) to defendant, a convicted sex offender whose criminal conduct occurred before the effective date of the statute, does not violate the Ex Post Facto Clause (US Const, art I, § 10, cl [1]), since the certification process is regulatory and not punitive. The certification ensures that information is conveyed to the criminal justice system in furtherance of its own internal procedures. The certification imposes no affirmative disability or restriction upon defendant; it is accomplished without consideration of defendant's scienter in committing the crime and without reference to the offender's particular status under SORA. Also, certification exacts no retribution and does not promote deterrence.

Crimes - Sex Offenders - Certification under Sex Offender Registration Act A trial court may certify defendant convicted sex offender under the Sex Offender Registration Act (SORA) (Correction Law § 168-d [1]), notwithstanding that a Federal court enjoined application of the public notification provisions of SORA (see, Doe v Pataki, 940 F Supp 603), since the certification provisions were not enjoined by the Federal court (see, Correction Law § 168-v [separability clause]) and, to the extent that that order might be binding on the trial court, it is inapposite.

 

733 of 992 DOCUMENTS


Herzog v. Board of Educ.


96-563


SUPREME COURT OF NEW YORK, NASSAU COUNTY


171 Misc. 2d 22; 652 N.Y.S.2d 473; 1996 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 465



November 21, 1996, Decided


NOTICE:  [***1] EDITED FOR PUBLICATION



DISPOSITION: The action for a declaratory judgment is dismissed. The petitioner's application is granted.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner school teacher brought an action seeking judgment on her application to the New York State Teachers' Retirement System. Respondent school board filed a declaratory judgment action/motion to dismiss on the petition.


OVERVIEW: A teacher brought an action to compel a school district to grant her membership in the New York State Teachers' Retirement System retroactive to the 1967-1968 school year. The school district filed a motion to dismiss the petition. The court found that the school district lacked capacity to challenge N.Y. Retire. & Soc. Sec. § 803 on the ground that the statute violates the school district's rights under the Due Process and Equal Protection Clauses of the N.Y. Const. The court also held that the school district did have the capacity to challenge the statute on the ground that their compliance with the statute would have required that they violate the N.Y. Const.'s proscription prohibiting a school district from making a gift.The court then held that the statute did not violate the constitutional prohibition against gifts set forth in N.Y. Const. art. VIII, § 1.


OUTCOME: The court granted the teacher's application and dismissed the school district's declaratory judgment action.


HEADNOTES

Parties - Standing - Challenge to State Legislation by School Board and Superintendent - Violation of Due Process and Equal Protection Clauses Respondents Board of Education and superintendent lack standing to seek a judgment declaring that Retirement and Social Security Law § 803, which governs retroactive membership in a public retirement system, violates their rights under the Due Process and Equal Protection Clauses of the State Constitution, since a school district, as a subdivision of the State, lacks the capacity to bring suit to invalidate State legislation except pursuant to an express statutory authorization, where the State legislation adversely affects a municipality's proprietary interest in a specific fund of moneys, where the State statute impinges upon home rule powers, or where compliance with the State statute will violate a constitutional proscription.

Parties - Standing - Challenge to State Legislation by School Board and Superintendent - Violation of Constitutional Proscription Respondents Board of Education and superintendent have standing to seek a judgment declaring Retirement and Social Security Law § 803, which governs retroactive membership in a public retirement system, unconstitutional on the ground that their compliance would require that they violate the New York Constitution's proscription prohibiting a school district from making a gift.

Constitutional Law - Gift of Public Funds - Validity of Statute Affording Retroactive Pension Benefits Retirement and Social Security Law § 803, which remedially affords retroactive pension benefits to persons who were eligible to enroll in the pension system during the term of their employment, but did not enroll because they did not have notice of their eligibility, does not violate the constitutional prohibition against gifts (see, NY Const, article VIII, § 1). The statute does not provide for the payment of pension benefits to persons who were not eligible for said benefits during the period of their employment. In addition, New York Constitution, article VII, § 8, cl (2) provides that the constitutional prohibition against gifts does not prevent the Legislature from providing for the increase in the amount of pension of any member of a retirement system of the State, or a subdivision of the State. Pursuant to this authority, the State Legislature has periodically enacted legislation granting increased pension benefits not related to increased services or corresponding benefit to be derived by the employer.

 

734 of 992 DOCUMENTS


West Village Comm. v. Zagata


97-050


SUPREME COURT OF NEW YORK, ALBANY COUNTY


171 Misc. 2d 454; 654 N.Y.S.2d 230; 1996 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 540



November 7, 1996, Decided


NOTICE:   [***1]  EDITED FOR PUBLICATION



DISPOSITION: The first, and portions of the tenth and twelfth causes of action are granted to the extent indicated herein. The remaining causes of action are dismissed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioners, a public interest group and others, commenced a N.Y. C.P.L.R. 78 proceeding challenging respondent's, Commissioner of the New York State Department of Environmental Conservation (DEC's), promulgation of amendments to N.Y. Comp. Codes R. & Regs. tit. 6, § 617 which effectuated the State Environmental Quality Review Act (SEQRA).


OVERVIEW: A public interest group and others challenged the promulgation of amendments which effectuated the SEQRA on the grounds that the regulations were contrary to the Environmental Conservation Law, lacked a rational basis, were ultra vires, that their promulgation violated the State Administrative Procedure Act, and that the generic environmental impact statement did not comply with SEQRA and former § 617 regulations in effect at the time of promulgation. The court held: 1) N.Y. Comp. Codes R. & Regs. tit. 6, § 617.5(c)(37), which exempted all actions of the governor from SEQRA review was contrary to law and ultra vires; 2) DEC's failure to include an item in the draft environmental impact statement was not fatal; 3) the scoping regulations were in compliance with the Environmental Conservation Law; 4) did not engage in segmented environmental review by removing items contained in the proposed regulations; 5) the DEC's review failed to take a hard look, failed to consider possible significant adverse environmental impacts, and failed to contain findings supported by a rational basis with respect to some of the additions to the Type II list; and 6) attorney fees were not warranted.


OUTCOME: The court entered judgment, in part, in favor of the public interest group and others and dismissed the remaining causes of action.


HEADNOTES

Constitutional Law - Validity of Regulation - Excluding Governor's Actions from SEQRA Review 6 NYCRR 617.5 (c) (37) is unconstitutional as contrary to law and ultra vires in that it designates all actions of the Governor as "Type II" actions thereby excluding them from review pursuant to the State Environmental Quality Review Act (SEQRA; ECL art 8). Pursuant to ECL 8-0105 (1) a State agency includes any State Department, and pursuant to Executive Law § 30 the Governor is the head of the Executive Department; neither SEQRA nor the former regulations contains an exception for this department. Thus, by the terms of the statute, SEQRA review is applicable to certain actions of the Governor. Also, the Governor's compliance with SEQRA does not violate the separation of powers doctrine. While certain constitutional powers of the Governor may not be controlled by the Legislature, the Constitution provides the Legislature with the authority to control the Executive offices (NY Const, art V, § 3).

Environmental Conservation - Environmental Quality Review - Project Sponsor's Discretion to Submit Information in Draft Environmental Impact Statement Pursuant to SEQRA 6 NYCRR 617.8 (h), which provides that in a proceeding pursuant to the State Environmental Quality Review Act (ECL art 8) a project sponsor, at its discretion, may incorporate information submitted late into the draft environmental impact statement (EIS), and any substantive information not incorporated into the draft EIS must be considered as public comment on the draft EIS, is not unconstitutional in that the discretion provided the sponsor is purely procedural and will not have any impact on the substantive content of the final EIS or SEQRA review. Sufficient environmental review will occur in the comment process even though the issue is not contained in the draft EIS. In addition, while omission of an item from a draft EIS cannot be cured by including the item in the final EIS, where there is substantial comment upon, discussion of, and consideration of the issue between the draft EIS and the final EIS, the failure to include it in the draft EIS is not fatal.

Environmental Conservation - Environmental Quality Review - Effective Public Participation in Scoping Procedure Pursuant to SEQRA 6 NYCRR 617.8, which provides that in a proceeding pursuant to the State Environmental Quality Review Act (ECL art 8) a copy of the draft scope must be provided to any individual who has expressed an interest in writing to the lead agency and requires the lead agency to either provide a period of time for the public to review and provide written comments on the draft scope or provide for public input through the use of meetings, exchanges of written material or other means, complies with the Environmental Conservation Law. Even though no specific procedure is set forth, the general requirement of effective public participation is clearly included (ECL 8-0113 [2] [i]). Any procedure followed by lead agencies which does not provide for effective public participation will be subject to judicial review.

Environmental Conservation - Environmental Quality Review - Effective Public Participation in SEQRA Procedure Amendments to 6 NYCRR part 617, which effectuate the State Environmental Quality Review Act, do not fail to provide effective public participation to the extent that they suggest a reduction in public participation in the scoping process and eliminate a requirement that generic environmental impact statements include requirements for public notice and comment on later actions, since no particular level of public participation is required by the statute. A showing of a reduction in public participation does not equate with a showing of ineffective public participation.

Environmental Conservation - Environmental Quality Review - Precluding Type II Actions from SEQRA Review 6 NYCRR 617.5 (a), which provides that Type II actions are precluded from environmental review under the State Environmental Quality Review Act (SEQRA; ECL art 8), is not inconsistent with the general statutory provisions requiring all agencies to consider environmental impacts and take actions which minimize or avoid any such impacts whether or not SEQRA review is required.

Environmental Conservation - Environmental Quality Review - Validity of Amendments to SEQRA Regulations Amendments to 6 NYCRR part 617, which effectuate the State Environmental Quality Review Act (ECL art 8), with the exception of additions to the Type II list, are valid in that the amendments do not contain substantive changes of any significance.

Environmental Conservation - Environmental Quality Review - Actions Added to Type II Exemption List 6 NYCRR 617.5 (c) (7), (8) and (9), which added actions to the Type II exemption list in a proceeding pursuant to the State Environmental Quality Review Act (ECL art 8), are invalid where respondents, in promulgating the regulations, did not consider worst case hypotheticals to determine whether permitted actions might have a significant adverse environmental impact, since this review failed to take a hard look, failed to consider possible significant adverse environmental impacts, and failed to contain findings supported by a rational basis with respect to those additions to the Type II list. An administrative review is insufficient when the impact cannot be forecast accurately from the hypotheticals used. These regulations have included certain types of projects in the Type II list which as worst case hypotheticals could have significant adverse environmental impacts. Respondents based their determination to add types of actions to the Type II list upon past experience and not potential. The final generic environmental impact statement acknowledges numerous possible significant adverse environmental impacts and accepts that some areas are stressed and should not be developed. The final generic environmental impact statement, rather than considering such impacts, uses language indicating that such projects "usually" or "typically" do not cause adverse impacts and relies upon local laws and land use planning to protect the environment.

Environmental Conservation - Environmental Quality Review - Revealing Adverse Environmental Effects in Environmental Impact Statement 6 NYCRR 617.11 (d) (5) is fully consistent with the statutory requirement that to the maximum extent practicable adverse environmental effects revealed in the environmental impact statement process will be minimized or avoided (ECL 8-0109 [8]) and, thus, is valid.

State - Equal Access to Justice Act - Challenging Regulations Effectuating SEQRA Where petitioners challenged the validity of amendments to 6 NYCRR part 617, which effectuate the State Environmental Quality Review Act (ECL art 8), their request for attorney's fees pursuant to CPLR article 86 is denied since a great majority of the petition was without merit and the portions of the regulations invalidated were supported by reasonable argument and therefore do not warrant an award of attorney's fees.

 

735 of 992 DOCUMENTS


Board of Coop. Educ. Servs. v. State


97-078


SUPREME COURT OF NEW YORK, ALBANY COUNTY


171 Misc. 2d 585; 654 N.Y.S.2d 954; 1996 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 548



November 5, 1996, Decided


NOTICE:   [***1]  EDITED FOR PUBLICATION



DISPOSITION: Plaintiffs' motion for summary judgment, seeking injunctive relief and a declaration of unconstitutionality as to Retirement and Social Security Law § 803, is denied in all respects. The temporary restraining orders of June 30, 1995 and January 29, 1996 are vacated. Defendants' cross-motion is granted, and the verified complaints dated June 27, 1995, January 19, 1996 and February 14, 1996 are dismissed. No attorney fees are awarded.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: In consolidated actions seeking injunctive relief and a declaration of unconstitutionality as to N.Y. Retire. & Soc. Sec. Law § 803, plaintiff school districts filed a motion for summary judgment against defendant State of New York. The state filed a cross-motion for summary judgment.


OVERVIEW: Section 803 allowed public employees who were members of one the state's retirement systems to backdate their membership to the date that they first became eligible for entrance into the retirement system. In most instances, that resulted in enhanced benefits for the employees. Originally, the employees' first employer was responsible for the additional benefits, but an amendment to § 803 allowed the public retirement system to distribute a percentage of the cost associated with retroactive membership among all participating employers. The school districts alleged that § 803 required them to make gifts of public funds and to incur debts without any corresponding benefit, contrary to the prohibition contained in N.Y. Const. art. VIII, §§ 1, 2. In granting the state's motion for summary judgment and upholding the constitutionality of the statute, the court held that the law was rationally related to the state's purpose of ensuring benefits for its public employees. It further ruled that even though it might not have been ideally drafted, all of the school districts shared the burden of retroactivity over time, and, therefore, the law provided equal protection.


OUTCOME: The court denied the school districts' motion for summary judgment in the declaratory judgment actions as to the constitutionality of a state retirement statute, granted the state's motion for summary judgment, and dismissed the complaints.


HEADNOTES

Parties - Standing - Municipal Corporations' Constitutional Challenge to State Law Changing Retirement Benefits Plaintiff municipal corporations have standing to challenge the constitutionality of Retirement and Social Security Law § 803, which grants certain public employees retroactive membership in the State retirement systems, on the ground that the statute violates NY Constitution, article VIII, §§ 1 and 2, which prohibit plaintiffs from making gifts of public funds and incurring debts without any corresponding benefits.

Constitutional Law - Gift of Public Funds - Retroactive Pension Benefits Retirement and Social Security Law § 803, which affords retroactive pension benefits to certain public employees who were eligible to enroll in the pension system during the term of their employment, but did not enroll because they did not have notice of their eligibility or because their applications were lost or delayed, does not violate the constitutional prohibition against gifts of public funds (NY Const, art VIII, § 1). The Legislature may provide for an increase in the amount of pensions of any member of a retirement system of the State or a subdivision of the State (NY Const, art VII, § 8, cl [2]). Applying this remedial statute to employees who are already members of the public retirement systems does not represent extra compensation but provides retroactive membership for those who had a right to join a system, but were not informed of that right or whose applications were lost or delayed. To the extent that section 803 imposes the full costs of a member's enhanced retirement benefits on the first employer and, thus, a school district or town may be in the situation of making contributions for the benefits of employees who are now employed by other school districts or public employers (see, Retirement and Social Security Law § 803 [e]), it does not violate NY Constitution, article VIII, § 2, which prohibits a county, city, town or school district from contracting any indebtedness except for county, city, town or school district purposes, since the statute does not involve a contract for indebtedness, nor does it prevent the Legislature from imposing costs upon municipal corporations regardless of whether they directly benefit therefrom.

Constitutional Law - Due Process of Law - Retroactive Pension Benefits Retirement and Social Security Law § 803, which affords retroactive pension benefits to certain public employees who were eligible to enroll in the pension system during the term of their employment, but did not enroll because they did not have notice of their eligibility or because their applications were lost or delayed, does not deprive plaintiff school districts, towns and taxpayers of property without substantive due process to the extent that it permits retroactive membership to temporary or part-time employees. From 1954, the annual retirement primer notified the school districts of their duty to advise part-time teachers of their right to join the retirement system. Even before the retirement system promulgated a regulation in 1977 requiring public employers to advise their part-time employees of their right to join the New York State Employees' Retirement System (2 NYCRR 324.5), policy mandated that employers inform their part-time employees of their membership rights. The statute spreads the responsibility for evaluating claims effectively, and spreads the costs associated with the statute (see, Retirement and Social Security Law § 803 [e]). Even though an employer may be forced to absorb the costs of section 803 relief where it is the first employer, other employers must absorb the costs when that same employer is a later employer, which employer had information concerning the employee's knowledge of his or her rights to join a public retirement system.

Constitutional Law - Due Process of Law - Retroactive Pension Benefits Retirement and Social Security Law § 803, which affords retroactive pension benefits to certain public employees who were eligible to enroll in the pension system during the term of their employment, but did not enroll because they did not have notice of their eligibility or because their applications were lost or delayed, sufficiently protects plaintiff municipal corporations' procedural due process rights. The member must prove to the employer by substantial evidence that he or she did not participate in a procedure which could have apprised him or her of their membership rights (Retirement and Social Security Law § 803 [b] [3]). The first employer may deny retroactive membership if the individual participated in a procedure explaining the option to join the system, or participated in a procedure that a reasonable person would recognize as an explanation or request requiring a formal decision to join a retirement system (Retirement and Social Security Law § 803 [b] [3] [ii], [iii]). Thus, evidence may be presented that a subsequent employer offered the employee membership, or that one of the retirement systems, or any other person or entity, conducted a procedure which could have apprised the individual of his or her rights. Furthermore, the employer may establish a review process which affords a member an opportunity to appear in person or in writing and which may include the employer's own records or the records of another employer (Retirement and Social Security Law § 803 [b] [3]). Section 804 authorizes each retirement system to promulgate rules and regulations to implement the statute and section 805 authorizes a public retirement system to require evidence of service based upon records kept in the ordinary course of business.

Constitutional Law - Equal Protection of Laws - Retroactive Pension Benefits Retirement and Social Security Law § 803, which affords retroactive pension benefits to certain public employees and which, in certain circumstances, imposes the costs of the retroactive membership on the first employer (Retirement and Social Security Law § 803 [e]), does not deprive first employers of equal protection of the laws. The standard of review for equal protection claims is whether the differential treatment has some reasonable basis. Here, the full cost of retroactive membership is imposed upon the first employer, only if the employer affidavit is filed after June 1, 1995. Also, while the first employer may bear the brunt of the enhanced costs in certain circumstances, that burden is shared by all public employers, and the imposition of the enhanced costs on the first employer fosters the diligent investigation of all claims.

 

736 of 992 DOCUMENTS


People v. Green


96-538


SUPREME COURT OF NEW YORK, BRONX COUNTY


170 Misc. 2d 519; 653 N.Y.S.2d 1013; 1996 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 442



November 1, 1996, Decided


NOTICE:  [***1] EDITED FOR PUBLICATION


SUBSEQUENT HISTORY: As Corrected January 27, 1997.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: The state sought to compel the appearance of two police officers in the Supreme Court of New York, Bronx County. The court sought to address whether the inherent power of the court could be exercised to direct an agency of government to revise a policy which interfered with its efficient judicial performance.


OVERVIEW: During the course of a trial, the assigned Assistant District Attorney was directed, on the record and as an officer of the court, to inform two scheduled witnesses, both police officers, the next day for the taking of testimony. The officers informed the District Attorney that they would need a "notification to appear" form. One of the policemen came two days later and the other never showed up. The police department had a policy that did not distinguish between a court mandate to appear and a District Attorney's request for a police officer to present himself. The court, under the inherent powers doctrine, invited the police department to revise its policy to reflect a clear understanding that a mandate to appear issued by a court was in sharp contrast to a departmental policy that was driving by a request form from the District Attorney. The court determined that there was no need for equivocation in such circumstances, nor should any be tolerated, particularly in light of an overburdened court system that places high value on the economy of judicial time.


OUTCOME: The court determined that it could exercise its inherent powers and sound policy considerations dictated the compelling necessity for police department to revise its policy to forestall continued difficulties. The court held that the revised policy should reflect a clear understanding that a mandate to appear issued by a court was in sharp contrast to a departmental policy that was driven by a request form from the District Attorney.


HEADNOTES

Courts - Inherent Powers Doctrine A court has the power to direct a nonjudicial agency of government to revise an offending policy that interferes with efficient judicial performance under the inherent powers doctrine which grants a court the power to take reasonable and necessary steps deemed appropriate to enable it to perform efficiently the judicial function for which it has been constituted. Accordingly, the Supreme Court has the power to direct the New York City Police Department to revise its policy regarding court appearances by police officers, which policy was promulgated to monitor and control outside appearances by police officers, and which has largely replaced the issuance of a subpoena to compel the appearance of a police witness. The policy does not distinguish between a request by the District Attorney's office that an officer appear in court, and a mandate from the court directing the officer to appear in court, and should be revised in order to reflect a clear understanding that a mandate to appear issued by a court is in sharp contrast to a departmental policy that awaits a District Attorney's request form.

 

737 of 992 DOCUMENTS


People v. Trolio


97-011


JUSTICE COURT OF NEW YORK, VILLAGE OF SCARSDALE, WESTCHESTER COUNTY


170 Misc. 2d 1017; 653 N.Y.S.2d 486; 1996 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 504



October 25, 1996, Decided


NOTICE:  [***1] EDITED FOR PUBLICATION



DISPOSITION: The code is not unconstitutional and the motion to dismiss is denied.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant was charged with violating Scarsdale, N.Y., Village Code § 205-2, for operating a gasoline-powered leaf blower beyond the statutory permissible time. Defendant's oral motion to dismiss was granted. However, the dismissal of the information was reversed and the information reinstated. Defendant filed a motion to dismiss on the grounds that the statutory provisions were unconstitutional.


OVERVIEW: Section 205-2 barred use of gasoline-powered blowers from June through September each year. A village police officer issued a summons to defendant's employee for operating a gas-operated leaf blower in the driveway and rear yard of a residence. The court held that defendant had the burden of proving beyond a reasonable doubt that the law was unconstitutional. The court found that § 205-2 reasonably attempted to limit noise, air, and water pollution. Defendant argued that the ordinance created an undue financial hardship on his landscaping business. But the court found that absent a showing of unreasonableness, financial hardship did not require a finding that an ordinance was unconstitutional. Reasonable alternatives remained to use of the gas-powered leaf blowers for landscaping, such as a grass-mulching mower that distributed the grass throughout the lawn. Section 205-2 was not unreasonable in its exclusion of other noise-producing tools.


OUTCOME: The court denied defendant's motion to dismiss the information that charged defendant with operating a gasoline-powered blower beyond the statutory permissible time period. The court declared that the ordinance was constitutional.


HEADNOTES

Constitutional Law - Validity of Statute - Restricting Use in Village of Gasoline-Powered Blowers - Valid Governmental Purpose A village code provision which prohibits the use of gasoline-powered blowers from June 1 through September 30 of each year is reasonably related to the valid governmental purpose of reducing noise, air, water and solid waste pollution and, thus, is not unconstitutional. The legislation was the result of thorough and lengthy investigation, involving consideration of noise complaints by residents, consultations with health and air quality experts, conferences with landscapers, studies of the results of similar laws and public hearings.

Constitutional Law - Validity of Statute - Restricting Use in Village of Gasoline-Powered Blowers - Economic Hardship A village code provision which prohibits the use of gasoline-powered blowers from June 1 through September 30 is not unconstitutional to the extent that it prohibits the use of this, but not other landscaping tools and thereby creates economic hardship on defendant landscaper since, absent a showing of unreasonableness or irrationality, individual economic hardship does not require a finding of unconstitutionality of an otherwise valid ordinance. So long as the law is not arbitrary or irrational, the choice among permissible alternatives is to be made by the village. Here the village seeks to encourage grass recycling via the grass-mulching mower which is a cost-cutting alternative. In addition, this method does not dry out the soil and acts as a natural fertilizer, thus reducing fertilizer and manpower costs. Further, there is insufficient proof to show a significant financial hardship to defendant. In any event, financial hardship is only one factor to consider. Businesses have long been regulated for the sake of the community.

Constitutional Law - Validity of Statute - Restricting Use in Village of Gasoline-Powered Blowers - Permitting Other Noise Producing Tools A village code provision which prohibits the use of gasoline-powered blowers from June 1 through September 30 is not unconstitutional to the extent that it permits numerous other noise producing tools, since the law is not unreasonable and strikes a balance between public and private interests. Noise is but one evil the law is designed to prevent. Other tools may not be used as extensively or as often as the gas blower and thus produce less cumulative noise. Also, the village may prevent the use of only one piece of noisy equipment while allowing the operation of others. The elimination of the gas blower exclusively ipso facto achieves a reduction in the amount of noise. The code need not cover every contingency nor solve every problem to be constitutional. Statutes have, and by nature, often must impose individual restrictions to confer long-term benefits to the public at large. Finally, defendant landscaper has not shown a total absence of any reasonable basis for the code and the summertime ban is not a punitive measure. Laws frequently affect and regulate the conduct of business.

 

738 of 992 DOCUMENTS


Stringfellow's of New York v. City of New York


97-042


SUPREME COURT OF NEW YORK, NEW YORK COUNTY


171 Misc. 2d 376; 653 N.Y.S.2d 801; 1996 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 537



October 23, 1996, Decided


NOTICE:   [***1]  EDITED FOR PUBLICATION


SUBSEQUENT HISTORY: As Corrected March 17, 1997.



DISPOSITION: The City's motions for summary judgment are granted, and the plaintiffs' motions for summary judgment are denied. The Stringfellow's, Amsterdam Video, and Hickerson actions are dismissed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff adult entertainment establishments alleged that the attempt by defendant city to disperse the concentration of their X-rated businesses in certain areas of the city violated their rights of freedom of expression guaranteed under the N.Y. Const. art. I, § 8. Both parties filed motions for summary judgment.


OVERVIEW: The business establishments alleged that the text amendment to the zoning resolution of the city approving the dispersal was unconstitutional because it placed undue burden on those seeking their services to go outside of their usual areas. The city's zoning amendment, which imposed a one-year moratorium on new or expanded adult entertainment establishments and dispersed some of them to certain permissible zoned districts, was based on a study of the conduct of the businesses based upon community concerns regarding the increase in adult establishments and their alleged impacts upon those communities. The majority of the establishments were located in zoning districts that permitted residential developments. The court granted the city's motion for summary judgment, denied the establishments' motion, and dismissed the action. It held that the city had power to preserve the character of specific areas of the city. The amendment did not violate the establishments' constitutional rights because there were alternative areas provided for them.


OUTCOME: The city's motion for summary judgment was granted, the establishments' motion was denied, and the suit was dismissed.


HEADNOTES

Constitutional Law - Freedom of Speech - Zoning Amendment Geographically Restricting Adult Entertainment Establishments An amendment to the New York City Zoning Resolution containing location restrictions and anticoncentration provisions for adult entertainment establishments does not violate the freedom of expression guaranteed to plaintiff adult entertainment establishments and patrons (NY Const, art I, § 8), insofar as the ordinance is justified by concerns based on adverse secondary effects, rather than speech. Preventing neighborhood deterioration is a legitimate public objective and if there is a reasonable relation between the end sought to be achieved and the means adopted, a zoning regulation will be upheld. Here, defendant City sufficiently established a reasonable belief that adult entertainment businesses produce at least some unwanted secondary effects. In making this determination, the City appropriately relied on studies performed by other municipalities and a study conducted by the City Department of City Planning (DCP) which sought to determine the nature and extent of the impact that adult establishments have on communities. The defendant not only reviewed studies from other jurisdictions, but actually used those studies to guide it in its study to determine the existence of negative secondary effects associated with adult use businesses, and in formulating a proper response. Based on this record the City Council was justified in finding that the present configuration of adult use establishments causes adverse secondary effects, a finding which demonstrates that the amendment to the Zoning Resolution was based on a compelling State interest related to combating such negative effects, rather than restricting speech.

Constitutional Law - Validity of Statute - Overbreadth - Zoning Amendment Geographically Restricting Adult Entertainment Establishments An amendment to the New York City Zoning Resolution containing location restrictions and anticoncentration provisions for adult entertainment establishments is not unconstitutional for overbreadth under the State Constitution, since a municipality may utilize its zoning powers to address the negative effects associated with adult use businesses given the fact that such effects are not subject to direct attack. A zoning regulation is an appropriate response to address the existing problems.

Constitutional Law - Validity of Statute - Vagueness - Zoning Amendment Geographically Restricting Adult Entertainment Establishments An amendment to the New York City Zoning Resolution containing location restrictions and anticoncentration provisions for adult entertainment establishments is not unconstitutionally vague. The amendment sufficiently provides a person of ordinary intelligence with fair notice that his or her conduct is forbidden by the Resolution inasmuch as the core language is specific, detailed, and definite, leaving no doubt as to whether a business falls within the definition of an adult establishment. Where a party's actions are clearly within the reach of the Resolution, a court will not strain to imagine hypothetical situations where the application of a statute or ordinance would be unclear. Also, to the extent that the amendment must establish explicit standards for those who apply them to preclude arbitrary and discriminatory resolution, the City must be allowed a reasonable opportunity to develop appropriate guidelines and standards.

Constitutional Law - Freedom of Speech - Alternate Avenues for Expression - Zoning Amendment Geographically Restricting Adult Entertainment Establishments An amendment to the New York City Zoning Resolution containing location restrictions and anticoncentration provisions for adult entertainment establishments is constitutional to the extent that it allows for reasonable alternative avenues of communication. The Resolution permits adult establishments in all of the boroughs and in districts which are also zoned to permit retail, recreational, entertainment and commercial uses. The Resolution permits the existing establishments to continue to operate and permits expansion in terms of numbers and size of establishments. While 147 establishments must relocate, approximately 500 potential sites exist, and these locations are close to transportation. Even if the City's estimate overstates the number of potentially viable relocation sites, ample space exists for more than the existing numbers of adult establishments. The City need not identify specific available sites, but need only afford a reasonable opportunity to relocate. Although instant availability to pornography on demand will be eliminated from some sections of the City, some patrons may be minimally inconvenienced by the need to travel, and owners and operators of some establishments may sustain some economic hardship, these factors do not render the Resolution constitutionally infirm.

 

739 of 992 DOCUMENTS


Brown v. Wing


96-497


SUPREME COURT OF NEW YORK, MONROE COUNTY


170 Misc. 2d 554; 649 N.Y.S.2d 988; 1996 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 399



October 18, 1996, Decided


NOTICE:   [***1]  EDITED FOR PUBLICATION


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioners filed a proceeding pursuant to N.Y. C.P.L.R. 78 and for declaratory judgment after they were denied benefits under N.Y. Soc. Serv. Law § 131-a(3), alleging that an amendment and implementing regulations to the statute were unconstitutional and requested retroactive restoration of benefits.


OVERVIEW: Petitioner indigents were denied public assistance benefits by defendant state agency under N.Y. Soc. Serv. Law § 131-a(3) because their previous states of residence did not provide the types of benefits petitioners were requesting. Petitioners filed a proceeding under N.Y. C.P.L.R. 78 and for declaratory judgment that the statute was unconstitutional. The court granted plaintiffs' motion, holding that jurisdiction and venue were proper, the class certification requirements were met, and the statute violated the federal and state constitutions. A class action was superior to other forms of adjudication because individual actions were oppressively burdensome to elderly and indigent petitioners and multiple lawsuits were subject to inconsistent rulings. Under the state constitution, defendant had a constitutional duty to support the needy.
