The statute restricted petitioners' constitutional right to travel and violated petitioners' equal protection rights because defendant did not have a compelling state interest in adopting the statute.


OUTCOME: The court granted petitioners' motion for class certification and request for declaratory relief, holding that petitioners' challenge to a state statute was properly before the court, a class action was proper, and a state law denying petitioners' public assistance benefits was unconstitutional under both federal and state constitutions.


HEADNOTES

Actions - Improper Form of Action - Conversion of CPLR Article 78 Proceeding to Declaratory Judgment Action - Unconstitutionality of Six-Month Residency Requirement for Home Relief Benefits Petitioners' combined CPLR article 78 proceeding and declaratory judgment action, which was commenced by petition like a conventional article 78 proceeding, is converted to a declaratory judgment action even though petitioners failed to commence the action as a special proceeding, since they allege violations of constitutional rights and a cause of action under CPLR article 30 for a declaratory judgment. Courts are required to correct actions brought in the wrong form (CPLR 103 [c]) and article 78 proceedings will be converted into declaratory judgment actions if constitutional questions are raised, as long as the proper parties are before the court. If petitioners had omitted any cause of action under CPLR article 30 the proceeding would have been converted. Petitioners should not be prejudiced because they did in fact plead this cause. Any procedural differences between article 78 and special proceedings has no significance for this case.

Trial - Place of Trial - Effect of Conversion from CPLR Article 78 Proceeding to Declaratory Judgment Action Where petitioners were denied Home Relief pursuant to a six-month residency requirement (Social Services Law § 131-a), and their combined CPLR article 78 proceeding and declaratory judgment action against respondents, two County Departments of Social Services, was converted to a declaratory judgment action, they will not lose the benefit of CPLR 506 (b) and their choice of venue in a different county, which was proper at the commencement of the action. As an article 78 proceeding, this action would be properly venued in the county chosen, because a proceeding against a body or officer may be brought anywhere within the judicial district where the acts complained of took place (CPLR 506 [b]). Their choice of venue was the best for all counsel and parties. The participation in the action by respondents is to implement and apply the directions of the State government. The issue involves the constitutionality of a statute, and litigation would be carried out by the Attorney-General and the Public Interest Law Office located in the chosen county regardless of whether venue were laid there or in one of the outlying counties.

Actions - Class Actions - Unconstitutionality of Six-Month Residency Requirement for Home Relief Benefits Petitioners who were denied Home Relief pursuant to a six-month residency requirement (Social Services Law § 131-a), and commenced an action against two County Departments of Social Services, are entitled to class certification, even though class certification is uncommon in actions against governments, since the proposed class consists of indigent individuals with little access to the court system, all of whom are in immediate need of relief. While the State may apply the decision of this or another court prospectively, no mechanism exists other than a class action to secure retroactive payment of Home Relief benefits for those individuals whose applications have already been denied. Furthermore, refusal to certify the class would simply invite additional parallel proceedings in other counties and other courts, wasting court resources and conceivably resulting in conflicting decisions. Class certification will both secure the rights of the people affected and bring the issue before the appellate courts in a coherent and expeditious manner.

Actions - Class Actions - Unconstitutionality of Six-Month Residency Requirement for Home Relief Benefits Petitioners who were denied Home Relief pursuant to a six-month residency requirement (Social Services Law § 131-a), and commenced an action against two County Departments of Social Services, will not be denied class certification on the grounds that the number of class members is insufficiently large and the class cannot be effectively managed. A class membership of 5,000 is not insufficiently large, and the failure of the Department of Social Services to monitor the effect of the statute cannot serve as a bar to petitioners' relief.

Social Services - Public Assistance - Home Relief - Unconstitutionality of Six-Month Residency Requirement for Home Relief Benefits - Obligation to Needy Social Services Law § 131-a (3) (d), which provides that those persons requesting Home Relief within six months of establishing residence, are limited, for the first six months after establishing residency, to the standard of payment, if any, that the person would receive under the laws of the State, if any, in which he or she resided immediately prior to establishing residence, is unconstitutional as violative of the State's constitutional duty to aid the needy (NY Const, art XVII, § 1), since it classifies welfare recipients by standards other than need itself. A statute which reduces benefits for some of the needy is as much an unconstitutional classification as one that eliminates them altogether.

Social Services - Public Assistance - Home Relief - Unconstitutionality of Six-Month Residency Requirement for Home Relief Benefits - Right to Travel Social Services Law § 131-a (3) (d), which mandates that those persons requesting Home Relief within six months of establishing residence, are limited, for the first six months after establishing residency, to the standard of payment, if any, that the person would receive under the laws of the State, if any, in which he or she resided immediately prior to establishing residence in this State, is unconstitutional as violative of the right to travel, as guaranteed by the United States Constitution. Enactments that penalize the right to travel must be justifiable as furthering a compelling State interest. Saving welfare costs cannot justify an invidious classification. Even temporary deprivations of important benefits and rights can operate to penalize migration. It is irrelevant whether the benefits involved are Federally or State funded, or whether evidence was provided that anyone was deterred from travel. The right to travel is implicated whenever there is an unequal distribution of rights and benefits among residents of the State based on time of residence.

 

740 of 992 DOCUMENTS


Mylod v. Pataki


97-076


SUPREME COURT OF NEW YORK, ALBANY COUNTY


171 Misc. 2d 556; 654 N.Y.S.2d 946; 1996 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 550



October 9, 1996, Decided


NOTICE:  [***1] EDITED FOR PUBLICATION


SUBSEQUENT HISTORY: As Corrected April 21, 1997.



DISPOSITION: The defendants' motion for summary judgment is granted, and plaintiffs' cross-motion for partial summary judgment is denied.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: The defendant State Department of Transportation moved for summary judgment in the plaintiff taxpayer's action that sought a declaration that the department's method of repaying the Federal Highway Administration for the Federal share it contributed to a cancelled interstate highway project violated N.Y. State Fin. Law § 4 (1) and N.Y. Const. art. VII, § 7.


OVERVIEW: A taxpayer contended that the department's use of billing credits and waivers of credits, on other federally funded projects, to repay the Federal Highway Administration for the federal share it contributed to a cancelled interstate highway project was an impermissible expenditure of state funds in the absence of legislative appropriation. The federal funds that were subject to the credit were due to the state but not yet paid. The court held that money due and owing the state but never relinquished from federal custody and control was not state funds or funding "under the management" of the state as those terms were used in N.Y. Const., art. VII, § 7 or § 4(1). The court found that the state's entitlement to federal reimbursement funds and the Federal Government's contractual obligation to pay its federal share were not tantamount to state control or ownership or management of the funds still held in federal accounts. The court stated that although the department had the right to name a designee for the reimbursement funds, that right was not the equivalent to having the funds under its "management" or being able to control, dispose of, invest, or withdraw the funds.


OUTCOME: The court granted summary judgment in favor of the department and denied the taxpayer's cross-motion for partial summary judgment.


HEADNOTES

Parties - Necessary Parties An action challenging defendant State Department of Transportation's (DOT) method of repaying the Federal Highway Administration (FHWA) for the Federal share it contributed to a cancelled interstate highway project will not be dismissed based upon plaintiffs' failure to join FHWA as a necessary party (CPLR 1001 [a]), since the FHWA fund will not be inequitably affected by a judgment and complete relief is available to the parties in its absence. Plaintiffs seek a declaration that DOT's repayment method violated the appropriations rules and budget bills, and seek an injunction directing DOT to recover the billing credits released to FHWA and the Federal cash due and owing to the State's general fund. Plaintiffs do not seek to directly recover the money from the Federal Government.

Equity - Laches The equitable doctrine of laches does not bar claims asserted in March 1996 against the State Department of Transportation (DOT) challenging its method of repaying the Federal Highway Administration (FHWA) for the Federal share it contributed to a cancelled interstate highway project where plaintiffs were aware in August 1995 of DOT's payment method. Plaintiffs timely commenced the action (CPLR 215 [4]) and are not requesting that a completed highway project be undone or funding be denied after the fact. If plaintiffs prevail, the judgment would require the State to recoup the repayment and find an alternate, legal repayment method. The Federal aid programs inject nearly $ 1 billion per year into the State highway program and involve an ongoing reimbursement and financing process, and entertaining a challenge to an $ 80 million repayment mechanism for a debt unquestionably owed by the State is not, under these facts, barred under the equitable doctrine of laches.

Parties - Standing - Citizen Taxypayer Action Plaintiff citizen taxpayer has standing to challenge the State Department of Transportation's method of repaying the Federal Highway Administration for the Federal share it contributed to a cancelled interstate highway project, since State Finance Law § 123-b authorizes a citizen taxpayer to maintain an action for equitable or declaratory relief against a State officer or employee who in the course of his or her duties has caused a wrongful, illegal or unconstitutional disbursement of State funds or State property.

Parties - Standing - Citizen Taxpayer Action Asserted by Not-for-Profit Corporations Plaintiff not-for-profit corporations lack standing to challenge the State Department of Transportation's method of repaying the Federal Highway Administration for the Federal share it contributed to a cancelled interstate highway project, since State Finance Law § 123-b only authorizes a citizen taxpayer to maintain an action for equitable or declaratory relief against a State officer or employee who in the course of his or her duties has caused a wrongful, illegal or unconstitutional disbursement of State funds or State property. Plaintiffs failed to allege they pay any State taxes so as to qualify them for citizen taxpayer standing and section 123-b does not create a substantive cause of action. Also, where the Legislature has authorized a limited taxpayer's suit, the statute is controlling and to confer common-law standing would ignore the expressed legislative policy.

Constitutional Law - Appropriations - Repayment to Federal Highway Administration of Federal Monies Contributed for Highway Project in Absence of Legislative Appropriation The State Department of Transportation (DOT) did not violate NY Constitution, article VII, § 7 or State Finance Law § 4 (1), both of which prohibit expenditure of State funds in the absence of legislative appropriation, when it repaid the Federal Highway Administration (FHWA), without legislative appropriation, for the Federal share it contributed to a cancelled interstate highway project, by installments, using billing credits, which represented money due the State from the Federal Government as reimbursement for Federal aid highway projects. Money due and owing the State but never relinquished from Federal custody and control is not State funds or funding "under the management of" the State as those terms are used in NY Constitution, article VII, § 7 or State Finance Law § 4 (1). Until the funds are under State control or in the State treasury, they do not fall under the appropriation rules. Under the Federal aid highway program the FHWA approves proposed projects, extends obligation limits to the States, the States provide the initial cash, and the Federal Government reimburses the States for the Federal share of costs actually incurred. The Federal approval is a contractual obligation of the Federal Government for the payment of its proportional contribution (23 USC § 106 [a]). The State's entitlement to reimbursement and the Federal Government's contractual obligation to pay are not tantamount to State control or ownership or management of the funds still held in Federal accounts. The fact that DOT was able to, and in fact did, waive or release the billing credits suggests some indicia of State control, but there is no indication that DOT had unfettered discretion to control the funds, or that the State had all the indicia and attributes of beneficial ownership or management. That the State had the right to name a designee for the reimbursement funds (23 USC § 121 [e]) is not equivalent to having the funds under its "management" or being able to control, dispose of, invest or withdraw the funds.

Public Authorities - Thruway Authority - Budget Provisions for Repayment of Federal Highway Administration The State Department of Transportation did not violate Public Authorities Law § 379 (1) (a) which authorizes, but does not require, the New York State Thruway Authority to issue up to $ 50 million in bonds and apply the proceeds to repay the Federal Highway Administration (FHWA) for the Federal share it contributed to a cancelled interstate highway project, when it repaid FHWA by installments, using billing credits. These budget provisions are permissive and authorize issuance of bonds as one method to effect the repayment but cannot preclude other methods, and the statutory and constitutional appropriation rules (see, NY Const, art VII, § 7; State Finance Law § 4 [1]) do not make such a method mandatory.

 

741 of 992 DOCUMENTS


Stahlbrodt v. Commissioner of Taxation & Fin.


97-077


SUPREME COURT OF NEW YORK, ALBANY COUNTY


171 Misc. 2d 571; 654 N.Y.S.2d 938; 1996 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 549



October 9, 1996, Decided


NOTICE:  [***1] EDITED FOR PUBLICATION


SUBSEQUENT HISTORY: As Amended.



DISPOSITION: Plaintiffs' motion for summary judgment, seeking a declaration of unconstitutionality as to Tax Law § 1115(i) (C), is denied in all respects and the Second Amended Complaint is dismissed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff shopping papers instituted this action against defendant Commissioner of Taxation and Finance of the State of New York for a declaratory judgment, seeking a ruling that, inter alia, certain conditions in the sales tax exemption statute, N.Y. Tax Law § 1115 (i), relating to shopping papers violated the First and Fourteenth Amendments to the US Constitution, as well as N.Y. Const. art. I, § 11.


OVERVIEW: For the shopping papers to receive a tax exemption, the advertisements in their publications could not exceed 90 percent of the printed area of each issue, N.Y. Tax Law § 1115(i)(C). The shopping papers claimed that this was an unconstitutional content-based regulation of free speech. The court rejected this claim, concluding that the distinction was not based upon the ideas expressed, did not suppress expression, and did not transgress First Amendment protections. Further, the sales tax was one of general applicability, N.Y. Tax Law § 1105(c)(2), the exemption applied to all shopping papers, N.Y. Tax Law § 1115 (i), and did not deny them equal protection merely because they were differentiated from newspapers. The court found that the shopping papers had not demonstrated that a newspaper and a shopping paper containing over 90% advertisement were "similarly situated" such that a differential tax treatment of them was irrational, arbitrary or effected invidious discrimination or a denial of equal protection. Accordingly, the shopping papers did not meet their heavy burden of demonstrating the constitutional invalidity of the shopping paper exemption criteria.


OUTCOME: The court denied the motion of the shopping papers for summary judgment, which sought a declaration of unconstitutionality as a portion of the N.Y. Tax Law. The court dismissed the shopping papers' second amended complaint.


HEADNOTES

Declaratory Judgments - When Remedy Appropriate In the absence of factual issues, a declaratory judgment action is an appropriate vehicle to challenge the validity or application of a particular statute without exhausting administrative remedies; accordingly, the failure of plaintiff newspaper publishers to exhaust administrative remedies or commence a CPLR article 78 proceeding does not bar their action seeking a declaration of the unconstitutionality of Tax Law § 1115 (i) (C). To the extent, however, that plaintiffs seek review of any administrative factual determination regarding their shopping paper, or the unconstitutionality of Tax Law provisions as applied to it, such factual issues and review of the administrative determination are outside the scope of the declaratory judgment action.

Constitutional Law - Freedom of Press - Freedom of Speech - Tax Law Exempting Receipts from Sale of Printing Services Performed in Publishing Shopping Paper Tax Law § 1115 (i) (C), which exempts from sales tax the receipts from the sale of printing services performed in publishing a shopping paper, i.e., community publications distributed to the public without consideration for purposes of advertising the public information, so long as the advertisements do not exceed 90% of the printed area of each issue, does not violate freedom of speech or freedom of the press (US Const First Amend). Differential taxation of the media or press is constitutionally suspect when it is based on the content of the ideas being expressed. The sales tax on the sale of printing services is broad based and generally applicable outside the press (Tax Law § 1105 [c] [2]). The tax applies to newspapers and shopping papers, and neither the sales tax itself (§ 1105 [c] [2]) nor the shopping paper exemption (§ 1115 [i]) targets a small group of shopping papers. The content of the advertisements is not regulated, and the requirement that at least 10% of the publication be nonadvertisements does not regulate the substantive content, ideas, viewpoints or subject matter of the nonadvertising portion. The 90% rule uses objective criteria to measure the percentage of printed space devoted to the function of news of community interest and advertising regardless of their subject matter, and the methodology is rational. Further, the agency's interpretation of a statute it is charged with enforcing and which it assisted in drafting is accorded great deference and the lack of a statutory definition of the term "advertising" has not resulted in unbridled discretion, as a common understanding of that term has been recognized. Moreover, the tax does not violate the First Amendment because it treats newspapers differently from shopping papers inasmuch as the distinction is not based upon the content of the publications.

Constitutional Law - Equal Protection of Laws - Freedom of Press Tax Law § 1115 (i) (C), which exempts from sales tax the receipts from the sale of printing services performed in publishing a shopping paper, i.e., community publications distributed to the public without consideration for purposes of advertising the public information, so long as the advertisements do not exceed 90% of the printed area of each issue, does not violate the First Amendment protection against content-based distinctions or deny shopping papers equal protection of the laws because the 90% advertising rule precludes shopping papers from qualifying as "newspapers" under Tax Law § 1115 (a) (5). The only distinction to be drawn is that newspapers sold at retail may claim a sales tax exemption for purchase of printing services as a purchase for resale regardless of their advertising content or ratio (see, Tax Law § 1105 [c] [2]), while shopping papers must satisfy the special exemption criteria of section 1115 (i), and such distinction is not based upon the ideas expressed, does not suppress expression, and does not transgress First Amendment protections. Moreover, plaintiff publisher has not demonstrated that a newspaper and a shopping paper containing over 90% advertisement are "similarly situated" such that a differential tax treatment of them is irrational, palpably arbitrary or effects invidious discrimination or a denial of equal protection.

 

742 of 992 DOCUMENTS


Terenzi v. Westchester County Comm. of the Conservative Party


97-023


SUPREME COURT OF NEW YORK, WESTCHESTER COUNTY


171 Misc. 2d 93; 653 N.Y.S.2d 483; 1996 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 516



October 4, 1996, Decided


NOTICE:   [***1]  EDITED FOR PUBLICATION



DISPOSITION:  Petition is granted to the extent the amendments to Article III, section 2 of the Rules and Regulations of the Westchester County Committee of the Conservative Party are annulled.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: In a proceeding pursuant to N.Y. C.P.L.R. art. 78, petitioner member sought to annul certain amendments to art. III, § 2 of the Rules and Regulations of respondent party (party), and to declare himself eligible for election as an officer of the party.


OVERVIEW: Petitioner, a member of the party for only four years, did not qualify for office under the amendments. The member argued that additional qualifications violated N.Y. Elec. Law § 2-112 in that the requirements of the Election Law were all that could be required. The party argued that § 2-112 did not preclude additional requirements and that the additional requirements did not violate § 2-112. The party maintained the amendments were necessary to ensure a level of commitment and experience in the party's leadership. The court granted the petition to the extent the amendments to art. III, § 2 of the Rules and Regulations of the party were annulled. The court found that the outgoing County Committee attempted to directly handicap a class of persons recognized by N.Y. Elec. Law § 2-112 as eligible to run for party offices. The court opined that the amendments also substantially impaired, if not prevented, the ability of the party members to field an opposition slate of officers who might meet the eligibility requirements. The court concluded that the amendments contravened § 2-112 by altering the eligibility requirements for party offices.


OUTCOME: The court granted the petition to the extent that the amendments to art. III, § 2 of the Rules and Regulations of the party were annulled.


HEADNOTES

Elections - Political Parties - Qualifications for Officers of County Committee Amendments to the rules and regulations of defendant County Committee of the Conservative Party, providing that nominees for chairperson and vice-chairperson must be members of the party for 10 years and have served as officers of the committee for 6 years, are invalid. To the extent that Election Law § 2-112 provides that officers shall be enrolled members of the party but need not be members of the committees, the amendments alter the statutory eligibility requirements and diminish the pool of eligible candidates. Also, the amendments impair the ability of party members to field an opposition slate of officers who might meet the eligibility requirements. Furthermore, years of membership in the party or service in a prior position as an officer on the County Committee are factors that the party membership may consider when choosing its officers; the lack of such qualifications should not limit the choice among candidates. Moreover, the court may properly intervene in this matter, inasmuch as petitioner lacks an effective remedy within the party. Even if the amendments were repealed by the incoming County Committee, the repeal would only be effective prospectively. The power to repeal the amendments also presupposes that the amendments are otherwise valid and should stand unless repealed.

 

743 of 992 DOCUMENTS


People v. Davis


97-002


CITY COURT OF NEW YORK, POUGHKEEPSIE


170 Misc. 2d 987; 653 N.Y.S.2d 789; 1996 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 494



September 20, 1996, Decided


NOTICE:  [***1] EDITED FOR PUBLICATION



DISPOSITION: Defendant's motion is denied.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant, who had been arrested on two felony counts of attempted robbery, filed a motion that sought an order granting a preliminary hearing pursuant to N.Y. Crim. Proc. Law § 180.10 after the prosecution had declined to go forward with a preliminary hearing and had stated that it would not oppose a motion to release defendant on his own recognizance.


OVERVIEW: Defendant was arrested on two felony counts of attempted robbery under N.Y. Penal Law §§ 110.00, 160.10(1), and 160.10(2). Defendant was promptly arraigned before a judge that same day and bail was set. The district attorney declined to go forward with the preliminary hearing and stated that the prosecution would not oppose a motion to release defendant on his own recognizance. Defendant declined a strait release and filed a motion that sought an order granting a preliminary hearing pursuant to N.Y. Crim. Proc. Law § 180.10. The motion was denied because, if defendant had accepted the offered release, his only obligations were to appear in court when required and to remain available for prosecution until the disposition of the case. The court found those obligations did not amount to a "significant pretrial restraint of liberty." Therefore, the constitutional requirement of a probable cause hearing was not triggered. In addition, the court noted if the prosecution refused to proceed with a preliminary hearing contrary to defendant's wishes under § 180.10, the sole remedy for that failure was to release defendant on his own recognizance pursuant to N.Y. Crim. Proc. Law § 180.80.


OUTCOME: Motion was denied because defendant's only obligations were to appear in court when required and to remain available for prosecution until the disposition of the case. Such obligation did not amount to a "significant pretrial restraint of liberty." Therefore, no constitutional requirements for a probable cause hearing were triggered. Furthermore, only remedy under state statute was to release defendant on his own recognizance.


HEADNOTES

Crimes - Preliminary Hearing - What Constitutes Significant Pretrial Restraint of Liberty Defendant was not subject to a significant pretrial restraint of liberty as prohibited by the Fourth Amendment and, therefore, is not entitled to an adversarial probable cause determination where, upon arrest for attempted robbery, he was arraigned and bail was set, prior to his preliminary hearing he was arraigned in superior court on a violation of probation complaint, bail was set and he was incarcerated and, upon appearing in court on the robbery charges, the People declined to go forward with a preliminary hearing and did not oppose release of the defendant on his own recognizance. A significant pretrial restraint of liberty triggers the constitutional requirement for a fair and reliable determination of probable cause. Incarceration as well as pretrial release situations accompanied by burdensome conditions constitute restraint. Restraint necessitates more than the obligation to appear in court. Here, defendant was offered release on his own recognizance. If he had accepted his release, and if he were not incarcerated on the separate probation violation charge, his only obligations would have been to appear in court when required and remain available for prosecution until the disposition of the case. These obligations do not amount to a significant pretrial restraint of liberty.

Crimes - Preliminary Hearing - Remedy for People's Failure to Participate in Scheduled Preliminary Hearing In determining a defendant's right to a prompt preliminary hearing where the People failed to proceed with a preliminary hearing and did not oppose defendant's release on his own recognizance, the term "holding" in CPL 180.10 (2), which provides the accused with the right to a prompt hearing to determine whether there is sufficient evidence to warrant holding him or her for Grand Jury action, means a significant pretrial restraint of liberty. This interpretation prevents a conflict between CPL 180.10 (2) and 180.70 (4), which envisions the possibility of a preliminary hearing absent incarceration. Also, CPL 180.70 (4) applies regardless of a defendant's custody status, so long as he is suffering a significant pretrial restraint on liberty. In addition, this interpretation does not present a conflict with CPL 180.10 (4), in that the affirmative action to be effectuated by the court is release of the defendant from the restraint of liberty placed pursuant to CPL 180.80. Further, the right under CPL 180.10 (2) is illusory since the People can avoid the hearing by presenting the charge to a Grand Jury. The only remedy provided by statute for situations where the People fail or refuse to proceed with a preliminary hearing is release of defendant on his own recognizance.

 

744 of 992 DOCUMENTS


Gleason v. Holman Contract Warehousing


96-476


SUPREME COURT OF NEW YORK, ALBANY COUNTY


170 Misc. 2d 668; 649 N.Y.S.2d 647; 1996 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 383



September 18, 1996, Decided


NOTICE:  [***1] EDITED FOR PUBLICATION


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff injured employee filed a motion pursuant to N.Y. C.P.L.R. 603 for an order severing the third party action brought by third-party plaintiff corporation against third-party defendant, plaintiff's employer, from the action brought by plaintiff against defendant corporations so as not to delay the commencement of trial pending a determination of whether the Omnibus Workers' Compensation Reform Act of 1996 was retroactive.


OVERVIEW: Plaintiff injured employee was severely hurt while he unloaded a tractor-trailer owned by third-party defendant, plaintiff's employer. Plaintiff filed a motion to sever the third-party action brought by third-party plaintiff corporation against third-party defendant so as not to delay the commencement of plaintiff's trial against defendant corporations pending a judicial determination of whether the Omnibus Workers' Compensation Reform Act of 1996 (Act) and its component parts were retroactive or prospective only. By applying the statutory rules of construction of N.Y. Stat. Law § 51 et seq. for determining whether a statute was to be applied retroactively or prospectively, the court determined that the Act, which forbade third-party actions against employers for contribution except in cases where the employee sustained "grave injury," was to be applied prospectively only. The Act was to take effect "immediately," indicating a prospective application, and the legislation was silent as to any retroactive application. Because all claims could be decided in a single proceeding, the court denied plaintiff's motion to sever.


OUTCOME: The court denied plaintiff injured employee's motion to sever the third-party action brought by third-party plaintiff corporation against third-party defendant, plaintiff's employer, because the Omnibus Workers' Compensation Reform Act of 1996 was prospective only and all claims could be decided in a single proceeding. The court re-scheduled the trial to allow third-party defendant to prepare for trial.


HEADNOTES

Statutes - Retroactive Application of Statute - Omnibus Workers' Compensation Reform Act of 1996 The Omnibus Workers' Compensation Reform Act of 1996 (L 1996, ch 635), which forbids third-party actions against employers for contribution except in cases where the employee sustained a grave injury, is not retroactive but prospective only to accidents occurring subsequent to the effective date of the statute, i.e., September 10, 1996; accordingly, the motion by plaintiff employee, who has not sustained a "grave injury", to sever the third-party action involving his employer is denied without prejudice. This act was passed to entice new business to New York State by lowering employer liability insurance rates and, where applicable, apportioning liability and contribution between joint tortfeasors, not on an equitable basis measured by relative culpability, but upon an economic basis. A substantive, not a remedial statute, this Act shifts the vested right of joint tortfeasors--increasing the liability of some and decreasing the liability of others. In addition, the language of the statute, i.e., that the act is to take effect "immediately", indicates a prospective intent, and the Act is silent as to any retroactive application. Prospective intent is also indicated by the Legislature's intent to "create a system" related to culpability and apportionment. Furthermore, the Act does not provide for redistribution of windfall profits to the workers' compensation insurance carriers that would result from a retroactive application, and does not provide for return of premiums to businesses that paid them. Finally, retroactivity would not warm the business climate of New York and attract new business to the State.

 

745 of 992 DOCUMENTS


People v. Alvarez


Docket No. 95X021434


CRIMINAL COURT OF THE CITY OF NEW YORK, BRONX COUNTY


172 Misc. 2d 440; 659 N.Y.S.2d 382; 1996 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 582



September 4, 1996, Decided


NOTICE:   [***1]  EDITED FOR PUBLICATION


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant was charged by information with operating a motor vehicle while under the influence of alcohol, pursuant to N.Y. Veh. & Traf. Law §1192(2), (3), and his driver's license was suspended at arraignment pursuant to the prompt suspension law, N.Y. Veh. & Traf. Law § 1193(2)(e)(7). Defendant had filed a motion to dismiss alleging insufficiency of the information on the ground that it was based on hearsay.


OVERVIEW: An officer's affidavit attached to an information charging defendant with operating a motor vehicle while under the influence of alcohol, under N.Y. Veh. & Traf. Law § 1192(2), (3), alleged that an informant observed defendant driving and was nearly hit by him. The officer stated that there was a strong odor of alcohol on defendant's breath, his eyes were bloodshot, he was swaying, and his blood alcohol level was greater than .10. At the arraignment, defendant's driver's license was suspended under the prompt suspension law, N.Y. Veh. & Traf. Law § 1193(2)(e)(7), and defendant sought to reargue his dismissal motion, alleging violation of due process and insufficiency of the information. The court held that: (1) § 1193(2)(e)(7) did not require a formal hearing at arraignment to make a prima facie showing of reasonable cause before suspending defendant's license; (2) defendant was given an opportunity to request a short adjournment to marshal evidence and to seek hardship relief; and (3) due process was not violated in the suspension of defendant's license because he did not challenge the facial sufficiency of the breath analysis machine or rebut the prima facie showing.


OUTCOME: The court denied defendant's motion to dismiss the information, which had charged defendant with operating a motor vehicle while under the influence of alcohol.


HEADNOTES

Motor Vehicles - Operating Vehicle while Under Influence of Alcohol or Drugs - Sufficiency of License Suspension Hearing

Where defendant's driver's license was suspended pursuant to Vehicle and Traffic Law § 1193 (2) (e) (7), pending charges of operating a motor vehicle while under the influence of alcohol (Vehicle and Traffic Law § 1192 [2], [3]), the court was not required, at arraignment and prior to suspension, to hold a formal hearing and issue a formal ruling on whether the People made a prima facie showing of reasonable cause. To attain the State's objectives of maintaining highway safety a State may adopt summary procedures. The hearing under section 1193 (2) (e) (7) accords a defendant all of and probably more than the process that the Federal Constitution assures. Once a prima facie showing is made, the defendant must be given the opportunity to make a statement on the sufficiency of the accusatory instrument and the documented results of a reliable chemical test, which comprise the prima facie showing for license suspension, and an opportunity to request a short adjournment if necessary to marshall the evidence. This opportunity, as well as the opportunity to seek hardship relief, were given to defendant. Also, at arraignment, the court had the factual allegations of the accusatory instrument and the inferences that may be drawn therefrom; the certified chemical test analysis, which showed that the defendant's blood alcohol level was .19%; the supporting deposition of the officer who administered the test; paperwork containing defendant's statements that he had been driving and drinking, as well as the arresting officer's observation of the defendant and the results of the physical coordination test. Moreover, defendant was on notice that his license may be suspended, but he did not then challenge the facial sufficiency of the instrument, rebut the prima facie showing, or seek an adjournment to do so. Even if a prima facie basis was not then shown, and even assuming that the defendant may now challenge the sufficiency of the instrument for suspension purposes, such error does not give rise to a legal or jurisdictional impediment that, pursuant to CPL 170.30 (1) (f), would necessitate dismissal. Further, defendant has failed to establish the requisite compelling factors that would justify dismissal in the interests of justice ( CPL 170.30 [1] [g]).

 

746 of 992 DOCUMENTS


People v. Rambersed


96-493


SUPREME COURT OF NEW YORK, BRONX COUNTY


170 Misc. 2d 923; 649 N.Y.S.2d 640; 1996 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 398



August 26, 1996, Decided


NOTICE:  [***1] EDITED FOR PUBLICATION


SUBSEQUENT HISTORY: As Corrected December 16, 1996.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: During voir dire at a trial for assault and weapons possession, defendant moved to exclude jury members of Italian descent, alleging that such potential jurors were not members of a cognizable racial group warranting protection from discrimination under Batson. The prosecution voiced a prima facie Batson challenge to defendant's peremptory strikes.


OVERVIEW: During voir dire, defendant, charged with assault and weapons possession, exercised a pattern of peremptory strikes against all prospective jurors of Italian descent. The prosecution voiced a prima facie Batson challenge and defendant argued that Italian-Americans were not members of a cognizable racial group warranting protection from discrimination. The court denied defendant's pattern of peremptory challenges and upheld the prosecution's Batson challenge to defendant's peremptory strikes. The court held that Batson represented a significant step in eradicating all forms of discrimination in jury selection procedures. As such, the court held that Italian-Americans were members of a cognizable racial group shielded by the equal protection clause's prohibition against discrimination on basis of ancestry or national origin. The court found that racially based peremptory strikes also violated the Civil Rights Clause of the state constitution, N.Y. Const. art. I, § 11. Finally, the court held that defendant had failed to provide sufficiently neutral explanations for such challenges and ruled that a prima facie showing of discrimination against Italian-Americans had been made out.


OUTCOME: The court denied defendant's peremptory challenges excluding jury members of Italian descent during voir dire at defendant's trial for assault and weapons possession. The court upheld the prosecution's prima facie Batson challenge to defendant's peremptory strikes and concluded that defendant had failed to provide sufficiently neutral explanations for excluding all potential jurors of Italian descent.


HEADNOTES

Crimes - Jurors - Selection of Jury - Use of Race-Based Peremptory Challenges - Prospective Jurors of Italian Descent as Members of Cognizable Racial Group Prospective jurors of Italian descent are members of a cognizable racial group warranting protection from the discriminatory use of peremptory challenges under Batson v Kentucky (476 US 79). Batson and its progeny make clear that no matter what the factual context, neither the prosecution nor the defense can utilize the mechanism of peremptory strikes to exclude persons of a particular race from jury service, and Batson supports an expansive construction of the meaning of cognizable racial group that is inclusive of a variety of ethnic and ancestral groups subject to intentional discrimination including Americans of Italian descent. Accordingly, defendant must provide racially neutral explanations for exercising peremptory strikes against all prospective jurors of apparent or conceded Italian descent.

Crimes - Jurors - Selection of Jury - Use of Race-Based Peremptory Challenges - State Equal Protection Clause and Civil Rights Clause Racially based peremptory strikes are violative of both the Equal Protection Clause and the Civil Rights Clause of the New York State Constitution. Jury service is a privilege of citizenship protected under the State Constitution, and Civil Rights Law § 13 specifically prohibits disqualification of a potential juror because of national origin. Accordingly, the exercise of peremptory strikes by defendant against all prospective jurors of apparent or conceded Italian descent is constitutionally prohibited.

 

747 of 992 DOCUMENTS


Checchia v. Tioga County Bd. of Elections


96-428


SUPREME COURT OF NEW YORK, TIOGA COUNTY


169 Misc. 2d 732; 647 N.Y.S.2d 458; 1996 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 334



August 23, 1996, Decided


NOTICE:   [***1]  EDITED FOR PUBLICATION



DISPOSITION: The petition is denied in all respects.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner candidates filed an action against respondent Board of Elections pursuant to N.Y. C.P.L.R. 78 seeking judicial review, by order to show cause, of the Board's decision, which had declared certain other candidates were the unopposed winners for the office of member of the republican county committee to be elected at the upcoming primary election and had invalidated the candidates' designating petitions for the same position.


OVERVIEW: The candidates circulated designating petitions to qualify as candidates for the office of member of the republican county committee in various election districts, for election at an upcoming primary election. The Board then declared that other candidates were unopposed winners under the rules of the committee because there were no other candidates for those positions and invalidated the candidates' designating petitions. Almost one month later, the candidates filed an action styled as a proceeding under N.Y. C.P.L.R. 78 to obtain judicial review of and to nullify the Board's declaration. The court held that: (1) the rules provided that a "preference" should be given to one man and one woman in each district by declaring the sole candidate of a particular gender as the winner of one seat and requiring the remaining opposite-gender candidates to be voted upon at the primary election; (2) N.Y. Elec. Law § 2-102 expressly permitted equal representation of the sexes on state committees; and (3) the action was untimely under N.Y. Elec. Law § 2-102 because it was not filed within 14 days after the last day to file petitions or within 3 days after the Board's decision.


OUTCOME: The court denied the candidates' petition for judicial review of the Board's declaration and invalidation of the candidates' designating petitions.


HEADNOTES

Elections - Political Parties - Validity of Gender Preference in Composition of County Committee Respondent Board of Elections appropriately interpreted the rules and regulations or bylaws of the County Republican Party, which provide for the County Committee to consist of two members from each district with preference to one man and one woman in each district but to allow two men or two women in a district, to mean that when only one candidate of a particular gender duly qualified in an election district, then that individual was to be declared the unopposed winner of one of the two Committee member offices in that district. This "preference" to the election of one man and one woman in each district is reasonable. In the event that all candidates are of the same gender, the rules allow two men or two women. However, the term "preference" would have no meaning if a woman could be defeated by two men each receiving more votes. This ensures equal representation of gender on the County Committee, an admirable goal, and reflects the makeup of the State committees permitted to each party (see, Election Law § 2-102).

Elections - Designating Petitions - Timeliness of Proceeding Challenging Invalidation Where respondent Board of Elections considered objections to petitioner's designating petitions for office of member of a County Committee filed by a nonresident of the respective election districts, upheld these objections and invalidated the petitions, petitioner's claim in a CPLR article 78 proceeding that the Board lacked jurisdiction to act upon the objections is barred by the Statute of Limitations. Election Law § 16-102 (2) requires that any proceeding with respect to a petition must be instituted within 14 days after the last day to file petitions, or within three business days after the Board made its determination. Petitioners are beyond these time limitations in that their application for review was filed nearly one month after their petitions were invalidated. Petitioner's attempt to void this time limitation in a CPLR article 78 proceeding is unpersuasive.

 

748 of 992 DOCUMENTS


Law Enforcement Officers Union v. State by Seide


96-426


SUPREME COURT OF NEW YORK, ALBANY COUNTY


170 Misc. 2d 143; 647 N.Y.S.2d 916; 1996 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 331



August 19, 1996, Decided


NOTICE:   [***1]  EDITED FOR PUBLICATION



DISPOSITION: The subject final rule is hereby vacated, annulled and voided on the ground that it is arbitrary and capricious (see, L.E.O.U. v. State I). Petitioners' request for an order enjoining D.O.C.S. or the Commission from implementing double occupancy housing units is hereby granted.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner correctional officers and union brought suit against respondent agencies, requesting that N.Y. Comp. Codes R. & Regs. tit. 9, § 7621.5, providing for double occupancy housing units in state prisons, be vacated and that an injunction prohibiting "double ceiling" be granted. They argued that the rule was arbitrary and capricious and that its adoption violated N.Y. A.P.A. § 202, part of the Administrative Procedure Act.


OVERVIEW: An emergency version of the rule was found to be arbitrary and capricious in an earlier proceeding. The court held that the permanent rule was also arbitrary and capricious, stating that because it did not correct or address the omission of minimum square footage per inmate in the emergency rule, it, the previous conclusion that the emergency regulation was irrational for failure to provide a minimum square footage requirement was equally applicable to the permanent rule. It held, however, that in adopting the permanent rule, the agency complied with the notice, filing, publication, and public comment requirements of N.Y. A.P.A. § 202, stating that although the process of adopting the emergency rule may have been flawed, this did not invalidate the separate and distinct process for final adoption. It held that the interests asserted by the correctional officers and their union, protection from the increased dangers double occupancy presented, gave them standing to bring suit. Finally, it held that given its findings on the square footage issue, injunctive relief prohibiting double ceiling was appropriate.


OUTCOME: The court vacated and voided the rule. It enjoined the agencies from implementing double occupancy housing units.


HEADNOTES

Prisons and Prisoners - Conditions of Confinement - Double Occupancy Housing Units - Rule Making A final rule (9 NYCRR 7621.5) adopted by respondent New York State Commission of Correction providing for "double occupancy housing units" in State prisons, which did not correct or address the omission of minimum square footage per inmate in the emergency rule held invalid in a prior CPLR article 78 proceeding ( Matter of Law Enforcement Officers Union v State of New York, 168 Misc 2d 781), is vacated and annulled as arbitrary, capricious and irrational in that it shares the same infirmities as the emergency rule. Judicial deference to an administrative agency's exercise of its rule making powers and interpretation of a statute is inappropriate where the rule is irrational or arbitrary and capricious. Here, respondents proffered an extensive explanation in the revised notice for lack of minimum square footage per inmate in double cells, but this omission was not addressed in the final rule. Significantly, the rule does not delineate factors to be considered in the conversion determination (9 NYCRR 7621.5 [h]). Although no constitutional minimum square footage per inmate in double cells has been established, there is no reason to diverge from the rationale employed in the previous determination concerning the same parties on the identical issue as to the irrationality of the emergency rule, especially since the rule delineates no objective factors or standard which must be used when double celling is being considered.

Administrative Law - Collateral Estoppel - Annulling Emergency Rule - Effect on Final Adopted Rule The doctrine of collateral estoppel does not prevent a determination on the merits of a CPLR article 78 proceeding which challenges a final rule adopted by respondent New York State Commission of Correction where a prior article 78 proceeding held the predecessor emergency rule invalid. Collateral estoppel operates where there has been a final judgment on the merits, and the previous proceeding may be used as a basis for collateral estoppel even though an appeal is pending. However, the doctrine is flexible and not automatic, even where formal prerequisites are met, and it will not be applied here where the previous determination involved an emergency rule.

Administrative Law - Rule Making - Rule Providing for Double Celling of Prisoners Respondent New York State Commission of Correction did not violate State Administrative Procedure Act requirements when promulgating a rule providing for "double occupancy housing units" since it complied with the notice, filing, publication and public comment requirements for the notice of proposed rule making, notice of revised proposed rule making and notice of adoption (State Administrative Procedure Act § 202 [1], [4-a], [5]), even though it failed to comply with State Administrative Procedure Act provisions when adopting the predecessor emergency rule. The emergency procedures differ from the procedures applicable to ordinary rule making (§ 202 [1], [4-a], [5]). That the initial notice was simultaneously a notice of emergency adoption (§ 202 [6]) and a notice of proposed rule making (§ 202 [1]) is contemplated by statute (§ 202 [6] [d] [ii]) and does not make the latter process dependent on the former. The process for the emergency adoption of a rule may be flawed and the emergency rule invalidated, while the separate and distinct process for final adoption may be complied with and the final rule upheld.

Parties - Standing - Challenge to Rule Promulgated by New York State Commission of Correction A CPLR article 78 proceeding by petitioner Law Enforcement Officers Union challenging a rule promulgated by respondent New York State Commission of Correction, authorizing double occupancy housing units, will not be dismissed for lack of standing. Petitioner represents the security services and security supervisors bargaining units, which include State correction officers, sergeants and lieutenants, employed by the Department of Correctional Services, who provide security in State correctional facilities. Also, one individual petitioner, the chief operating officer for the Union Council, is empowered to act on its behalf and the other individual is a correction sergeant and serves as staff director for the Council. Regarding associational standing, the Council is the certified bargaining representative under the Civil Service Law for correctional officers/sergeants/lieutenants, and the interests it asserts--protection of correctional employees from increased dangers from double celling--are germane to its purposes. Also, one or more of its members would have standing to sue, as the correctional employees are within the zone of interest to be protected by the double celling regulation. Finally, nothing in the relief requested or the causes of action requires the participation of individual correctional officers/sergeants/lieutenants.

Prisons and Prisoners - Conditions of Confinement - Double Occupancy Housing Units - Minimum Standards Respondents Department of Correctional Services and New York State Commission of Correction are enjoined from implementing double occupancy housing units in State prisons where a rule promulgated by respondents was held invalid as irrational since respondents must promulgate a valid rule in order to double house inmates; they do not have implied or express statutory authority and discretion to determine whether to double cell inmates pursuant to Correction Law §§ 45 and 46. In the absence of the final rule, respondents have not promulgated "minimum standards" (§ 45 [6]) governing double celling as they have for single and multiple occupancy housing units. While the practice of double celling is neither per se unconstitutional nor does it violate any statutory provisions, and the practice as applied is not within the scope of this proceeding, injunctive relief prohibiting double celling is appropriate in view of the fact that double celling would be inconsistent with the Commission's regulations relating to multiple occupancy housing units minimum square footage (9 NYCRR 7621.6), whether implemented pursuant to a final rule or an agency practice.

 

749 of 992 DOCUMENTS


People v. Afrika


96-408


SUPREME COURT OF NEW YORK, MONROE COUNTY


168 Misc. 2d 618; 648 N.Y.S.2d 235; 1996 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 319



August 15, 1996, Decided


NOTICE:   [***1]  EDITED FOR PUBLICATION



DISPOSITION: The Defendants' motion are hereby denied in their entirety.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendants appeared pursuant to the Sex Offender Registration Act (SORA), N.Y. Correct. Law § 168 et seq., to obtain judicial determination as to the level of notification or classification applicable to them. Prior to the court's assessment of their risk levels, they filed motions that challenged the constitutionality of the SORA.


OVERVIEW: Defendants were released to parole supervision following their incarceration resulting from their convictions for sexual offenses. They argued that the application of SORA to them violated the Ex Post Facto Clause of the United States Constitution. The state argued to the contrary on the basis that the law was remedial and not punitive. The court held that the legislative intent was not to punish. Rather it was intended to promote public safety and enhance law enforcement efforts by providing for the accumulation and dissemination of pertinent information regarding dangerous sex offenders. The SORA was also not punitive in form or effect. Criminal convictions were matters for public record. The fact that the SORA had a deterrent effect or potentially adversely affected some of the subjects did not change its remedial nature. Thus, SORA was not unconstitutional.


OUTCOME: The court denied defendants' motion challenging the constitutionality of the SORA.


HEADNOTES

Constitutional Law - Ex Post Facto Law - Sex Offender Registration Act The Sex Offender Registration Act (Correction Law § 168 et seq. [SORA]), which requires those individuals convicted of designated offenses, principally sex offenses, to register with the Division of Criminal Justice Services 10 days after their discharge from prison, or their release or parole, and which provides that a failure to register is punishable as a misdemeanor for the first offense with any subsequent failure to do so constituting a class D felony and may constitute grounds for a parole revocation, is not unconstitutional as inflicting greater punishment for past crimes in violation of the Ex Post Facto Clause. SORA evinces an unmistakable intent to promote public safety and enhance law enforcement efforts by providing for the accumulation and dissemination of pertinent information regarding dangerous sex offenders and is not excessive in its reach or burdens, but conversely, is a measured response to a perceived danger. Thus, the Act is constructed in a fashion consonant with the Legislature's pronounced remedial design. Moreover, the Act is not the product of lust for retribution; it is a measured attempt to achieve remedial with attendant deterrent goals. The question in each case, where unpleasant consequences are brought to bear upon an individual for prior conduct, is whether the legislative aim was to punish that individual for past activity, or whether the restriction of the individual comes about as a relevant incident to a regulation of a present situation. When judged by this standard, SORA passes muster as a remedial law, since the burdens that are imposed were occasioned by bona fide governmental concerns regarding the peril presented to the public by known sexual predators who are at liberty.

 

750 of 992 DOCUMENTS


N.Y. Ass'n of Convenience Stores v. Urbach


96-477


SUPREME COURT OF NEW YORK, ALBANY COUNTY


170 Misc. 2d 445; 648 N.Y.S.2d 890; 1996 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 382



August 13, 1996, Decided


NOTICE:   [***1]  EDITED FOR PUBLICATION


SUBSEQUENT HISTORY: As Amended November 18, 1996.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner off-reservation non-Indian retailers sought a judgment compelling respondent state taxation and finance officials to determine, assess, collect, and enforce New York state cigarette and motor fuel taxes pertaining to on-reservation sales of cigarettes and motor fuel by Indian retailers to non-Indian consumers, citing N.Y. Tax Law art. 12-A, 20, 28 and N.Y. Comp. Codes R. & Regs. tit. 20, parts 336, 414 (collectively tax laws).


OVERVIEW: The retailers alleged that the on-reservation Indian retailers failed to collect the taxes provided for under the tax laws from non-Indian purchasers and turn them over to the state of New York, and that the state had failed to enforce the statutory provisions and regulations pertaining to the collection by on-reservation Indians from sales to on-reservation non-Indians and payment of same over to the authorities of the state. The retailers sought relief by way of mandamus and the court granted summary judgment in their favor, under certain conditions. The tax laws were part of a regulatory scheme that had been approved by the United States Supreme Court, but never implemented by the state of New York. Because the retailers were seeking only implementation of the scheme, and not any change in policy or reordering of priorities, mandamus was a proper remedy. There were no issues of fact to be resolved and the court concluded that unless some "kinetic energy" were infused into the officials, the tax laws would remain unenforced. Such a failure would be unconstitutional as violative of equal protection laws. Thus, the court ordered equal implementation and enforcement of the tax laws.


OUTCOME: The court denied the officials' motion to dismiss the retailers' petition for mandamus and also denied the officials' motion for summary judgment. The retailers' motion for summary judgment was granted under certain conditions. The court ordered equal implementation and enforcement of the tax laws, to be stayed for 120 days to allow for compliance.


HEADNOTES

Proceeding against Body or Officer - Mandamus - Compelling Department of Taxation and Finance to Enforce Cigarette and Motor Fuel Tax Laws on Indian Reservations Petitioners, individual and associations of off-reservation non-Indian retailers, are entitled to a writ of mandamus compelling respondents Department of Taxation and Finance and its Commissioner to determine, assess, collect and enforce New York State cigarette and motor fuel taxes pertaining to on-reservation sales of cigarettes and motor fuel by Indian retailers to non-Indian consumers pursuant to Tax Law articles 12-A, 20 and 28 and 20 NYCRR parts 336 and 414, since respondents' failure to enforce these tax laws against some to whom they apply, to the detriment of others, is unconstitutional. A writ of mandamus is available to compel a body to perform a legal duty under statute. By enacting articles 12-A, 20 and 28, the Legislature has already presumably examined all issues involved, including complex political issues, and expressly declared its policy in this matter. By promulgating 20 NYCRR parts 336 and 414, the executive branch has done the same on its part. In 1994, the United States Supreme Court upheld the validity of the regulations. Accordingly, all that remains is enforcement and implementation of the tax statutes to prevent unequal enforcement.

 

751 of 992 DOCUMENTS


Miriam Osborn Mem. Home Ass'n v. Chassin


Index # 2248/93


SUPREME COURT OF NEW YORK, WESTCHESTER COUNTY


172 Misc. 2d 878; 658 N.Y.S.2d 156; 1996 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 581



August 7, 1996, Decided


NOTICE:  [***1] EDITED FOR PUBLICATION


SUBSEQUENT HISTORY: As Corrected June 16, 1997.



DISPOSITION: The defendants' motion for summary judgment dismissing the complaint is granted and the complaint is dismissed. The defendants' motion for partial summary judgment on their counterclaims is also granted and the plaintiff is directed to comply with the reporting requirements of Public Health Law § 2807-d. The plaintiff's cross motion is denied in its entirety.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant state officials moved for summary judgment dismissing plaintiff nursing home's 42 U.S.C.S. § 1983 complaint alleging that N.Y. Pub. Health Law § 2807-d was unconstitutional. Further, the state officials and the nursing home moved for summary judgment on the state officials' counterclaims directing the nursing home to comply with the filing requirements of § 2807-d.


OVERVIEW: The nursing home filed suit against the state officials challenging the constitutionality of N.Y. Pub. Health Law § 2807-d, which charged the nursing home assessments based on the gross receipts received from all patient care services and other operating income less personal needs allowances and refunds. The nursing home claimed that § 2807-d violated its substantive due process rights, denied it equal protection, and constituted an unconstitutional taking without just compensation. The state officials counterclaimed for an order directing the nursing home to comply with § 2807-d's reporting requirements. The nursing home moved for summary judgment dismissing the state officials' counterclaims. The state officials moved for summary judgment on both the nursing home's complaint and its own counterclaims. The court granted the state officials' motions and denied the nursing home's motion. Section 2807-d satisfied the requirements of substantive due process because it was reasonably related to the legitimate governmental objective of reducing a budget deficit. There was no evidence of a taking because the nursing home did not show that the assessment would cause economic hardship.


OUTCOME: The court granted the state officials' motions for summary judgment on the nursing home's complaint challenging the constitutionality of a statute charging it assessments on its gross receipts and other operating income and on their counterclaims directing the nursing home to comply with the statute's reporting requirements. The court denied the nursing home's motion for summary judgment on the counterclaims.


HEADNOTES

Constitutional Law - Validity of Statute - Statute Imposing Assessment on Gross Receipts of Certain Hospitals - Due Process of Law

Public Health Law § 2807-d, which imposes an assessment on a percentage of the gross receipts from patient care and all other operating income of certain hospitals, does not violate plaintiff nursing home's right to due process as the application of the statute to plaintiff furthers the legislative objective of the statute, which is reduction of the State budget deficit, a legitimate governmental objective. Legislation satisfies the requirements of substantive due process if it is reasonably related to a legitimate governmental objective, and the Legislature has nearly unconstrained authority in the design of taxing measures unless they are utterly unreasonable or arbitrary.

Constitutional Law - Validity of Statute - Statute Imposing Assessment on Gross Receipts of Certain Hospitals - Equal Protection of Laws

Public Health Law § 2807-d, which imposes an assessment on a percentage of the gross receipts from patient care and all other operating income of certain hospitals, does not exempt nursing homes similarly situated to plaintiff in violation of the Equal Protection Clause of the Federal and State Constitutions. The Equal Protection Clause does not prevent the Legislature from treating one class of individuals or entities differently from others as long as the different tax treatment is not palpably arbitrary and does not amount to invidious discrimination, and plaintiff has failed to meet its burden of challenging the legislative arrangement to negate every conceivable rational basis which might support it. Plaintiff, which receives private payment from its patients and is not dedicated solely to the care of low-income patients or solely to the care of police, firefighters and emergency personnel, is not similarly situated to those nursing homes which are exempt from the statute because they are either totally financed by charitable contributions and dedicated solely to the care of low-income patients, or because they provide care only for police, firefighters and emergency personnel, exemptions which are rationally related to legitimate State objectives.

Constitutional Law - Validity of Statute - Statute Imposing Assessment on Gross Receipts of Certain Hospitals - Equal Protection of Laws

Defendant Department of Health is not selectively enforcing Public Health Law § 2807-d, which imposes an assessment on a percentage of the gross receipts from patient care and all other operating income of certain hospitals, against plaintiff nursing home in violation of the Equal Protection Clause of the Federal and State Constitutions even though it has not enforced the statute against three other nursing homes which, like plaintiff, are not exempt from the statute. Plaintiff has failed to come forward with proof that defendant's enforcement of the statute against it and not against certain other nursing homes was based upon an impermissible standard such as race, religion or some other arbitrary classification rather than as a result of a legitimate enforcement strategy. The three other nursing homes, unlike plaintiff, complied with the reporting requirements of the statute and claimed no assessable income, and although defendant has since learned that those nursing homes may, in fact, have had assessable income during the period in question, defendant has not yet determined whether such assessable income existed.

Constitutional Law - Validity of Statute - Statute Imposing Assessment on Gross Receipts of Certain Hospitals - Taking of Property

Public Health Law § 2807-d, which imposes an assessment on a percentage of the gross receipts from patient care and all other operating income of certain hospitals, does not result in an unconstitutional taking without just compensation in violation of the Federal and State Constitutions. Although there is no precise rule as to when there has been an unconstitutional taking, the following factors should be considered in determining whether a regulation results in a taking: the economic impact of the regulation on the claimant; the extent to which the regulation has interfered with distinct investment-backed expectations; and the character of the governmental action. Plaintiff has failed to produce any evidence that the imposition of the statutory assessment will result in severe economic hardship or that it has interfered with any investment-backed expectations held by plaintiff. Furthermore, insofar as the statutory assessment was part of a legislative package aimed at reducing the State budget deficit, it adjusted the benefits and burdens of economic life to promote the common good.

Taxation - Franchise Tax on Business Corporations - Exemption for Not-for-Profit Nursing Home

Although the assessment imposed by Public Health Law § 2807-d, which imposes an assessment on a percentage of the gross receipts from patient care and all other operating income of certain hospitals, constitutes a tax on plaintiff not-for-profit nursing home's income, it is not an unlawful tax on a tax-exempt entity. While plaintiff is exempt from the franchise tax imposed by Tax Law § 209, that exemption is limited to taxes imposed by article 9-A of the Tax Law and does not prohibit taxation of the income of corporations under other laws of the State, including the Public Health Law.

 

752 of 992 DOCUMENTS


Diamond Asphalt Corp. v. Sander


97-119


SUPREME COURT OF NEW YORK, NEW YORK COUNTY


171 Misc. 2d 879; 655 N.Y.S.2d 706; 1996 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 565



August 1, 1996, Decided


NOTICE:   [***1]  EDITED FOR PUBLICATION



DISPOSITION: The applications of petitioners are denied and the petitions are dismissed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner unsuccessful bidders moved for an application seeking an order annulling the award by respondent municipal officials of street repair and reconstruction contracts to other businesses, and directing the municipality to award the contracts to petitioners on the ground that the bid selection procedure violated N.Y. Gen. Municipal Law § 103(1), which governed the award of public works contracts.


OVERVIEW: Petitioner unsuccessful bidders filed suit against respondent municipal officials seeking an order to annul the award by respondents of street repair and reconstruction contracts to other businesses, and sought an order directing the municipality to award the contracts to petitioners on the ground that the bid selection procedure violated N.Y. Gen. Mun. Law § 103(1). Petitioners contended that they were the lowest responsible bidders for the city work portion of the contracts and contended that the a new joint bidding agreement requiring contractors to submit joint bids for the utility work and city work was illegal under § 103(1). The court denied petitioners' applications and dismissed their petitions and concluded that even if petitioners were the lowest responsible bidders, the mayor had the power to bypass them under N.Y City, N.Y., Charter § 313(b)(2). The court found that the joint bidding agreement did not subvert competitive bidding and did not impose any illegal precondition on bidders. The court found that having the city and utility work performed by the same contractor would eliminate the need to coordinate different contractors' work and reduce delay and waste.


OUTCOME: The court denied petitioner bidders' application for an order annulling the award by respondent municipal officials of street repair and reconstruction contracts to other businesses, and directing the municipality to award the contracts to petitioners on the ground that the bid selection procedure violated a municipal law. The court dismissed the petitions and found that it was in the city's best interest to use the joint bidding agreement.


HEADNOTES

Parties - Intervention - Intervention by Public Utilities in Proceeding Challenging Joint Bidding Procedures for Public Works Projects Involving Municipal and Utility Work Public utilities may intervene in an action challenging defendant municipality's award of a public improvements contract pursuant to a joint bidding procedure on projects involving a combination of City work and utility work, whereby the contractors are required to bid on both the utility work and the City work as a package in the same contract, since the utilities have a direct interest in the outcome of these proceedings. The utilities are designated as third-party beneficiaries in the bidding agreement, which would be impossible to implement if the court were to hold that the joint bidding arrangement specified in the public works contracts was invalid.

Municipal Corporations - Bids and Bidders - Lowest Responsible Bidder The lowest joint bidders who were awarded public improvement contracts do not constitute the "lowest responsible bidders" under General Municipal Law § 103 (1), which unequivocally states that the lowest responsible bidder shall be awarded contracts for public work, i.e., work done on behalf of the City and citizenry, where the contract package involved a joint bidding procedure on projects involving a combination of City work and utility work in which the contractors were required to bid on both the utility work and the City work as a package in the same contract, since the utility work included in the project contracts is not public work. The utility work directly benefits and is on behalf of privately owned utilities and any benefit to the City is indirect.

Municipal Corporations - Bids and Bidders - Collateral Estoppel - Reliance on Bypass Provision The municipal respondents are not collaterally estopped by Matter of Seabury Constr. Corp. v Department of Envtl. Protection (160 Misc 2d 87) from relying on the bypass provision in New York City Charter § 313 (b) (2), which authorizes respondent Mayor to bypass the lowest responsible bidder on a public improvement project, where prior case law presents conflicting precedent with respect to the validity of bypass authority. Moreover, collateral estoppel is inapplicable because the decisions on the issue came from courts of coordinate jurisdiction and no appellate court has ruled on the issue. Further, collateral estoppel rarely if ever applies, as here, to pure questions of law.

Municipal Corporations - Bids and Bidders - Authority of Mayor of City of New York to Bypass Lowest Responsible Bidder Provision The respondent Mayor or his designees may, pursuant to New York City Charter § 313 (b) (2), bypass the provisions of General Municipal Law § 103 (1), which provides that except as otherwise expressly provided by an act or local law adopted prior to September 1, 1953, all contracts for public work must be awarded to the lowest responsible bidder, since section 313 is a recodification of prior Charter provisions which authorized bypasses and, accordingly, falls within the ambit of pre-1953 procurement procedures exempt from the lowest bidder requirement. The 1897 Charter vested bypass authority in the Board of Public Improvements. This authority was transferred to the Board of Estimate in 1938 and in 1989, when the City adopted a new Charter abolishing the Board of Estimate, the authority was transferred to the City's executive branch. All these bypass provisions are based on the same principle. That the power has passed from a group to a single official (the Mayor) is not significant; it is the continuity of the authority as an executive power that is dispositive.

Municipal Corporations - Bids and Bidders - Legality of City's Joint Bidding Procedures on Public Works Projects With respect to a public improvements contract awarded pursuant to the City's joint bidding procedures on projects involving a combination of City work and utility work, in which contractors were required to competitively bid both on the utility work and the City work as a package in the same contract and the contract was awarded to the over-all lowest responsible bidder for the combined work, the City's agreement to pay as its share only the lowest price for the City work that was contained in any bid and the utilities' agreement to pay the City the difference between the price of the lowest bidder for the City work and the City work portion of the lowest joint bid, does not unlawfully enable the utilities to determine who will be awarded the contract. The Mayor or his deputy must establish reasonable grounds why the award of the contract to a particular bidder is in the City's best interest if the bid accepted exceeds that of the lowest responsible bidder. Moreover, here the Mayor has been promised reimbursement for the difference in the public work bids, and the public will not be penalized as a result.

Municipal Corporations - Bids and Bidders - Legality of City's Joint Bidding Procedures on Public Works Projects The joint bidding procedure and award criteria set forth in a joint bidding agreement involving a combination of City work and utility work, whereby contractors were required to competitively bid both on the utility work and the City work as a package in the same contract and the City agreed to pay as its share only the lowest price for the City work that was contained in any bid and the utilities agreed to pay the City the difference between the price of the lowest bidder for the City work and the City work portion of the lowest joint bid, do not impose an illegal precondition to the award of a contract to the lowest responsible bidder. These provisions establish criteria pursuant to which a legal bypass under General Municipal Law § 103 (1) will be exercised.

 

753 of 992 DOCUMENTS


Montecalvo v. City of Utica


96-406


SUPREME COURT OF NEW YORK, ONEIDA COUNTY


170 Misc. 2d 107; 647 N.Y.S.2d 445; 1996 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 308



July 26, 1996, Decided


NOTICE:   [***1] EDITED FOR PUBLICATION



DISPOSITION: Defendant's motion to dismiss Plaintiffs' Amended Verified Complaint for failure to State cause of action is hereby GRANTED in its entirety without costs.


CASE SUMMARY:
