PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendants, municipality and public officials, sought a motion to dismiss plaintiff citizens' complaint in an action for declaratory and injunctive relief based upon causes of action under N.Y. Gen. Mun. Law § 51, N.Y. Const. art. IX, § 1(h), and the State Environmental Quality Review Act. Plaintiffs alleged that the acts of defendants in connection with a transfer of defendant municipality's water system constituted a waste of municipal assets.


OVERVIEW: Defendants, municipality and public officials, sought to dismiss plaintiff citizens' complaint that alleged that the acts of defendants in connection with a transfer of defendant municipality's water system constituted a waste of municipal assets. Defendants contended that plaintiffs failed to state any cause of action. The motion to dismiss was granted. The court held that plaintiffs failed to articulate any factual allegations, which, if believed, would have led the court to believe that official misconduct had or would necessarily lead to waste of municipal assets. The court held that plaintiffs had alleged no causes of action for waste. Further, the court found that having failed to demonstrate any colorable claim to a referendum requirement, especially in the face of a state statutory prohibition, plaintiffs had no cause of action to enforce voting rights. The court concluded that having failed to allege or demonstrate any injury in fact, plaintiffs had no cause of action under the State Environmental Quality Review Act.


OUTCOME: The motion to dismiss plaintiff citizens' complaint in a cause of action involving the transfer of defendant municipality's water system was granted based on failure to state a cause of action. The court held that plaintiffs failed to demonstrate any colorable claim to a referendum requirement. Further, the court concluded that plaintiffs failed to allege or demonstrate any injury in fact and therefore, had no cause of action.


HEADNOTES

Municipal Corporations - Taxpayer's Action - Waste of Municipal Assets - Sale and Transfer of Municipal Water System to Regional Authority A taxpayers' and property owners' action pursuant to Second Class Cities Law § 22 and General Municipal Law § 51 challenging the proposed sale and transfer of a municipal water system to a regional water authority without any referenda as a waste of municipal assets must be dismissed for failure to state a cause of action in the absence of any allegations of fraud, collusion, corruption or bad faith. The waste and anticorruption statutes require a factual nexus between illegality and waste which is totally absent from plaintiffs' pleading. While plaintiffs articulate a wide range of public policy disputes with defendants and have set forth alternatives which may be more financially remunerative to the City, they fail to allege facts which demonstrate actual damages which could be fairly characterized as waste or as traceable to official corruption. Private causes of action for public official misconduct must be read narrowly to avoid inappropriate intervention by the judiciary in public policy issues which must be decided, in the last instance, by duly elected representatives, as here, acting within an area of competence committed to their discretion in accordance with a comprehensive statutory scheme (see, Public Authorities Law § 1226-a et seq.).

Municipal Corporations - Taxpayer's Action - Referendum Requirement - Sale and Transfer of Municipal Water System to Regional Authority A taxpayers' and property owners' action challenging the proposed sale and transfer of a municipal water system to a regional water authority without any referenda as an infringement of constitutionally based voting rights must be dismissed for failure to state a cause of action due to the absence of any express constitutional or statutory provision imposing a referendum requirement, especially since the comprehensive State statutory scheme which has enabled the completion of the municipal defendants' plans and determinations specifically prohibits a referendum on the transfer of this water system (Public Authorities Law § 1226-g [1]).

Parties - Standing - SEQRA Challenge to Sale and Transfer of Municipal Water System to Regional Authority A taxpayers' and property owners' action challenging the proposed sale and transfer of a municipal water system to a regional water authority as being violative of the State Environmental Quality Review Act (SEQRA) must be dismissed since plaintiffs have failed to allege sufficient injury in fact to satisfy SEQRA standing requirements. To obtain any judicial review, plaintiffs must allege something more than the interests of the public at large; they must specifically allege facts which demonstrate some "special injury" beyond their bare identities as voters, taxpayers, rate payers, property owners, residents or citizens concerned about or involved in public affairs. Plaintiffs' allegations of harm are uniformly conclusions bereft of factual foundation, vague or prospective and uncertain.

 

754 of 992 DOCUMENTS


People v. Prisinzano


96-400


CRIMINAL COURT OF THE CITY OF NEW YORK, NEW YORK COUNTY


170 Misc. 2d 525; 648 N.Y.S.2d 267; 1996 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 301



July 24, 1996, Decided


NOTICE:   [***1]  EDITED FOR PUBLICATION



DISPOSITION: Defendant's motions to dismiss the accusatory instrument for both: (1) violation of his constitutional rights to free speech; and (2) for selective and discriminatory prosecution, are denied in all respects.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant was charged with New York City, N.Y., Rules of the City of New York, tit. 66, § 1-35(i), intimidation or disruption of Fulton Fish Market business, and N.Y. Penal Law § 240.26(1), harassment in the second degree. Defendant filed a motion to dismiss the accusatory instrument.


OVERVIEW: Defendant moved to dismiss the accusatory instrument upon the grounds that the offenses charged were unconstitutional as applied to his words, in violation of his free speech rights under both the United States and New York Constitutions, and that he was a victim of selective and discriminatory prosecution. Defendant further moved to preclude the State from introducing evidence at trial for failure to timely answer defendant's discovery demand. It was defendant's position that his speech, aimed at the three different complainants, did not constitute "fighting words," did not create a clear and present danger of violence, and did not comprise any other form of proscribable speech. The court held that the fact that defendant's threats were conditioned on the police first leaving the area did not rule out the likelihood of imminent violent response. The court found that the allegations in the accusatory instrument were sufficient to support defendant's prosecution under both the "fighting words" and "true threat" doctrines. Also, defendant's motion papers did not rise to the level required to obtain a hearing, and there were no grounds for the imposition of any sanction.


OUTCOME: The court denied defendant's motions to dismiss the accusatory instrument for both violation of his constitutional rights to free speech and for selective and discriminatory prosecution.


HEADNOTES

Constitutional Law - Freedom of Speech - Prosecutable "Fighting Words" and "True Threats" - Interference with Business Based on Verbal Threats Defendant's constitutional free speech rights will not be violated by his prosecution for having interfered with and disrupted the business of the Fulton Fish Market (Administrative Code of City of NY § 22-215 [b] [ii]; 66 RCNY 1-35 [i]) based upon his having made statements to three replacement workers in face-to-face confrontations during a union protest that "once the police leave", "I'm going to get you", "blood is going to run" and "you'll get yours", since defendant's highly provocative words constitute proscribable "fighting words" for pleading purposes, taken in the factual context of the well-publicized history of unlawful activities within the Fulton Fish Market which caused the Mayor to terminate existing contracts with defendant's unloading companies, including acts of violence, intimidation, property damage and alleged links to organized crime. The fact that defendant's threats were conditioned on the police first leaving the area does not rule out the likelihood of imminent violent response nor can an alleged police presence of unknown size and location be said to be an impenetrable barrier to violent response. Moreover, even if defendant's hostile words, voiced during a labor dispute, were of some limited value to the exchange of ideas in the course of the demonstrations, an imminent and likely threat of responsive violence by the replacement workers would outweigh any speech value attached to such words and allow for their prosecution. In addition, defendant's statements are also sufficient for pleading purposes to support a prosecution for "true threats" to physically injure the complainants. Defendant's words, on their face, demonstrate a serious threat to inflict physical injury on the complainants as soon as the police left the area. However, while the content of defendant's words is of a kind which could have incited third parties to violence against the complainants, in the absence of any allegations that third parties were present when defendant uttered the threats to complainants, the facts as alleged in the accusatory instrument do not support defendant's prosecution under the doctrine of incitement to "imminent lawless action".

Crimes - Selective Prosecution Defendant may lawfully be prosecuted for having interfered with and disrupted the business of the Fulton Fish Market (Administrative Code of City of NY § 22-215 [b] [ii]; 66 RCNY 1-35 [i]) based upon his having made prosecutable threats to three replacement workers in face-to-face confrontations during a union protest that "once the police leave", "I'm going to get you", "blood is going to run" and "you'll get yours". Defendant's conclusory allegations that the police were targeting only protestors in favor of replacement workers are insufficient to meet his heavy burden of showing selective and discriminatory prosecution. Even if defendant could demonstrate sufficient factual details as to a single instance of a crime by a replacement worker who was not prosecuted, one instance would not be sufficient to demonstrate a pattern of selective prosecution. Additionally, defendant has failed to set forth the necessary allegations to show that he was selected for prosecution because of his membership in an impermissible arbitrary classification.

Crimes - Disclosure - Sanctions There are no grounds for the imposition of any sanction against the People for an alleged late response to defendant's discovery demands (see, CPL 240.70 [1]; 240.80 [3]) where defendant's discovery demands were served by mail on February 1, 1996 and the court file contains the People's response to defendant's discovery requests, including a voluntary disclosure form, dated March 10, 1996. The requested information has now been furnished to defendant and defendant has shown no prejudice by the short delay in its production.

 

755 of 992 DOCUMENTS


People v. Frie


96-375


DISTRICT COURT OF NEW YORK, FOURTH DISTRICT, SUFFOLK COUNTY


169 Misc. 2d 407; 646 N.Y.S.2d 961; 1996 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 271



July 10, 1996, Decided


NOTICE:  [***1] EDITED FOR PUBLICATION



DISPOSITION: The motion to dismiss is denied.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant was charged with several violations of Smithtown, N.Y., Town Code § 207-2(B)(2), an anti-noise ordinance that prohibited noise disturbance from a barking dog. Defendant filed a motion to dismiss the charges on the ground that the ordinance was void for vagueness under the Due Process Clauses in U.S. Const. amend. XIV and N.Y. Const. art. I, § 6. The court issued its ruling on the motion.


OVERVIEW: The court denied defendant's motion to dismiss the charges. The court held that the ordinance was unconstitutionally vague. The court found that any imprecision which might normally attach to any of the language of the ordinance was not fatal because noise disturbance was defined in terms of the reasonable man standard, and § 207-2(B)(2) was addressed to a specific context, barking dogs. An ordinary individual should have no difficulty in ascertaining whether or not the barking of defendant's dog on the occasions forming the bases of the prosecutions was a noise disturbance. The court also found that the risk of conviction due to the arbitrary whims of defendant's neighbors or the unbridled discretion of those charged with the administration of the law was eliminated because the use of the reasonableness standard limited the application of the ordinance to those noise disturbances that a reasonable person, under the circumstances, would not tolerate. Finally, the court stated that the ordinance provided fair notice of the conduct proscribed and used an objective standard that protected the individual from conviction based on arbitrary complaint or enforcement.


OUTCOME: The court denied defendant's motion to dismiss the charges that were filed against her.


HEADNOTES

Constitutional Law - Validity of Statute - Vagueness - Statute Proscribing Dog Barking Smithtown Town Code § 207-2 (B) (2), which proscribes noise disturbance from a barking dog, defined as permitting a dog to bark for 15 minutes within a 1-hour period, is not unconstitutionally vague as applied to defendant. The ultimate test when determining whether any statute is vague or not, is whether a reasonable man subject to the statute would be informed of the nature of the offense prohibited and what is required of him. Here, the Town Code defines "noise disturbance" in terms of the reasonable man standard--sound that disturbs a reasonable person of normal sensitivities--and section 207-2 (B) (2) is addressed to a specific context, barking dogs. This context is further objectified by the requirement that the barking must be heard over the property line for 15 minutes within a 1-hour period. What constitutes and does not constitute a "noise disturbance" in the context of a dog barking for 15 minutes within a 1-hour period is common knowledge, and an ordinary individual should have no difficulty in ascertaining whether or not the barking of defendant's dog on the occasions forming the bases of the instant prosecutions was a noise disturbance. The context clothes any otherwise imprecise or inexact terms with the required definiteness, so that a reasonable man subject to Smithtown Town Code § 207-2 (B) (2) would be informed of the nature of the offense prohibited and what is required of him. In addition, since the term "noise disturbance" itself is defined in accordance with a standard of reasonableness, the risk of conviction due to the arbitrary whims of a defendant's neighbors or the unbridled discretion of those charged with the administration of the law is eliminated, the use of the reasonableness standard limiting the application of the ordinance to those noise disturbances that a reasonable person, under the circumstances, would not tolerate.

 

756 of 992 DOCUMENTS


People v. Eason


96-216


SUPREME COURT OF NEW YORK, QUEENS COUNTY


168 Misc. 2d 44; 641 N.Y.S.2d 1018; 1996 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 121



April 17, 1996, Decided


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant pleaded guilty to robbery in the second degree. Pursuant to a plea bargain, defendant was sentenced as a second felony offender. Pursuant to N.Y. Crim. Proc. Law § 440.20(a), defendant moved to set aside the sentence on the ground that his adjudication and sentencing as a second felony offender was erroneous and, therefore, illegal.


OVERVIEW: Defendant pleaded guilty to the alleged predicate felony offense on July 18, 1991, after the commission of the second felony offense on April 6, 1991. People conceded that the July 18, 1991, conviction did not meet the statutory definition of a predicate felony which could be used to enhance defendant's sentence under N.Y. Penal Law § 70.06, but alleged that defendant waived his right to contest the second felony offender status when he failed to controvert the allegations in the felony statement at the predicate felony proceeding. The court granted defendant's motion to set aside his sentence and held that defendant was improperly adjudicated a second felony offender and that the imposed sentenced was unauthorized. The court's finding was not made pursuant to the statute as the People failed to meet their burden of proof pursuant to N.Y. Crim. Proc. Law § 400.21(7)(a) that defendant had committed a predicate felony conviction.


OUTCOME: The court granted defendant's motion to set aside his sentence as a second felony offender.


HEADNOTES

Crimes - Sentence - Second Felony Offender - Waiver of Objection to Second Felony Offender Status In a prosecution for robbery in which defendant was sentenced as a second felony offender, defendant's motion to set aside his sentence on the ground that it was illegal is granted since the conviction which served as the predicate felony does not meet the statutory definition of predicate felony (see, Penal Law § 70.06 [1] [b] [ii]): in order for a prior felony conviction to be a predicate felony conviction, sentence thereon must have been imposed before commission of the present felony; however, defendant was both convicted of and sentenced for the prior felony approximately three months after the commission of the crime at issue. Although the People maintain that defendant waived any objection to his sentence when he failed to controvert the allegations in the felony statement at sentencing, there is nothing to preclude a trial court from addressing the issue on a CPL article 440 motion, which is the proper vehicle for addressing an alleged illegal sentence arising from mutual mistake of fact or law. Nor does CPL 400.21 (8), which states that "[w]here a finding [that the defendant has been subjected to a predicate felony conviction], has been entered pursuant to this section, such finding shall be binding upon that defendant in any future proceeding in which the issue may arise", require a different result, since the court's finding was not made "pursuant to [the] section", where the People, on the face of the record, failed to meet their burden of proof with respect to the defendant having been subject to a predicate felony conviction ( CPL 400.21 [7] [a]). Moreover, as defendant has already served the minimum agreed term and is currently on work release, the interests of justice require that the erroneous second felony offender status be corrected.

 

757 of 992 DOCUMENTS


City of New York v. Patrolmen's Benevolent Ass'n


96-245


SUPREME COURT OF NEW YORK, NEW YORK COUNTY


169 Misc. 2d 566; 642 N.Y.S.2d 1003; 1996 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 155



April 10, 1996, Decided


NOTICE:   [***1]  EDITED FOR PUBLICATION


SUBSEQUENT HISTORY: As Amended June 28, 1996.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff city sought a declaratory judgment declaring unconstitutional § 1 of chapter 13 of the Laws of 1996 (§ 1), which enabled the state's public employment relations board (state board) to invoke its jurisdiction when collective bargaining negotiations between the city and its police officers reached an impasse. The action arose out of a dispute between the city and defendant association.


OVERVIEW: The heart of the dispute was whether the city board of collective bargaining (city board) or the state board had impasse jurisdiction. The city sought the intervention of the city board while the association sought the state board's intervention to declare that the parties' purported negotiations had reached an impasse. The court granted the city's motion for summary judgment and held that the city board still had jurisdiction. The Home Rule provision of the New York Constitution, N.Y. Const. art. IX, § 2(b)(2), granted the city greater constitutional protection against state intrusion than other localities. The city challenged the constitutionality of § 1 of chapter 13 of the Laws of 1996 on the ground that the law's enactment without a Home Rule message violated the Home Rule provision of New York's Constitution. The court declared that chapter 13 of the Laws of 1996 was unconstitutional on the ground that it violated the Home Rule provision of New York's Constitution. Although on its face § 1 did not purport to interfere with the city's control and organization of its police department, in substance it had precisely that effect.


OUTCOME: The court granted the city's motion for summary judgment and denied the association's motion to dismiss.


HEADNOTES

Courts - Ripeness Doctrine - New York City Labor Dispute A declaratory judgment action challenging the constitutionality of a State enactment which displaces the jurisdiction of the New York City Board of Collective Bargaining (BCB) with that of the State Public Employment Relations Board (PERB) in labor disputes between the City and its police officers is not subject to dismissal on the ground that it is premature and, hence, nonjusticiable. Although neither the BCB nor PERB has determined that an impasse exists in the labor negotiations between the City of New York and the union representing its police officers, and although neither Board has ordered the parties to arbitration, whether or not an impasse exists now or in the future can only properly be determined by the agency having jurisdiction, i.e., PERB or BCB, both of which have expertise to determine such issues. Therefore, it is necessary and appropriate for the court to rule now on the issues submitted which involve statutory and constitutional interpretations and which are ripe for adjudication. Judicial intervention is clearly warranted where the heart of the parties' dispute is which agency has impasse jurisdiction. Absent judicial intervention, each agency could render a decision, only to have the potentially conflicting decisions judicially challenged, resulting in a waste of time which would adversely complicate the parties' labor negotiations.

Statutes - General and Special Laws - Jurisdiction of Public Employment Relations Board over Labor Disputes Involving New York City and Its Police Officers Chapter 13, § 1 of the Laws of 1996, which enables the State Public Employment Relations Board (PERB) to invoke its jurisdiction when collective bargaining negotiations between the City of New York and its police officers reach an impasse and which concomitantly displaces the similar jurisdiction of the New York City Board of Collective Bargaining (BCB) is a special law, i.e., one that applies in terms and effect to one or more, but not all, cities since it makes PERB procedures applicable to disputes between the City and its police union, while leaving intact the right of other local governments, such as Nassau, Suffolk, and Westchester Counties, the Town of Hempstead, and the Syracuse City School District, to opt out of PERB's jurisdiction.

Municipal Corporations - Home Rule Powers - Jurisdiction of Public Employment Relations Board over Labor Disputes Involving New York City and Its Police Officers Chapter 13, § 1 of the Laws of 1996, a special law which enables the State Public Employment Relations Board (PERB) to invoke its jurisdiction when collective bargaining negotiations between the City of New York and its police officers reach an impasse and which concomitantly displaces the similar jurisdiction of the New York City Board of Collective Bargaining (BCB), is unconstitutional because it deals with a matter of purely local concern, i.e., the day-to-day management of the municipal police department, and was enacted without a home rule message in violation of the State Constitution's home rule provisions (NY Const, art IX, § 2 [b] [2]). It has been held that the organization, operation and administration of a municipal fire department is a matter of local concern and no logical rationale is presented to indicate that a police department should be treated differently. Although on its face the challenged legislation does not purport to interfere with the City's control and organization of its police department, in substance it has precisely that effect: the still effective collective bargaining agreement between the City and its police officers covers in addition to "salaries" areas such as "leaves", "vacations", "seniority", "hours and overtime", "tours of duty", "optional work during vacation", and "overtime travel guarantee", and it would be difficult to find matters of more local concern than these. Should the State, through PERB, be permitted to invoke its impasse procedures, these purely local matters would be subject to binding arbitration, with the net effect being to permit the State to determine by way of binding arbitration not only wages, but also the day-to-day organization, operation and administration of the municipality's police department, and the job performance of its employees. If the Legislature can amend the Taylor Law by narrowing BCB's jurisdiction to exclude impasses involving its police, while allowing other localities to retain such jurisdiction and by so doing vastly increase the City's labor cost without making any contribution thereto, nothing would remain of home rule.

 

758 of 992 DOCUMENTS


People v. Bolivar


96-244


SUPREME COURT OF NEW YORK, QUEENS COUNTY


169 Misc. 2d 458; 643 N.Y.S.2d 305; 1996 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 154



April 9, 1996, Decided


NOTICE:   [***1]  EDITED FOR PUBLICATION


SUBSEQUENT HISTORY: As Amended July 1, 1996.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant, an illegal alien, pleaded guilty to a drug felony, was sentenced to a five-year term of probation, and was directed to report to the immigration authorities to clarify her status as an alien. A directive was brought to determine whether the order was unreasonable in that it contributed nothing to her rehabilitation or was excessive in that it required her to violate her rights against self-incrimination.


OVERVIEW: At the time of the plea on the drug offense, defendant's counsel did not specifically address the consequences of her plea as to her immigration status. The court concluded that the condition of reporting to the immigration authorities was not excessive. Probation was a method of offering an offender an opportunity to rehabilitate without institutional confinement. If defendant's probation was revoked, she would have been incarcerated, she would have been automatically subject to N.Y. Exec. Law § 259-i(2)(d)(i), (ii), her alien status would have been reported to the immigration authorities, and deportation procedures would have been triggered. Deportation was not a punishment but the refusal of the federal government to harbor persons whom it did not want, and alien policies were exclusively entrusted to the political branches of government. The state court did not have the authority or discretion to prevent her deportation. Because defendant's plea was knowingly, voluntarily, and intelligently made, with the advice of counsel, it passed constitutional muster. Her attorney's failure to warn of the collateral consequences did not affect the voluntariness of the plea.


OUTCOME: The court upheld the order and directed that defendant report to immigration authorities as a condition of probation.


HEADNOTES

Crimes - Sentence - Probation - Requirement That Illegal Alien Report to Immigration Authorities A condition of a sentence of probation directing defendant, an illegal alien who pleaded guilty to a felony drug sale, to report to the immigration authorities to clarify her status is reasonable and within the sentencing court's authority pursuant to Penal Law § 65.10, especially since the Probation Department has the power to notify the immigration authorities of defendant's conviction. Requiring defendant to clarify her alien status furthers the overriding purpose of probation of restoring the probationer to the status of a "law-abiding member of the community". Furthermore, since deportation is a collateral consequence of conviction peculiar to an individual and a State court does not have the authority or discretion to prevent the deportation of a noncitizen convicted of a narcotics offense (see, 8 USC § 1251 [a] [2] [B] [i]), the failure to specifically warn defendant of the possibility of deportation did not render the plea allocution improper under CPL 220.50 (7), especially since defendant was provided meaningful representation by defense counsel. Lastly, defendant's obligation to report her illegal alien status to the immigration authorities is not violative of her constitutional right against self-incrimination in a criminal case since deportation proceedings are civil in nature rather than criminal.

 

759 of 992 DOCUMENTS


JOHN P.A. MARCIN, AS AN OWNER and MARY ROSATO and RAY MARCHAND, AS TENANTS, Plaintiff(s) v. INC. VILLAGE OF HEMPSTEAD, Defendant(s).


Index No. 30144/95


SUPREME COURT OF NEW YORK, NASSAU COUNTY


1996 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 615



April 5, 1996, Decided 
July 10, 1996, Entered


NOTICE: NOT APPROVED BY REPORTER OF DECISIONS FOR REPORTING IN STATE REPORTS.


SUBSEQUENT HISTORY: Affirmed by Marcin v. Incorporated Village of Hempstead, 238 A.D.2d 389, 657 N.Y.S.2d 363, 1997 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 3887 (N.Y. App. Div. 2d Dep't, 1997)

 

760 of 992 DOCUMENTS


People v. Uzquiano


96-233


JUSTICE COURT OF NEW YORK, TOWN OF ARCADIA, WAYNE COUNTY


169 Misc. 2d 109; 642 N.Y.S.2d 769; 1996 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 148



March 7, 1996, Decided


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: The defendants were charged with driving with a blood alcohol content of .10 percent or more in violation of N.Y. Veh. & Traf. Law § 1192(2) and driving while intoxicated in violation of N.Y. Veh. & Traf. Law § 1192(3). The defendants filed motions to dismiss the charges on the ground the prior suspension of their licenses, pursuant to N.Y. Veh. & Traf. Law § 1192(3)(e)(7), subjected them to double jeopardy.


OVERVIEW: The defendants contended that the misdemeanor traffic charges, N.Y. Veh. & Traf. Law § 1192(2)-(3), were unconstitutional on the ground that the prior suspension of their licenses pending prosecution was a punishment, and the subsequent trial of the criminal charges was barred by the double jeopardy guarantee. The court held that the suspension of the defendant's driver's licenses barred the prosecution of § 1192(2)-(3), by virtue of the double jeopardy clause's proscription against multiple punishments. In so holding, the court found that 1) the defendants were subjected to judicial sanctions twice for the same conduct; 2) the suspension of the driver's licenses was solely conditional upon the commission of a crime; 3) the suspension of the driver's licenses was not solely remedial, but was intended to punish; 4) the prosecution was collaterally estopped from using any and all evidence used to support the suspension of the driver's licenses against the defendants at their respective criminal trials; and 5) the criminal prosecution of § 1192(2)-(3) were barred by the compulsory joinder or procedural double jeopardy provision of N.Y. Crim. Proc. Law 40.40.


OUTCOME: The court found that the suspension of the defendants' driver's licenses barred the prosecution of the defendants on the substantive criminal charges of driving while intoxicated and driving with a blood alcohol content above .10 percent.


HEADNOTES

Crimes - Former Jeopardy - Suspension of Driver's License Pending Prosecution for Alcohol-Related Offense The double jeopardy guarantee against multiple punishments bars defendants' prosecutions for driving with a blood alcohol content of .10% or more (Vehicle and Traffic Law § 1192 [2]) where defendants' driver's licenses were suspended by the court pending prosecution in accordance with Vehicle and Traffic Law § 1193 (2) (e) (7). The double jeopardy bar applies since suspension pending prosecution constitutes punishment, the civil forfeiture of a driver's license is for the same offense as the criminal conduct, and the civil forfeiture proceeding and criminal prosecution constitute separate proceedings. Furthermore, defendants' prosecutions for driving while intoxicated or the lesser included offense of driving while ability impaired (Vehicle and Traffic Law § 1192 [3], [1]) are likewise barred by virtue of the Double Jeopardy Clause's doctrine of collateral estoppel and the compulsory joinder or procedural double jeopardy provision of CPL 40.40 (1), which generally prohibits a separate prosecution of joinable offenses that arise out of the same transaction. Since evidence of blood alcohol content and all other evidence set forth in the supporting depositions and verified bills of particulars were considered at the arraignment and were necessary to support the judgment and penalty of suspension pending prosecution, the prosecution is collaterally estopped from using that evidence. Furthermore, without the evidence precluded by the civil forfeiture judgment, defendants' inculpatory statements in which they admit driving as well as drinking alcoholic beverages are insufficient to prove that defendants were both intoxicated and driving at the same time.

 

761 of 992 DOCUMENTS


Corletta v. Oliveri


96-186


SUPREME COURT OF NEW YORK, MONROE COUNTY


169 Misc. 2d 1; 641 N.Y.S.2d 498; 1996 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 107



February 26, 1996, Decided


NOTICE:   [***1]  EDITED FOR PUBLICATION



DISPOSITION: The award shall be vacated and the matter shall be transferred to City Court to establish the value of services rendered.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner attorney sought to vacate an arbitration award between himself and respondent client. The award was the result of compulsory arbitration pursuant to 22 NYCRR 136.


OVERVIEW: The client requested that the attorney represent him in a divorce action. The attorney spent time reviewing the client's file and doing preliminary research. At this time, 22 NYCRR 136, the statute that dictated the circumstance where mandatory fee arbitration was required, did not apply to preliminary fee negotiations. The attorney alleged that the fee arbitration should not have applied to his preliminary work because the 1994 amendment to the provision, which did apply to preliminary fee negotiations was not retroactive. The court agreed and noted that the arbitrator mistakenly excluded time spent with regard to the items required as a part of the new domestic relations procedure for attorneys. The court granted the petition to vacate the award. The court added that N.Y. Jud. Law § 474 stated that an attorney's fees were governed by agreement that was not restrained by law and the appellate division could not make substantive law by rules. Because the agreement was enforceable under § 474, the mandatory written retainer agreement was unconstitutional.


OUTCOME: The court vacated the arbitration award and transferred the matter to city court to establish the value of services rendered by the attorney.


HEADNOTES

Attorney and Client - Compensation - Mandatory Matrimonial Fee Arbitration - Preliminary Negotiations An arbitration award rendered in a compulsory arbitration proceeding pursuant to the newly promulgated matrimonial court rules (22 NYCRR part 136) regarding preliminary legal services rendered by petitioner in evaluating whether to accept respondent as a client in a pending matrimonial action with an extensive history must be vacated and petitioner allowed to be compensated for his work on a quantum meruit basis since, at the time the legal relationship between the parties commenced in December 1993, the matrimonial rules requiring mandatory fee arbitration did not apply to the type of preliminary negotiations involved in this case (cf., 22 NYCRR 136.1, as amended eff June 22, 1994). Furthermore, the arbitrator mistakenly excluded time spent by petitioner on additional work required to comply with the new domestic relations procedure.

Attorney and Client - Compensation - Mandatory Matrimonial Fee Arbitration - Validity of Mandatory Written Matrimonial Retainer Agreements An arbitration award rendered in a compulsory arbitration proceeding pursuant to the newly promulgated matrimonial court rules (22 NYCRR part 136) regarding preliminary legal services rendered by petitioner in evaluating whether to accept respondent as a client in a pending matrimonial action with an extensive history must be vacated and petitioner allowed to be compensated for his work on a quantum meruit basis since the mandatory written retainer agreements provided for by the rules unconstitutionally impinge on the substantive contract rights of matrimonial attorneys. To the extent that the rules direct matrimonial attorneys to abstain from implied contracts under threat of disciplinary proceedings, they invade an attorney's common-law right to contract and are also contrary to Judiciary Law § 474, which provides that the "compensation of an attorney or counsellor for his services is governed by agreement, express or implied, which is not restrained by law". Petitioner entered into an otherwise enforceable agreement under the statute and is entitled to reasonable remuneration for the implied contract.

 

762 of 992 DOCUMENTS


People v. Kleber


Dkt. No. V01410


JUSTICE COURT OF NEW YORK, VILLAGE OF MUTTONTOWN, NASSAU COUNTY


168 Misc. 2d 824; 641 N.Y.S.2d 488; 1996 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 13



February 8, 1996, Decided


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant moved to dismiss the information brought against him for violating the Village of Muttontown, N.Y. Gen. Ordinance § 1420.04, because the people did not bring the case to trial in the speedy fashion provided for under N.Y. Crim. Proc. Law § 30.30, the Speedy Trial Act.


OVERVIEW: The court ruled that § 30.30 only applied to crimes and that not all violations were crimes. The definition of "crime" was limited to felonies and misdemeanors, and did not include petty offenses. The ordinance, which imposed a fine for keeping an animal which caused frequent or long continued noise, was found to be a petty offense, the Speedy Trial Act did not apply. However, the court found the ordinance was not constitutional. Under the ordinance, a person could be prosecuted for violation based upon the subjective feelings of any person in the vicinity or even someone merely passing by temporarily. To be constitutional, the ordinance had to prescribe an objective standard, and it failed to do so.


OUTCOME: The court dismissed the charges against defendant because, although he was not entitled to a speedy trial, the ordinance which he allegedly violated, was found to be unconstitutional.


HEADNOTES

Crimes - Right to Speedy Trial - Violation of Village Antinoise Ordinance A village antinoise ordinance, which imposes only fines but not imprisonment as a punishment, is not subject to the speedy trial provisions of CPL 30.30 (1) (d), which requires that the People be ready for trial within 30 days of commencement of a criminal action "wherein the defendant is accused of one or more offenses, at least one of which is a violation and none of which is a crime". Although defendant herein is charged with an "offense" for maintaining a dog kennel responsible for "loud and frequent barking noises", CPL 30.30 (1) (d) further requires that at least one of the "offenses" charged must be a noncriminal "violation". Since, for Penal Law purposes, a "violation" is limited to only those offenses punishable by imprisonment (Penal Law § 10.00 [1], [3]), defendant is not charged with a "violation" within the meaning of CPL 30.30 (1) (d). Accordingly, defendant's motion to dismiss the information on speedy trial grounds is denied.

Constitutional Law - Validity of Statute - Vagueness - Village Antinoise Ordinance A village antinoise ordinance, which prohibits "the keeping of any animals which by causing frequent or long continued noise shall disturb the comfort or repose of any person or persons in the vicinity", is unconstitutionally vague since it does not prescribe an objective standard or even a standard of conduct common to the community, and it thus has the potential for discriminatory or arbitrary application. A person could be prosecuted for violation of the ordinance based upon the subjective feelings of any person in the vicinity or even someone merely passing by temporarily. Under these circumstances, it is not possible to know beforehand what is and is not legal, so that a person cannot readily conform his or her conduct to assure against violation of the ordinance. Accordingly, the information charging defendant with violating the ordinance for maintaining a dog kennel responsible for "loud and frequent barking noises" is dismissed.

 

763 of 992 DOCUMENTS


People v. Quarles


96-115


CITY COURT OF NEW YORK, ROCHESTER


168 Misc. 2d 638; 639 N.Y.S.2d 661; 1996 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 43



February 8, 1996, Decided


NOTICE:   [***1] EDITED FOR PUBLICATION


SUBSEQUENT HISTORY: As Amended March 29, 1996.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant sought dismissal of charges brought against him for aggravated unlicensed operation in the third degree, unlicensed operator, passing a red light, speed not reasonable and prudent and failure to reduce speed, in violation of N.Y. Veh. & Traf. Law §§ 511(1)(a), 509(1), 1111(d)(1), and 1180(a) and (e).


OVERVIEW: Defendant was charged by simplified informations with various traffic violations and driving without a license. Accompanying the simplified informations was a supporting printout of defendant's driving record. At a later point, the People filed long-form informations regarding the traffic infractions in an effort to supersede the simplified informations. Defendant moved for dismissal of all of the accusatory instruments on the ground of facial insufficiency and unconstitutionality. According to the court, defendant's due process rights were not violated. The court held that the high volume of traffic violations supplied a rational basis for the reasonable cause standard of review when evaluating the facial sufficiency of simplified informations. Additionally, because accused violators were guaranteed a supporting deposition upon demand, defendant had fair notice. However, the court also ruled that the People improperly attempted to supersede simplified traffic informations with long-form informations. Thus, defendant's motion to dismiss the charge of unlicensed operation in the third degree was denied, but his motion to dismiss the traffic infractions was granted.


OUTCOME: Defendant's motion to dismiss the charge of aggravated unlicensed operation in the third degree was denied based on the court's holding that there were no constitutional violations, and defendant's motion to dismiss the traffic infractions was granted based on the court's holding that the People could not supersede simplified traffic informations with long-form informations.


HEADNOTES

Crimes - Information - Simplified Traffic Information - Sufficiency of Traffic-Related Misdemeanor Charge - Constitutionality of Dual Sufficiency Standard CPL 100.40 (2), which, in conjunction with CPL 100.25 (2), provides that a simplified information charging a traffic-related misdemeanor is sufficient on its face if the simplified information and supplementing supporting deposition provide "reasonable cause" to believe that the defendant committed the offense, a lesser sufficiency standard of review than if the police officer instead elects to charge a traffic misdemeanor by information (see, CPL 100.10 [2] [a]; 100.40 [1]), is not violative of equal protection when applied to defendants charged with traffic misdemeanors by simplified informations supplemented by supporting depositions since the high volume of traffic misdemeanors supplies a rational basis justifying application of the "reasonable cause" standard of review in such cases. Similarly, the mere fact that CPL 100.40 incorporates different standards for the facial sufficiency of informations and simplified informations does not, without more, violate due process. The statute incorporates the "guarantee" of a supporting deposition upon demand, a procedure which provides the defendant with fair notice of the conduct upon which the People seek prosecution. Moreover, although the requirements for facial sufficiency of a simplified information are less than those for facial sufficiency of an information, those requirements are sufficient to insure that the defendant is adequately informed of the specific conduct to be prosecuted.

Motor Vehicles - Aggravated Unlicensed Operation of Motor Vehicle - Sufficiency of Simplified Information A simplified information charging defendant with the misdemeanor of aggravated unlicensed operation in the third degree for operating his motor vehicle on a public highway while knowing or having reason to know that his license was suspended (Vehicle and Traffic Law § 511 [1] [a]) is sufficient on its face (CPL 100.40 [2]), where the factual allegations in the officer's supporting deposition provide "reasonable cause" to believe that defendant committed the crime. The element of operation is established by defendant's admission to the officer that he had been operating the vehicle. The element of "while knowing or having reason to know" that his license or privilege to operate a vehicle was suspended is established through the officer's computer check of Department of Motor Vehicles (DMV) records and attachment of the DMV teletype indicating that defendant's license was suspended for failure to pay a fine and had previously been suspended for failure to pay a fine. Lastly, the fact that defendant's license is, in fact, suspended is also sufficiently pleaded through the officer's computer check of DMV records and attachment of the DMV teletype.

Crimes - Information - Simplified Traffic Information - Untimely Service of Supporting Deposition - Superseding Long-Form Information Traffic infractions charged in simplified traffic informations must be dismissed for legal insufficiency (CPL 100.40 [2]) without prejudice where the police officer's second supporting deposition was untimely served on defendant more than 30 days after defendant's request (CPL 100.25 [2]) and thus cannot be considered for purposes of determining the sufficiency of the traffic charges. The original deposition, while sufficient to sustain the misdemeanor charge of aggravated unlicensed operation, is insufficient to sustain the traffic infractions since any facts therein relating to traffic infractions are conclusory and based upon hearsay from unidentified sources. Furthermore, defendant's "arraignment" on a superseding long-form information after service of the second deposition is a nullity since a long-form information cannot be used to supersede simplified traffic informations (see, CPL 100.50).

 

764 of 992 DOCUMENTS


People v. Moore


96-057


CRIMINAL COURT OF THE CITY OF NEW YORK, NEW YORK COUNTY


167 Misc. 2d 994; 637 N.Y.S.2d 652; 1996 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 11



January 25, 1996, Decided


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant filed a motion to dismiss the information which charged him with criminal sale of marihuana in the fourth degree under N.Y. Penal Law § 221.40 and unlawful possession of marihuana under N.Y. Penal Law § 221.05 in the interest of justice pursuant to N.Y. Crim. Proc. Law § 170.40, characterizing his actions as a humanitarian effort to relieve suffering.


OVERVIEW: After defendant obtained relief for chronic health problems through smoking marihuana, he founded a medical marihuana buyers club to assist other sufferers to obtain marihuana for medical purposes at cost. After a transaction in a public park, defendant was arrested and charged with unlawful possession of and criminal sale of marihuana. Defendant filed a motion asking the court to dismiss the charges in the interest of justice under N.Y. Crim. Proc. Law § 170.40 which permitted dismissal if the court found some compelling factor or circumstance which demonstrated that prosecution of the defendant would result in injustice. Section 170.40 listed 10 factors which the court was required to consider. After considering each factor, the court held dismissal was not warranted under the statute because of the seriousness of the offense, defendant's admission of guilt, and the possibility that dismissal would negatively impact the public welfare by appearing to sanction defendant's willful violation of the law. The court stated that legislative acts were presumed valid absent infringement of constitutional or fundamental rights.


OUTCOME: The court denied defendant's motion to dismiss because of concerns that such action would negatively impact the public welfare and could constitute a violation of the doctrine of separation of powers.


HEADNOTES

Crimes - Information - Dismissal in Interest of Justice - "Medically Necessary" Sale of Marihuana The information charging defendant with criminal sale and unlawful possession of marihuana will not be dismissed in the interest of justice, where defendant is the founder of one of several "Medical Marijuana Buyer's Clubs" which distribute marihuana to those for whom it is medically "necessary", since upon consideration of the factors in CPL 170.40, dismissal is not warranted. Specifically, defendant is charged with a serious offense, a class A misdemeanor. Even though his actions may be portrayed as humanitarian, and he may be engaged in a mission of mercy, defendant has neither medical nor pharmacological credentials. In addition, the literature which supports marihuana's therapeutic value emphasizes that it must be administered under appropriate medical supervision. Here, the drug was not distributed in a medically supervised environment, but a public park. Also, while defendant's "club" requires documentation of a purchaser's medical need, defendant does not appear to be an appropriate person to make such determinations. Further, although well motivated, distribution of an illegal drug, whose unsupervised consumption might be injurious, cannot be condoned; in fact, the distribution of unprescribed legal drugs by unlicensed individuals is a crime. Moreover, a trier of fact is in the best position to determine whether defendant's actions were justified by medical necessity. Finally, the other factors in CPL 170.40 also weigh against dismissal.

Constitutional Law - Privileges and Immunities Clause - Sale and Possession of Marihuana Defendant's motion to dismiss an information charging him with unlawful possession and criminal sale of marihuana, on the ground that the marihuana laws violate the Privileges and Immunities Clause (US Const, art IV, § 2), is denied. Smoking marihuana receives no explicit or implicit constitutional protection and selling marihuana is equally unprotected. In addition, the illegality of marihuana involves medical, psychological and moral issues of considerable controversy, best left to the other branches of government. Finally, there being no fundamental constitutional right to possess or sell marihuana, the views of the Legislature in proscribing its possession or sale will not be disturbed.

 

765 of 992 DOCUMENTS


Adams v. Franco


Index No. 400895/95


SUPREME COURT OF NEW YORK, NEW YORK COUNTY


168 Misc. 2d 399; 638 N.Y.S.2d 1013; 1996 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 18



January 19, 1996, Decided


NOTICE:   [***1]  NOT FOR PUBLICATION


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner son brought an action against respondents, public housing authority (NYCHA) and others, to reopen a termination proceeding, to vacate the NYCHA's decision to terminate his mother's tenancy, and to grant him a lease as a remaining family member.


OVERVIEW: The son's mother was a NYCHA tenant until she was incarcerated for killing her lover in the apartment. She surrendered her right to the apartment in favor of her son, as a remaining family member. The son was allowed to stay in the apartment until the NYCHA decided to hold a hearing and terminated the mother's lease for undesirability. Under its rules, the NYCHA argued that the son could not claim remaining family status once his mother's lease was terminated. The court noted the facts of the case and concluded that the NYCHA abused its discretion in denying the son remaining family status before terminating the mother's lease. The court found that NYCHA employees had led the son to believe that he would receive a lease and had recalculated the rent, which the son paid, and that the apartment was the only home that the son had known. While the statute of limitations barred the reopening on the termination proceedings, it did not bar the son's claim.


OUTCOME: The court ordered NYCHA to accept the mother's intent to vacate and grant the son a lease. The mother was bared from future residence at NYCHA housing.


HEADNOTES

Public Housing - Eviction of Nondesirable Tenant - Right of "Remaining Family Member" to Apartment Lease The refusal of respondent New York City Housing Authority to grant petitioner, the son of the former tenant of record, an apartment lease as a "remaining family member" (see, 24 CFR 966.53 [f] [2]) before it terminated his mother's tenancy on grounds of nondesirability because she had been convicted of killing her lover in the apartment is so shocking to basic notions of fairness as to constitute an abuse of discretion under the applicable Federal regulations governing eviction from public housing for criminal activity (24 CFR 966.4 [l] [5] [i]). Innocent persons should not be penalized for the acts of other family members. Furthermore, the over-all course of respondent's actions in lulling petitioner and his mother into believing that petitioner would receive a lease in his own name if his mother, who was in prison, relinquished her rights to the apartment, and then initiating a termination proceeding against the mother months after petitioner's rent had been recalculated and accepted without apprising petitioner, the known, actual apartment resident, of the termination proceeding operates as an estoppel against respondent. Moreover, depriving petitioner of the occupancy of the apartment in which he lived for his mother's entire 17-year tenancy is an excessive penalty. Respondent could protect the safety of its tenants by prohibiting petitioner's mother from ever residing in the apartment again.

Limitation of Actions - Four-Month Statute of Limitations - Termination of Public Housing Tenancy for Criminal Activity - Right of "Remaining Family Member" to Apartment Lease A CPLR article 78 proceeding brought by petitioner, the son of the former tenant of record of a public housing apartment, to compel respondent New York City Housing Authority to grant him an apartment lease as a "remaining family member" (see, 24 CFR 966.53 [f] [2]) after respondent terminated his mother's tenancy on grounds of nondesirability because she had been convicted of killing her lover in the apartment (see, 24 CFR 966.4 [l] [5] [i]) is not time barred by the four-month Statute of Limitations (CPLR 217) where respondent never recognized petitioner as a "remaining family member" or even offered petitioner a grievance opportunity. Under these circumstances, while reopening the termination of tenancy proceedings against the mother is time barred, the Statute of Limitations does not bar petitioner from his claim to the apartment lease as a "remaining family member".

 

766 of 992 DOCUMENTS


Ontario Trucking Ass'n v. New York State Dep't of Taxation & Fin.


96-117


SUPREME COURT OF NEW YORK, ALBANY COUNTY


168 Misc. 2d 648; 640 N.Y.S.2d 377; 1996 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 44



January 12, 1996, Decided


NOTICE:  [***1] EDITED FOR PUBLICATION


SUBSEQUENT HISTORY: As Amended.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff foreign truckers sought an injunction and a declaration that the corporate franchise tax imposed by N.Y. Tax Law §§ 183, 184 was unconstitutional under U.S. Const. art. I, § 8, cl. 3 and violative of U.S. Const. art. I, § 10, cl. 2, U.S. Const. amend. XIV, 42 U.S.C.S. § 1983, and international treaties.


OVERVIEW: The foreign truckers claimed that the franchise tax was patently unfair because it was imposed on those that did minimal business in the state and included pass-through mileage in its computation. The court held that the foreign truckers failed to establish the requisite burdens of proof. The tax did not contravene art. I, § 8, cl. 3 or art. I, § 10, cl. 2 because the taxed activity had a substantial nexus with the state, the tax was fairly apportioned, the tax did not discriminate against interstate commerce, and the tax was fairly related to the services provided by the state. The tax's basis upon gross earnings apportioned according to revenue miles in the state did not violate the prohibition against multiple taxation, it did not impair the government's ability to speak with one voice because there was no federal policy that indicated disapproval, and it did not divert import revenues from the government. There was an ample connection between the foreign truckers' interstate activities and the state, and a rational basis for imposition of the tax. There was no proof that the tax transgressed any existing international treaty.


OUTCOME: The court denied the foreign truckers' action for declaratory and injunctive relief because they failed to carry their burdens of proof.


HEADNOTES

Taxation - Franchise Tax on Business Corporations - Foreign Trucking Companies - Interstate Commerce Tax Law §§ 183 and 184, which impose a franchise tax on trucking companies doing business in New York, do not contravene the constitutional prohibition against multiple taxation since the tax is based upon gross earnings, and apportioned according to revenue miles in New York State. Moreover, the statutes do not transgress any existing treaty between Canada and the United States, nor do they violate the current income tax treaty between Canada and the United States since the tax imposed is not identical to or substantially similar to the Federal income tax. Additionally, the United States-Canada Free-Trade Agreement and the North American Free Trade Agreement do not prohibit imposition by New York State of a corporate franchise tax on Canadian trucking companies, and given the absence of evidence of Federal policy which in some manner indicates a disapproval of the tax in question, there is no violation of the "one voice" test of the foreign Commerce Clause. Accordingly, plaintiffs have failed to meet their burden that the statutes contravene the foreign Commerce Clause.

Taxation - Franchise Tax on Business Corporations - Foreign Trucking Companies - Import-Export Clause Tax Law §§ 183 and 184, which impose a franchise tax on trucking companies doing business in New York, do not contravene the Import-Export Clause of the US Constitution (art I, § 10, cl [2]) since the corporate franchise tax in question does not draw revenue from the importation process and does not divert import revenue from the Federal Government: the tax is not levied on imported goods or the trucks that may transport such goods; rather, the tax is imposed upon the franchise or privilege of doing business within New York's borders.

Taxation - Franchise Tax on Business Corporations - Foreign Trucking Companies - Due Process Tax Law §§ 183 and 184, which impose a franchise tax on trucking companies doing business in New York, do not contravene the Due Process Clause of the US Constitution since the activities of plaintiffs, in availing themselves of the safe business environment, physical infrastructure and protections afforded by the State of New York, provide ample connection for imposition of the franchise tax. Moreover, the taxing formula of section 184 furnishes a rational relationship between the income attributed to the State and the intrastate values of plaintiffs' enterprises. Accordingly, plaintiffs have not met their burden of demonstrating that the subject taxes violate the Due Process Clause of the Federal Constitution.

Taxation - Franchise Tax on Business Corporations - Foreign Trucking Companies - Equal Protection - Rational Basis Tax Law §§ 183 and 184, which impose a franchise tax on trucking companies doing business in New York, do not contravene the Equal Protection Clause of the US Constitution. Inasmuch as the situation does not involve a suspect class or fundamental right, a rational basis standard of review is appropriate, and in light of the benefits that foreign trucking companies receive from the State by way of highway maintenance, traffic regulation and enforcement, etc., there is a rational basis for imposing the taxes in question.

Taxation - Franchise Tax on Business Corporations - Foreign Trucking Companies - Supremacy Clause - State Due Process Tax Law §§ 183 and 184, which impose a franchise tax on trucking companies doing business in New York, do not contravene the Supremacy Clause of the US Constitution since plaintiffs have failed to show that the statutes in question violate the Convention Between the United States and Canada With Respect to Taxes on Income and on Capital. Moreover, plaintiffs have failed in their burden to establish a violation of the State Due Process Clause (NY Const, art I, § 6).

 

767 of 992 DOCUMENTS


People v. Rodriguez


96-086


COUNTY COURT OF NEW YORK, CAYUGA COUNTY


167 Misc. 2d 260; 637 N.Y.S.2d 1014; 1996 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 24



January 4, 1996, Decided


NOTICE:  [***1] EDITED FOR PUBLICATION


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendants filed motions to dismiss their indictments for promoting prison contraband in the first degree.


OVERVIEW: Defendants, who were both prison inmates, were indicted for promoting prison contraband in the first degree. Only a small number of those crimes had been prosecuted, and defendants claimed that they had been subjected to discriminatory prosecutions, so they filed motions to dismiss the indictments. The court granted the motions holding that defendants had established their defense by showing that the prosecutor had based his decision to prosecute them on an arbitrary basis, their proposed release dates. The court further held that selecting defendants for prosecution based on their release dates violated their right to equal protection under the law. The court also held that there was no reasonable or rational explanation for using defendants' release dates as a criterion for their prosecutions.


OUTCOME: The court granted defendants' motions to dismiss their indictments.


HEADNOTES

Crimes - Selective Prosecution - Inmates Possessing Contraband within 3 1/2 Years of Release Date Defendants' motions to dismiss indictments charging them with promoting prison contraband in the first degree is granted where between January 1, 1994 and September 4, 1995 there were 337 incidents where inmates had been found in possession of dangerous contraband, but only 13 were prosecuted and the District Attorney, by letter, indicated his interest in prosecuting cases where the inmate was within 3 1/2 years of his or her maximum release date, since the defendants were selected for prosecution based on their release date, and using the release date as criterion is arbitrary and, thus, discriminatory. There is a strong presumption of the legality of a prosecution of a defendant. Having exercised discretion, a prosecutor's actions are subject to judicial scrutiny to determine if the discretion has been discriminatory. In a defense of discriminatory prosecution, the defendant must show a selectivity in prosecution, that the selectivity was intentional, and that the selectivity was based on some invidious or unjustifiable standard. Here, selectivity is proven by virtue of the numbers, i.e., 337 inmates possessed contraband and only 13 were prosecuted. In addition the selectivity was intentional in that the District Attorney admitted the selection was based on the maximum release date. Finally, although not all selectivity is arbitrary, here the selection was arbitrary. The release date has no relationship to the particular crime charged, and any legislation which proscribed possession of contraband only to persons within 3 1/2 years of their release date would not pass constitutional muster.

 

768 of 992 DOCUMENTS


In re Adoption of Michael


96-029


SURROGATE'S COURT OF NEW YORK, BRONX COUNTY


166 Misc. 2d 973; 636 N.Y.S.2d 608; 1996 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 1



January 3, 1996, Decided


NOTICE:  [***1] EDITED FOR PUBLICATION


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Applicant husband sought to adopt his wife's child, who had been conceived by his wife through artificial insemination by an unknown donor. The husband argued that no attempt need be made to find and notify the sperm donor.


OVERVIEW: The husband was not married to the child's mother either at the time she underwent artificial insemination or at the time the child was born. The sperm donor's identity was unknown to the mother. In the agreement between the medical laboratory and the sperm donor, the donor waived an rights to offspring and the facility agreed not to reveal his identity, except upon written consent. After they were married, the husband sought to adopt the child. The court held that it was not necessary to find and notify the sperm donor about the adoption proceeding. The unknown donor had forfeited any parental rights. Where a man donated his sperm to a medical facility for artificial insemination, and all parties agree that they were forever to remain anonymous from each other, it should not matter if his sperm was utilized to impregnate a married woman instead of one who was not married. While surrogate parenting contracts were against the public policy of the state, under N.Y. Dom. Rel. Law § 122, artificial insemination was not, under N.Y. Dom. Rel. Law § 73.


OUTCOME: The parties did not have to give notice of the adoption proceedings to the unknown sperm donor. The court referred the matter to the adoption clerk for such further proceedings as were needed to complete the application.


HEADNOTES

Adoption - Notice to Putative Father - Artificial Insemination of Unmarried Mother In a proceeding for the adoption of a child by his mother's husband, the parties do not need to find and notify the sperm donor whose specimen was used to artificially inseminate the mother, even though the mother was not married when the procedure was performed or when the child was born. Domestic Relations Law § 73 provides that a child born to a married woman by means of artificial insemination is the legitimate child of both spouses where they both execute a written consent form. Compliance with the statute makes the husband the father and terminates the sperm donor's right to claim paternity without notice to him. This statute does not appear to apply where the mother is not married at the time of insemination. However, the rule should not be different if the mother is not married particularly where, as here, the man donated his sperm to a medical facility to be used for the purpose of artificial insemination and all parties agreed to remain anonymous. In addition, while surrogate parenting contracts are against public policy, artificial insemination is not. Furthermore, the law regarding a woman's right to be artificially inseminated does not distinguish between married and unmarried women. The unknown donor has forfeited parental rights and notice is not required.

 

769 of 992 DOCUMENTS


People v. Yates


96-049


SUPREME COURT OF NEW YORK, NEW YORK COUNTY


168 Misc. 2d 101; 637 N.Y.S.2d 625; 1995 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 646



December 21, 1995, Decided



DISPOSITION:  [***1] Denied.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: The Supreme Court of New York, New York County, heard the State's motion in which it claimed that a defendant who claimed to have been a rape victim could not introduce expert testimony at trial regarding rape trauma syndrome without first establishing that such testimony has attained acceptance within the scientific community.


OVERVIEW: Defendant was criminally charged following a homosexual incident between the complainant and defendant. Defendant claimed he was raped and the State claimed the incident was consensual in nature and that defendant thereafter extorted money from the complainant by threatening to expose him as a homosexual and to bring charges of rape. Defendant wanted to introduce expert testimony at trial regarding rape trauma syndrome, and while the State conceded that New York law permitted such testimony without a Frye hearing for female victims, the State argued that rape trauma syndrome evidence was inadmissible without a Frye hearing because defendant was sodomized and not raped. The State argued further that there was no precedent in New York or in any other jurisdiction for accepting expert testimony of a male sexual victimization syndrome. The court found that a review of literature describing the effect of sexual assault on men revealed that male victims, both heterosexual and homosexual, exhibited a well-defined trauma syndrome similar to and parallel to that found in female victims of rape. Thus, no Frye hearing was necessary prior to the admission of the testimony at issue.


OUTCOME: The court denied the State's motion.


HEADNOTES

Crimes - Witnesses - Expert Witness - "Male Sexual Assault Trauma Syndrome" In a grand larceny prosecution arising out of a homosexual incident between complainant and defendant in which defendant alleges that he had been "raped" by complainant, defendant may introduce expert testimony at trial regarding "male sexual assault trauma syndrome" to explain his subsequent actions towards complainant and why he had failed to report the sexual assault to the police, without first establishing that such testimony has attained acceptance within the scientific community. Expert testimony concerning rape trauma syndrome has attained acceptance within the scientific community under New York law and there is nothing in the peculiar reactions of male victims of sexual assault which would place them outside the medical definition of posttraumatic stress disorder. Legal authorities, scientific writings, constitutional doctrine and logic all favor acceptance of the principle that expert testimony concerning rape trauma syndrome, as applied to male victims, is scientifically reliable and may, when appropriate, be admitted to aid a jury in understanding the conduct of the victim after the attack.

 

770 of 992 DOCUMENTS


City of New York v. State


96-159


SUPREME COURT OF NEW YORK, NEW YORK COUNTY


168 Misc. 2d 750; 640 N.Y.S.2d 951; 1995 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 690



December 20, 1995, Decided


NOTICE:  [***1] EDITED FOR PUBLICATION


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiffs, city and city officials, filed a motion for summary judgment and defendants, state and state officials, cross-moved for summary judgment in the city's action seeking to declare N.Y. Laws of 1995 ch. 83, § 206, which amended City Crim. Ct. Act § 31, unconstitutional and enjoining enforcement of the law.


OVERVIEW: The city and city officials argued that, as amended, § 31 divested the city criminal court of jurisdiction over violations of the city's administrative code. The city and city officials sought a declaration that the amendment was unconstitutional and unenforceable. Each party filed a motion for summary judgment, and the court granted summary judgment in favor of the city and city officials. The court found that the amendment to § 31 divested the city criminal court of jurisdiction mandated by N.Y. Const. art. VI, § 15(c). Such a divestiture of power could only be accomplished by a constitutional amendment. Furthermore, the legislation interfered with the city's home rule power to provide for the enforcement of local laws and to prescribe that violations of such laws might be criminally penalized. The state stated its interest in the amendment as budgetary, but this was not a substantial interest in view of the entire budget. Accordingly, the amendment was not a special law as allowed by N.Y. Const. art. IX, § 2(b)(2).


OUTCOME: The court granted summary judgment in favor of the city and city officials and denied the motion for summary judgment filed by the state and state officials, thereby, declaring the challenged legislation unconstitutional.


HEADNOTES

Courts - New York City Criminal Court - Unconstitutional Divestiture of Jurisdiction over "Violations" of Administrative Code Section 206 of chapter 83 of the Laws of 1995 (amending NY City Crim Ct Act § 31), which, as a cost-cutting measure, provides that the New York City Criminal Court "shall not exercise jurisdiction over any charge of a violation" of the Administrative Code of the City of New York, "except a violation that is classified as a misdemeanor", unconstitutionally divests the New York City Criminal Court of criminal jurisdiction mandated by article VI, § 15 (c) of the State Constitution over crimes and "other violations of law." The amendment to section 31 does not merely express an intent to decriminalize certain quality of life violations of the Administrative Code, but rather, divests the New York City Criminal Court of its jurisdiction over such offenses, which can only be accomplished by constitutional amendment.

Courts - New York City Criminal Court - Unconstitutional Divestiture of Jurisdiction over "Violations" of Administrative Code - Noncompliance with Constitutional Home Rule Procedures Section 206 of chapter 83 of the Laws of 1995 (amending NY City Crim Ct Act § 31), which, as a cost-cutting measure, provides that the New York City Criminal Court "shall not exercise jurisdiction over any charge of a violation" of the Administrative Code of the City of New York, "except a violation that is classified as a misdemeanor", in addition to unconstitutionally divesting the New York City Criminal Court of criminal jurisdiction mandated by article VI, § 15 (c) of the State Constitution over crimes and "other violations of law", is also unconstitutional as violative of the Constitution's home rule procedures (NY Const, art IX, § 2 [b] [2]). The legislation interferes with the City's home rule power to provide for the enforcement of local laws and to prescribe that violations of such laws may be criminally penalized and the State's concern is not of sufficient importance to transcend the City's interest, especially when the projected savings to the State of $ 1 million for 1995 and $ 2 million in future years is viewed in light of the State's or even the judiciary's annual budget. Accordingly, the amendment to section 31 must be deemed a "special law" affecting only New York City that was unconstitutionally enacted without the requisite home rule message from the City.

 

771 of 992 DOCUMENTS


R.J. Reynolds Tobacco Co. v. City of New York Dep't of Fin.


96-256


SUPREME COURT OF NEW YORK, NEW YORK COUNTY


169 Misc. 2d 674; 643 N.Y.S.2d 865; 1995 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 696



December 18, 1995, Decided


SUBSEQUENT HISTORY:  [***1] As Amended, August 23, 1996.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff corporate taxpayer sought summary judgment in its action in a New York trial court to declare a local tax ordinance, New York City, N.Y., Rules of the City of New York, tit. 11, §§ 602(8)(a)(10), (8)(j), and (8)(b)(11), unconstitutional under the Commerce Clause, U.S. Const. art I, § 8, cl. 3, and to enjoin defendant City of New York Department of Finance (city) from enforcing the local tax ordinance.


OVERVIEW: Under New York City, N.Y., Rules of the City of New York, tit. 11, § 602(8)(b), if a corporate taxpayer took accelerated depreciation deductions under 26 U.S.C.S. § 168 in calculating its federal taxable income, that amount had to be added back into the entire net income (ENI) for local tax purposes if the deduction was for property placed in service outside of New York. For property placed in service in New York, however, under New York City, N.Y., Rules of the City of New York, tit. 11, § 602(8)(b)(11), a taxpayer did not have to make this adjustment. The corporate taxpayer did business in New York City and in computing its ENI for local tax purposes, relied upon the system of depreciation under § 602(8)(b)(11) for its property placed in service outside of New York. The city issued a notice alleging that the corporate taxpayer owed taxes. The corporate taxpayer challenged the notice. The court granted summary judgment to the corporate taxpayer, holding that the local tax ordinances were unconstitutional as violating the Commerce Clause, U.S. Const. art. I, § 8, cl. 3, by discriminating against property placed in service outside of New York.


OUTCOME: The court granted the corporate taxpayer's motion for summary judgment and declared the local tax ordinances unconstitutional.


HEADNOTES

Constitutional Law - Commerce Clause - New York City Business Tax Favoring In-State Property Holders That portion of New York City's business tax which allows a corporate taxpayer to take accelerated depreciation deductions allowed under the Internal Revenue Code (26 USC § 168) for property "placed in service" in New York in computing its local taxes but requires the taxpayer to add the depreciation deductions back to its entire net income if the deduction is for property "placed in service" outside of the State (Administrative Code of City of NY § 11-602 [8]) is unconstitutional as violative of the Commerce Clause (US Const, art I, § 8, cl [3]) since the taxing scheme's differential treatment based solely on the situs of the corporate taxpayer's activities constitutes facial discrimination against interstate commerce and thus cannot be sustained in the absence of a sufficient showing by the City that the taxing scheme provides the only available means of advancing a legitimate local interest. By only allowing taxpayers to take advantage of the Federal accelerated cost recovery system of depreciation allowances for property "placed in service" in New York State, the New York City taxing scheme impermissibly provides a direct commercial advantage to local business and disadvantages the out-of-State property holders on a continuing basis in the hope that this will encourage relocation to New York. While States can encourage intrastate commerce and compete for the interstate commerce market, they cannot do so by discriminatorily taxing interstate commerce. Whenever a municipality attempts to foster in-State economic growth by burdening out-of-State interests, these measures constitute economic protectionism, which is flatly prohibited by the Commerce Clause.

 

772 of 992 DOCUMENTS


Waste-Stream Inc. v. St. Lawrence County Solid Waste Disposal Auth.


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


SUPREME COURT OF NEW YORK, ST. LAWRENCE COUNTY


167 Misc. 2d 542; 636 N.Y.S.2d 602; 1995 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 596



December 15, 1995, Decided


NOTICE:  [***1] EDITED FOR PUBLICATION


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff waste disposal service brought a declaratory action against defendant solid waste disposal authority (SWDA), challenging SWDA's collection of waste as outside its statutory powers. The waste disposal service sought summary judgment, dismissal of SWDA's affirmative defenses pursuant to N.Y. C.P.L.R. 3211(b) for failure to state a defense and/or because they lacked merit, and an injunction forbidding the SWDA from collecting solid waste.
