OVERVIEW: SWDA, a public benefit corporation, was created by the state legislature to establish a county-level centralized waste system to facilitate the development of integrated solid waste management. Experiencing financial difficulties, SWDA began to pick up waste at generation sites for transport to its own facilities for disposal. This action put it in direct competition with the waste disposal service and the waste disposal service alleged that such activities were outside its statutory powers. The court granted the waste disposal service summary judgment and dismissed SWDA's affirmative defenses. The court held that (1) the complaint did state a cause of action because N.Y. Pub. Auth. Law § 2048-e(4), the legislation establishing SWDA, did not include the word "collect" in the activities that SWDA was permitted to engage in with respect to solid waste; (2) the suit was not barred by the four-month statute of limitations respecting N.Y. C.P.L.R. art. 78 proceedings; (3) N.Y. Pub. Auth. Law § 2048-e(1) provided that SWDA had the ability to sue and be sued; (4) the waste disposal service had standing to bring suit; and (5) the defense of laches was unavailable.


OUTCOME: The court granted the waste disposal service's motion for summary judgment in all respects and dismissed the SWDA's affirmative defenses and enjoined it from engaging in the "collection" of solid waste or its by-products.


HEADNOTES

Public Authorities - Solid Waste Disposal Authority - Powers Defendant, Solid Waste Disposal Authority, established pursuant to Public Authorities Law § 2048-e (4), to receive, transport, process, dispose of, sell, store, convey, recycle and deal with solid waste or its by-products, may not "collect" solid waste or its by-products. Public authorities are created by statute and their powers are limited to those granted by the Legislature. Under the Public Authorities Law three separate categories of public benefit corporations are authorized to deal with solid waste: Solid Waste Disposal Authorities, Management Authorities and Resource Recovery Agencies. Management Authorities and Resource Recovery Agencies are granted, by statute, the power to collect in addition to other activities regarding solid waste. Absent in the statutory language establishing the Solid Waste Disposal Authorities is the term "collect" (see, Public Authorities Law § 2048-e [4]). In addition, the definitional section states that a Solid Waste Disposal Authority, like defendant, is a facility used, occupied or employed beyond the initial solid waste collection process (see, Public Authorities Law § 2048-b [14]). The absence of the term "collect" as a power granted to defendant was intentional, and neither an oversight nor redundant verbiage for the granted power to "receive".

Limitation of Actions - Four-Month Statute of Limitations - Declaratory Judgment Action to Construe Public Authorities Law Plaintiff solid waste collection corporation is not barred by the four-month Statute of Limitations period respecting CPLR article 78 proceedings from instituting a declaratory judgment action for construction of Public Authorities Law § 2048-e (4), which established defendant Solid Waste Disposal Authority, to determine whether defendant is empowered to collect waste from commercial and institutional generators in direct competition with plaintiff's business. Questions as to construction of a statute may be entertained in declaratory judgment proceedings commenced in Supreme Court provided there is an actual or justiciable controversy to be determined, and such proceedings are particularly appropriate to determine questions as to the interpretation of statutes and any rights or entitlements. These issues are present here.

Public Authorities - Solid Waste Disposal Authority - Powers - Right to Sue and Be Sued Defendant Solid Waste Disposal Authority, established pursuant to Public Authorities Law § 2048-e (4), has the ability to sue and be sued since section 2048-e (1) clearly grants defendant such powers.

Parties - Standing - Declaratory Judgment Action Commenced by Solid Waste Collection Corporation Plaintiff solid waste collection corporation has standing to commence a declaratory judgment action against defendant Solid Waste Disposal Authority, established pursuant to Public Authorities Law § 2048-e (4), to determine whether the Public Authorities Law empowers defendant to "collect" solid waste, which is in direct competition with plaintiff's business, based on the interests asserted and sought to be protected.

Public Authorities - Claims against Public Authorities - Laches A declaratory judgment action commenced by plaintiff solid waste collection corporation against defendant Solid Waste Disposal Authority for usurping its statutory power and engaging in collection of solid waste, is not barred by laches where defendant failed to demonstrate delay occasioned by plaintiff. Once plaintiff discovered that defendant's actions might be ultra vires, it immediately commenced its declaratory judgment action. Defendant's alleged prejudice from the delay by virtue of its capital investment in equipment to engage in collection is irrelevant because the investment had to have been made to engage in collection activities. It was only when defendant was able to, and did, engage in these activities that the plaintiff was aggrieved and had standing to commence the declaratory judgment action.

 

773 of 992 DOCUMENTS


McCall v. State


97-073


SUPREME COURT OF NEW YORK, ALBANY COUNTY


170 Misc. 2d 644; 654 N.Y.S.2d 933; 1995 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 709



December 14, 1995, Decided


NOTICE:  [***1] EDITED FOR PUBLICATION



DISPOSITION: The motions of plaintiffs for summary judgment declaring that sections 13 and 16 of chapter 119 of the Laws of 1995 are void and unconstitutional and declaring that the supplemental retirement allowances provided for in sections 1 through 11 of that chapter shall be payable on September 1, 1995 are granted.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiffs, comptroller and members of the employees' retirement system, filed a motion for summary judgment in consolidated declaratory actions against defendants, state and public officials, in which plaintiffs sought a declaration invalidating1995 N.Y. Laws ch. 119, §§ 13 and 16.


OVERVIEW: Plaintiffs sought a declaration invalidating 1995 N.Y. Laws ch. 119, §§ 13 and 16. Plaintiffs and defendants cross-moved for summary judgment. The court granted plaintiffs' motions for summary judgment, declaring that §§ 13 and 16 of were void and unconstitutional. First, the court held that § 16 violated the Nonimpairment Clause of the state constitution. Section 16 limited the comptroller's ability to act in a manner consistent with the exercise of his duties by conditioning the payment of supplemental benefits on his forbearance from bringing suit. There was no rational connection between an increase in benefits and the commencement of litigation. Section 16 also impermissibly delegated legislative power to private citizens because any employee could determine, by bringing suit, when the increase in supplemental benefits began. Thus, § 16 was invalid. Next, the court held that § 13 violated N.Y. Const. art. V, § 7 because monies contributed for supplemental retirement allowances were placed in the general accumulation pension fund, protected by § 7. Finally, the court held that its findings did not invalidate the remaining provisions of chapter 119.


OUTCOME: The court granted plaintiffs' motions for summary judgment, in the declaratory action filed against defendants, declaring that two sections of the act in question were void and unconstitutional and declaring that the supplemental retirement allowances provided for would be payable on the date provided by the legislation.


HEADNOTES

Constitutional Law - Nonimpairment Clause - Retirement and Pension Benefits - Commencement Date of Supplemental Retirement Benefits Conditioned on Outcome of Litigation Challenging Pension Fund Credit Section 16 of Laws of 1995 (ch 119) violates the Nonimpairment Clause (NY Const, art V, § 7) to the extent that it conditions commencement of the date of supplemental retirement benefits to be paid to certain former public employees (see, L 1995, ch 199, §§ 1-12) on the outcome of any litigation challenging section 13 of Laws of 1995 (ch 119), which directed plaintiff Comptroller to credit, from the Supplemental Reserve Fund, the affected employees' employers with $ 230 million towards required obligation payments. Section 16 limits the Comptroller's ability to exercise his duties as trustee of the pension fund by conditioning the payment of the supplemental benefits on his forbearance from bringing suit and penalizes plaintiffs for bringing suit. Section 16 provides no rational connection between the increase in the supplemental retirement allowances and commencement of any litigation. Further, the section impermissibly delegates legislative power to private citizens by permitting current or retired employees to determine, by bringing suit, when the increase begins.

Constitutional Law - Nonimpairment Clause - Retirement and Pension Benefits - Credit to Employers from Supplemental Reserve Fund Section 13 of Laws of 1995 (ch 119) violates the Nonimpairment Clause (NY Const, art V, § 7) to the extent that it directs plaintiff Comptroller to credit, from the Supplemental Reserve Fund, employers of certain former public employees who were granted an increase in supplemental pension benefits (L 1995, ch 19, § 1-12), with $ 230 million towards required obligation payments, since section 13 will diminish or impair the funds in the system itself, the source of those funds and the independent discretion of the Comptroller. The Supplemental Reserve Fund is not separate or distinct from the Pension Accumulation Fund, and is entitled to protection under the Nonimpairment Clause. All monies contributed for supplemental retirement allowances are placed in the general "constitutionally protected" Pension Accumulation Fund (Retirement and Social Security Law § 78 [e]; § 378 [e]). The monies in the Supplemental Reserve Fund consist of employer contributions and earnings thereon, exist only on actuarial paper and have always and only been considered an asset of the Pension Accumulation Fund. Also, the Supplemental Reserve Fund has been used as security for existing allowances and for future allowances and is permanent. No distinction is made between funds held in reserve for fixed pension benefits or supplemental retirement allowances, and protection should not be limited to the fixed pension benefits.

Constitutional Law - Validity of Statute - Retirement and Pension Benefits - Striking Unconstitutional Portions of Laws of 1995 (ch 119) A finding of unconstitutionality regarding sections 13 and 16 of Laws of 1995 (ch 119) does not invalidate the remaining portions of chapter 119, which provide an increase in supplemental pension benefits to certain former public employees. Section 16 anticipates the unconstitutionality of section 13 and could, but does not, dictate that a judgment declaring section 13 unconstitutional would invalidate sections 1 through 12. The Legislature specifically considered and rejected anti-severability clauses in chapter 119.

 

774 of 992 DOCUMENTS


Big Apple Food Vendors' Ass'n v. City of New York


96-087


SUPREME COURT OF NEW YORK, NEW YORK COUNTY


168 Misc. 2d 483; 638 N.Y.S.2d 540; 1995 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 668



December 14, 1995, Decided


NOTICE:   [***1]  EDITED FOR PUBLICATION


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff food vendors challenged the constitutionality of those portions of New York, N.Y., Local Law 15 (1995), which prohibited current permit holders from renewing more than one permit and designated 200 permits for boroughs other than Manhattan. The food vendors also sought a preliminary injunction compelling defendants, city and department of health, to use any remaining permits without regard to the restrictions.


OVERVIEW: The food vendors challenged New York, N.Y., Local Law 15 (1995), which greatly influenced the manner in which sidewalk food vendors and food vendors in public places had been doing business. The food vendors believed that the law was unconstitutional and that it would have a disastrous impact on the industry. The court denied the food vendors' request for a preliminary injunction and granted the city and department of health's motion to dismiss. The court concluded that: (1) the city and department of health demonstrated a legitimate purpose which was to enable a broader spectrum of individuals to obtain the permits and to prevent illegal trafficking of the permits; (2) the prohibition on multiple permits was rationally related to that purpose because it prevented the perpetual monopolization of permits and the charging of excessive fees for leasing permitted carts; (3) the food vendors did not have a property interest in the permits; and (4) the law did not prevent participation in the business, but merely regulated the business.


OUTCOME: The court denied the food vendors' motion for a preliminary injunction and granted the city and department of health's motion to dismiss the complaint to the extent of declaring that the local law was constitutional.


HEADNOTES

Licenses - Food Vendors - Constitutionality of Statute Prohibiting One Person from Holding Multiple Permits Administrative Code of the City of New York § 17-307 (b) (2) (c), which prohibits one person from holding multiple food vending permits, is not unconstitutional as an arbitrary and capricious act not rationally related to a legitimate government purpose, since defendants City and Department of Health (DOH) have demonstrated a legitimate end, i.e., enabling a broader spectrum of individuals and entities to obtain mobile food vender permits and preventing illegal trafficking. The prohibition on multiple permits is rationally related to that interest since it prevents individuals or corporations from perpetually monopolizing permits to the exclusion of other interested parties and prevents permit holders from charging excessive fees to those who are forced to lease the carts from them. Monopolies may exclude individuals from entering the industry and allows the permit holder, rather than DOH, to determine who may use the permits. Plaintiffs are not precluded from continuing to sell or lease mobile food vending carts or other vehicles; rather, such sale or lease may not include the permit for the vehicle. The legislation is not invalid on the ground that it renders it impossible for some individuals to continue in the business. In addition, removing the cap on the number of permits which may be issued (see, Administrative Code § 17-307 [f] [3][a]) does not resolve the issue. The City is empowered to decide the number of permits and, here, has decided that a cap protects the flow of pedestrian and vehicular traffic. Moreover, the constitutionality of the cap has already been upheld.

Licenses - Food Vendors - Constitutionality of Statute Limiting Number of Permits and Prohibiting One Person from Holding Multiple Permits - Regulatory Taking Administrative Code of the City of New York § 17-307 (b) (2) (a) and (c), which limit the number of full-time and temporary food vending permits and prohibit one person from holding multiple permits, do not violate plaintiff multiple permit holders' due process rights by allegedly depriving them of a constitutionally protected property right, since plaintiffs do not have a property interest in the permits. A license is subject to reasonable restrictions and to revocation by an issuing authority. The right to hold a license may change because it is not a vested right. Moreover, an application for a renewal license is to be regarded in the same manner as an application for a new license. Due process may prevent revocation without a hearing, but it does not guarantee a permit may be held in perpetuity.

Licenses - Food Vendors - Constitutionality of Statute Limiting Number of Permits and Prohibiting One Person from Holding Multiple Permits - Due Process of Law Plaintiff multiple food vendor permit holders were not deprived of a fundamental liberty without due process of law where the defendant City enacted Administrative Code of the City of New York § 17-307 (b) (2) (a) and (c), which limit the number of full-time and temporary food vending permits and prohibit one person from holding multiple permits. The City is vested with broad power to regulate the use of streets, to provide by local law for good government and to preserve and promote the health, safety and general welfare of its inhabitants. Accordingly, the City may enact laws which are reasonably calculated to achieve a legitimate public purpose. The test is whether the governmental decision affecting the property has been made in an arbitrary and capricious manner and without any rational basis. Here, the law does not prohibit plaintiffs from engaging in the food vending business, but restricts the number of permits each vendor may hold, to prevent monopolization and exorbitant lease charges. Although the regulation may render it impossible for some individuals to continue in the business, the legislation is not invalid. The City permitted vendors to accumulate multiple permits, and it retains the power to alter or eliminate that right without violating the Due Process or Takings Clause.

Licenses - Food Vendors - Constitutionality of Statute Restricting Number of Permits by Borough - Due Process of Law Administrative Code of the City of New York § 17-307 (b) (2) (b), which designated 200 of 3,000 full-time food vending permits for use exclusively in the four boroughs outside of Manhattan, i.e., 50 for each borough, does not violate the Due Process Clause, since defendant City's goal of ensuring that those boroughs are not underserved is legitimate and establishing 200 borough-specific permits is rationally related to that end.

Licenses - Food Vendors - Constitutionality of Statute Limiting Number of Permits and Prohibiting One Person from Holding Multiple Permits - Equal Protection of Laws Administrative Code of the City of New York § 17-307 (b) (2) (a) and (c), which limit the number of full-time and temporary food vending permits and prohibit one person from holding multiple permits, and only apply to vendors who operate on public space, but not to concessionnaires of public parks or to restaurants and vendors who operate on private space, do not violate plaintiff multiple permit holders' right to equal protection. Mobile food vendors who hold multiple permits are not members of any suspect class. Moreover, a law which regulates the right to sell food in public places does not impinge upon fundamental rights, including the right to pursue one's livelihood. Also, the law has a reasonable or rational basis, i.e., defendants City and Department of Health have a legitimate interest in enabling a broader spectrum of individuals and entities to obtain mobile food vendor permits and in preventing illegal trafficking. The prohibition on multiple permits is rationally related to that interest.

Licenses - Food Vendors - Constitutionality of Statute Limiting Number of Permits and Prohibiting One Person from Holding Multiple Permits - Vagueness Administrative Code of the City of New York § 17-307 (b) (2) (a) and (c), which limit the number of full-time and temporary food vending permits and prohibit one person from holding multiple permits, are not unconstitutionally vague since the statute does not give the Commissioner of defendant Department of Health unfettered discretion and does give notice regarding eligibility to receive a permit. The law states that permits shall be issued to persons who at the time of the application have not had a permit revoked or suspended and who satisfy to the Commissioner that they are fit and able to conduct, maintain or operate a food vending business. The potential vendors are not forced to guess at the meaning of the law's terms. In addition, Administrative Code § 17-317 details criteria for permit issuance and renewal. Also, the Commissioner's decisions are subject to the requirement that they not be arbitrary and capricious.

Licenses - Food Vendors - Constitutionality of Statute Limiting Number of Permits and Prohibiting One Person from Holding Multiple Permits - Property Interest in Multiple Permits Administrative Code of the City of New York § 17-307 (b) (2) (a) and (c), which limit the number of full-time and temporary food vending permits and prohibit one person from holding multiple permits, do not constitute an unconstitutional taking of plaintiff multiple permit holders' property, who have made significant investments in their businesses over many years, since plaintiffs have not demonstrated that they have a property interest in holding multiple permits that would invoke constitutional protection. Having given vendors the ability to hold multiple permits, the defendant City retains the power to enact new legislation altering or eliminating that ability, and that elimination does not constitute an unconstitutional taking. Also, plaintiffs have not demonstrated that defendant City and Department of Health should be compelled to issue any permits within an established permit cap that remain unissued (see, Administrative Code § 17-307 [f] [3] [a]). Although not required to maintain waiting lists until 1995, DOH informally kept such lists.

 

775 of 992 DOCUMENTS


People v. McRobbie


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


JUSTICE COURT OF NEW YORK, TOWN OF HENRIETTA, MONROE COUNTY


168 Misc. 2d 151; 636 N.Y.S.2d 975; 1995 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 623



December 1, 1995, Decided


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendants filed a motion to dismiss the charges brought against them under N.Y. Veh. & Traf. Law §1192(2) and (3) for violating the double jeopardy provisions of the U.S. Const. amend. V and N.Y. Const. art. I, § 6.


OVERVIEW: Defendants were charged with violating N.Y. Veh. & Traf. Law § 1192(2) and (3). Both defendants entered not guilty pleas and both had their driving privileges suspended pending prosecution pursuant to § 1193(2)(e)(7). Defendants moved to dismiss the charges as violative of the prohibitions against double jeopardy of the U.S. Const. amend. V and N.Y. Const. art. I, § 6. Plaintiff argued that the suspension of driving privileges was essentially civil in nature and was a remedial regulatory measure solely for the purpose of protecting the public. In its determination, the court focused its attention on whether the sanction in question was criminal or civil, and not on the nature of the proceeding. Finding that the purpose of the revocation was not remedial, but rather retributive or deterrent, the court pronounced the revocation proceeding to be criminal and thus barred further prosecution under § 1192(2). The court found that a conviction under § 1192(3) required proof of facts additional to those required for conviction under § 1193(2)(e)(7); therefore, the § 1192(3) charges were not dismissed.


OUTCOME: Motion to dismiss granted in part, because under double jeopardy analysis the purpose of statutory license suspension was not remedial, thereby barring further prosecution under one section of the statute; however, charges under the other section remained, because it required proof of facts in addition to those required under license suspension statute.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Motor Vehicles - Operating Vehicle while Under Influence of Alcohol or Drugs - Former Jeopardy - Preconviction Suspension of Driver's License Vehicle and Traffic Law § 1193 (2) (e) (7), which permits a court to suspend a defendant's driver's license pending prosecution of a defendant charged with an alleged violation of Vehicle and Traffic Law § 1192 (2), violates double jeopardy since it fails to pass the two-prong test established in United States v Ward (448 US 242). To determine a violation of double jeopardy, a determination must be made whether the Legislature indicated either expressly or impliedly that the proceeding was criminal and punitive or civil and remedial. If the penalty is civil the inquiry is whether the statutory scheme is so punitive in purpose or effect as to negate that intention. Here, the statute does not define the proceeding as civil or criminal. Located in the driving while intoxicated provisions of the Vehicle and Traffic Law, it makes no provision, even remotely, for a civil or administrative proceeding. The statute is enforced by a judicially ordered suspension in the context of the already existing criminal proceeding. In addition, its main effect is deterrence and punishment. By mandating application of this sanction in close relation to the criminal proceeding, the Legislature has created serious doubt that the sole purpose of the statute is remedial. Also, suspension of the license does not guarantee that a drunk driver will be kept off the road.

Motor Vehicles - Operating Vehicle while Under Influence of Alcohol or Drugs - Former Jeopardy - Preconviction Suspension of Driver's License In determining whether Vehicle and Traffic Law § 1193 (2) (e) (7), which permits a court to suspend a defendant's driver's license pending prosecution of a driving while intoxicated charge, violates the Double Jeopardy Clause, it is irrelevant whether the sanction, i.e., suspension of the driver's license, precedes or follows the prosecution of the crime charged. Section 1193 (2) (e) (7) makes the sanction conditioned on the commission of a crime, imposed after the motorist is arrested for a violation of section 1192 (2). Thus, a defendant is prosecuted criminally after being subject to a civil sanction for the same conduct. If the civil sanction is characterized only as a deterrent or retribution then its exaction before imposition of criminal punishment should have the same double jeopardy effect as exaction afterward.

Motor Vehicles - Operating Vehicle while Under Influence of Alcohol or Drugs - Former Jeopardy - Preconviction Suspension of Driver's License Vehicle and Traffic Law § 1193 (2) (e) (7), which permits a court to suspend a defendant's driver's license pending prosecution of a defendant charged with an alleged violation of Vehicle and Traffic Law § 1192 (2), violates double jeopardy since the license suspending statute is actually punishment. Punishment is determined by the purpose served by the sanction, not the underlying nature of the proceeding giving rise to the sanction. To the extent a civil sanction serves as a deterrent or retribution, it is irrelevant whether the sanction is monetary or, as here, suspension of the license. Section 1193 has some remedial purposes, but it cannot reasonably be labeled as "solely" to serve a remedial purpose. Also, the removal of the driver's license cannot be said solely to relate to the State's objective of removing drunk drivers from the road because removal of a license will not guarantee a remedy to the problem needing correction, i.e., the behavior of the drunken driver.

Motor Vehicles - Operating Vehicle while Under Influence of Alcohol or Drugs - Dismissal of Charges Where a charge of driving while intoxicated pursuant to Vehicle and Traffic Law § 1192 (2) is dismissed on double jeopardy grounds because the court imposed sanctions under Vehicle and Traffic Law § 1193 (2) (e) (7), the separate charge of driving while intoxicated pursuant to Vehicle and Traffic Law § 1192 (3) will not be dismissed, since the People's proof in a section 1192 (2) case rests on the introduction of a chemical analysis constituting a per se violation, while the proof offered in a section 1192 (3) charge involves whether or not the defendant's consumption of alcohol has rendered him incapable of employing the physical or mental abilities needed in order to operate a vehicle as a reasonable and prudent driver.

 

776 of 992 DOCUMENTS


New York City Transit Auth. v. New-York Historical Soc'y


Index No. 46131/93


SUPREME COURT OF NEW YORK, KINGS COUNTY


167 Misc. 2d 31; 635 N.Y.S.2d 998; 1995 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 553



November 16, 1995, Decided


NOTICE:  [***1] EDITED FOR PUBLICATION


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: In an action to recover possession of chattels pursuant to N.Y. C.P.L.R. 71, plaintiffs, who were city transit authorities, filed a motion for summary judgment declaring that a transit authority was entitled to possession of certain historical items, and directing defendant historical society to deliver the items to the transit authority. The historical society filed a cross-motion for summary judgment dismissing the complaint.


OVERVIEW: On three separate occasions, the city board of transportation (board) and/or the transit authority transferred historical items such as photographs and documents to the historical society. The transfers were recorded as gifts. The transit authority requested the return of the collections, but the historical society refused. The historical society had always publicly maintained that the collections were gifts and had asserted ownership over the collections. The court held that the claims to recover possession of the collections were time barred because the transit authorities did not commence the action within the applicable statute of limitations.


OUTCOME: Transit authorities' motion for summary judgment was denied, and the historical society's cross motion for summary judgment dismissing the complaint was granted.


HEADNOTES

Limitation of Actions - When Cause of Action Accrues - Recovery of Chattel In an action for recovery of a chattel, where plaintiff public authorities seek recovery of historical documents transferred to defendant historical society, in 1943, 1950 and 1981, all of which were recorded as gifts, the Statute of Limitations period accrued at the time of the initial unlawful possession. Inasmuch as plaintiffs seek return of the collections under New York Constitution, article VIII, § 1, which forbids city agencies to make gifts of their property to anyone other than public agencies or public corporations, the purported gifts were unlawful at the time of each transfer, and the Statute of Limitations began to run at that time.

Limitation of Actions - When Cause of Action Accrues - Recovery of Chattel - Necessity of Demand Where plaintiff public authorities seek recovery of historical documents transferred to defendant historical society, and recorded as gifts, in 1943, 1950 and 1981, pursuant to New York Constitution, article VIII, § 1, which forbids city agencies to make gifts of their property to anyone other than public agencies or public corporations, the Statute of Limitations accrued at the time of the initial unlawful possession and no demand by plaintiffs is necessary. A demand is a substantive requirement of a cause of action to recover chattels where one in possession of the chattels acquired such possession lawfully or where, as in the case of a good-faith purchaser for value, the initial possession of the chattels is not considered wrongful. Under plaintiffs' theory of recovery, defendant did not acquire the collections lawfully. In addition, New York Constitution, article VIII, § 1 prohibits all types of loans. Finally, the taking of property without right constitutes a conversion and no demand and refusal are necessary to render the defendant liable.

Conversion - What Constitutes - Good-Faith Possession The transfer of historical documents by plaintiff public authorities and their predecessor to defendant historical society, in 1943, 1950 and 1981, all of which were recorded as gifts, constitutes a conversion, even though defendant allegedly held the collections in good faith up until plaintiffs demanded their return, since New York Constitution, article VIII, § 1 forbids city agencies to make gifts of their property to anyone other than public agencies or public corporations. A transfer may be wrongful and constitute a conversion even where the defendant acted in good faith and the plaintiff was unaware at the time that the taking was wrongful. All that is necessary is that the defendant had no right to possess the property in question. In addition, theft or outright misappropriation is not a necessary element of conversion. It is sufficient if there is interference with the owner's dominion over the property to the exclusion of the owner's rights. Here, defendant has always publicly maintained that the collections were gifts and has asserted ownership over the collection.

Limitation of Actions - Three-Year Statute of Limitations - Applicability to State Entity CPLR 214 (3) is the applicable Statute of Limitations period for recovery of historical documents plaintiff public authorities and their predecessor transferred to defendant historical society, even though plaintiffs are acting on behalf of the State to recover the collections, since CPLR 201 expressly provides that the periods of limitation prescribed in CPLR article 2 apply to all actions, including ones brought in the name or for the benefit of the State. This statute waives sovereign immunity on the part of the State with respect to the Statute of Limitations, and subjects the State to the periods of limitations set forth in CPLR article 2, including CPLR 214 (3), the statute applicable to actions for recovery of chattels. Also, the State is not exercising uniquely sovereign powers here. Rather, plaintiffs are asserting ordinary property rights in an action based upon CPLR article 71.

 

777 of 992 DOCUMENTS


City of New York v. Capri Cinema


96-204


SUPREME COURT OF NEW YORK, NEW YORK COUNTY


169 Misc. 2d 18; 641 N.Y.S.2d 969; 1995 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 693



November 13, 1995, Decided



DISPOSITION:  [***1] Plaintiffs' motion against defendants is granted.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff city sought to continue the closure of defendant adult theater for violating 10 NYCRR 24-2, and City of New York Administrative Code § 7-703(e) and (l) by allowing illegal sexual activity that transmitted the HIV virus on its premises, and sought a permanent injunction against defendant landlord pursuant to the City of New York Administrative Code § 7-707(a) to prevent the operation of a public nuisance.


OVERVIEW: The city notified the adult theater that it was to have been closed unless prohibited illegal sexual activity on the premises ceased immediately. The adult theater's attempts to stop such activity failed, and thereafter based upon the city's monitoring of the continued activity, shut the premises down. The court held that 10 NYCRR 24-2 was not unconstitutional because it was rationally related to the legitimate governmental objective of preventing the spread of the HIV virus, which was the leading cause of death among adults in the city. As to the adult theater's assertion that 10 NYCRR 24-2 violated free expression, the court held that closure was no broader than needed to achieve the regulation's purpose where it was proven that the city allowed time for curative action, and that the adult theater's attempts to prevent illicit sexual activity had either failed or was merely cosmetic. The landlord, even if absent, could not escape liability from the City of New York Administrative Code § 7-707(a) that allowed for preliminary injunctions to enjoin a public nuisance because he was presumed to have knowledge of the activities and he had notice of the closure.


OUTCOME: The court granted the continued temporary closing of the adult theater, and granted a permanent injunction against the landlord.


HEADNOTES

Health - Communicable and Sexually Transmitted Diseases - Human Immunodeficiency Virus - Closure of Establishment Permitting High-Risk Behavior - Fellatio In an action to continue the temporary closing order previously granted against a movie theater pending trial for a permanent injunction, which would close the theater for one year, on the ground that the theater is violating 10 NYCRR subpart 24-2, which was promulgated to deal with the risks of multiple, anonymous sexual acts occurring in certain public establishments, defendants have failed to satisfy their burden of showing that the facts underlying the regulation are not only erroneous but the issue is not even truly debatable, since the testimony of defendant's expert was not unequivocal with respect to whether fellatio, the act most often observed by the public health inspectors in defendants' establishment, was high or low risk in transmitting HIV infection in instances involving multiple, anonymous partners. Since the New York State Public Health Council has determined that an establishment which makes facilities available for fellatio is a threat to the public health, the court cannot interfere with such determination. If the State's police power is sustainable when used to zone adult oriented establishments to prevent the deterioration of neighborhoods, the exercise of such power must be upheld when its goal is to prevent the spread of a disease that is the leading cause of death among adults aged 25 to 44 in New York City.

Health - Communicable and Sexually Transmitted Diseases - Human Immunodeficiency Virus - Closure of Establishment Permitting High-Risk Behavior - Freedom of Expression - Least Restrictive Means In an action to continue the temporary closing order previously granted against a movie theater pending trial for a permanent injunction, which would close the theater for one year, on the ground that the theater is violating 10 NYCRR subpart 24-2, which was promulgated to deal with the risks of multiple, anonymous sexual acts occurring in certain public establishments, the determination that the police power is properly invoked does not end the inquiry since the closure of an establishment such as a theater implicates the constitutional guarantee of freedom of expression, and, therefore, the means chosen to protect the public health must be no broader than needed. Although less drastic means were initially undertaken by way of a letter advising defendants in no uncertain terms that unless the offensive activity ceased immediately the theater would be closed, subsequent inspections over the next several months revealed that said activity continued unabated, and while defendants maintained that they took increased measures to police their premises, the inescapable conclusion is that nothing short of closure will eliminate the proscribed conduct.

Health - Communicable and Sexually Transmitted Diseases - Human Immunodeficiency Virus - Closure of Establishment Permitting High-Risk Behavior - Alternative State Action In an action to continue the temporary closing order previously granted against a movie theater pending trial for a permanent injunction, which would close the theater for one year, on the ground that the theater is violating 10 NYCRR subpart 24-2, which was promulgated to deal with the risks of multiple, anonymous sexual acts occurring in certain public establishments, defendants' contention that plaintiffs either arrest the violators or seek to enjoin their offensive, health-jeopardizing activity is unavailing: given the testimonial evidence of the nature of the prohibited sexual activity and the frequency of the acts taking place in the theater, to require the police to arrest patrons of the theater under little-used criminal statutes would embrace form over substance, and to first require injunctive relief in the face of the proven futility of any less intrusive solution would ignore the immediacy of the plague in our midst.

Health - Communicable and Sexually Transmitted Diseases - Human Immunodeficiency Virus - Closure of Establishment Permitting High-Risk Behavior - Enjoining Owner of Premises from Any Use Thereof In an action to continue the temporary closing order previously granted against a movie theater pending trial for a permanent injunction, which would close the theater for one year, on the ground that the theater is violating 10 NYCRR subpart 24-2, which was promulgated to deal with the risks of multiple, anonymous sexual acts occurring in certain public establishments, and the New York City Administrative Code, the contention of defendant owner of the building that because he was not given notice of the public nuisance and an opportunity to abate such nuisance plaintiffs are not entitled to a preliminary injunction enjoining him from using the premises in any way during the pendency of this action, is unavailing since section 7-707 (a) of the Administrative Code provides that a court may grant a preliminary injunction enjoining a public nuisance and the person conducting, maintaining or permitting the nuisance. The court's jurisdiction is in rem and its orders are enforced against the premises: since the personal fault of the owner is not a material consideration, a preliminary injunction may be granted against defendant owner based on the prima facie showing that a public nuisance has existed on the premises. Moreover, assuming arguendo that personal fault is a material consideration, defendant's claim that he has not visited the premises for 27 years is incredible: as an absentee landlord, defendant proceeds at his own peril, and may suffer legal consequences as a result of his do-nothing policy. In any event, defendant acquired notice of the nuisance when he was served with the order to show cause temporarily closing the theater, and since that time, he has failed to undertake any measure to eliminate the nuisance. Accordingly, defendant's do-nothing approach should not insulate him from liability.

 

778 of 992 DOCUMENTS


Robert C. v. Wack


Index No. 95423/92


SUPREME COURT OF NEW YORK, NEW YORK COUNTY


167 Misc. 2d 677; 635 N.Y.S.2d 426; 1995 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 558



October 31, 1995, Decided


NOTICE:  [***1] EDITED FOR PUBLICATION


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner mental patient sought a rehearing and review of a retention hearing in which the justices found that he was still mentally ill and in need of retention. The state moved for partial dismissal of the patient's request for a trial de novo.


OVERVIEW: The patient was a civilly committed mental patient, under involuntary in-patient treatment at a state psychiatric hospital. He sought a rehearing and review, pursuant to N.Y. Mental Hyg. Law § 9.35, of a judicial retention hearing, in which the justices found that he was still mentally ill and in need of retention. The state moved for partial dismissal of the request for a trial de novo on the issues of the patient's dangerous mental disorder and the need for his retention in a secure facility and dismissal of the patient's request for transfer to a nonsecure state psychiatric hospital. The trial court granted the state's motion. N.Y. Mental Hyg. Law § 9.35 specifically delimited the scope of jury review to mental illness and the need for retention. The issues of dangerous mental disorder and secure retention were inapplicable to a non N.Y. Crim. Proc. Law § 330.20 patient and were thus not in issue in the N.Y. Mental Hyg. Law § 9.35 retention proceeding. Transfer from a secure facility to a nonsecure psychiatric hospital was not a question under § 9.35. Hence, the scope of the jury question was limited to the issues of the patient's mental illness and the need for retention.


OUTCOME: The trial court granted the state's motion to dismiss, in part, the patient's request for a rehearing and review and limited the jury issues to the patient's mental illness and need for retention.


HEADNOTES

Insane and Other Incompetent Persons - Order of Retention - Scope of Jury Trial Where petitioner, a long-term, civilly committed mental patient who was transferred from a nonsecure mental hospital to a high security State psychiatric hospital, seeks a rehearing and review of the retention order (Mental Hygiene Law § 9.35), the scope of the jury question is limited to the issues of mental illness and the need for retention, and may not include review of the alleged dangerous mental disorder and the need for secure retention or transfer to a nonsecure hospital if the jury finds petitioner is no longer dangerous. Mental Hygiene Law § 9.35 specifically limits the scope of jury review to mental illness and the need for retention. Although the Criminal Procedure Law uses the terms "dangerous mental disorder" and "secure facility" to determine the classification of insanity acquittees (see, CPL 330.20), these terms and the classification procedure used for insanity acquittees do not exist and are inapplicable in Mental Hygiene Law proceedings. These terms and procedures do not relate to the Mental Hygiene Law definition of mental illness or the Mental Hygiene Law standard for retention of a civilly committed, non-CPL 330.20 mental patient. While the CPL 330.20 definition of dangerous mental disorder incorporates by reference the Mental Hygiene Law definition of mental illness, the CPL also requires a finding of current physical dangerousness under different standards.

Insane and Other Incompetent Persons - Order of Retention - Right to Jury Trial - Equal Protection of Laws - Due Process of Law Where petitioner, a long-term, civilly committed mental patient who was transferred from a nonsecure mental hospital to a high security State psychiatric hospital, seeks a rehearing and review of the retention order (Mental Hygiene Law § 9.35), the scope of the jury question is limited to the issues of mental illness and the need for retention; constitutional considerations of due process and equal protection do not require that the jury review issues of the alleged dangerous mental disorder and the need for secure retention. Due process does not require jury review, or even a fixed level of a type of procedural review in every case, but rather an opportunity to be heard appropriate to the circumstances. The right to jury review in a Mental Hygiene Law proceeding is limited to the existence of the mental illness and the need for involuntary institutionalization and does not extend to changes in levels of care, treatment, classification or supervision based on dangerousness, response to treatment or prognosis. Jury rehearing and review of a civil commitment embraces all elements required for civil retention, including the element of the threat of physical harm. However, relative degrees of dangerousness and levels of security appropriate under the circumstances are not to be determined by juries. In addition, transfer under Mental Hygiene Law § 9.35 refers to a judicial order moving a patient from a general hospital or psychiatric hospital operated by a State subdivision to either a State psychiatric hospital, a private psychiatric hospital or the patient's family or guardian. Transfer from a secure facility to a nonsecure psychiatric hospital is not at issue.

Insane and Other Incompetent Persons - Order of Retention - Right to Jury Trial - Questions to be Considered by Jury Where petitioner, a long-term, civilly committed mental patient who was transferred from a nonsecure mental hospital to a high security State psychiatric hospital, seeks a rehearing and review of the retention order (Mental Hygiene Law § 9.35), the scope of the jury question is limited to the issues of mental illness and the need for retention. CPLR 4102 does not entitle petitioner to a jury trial on any question of fact, but permits a party to demand a jury only if there is an independent right to a jury trial, under one of the enumerated causes of action (see, CPLR 4101 [1], [2]) or where such a right has been granted by Constitution or other statutory provision. The issues petitioner requests the jury to review, i.e., dangerous mental disorder and secure retention, do not fall into either category.

Insane and Other Incompetent Persons - Order of Retention - Appointment of Independent Psychiatrist in Conjunction with Judicial Review of Retention Order Where petitioner, a long-term, civilly committed mental patient who was transferred from a nonsecure mental hospital to a high security State psychiatric hospital, seeks a rehearing and review of the retention order (Mental Hygiene Law § 9.35), he is not entitled to an independent psychiatrist, since he failed to allege a basis for appointing an independent examiner. Appointment of an independent psychiatrist provides an additional impartial expert to aid the court's determination, and is not intended to provide a partisan expert witness for one side or the other. Thus, request for an independent examiner must be supported by adequate proof of entitlement, which petitioner failed to do.

 

779 of 992 DOCUMENTS


Dorst v. Pataki


RJI No. 01-95-ST5677, Index No. 1186-95


SUPREME COURT OF NEW YORK, ALBANY COUNTY


167 Misc. 2d 329; 633 N.Y.S.2d 730; 1995 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 495



October 9, 1995, Decided


NOTICE:  [***1] EDITED FOR PUBLICATION


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner inmates filed an action pursuant to N.Y. C.P.L.R. 78 to challenge respondent governor's order that changed the eligibility requirements for the state's temporary release program and that eliminated inmates convicted of violent felonies from future participation in the program.


OVERVIEW: The governor issued an executive order that changed the eligibility requirements for the state's temporary release program and eliminated inmates convicted of violent felonies from future participation in the program. The inmates argued that the governor exceeded his authority and impermissibly exercised legislative power in that order, and the court agreed, holding that the executive order was constitutionally invalid. The governor invaded the province of the legislature by seeking to impose by executive order restrictions on the temporary release program that were inconsistent with eligibility requirements clearly set forth in N.Y. Correct. Law § 851. The court concluded that the amendment to N.Y. Correct. Law § 851(2), giving the governor the authority to exclude or limit the participation of otherwise eligible inmates, did not retroactively validate the governor's executive order, but the amendment itself did not violate the principle of the separation of powers in its delegation of lawmaking powers to the governor.


OUTCOME: The court found that the governor's executive order that eliminated inmates convicted of violent felonies from participation in the temporary release program was constitutionally invalid and that the amended statute permitting the governor to limit the participation of inmates in that program did not violate the separation of powers principle.


HEADNOTES

Actions - Conversion of One Form of Action to Another - Conversion of CPLR Article 78 Proceeding to Declaratory Judgment Action Petitioner inmates' CPLR article 78 proceeding will be converted into a declaratory judgment action ( CPLR 3001) where petitioners sought to challenge, as unconstitutional, Governor's Executive Order No. 5, which empowered the Commissioner of the Department of Correctional Services to establish regulations barring an inmate, under certain circumstances, from participating in the temporary release program. While an article 78 proceeding is generally the appropriate vehicle to determine whether a statute is being applied in an unconstitutional manner, conversion to a declaratory judgment action is appropriate where the constitutionality of a statute is at issue, or where the petitioners seek review of a continuing policy. Here, the petition also challenges the respondents' refusal to allow two of the petitioners to participate in the temporary release program, despite the fact that they had been approved for participation prior to the issuance of the Executive Order. Although this constitutes an "as applied" challenge properly raised in the context of an article 78 proceeding, the thrust of petitioners' argument is that the Governor exceeded his constitutional authority in issuing the Executive Order. Further, this case also raises an issue as to whether the Legislature improperly delegated legislative authority to the Governor in amending the Correction Law to permit the Governor to change the eligibility categories for the temporary release program.

Constitutional Law - Separation of Powers - Validity of Executive Order Directing Commissioner of Department of Correctional Services to Issue Regulations Regarding Temporary Release Program Governor's Executive Order No. 5, which grants the Commissioner of the Department of Correctional Services authority to amend 7 NYCRR 1900.4 (c) to provide that an inmate is barred from participating in the temporary release program, under certain circumstances, violates the separation of powers doctrine. The executive power, which is vested in the Governor, is extremely broad (NY Const, art IV, § 1). Although some overlap between the three separate branches does not violate the constitutional principle of separation of powers, no one branch may invade the province of another. The Correction Law sets forth eligibility requirements for the temporary release program and provides the Commissioner broad authority to administer the temporary release program, including authority to promulgate rules and regulations for administration (Correction Law § 851 [2]; § 852 [1]). Judicial review of determinations granting an inmate participation in a temporary release program is extremely deferential. Here, the Executive Order precludes the Commissioner from exercising any discretion concerning the participation of violent felons in the temporary release program, despite the fact that the Legislature explicitly confers this discretion upon the Commissioner. By eliminating violent felons as a class from future participation, the Executive Order directly conflicts with the statutory eligibility requirements in Correction Law § 851.

Constitutional Law - Separation of Powers - Validity of Emergency Regulation Barring Participation of Certain Inmates in Temporary Release Program Where Governor's Executive Order No. 5, which grants the Commissioner of the Department of Correctional Services authority to amend 7 NYCRR 1900.4 (c) to provide that an inmate is barred from participating in the temporary release program, under certain circumstances, is determined to be inconsistent with the Correction Law, and, thus, violative of the separation of powers doctrine, the emergency regulations, promulgated by the Commissioner in response to the Executive Order, are also invalid inasmuch as they are inconsistent with the Correction Law and create a policy toward the treatment of inmates convicted of violent felonies that is not embraced by the applicable State statutes.

Statutes - Retroactive Application of Statute - Statute Authorizing Governor to Regulate Inmates' Participation in Temporary Release Program An amendment to Correction Law § 851 (2), which authorizes the Governor to exclude or otherwise limit the participation of otherwise eligible inmates in the temporary release program, does not retroactively validate Executive Order No. 5, which was held unconstitutional as a violation of the separation of powers doctrine. As a general rule, statutes are to be construed prospectively. Here, the amendment provides that it is not intended to affect the validity of prior Executive Orders limiting participation in temporary release programs. The statute contains no language indicating an intention for retroactive effect; rather the language appears to indicate a prospective effect. Thus, amending Correction Law § 851 (2) does not cure the constitutional defects in Executive Order No. 5, but codifies the authority of the Governor to implement future exclusions or limitations on participation in the temporary release program by Executive Order.

Constitutional Law - Separation of Powers - Statute Authorizing Governor to Regulate Inmates' Participation in Temporary Release Program A legislative amendment to Correction Law § 851 (2), giving the Governor the authority to exclude or otherwise limit the participation of otherwise eligible inmates in the temporary release program, is not an unconstitutional delegation of legislative authority, nor a violation of the separation of powers doctrine. The Legislature has not given the Governor unlimited authority to overhaul the temporary release program; the authority is limited to the issue of determining whether certain otherwise eligible inmates should nonetheless be excluded from the program. Inasmuch as the Commissioner is guided by considerations for the safety of the community and the welfare of the inmate in administering the temporary release program, the Governor will presumably take into account these same considerations in exercising the authority granted by virtue of this section.

 

780 of 992 DOCUMENTS


Blue Cross & Blue Shield v. McCall


INDEX NO. 7251-4, RJI NO. 0195040495


SUPREME COURT OF NEW YORK, ALBANY COUNTY


166 Misc. 2d 168; 632 N.Y.S.2d 449; 1995 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 445



September 19, 1995, Decided


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff insurance companies filed a motion for summary judgment asking for an order declaring the provisions of the State Operations Budget Bills, which granted defendant Comptroller of the State of New York (comptroller) the authority to conduct audits of the companies pursuant to N. Y. Ins. Law § 4308, to be unconstitutional. The comptroller opposed the motion and sought an order sustaining the constitutionality of his auditing power.


OVERVIEW: The companies argued that the provisions of the budget bills were unconstitutional because the New York Constitution prohibited the legislature from granting authority to the comptroller to do audits of a private corporation. The companies alleged violations of N.Y. Const. art. V, § 1 and art. III, § 1. The court held that the comptroller had the authority to conduct audits of the companies and that the comptroller's audits conducted under the budget bills were indeed audits and not administrative reviews. Nothing in art. V, § 1 limited the legislature's ability to delegate a state-authorized audit to the state's chief auditor who had the unique expertise to perform the onerous task. The court found no violation of art. III, § 1 as the legislature had the authority to so delegate. However, the court declined to require the companies to comply with subpoenas that were issued by the comptroller. The subpoenas were unduly burdensome on the companies, compliance with the subpoenas would have cost the companies millions of dollars, and a less expensive and more efficient time-consuming approach could be utilized by the comptroller in having records produced.


OUTCOME: The court did not declare the budget bills unconstitutional, but declined to require the companies to comply with subpoenas that were issued by the comptroller.


HEADNOTES

State - Comptroller - Power to Audit Insurance Companies The 1993 and 1994 State Operations Budget Bills (L 1993, ch 50; L 1994, chs 50, 60), which permit defendant Comptroller to audit plaintiff insurance companies pursuant to Insurance Law § 4308, do not violate New York Constitution, article V, § 1, which prohibits the Legislature from assigning the Comptroller administrative duties since the audits conducted under the Budget Bills are audits and not "administrative reviews". Article V, § 1 creates the Comptroller, establishes his or her powers, allows the Legislature to assign auditing functions to the Comptroller, and imposes limited restrictions on the duties which may be delegated to the Comptroller. However, this article does not limit the Legislature's ability to delegate a State-authorized audit pursuant to the Insurance Law to the State's chief auditor who has the unique expertise to perform this task. Merely because the Legislature may not assign administrative functions does not restrict the Comptroller from duties assigned by the Legislature which do not conflict with the Constitution. Thus, they are authorized under Insurance Law § 4308 (d), (e).

State - Comptroller - Power to Audit Insurance Companies New York Constitution, article III, § 1 is not violated by provisions of the 1993 and 1994 State Operations Budget Bills (L 1993, ch 50; L 1994, chs 50, 60) which vest the Comptroller with the authority to audit plaintiff insurance companies pursuant to Insurance Law § 4308 since the Legislature had the authority to delegate these auditing duties (see, NY Const, art V, § 1).

State - Comptroller - Subpoena Power When Auditing Insurance Companies Defendant State Comptroller, in conducting an audit of plaintiff insurance companies pursuant to the 1993 and 1994 State Operations Budget Bills, may issue plaintiffs subpoenas pursuant to State Finance Law § 9 and CPLR 2302. Even though the Budget Bills did not specifically provide for subpoena power, the lack of a specific grant does not prevent defendant from issuing subpoenas.

State - Comptroller - Validity of Subpoena Issued during Audit of Insurance Companies The subpoenas issued by defendant State Comptroller, in conducting an audit of plaintiff insurance companies pursuant to the 1993 and 1994 State Operations Budget Bills, are quashed where plaintiff demonstrated that compliance would be unduly burdensome and cost millions of dollars and defendant offered no estimate of actual cost. The purpose of the audit is to save insureds money and to determine whether plaintiffs are fiscally sound. The imposition of unnecessary and exorbitant administration and record-producing expenses is contrary to the public's interest. A less intrusive, less expensive and more efficient approach should be utilized by the Comptroller in having the records produced.

 

781 of 992 DOCUMENTS


In re 1,750 Cases of Liquor


INDEX #95-00679, RJI #32-95-389


SUPREME COURT OF NEW YORK, ONEIDA COUNTY


166 Misc. 2d 739; 633 N.Y.S.2d 702; 1995 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 465



September 8, 1995, Decided


NOTICE:   [***1]  EDITED FOR PUBLICATION


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff Indian tribe filed a motion challenging the seizure of a truckload of liquor by defendant New York Department of Taxation.


OVERVIEW: During a routine truck roadcheck, a tractor-trailer was discovered to be delivering liquor to the Saint Regis Indian Reservation. Papers in possession of the driver did not include the state department of taxation's manifest. No person or entity identified in the papers was listed with the department as a registered distributor of liquor. The truck was seized and the driver arrested. Thereafter, the tribe filed a motion to require the state to release the seized liquor, dismiss the complaint, grant the tribe a preliminary injunction prohibiting the department from further seizures, and imposing sanctions against the department. The basis of the motion was that the state's ability to regulate the importation of alcoholic beverages was preempted by either federal law or by sovereign immunity. Denying the tribe's motion, the court held that federal legislation had not preempted the traditional police power of the state to regulate a matter of uniquely local concern. The court further held that a tribal alcoholic beverage distributor did not possess an immunity from compliance with reasonable state regulation of such importation.


OUTCOME: The court denied the tribe's motion and denied return of the seized liquor.


HEADNOTES

Statutes - Federal Preemption - State Regulation of Liquor Importation and Distribution on Indian Reservation Federal statutory and decisional law explicitly recognizes State sovereignty over Indians, Tribes and others conducting activities on reservations and, thus, does not preempt State regulation of liquor importation and distribution. The regulation of activities in Indian country is preempted when application of a State law would interfere with the reservation self-government, or would impair a right granted or reserved by Federal law. The Federal statutes which legalized the importation and distribution of liquor into Indian reservations did not vest Tribes with exclusive jurisdiction over such activity and do not strip the States of their authority and power to regulate such importation and distribution or to enforce such regulation. In the absence of a demonstration of such a Federal legislative determination, there can be no preemption of State jurisdiction (see, 18 USC §§ 1161, 3669). Thus, the adoption, publication and approval of the St. Regis Mohawk Tribe's Tribal Alcoholic Beverage Control Act by the Secretary of the Interior does not preempt the State from regulating the transportation and distribution of liquor to the Indian Tribe and reservation.

Indians - Sovereign Immunity of Indian Tribe - State Regulation of Liquor Importation and Distribution on Indian Reservation The adoption, publication and approval of the St. Regis Mohawk Tribe's Tribal Alcoholic Beverage Control Act by the Secretary of the Interior does not preempt the State from regulating the transportation and distribution of liquor to the Indian Tribe and reservation, and a Tribe's historical claims to independence in the importation and distribution of such a commodity is insufficient to support the asserted preemption.

Indians - Sovereign Immunity of Indian Tribe - Validity of State Regulation of Importation and Distribution of Liquor on Indian Reservation The Legislature was justified in enacting Laws of 1983 (ch 508), codified at Tax Law §§ 421 and 428, which establishes licensing and record-keeping procedures for liquor transporters and distributors, as an evident, legitimate and substantial regulatory interest in controlling the effect on the State of importation and distribution of alcoholic beverages on Indian reservations. Off-reservation effects, i.e., liquor tax evasions, injure legitimate businesses and necessitated this new State regulation. Thus, granting the St. Regis Mohawk Tribe immunity from following the importation and record-keeping provisions would evade New York liquor import and distribution laws. In addition, inasmuch as the Tribe conceded New York had the sovereign power to prohibit the sale of liquor, the State must have the lesser power to regulate, including the regulation requiring that appropriate manifest documents must accompany liquor shipments and that importation be done by registered wholesalers.

Indians - Sovereign Immunity of Indian Tribe - Validity of Tax Statute Regulating Importation and Distribution of Liquor on Indian Reservation Laws of 1983 (ch 508), codified at Tax Law §§ 421 and 428, which establishes licensing and record-keeping procedures for liquor transporters and distributors, is not an impermissible State "taxation" of an Indian Tribe even though the chapter is enforced through the Regulations of the State Commissioner of Taxation and Finance (20 NYCRR part 323), is regulatory in that it requires the transporter to complete, possess and produce mandatory manifest documents, and it is also a forfeiture and a taxing statute. It is the prerogative of the Legislature to combine these several functions in one statute, to determine to amend the Tax Law rather than the Alcoholic Beverage Control Law, and to assign the regulation and enforcement to the Department of Taxation and police officers rather than the State Liquor Authority. New York Constitution, article V, § 3 clearly provides that it is a legislative function to assign powers and functions to various agencies subject only to explicit constitutional restrictions. Because the Department of Taxation enforces these discrete activities relating to the importation and distribution of alcoholic beverages does not make the enforcement impermissible.

Statutes - Federal Preemption - Failure of Indian Tribe to Register as Liquor Distributor The New York State Department of Taxation is not preempted, and may regulate, within the sphere of legitimate State activity, the transportation, distribution and taxation, where appropriate, of liquor to an Indian Tribe or reservation. Thus, the State Police appropriately seized liquor being transported to the St. Regis Mohawk reservation since the Tribe is a distributor under Tax Law § 421, but was not so registered under the Tax Law, nor licensed under the Alcoholic Beverage Control Law on the date and time of the seizure, and the Tribe caused the liquors involved to be imported into this State for sale or use within this State, but at the time of the seizure the operator of the motor vehicle carrying the liquor did not have in his possession the manifest document as required by Tax Law § 428 and 20 NYCRR part 323. The liquors were imported into this State for sale or use by other than registered distributors and, thus, the temporary seizure of the liquor is confirmed.

 

782 of 992 DOCUMENTS


Schulz v. New York State Bd. of Elections


Index No. 4797-94


SUPREME COURT OF NEW YORK, ALBANY COUNTY


167 Misc. 2d 404; 633 N.Y.S.2d 915; 1995 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 468



September 7, 1995, Decided


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff, independent candidate, sought a preliminary and permanent injunction against defendants, New York State Board of Elections (state board) and County Boards of Election (county boards), requiring defendants to furnish computerized registration and enrollment records (records) pursuant to N.Y. Elec. Law §§ 5-602 and 5-604, to independent candidates on the same basis as the records were furnished to political parties and their chairmen.


OVERVIEW: The independent candidate sought the records in order to comply with the requirements for nominating petitions needed to obtain a position on election ballots in the State of New York. Because of time constraints, the county boards were ordered to produce the records to the independent candidate at the show cause hearing. All but three of the county boards turned their records over to the independent candidate, at an agreed charge, at no charge, or for the amount to be determined by the court. The independent candidate placed in the court's escrow the amount sought by the three county boards who appeared at the hearing. The court found that the independent candidate had standing to bring the lawsuit. The court found the amounts of the charges could not exceed the direct cost of reproducing the records, and could not include the cost of compiling the records. The court held that computerized records, while helpful, were not yet required by law. The court referred the unsettled cases to a Judicial Hearing Officer to hear and report, or with the consent of the parties, to hear and determine.


OUTCOME: The court held that computerized records were not required, that the cost to the independent candidate could not exceed the actual cost of reproducing the records, and that the cost of compiling the records could not be included. The court referred the unsettled cases to a Judicial Hearing Officer.


HEADNOTES

Parties - Standing - Access to Voter Registration and Enrollment Records Plaintiff-petitioner, a candidate seeking an independent line for the Office of Governor, has standing to challenge the constitutionality of Election Law § 5-602, 5-604 and 6-140, since he is a citizen-taxpayer and a person aggrieved by the prohibitive impact of these statutes which establish procedures for accessing registration and enrollment records.

Constitutional Law - Validity of Statute - Equal Access to Voter Registration Records - Publication Charges for Records To the extent that the Second Circuit Court of Appeals held Election Law § 5-602 unconstitutional under the United States Constitution (see, Schulz v Williams, 44 F3d 48), the constitutionality of that statute under the New York Constitution need not be passed upon by a State court.

Constitutional Law - Validity of Statute - Equal Access to Voter Enrollment Lists - Publication Charges for Records Election Law § 5-604, which requires County Boards of Election to compile enrollment lists to aid ballot access by petition, is unconstitutional under the Federal and New York Constitutions in that it requires voter registration records to be provided to political parties and chairpersons, unrequested and free of charge, while all others, including independent bodies and independent candidates, must pay the costs of the publication of such records. Election Law § 5-604 serves a legitimate State interest with only a slight burden on ballot access and is fully legitimate and reasonable except for that portion that discriminates between political parties on the one hand and independent bodies and independent candidates on the other with respect to payment for records and information furnished.

Constitutional Law - Validity of Statute - Election Law Statute Establishing Procedure for Petitions for Independent Nominations Election Law § 6-140 which requires that petitions for independent nominations indicate the signer's election district, assembly district and ward, and thereby requires a candidate to obtain voter registration and enrollment lists pursuant to Election Law § 5-602 and 5-604, is not an unconstitutional burden on a candidate's US Constitution First and Fourteenth Amendment rights. Where a provision imposes only reasonable restrictions, the State's important regulatory interests are sufficient to justify the restriction. Here, the burden is not severe so as to require strict scrutiny, but slight, requiring an evaluation of whether the restriction to ballot access caused by the requirements unreasonably interferes with the effort to place a candidate on the ballot. Since the burden imposed is not severe, strict scrutiny is not applied to the statutory requirement.

Constitutional Law - Validity of Statute - Severing Unconstitutional Portion of Election Law Statute Inasmuch as Election Law § 5-602 and 5-604 are constitutional to the extent that they require County Boards of Election to compile voter registration and enrollment lists to aid ballot access by petition, but are unconstitutional in that they provide these records free of charge to some political entities, but not others, the payment subsections may be severed and deleted and Public Officers Law § 87, which prescribes a charge for information of not more than the "actual cost" of "reproducing" the record furnished, may be substituted since the information compiling sections of Election Law § 5-602 and 5-604 are not inextricably intertwined with the payment subsections.

Elections - Registration - Cost of Reproduction of Voter Registration and Enrollment Lists The costs of producing and compiling the voter registration and enrollment lists in Election Law § 5-602 and 5-604 are to be borne by the respective counties from their general funds without passing the cost on to electoral candidates seeking the information. The cost to political parties, bodies and candidates, for registration and enrollment lists should not exceed the actual cost of reproducing such records and information. The actual cost of reproduction includes the most direct costs involved in reproduction and does not include indirect or compilation costs, and should not constitute a subsidy to any other function of government. The charge includes costs commencing only from the time the record is ready for reproduction and is requested. That which is not necessary to a State's legitimate interest in holding elections with a minimum of complexity and devoid of fraud, constitutes an unconstitutional burden and must be eliminated. This includes all charges to potential candidates not directly related to the reproduction of the information or records requested.

 

783 of 992 DOCUMENTS


Brady v. A Certain Teacher


INDEX #95/05095


SUPREME COURT OF NEW YORK, SUFFOLK COUNTY


166 Misc. 2d 566; 632 N.Y.S.2d 418; 1995 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 427



September 5, 1995, Decided


NOTICE:  [***1] EDITED FOR PUBLICATION


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff school district sought a declaratory judgment against defendant teacher that N.Y. Educ. Law §§ 3012, 3020-a violated N.Y. Const. art. VIII, § 1 because they required plaintiff to pay defendant after he was suspended, that N.Y. Educ. Law § 3015 required plaintiff to withhold defendant's salary, that §§ 3012, 3020-a violated U.S. Const. art. 1, § 10, and that §§ 3012, 3020-a violated N.Y. Const. art. IX, § 1.


OVERVIEW: Defendant teacher was suspended from teaching and told not to return to an office position pending a disciplinary hearing. Plaintiff school district brought an action in which it challenged, on a constitutional basis, state laws that required plaintiff to have paid defendant's salary during his suspension. The court issued a declaratory judgment in which it held that N.Y. Educ. Law §§ 3012, 3020-a did not violate N.Y. Const. art. VIII, § 1 because the payments were not were not gifts of public monies, but rather a condition of defendant's employment. The court held that N.Y. Educ. Law § 3015 did not require plaintiff to withhold defendant's salary because that section did not affect the salary right of tenured teachers. The court found that §§ 3012, 3020 did not violate U.S. Const. art. 1, § 10 because they did not impair an existing collective bargaining agreement between plaintiff and defendant's agent because the agreement was silent as to salary payments during periods of suspension. The court also held that §§ 3012, 3020 did not violate N.Y. Const. art. IX, § 1 because that section did not place the burden of providing a public education on plaintiff.


OUTCOME: The court held that a state law that required plaintiff school district to have paid defendant teacher after he was suspended did not violate the state constitution because defendant's salary was a condition of his employment, that the law did not require plaintiff to withhold defendant's salary, that the law did not affect students' education rights, and that the law did not violate the Contracts Clause of the U.S. Constitution.


HEADNOTES

Constitutional Law - Validity of Statute - Gift of Public Moneys - Continuation of Teacher's Salary and Employment Benefits Pending Disciplinary Proceedings Education Law §§ 3012 and 3020-a, to the extent that they require a school board to continue to pay salary and employment benefits to a teacher who has been suspended pursuant to Education Law § 3020-a even when the teacher is rendering no meaningful services during the pendency of disciplinary proceedings, do not violate, as an inappropriate gift of public monies, New York Constitution, article VIII, § l, which was enacted to curb raids on the public purse for the benefit of favored individuals of enterprises furnishing no corresponding benefit or consideration to the State or locality. Granting pensions, vacations, military leave and sick leave to public employees are conditions of employment and not gifts of public money. Thus, the payment of salary and other employment benefits to a teacher involved in a section 3020-a proceeding must be viewed as a condition or component of employment enjoyed by the tenured teacher and not a gift of public monies. Withholding salary and benefits prior to the hearing and determination would deprive the tenured teacher of his or her constitutionally protected property interest in continued employment and compensation without due process of law.
