Constitutional Law - Contract Clause - Continuation of Teacher's Salary and Employment Benefits Pending Disciplinary Proceedings Education Law §§ 3012 and 3020-a, to the extent that they require a school board to pay salary and other employment benefits to a teacher who has been suspended pursuant to Education Law § 3020-a and who, thus, does not perform the contracted services under the collective bargaining agreement, do not violate the Contract Clause of United States Constitution, article I, § 10 and do not substantially impair the contract between the board of education and the collective bargaining unit for the teacher. The collective bargaining agreement is silent on the issue of paying salary to a teacher suspended pursuant to section 3020-a. In addition, a provision for a payless suspension of a tenured teacher pending resolution of disciplinary charges does not violate the Education Law and may properly be the term of a negotiated agreement. Thus, the provision does not violate the Contract Clause.

Constitutional Law - Validity of Statute - Termination of Tenured Teacher Education Law §§ 3012 and 3020-a, which place the burden of proof upon boards of education who seek to terminate a tenured teacher pursuant to Education Law § 3020-a, do not violate New York Constitution, article XI, § 1, which provides that the Legislature is required to provide for the maintenance and support of a system of free common schools, and do not limit the rights of the students of such a teacher to obtain public education and instruction within the meaning of article XI. The Constitution places the obligation of maintaining and supporting a system of public schools upon the Legislature, and not the local school boards. Also, there is no fundamental right to education or to a minimum level of education under the State Constitution or the Federal Constitution.

Schools - Teachers - Paying Salary and Employment Benefits to Teacher Suspended Pending Disciplinary Proceeding Education Law § 3015 (3), which prevents a school district from paying a teacher's salary in advance of rendering service, does not prohibit a board of education from paying salary and other employment benefits to a teacher who has been suspended pending a disciplinary proceeding under Education Law § 3020-a, even where the teacher refuses or fails to render meaningful services during the proceeding. Section 3015 provides authority for school districts to establish an orderly payroll process. Subdivision (2) specifically provides that the statute cannot alter the provisions of section 3012, which governs tenure. Reading section 3012 in conjunction with section 3020-a, which governs disciplinary procedures and penalties concerning persons enjoying tenure as provided in section 3012, reveals that section 3020-a may not be altered by section 3015. Thus, section 3015 (3) cannot interfere with sections 3012 and 3020-a.

Schools - Teachers - Paying Salary and Employment Benefits to Teacher Suspended Pending Disciplinary Proceeding Where defendant teacher was suspended pending disciplinary proceedings pursuant to Education Law § 3020-a, was reassigned to perform work on a curriculum, and was later ordered to leave upon the allegation that his work was inadequate, the school district may not withhold pay from the teacher during the period of suspension on the ground that the teacher refused to perform the assigned nonteaching duties. A tenured teacher suspended with pay may be assigned to a nonteaching assignment. In the event that a teacher appears for assigned tasks but fails to adequately perform the tasks, the teacher may be charged with a second set of charges for such insubordination or misconduct, be subject to dismissal after a hearing pursuant to section 3020-a, and, if the teacher unjustifiably failed to accept a reassignment, any claim to salary may be barred. Here, however, the charges filed against the teacher do not include any charges with respect to his work performance during the reassignment and no supplemental charges to that effect were filed. The teacher was sent home from the reassignment and directed not to return to work. Thus, the school district cannot withhold his salary during the period of suspension pending hearing and determination of the disciplinary charges filed.

 

784 of 992 DOCUMENTS


People v. Malon


Docket No. 95R002032


CRIMINAL COURT OF THE CITY OF NEW YORK, RICHMOND COUNTY


166 Misc. 2d 423; 633 N.Y.S.2d 697; 1995 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 503



August 29, 1995, Decided


NOTICE:  [***1] EDITED FOR PUBLICATION


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant filed a motion to dismiss the information on the ground that it failed to set forth actual allegations to support a charge of one count of an attempt to commit a violation of N.Y. Veh. & Traf. Law § 415-a (1).


OVERVIEW: The court denied defendant's motion to dismiss the information. The court found that the information alleged that the deponent police officer observed defendant in possession of numerous motor vehicles at various stages of repair, as well as electric saws and other tools commonly used for the purpose of dismantling motor vehicles. The information provided that the premises in question was a motor vehicle repair shop bearing a sign identifying it as a business, and the police officer was told by defendant that the latter was the owner of the business. The court also found that the information asserted that defendant did not possess a valid registration for the business of dismantling motor vehicles. The court was satisfied that the nonhearsay factual allegations in the information before it, taken collectively, satisfied the requirements of a valid information.


OUTCOME: Defendant's motion for an order dismissing the information as facially defective was denied.


HEADNOTES

Motor Vehicles - Vehicle Dismantlers - Sufficiency of Information The information charging defendant with attempting to commit a violation of Vehicle and Traffic Law § 415-a (1), which mandates that a person must be a registered vehicle dismantler in order to engage in the business of vehicle dismantling, is sufficient based on allegations that: the deponent police officer observed defendant in possession of "numerous" motor vehicles at various stages of repair, as well as electric saws and "other tools commonly used for the purpose of dismantling motor vehicles"; the premises was a motor vehicle repair shop bearing a sign identifying it as a business; and deponent was told by defendant that the latter was then the owner of the business; further, the information asserts that defendant did not possess a valid registration for the business of dismantling motor vehicles. To be sufficient under Vehicle and Traffic Law § 415-a (1), the information must allege that the accused is engaged in the business of acquiring motor vehicles for the purpose of dismantling them for parts or for resale and that a requisite registration had not been issued to defendant. Proof of the first element is satisfied by circumstantial evidence including police observation of facts which, taken together, would constitute circumstantial evidence that defendant was a dismantler.

 

785 of 992 DOCUMENTS


Bernard v. Scharf


Index No. HP 5483/94


CIVIL COURT OF THE CITY OF NEW YORK, NEW YORK COUNTY


167 Misc. 2d 502; 634 N.Y.S.2d 919; 1995 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 519



August 29, 1995, Decided


NOTICE:  [***1] EDITED FOR PUBLICATION


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner tenants sought an order compelling respondent landlords to repair a cooperative after a fire and restore its habitability.


OVERVIEW: A fire occurred in the upper part of a cooperative owned by the landlords, causing extensive damage and rendering the building uninhabitable. The landlords underinsured the building to save money, and did not believe it was economical to restore the building so the tenants could move back in. The tenants filed an action to force the landlords to restore the building. The landlords argued that an order forcing them to make repairs that were economically infeasible would amount to an unconstitutional taking in violation of the Fifth and Fourteenth Amendments. The court found that the marine rule did not apply to landlords' building because it was not a commercial building, that the landlords had a statutory obligation to keep the building habitable, that the reduction in insurance coverage was a breach of the tenants' proprietary leases, and that the landlords could not use economic infeasibility as a valid defense to the tenants' action.


OUTCOME: The court held in favor of the tenants and ordered the landlords to return the building to a safe and habitable condition within eight months.


HEADNOTES

Landlord and Tenant - Rent Regulation - Restoration of Fire Damaged Building - Applicability of Marine Duty The marine duty, which provides that if the cost of restoration of a building to the condition it was in immediately preceding a fire is more than one half the value of the building prior to the fire, then the building is deemed totally destroyed and repair is not required, is inapplicable in determining an owner's duty in a Housing Part proceeding commenced by petitioner rent-stabilized tenants and proprietary lessees of a building that was severely damaged by fire, since the marine duty applies to commercial buildings. Focusing on economic gain, the duty gives no consideration to protected residential tenancies or the fact that families' homes are involved. In addition, rent regulations make application of the marine duty to residential property contrary to public policy. The owner must maintain the residential premises in a safe and habitable condition (Multiple Dwelling Law § 78; Administrative Code of City of NY § 27-2005), and cannot give up on a residential building, without seeking prior permission from the appropriate governmental agency. Even if the marine rule were applicable, it is not warranted here. Factors other than the application of the 50% valuation should be considered. Petitioners' rights and interests must be considered. Protected tenancies and cooperative apartments with substantial financial investment are at stake.

Landlord and Tenant - Rent Regulation - "Owner" Defined Petitioners, rent-stabilized tenants and proprietary lessees, appropriately commenced a Housing Part proceeding under CCA 110 (a) (4) against respondents, manager of the premises and his son who was responsible for the day-to-day management functions of the building under the direction of the father, since under Administrative Code of the City of New York § 27-2005 (45), the term "owner" includes an agent or any other person directly or indirectly in control of a dwelling. Respondent manager was directly in control of the premises and made all the important decisions, while respondent son was responsible for the day-to-day management functions.

Landlord and Tenant - Rent Regulation - Restoration of Fire Damaged Building - Economic Infeasibility Defense - Proof of Cost In a Housing Part proceeding where petitioners, rent-stabilized tenants and proprietary lessees, seek restoration of a building that was severely destroyed by fire, respondents may not rely on the affirmative defense of economic infeasibility, if available, to support nonrestoration since they failed to prove the difference between the cost of restoring the building and the cost of not doing so, while remaining in compliance with their obligations to the State and City of New York and to the individual petitioners, rent-stabilized tenants and proprietary lessees. Respondents cannot abandon the property (Multiple Dwelling Law § 78; Administrative Code of City of NY § 27-2005); thus, they must either demolish the building or restore it and bring it into compliance with New York State and City statutes. The rent-stabilized tenants and proprietary lessees have rights which cannot merely be ignored. The vacate order issued by the City did not terminate the tenancies, but required the owner to correct the conditions (Administrative Code § 27-2140 [c] [1]). Here, respondents failed to provide proof of the costs of demolition, costs of relocating the rent-stabilized tenants and costs of liability to the tenant shareholders for the destruction of the proprietary leaseholds if the building is not restored. In addition, they presented no evidence that the market value, once restored, although less than the total cost of repairs, will not equal the difference between the cost of restoration and the cost of demolishing the building along with ancillary expenses. Also, respondents failed to show that if the building is restored to residential housing, it will not generate sufficient income to recover the difference between these two costs within a reasonable amount of time.

Landlord and Tenant - Rent Regulation - Restoration of Fire Damaged Building - Economic Infeasibility Defense - Self-Inflicted Hardship In a Housing Part proceeding where petitioners, rent-stabilized tenants and proprietary lessees, seek restoration of a building that was severely destroyed by fire, respondent owners may not rely on the affirmative defense of economic infeasibility, since they breached a statutory and direct contractual duty regarding insurance coverage to petitioner lessees, thereby causing the economic difficulty by their own actions. Respondents, holders of the unsold two thirds of the shares, reduced the replacement cost insurance from $ 3,000,000 to $ 2,000,000, but never amended the offering plan to reflect this change. Accordingly, respondents are in violation of 13 NYCRR 18.3 (w) (11), which mandates that holders of unsold shares must amend the offering plan to include current and accurate information regarding insurance coverage until the shares are sold to bona fide purchasers. This reduction in insurance coverage also breached a contractual duty owed to petitioner proprietary lessees. The sponsors made a representation that the building would have $ 3,000,000 all risk insurance for 100% replacement cost. The offering plan is a part of the contract between the parties. Thus, respondents made an unambiguous and enforceable representation that the $ 3,000,000 coverage would continue, at least until the plan was amended or they were no longer holders of a majority of the shares as unsold shares. No amendment was made to the plan and the respondents are still holders of the unsold two thirds of the shares.

Landlord and Tenant - Rent Regulation - Restoration of Fire Damaged Building - Economic Infeasibility Defense - Clean Hands In a Housing Part proceeding where petitioners, rent-stabilized tenants and proprietary lessees, seek restoration of a building that was severely destroyed by fire, respondent owners may not rely on the affirmative defense of economic infeasibility, since they knowingly underinsured the building, and brought the loss upon themselves by changing the amount of insurance coverage stated in the cooperative offering plan without amending the plan. Petitioners seek equitable relief under CCA 110 (a) (4), and respondents must come to court with clean hands to benefit from the equitable defense of economic infeasibility, which seeks to avoid clearly stated statutes based upon economic hardship. Respondents do not have the clean hands necessary to assert this equitable defense because they underinsured the building in violation of the offering plan and, accordingly, they are estopped from asserting this defense based on economic hardship.

Constitutional Law - Taking of Property - Restoration of Fire Damaged Residential Apartment Building In a Housing Part proceeding, an order mandating respondent owners to restore a building that was severely destroyed by fire, and was formerly occupied by petitioners, rent-stabilized tenants and proprietary lessees, does not constitute an unconstitutional taking where the respondents knowingly underinsured the building and changed the amount of insurance coverage stated in the cooperative offering plan without amending the plan. The United States Constitution does not protect parties from economic loss caused by their own bad or foolish business decisions.

Constitutional Law - Taking of Property - Restoration of Fire Damaged Residential Apartment Building - Right to Exclude Others In a Housing Part proceeding, an order mandating respondent owners to restore a building that was severely destroyed by fire, and was formerly occupied by petitioners, rent-stabilized tenants and proprietary lessees, does not constitute an unconstitutional taking by forcing respondents to do business with tenants with whom they had no prior dealings, since they have leases with and obligations to all petitioners, and are in breach of the duties imposed by these leases. It is not unconstitutional for an owner to be required to restore, or even reconstruct, a building to be occupied by tenants with whom it already has privity, and who resided in the building before it was damaged.

Constitutional Law - Taking of Property - Restoration of Fire Damaged Residential Apartment Building - Conferring Special Privilege In a Housing Part proceeding, an order mandating respondent owners to restore a building that was severely destroyed by fire, and was formerly occupied by petitioners, rent-stabilized tenants and proprietary lessees, does not constitute an unconstitutional taking, since applying the housing statutes and regulations which require owners of residential apartment buildings to maintain them in habitable condition, to respondents, does not give any particular class of persons or entities special privileges or burdens. Multiple Dwelling Law § 78 and Administrative Code of the City of New York § 27-2005 impose a duty to repair and to keep the premises in a habitable condition. Respondents are not being forced to keep any tenants in perpetuity. Their right of reversion remains the same under the Rent Stabilization Law regarding the rent-stabilized tenants and under the proprietary leases of the tenants who subscribed to the cooperative offering plan.

 

786 of 992 DOCUMENTS


Barbulean v. City of Newburgh


96-146


SUPREME COURT OF NEW YORK, ORANGE COUNTY


168 Misc. 2d 728; 640 N.Y.S.2d 935; 1995 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 687



August 21, 1995, Decided


NOTICE:   [***1]  NOT FOR PUBLICATION


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff peep show operator and defendants, city and its zoning appeals board, filed motions for summary judgment in the peep show operator's action challenging the constitutionality of city zoning ordinances that required him to obtain a special use permit for his business. He sought a declaration of unconstitutionality, a declaration that he could continue to operate without the permit, and a restraining order enjoining a violation notice.


OVERVIEW: The peep show operator began offering peep show services in his bookstore in the city. The city cited him with a notice of violation of zoning ordinances that required a special use permit to operate a movie theater. The city's zoning appeal's board ruled that the provision was constitutional and that the permit had to be obtained. One of the provisions stipulated that the zoning appeals board was to consider a certain list of factors, "among other things," in determining whether to grant a special use permit. The court declared that the peep show operator could conduct the business without the permit. The court found that the provisions were content neutral because they were not directed at specific types of expression, and that they served the substantial government interest of easing traffic burdens. However, it found that the provision governing permit determinations was unconstitutional on its face because it was not sufficiently narrowly tailored as to constitutional time, place, and manner restrictions.


OUTCOME: Plaintiff peep-show operator's motion for summary judgment was granted, because the city ordinances that required the peep-show operator to obtain a special use permit were unconstitutional on their face. The court declared that the peep-show operator could conduct business without the special use permit.


HEADNOTES

Constitutional Law - Freedom of Speech - Zoning Regulation - "Peep" Shows - Content Neutral Ordinance In an action challenging the constitutionality of a municipal zoning ordinance, which defendants invoked to deny a special use permit to the operator of an adult bookstore to conduct a "peep show", it cannot be said that the ordinance creates a "content based" prior restraint since a reading of the challenged provisions of the ordinance reveals that they are "content neutral", in that they are not directed at specific types of expression or at businesses where particular types of expression are conducted. Accordingly, those provisions do not come before the court bearing the heavy presumption of unconstitutionality as a matter of Federal constitutional law. Similarly, since they are not "directed at the message conveyed", they are not presumptively invalid and therefore subject to strict scrutiny under State constitutional standards, which are broader than their Federal counterpart. Consequently, consideration must be shifted to whether the provisions are valid time, place and manner restrictions.

Constitutional Law - Freedom of Speech - Zoning Regulation - "Peep" Shows - Time, Place and Manner Restrictions In an action challenging the constitutionality of a "content neutral" municipal zoning ordinance, which defendants invoked to deny a special use permit to the operator of an adult bookstore to conduct a "peep show", in light of the clear and legitimate goal of the ordinance, i.e., to ensure that retail establishments are not adversely affected by the influx of a large number of individuals whose presence at a theater-type business creates pedestrian and vehicular traffic and parking burdens, and inasmuch as the ordinance, which permits the operation of theaters in other zoning districts as of right, does not prohibit all exercise of the particular mode of free expression at issue, it cannot be said, at this point, that the ordinance is an unconstitutional time, place and manner restriction. Given the "content neutral" aspect of the ordinance, the fact that it promotes the substantial governmental interest of providing retail business operators with an environment appropriate for the conduct of small retail concerns, and the availability of alternate modes of expression in other portions of the municipality without the need to secure a special use permit, the challenged provisions of the ordinance are facially valid, aside from the question of the standards applicable to the grant or denial of special use permits.

Constitutional Law - Freedom of Speech - Zoning Ordinance - "Peep" Shows - Standards for Granting Special Use Permit Although a "content neutral" zoning ordinance, which requires a special use permit to operate a theater (or "peep" show) in a certain zoning district, promotes those legitimate governmental interests associated with time, place and manner restrictions, it is nevertheless facially unconstitutional since it lacks specific standards for the zoning authority to use when determining whether or not to grant a special use permit. While the ordinance does list 12 specific factors for the zoning authority to consider, it also permits the consideration of "other things" which gives the authority virtually unlimited discretion in making its determination. The same general standards which support a grant of authority from a municipal governing board to its zoning board are insufficient to meet constitutional requirements applicable to the exercise of that authority, and merely because the activity in question (i.e., "peep" shows) is permitted in another area of the municipality, the ordinance cannot be considered constitutional since the standards whereby First Amendment freedoms are subjected to prior restraint must be narrow, objective and definite. In light of the open-ended language of the ordinance, it is concluded that the ordinance is facially unconstitutional because the time, place and manner restrictions are broader than needed to achieve the municipality's purpose of controlling traffic.

Constitutional Law - Freedom of Speech - Unconstitutional Zoning Ordinance - "Peep" Shows - Remedy In an action successfully challenging the facial constitutionality of a municipal zoning ordinance, which defendants invoked to deny a special use permit to the operator of an adult bookstore to conduct a "peep show", the appropriate remedy is to declare that plaintiff may conduct his bookstore and "theater" business at his present location without the necessity of obtaining a special use permit, since the remedy of invalidating the special use permit requirement is consistent with the fundamental rule that an unconstitutional part of a statute may be severed and rejected, while the valid portion may stand. Moreover, by permitting plaintiff to operate his business without a permit, the court avoids the impermissible effect of depriving other nonconforming use business owners of their property without due process of law. Thus, if the court concluded that the zoning board was not authorized to grant permits for special uses, no entity could lawfully conduct a special use in any similar zone in the municipality, and this would have the effect of declaring that any theater, motel, hotel, assembly hall, funeral parlor, public school or business school presently located in such a zone would be prohibited from continuing its operation. Such a result is clearly in violation of the property rights of such business owners, and cannot be permitted.

 

787 of 992 DOCUMENTS


In re Lawrence T.


Docket No. S-41-95


FAMILY COURT OF NEW YORK, ONEIDA COUNTY


165 Misc. 2d 1008; 630 N.Y.S.2d 910; 1995 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 382



July 27, 1995, Decided


NOTICE:  [***1] EDITED FOR PUBLICATION


SUBSEQUENT HISTORY: As Amended September 22, 1995.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner school district brought a petition alleging that respondent youth was a person in need of supervision as defined in N.Y. Fam. Ct. Act art. 7 by virtue of his alleged failure to attend school as required by N.Y. Educ. Law art. 65, pt. I.


OVERVIEW: The school district brought a petition alleging that the youth was a person in need of supervision due to his alleged failure to attend school. The school district alleged that the youth was illegally absent from school on 21 days between April 3, 1995, and May 12, 1995. On its own motion, the court ruled that the petition should be dismissed because all but one of the illegal absences occurred after the youth turned 16. The court found that the youth did not become a habitual truant until after reaching the maximum age of a youth that could be declared a person in need of supervision under N.Y. Fam. Ct. Act § 712(a).


OUTCOME: The court dismissed the school district's petition to declare the youth a person in need of supervision.


HEADNOTES

Infants - Persons in Need of Supervision - Truancy A city school district's petition that respondent be declared a person in need of supervision (PINS) because he missed 21 days of school between April 3, 1995 and May 12, 1995 is denied where respondent turned 16 on April 4, 1995, so that he was truant only one day before Family Court Act § 712 (a) ceased to affect him, despite the effect of a "gap" created by the effect of Education Law § 3205, which requires that the student remain in attendance until at least the end of the school year in which a minor becomes 16. The "gap" is created by the fact that respondent did not become a "habitual truant" until after his sixteenth birthday and thus Family Court Act § 712 (a) is without effect as it defines a person in need of supervision as a minor less than 16 years of age. Education Law § 3205 requires that a student remain in attendance until the last day of the session of the school year in which the student turns 16 and further provides that a school board may, as was done in the instant matter, require a student to remain enrolled until the age of 17 if said student is unemployed. However, as the Family Court's powers are derived from and limited by statute, such statutory "gaps" must be dealt with by the Legislature and not the Family Court.

 

788 of 992 DOCUMENTS


People v. Lewis


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


JUSTICE COURT OF NEW YORK, VILLAGE OF FISHKILL, DUTCHESS COUNTY


166 Misc. 2d 898; 636 N.Y.S.2d 539; 1995 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 621



July 18, 1995, Decided


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant challenged a law that permitted suspension of her driver's license without a hearing.


OVERVIEW: The matter before the court concerned the constitutionality of a traffic law. Defendant contended that N.Y. Veh. & Traf. Law § 1193 (2)(e)(7) was unconstitutional because it violated her rights to the due process of law as guaranteed by both the federal and state constitutions. Defendant argued that the statute must fall because it failed to provide her a meaningful hearing either prior to the mandated suspension or within a short time thereafter. The State responded by arguing that the constitution did not require pre-suspension due process. The court disagreed. The court held that the statute unconstitutionally violated defendant's due process rights.


OUTCOME: The court held that defendant's due process rights had been violated.


HEADNOTES

Motor Vehicles - Operating Vehicle while Under Influence of Alcohol or Drugs - Validity of Statutory Suspension of Driver's License Pending Prosecution - Lack of Hearing Any further action to suspend defendant's driver's license pursuant to Vehicle and Traffic Law § 1193 (2) (e) (7) shall be permanently stayed pending a final determination by an appellate court regarding the constitutionality of the aforementioned statute. The statute violates the defendant's rights to due process of law as guaranteed by both the Federal and State Constitutions inasmuch as it fails to provide a defendant a meaningful hearing either prior to the mandated suspension or within a short time thereafter.

 

789 of 992 DOCUMENTS


People v. McLees


DOCKET NO. 3419936-39


DISTRICT COURT OF NEW YORK, FIRST DISTRICT, SUFFOLK COUNTY


166 Misc. 2d 260; 631 N.Y.S.2d 990; 1995 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 399



July 12, 1995, Decided


NOTICE:  [***1] EDITED FOR PUBLICATION


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant moved for dismissal of criminal action brought against him for driving while intoxicated on the grounds that N.Y. Veh. & Traf. Law § 1193(2)(e)(7) was unconstitutional, and in the alternative defendant moved for suppression of his blood-alcohol test results.


OVERVIEW: Defendant was charged with driving while intoxicated. He moved for dismissal of the action against him on the grounds that N.Y. Veh. & Traf. Law § 1193(2)(e)(7) was unconstitutional and, in the alternative, for suppression of his blood-alcohol test results. The court denied both motions. Although defendant had already been subjected to a hearing for the suspension of his driver's license, the criminal prosecution of defendant did not constitute double jeopardy because the suspension hearing was civil and remedial in nature, not a punishment. As a vehicle operator in the state of New York, defendant was deemed to have consented to the blood-alcohol test, and he did not revoke his consent. Therefore, his test results were admissible.


OUTCOME: The court denied defendant's motions, because the suspension of defendant's driver's license and the criminal action did not constitute double jeopardy, and defendant consented to the blood-alcohol test.


HEADNOTES

Motor Vehicles - Operating Vehicle while Under Influence of Alcohol or Drugs - Former Jeopardy - License Suspension Pending Prosecution Vehicle and Traffic Law § 1193 (2) (e) (7) is not unconstitutional as violative of the Double Jeopardy Clause where defendant was arrested for driving while intoxicated, consented to an intoxilyzer test, his license was suspended, after a hearing he received a hardship license, and he was still subject to punishment pursuant to the criminal action, since the New York driving while intoxicated procedure involves a number of proceedings, flowing from and part of the same criminal action, which are conducted in and by the same court under the same caption and docket number; all portions are part of and not independent of the underlying action. This result does not change because a defendant, preliminarily and prior to the conclusion of the criminal case, might be "punished" while still potentially in jeopardy for the underlying crime.

Motor Vehicles - Operating Vehicle while Under Influence of Alcohol or Drugs - Remedial Nature of License Suspension Pending Prosecution The license suspension procedure under Vehicle and Traffic Law § 1193 (2) (e) (7), utilized pending prosecution of charges of operating a motor vehicle while under the influence of alcohol or drugs, is not "punishment", but rather remedial in nature. The statute involves a balancing of the public's interest in highway safety with the defendant's rights and keeps the potentially dangerous driver off the road.

Motor Vehicles - Chemical Tests - Voluntary Consent Defendant's consent to an intoxilyzer test was voluntarily obtained where he was informed of what would happen if he refused the test, but he was not informed of what would happen if he submitted to the test. There is no constitutional privilege to refuse testing. The defendant--as an operator of a motor vehicle in this State--was deemed to have consented to testing with one caveat: prior to testing, he must be advised of the consequences of a withdrawal of his consent and afforded the opportunity to "affirmatively" do so. He was so advised and chose not to withdraw consent. That was sufficient to satisfy the law. Further, knowing and voluntary consent may be achieved without a warning of the consequences, since a driver cannot be warned of all potential consequences following a consent. Finally, any such omnibus warning which embraces all of the consequences would be a surrender to form as opposed to substance.

 

790 of 992 DOCUMENTS


Prodell v. State


Index No. 2336-86, R.J.I. No. 01-86-000939


SUPREME COURT OF NEW YORK, ALBANY COUNTY


166 Misc. 2d 608; 630 N.Y.S.2d 880; 1995 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 373



June 29, 1995, Decided


NOTICE:  [***1] EDITED FOR PUBLICATION


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff taxpayers instituted the action for injunctive and declaratory relief against defendant town regarding the payment of a school tax refund to the former owner of a nuclear power plant. The taxpayers and the town sought summary judgment.


OVERVIEW: Under the Suffolk County Tax Act (SCTA), codified at 1983 N.Y. Laws § 1018, the taxpayers were responsible for the school tax refund owed to the former owner of a nuclear power plant. The taxpayers instituted the action for declaratory and injunctive relief against the town, arguing that § 1018 was unconstitutional. The court granted the taxpayers' motion for summary judgment and denied the town's motion for summary judgment, holding that the constitutionality of §1018 turned on whether this classification rationally related to the state's interest in seeing that all similarly situated taxpayers bore the same tax burden with respect to real property tax refunds. The classification was flawed because it presumed that the presence of a nuclear power plant in a school district created a tax haven and/or windfall for the residents of that school district. The classification shifted the burden of refunding property taxes from the town to the school district based upon a single irrelevant criterion, the involvement of property improved by a nuclear power plant. The classification did not apply to all persons similarly situated. Accordingly, it was unconstitutional.


OUTCOME: The court granted the taxpayers motion for summary judgment in their action for declaratory and injunctive relief against the town based on the unconstitutionality of the SCTA. The court denied the towns' motion for summary judgment.


HEADNOTES

Trial - Place of Trial - Demand for Change of Venue - Taxpayer Action against Town Where plaintiff taxpayers commenced an action in Albany County against the State and their Town based on a court-ordered tax assessment, the venue will remain in Albany County, even though CPLR 504 (2) provides that an action should be venued in the county where the town is located and the Town desires a change of venue, since the Town failed to demonstrate that the convenience of material witnesses and the ends of justice will be promoted by the change of venue sought (CPLR 510 [3]), and the motion for a change of venue was not made within a reasonable time after the action was commenced (CPLR 511 [a]). There has been no showing made regarding the identities and occupations of the material witnesses who would need to travel to Albany County and the attorney's affidavit in support of the motion supplies no basis for a finding that the convenience of material witnesses and the ends of justice will be promoted by the change. Further, the operative facts controlling any decision regarding venue were known to the Town from the outset of the litigation; thus, the 7 1/2-year period from commencement of the action to the date of the motion is not a reasonable time after commencement.

Constitutional Law - Equal Protection of Laws - School Tax Refunds An amendment to the Suffolk County Tax Act (SCTA) (L 1983, ch 1018) providing that school tax refunds may not be charged by a town to a school district except where the assessment subject to such proceeding is applicable to property improved by a nuclear facility violates the Equal Protection Clause of the New York and Federal Constitutions because the classification created bears no relationship to the achievement of a legitimate State purpose. Taxing statutes must be upheld if the challenged classification is rationally related to achievement of a legitimate State purpose. The State has a legitimate interest in ensuring that similarly situated taxpayers pay the same share of the tax burden. Here, the class of taxpayers designated in the amendment are the only class of Suffolk County taxpayers that may not look to their Town to refund overpaid school taxes. This classification presumes that the presence of a nuclear power plant in a school district creates a tax haven and/or windfall for the residents of that school district. However, any type of improvement to real property can create a tax haven for residents of a school district. The classification is arbitrary since it shifts the burden of refunding property taxes from the Town to the school district based upon a single irrelevant criterion--the involvement of property improved by a nuclear power plant. Nor may the constitutional infirmity be cured because the amendment achieves a result perceived as fair.

 

791 of 992 DOCUMENTS


Cappelli v. Sweeney


Index No. 3980/95


SUPREME COURT OF NEW YORK, CIVIL TERM, KINGS COUNTY


167 Misc. 2d 220; 634 N.Y.S.2d 619; 1995 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 497



June 29, 1995, Decided


NOTICE:  [***1] EDITED FOR PUBLICATION


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner members of the state unemployment insurance appeals board (board members) brought a proceeding under N.Y. C.P.L.R. 78 to compel respondent commissioner of labor (commissioner) to process the necessary forms to put the board members on the state payroll.


OVERVIEW: The board members were appointed to serve the balance of six-year terms which the prior incumbents had occupied on the state unemployment insurance appeals board, which was a five-member entity created by N.Y. Labor Law § 534. The board members contended that the commissioner failed to put them on the state payroll because of their political affiliation. The board members alleged a taking and illegal discrimination based on political affiliation in violation of the U.S. Const. amend. I, XIV and 42 U.S.C.S. § 1983. The commissioner argued that the N.Y. Const. art. V, § 4 expressly required senate confirmation of all appointed board members serving in the executive branch of state government. The board members were not so confirmed. The court held that the legislative intention was to bring greater economy and efficiency to government. Thus, the court concluded that N.Y. Const. art. V, § 4 applied only to the heads of departments and not to subsidiary boards. The court also held that the commissioner's willful failure to provide compensation constituted a violation of the board members' rights to due process under the U.S. Const. amend. XIV, in violation of 42 U.S.C.S. § 1983.


OUTCOME: The court held that the board members were the lawful occupants of their respective positions and were entitled to complete their designated terms of office with compensation. The board members were awarded costs and reasonable attorneys fees because of the commissioner's egregious conduct in forcing the board members to resort to legal action in order to secure their right to compensation.


HEADNOTES

Civil Service - Appointment and Promotion - Confirmation by Senate Petitioners, appointed by the Governor as members of the New York State Unemployment Insurance Appeals Board (Board), are the lawful occupants of their respective positions and entitled to complete their designated terms of office, even though the appointments were not approved by the Senate pursuant to NY Constitution, article V, § 4 which requires Senate confirmation of "the heads of all other departments and the members of all boards and commissions" appointed to serve in the executive branch of the State government. Legislative history of NY Constitution, article V, § 4 indicates the Legislature intended to require Senate confirmation only of the "head", be they single individuals or the members of boards or commissions, of the 17 original proposed constitutional executive departments, unless the method of selection was otherwise expressly provided in the Constitution. The intent was not to require Senate confirmation of each and every member of every subordinate bureau, board or commission within the departments. Legislative history indicates that "boards and commissions" were also to be "heads of departments". Thus, where a board or commission continued as the "head" of a department, its members would require Senate confirmation. In addition, Labor Law § 534 provides that the five members on this Board will be appointed by the Governor. The statute never provided for Senate confirmation of the Governor's appointments, and since its creation in 1935, no appointment to the Board has been submitted to the Senate for confirmation. Inasmuch as members have never been confirmed by the Senate, failure to provide for such confirmation in the legislation must be deemed deliberate.

Civil Rights - Federal Civil Rights Claim - Appointed Civil Servant's Right to Compensation Respondents, the Commissioner of the New York State Department of Labor and the Governor, violated petitioners' rights to due process pursuant to US Constitution 14th Amendment, thereby depriving them, under color of State law, of rights, privileges and immunities secured by the Constitution in violation of 42 USC § 1983, where petitioners were lawful members of the New York State Unemployment Insurance Appeals Board (Board), appointed by the former Governor on the eve of his departure from office, and respondents willfully failed to provide compensation to which petitioners were entitled, in an effort to force them from office. No inference was made that petitioners' performance was inadequate or that the Governor had cause for their discharge. Respondents have acknowledged petitioners' right to compensation, but apparently intended to induce their departure from office. Consequently, petitioners were constructively discharged by respondents' actions. In addition, respondents' legal challenge based on the lack of Senate confirmation appears to be disingenuous given respondent Governor's own appointments made without Senate confirmation. Also, given petitioners' duties, the mechanism for their direct appointment by the Governor and their status as high level policymakers, they are not protected from political discharge or other adverse employment conditions by the First Amendment. Nevertheless, a State job and the right to regular paychecks and employment benefits is a valuable property interest for which the Fourteenth Amendment provides due process protection. By virtue of their clear entitlement under Labor Law § 534 not to be removed except for cause following a hearing, petitioners' rights under the Fourteenth Amendment to be afforded notice and an opportunity to be heard before being deprived of property to which they were lawfully entitled, i.e., their salaries and benefits, were violated.

Civil Rights - Federal Civil Rights Claim - Counsel Fees Where petitioners were lawful members of the New York State Unemployment Insurance Appeals Board (Board), appointed by the former Governor on the eve of his departure from office, and respondents, Commissioner of the New York State Department of Labor and Governor, deprived petitioners of their rights under United States Constitution 14th Amendment by willfully failing to provide petitioners' compensation in an effort to force them from office, petitioners are entitled to legal fees pursuant to 42 USC § 1988. Respondents engaged in egregious conduct forcing petitioners to resort to legal action in order to secure their right to compensation, thereby incurring considerable expense in legal fees.

 

792 of 992 DOCUMENTS


People v. Johnson


95-410


JUSTICE COURT OF NEW YORK, TOWN OF CHILI, MONROE COUNTY


165 Misc. 2d 904; 630 N.Y.S.2d 647; 1995 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 361



June 26, 1995, Decided


NOTICE:  [***1] EDITED FOR PUBLICATION


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant, after being charged with driving while intoxicated in violation of N.Y. Veh. & Traf. Law § 1192(2) and (3), challenged the constitutionality of the license suspension process provided in N.Y. Veh. & Traf. Law § 1193(2)(e)(7) under the Due Process and Equal Protection Clauses of the York State and United States Constitutions.


OVERVIEW: Defendant was stopped and arrested for failure to maintain lane and speeding, in violation of N.Y. Veh. & Traf. Law §§ 1128(a) and 1180(d). Defendant was also arrested for two counts of driving while intoxicated under N.Y. Veh. & Traf. Law § 1192(2) and (3). Defendant was given an appearance ticket. At the time of his initial appearance, defendant objected on constitutional grounds to N.Y. Veh. & Traf. Law § 1193(2)(e)(7), which provided for the suspension of the driver's license pending prosecution of any person charged with a violation of N.Y. Veh. & Traf. Law § 1192(2) or (3), who at the time of arrest was alleged to have had a blood alcohol level of .10 of one percent or more. The court held that the license suspension process did not comport with due process because it (1) failed to provide adequate notice of the suspension process, (2) failed to provide for a meaningful hearing, (3) reversed the burden of proof and presumption of innocence. The court held that N.Y. Veh. & Traf. Law § 1193(2)(e)(7) was unconstitutional and could not be applied or enforced against defendant. However, the court ordered defendant to appear for completion of arraignment.


OUTCOME: The court concluded that the license suspension process was unconstitutional and could not be enforced or applied against defendant. The court, however, ordered defendant to appear for completion of arraignment.


HEADNOTES

Motor Vehicles - Operating Vehicle while Under Influence of Alcohol or Drugs - Constitutionality of Statute Suspending License Pending Prosecution Vehicle and Traffic Law § 1193 (2) (e) (7), which suspends a driver's license pending prosecution of any person charged with violating Vehicle and Traffic Law § 1192 (2) or (3), where there has been a test for blood alcohol content with a result of .10% or more, is unconstitutional since the suspension sanction is punitive in nature and the suspension process, as part of a criminal proceeding, does not comport with due process requirements. The statute contains no notice provisions and no provision for a prompt postsuspension hearing; there is no meaningful hearing, since the court makes its findings first, and then the defendant may make a statement regarding the findings; any "defense" presented by defendant is a rebuttal, which appears to be an impermissible shift in the burden of proof; and the hearing process dispenses with any presumption of innocence.

 

793 of 992 DOCUMENTS


230 Park Ave. Assocs. v. State


Claim No. 84601, Motion No. M-50344, Cross Motion No. CM-50541


COURT OF CLAIMS OF NEW YORK


165 Misc. 2d 920; 630 N.Y.S.2d 855; 1995 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 359



June 21, 1995, Decided


NOTICE:  [***1] EDITED FOR PUBLICATION


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: In a dispute arising from a commercial lease gone awry, claimant commercial landlord and defendant state filed cross motions for summary judgment or alternative relief relating to the state's assertion of affirmative defenses.


OVERVIEW: The state commerce department occupied offices on a sublease from another state agency. Despite occupying the office space for over 29 months, including a holdover period during which the state paid no rent, the state never executed an independent temporary lease as required by State Financial Law § 112(2). The landlord filed suit, alleging breach of contract and unjust enrichment. On the parties' cross-motions for partial summary judgment or other appropriate relief, the court held that: (1) because the state did not deny the landlord's assertion in its complaint that the landlord's claim was timely, the state was deemed to have admitted that assertion under N.Y. C.P.L.R. 3018; (2) State Finance Law § 112(2) applied to temporary leases; (3) the state was not a holdover tenant because it paid no rent after expiration of its lease; (4) § 112(2) precluded the landlord's claim because it exceeded the statutory $ 5000 maximum; (5) state officials could not waive operation of § 112(2); and (6) the landlord could claim against the state in unjust enrichment because such actions were not limited to money had and received, but instead included an attempt to redress the state's trespass.


OUTCOME: The court denied the state's cross motion for summary judgment regarding the alleged untimeliness of the landlord's claim, granted the landlord's motion to strike the state's affirmative defense against the landlord's unjust enrichment claim, and granted a partial summary judgment as to the state's liability thereon.


HEADNOTES

State - Claim against State - Timeliness of Notice of Claim In an action arising out of State agencies' occupation of office space for 2 1/2 years under invalid temporary leases (see, State Finance Law § 112 [2]) without making payments, claimant landlord's claim for breach of contract and unjust enrichment is deemed timely where one paragraph of the claim alleged that the filing was within the time constraints set forth in Court of Claims Act § 6, and the State answered that it "leaves to the Court's determination the legal conclusions contained" in the subject paragraph, since all statements in a complaint not denied are deemed admitted (CPLR 3018). Alternatively, the claim is timely as to the cause of action for unjust enrichment since the cause of action accrued not when the defendant vacated the premises in January 1990 but when the purported lease under which defendant was in possession, and was subject to ratification under State Finance Law § 112 (2), was disaffirmed in August 1991. A cause of action for use and occupation could not accrue until the lease was disaffirmed.

State - Claim against State - Breach of Contract - Invalid Lease In an action arising from State agencies' occupation of office space for 2 1/2 years under temporary leases after expiration of a properly approved sublease (State Finance Law § 112 [2]) without paying rent while a formal lease was purportedly being finalized, but which was never filed and approved by the State Comptroller pursuant to section 112 (2), claimant landlord's breach of contract claim is dismissed. State Finance Law § 112 (2) mandates that a contract made for or by the State, which exceeds $ 5,000, must be approved by the Comptroller and filed in his or her office. The State's acceptance of benefits under an unapproved contract does not estop it from denying liability under the contract and State officers cannot waive the provisions of section 112 (2). Here, section 112 (2) applies to the temporary leases; renewals and extensions of approved contracts, unless the renewal is pursuant to, and in accordance with an option provision contained in the approved contract, must be independently approved by the Comptroller, and the temporary leases were not approved. Also, the State was not a holdover tenant under Real Property Law § 232-c so as to be liable for the rent under a month-to-month tenancy.

State - Claim against State - Unjust Enrichment - Use and Occupancy of Premises without Approved Lease Claimant landlord may assert an unjust enrichment cause of action against the State predicated upon the State's use and occupancy of office space for 2 1/2 years under temporary leases involving rent payments of over $ 70,000 per year, without making payments, even though the temporary leases were not approved by the State Comptroller as required (see, State Finance Law § 112). Real Property Law § 220 provides that a landlord may recover reasonable compensation for the use and occupation of real property, by any person, under an agreement not made by deed. Although under General Construction Law § 37, the term "person" generally does not include the State, the definitions in section 37 are not exclusive and are inapplicable when the proper construction of the statute requires a different interpretation; moreover, the State is not a person under a general statute only when it acts in its governmental capacity, and here the State was acting in its proprietary capacity, leasing real property as any tenant would. If the State trespasses or holds over after the expiration of its lease the landlord may evict it and recover damages for the reasonable value of the use and occupancy to prevent unjust enrichment, regardless of whether the continued possession has been approved by the Comptroller, whether it was fiscally prudent and whether money has been appropriated therefor. Any other rule would be unconstitutional as taking property without due process and for a public use without compensation.

 

794 of 992 DOCUMENTS


Town of Esopus v. State


Claim No. 88266.


COURT OF CLAIMS OF NEW YORK


166 Misc. 2d 36; 631 N.Y.S.2d 213; 1995 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 401



May 30, 1995, Decided


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Claimant town filed an action against defendant state alleging that the state's action in ordering the town to close a landfill it owned and operated constituted a "taking" in that it destroyed all economically viable uses of the property. The town sought damages for the value of the land, the revenues that could have been anticipated over the estimated life of the landfill, and the costs of carrying out the closure.


OVERVIEW: The town operated the landfill for many years pursuant to a license granted by the Department of Environmental Conservation (DEC) which required the landfill to comply with the applicable regulations. Shortly after the license expired, the DEC charged the town with violating the regulations governing landfills. An investigation revealed that the landfill was not in compliance with the standards and its closure was ordered. The town complied, and then filed its action alleging a "taking" of the property. The court held that the closure because of a violation of regulations enacted for the health and safety of the public did not constitute a taking entitling the town to just compensation, unless the town previously had a vested right to use the land in the prohibited manner. The town never had a vested right to continue using its property as a landfill. The licenses were issued for a finite number of years and were effective only as long as the town complied with the relevant regulatory guidelines. The closure did not render the property totally valueless, as evidenced by the town's construction of a solid waste transfer station on the site of the former landfill.


OUTCOME: The court granted the state's motion to dismiss and dismissed the claim.


HEADNOTES

State - Claim against State - Unconstitutional Taking of Property - Closing Municipal Landfill for Failure to Comply with Regulations Where the Department of Environmental Conservation (DEC) informed the claimant Town that its municipal landfill was not in compliance with DEC regulations, could not be brought into compliance and must be closed, the Town's claim against the State for an unconstitutional taking of property based upon the closure of the landfill is dismissed. Infringement on the use of property because of governmental regulations enacted for the health and safety of the general populace does not constitute a taking for which the landowner is entitled to just compensation, even if the usefulness is significantly compromised or destroyed, unless the property owner previously had a vested right to use the land in the now-prohibited manner. Where a landowner had the right to use property in a certain manner, which use was subsequently prohibited by regulation, there can be no recovery from the regulating authority unless all possible uses are prohibited. Here, the Town never had a "vested" right to continue using its property as a landfill. The DEC issued licenses to the Town for a finite number of years and the licenses were effective only as long as certain express conditions were met, including compliance with the regulatory guidelines. The Town had no absolute, secured right to have its license renewed, and thus its right to use the property as a landfill was contingent on receiving the appropriate licenses. In addition, DEC's actions did not render the property totally valueless. The Town has constructed and is currently operating a solid waste transfer station on the site. Whether or not significant revenues can be anticipated from operation of the facility, it has value insofar as it assists the Town in meeting its responsibility to arrange for the disposal of solid waste.

 

795 of 992 DOCUMENTS


People v. M.K.R.


Docket # 94-5-3


JUSTICE COURT OF NEW YORK, VILLAGE OF FLEISCHMANNS, DELAWARE COUNTY


166 Misc. 2d 456; 632 N.Y.S.2d 382; 1995 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 439



May 26, 1995, Decided


SUBSEQUENT HISTORY:  [***1] As Amended October 20, 1995.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant moved to dismiss the misdemeanor sexual misconduct charge against him under N.Y. Penal Law § 130.20(1), claiming the statute was unconstitutional as violating the equal protection guarantees of U.S. Const. amend. XIV, § 1, and N.Y. Const. art I, § 11.


OVERVIEW: Defendant teenager was accused of committing misdemeanor sexual misconduct under N.Y. Penal Law § 130.20(1) (the statute) after engaging in a sexual relationship with his 15-year-old girlfriend. Defendant moved to dismiss, claiming the statute violated equal protection guarantees under U.S. Const. amend. XIV, § 1, and N.Y. Const. art I, § 11. The court granted defendant's motion under N.Y. Crim. Proc. Law § 170.40 because there was no force, the relationship between defendant and girlfriend was consensual, defendant was a first time offender who did not threaten the safety or welfare of the community, and the impact of the dismissal upon the confidence of the public in the criminal justice system would be minimal. The court noted that, while the statute was unconstitutional because it discriminated against males, the appropriate remedy was to preserve the statute and strike the gender exemption, since dismissal was not warranted on that ground alone.


OUTCOME: The court dismissed the misdemeanor sexual misconduct charge against defendant because defendant was a first time offender who did not threaten the safety or welfare of the community, and the impact of the dismissal upon the confidence of the public in the criminal justice system would be minimal.


HEADNOTES

Constitutional Law - Equal Protection of Laws - Sexual Misconduct Penal Law § 130.20 (1), which provides that a person is guilty of sexual misconduct when, "being a male", he engages in sexual intercourse with a female without her consent, is unconstitutional since a statute, which burdens only males and not females, violates a male defendant's equal protection right. Inasmuch as neither a fundamental right was abridged nor a suspect classification was created by section 130.20 (1), this statute is valid if it bears a reasonable relationship to a legitimate legislative objective. Penal Law § 130.20 (1) is intended to deter teenage pregnancy. However, there is no substantial relationship between the objective of preventing teenage pregnancy and a statute that permits 17-year-old females and 16-year-old males, or females under 18 and younger male victims, to engage in nonforcible sexual intercourse without criminal sanction. Moreover, the Legislature has gender-neuturalized the statutory rape statutes. If a gender-neutral law would better serve the objective of deterring and punishing forcible sexual assaults, then the same type of law would also better suit a case where the sexual activity is mutual, consensual, and nonforcible. Thus, the statute is unconstitutional because of its underinclusion of females.

Constitutional Law - Validity of Statute - Striking Unconstitutional Portions of Penal Law § 130.20 (1) Where Penal Law § 130.20 (1), which penalizes males for engaging in sexual intercourse with a female without her consent, has been held unconstitutional because of its underinclusion of females, the appropriate remedy is to strike the gender exemption and preserve the statute. Unless it is evident that the Legislature would not have enacted those provisions which are within its power, independently of that which is not, the invalid part may be dropped if what is left is fully operative as a law. Here, given the choice of striking the statute as unconstitutional or of striking only that portion which rendered it constitutionally defective by reason of underinclusion, the Legislature would opt for striking the gender exemption.

Crimes - Sexual Misconduct - Retaining Charges Where Portion of Statute Struck as Unconstitutional Dismissal of a Penal Law § 130.20 (1) charge against the defendant is not warranted or required where the statute, which penalizes males for engaging in sexual intercourse with a female without her consent, has been held unconstitutional because of its underinclusion of females, and the court chooses to strike the gender exemption and preserve the statute, since the fact that defendant was successful in his constitutional challenge does not change the fact that he has violated the statute.

Crimes - Information - Dismissal in Interest of Justice - Sexual Misconduct The information charging defendant with sexual misconduct under Penal Law § 130.20 (1) is dismissed in the interest of justice where the 16-year-old defendant engaged in nonforcible sexual intercourse with his 15-year-old girlfriend. Under CPL 170.40, an information may be dismissed as a matter of judicial discretion where a compelling factor, consideration or circumstance demonstrates that conviction or prosecution of the defendant constitutes or results in injustice. Here, the defendant 16-year-old boy and his less than a year younger girlfriend met in high school. No force was employed and the sexual relationship between the two was consensual, even though the female participant was only 15 and by statute technically could not consent to the sexual intercourse. Defendant, a product of a broken home, has been self-sufficient from a young age and graduated from high school at 16 while working toward his aspirations for college. Defendant is a first time offender, presents no threat to society and the impact of dismissal upon the confidence of the public in the criminal justice system will be minimal. A Probation Department investigation report reveals defendant is not likely to have future legal problems and probation supervision is not indicated. Defendant's prosecution or conviction, solely by reason of this gender-based statute, would be manifestly unfair and defendant should be spared the imposition of the stigma which would attach with a conviction of sexual misconduct under these circumstances.

 

796 of 992 DOCUMENTS


City of New York v. Enzo Biochem, Inc.


95-257


CIVIL COURT OF THE CITY OF NEW YORK, NEW YORK COUNTY


164 Misc. 2d 918; 626 N.Y.S.2d 435; 1995 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 202



April 20, 1995, Decided


NOTICE:  [***1] EDITED FOR PUBLICATION


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Respondent tenant sought reargument in petitioner landlord's action to recover possession of rental property, alleging that it never took possession of the demised premises due to asbestos removal cost issues, and that it was not properly served with process pursuant to N.Y. C.P.L.R. 311(1). The tenant also filed a motion to dismiss.


OVERVIEW: The tenant alleged that service of process at the demised premises was inadequate notification where the landlord knew of the tenant's actual place of business, and was aware that the tenant did not occupy the premises at issue. The court found, however, that the landlord sufficiently complied with the "reasonable application" requirements of N.Y. Real Prop. Acts. Law § 735, and, accordingly, denied the tenant's motion to dismiss.


OUTCOME: The court denied the tenant's motion for a rehearing and to dismiss the petition.


HEADNOTES

Process - Service of Process - Summary Proceeding Involving Vacated Commercial Premises In a summary proceeding involving premises vacated by a commercial tenant who has principal corporate headquarters or a principal office elsewhere, the "reasonable application" requirement of RPAPL 735 (1) does not incorporate CPLR 308 (2)'s mandate of "due diligence" and thereby restrict corporate representatives eligible to be served with process to those specified in CPLR 311 (1).

 

797 of 992 DOCUMENTS


Pringle v. Wolfe


95-221


SUPREME COURT OF NEW YORK, WAYNE COUNTY


164 Misc. 2d 733; 625 N.Y.S.2d 879; 1995 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 154



March 17, 1995, Decided


NOTICE:  [***1] EDITED FOR PUBLICATION


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff motorist filed a declaratory judgment action against defendant township justice to declare N.Y. Veh. & Traf. Law § 1193(2)(e)(7) unconstitutional on the grounds of denial of due process and equal protection and vagueness and for an injunction, pursuant to N.Y. C.P.L.R. 6301, enjoining enforcement of N.Y. Veh. & Traf. Law § 1193(2)(e)(7) against the motorist as a result of his arrest for violating N.Y. Veh. & Traf. Law § 1192(2).


OVERVIEW: A motorist, who was arrested for a violation of N.Y. Veh. & Traf. Law § 1192(2), filed an action against the town justice and others seeking a declaration that N.Y. Veh. & Traf. Law § 1193(2)(e)(7), which imposed an indefinite suspension of his driver's license until prosecution of the violation, was unconstitutional on the grounds of denial of due process and of equal protection and of vagueness. The motorist also sought to enjoin enforcement of § 1193(2)(e)(7). The court issued an order to show cause pursuant to N.Y. C.P.L.R. 6301, 6313, and granted a preliminary injunction in holding that: (1) the motorist had a reasonable likelihood of success on the merits because there was a likelihood that N.Y. Veh. & Traf. Law § 1193(2)(e)(7) would be found to be violative of due process and equal protection and unconstitutionally vague; (2) there would be irreparable harm to the motorist upon an indefinite suspension of his driver's license; and (3) a balancing of the equities weighed in favor of the motorist, who stood to have his driver's license suspended indefinitely pending criminal prosecution based upon conduct that did not constitute a violation of the Vehicle and Traffic Law.


OUTCOME: The court granted the motorist's request for a preliminary injunction and restrained and prevented the town justice from enforcing the applicable statute against the motorist pending the determination of the motorist's action, which sought a declaratory judgment that the statute was unconstitutional.


HEADNOTES

Motor Vehicles - Operating Vehicle while Under Influence of Alcohol or Drugs - Validity of Statutory Suspension of Driver's License Pending Prosecution - Preliminary Injunction In an action seeking to declare unconstitutional Vehicle and Traffic Law § 1193 (2) (e) (7), which, inter alia, provides for the suspension of a driver's license, pending prosecution, of any person alleged to have had a blood alcohol content of .10% or greater "at the time of arrest", plaintiff, who was arrested for driving while intoxicated (Vehicle and Traffic Law § 1192 [2]), is granted a preliminary injunction restraining enforcement of the statute against him pending the determination of the action. Plaintiff has made a showing that there is a likelihood that the statute will be found violative of due process and equal protection and unconstitutionally vague in view of the statute's requirement that the arraigning court make findings of reasonable cause before the motorist has been afforded an opportunity to call witnesses or produce evidence, the fact that it is not a crime to have a blood alcohol level of .10% or greater at the time of arrest, and the fact that the statute imposes, without limitation, a suspension for the duration of the underlying criminal proceeding.

 

798 of 992 DOCUMENTS


Sandusky v. McCummings


Index No. 131434/93, Mot. Seq. 002, #184


SUPREME COURT OF NEW YORK, NEW YORK COUNTY


164 Misc. 2d 700; 625 N.Y.S.2d 457; 1995 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 131



March 16, 1995, Decided


NOTICE:  [***1] EDITED FOR PUBLICATION


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff victim filed an action under the revised "Son of Sam" Law, N.Y. Exec. Law § 632-a, to recover damages from defendant mugger. The mugger filed motions to dismiss under N.Y. C.P.L.R. 3211(a)(7) alleging that the complaint failed to state a cause of action and under N.Y. C.P.L.R. 3211(a)(5) alleging that it was barred by the statute of limitations. The mugger filed a motion under N.Y. C.P.L.R. 6314 to vacate the preliminary injunction.


OVERVIEW: The mugger attacked the victim in a subway station. Two transit authority police officers observed the crime, shot the mugger, and paralyzed him for life. The mugger won a large personal injury award in a negligence action against the transit authority. The victim brought an action against the mugger pursuant to N.Y. Exec. Law § 632-a. The court granted the mugger's motion to dismiss for failure to state a claim and vacated the preliminary injunction. The court held that N.Y. Exec. Law § 632-a(1)(b) defined "profits from the crime" as any property obtained through or income generated from the commission of a crime of which a criminal was convicted. It did not apply to any income realized by a criminal from any source whatsoever. Therefore, the victim's source of recovery was limited to income generated from the commission of the crime of which the mugger was convicted. The court held that the officers' negligence in employing deadly physical force in an effort to apprehend the mugger was an intervening event that broke any causal connection with the crime itself. Thus, the mugger's personal injury award was not "profits from the crime" within the purview of § 632-a(1)(b).


OUTCOME: The court granted the mugger's motion to dismiss for failure to state a claim in the victim's action to recover damages pursuant to the revised "Son of Sam" Law. The court vacated the preliminary injunction.


HEADNOTES

Crimes - Crime Victims Board - Civil Action by Victim to Recover Damages from Profits of Crime A personal injury verdict obtained by the convicted perpetrator of a mugging based upon injuries sustained by the perpetrator as a result of the common-law negligence of a police officer who improperly employed deadly physical force in an effort to apprehend the perpetrator at the scene of the crime does not constitute "profits of the crime" within the meaning of the Son of Sam Law (Executive Law § 632-a [3]). Profits from the crime consist of any property obtained through or income generated from the commission of the crime of which the defendant was convicted. Here, the negligence of the police officer was an intervening event that broke any causal connection with the crime itself. Accordingly, plaintiff victim's cause of action pursuant to section 632-a for damages to be recovered out of the proceeds of the personal injury verdict is dismissed.

 

799 of 992 DOCUMENTS


Grumet v. Cuomo


Index No. 4210-94


SUPREME COURT OF NEW YORK, ALBANY COUNTY


164 Misc. 2d 644; 625 N.Y.S.2d 1000; 1995 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 173



March 8, 1995, Decided


NOTICE:  [***1] EDITED FOR PUBLICATION


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant officials filed a motion for summary judgment in plaintiff taxpayers' claim that N.Y. Educ. Law ch. 241 (1994) (law), which permitted the creation of a public school to provide education for disabled children who were members of a religious community, violated the First Amendment and N.Y. Const. art. XI.


OVERVIEW: The law permitted the creation of a public school to provide education for disabled children who were members of a religious community. The taxpayers filed a suit against the officials, claiming that the law violated the First Amendment and the New York Constitution. The officials filed a motion for summary judgment. The court granted the motion and dismissed the suit. The taxpayers did not raise fact issues as to the law's constitutionality. The law was constitutional as a matter of law. The primary purpose could neither have been seen as religious nor as a sham but instead as valid and secular with purpose with, at most, an ancillary purpose of accommodating religion. The law neither created nor required the creation of the school and did not foreclose the creation of other school districts under its provisions. It did not aid or prefer a religion. It neither constituted direct, state-funded efforts to indoctrinate youngsters in specific religious beliefs, nor fostered a close identification of the state government's powers and responsibilities with those of any religious denomination. It did not confer any imprimatur of state approval on religious sects or practices.


OUTCOME: The court granted summary judgment to the officials and dismissed the taxpayers' suit alleging that a New York law that permitted the creation of a public school to provide education for disabled children who were members of a religious community was unconstitutional.


HEADNOTES

Parties - Standing - Citizen Taxpayer Challenge to State Law Permitting Municipality to Establish School District Solely within Municipality Plaintiffs have standing to challenge Laws of 1994 (ch 241), which permits municipalities to organize a union free school district consisting of the entire territory of such municipality when the educational interests of the community so require, as an unconstitutional infringement on the separation between church and State, arising from the establishment by the Satmar Hassidim of the Village of Kiryas Joel of a school district solely within their Village, since they sue in their capacities as citizen taxpayers. Each plaintiff meets the definition of citizen taxpayer contained in State Finance Law § 123-a and the new school district is the recipient of State funds. Thus, plaintiffs have statutory standing to maintain an action for declaratory or injunctive relief to prevent the unconstitutional disbursement of State funds.

Constitutional Law - Establishment of Religion - Statute Permitting Municipalities to Establish Public School District to Meet Required Educational Needs of Community Laws of 1994 (ch 241), which permits a municipality to organize a union free school district consisting of the entire territory of such municipality when the educational interests of the community so require if certain additional requirements are fulfilled (see, Education Law § 1504 [3] [a]), does not violate the Establishment of Religion Clause since the statute satisfies the three-prong test established under Lemon v Kurtzman (403 US 602); thus, the creation of a school in the Village of Kiryas Joel by the Satmar Hassidim pursuant to chapter 241 does not contravene the Establishment Clause. First, the statute is secular in purpose since it speaks in neutral terms and the conditions established for municipalities to establish schools are nonreligious and reflect reasonable and legitimate State education policy concerns. Second, the primary effect of the statute is the expansion of a municipality's ability to meet education needs, not to convey a message of government endorsement or disapproval of the Satmar sect or any religion. The legislation does not aid one religion, aid all religions, or prefer one religion over another and maintains the requisite course of neutrality. Third, the statute does not foster excessive government entanglement with religion since there is no delegation of government power to religious bodies. Here, the school is public in every sense and manner. Merely because the school board consists of all Satmar members does not make the statute unconstitutional because this would impinge their right of free exercise of religion.

Constitutional Law - Validity of Statute - Statute Permitting Municipalities to Establish Public School District to Meet Required Educational Needs of Community - State Constitution Laws of 1994 (ch 241), which permits a municipality to organize a union free school district consisting of the entire territory of such municipality when the educational interests of the community so require if certain additional requirements are fulfilled (see Education Law § 1504 [3] [a]), and empowered the Satmar Hassidim of the Village of Kiryas Joel to establish a public school, does not violate New York Constitution, article XI, § 3, which prohibits the use of public money directly or indirectly in aid or maintenance other than for examination or inspection of any school or institution of learning wholly or in part under the control or direction of any religious denomination. The school district is not under the de facto control of the Satmar sect merely because all members of the Board of Education are Satmar. No proof was presented that Satmar tenets are being propagated in the school or that religion pervades the school, or that it is being run with a religious end. The Satmars may not be excluded from their elected civic posts merely because they are coreligionists as this would impinge upon their right of free exercise of religion.

 

800 of 992 DOCUMENTS


People v. Boulton


95-193


CITY COURT OF NEW YORK, TROY


164 Misc. 2d 604; 625 N.Y.S.2d 428; 1995 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 137



March 3, 1995, Decided


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant filed a motion for termination of the suspension of his driver's license under N.Y. Veh. & Traf. Law § 1193 (2)(e)(7)(b).


OVERVIEW: The State sought suspension of defendant's driver's license under N.Y. Veh. & Traf. Law § 1193 (2)(e)(7)(b). Defendant filed a motion to terminate the suspension and contended that the statute constituted an unconstitutional deprivation of his right to due process of law. The court found that the statute provided all the due process that was required and no more. The court also found that the statute did not violate the constitutional separation of powers provision. Thus, the court denied defendant's motion to terminate suspension of his driver's license and proceeded with arraignment.


OUTCOME: The court denied defendant's motion and continued with his arraignment.


HEADNOTES

Constitutional Law - Due Process of Law - Suspension of Driver's License for Operating Vehicle while Under Influence of Alcohol or Drugs Vehicle and Traffic Law § 1193 (2) (e) (7) (a), which permits a court to suspend a driver's license pending determination of charges of operating a motor vehicle while under the influence of alcohol or drugs, does not violate a defendant's due process of law rights. In order to take the license, a court must determine that the accusatory instrument is sufficient on its face (see, CPL 100.40) and that reasonable cause exists that defendant operated a motor vehicle with more than .10 of 1% or more by weight of alcohol in his or her blood. Inasmuch as an accusatory instrument must always be sufficient on its face, the CPL 100.40 review that is described in section 1193 (2) (e) (7) (b) does not afford the defendant any more due process than he or she is entitled to already. In addition, the process of taking the license requires no additional exercise of process. The statute mandates return of the license whenever evidence is presented tending to rebut the court's finding. This burden is neither onerous nor cumbersome since the prosecutor may not participate, thereby leaving defendant the opportunity to exercise his or her due process rights without constraint.

Constitutional Law - Separation of Powers - Suspension by Court of Driver's License for Operating Vehicle while Under Influence of Alcohol or Drugs Vehicle and Traffic Law § 1193 (2) (e) (7) (a), which permits a court to suspend a driver's license pending determination of charges of operating a motor vehicle while under the influence of alcohol or drugs, does not violate the separation of powers doctrine. Vehicle and Traffic Law § 510 gives a court permissive authority to temporarily suspend a defendant's driver's license. Judiciary responsibilities often overlap with duties and responsibilities of the executive branch. In upholding the statute, the court is not placed within the administration of the executive branch; thus there is no violation of separation of powers.

Constitutional Law - Equal Protection of Laws - Suspension of Driver's License for Operating Vehicle while Under Influence of Alcohol or Drugs Vehicle and Traffic Law § 1193 (2) (e) (7) (a), which permits a court to suspend a driver's license pending determination of charges of operating a motor vehicle while under the influence of alcohol or drugs, does not violate the Equal Protection Clauses of the New York or United States Constitutions. Applying the rational basis test to Vehicle and Traffic Law § 1193 (2) (e) (7) (a), it is not impermissible to treat a person who pleads guilty differently from a person who pleads not guilty. Although persons charged with a violation of Vehicle and Traffic Law § 1192 (4) and/or § 1192 (3) are treated differently than those charged under Vehicle and Traffic Law § 1192 (2) the distinction is not a violation of the Equal Protection Clauses.
